href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.i32.html#method.rem_euclid"><code>rem_euclid</code></a> -- for all integer primitives. <code>checked</code>, <code>overflowing</code>, and <code>wrapping</code> versions are also available.</li> </ul> <h3 id="other-changes">Other changes</h3> <p>There are other changes in the Rust 1.38 release: check out what changed in <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1380-2019-09-26">Rust</a>, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#cargo-138-2019-09-26">Cargo</a>, and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-clippy/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#rust-138">Clippy</a>.</p> <h3 id="corrections">Corrections</h3> <p>A Previous version of this post mistakenly marked these functions as stable. They are not yet stable. <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/time/struct.Duration.html#method.div_duration_f32"><code>Duration::div_duration_f32</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/time/struct.Duration.html#method.div_duration_f64"><code>Duration::div_duration_f64</code></a>.</p> <h2 id="contributors-to-1-38-0">Contributors to 1.38.0</h2> <p>Many people came together to create Rust 1.38.0. We couldn't have done it without all of you. <a href="https://thanks.rust-lang.org/rust/1.38.0/">Thanks!</a></p> Upcoming docs.rs changes Wed, 18 Sep 2019 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/upcoming-docsrs-changes/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/upcoming-docsrs-changes/ <p>On September 30th breaking changes will be deployed to the <a href="https://docs.rs">docs.rs</a> build environment. <a href="https://docs.rs">docs.rs</a> is a free service building and hosting documentation for all the crates published on <a href="https://crates.io">crates.io</a>. It's <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/docs.rs">open source</a>, maintained by the <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/governance/teams/dev-tools#rustdoc">Rustdoc team</a> and operated by the <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/governance/teams/operations#infra">Infrastructure team</a>.</p> <h2 id="what-will-change">What will change</h2> <p>Builds will be executed inside the <a href="https://hub.docker.com/r/rustops/crates-build-env">rustops/crates-build-env</a> Docker image. That image contains a lot of system dependencies installed to ensure we can build as many crates as possible. It's already used by <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/crater">Crater</a>, and we added all the dependencies previously installed in the legacy build environment.</p> <p>To ensure we can continue operating the service in the future and to increase its reliability we also improved the sandbox the builds are executed in, adding new limits:</p> <ul> <li>Each platform will now have <strong>15 minutes</strong> to build its dependencies and documentation.</li> <li><strong>3 GB of RAM</strong> will be available for the build.</li> <li>Network access will be <strong>disabled</strong> (crates.io dependencies will still be fetched).</li> <li>Only the <code>target/</code> directory will be writable, and it will be purged after each build.</li> </ul> <p>Finally, docs.rs will now use the latest nightly available when building crates, instead of using a manually updated pinned version of nightly.</p> <h2 id="how-to-prepare-for-the-changes">How to prepare for the changes</h2> <p>To test if your crate builds inside the new environment you can download the Docker image locally and execute a shell inside it:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">docker pull rustops/crates-build-env docker run --rm --memory 3221225472 -it rustops/crates-build-env bash </span></pre> <p>Once you're in a shell you can install <a href="https://rustup.rs">rustup</a> (it's not installed by default in the image), install Rust nightly, clone your crate's repository and then build the documentation:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">cargo fetch time cargo doc --no-deps </span></pre> <p>To aid your testing these commands will limit the available RAM to 3 GB and show the total execution time of <code>cargo doc</code>, but network access will not be blocked as you'll need to fetch dependencies.</p> <p>If your project needs a system dependency missing in the build environment, please <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/crates-build-env/issues">open an issue</a> on the Docker image's <a href="https://hub.docker.com/r/rustops/crates-build-env">repository</a> and we'll consider adding it.</p> <p>If your crate fails to build because it took more than 15 minutes to generate its docs or it uses more than 3 GB of RAM please <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/docs.rs/issues">open an issue</a> and we will consider reasonable limit increases for your crate. We will <strong>not</strong> enable network access for your crate though: you'll need to change your crate not to require any external resource at build time.</p> <p>We recommend using <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/reference/manifest.html#the-features-section">Cargo features</a> to remove the parts of the code causing build failures, enabling those features with <a href="https://docs.rs/about">docs.rs metadata</a>.</p> <h2 id="acknowledgements">Acknowledgements</h2> <p>The new build environment is based on <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rustwide">Rustwide</a>, the library powering <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/crater">Crater</a>. It was extracted from the Crater codebase, and created both by the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/crater/graphs/contributors">Crater contributors</a> and the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rustwide/graphs/contributors">Rustwide contributors</a>.</p> <p>The implementation work on the docs.rs side was done by <a href="https://github.com/pietroalbini">Pietro Albini</a> and <a href="https://github.com/onur">Onur Aslan</a>, with <a href="https://github.com/QuietMisdreavus">QuietMisdreavus</a> and <a href="https://github.com/Mark-Simulacrum">Mark Rousskov</a> reviewing the changes.</p> Announcing Rust 1.37.0 Thu, 15 Aug 2019 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-37-0/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-37-0/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce a new version of Rust, 1.37.0. Rust is a programming language that is empowering everyone to build reliable and efficient software.</p> <p>If you have a previous version of Rust installed via rustup, getting Rust 1.37.0 is as easy as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">rustup update stable </span></pre> <p>If you don't have it already, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">get <code>rustup</code></a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1370-2019-08-15">detailed release notes for 1.37.0</a> on GitHub.</p> <h2 id="what-s-in-1-37-0-stable">What's in 1.37.0 stable</h2> <p>The highlights of Rust 1.37.0 include referring to <code>enum</code> variants through <code>type</code> aliases, built-in <code>cargo vendor</code>, unnamed <code>const</code> items, profile-guided optimization, a <code>default-run</code> key in Cargo, and <code>#[repr(align(N))]</code> on <code>enum</code>s. Read on for a few highlights, or see the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1370-2019-08-15">detailed release notes</a> for additional information.</p> <h3 id="referring-to-enum-variants-through-type-aliases">Referring to <code>enum</code> variants through <code>type</code> aliases</h3> <p>With Rust 1.37.0, you can now refer to <code>enum</code> variants through type aliases. For example:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">type </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">ByteOption </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Option&lt;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u8</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&gt;; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">increment_or_zero</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">x</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: ByteOption) -&gt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u8 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">match</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> x { ByteOption::Some(y) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> y </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, ByteOption::None </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, } } </span></pre> <p>In implementations, <code>Self</code> acts like a type alias. So in Rust 1.37.0, you can also refer to <code>enum</code> variants with <code>Self::Variant</code>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">impl </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Coin { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">value_in_cents</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) -&gt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u8 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">match </span><span style="color:#c82829;">self </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">Self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">::Penny </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">Self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">::Nickel </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">5</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">Self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">::Dime </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">10</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">Self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">::Quarter </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">25</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, } } } </span></pre> <p>To be more exact, Rust now allows you to refer to <code>enum</code> variants through <em>&quot;type-relative resolution&quot;</em>, <code>&lt;MyType&lt;..&gt;&gt;::Variant</code>. More details are available in <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/61682/#issuecomment-502472847">the stabilization report</a>.</p> <h3 id="built-in-cargo-support-for-vendored-dependencies">Built-in Cargo support for vendored dependencies</h3> <p>After being available <a href="https://crates.io/crates/cargo-vendor">as a separate crate</a> for years, the <code>cargo vendor</code> command is now integrated directly into Cargo. The command fetches all your project's dependencies unpacking them into the <code>vendor/</code> directory, and shows the configuration snippet required to use the vendored code during builds.</p> <p>There are multiple cases where <code>cargo vendor</code> is already used in production: the Rust compiler <code>rustc</code> uses it to ship all its dependencies in release tarballs, and projects with monorepos use it to commit the dependencies' code in source control.</p> <h3 id="using-unnamed-const-items-for-macros">Using unnamed <code>const</code> items for macros</h3> <p>You can now create <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/61347/">unnamed <code>const</code> items</a>. Instead of giving your constant an explicit name, simply name it <code>_</code> instead. For example, in the <code>rustc</code> compiler we find:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#999999;">/// Type size assertion where the first parameter /// is a type and the second is the expected size. </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">#[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">macro_export</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">macro_rules! </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">static_assert_size { (</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">$ty</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">:</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">ty</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">$size</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">:</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">expr</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">const </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">_</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: [(); </span><span style="color:#c82829;">$size</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[(); ::std::mem::size_of::&lt;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">$ty</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&gt;()]; </span><span style="color:#999999;">// ^ Note the underscore here. </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} } static_assert_size!(Option&lt;Box&lt;String&gt;&gt;, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">8</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// 1. </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">static_assert_size!(</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">usize</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">8</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// 2. </span></pre> <p>Notice the second <code>static_assert_size!(..)</code>: thanks to the use of unnamed constants, you can define new items without naming conflicts. Previously you would have needed to write <code>static_assert_size!(MY_DUMMY_IDENTIFIER, usize, 8);</code>. Instead, with Rust 1.37.0, it now becomes easier to create ergonomic and reusable declarative and procedural macros for static analysis purposes.</p> <h3 id="profile-guided-optimization">Profile-guided optimization</h3> <p>The <code>rustc</code> compiler now comes with <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/61268/">support for Profile-Guided Optimization (PGO)</a> via the <code>-C profile-generate</code> and <code>-C profile-use</code> flags.</p> <p><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Profile-guided_optimization">Profile-Guided Optimization</a> allows the compiler to optimize code based on feedback from real workloads. It works by compiling the program to optimize in two steps:</p> <ol> <li>First, the program is built with instrumentation inserted by the compiler. This is done by passing the <code>-C profile-generate</code> flag to <code>rustc</code>. The instrumented program then needs to be run on sample data and will write the profiling data to a file.</li> <li>Then, the program is built <em>again</em>, this time feeding the collected profiling data back into <code>rustc</code> by using the <code>-C profile-use</code> flag. This build will make use of the collected data to allow the compiler to make better decisions about code placement, inlining, and other optimizations.</li> </ol> <p>For more in-depth information on Profile-Guided Optimization, please refer to the corresponding <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/rustc/profile-guided-optimization.html">chapter in the rustc book</a>.</p> <h3 id="choosing-a-default-binary-in-cargo-projects">Choosing a default binary in Cargo projects</h3> <p><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/commands/cargo-run.html"><code>cargo run</code></a> is great for quickly testing CLI applications. When multiple binaries are present in the same package, you have to explicitly declare the name of the binary you want to run with the <code>--bin</code> flag. This makes <code>cargo run</code> not as ergonomic as we'd like, especially when a binary is called more often than the others.</p> <p>Rust 1.37.0 addresses the issue by adding <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/reference/manifest.html#the-default-run-field"><code>default-run</code></a>, a new key in <code>Cargo.toml</code>. When the key is declared in the <code>[package]</code> section, <code>cargo run</code> will default to the chosen binary if the <code>--bin</code> flag is not passed.</p> <h3 id="repr-align-n-on-enums"><code>#[repr(align(N))]</code> on <code>enum</code>s</h3> <p><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/reference/type-layout.html#the-alignment-modifiers">The <code>#[repr(align(N))]</code> attribute</a> can be used to raise the <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/reference/type-layout.html#size-and-alignment">alignment</a> of a type definition. Previously, the attribute was only allowed on <code>struct</code>s and <code>union</code>s. With Rust 1.37.0, the attribute can now also be used <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/61229">on <code>enum</code> definitions</a>. For example, the following type <code>Align16</code> would, as expected, report <code>16</code> as the alignment whereas the natural alignment without <code>#[repr(align(16))]</code> would be <code>4</code>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">#[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">repr</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#c82829;">align</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">(16)</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">)] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">enum </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Align16 { Foo { foo: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u32 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">}, Bar { bar: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u32 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">}, } </span></pre> <p>The semantics of using <code>#[repr(align(N))</code> on an <code>enum</code> is the same as defining a wrapper struct <code>AlignN&lt;T&gt;</code> with that alignment and then using <code>AlignN&lt;MyEnum&gt;</code>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">#[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">repr</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#c82829;">align</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">(N)</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">)] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">AlignN&lt;T&gt;(T); </span></pre><h3 id="library-changes">Library changes</h3> <p>In Rust 1.37.0 there have been a number of standard library stabilizations:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/io/struct.BufReader.html#method.buffer"><code>BufReader::buffer</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/io/struct.BufWriter.html#method.buffer"><code>BufWriter::buffer</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/cell/struct.Cell.html#method.from_mut"><code>Cell::from_mut</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/cell/struct.Cell.html#method.as_slice_of_cells"><code>Cell::as_slice_of_cells</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/iter/trait.DoubleEndedIterator.html#method.nth_back"><code>DoubleEndedIterator::nth_back</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/option/enum.Option.html#method.xor"><code>Option::xor</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.u8.html#method.reverse_bits"><code>{i,u}{8,16,32,64,128,size}::reverse_bits</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/num/struct.Wrapping.html#method.reverse_bits"><code>Wrapping::reverse_bits</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.slice.html#method.copy_within"><code>slice::copy_within</code></a></li> </ul> <h3 id="other-changes">Other changes</h3> <p>There are other changes in the Rust 1.37 release: check out what changed in <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1370-2019-08-15">Rust</a>, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#cargo-137-2019-08-15">Cargo</a>, and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-clippy/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#rust-137">Clippy</a>.</p> <h2 id="contributors-to-1-37-0">Contributors to 1.37.0</h2> <p>Many people came together to create Rust 1.37.0. We couldn't have done it without all of you. <a href="https://thanks.rust-lang.org/rust/1.37.0/">Thanks!</a></p> <h2 id="new-sponsors-of-rust-infrastructure">New sponsors of Rust infrastructure</h2> <p>We'd like to thank two new sponsors of Rust's infrastructure who provided the resources needed to make Rust 1.37.0 happen: Amazon Web Services (AWS) and Microsoft Azure.</p> <ul> <li>AWS has provided hosting for release artifacts (compilers, libraries, tools, and source code), serving those artifacts to users through CloudFront, preventing regressions with Crater on EC2, and managing other Rust-related infrastructure hosted on AWS.</li> <li>Microsoft Azure has sponsored builders for Rust’s CI infrastructure, notably the extremely resource intensive rust-lang/rust repository.</li> </ul> Announcing Rust 1.36.0 Thu, 04 Jul 2019 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-36-0/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-36-0/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce a new version of Rust, 1.36.0. Rust is a programming language that is empowering everyone to build reliable and efficient software.</p> <p>If you have a previous version of Rust installed via rustup, getting Rust 1.36.0 is as easy as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">rustup update stable </span></pre> <p>If you don't have it already, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">get <code>rustup</code></a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1360-2019-07-04">detailed release notes for 1.36.0</a> on GitHub.</p> <h2 id="what-s-in-1-36-0-stable">What's in 1.36.0 stable</h2> <p>This release brings many changes, including the stabilization of the <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/future/trait.Future.html"><code>Future</code></a> trait, the <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/alloc/index.html"><code>alloc</code></a> crate, the <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/mem/union.MaybeUninit.html"><code>MaybeUninit&lt;T&gt;</code></a> type, <a href="http://blog.pnkfx.org/blog/2019/06/26/breaking-news-non-lexical-lifetimes-arrives-for-everyone/">NLL for Rust 2015</a>, a new <code>HashMap&lt;K, V&gt;</code> implementation, and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/commands/cargo-build.html#cargo_build_manifest_options"><code>--offline</code></a> support in Cargo. Read on for a few highlights, or see the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1360-2019-07-04">detailed release notes</a> for additional information.</p> <h3 id="the-future-is-here">The <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/future/trait.Future.html"><code>Future</code></a> is here!</h3> <p>In Rust 1.36.0 the long awaited <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/future/trait.Future.html"><code>Future</code></a> trait has been <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/59739">stabilized</a>!</p> <p>With this stabilization, we hope to give important crates, libraries, and the ecosystem time to prepare for <code>async</code> / <code>.await</code>, which we'll tell you more about in the future.</p> <h3 id="the-alloc-crate-is-stable">The <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/alloc/index.html"><code>alloc</code></a> crate is stable</h3> <p>Before 1.36.0, the standard library consisted of the crates <code>std</code>, <code>core</code>, and <code>proc_macro</code>. The <code>core</code> crate provided core functionality such as <code>Iterator</code> and <code>Copy</code> and could be used in <code>#![no_std]</code> environments since it did not impose any requirements. Meanwhile, the <code>std</code> crate provided types like <code>Box&lt;T&gt;</code> and OS functionality but required a global allocator and other OS capabilities in return.</p> <p>Starting with Rust 1.36.0, the parts of <code>std</code> that depend on a global allocator, e.g. <code>Vec&lt;T&gt;</code>, are now available in the <code>alloc</code> crate. The <code>std</code> crate then re-exports these parts. While <code>#![no_std]</code> <em>binaries</em> using <code>alloc</code> still require nightly Rust, <code>#![no_std]</code> <em>library</em> crates can use the <code>alloc</code> crate in stable Rust. Meanwhile, normal binaries, without <code>#![no_std]</code>, can depend on such library crates. We hope this will facilitate the development of a <code>#![no_std]</code> compatible ecosystem of libraries prior to stabilizing support for <code>#![no_std]</code> binaries using <code>alloc</code>.</p> <p>If you are the maintainer of a library that only relies on some allocation primitives to function, consider making your library <code>#[no_std]</code> compatible by using the following at the top of your <code>lib.rs</code> file:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">#![</span><span style="color:#c82829;">no_std</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">extern crate</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> alloc; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">use </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">alloc::vec::Vec; </span></pre><h3 id="maybeuninit-t-instead-of-mem-uninitialized"><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/mem/union.MaybeUninit.html"><code>MaybeUninit&lt;T&gt;</code></a> instead of <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/mem/fn.uninitialized.html"><code>mem::uninitialized</code></a></h3> <p>In previous releases of Rust, the <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/mem/fn.uninitialized.html"><code>mem::uninitialized</code></a> function has allowed you to bypass Rust's initialization checks by pretending that you've initialized a value at type <code>T</code> without doing anything. One of the main uses of this function has been to lazily allocate arrays.</p> <p>However, <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/mem/fn.uninitialized.html"><code>mem::uninitialized</code></a> is an incredibly dangerous operation that essentially cannot be used correctly as the Rust compiler assumes that values are properly initialized. For example, calling <code>mem::uninitialized::&lt;bool&gt;()</code> causes <em>instantaneous <strong>undefined behavior</strong></em> as, from Rust's point of view, the uninitialized bits are neither <code>0</code> (for <code>false</code>) nor <code>1</code> (for <code>true</code>) - the only two allowed bit patterns for <code>bool</code>.</p> <p>To remedy this situation, in Rust 1.36.0, the type <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/mem/union.MaybeUninit.html"><code>MaybeUninit&lt;T&gt;</code></a> has been <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/60445">stabilized</a>. The Rust compiler will understand that it should not assume that a <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/mem/union.MaybeUninit.html"><code>MaybeUninit&lt;T&gt;</code></a> is a properly initialized <code>T</code>. Therefore, you can do gradual initialization more safely and eventually use <code>.assume_init()</code> once you are certain that <code>maybe_t: MaybeUninit&lt;T&gt;</code> contains an initialized <code>T</code>.</p> <p>As <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/mem/union.MaybeUninit.html"><code>MaybeUninit&lt;T&gt;</code></a> is the safer alternative, starting with Rust 1.39, the function <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/mem/fn.uninitialized.html"><code>mem::uninitialized</code></a> will be deprecated.</p> <p>To find out more about uninitialized memory, <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/mem/fn.uninitialized.html"><code>mem::uninitialized</code></a>, and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/mem/union.MaybeUninit.html"><code>MaybeUninit&lt;T&gt;</code></a>, read <a href="https://gankro.github.io/blah/initialize-me-maybe/">Alexis Beingessner's blog post</a>. The standard library also contains extensive documentation about <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/mem/union.MaybeUninit.html"><code>MaybeUninit&lt;T&gt;</code></a>.</p> <h3 id="nll-for-rust-2015">NLL for Rust 2015</h3> <p><a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/12/06/Rust-1.31-and-rust-2018.html#non-lexical-lifetimes">In the announcement for Rust 1.31.0</a>, we told you about NLL (Non-Lexical Lifetimes), an improvement to the language that makes the borrow checker smarter and more user friendly. For example, you may now write:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">5</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> y </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= &amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">x; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> z </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= &amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> x; </span><span style="color:#999999;">// This was not allowed before 1.31.0. </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p>In 1.31.0 NLL was stabilized only for Rust 2018, with a promise that we would backport it to Rust 2015 as well. With Rust 1.36.0, we are happy to announce that we have done so! NLL is now available for Rust 2015.</p> <p>With NLL on both editions, we are closer to removing the old borrow checker. However, the old borrow checker unfortunately accepted some <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soundness">unsound</a> code it should not have. As a result, NLL is currently in a &quot;migration mode&quot; wherein we will emit warnings instead of errors if the NLL borrow checker rejects code the old AST borrow checker would accept. Please see <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/60680#issuecomment-495089654">this list</a> of public crates that are affected.</p> <p>To find out more about NLL, MIR, the story around fixing soundness holes, and what you can do about the warnings if you have them, read <a href="http://blog.pnkfx.org/blog/2019/06/26/breaking-news-non-lexical-lifetimes-arrives-for-everyone/">Felix Klock's blog post</a>.</p> <h3 id="a-new-hashmap-k-v-implementation">A new <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/collections/struct.HashMap.html"><code>HashMap&lt;K, V&gt;</code></a> implementation</h3> <p>In Rust 1.36.0, the <code>HashMap&lt;K, V&gt;</code> implementation has been <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/58623">replaced</a> with the one in the <a href="https://crates.io/crates/hashbrown"><code>hashbrown</code></a> crate which is based on the <a href="https://abseil.io/blog/20180927-swisstables">SwissTable</a> design. While the interface is the same, the <code>HashMap&lt;K, V&gt;</code> implementation is now <a href="https://perf.rust-lang.org/compare.html?start=b57fe74a27590289fd657614b8ad1f3eac8a7ad2&amp;end=abade53a649583e40ed07c26ee10652703f09b58&amp;stat=wall-time">faster on average</a> and has lower memory overhead. Note that unlike the <code>hashbrown</code> crate, the implementation in <code>std</code> still defaults to the SipHash 1-3 hashing algorithm.</p> <h3 id="offline-support-in-cargo"><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/commands/cargo-build.html#cargo_build_manifest_options"><code>--offline</code></a> support in Cargo</h3> <p>During most builds, Cargo doesn't interact with the network. Sometimes, however, Cargo has to. Such is the case when a dependency is added and the latest compatible version needs to be downloaded. At times, network access is not an option though, for example on an airplane or in isolated build environments.</p> <p>In Rust 1.36, a new Cargo flag has been stabilized: <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/commands/cargo-build.html#cargo_build_manifest_options"><code>--offline</code></a>. The flag alters Cargo's dependency resolution algorithm to only use locally cached dependencies. When the required crates are not available offline, and a network access would be required, Cargo will exit with an error. To prepopulate the local cache in preparation for going offline, use the <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/commands/cargo-fetch.html"><code>cargo fetch</code></a> command, which downloads all the required dependencies for a project.</p> <p>To find out more about <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/commands/cargo-build.html#cargo_build_manifest_options"><code>--offline</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/commands/cargo-fetch.html"><code>cargo fetch</code></a>, read <a href="https://www.ncameron.org/blog/cargo-offline/">Nick Cameron's blog post</a>.</p> <p>For information on other changes to Cargo, see the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#cargo-136-2019-07-04">detailed release notes</a>.</p> <h3 id="library-changes">Library changes</h3> <p>The <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/macro.dbg.html"><code>dbg!</code></a> macro now supports multiple arguments.</p> <p>Additionally, a number of APIs have been made <code>const</code>:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/core/alloc/struct.Layout.html#method.from_size_align_unchecked"><code>Layout::from_size_align_unchecked</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/mem/fn.needs_drop.html"><code>mem::needs_drop</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/ptr/struct.NonNull.html#method.dangling"><code>NonNull::dangling</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/ptr/struct.NonNull.html#method.cast"><code>NonNull::cast</code></a></li> </ul> <p>New APIs have become stable, including:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/task/struct.Waker.html"><code>task::Waker</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/task/enum.Poll.html"><code>task::Poll</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/collections/struct.VecDeque.html#method.rotate_left"><code>VecDeque::rotate_left</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/collections/struct.VecDeque.html#method.rotate_right"><code>VecDeque::rotate_right</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/io/trait.Read.html#method.read_vectored"><code>Read::read_vectored</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/io/trait.Write.html#method.write_vectored"><code>Write::write_vectored</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/iter/trait.Iterator.html#method.copied"><code>Iterator::copied</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/60404"><code>BorrowMut&lt;str&gt; for String</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.str.html#method.as_mut_ptr"><code>str::as_mut_ptr</code></a></li> </ul> <p>Other library changes are available in the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1360-2019-07-04">detailed release notes</a>.</p> <h3 id="other-changes">Other changes</h3> <p>Detailed 1.36.0 release notes are available for <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1360-2019-07-04">Rust</a>, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#cargo-136-2019-07-04">Cargo</a>, and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-clippy/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#rust-136">Clippy</a>.</p> <h2 id="contributors-to-1-36-0">Contributors to 1.36.0</h2> <p>Many people came together to create Rust 1.36.0. We couldn't have done it without all of you. <a href="https://thanks.rust-lang.org/rust/1.36.0/">Thanks!</a></p> The Governance WG is going public Mon, 03 Jun 2019 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/governance-wg-announcement/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/governance-wg-announcement/ <p>Hey all! Today we're happy to announce the <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/governance-working-group-announcement/9637">Governance Working Group</a> is going public. We've been spending the last couple weeks finding our bearings and structuring the working group.</p> <p>You can find <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/wg-governance/blob/master/CHARTER.md">our charter</a> outlining our main goals and priorities in <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/wg-governance">our work repository</a>. We are using the Github issues, milestones and projects to organise and track our progress. The <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/wg-governance/">readme in the repository</a> explains our working process a bit more in detail. It also states how you can talk to us (hint, via discord) and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/wg-governance/#how-can-i-get-involved">get involved</a>.</p> <p>If you're interested in the governance working group, you may also be interested in the <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/lang-team-meta-working-group/9989">Lang Team Meta WG</a>, which is exploring solutions specific to the lang team.</p> The 2019 Rust Event Lineup Mon, 20 May 2019 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/the-2019-rust-event-lineup/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/the-2019-rust-event-lineup/ <p>We're excited for the 2019 conference season, which we're actually late in writing up. Some incredible events have already happened! Read on to learn more about all the events occurring around the world, past and future.</p> <h3 id="december-15-16-2018-rustrush">December 15-16, 2018: RustRush</h3> <p>Yes, <a href="https://rustrush.ru/">RustRush</a> was actually in 2018, but we didn't cover it in the <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/01/31/The-2018-Rust-Event-Lineup.html">2018 event lineup</a> so we're counting it in 2019! This was the first Rust event in Russia. You can <a href="https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLTooeo4dmVkQ_1lHJEY99ZTH_oP5ksIUL">watch the talk videos</a> and <a href="https://twitter.com/rustrush1">follow the conference on Twitter</a>.</p> <h3 id="march-29-30-2019-rust-latam">March 29-30, 2019: Rust Latam</h3> <p>The <a href="https://rustlatam.org/">Rust Latam Conference</a> is Latin America's leading event about Rust. Their first event happened in Montevideo this year, and <a href="https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL85XCvVPmGQjuWUNeFCgl8X2EOC_aAq5N">the videos are available</a> to watch! Rust Latam plans to be a yearly event, so <a href="https://twitter.com/RustLatamConf">watch Twitter</a> for information about next year's event.</p> <h3 id="april-20-23-2019-rustcon-asia">April 20-23, 2019: RustCon Asia</h3> <p><a href="https://rustcon.asia/">RustCon Asia</a> was the first Rust conference in Asia! The <a href="https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL85XCvVPmGQjPvweRqkBgnh_HKE5MBB8x">talk videos</a> are already available on YouTube! <a href="https://twitter.com/RustConAsia">Follow @RustConAsia</a> on Twitter for future updates.</p> <h3 id="april-26-29-2019-oxidize">April 26-29, 2019: Oxidize</h3> <p><a href="https://oxidizeconf.com/">Oxidize</a> was a conference specifically about using Rust on embedded devices that took place in Berlin. The videos are now <a href="https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLXajQV_H-DxJPiJQK8gvou4SUZ8Zfvgm6">available on YouTube</a>, and <a href="https://twitter.com/OxidizeConf">follow @oxidizeconf</a> on Twitter for future updates.</p> <h3 id="june-28-29-2019-rustlab">June 28-29, 2019: RustLab</h3> <p><a href="https://www.rustlab.it/">RustLab</a> is a new conference for this year that will be taking place in Florence, Italy. Their session and workshop lineup has been announced, and tickets are now available! <a href="https://twitter.com/rustlab_conf">Follow the conference on Twitter</a> for the most up-to-date information.</p> <h3 id="august-22-23-rustconf">August 22-23: RustConf</h3> <p><a href="https://rustconf.com/">The official RustConf</a> will again be taking place in Portland, OR, USA. Thursday is a day of trainings and Friday is the main day of talks. See <a href="https://twitter.com/rustconf">Twitter</a> for the latest announcements! The videos are now <a href="https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL85XCvVPmGQhDOUIZBe6u388GydeACbTt">available on YouTube</a>.</p> <h3 id="september-20-21-colorado-gold-rust">September 20-21: Colorado Gold Rust</h3> <p><a href="https://cogoldrust.com/">Colorado Gold Rust</a> is a new conference for this year, and is taking place in Denver, CO, USA. Their CFP and ticket sales are open now, and you can also <a href="https://twitter.com/COGoldRust">follow them on twitter</a>!</p> <h3 id="october-18-19-rust-belt-rust">October 18-19: Rust Belt Rust</h3> <p>This year's <a href="https://www.rust-belt-rust.com/">Rust Belt Rust</a> will be taking place in Dayton, OH, USA, the birthplace of flight! The CFP and ticket sales will open soon. Check <a href="https://twitter.com/rustbeltrust">Twitter</a> for announcements.</p> <h3 id="october-26th-2019-rust-tokyo">October 26th, 2019: Rust.Tokyo</h3> <p><a href="https://rust.tokyo/">Rust.Tokyo</a> is a one-day conference for Rustaceans with 200+ attendees in Tokyo, Japan. The <a href="https://ti.to/rust-tokyo/2019/en">ticket</a> sales are open now, and you can also <a href="https://twitter.com/rustlang_tokyo">follow them on twitter</a>!</p> <h3 id="november-rustfest-barcelona">November: RustFest Barcelona</h3> <p>The exact dates for <a href="https://barcelona.rustfest.eu/">RustFest Barcelona</a> haven't been announced yet, but it's slated to happen sometime in November. Keep an eye on the <a href="https://twitter.com/rustfest">RustFest Twitter</a> for announcements!</p> <p>+++</p> <p>We are so lucky and excited to have so many wonderful conferences around the world in 2019! Have fun at the events, and we hope there are even more in 2020!</p> 4 years of Rust Wed, 15 May 2019 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/4-years-of-rust/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/4-years-of-rust/ <p>On May 15th, 2015, <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2015/05/15/Rust-1.0.html">Rust</a> was released to the world! After 5 years of open development (and a couple of years of sketching before that), we finally hit the button on making the attempt to create a new systems programming language a serious effort!</p> <p>It’s easy to look back on the pre-1.0 times and cherish them for being the wild times of language development and fun research. Features were added and cut, syntax and keywords were tried, and before 1.0, there was a big clean-up that removed a lot of the standard library. For fun, you can check Niko’s blog post on <a href="https://smallcultfollowing.com/babysteps/blog/2012/04/09/rusts-object-system/">how Rust's object system works</a>, Marijn Haverbeke’s talk on <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=olbTX95hdbg">features that never made it close to 1.0</a> or even the <a href="http://venge.net/graydon/talks/intro-talk-2.pdf">introductory slides about Servo</a>, which present a language looking very different from today.</p> <p>Releasing Rust with stability guarantees also meant putting a stop to large visible changes. The face of Rust is still very similar to Rust 1.0. Even with the changes from last year’s 2018 Edition, Rust is still very recognizable as what it was in 2015. That steadiness hides that the time of Rust’s fastest development and growth is <em>now</em>. With the stability of the language and easy upgrades as a base, a ton of new features have been built. We’ve seen a bunch of achievements in the last year:</p> <ul> <li>We have been StackOverflow’s <a href="https://insights.stackoverflow.com/survey/2019#most-loved-dreaded-and-wanted">“Most loved programming language”</a> 4 consecutive years in a row</li> <li>We opened up a whole new area of development for stable Rust: <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/what/embedded">embedded development</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/what/wasm">Rust+WASM</a> went from an experiment to a usable product, making rustc the first compiler with focus on supporting WASM</li> <li>We shipped a new language edition: <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/12/06/Rust-1.31-and-rust-2018.html">Rust 2018</a></li> <li><a href="http://crates.io">Crates.io</a> passed a billion downloads and has over 25,000 crates available</li> <li>There’s now over 100 meetups around the world, in 42 countries</li> <li>6(!) new conferences were spun up (<a href="https://rustrush.ru/">RustRush</a>, <a href="https://rustcon.asia/">RustCon Asia</a>, <a href="https://oxidizeconf.com/">Oxidize</a>, <a href="https://rustlatam.org/">Rust LATAM</a>, <a href="https://cogoldrust.com/">Colorado Gold Rust</a>, <a href="https://www.rustlab.it/">RustLab Italy</a>)</li> </ul> <p>This list could go on and on. While the time before and after release was a time where language changes had huge impact how Rust is perceived, it's becoming more and more important what people start building in and around it. This includes projects like whole game engines, but also many small, helpful libraries, meetup formats, tutorials other educational material. Birthdays are a great time to take a look back over the last year and see the happy parts!</p> <p>Rust would be nothing, and especially not winning prizes, without its community. Community happens everywhere! We would like to thank everyone for being along on this ride, from team members to small scale contributors to people just checking the language out and finding interest in it. Your interest and curiosity is what makes the Rust community an enjoyable place to be. Some meetups <a href="https://calendar.google.com/calendar/embed?showTitle=0&amp;showPrint=0&amp;showTabs=0&amp;showCalendars=0&amp;mode=AGENDA&amp;height=400&amp;wkst=1&amp;bgcolor=%23FFFFFF&amp;src=apd9vmbc22egenmtu5l6c5jbfc%40group.calendar.google.com&amp;color=%23691426&amp;ctz=Europe%2FMadrid">are running birthday parties</a> today to which everyone is invited. If you are not attending one, you can take the chance to celebrate in any other fashion: maybe show us a picture of what you are currently working on or talk about what excites you. If you want to take it to social media, consider tagging our <a href="https://twitter.com/rustlang">Twitter account</a> or using the hashtag #rustbirthday.</p> Announcing Rust 1.34.2 Tue, 14 May 2019 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-34-2/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-34-2/ <p>The Rust team has published a new point release of Rust, 1.34.2. Rust is a programming language that is empowering everyone to build reliable and efficient software.</p> <p>If you have a previous version of Rust installed via rustup, getting Rust 1.34.2 is as easy as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">rustup update stable </span></pre> <p>If you don't have it already, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">get <code>rustup</code></a> from the appropriate page on our website.</p> <h2 id="what-s-in-1-34-2-stable">What's in 1.34.2 stable</h2> <p>Sean McArthur reported a <a href="https://groups.google.com/d/msg/rustlang-security-announcements/aZabeCMUv70/-2Y6-SL6AQAJ">security vulnerability</a> affecting the standard library that caused the <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/std/error/trait.Error.html#method.downcast"><code>Error::downcast</code></a> family of methods to perform unsound casts when a manual implementation of the <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/std/error/trait.Error.html#method.type_id"><code>Error::type_id</code></a> method returned the wrong <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/std/any/struct.TypeId.html"><code>TypeId</code></a>, leading to security issues such as out of bounds reads/writes/etc.</p> <p>The <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/std/error/trait.Error.html#method.type_id"><code>Error::type_id</code></a> method was recently stabilized as part of Rust 1.34.0. This point release <strong>destabilizes</strong> it, preventing any code on the stable and beta channels to implement or use it, awaiting future plans that will be discussed in <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/60784">issue #60784</a>.</p> <p>An in-depth explanation of this issue was posted in yesterday's <a href="https://groups.google.com/d/msg/rustlang-security-announcements/aZabeCMUv70/-2Y6-SL6AQAJ">security advisory</a>. The assigned CVE for the vulnerability is <a href="https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2019-12083">CVE-2019-12083</a>.</p> Security advisory for the standard library Mon, 13 May 2019 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/security-advisory/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/security-advisory/ <p>This is a cross-post of the <a href="https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/rustlang-security-announcements/aZabeCMUv70">official security advisory</a>. The official post contains a signed version with our PGP key, as well.</p> <p>The CVE for this vulnerability is <a href="https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2019-12083">CVE-2019-12083</a>.</p> <p>+++</p> <p>The Rust team was recently notified of a security vulnerability affecting manual implementations of <code>Error::type_id</code> and their interaction with the <code>Error::downcast</code> family of functions in the standard library. If your code does not manually implement <code>Error::type_id</code> your code is not affected.</p> <h2 id="overview">Overview</h2> <p>The <code>Error::type_id</code> function in the standard library was stabilized in the 1.34.0 release on 2019-04-11. This function allows acquiring the concrete <code>TypeId</code> for the underlying error type to downcast back to the original type. This function has a default implementation in the standard library, but it can also be overridden by downstream crates. For example, the following is currently allowed on Rust 1.34.0 and Rust 1.34.1:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">MyType; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">impl </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Error </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">for </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">MyType { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">type_id</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) -&gt; TypeId { </span><span style="color:#999999;">// Enable safe casting to `String` by accident. </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">TypeId::of::&lt;String&gt;() } } </span></pre> <p>When combined with the <code>Error::downcast*</code> family of methods this can enable safe casting of a type to the wrong type, causing security issues such as out of bounds reads/writes/etc.</p> <p>Prior to the 1.34.0 release this function was not stable and could not be either implemented or called in stable Rust.</p> <h2 id="affected-versions">Affected Versions</h2> <p>The <code>Error::type_id</code> function was first stabilized in Rust 1.34.0, released on 2019-04-11. The Rust 1.34.1 release, published 2019-04-25, is also affected. The <code>Error::type_id</code> function has been present, unstable, for all releases of Rust since 1.0.0 meaning code compiled with nightly may have been affected at any time.</p> <h2 id="mitigations">Mitigations</h2> <p>Immediate mitigation of this bug requires removing manual implementations of <code>Error::type_id</code>, instead inheriting the default implementation which is correct from a safety perspective. It is not the intention to have <code>Error::type_id</code> return <code>TypeId</code> instances for other types.</p> <p>For long term mitigation we are going to destabilize this function. This is unfortunately a breaking change for users calling <code>Error::type_id</code> and for users overriding <code>Error::type_id</code>. For users overriding it's likely memory unsafe, but users calling <code>Error::type_id</code> have only been able to do so on stable for a few weeks since the last 1.34.0 release, so it's thought that the impact will not be too great to overcome.</p> <p>We will be releasing a 1.34.2 point release on 2019-05-14 (tomorrow) which reverts <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/58048">#58048</a> and destabilizes the <code>Error::type_id</code> function. The upcoming 1.35.0 release along with the beta/nightly channels will also all be updated with a destabilization.</p> <p>The final fate of the <code>Error::type_id</code> API isn't decided upon just yet and is the subject of <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/60784">#60784</a>. No action beyond destabilization is currently planned so nightly code may continue to exhibit this issue. We hope to fully resolve this in the standard library soon.</p> <h2 id="timeline-of-events">Timeline of events</h2> <ul> <li>Thu, May 9, 2019 at 14:07 PM - Bug reported to security@rust-lang.org</li> <li>Thu, May 9, 2019 at 15:10 PM - Alex reponds, confirming the bug</li> <li>Fri, May 10, 2019 - Plan for mitigation developed and implemented</li> <li>Mon, May 13, 2019 - PRs posted to GitHub for <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/60785">stable</a>/<a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/60786">beta</a>/<a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/60787">master</a> branches</li> <li>Mon, May 13, 2019 - Security list informed of this issue</li> <li>(planned) Tue, May 14, 2019 - Rust 1.34.2 is released with a fix for this issue</li> </ul> <h2 id="acknowledgements">Acknowledgements</h2> <p>Thanks to Sean McArthur, who found this bug and reported it to us in accordance with our <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/policies/security">security policy</a>.</p> Mozilla IRC Sunset and the Rust Channel Fri, 26 Apr 2019 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/mozilla-irc-sunset-and-the-rust-channel/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/mozilla-irc-sunset-and-the-rust-channel/ <p>The Rust community has had a presence on Mozilla’s IRC network almost since Rust’s inception. Over time, the single channel grew into a set of pretty active channels where folks would come to ask Rust questions, coordinate work on Rust itself, and just in general chat about Rust.</p> <p>Mozilla <a href="http://exple.tive.org/blarg/2019/04/26/synchronous-text/">recently announced</a> that it would be shutting down its IRC network, citing a growing maintenance and moderation burden. They are looking into new options for the Mozilla community, but this does leave the question open as to what the Rust project will do.</p> <p>Last year a lot of the teams <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/exploring-new-communication-channels/7859">started exploring new communication platforms</a>. Almost all the Rust teams no longer use IRC as their official discussion platform, instead using Discord or Zulip (as well as a variety of video chat tools for synchronous meetings). The few teams that do use IRC are working with us to find a new home, likely a channel on Discord or Zulip.</p> <p>This leaves the #rust and #rust-beginners channels on Mozilla’s IRC network, which are still quite active, that will need a new home when Mozilla’s network shuts down. Rust’s <a href="http://discord.gg/rust-lang">official Discord server</a> does have the #users, #help, and #beginners channels that fill in this purpose, and we recommend people start using those.</p> <p>We understand that not everyone wishes to switch to Discord for many reasons. For people who wish to continue using IRC, there is <a href="http://webchat.freenode.net/?channels=##rust">an unofficial freenode channel</a> which you can hang out in, though we’d like to emphasize that this is not associated with the Rust teams and is not moderated by our Moderation team. You’re also free to create new channels on freenode <a href="https://freenode.net/policies#off-topic-use">in accordance with the freenode rules</a>.</p> <p>There are still a couple months before irc.mozilla.org shuts down — we’ll work at making this transition as smooth as possible in this time. Thanks to everyone who made #rust and #rust-beginners on Mozilla IRC a great place to hang out! We are sad to see it go. 😢</p> Announcing Rust 1.34.1 Thu, 25 Apr 2019 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-34-1/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-34-1/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce a new version of Rust, 1.34.1, and a new version of rustup, 1.18.1. Rust is a programming language that is empowering everyone to build reliable and efficient software.</p> <p>If you have a previous version of Rust installed via rustup, getting Rust 1.34.1 and rustup 1.18.1 is as easy as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">rustup update stable </span></pre> <p>If you don't have it already, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">get <code>rustup</code></a> from the appropriate page on our website.</p> <h2 id="what-s-in-1-34-1-stable">What's in 1.34.1 stable</h2> <p>This patch release fixes two false positives and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-clippy/pull/3805">a panic when checking macros</a> in <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-clippy">Clippy</a>. Clippy is a tool which provides a collection of lints to catch common mistakes and improve your Rust code.</p> <h3 id="false-positive-in-clippy-redundant-closure">False positive in <code>clippy::redundant_closure</code></h3> <p>A false positive in the <code>redundant_closure</code> lint was <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-clippy/pull/3821">fixed</a>. The lint did not take into account <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-clippy/issues/3802">differences in the number of borrows</a>.</p> <p>In the following snippet, the method <code>required</code> expects <code>dep: &amp;D</code> but the actual type of <code>dep</code> is <code>&amp;&amp;D</code>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">dependencies.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">iter</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">().</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">filter</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(|</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">dep</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">| dep.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">required</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">()); </span></pre> <p>Clippy erronously suggested <code>.filter(Dependency::required)</code>, which is rejected by the compiler due to the difference in borrows.</p> <h3 id="false-positive-in-clippy-missing-const-for-fn">False positive in <code>clippy::missing_const_for_fn</code></h3> <p>Another false positive in the <code>missing_const_for_fn</code> lint was <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-clippy/pull/3844">fixed</a>. This lint did not take into account that functions inside <code>trait</code> implementations cannot be <code>const fn</code>s. For example, when given the following snippet, the lint would trigger:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">#[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">derive</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(PartialEq, Eq)] </span><span style="color:#999999;">// warning: this could be a const_fn </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Point(</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">isize</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">isize</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">impl </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">std::ops::Add </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">for </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Point { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">type </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Output </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">Self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">add</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">other</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">Self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) -&gt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">Self </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#999999;">// warning: this could be a const_fn </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> Point(</span><span style="color:#c82829;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">.</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> other.</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#c82829;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">.</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> other.</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) } } </span></pre><h2 id="what-s-new-in-rustup-1-18-1">What's new in rustup 1.18.1</h2> <p>A recent rustup release, 1.18.0, introduced <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rustup.rs/issues/1794">a regression</a> that prevented installing Rust through the shell script on older platforms. A patch was released that fixes the issue, avoiding to force TLS v1.2 on the platforms that don't support it.</p> <p>You can check out other rustup changes in its <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rustup.rs/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#1181---2019-04-25">full release notes</a>.</p> Rust's 2019 roadmap Tue, 23 Apr 2019 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/2019-roadmap/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/2019-roadmap/ <p>Each year the Rust community <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1728">comes together</a> to set out a roadmap. This year, in addition to the <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/11/27/Rust-survey-2018.html">survey</a>, we put out a <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/12/06/call-for-rust-2019-roadmap-blogposts.html">call for blog posts</a> in December, which resulted in <a href="https://readrust.net/rust-2019/">73 blog posts</a> written over the span of a few weeks. The end result is the recently-merged <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/2657-roadmap-2019.md">2019 roadmap RFC</a>. To get all of the details, please give it a read, but this post lays out some of the highlights.</p> <h1 id="the-theme-maturity">The theme: Maturity</h1> <p>In short, 2019 will be a year of <em>rejuvenation</em> and <em>maturation</em> for the Rust project. We shipped a lot of stuff last year, and grew a lot. Now it's time to take a step back, take stock, and prepare for the future.</p> <p>The work we have planned for this year falls into three major categories:</p> <ul> <li>Governance: improving how the project is run</li> <li>Finish long-standing requests: closing out work we've started but never finished</li> <li>Polish: improving the overall quality of the language and tooling</li> </ul> <h2 id="governance">Governance</h2> <p>Over the last three years, the Rust project has grown a lot. Rust used to have a core team of 8 members. When we added sub-teams in 2015, we grew to 23 members. We've now grown to over 100 — that's bigger than many companies! And of course, looking beyond the teams, the size of the Rust community as a whole has grown tremendously as well. As a result of this growth, we've found that the processes which served us well when we were a smaller project are starting to feel some strain.</p> <p>Many of the teams have announced plans to review and revamp their processes so as to scale better. Often this can be as simple as taking the time to write down things that previously were understood only informally — sometimes it means establishing new structures. </p> <p>Because of this widespread interest in governance, we've also created a new <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/governance-working-group-announcement/9637"><strong>Governance Working Group</strong></a>. This group is going to be devoted to working with each team to hone its governance structure and to help pass lessons and strategies between teams.</p> <p>Additionally, the RFC process has been a great boon for Rust, but as we've grown, there have been times where it didn't work so well too. We may look at revisions to the process this year.</p> <h2 id="long-standing-requests">Long-standing requests</h2> <p>There are a number of exciting initiatives that have been sitting in a limbo state — the majority of the design is done, but there are some lingering complications that we haven't had time to work out. This year we hope to take a fresh look at some of these problems and try hard to resolve those lingering problems.</p> <p>Examples include:</p> <ul> <li>The Cargo team and custom registries</li> <li>The Language team is taking a look at async/await, specialization, const generics, and generic associated types</li> <li>The Libs team wants to finish custom allocators</li> </ul> <h2 id="polish">Polish</h2> <p>Finally, the last few years have also seen a lot of foundational work. The compiler, for example, was massively refactored to support incremental compilation and to be better prepared for IDEs. Now that we've got these pieces in place, we want to do the “polish” work that really makes for a great experience.</p> <p>Examples:</p> <ul> <li>Compile times and IDE support</li> <li>Polishing the specification of the language by improving <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/reference/">the reference</a> and laying out <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/unsafe-code-guidelines">the unsafe code guidelines</a></li> <li>The WebAssembly WG's work this year includes polishing our wasm support, for example, debugging</li> </ul> <h2 id="conclusion">Conclusion</h2> <p>This post only covered a few examples of the plans we've been making. <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/2657-roadmap-2019.md">If you'd like to see the full details, take a look at the RFC itself.</a></p> <p>Here's to a great 2019 for Rust!</p> Announcing Rust 1.34.0 Thu, 11 Apr 2019 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-34-0/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-34-0/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce a new version of Rust, 1.34.0. Rust is a programming language that is empowering everyone to build reliable and efficient software.</p> <p>If you have a previous version of Rust installed via rustup, getting Rust 1.34.0 is as easy as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">rustup update stable </span></pre> <p>If you don't have it already, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">get <code>rustup</code></a> from the appropriate page on our website.</p> <h2 id="what-s-in-1-34-0-stable">What's in 1.34.0 stable</h2> <p>The largest feature in this release is the introduction of <em>alternative</em> <code>cargo</code> registries. The release also includes support for <code>?</code> in documentation tests, some improvements for <code>#[attribute(..)]</code>s, as well as the stabilization of <code>TryFrom</code>. Read on for a few highlights, or see the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1340-2019-04-11">detailed release notes</a> for additional information.</p> <h3 id="alternative-cargo-registries">Alternative <code>cargo</code> registries</h3> <p>Since before 1.0, Rust has had a public crate registry, <a href="http://crates.io/">crates.io</a>. People publish crates with <code>cargo publish</code> and it's easy to include these crates in the <code>[dependencies]</code> section of your <code>Cargo.toml</code>.</p> <p>However, not everyone <em>wants</em> to publish their crates to crates.io. People maintaining proprietary/closed-source code cannot use crates.io, and instead are forced to use <code>git</code> or <code>path</code> dependencies. This is usually fine for small projects, but if you have a lot of closed-source crates within a large organization, you lose the benefit of the versioning support that crates.io has.</p> <p>With this release, Cargo gains support for alternate registries. These registries coexist with crates.io, so you can write software that depends on crates from both crates.io and your custom registry. Crates on crates.io cannot however depend on external registries.</p> <p>To use an alternate registry, you must add these lines to your <code>.cargo/config</code>. This file can be in your home directory (<code>~/.cargo/config</code>) or relative to the package directory.</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">registries</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#c82829;">my-registry </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= { </span><span style="color:#c82829;">index </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;https://my-intranet:8080/git/index&quot; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p>Depending on a crate from an alternate registry is easy. When specifying dependencies in your <code>Cargo.toml</code>, use the <code>registry</code> key to let Cargo know that you wish to fetch the crate from the alternate registry:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">dependencies</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#c82829;">other-crate </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= { </span><span style="color:#c82829;">version </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;1.0&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#c82829;">registry </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;my-registry&quot; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p>As a crate author, if you wish to publish your crate to an alternate registry, you first need to save the authentication token into <code>~/.cargo/credentials</code> with the <code>cargo login</code> command:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">cargo</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> login</span><span style="color:#f5871f;"> --registry</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">my-registry </span></pre> <p>You can then use the <code>--registry</code> flag to indicate which registry to use when publishing:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">cargo</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> publish</span><span style="color:#f5871f;"> --registry</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">my-registry </span></pre> <p>There is <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/cargo/reference/registries.html#running-a-registry">documentation</a> on how to run your own registry.</p> <h3 id="in-documentation-tests"><code>?</code> in documentation tests</h3> <p><a href="https://rust-lang.github.io/rfcs/1937-ques-in-main.html">RFC 1937</a> proposed adding support for using the <code>?</code> operator in <code>fn main()</code>, <code>#[test]</code> functions, and doctests, allowing them to return <code>Option&lt;T&gt;</code> or <code>Result&lt;T, E&gt;</code>, with error values causing a nonzero exit code in the case of <code>fn main()</code>, and a test failure in the case of the tests.</p> <p>Support in <code>fn main()</code> and <code>#[test]</code> was implemented <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/05/10/Rust-1.26.html#main-can-return-a-result">many releases ago</a>. However, the support within documentation tests was limited to doctests that have an explicit <code>fn main()</code>.</p> <p>In this release, full support for <code>?</code> in doctests has been added. Now, you can write this in your documentation tests:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#999999;">/// ```rust /// use std::io; /// let mut input = String::new(); /// io::stdin().read_line(&amp;mut input)?; /// # Ok::&lt;(), io::Error&gt;(()) /// ``` </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">my_func</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() {} </span></pre> <p>You still have to specify the error type being used at the bottom of the documentation test.</p> <h3 id="custom-attributes-accept-arbitrary-token-streams">Custom attributes accept arbitrary token streams</h3> <p><a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/12/21/Procedural-Macros-in-Rust-2018.html">Procedural macros</a> in Rust can define custom attributes that they consume. Until now, such attributes were restricted to being trees of paths and literals according to a specific syntax, like:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">#[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">foo</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(bar)] #[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">foo </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;bar&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] #[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">foo </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> 0] #[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">foo</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(bar </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> true)] #[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">foo</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(bar, </span><span style="color:#c82829;">baz</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">(quux, foo </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;bar&quot;</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">)</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">)] </span></pre> <p>Unlike procedural macros, these helper attributes could not accept arbitrary token streams in delimiters, so you could not write <code>#[range(0..10)]</code> or <code>#[bound(T: MyTrait)]</code>. Procedural macro crates would instead use strings for specifying syntaxes like this, e.g. <code>#[range(&quot;0..10&quot;)]</code></p> <p>With this Rust release, custom attributes <code>#[attr($tokens)]</code> <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/57367">now accept</a> arbitrary token streams in <code>$tokens</code>, bringing them on par with macros. If you're the author of a procedural macro crate, please check if your custom attributes have unnecessary strings in their syntax and if they can be better expressed with token streams.</p> <h3 id="tryfrom-and-tryinto"><code>TryFrom</code> and <code>TryInto</code></h3> <p>The <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/convert/trait.TryFrom.html"><code>TryFrom</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/convert/trait.TryInto.html"><code>TryInto</code></a> traits were stabilized to allow fallible type conversions.</p> <p>For example, the <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.u32.html#method.from_be_bytes"><code>from_be_bytes</code></a> and related methods on integer types take arrays, but data is often read in via slices. Converting between slices and arrays is tedious to do manually. With the new traits, it can be done inline with <code>.try_into()</code>.</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> num </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">::from_be_bytes(slice.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">try_into</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">()</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">?</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); </span></pre> <p>For conversions that cannot fail, such as <code>u8</code> to <code>u32</code>, the <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/convert/enum.Infallible.html"><code>Infallible</code></a> type was added. This also permits a blanket implementation of <code>TryFrom</code> for all existing <code>From</code> implementations. In the future, we hope to turn <code>Infallible</code> into an alias for <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/35121">the <code>!</code> (never) type</a>.</p> <h3 id="fn-before-exec-deprecated-in-favor-of-unsafe-fn-pre-exec"><code>fn before_exec</code> deprecated in favor of <code>unsafe fn pre_exec</code></h3> <p>On Unix-like systems, the function <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/os/unix/process/trait.CommandExt.html#tymethod.before_exec"><code>CommandExt::before_exec</code></a> allows you to schedule a closure to be run before <code>exec</code> is invoked.</p> <p>The closure provided will be run in the context of the child process after a fork. This means that resources, such as file descriptors and memory-mapped regions, may get duplicated. In other words, you can now copy a value of a non-<code>Copy</code> type into a different process while retaining the original in the parent. This makes <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/39575#issuecomment-437658766">it possible</a> to cause undefined behavior and break <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/39575#issuecomment-439645949">libraries assuming non-duplication</a>.</p> <p>The function <code>before_exec</code> should therefore have been marked as <code>unsafe</code>. In this release of Rust, we have deprecated <code>fn before_exec</code> in favor of the <code>unsafe fn pre_exec</code>. When calling <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/os/unix/process/trait.CommandExt.html#tymethod.pre_exec"><code>CommandExt::pre_exec</code></a>, it is your responsibility to make sure that the closure does not violate library invariants by making invalid use of these duplicates. If you provide a library that is in a similar situation as <code>before_exec</code>, consider deprecating and providing an <code>unsafe</code> alternative as well.</p> <h3 id="library-stabilizations">Library stabilizations</h3> <p>In 1.34.0, the set of stable atomic integer types was expanded, with signed and unsigned variants from 8 (<a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/sync/atomic/struct.AtomicU8.html"><code>AtomicU8</code></a>) to 64 bits now available.</p> <p><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1280-2018-08-02">Previously</a>, non-zero unsigned integer types, e.g. <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/num/struct.NonZeroU8.html"><code>NonZeroU8</code></a>, were stabilized. This gave <code>Option&lt;NonZeroU8&gt;</code> the same size as <code>u8</code>. With this Rust release, signed versions, e.g. <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/num/struct.NonZeroI8.html"><code>NonZeroI8</code></a>, have been stabilized.</p> <p>The functions <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/iter/fn.from_fn.html"><code>iter::from_fn</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/iter/fn.successors.html"><code>iter::successors</code></a> have been stabilized. The former allows you to construct an iterator from <code>FnMut() -&gt; Option&lt;T&gt;</code>. To pop elements from a vector iteratively, you can now write <code>from_fn(|| vec.pop())</code>.
