Meanwhile, the latter creates a new iterator where each successive item is computed based on the preceding one.</p> <p>Additionally, these APIs have become stable:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/any/trait.Any.html#tymethod.type_id">Any::type_id</a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/error/trait.Error.html#method.type_id">Error::type_id</a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.slice.html#method.sort_by_cached_key">slice::sort_by_cached_key</a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.str.html#method.escape_debug">str::escape_debug</a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.str.html#method.escape_default">str::escape_default</a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.str.html#method.escape_unicode">str::escape_unicode</a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.str.html#method.split_ascii_whitespace">str::split_ascii_whitespace</a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/time/struct.Instant.html#method.checked_add">Instant::checked_add</a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/time/struct.Instant.html#method.checked_sub">Instant::checked_sub</a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/time/struct.SystemTime.html#method.checked_add">SystemTime::checked_add</a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/time/struct.SystemTime.html#method.checked_sub">SystemTime::checked_sub</a></li> </ul> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1340-2019-04-11">detailed release notes</a> for more details.</p> Announcing Rust 1.33.0 Thu, 28 Feb 2019 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-33-0/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-33-0/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce a new version of Rust, 1.33.0. Rust is a programming language that is empowering everyone to build reliable and efficient software.</p> <p>If you have a previous version of Rust installed via rustup, getting Rust 1.33.0 is as easy as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">rustup update stable </span></pre> <p>If you don't have it already, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">get <code>rustup</code></a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/stable/RELEASES.md#version-1330-2019-02-28">detailed release notes for 1.33.0</a> on GitHub.</p> <h2 id="what-s-in-1-33-0-stable">What's in 1.33.0 stable</h2> <p>The two largest features in this release are significant improvements to <code>const fn</code>s, and the stabilization of a new concept: &quot;pinning.&quot;</p> <h3 id="const-fn-improvements"><code>const fn</code> improvements</h3> <p>With <code>const fn</code>, you can <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/57175/">now do way more things!</a> Specifically:</p> <ul> <li>irrefutable destructuring patterns (e.g. <code>const fn foo((x, y): (u8, u8)) { ... }</code>)</li> <li><code>let</code> bindings (e.g. <code>let x = 1;</code>)</li> <li>mutable <code>let</code> bindings (e.g. <code>let mut x = 1;</code>)</li> <li>assignment (e.g. <code>x = y</code>) and assignment operator (e.g. <code>x += y</code>) expressions, even where the assignment target is a projection (e.g. a struct field or index operation like <code>x[3] = 42</code>)</li> <li>expression statements (e.g. <code>3;</code>)</li> </ul> <p>You're also <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/57067/">able to call <code>const unsafe fn</code>s inside a <code>const fn</code></a>, like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">const unsafe fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">foo</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() -&gt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">5 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">const fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">bar</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() -&gt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">unsafe </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">foo</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() } } </span></pre> <p>With these additions, many more functions in the standard library are able to be marked as <code>const</code>. We'll enumerate those in the library section below.</p> <h3 id="pinning">Pinning</h3> <p>This release introduces a new concept for Rust programs, implemented as two types: the <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/pin/struct.Pin.html"><code>std::pin::Pin&lt;P&gt;</code> type</a>, and the <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/marker/trait.Unpin.html"><code>Unpin</code> marker trait</a>. The core idea is elaborated on in <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/pin/index.html">the docs for <code>std::pin</code></a>:</p> <blockquote> <p>It is sometimes useful to have objects that are guaranteed to not move, in the sense that their placement in memory does not change, and can thus be relied upon. A prime example of such a scenario would be building self-referential structs, since moving an object with pointers to itself will invalidate them, which could cause undefined behavior.</p> <p>A <code>Pin&lt;P&gt;</code> ensures that the pointee of any pointer type <code>P</code> has a stable location in memory, meaning it cannot be moved elsewhere and its memory cannot be deallocated until it gets dropped. We say that the pointee is &quot;pinned&quot;.</p> </blockquote> <p>This feature will largely be used by library authors, and so we won't talk a lot more about the details here. Consult the docs if you're interested in digging into the details. However, the stabilization of this API is important to Rust users generally because it is a significant step forward towards a highly anticipated Rust feature: <code>async</code>/<code>await</code>. We're not quite there yet, but this stabilization brings us one step closer. You can track all of the necessary features at <a href="https://areweasyncyet.rs/">areweasyncyet.rs</a>.</p> <h3 id="import-as">Import as <code>_</code></h3> <p><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/56303/">You can now import an item as <code>_</code></a>. This allows you to import a trait's impls, and not have the name in the namespace. e.g.</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">use </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">std::io::Read </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">as _</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#999999;">// Allowed as there is only one `Read` in the module. </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">pub trait </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Read {} </span></pre> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/stable/RELEASES.md#version-1330-2019-02-28">detailed release notes</a> for more details.</p> <h3 id="library-stabilizations">Library stabilizations</h3> <p>Here's all of the stuff that's been made <code>const</code>:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/57566">The methods <code>overflowing_{add, sub, mul, shl, shr}</code> are now <code>const</code> functions for all numeric types.</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/57105">The methods <code>rotate_left</code>, <code>rotate_right</code>, and <code>wrapping_{add, sub, mul, shl, shr}</code> are now <code>const</code> functions for all numeric types.</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/57105">The methods <code>is_positive</code> and <code>is_negative</code> are now <code>const</code> functions for all signed numeric types.</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/57167">The <code>get</code> method for all <code>NonZero</code> types is now <code>const</code>.</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/57234">The methods <code>count_ones</code>, <code>count_zeros</code>, <code>leading_zeros</code>, <code>trailing_zeros</code>, <code>swap_bytes</code>, <code>from_be</code>, <code>from_le</code>, <code>to_be</code>, <code>to_le</code> are now <code>const</code> for all numeric types.</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/57234"><code>Ipv4Addr::new</code> is now a <code>const</code> function</a></li> </ul> <p>Additionally, these APIs have become stable:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/os/unix/fs/trait.FileExt.html#method.read_exact_at"><code>unix::FileExt::read_exact_at</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/os/unix/fs/trait.FileExt.html#method.write_all_at"><code>unix::FileExt::write_all_at</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/option/enum.Option.html#method.transpose"><code>Option::transpose</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/result/enum.Result.html#method.transpose"><code>Result::transpose</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/convert/fn.identity.html"><code>convert::identity</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/pin/struct.Pin.html"><code>pin::Pin</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/std/marker/trait.Unpin.html"><code>marker::Unpin</code></a> (mentioned above)</li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/std/marker/struct.PhantomPinned.html"><code>marker::PhantomPinned</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/vec/struct.Vec.html#method.resize_with"><code>Vec::resize_with</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/collections/struct.VecDeque.html#method.resize_with"><code>VecDeque::resize_with</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/time/struct.Duration.html#method.as_millis"><code>Duration::as_millis</code></a>, <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/time/struct.Duration.html#method.as_micros"><code>Duration::as_micros</code></a>, and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/time/struct.Duration.html#method.as_nanos"><code>Duration::as_nanos</code></a></li> </ul> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/stable/RELEASES.md#version-1330-2019-02-28">detailed release notes</a> for more details.</p> <h3 id="cargo-features">Cargo features</h3> <p><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/6484/">Cargo should now rebuild a crate if a file was modified during the initial build.</a></p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/stable/RELEASES.md#version-1330-2019-02-28">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h3 id="crates-io">Crates.io</h3> <p><a href="https://users.rust-lang.org/t/a-verified-email-address-will-be-required-to-publish-to-crates-io-starting-on-2019-02-28/22425">As previously announced</a>, coinciding with this release, crates.io will require that you have a verified email address to publish. Starting at 2019-03-01 00:00 UTC, if you don't have a verified email address and run <code>cargo publish</code>, you'll get an error.</p> <p>This ensures we can comply with DMCA procedures. If you haven't heeded the warnings cargo printed during the last release cycle, head on over to <a href="https://crates.io/me">crates.io/me</a> to set and verify your email address. This email address will never be displayed publicly and will only be used for crates.io operations.</p> <h2 id="contributors-to-1-33-0">Contributors to 1.33.0</h2> <p>Many people came together to create Rust 1.33.0. We couldn't have done it without all of you. <a href="https://thanks.rust-lang.org/rust/1.33.0">Thanks!</a></p> Changes in the core team Fri, 22 Feb 2019 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/core-team-changes/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/core-team-changes/ <p>Just a quick update: You may have noticed that, in the last month or so, a number of <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/governance/teams/core">Rust core team</a> members have changed their jobs and/or their roles in the project. Two people have decided to step back from the core team:</p> <ul> <li>Nick Cameron <a href="https://www.ncameron.org/blog/leaving-mozilla-and-most-of-the-rust-project/">left Mozilla to work at PingCap</a>. Although he won’t have time to stay active on the core team, he plans to continue co-leading the Cargo team in his new position.</li> <li>Aaron Turon <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/aturon-retires-from-the-core-team-but-not-from-rust/9392/3">decided to step back from the core team</a> so that he could focus on engineering work and the language design team. (He remains on the Rust team at Mozilla.)</li> </ul> <p>With Rust 2018 having shipped, this is a natural time of transition. While we’ll miss Nick and Aaron’s contributions to the core team, we are very excited for them to be focusing on something new, and we’re very happy that they are still going to stay involved with Rust. We’re also looking into growing the core team to help with the work ahead.</p> <p>Finally, two other members have changed their jobs, but plan to stay involved in the core team:</p> <ul> <li>Ashley Williams <a href="https://twitter.com/ag_dubs/status/1088118810157219848">joined Cloudflare and plans to work on Rust and WASM integration there</a>. She will be remaining on the core team. </li> <li>Steve Klabnik <a href="https://words.steveklabnik.com/thank-u-next">left Mozilla, but will remain on the core team.</a></li> </ul> <p>That’s it!</p> Announcing Rust 1.32.0 Thu, 17 Jan 2019 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-32-0/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-32-0/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce a new version of Rust, 1.32.0. Rust is a programming language that is empowering everyone to build reliable and efficient software.</p> <p>If you have a previous version of Rust installed via rustup, getting Rust 1.32.0 is as easy as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">rustup update stable </span></pre> <p>If you don't have it already, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">get <code>rustup</code></a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1320-2019-01-17">detailed release notes for 1.32.0</a> on GitHub.</p> <blockquote> <p>As a small side note, <code>rustup</code> has seen some new releases lately! To update <code>rustup</code> itself, run <code>rustup self update</code>.</p> </blockquote> <h2 id="what-s-in-1-32-0-stable">What's in 1.32.0 stable</h2> <p>Rust 1.32.0 has a few quality of life improvements, switches the default allocator, and makes additional functions <code>const</code>. Read on for a few highlights, or see the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1320-2019-01-17">detailed release notes</a> for additional information.</p> <h4 id="the-dbg-macro">The <code>dbg</code> macro</h4> <p>First up, a quality of life improvement. Are you a &quot;print debugger&quot;? If you are, and you've wanted to print out some value while working on some code, you have to do this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">5</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#666969;">{:?}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, x); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// or maybe even this </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#666969;">{:#?}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, x); </span></pre> <p>This isn't the <em>largest</em> speed bump, but it is a lot of stuff to simply show the value of <code>x</code>. Additionally, there's no context here. If you have several of these <code>println!</code>s, it can be hard to tell which is which, unless you add your own context to each invocation, requiring even more work.</p> <p>In Rust 1.32.0, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/56395/">we've added a new macro, <code>dbg!</code></a>, for this purpose:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">5</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; dbg!(x); } </span></pre> <p>If you run this program, you'll see:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[src/main.rs:4] x = 5 </span></pre> <p>You get the file and line number of where this was invoked, as well as the name and value. Additionally, <code>println!</code> prints to the standard output, so you really should be using <code>eprintln!</code> to print to standard error. <code>dbg!</code> does the right thing and goes to <code>stderr</code>.</p> <p>It even works in more complex circumstances. Consider this factorial example:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">factorial</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">n</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) -&gt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u32 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">if</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> n </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&lt;= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ n } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">else </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ n </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">* </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">factorial</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(n </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">- </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) } } </span></pre> <p>If we wanted to debug this, we might write it like this with <code>eprintln!</code>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">factorial</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">n</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) -&gt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u32 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ eprintln!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;n: {}&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, n); </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">if</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> n </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&lt;= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ eprintln!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;n &lt;= 1&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); n } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">else </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> n </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> n </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">* </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">factorial</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(n </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">- </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); eprintln!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;n: {}&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, n); n } } </span></pre> <p>We want to log <code>n</code> on each iteration, as well as have some kind of context for each of the branches. We see this output for <code>factorial(4)</code>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">n: 4 n: 3 n: 2 n: 1 n &lt;= 1 n: 2 n: 6 n: 24 </span></pre> <p>This is servicable, but not particularly great. Maybe we could work on how we print out the context to make it more clear, but now we're not debugging our code, we're figuring out how to make our debugging code better.</p> <p>Consider this version using <code>dbg!</code>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">factorial</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">n</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) -&gt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u32 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">if </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">dbg!(n </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&lt;= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) { dbg!(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">else </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ dbg!(n </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">* </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">factorial</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(n </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">- </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">)) } } </span></pre> <p>We simply wrap each of the various expressions we want to print with the macro. We get this output instead:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[src/main.rs:3] n &lt;= 1 = false [src/main.rs:3] n &lt;= 1 = false [src/main.rs:3] n &lt;= 1 = false [src/main.rs:3] n &lt;= 1 = true [src/main.rs:4] 1 = 1 [src/main.rs:5] n * factorial(n - 1) = 2 [src/main.rs:5] n * factorial(n - 1) = 6 [src/main.rs:5] n * factorial(n - 1) = 24 [src/main.rs:11] factorial(4) = 24 </span></pre> <p>Because the <code>dbg!</code> macro returns the value of what it's debugging, instead of <code>eprintln!</code> which returns <code>()</code>, we need to make <em>no</em> changes to the structure of our code. Additionally, we have <em>vastly</em> more useful output.</p> <p>That's a lot to say about a little macro, but we hope it improves your debugging experience! We are contining to work on support for <code>gdb</code> and friends as well, of course.</p> <h4 id="jemalloc-is-removed-by-default"><code>jemalloc</code> is removed by default</h4> <p>Long, long ago, Rust had a large, Erlang-like runtime. We chose to use <a href="http://jemalloc.net/">jemalloc</a> instead of the system allocator, because it often improved performance over the default system one. Over time, we shed more and more of this runtime, and eventually almost all of it was removed, but jemalloc was not. We didn't have a way to choose a custom allocator, and so we couldn't really remove it without causing a regression for people who do need jemalloc.</p> <p>Also, saying that <code>jemalloc</code> was always the default is a bit UNIX-centric, as it was only the default on <em>some</em> platforms. Notably, the MSVC target on Windows has shipped the system allocator for a long time.</p> <p>Finally, while jemalloc <em>usually</em> has great performance, that's not always the case. Additionally, it adds about 300kb to every Rust binary. We've also had a host of <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/36963#issuecomment-252029017">other issues</a> with jemalloc in the past. It has also felt a little strange that a systems language does not default to the system's allocator.</p> <p>For all of these reasons, once <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/08/02/Rust-1.28.html#whats-in-1.28.0-stable">Rust 1.28 shipped a way to choose a global allocator</a>, we started making plans to switch the default to the system allocator, and allow you to use <code>jemalloc</code> via a crate. In Rust 1.32, we've finally finished this work, and by default, you will get the system allocator for your programs.</p> <p>If you'd like to continue to use jemalloc, use <a href="https://crates.io/crates/jemallocator">the jemallocator crate</a>. In your <code>Cargo.toml</code>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">jemallocator </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;0.1.8&quot; </span></pre> <p>And in your crate root:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">#[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">global_allocator</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">static </span><span style="color:#666969;">ALLOC</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: jemallocator::Jemalloc </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">jemallocator::Jemalloc; </span></pre> <p>That's it! If you don't need jemalloc, it's not forced upon you, and if you do need it, it's a few lines of code away.</p> <h4 id="final-module-improvements">Final module improvements</h4> <p>In the past two releases, we announced several improvements to the module system. We have one last tweak landing in 1.32.0 and the 2018 edition. Nicknamed <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/56759#issuecomment-450051210">&quot;uniform paths&quot;</a>, it permits previously invalid import path statements to be resolved exactly the same way as non-import paths. For example:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">enum </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Color { Red, Green, Blue } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">use </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Color::</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">*</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span></pre> <p>This code did <em>not</em> previously compile, as <code>use</code> statements had to start with <code>super</code>, <code>self</code>, or <code>crate</code>. Now that the compiler supports uniform paths, this code will work, and do what you probably expect: import the variants of the <code>Color</code> enum defined above the <code>use</code> statement.</p> <p>With this change in place, we've completed our efforts at revising the module system. We hope you've been enjoying the simplified system so far!</p> <h4 id="macro-improvements">Macro improvements</h4> <p>A few improvements to macros have landed in Rust 1.32.0. First, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/56072/">a new <code>literal</code> matcher</a> was added:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4271ae;">macro_rules! </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">m { ($lt:literal) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{}; } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { m!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;some string literal&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); } </span></pre> <p><code>literal</code> matches against literals of any type; string literals, numeric literals, <code>char</code> literals.</p> <p>In the 2018 edition, <code>macro_rules</code> macros can also use <code>?</code>, like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4271ae;">macro_rules! </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">bar { (</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">$</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(a)?) =&gt; {} } </span></pre> <p>The <code>?</code> will match zero or one repetitions of the pattern, similar to the already-existing <code>*</code> for &quot;zero or more&quot; and <code>+</code> for &quot;one or more.&quot;</p> <h3 id="library-stabilizations">Library stabilizations</h3> <p>We talked above about the <code>dbg!</code> macro, which is a big library addition. Beyond that, 19 functions were made <code>const fn</code>s, and all integral numeric primitives now provide conversion functions to and from byte-arrays with specified endianness. These six functions are named <code>to_&lt;endian&gt;_bytes</code> and <code>from_&lt;endian&gt;_bytes</code>, where <code>&lt;endian&gt;</code> is one of:</p> <ul> <li><code>ne</code> - native endianness</li> <li><code>le</code> - little endian</li> <li><code>be</code> - big endian</li> </ul> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1320-2019-01-17">detailed release notes</a> for more details.</p> <h3 id="cargo-features">Cargo features</h3> <p>Cargo gained <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/6218/"><code>cargo c</code> as an alias for <code>cargo check</code></a>, and now <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/6242/">allows usernames in registry URLs</a>.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1320-2019-01-17">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h2 id="contributors-to-1-32-0">Contributors to 1.32.0</h2> <p>Many people came together to create Rust 1.32.0. We couldn't have done it without all of you. <a href="https://thanks.rust-lang.org/rust/1.32.0">Thanks!</a></p> Procedural Macros in Rust 2018 Fri, 21 Dec 2018 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/procedural-macros-in-rust-2018/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/procedural-macros-in-rust-2018/ <p>Perhaps my favorite feature in the Rust 2018 edition is <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/reference/procedural-macros.html">procedural macros</a>. Procedural macros have had a long and storied history in Rust (and will continue to have a storied future!), and now is perhaps one of the best times to get involved with them because the 2018 edition has so dramatically improved the experience both defining and using them.</p> <p>Here I'd like to explore what procedural macros are, what they're capable of, notable new features, and some fun use cases of procedural macros. I might even convince you that this is Rust 2018's best feature as well!</p> <h3 id="what-is-a-procedural-macro">What is a procedural macro?</h3> <p>First defined over two years ago in <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/1566-proc-macros.md">RFC 1566</a>, procedural macros are, in layman's terms, a function that takes a piece of syntax at compile time and produces a new bit of syntax. Procedural macros in Rust 2018 come in one of three flavors:</p> <ul> <li> <p><strong><code>#[derive]</code> mode macros</strong> have actually been stable since <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/02/02/Rust-1.15.html">Rust 1.15</a> and bring all the goodness and ease of use of <code>#[derive(Debug)]</code> to user-defined traits as well, such as <a href="https://serde.rs">Serde</a>'s <code>#[derive(Deserialize)]</code>.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Function-like macros</strong> are newly stable to the 2018 edition and allow defining macros like <code>env!(&quot;FOO&quot;)</code> or <code>format_args!(&quot;...&quot;)</code> in a crates.io-based library. You can think of these as sort of &quot;<code>macro_rules!</code> macros&quot; on steroids.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Attribute macros</strong>, my favorite, are also new in the 2018 edition and allow you to provide lightweight annotations on Rust functions which perform syntactical transformations over the code at compile time.</p> </li> </ul> <p>Each of these flavors of macros can be defined in a crate with <code>proc-macro = true</code> <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/reference/manifest.html">specified in its manifest</a>. When used, a procedural macro is loaded by the Rust compiler and executed as the invocation is expanded. This means that Cargo is in control of versioning for procedural macros and you can use them with all same ease of use you'd expect from other Cargo dependencies!</p> <h3 id="defining-a-procedural-macro">Defining a procedural macro</h3> <p>Each of the three types of procedural macros are <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/reference/procedural-macros.html">defined in a slightly different fashion</a>, and here we'll single out attribute macros. First, we'll flag <code>Cargo.toml</code>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">lib</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#c82829;">proc-macro </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">true </span></pre> <p>and then in <code>src/lib.rs</code> we can write our macro:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">extern crate</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> proc_macro; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">use </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">proc_macro::TokenStream; #[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">proc_macro_attribute</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">pub fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">hello</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">attr</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: TokenStream, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">item</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: TokenStream) -&gt; TokenStream { </span><span style="color:#999999;">// ... </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p>We can then write some unit tests in <code>tests/smoke.rs</code>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">#[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">my_crate</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">::</span><span style="color:#c82829;">hello</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">wrapped_function</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() {} #[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">test</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">works</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">wrapped_function</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(); } </span></pre> <p>... and that's it! When we execute <code>cargo test</code> Cargo will compile our procedural macro. Afterwards it will compile our unit test which loads the macro at compile time, executing the <code>hello</code> function and compiling the resulting syntax.</p> <p>Right off the bat we can see a few important properties of procedural macros:</p> <ul> <li>The input/output is this fancy <code>TokenStream</code> type we'll talk about more in a bit</li> <li>We're <em>executing arbitrary code</em> at compile time, which means we can do just about anything!</li> <li>Procedural macros are incorporated with the module system, meaning they can be imported just like any other name.</li> </ul> <p>Before we take a look at implementing a procedural macro, let's first dive into some of these points.</p> <h3 id="macros-and-the-module-system">Macros and the module system</h3> <p>First stabilized in <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/10/25/Rust-1.30.0.html">Rust 1.30</a> (noticing a trend with 1.15?) macros are now integrated with the module system in Rust. This mainly means that you no longer need the clunky <code>#[macro_use]</code> attribute when importing macros! Instead of this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">#[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">macro_use</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">extern crate</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> log; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { debug!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;hello, &quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); info!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;world!&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); } </span></pre> <p>you can do:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">use </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">log::info; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { log::debug</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">!</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;hello, &quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); info!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;world!&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); } </span></pre> <p>Integration with the module system solves one of the most confusing parts about macros historically. They're now imported and namespaced just as you would any other item in Rust!</p> <p>The benefits are not only limited to bang-style <code>macro_rules</code> macros, as you can now transform code that looks like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">#[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">macro_use</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">extern crate</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> serde_derive; #[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">derive</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(Deserialize)] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Foo { </span><span style="color:#999999;">// ... </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p>into</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">use </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">serde::Deserialize; #[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">derive</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(Deserialize)] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Foo { </span><span style="color:#999999;">// ... </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p>and you don't even need to explicitly depend on <code>serde_derive</code> in <code>Cargo.toml</code>! All you need is:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">dependencies</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#c82829;">serde </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= { </span><span style="color:#c82829;">version </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&#39;1.0.82&#39;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#c82829;">features </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= [</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&#39;derive&#39;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] } </span></pre><h3 id="what-s-inside-a-tokenstream">What's inside a <code>TokenStream</code>?</h3> <p>This mysterious <code>TokenStream</code> type comes from the <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/proc_macro/">compiler-provided <code>proc_macro</code> crate</a>. When it was first added all you could do with a <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/proc_macro/struct.TokenStream.html"><code>TokenStream</code></a> was call convert it to or from a string using <code>to_string()</code> or <code>parse()</code>. As of Rust 2018, you can act on the tokens in a <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/proc_macro/struct.TokenStream.html"><code>TokenStream</code></a> directly.</p> <p>A <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/proc_macro/struct.TokenStream.html"><code>TokenStream</code></a> is effectively &quot;just&quot; an iterator over <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/proc_macro/enum.TokenTree.html"><code>TokenTree</code></a>. All syntax in Rust falls into one of these four categories, the four variants of <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/proc_macro/enum.TokenTree.html"><code>TokenTree</code></a>:</p> <ul> <li><code>Ident</code> is any identifier like <code>foo</code> or <code>bar</code>. This also contains keywords such as <code>self</code> and <code>super</code>.</li> <li><code>Literal</code> include things like <code>1</code>, <code>&quot;foo&quot;</code>, and <code>'b'</code>. All literals are one token and represent constant values in a program.</li> <li><code>Punct</code> represents some form of punctuation that's not a delimiter. For example <code>.</code> is a <code>Punct</code> token in the field access of <code>foo.bar</code>. Multi-character punctuation like <code>=&gt;</code> is represented as two <code>Punct</code> tokens, one for <code>=</code> and one for <code>&gt;</code>, and the <code>Spacing</code> enum says that the <code>=</code> is adjacent to the <code>&gt;</code>.</li> <li><code>Group</code> is where the term &quot;tree&quot; is most relevant, as <code>Group</code> represents a delimited sub-token-stream. For example <code>(a, b)</code> is a <code>Group</code> with parentheses as delimiters, and the internal token stream is <code>a, b</code>.</li> </ul> <p>While this is conceptually simple, this may sound like there's not much we can do with this! It's unclear, for example, how we might parse a function from a <code>TokenStream</code>. The minimality of <code>TokenTree</code> is crucial, however, for stabilization. It would be infeasible to stabilize the Rust AST because that means we could never change it. (imagine if we couldn't have added the <code>?</code> operator!)</p> <p>By using <code>TokenStream</code> to communicate with procedural macros, the compiler is able to add new language syntax while also being able to compile and work with older procedural macros. Let's see now, though, how we can actually get useful information out of a <code>TokenStream</code>.</p> <h3 id="parsing-a-tokenstream">Parsing a <code>TokenStream</code></h3> <p>If <code>TokenStream</code> is just a simple iterator, then we've got a long way to go from that to an actual parsed function. Although the code is already lexed for us we still need to write a whole Rust parser! Thankfully though the community has been hard at work to make sure writing procedural macros in Rust is as smooth as can be, so you need look no further than the <a href="https://crates.io/crates/syn"><code>syn</code> crate</a>.</p> <p>With the <a href="https://crates.io/crates/syn"><code>syn</code></a> crate we can parse any Rust AST as a one-liner:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">#[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">proc_macro_attribute</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">pub fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">hello</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">attr</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: TokenStream, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">item</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: TokenStream) -&gt; TokenStream { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> input </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">syn::parse_macro_input</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">!</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(item </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">as </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">syn::ItemFn); </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> name </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= &amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">input.ident; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> abi </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= &amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">input.abi; </span><span style="color:#999999;">// ... </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p>The <a href="https://crates.io/crates/syn"><code>syn</code></a> crate not only comes with the ability to parse built-in syntax but you can also easily write a recursive descent parser for your own syntax. The <a href="https://docs.rs/syn/0.15/syn/parse/index.html"><code>syn::parse</code> module</a> has more information about this capability.</p> <h3 id="producing-a-tokenstream">Producing a <code>TokenStream</code></h3> <p>Not only do we take a <code>TokenStream</code> as input with a procedural macro, but we also need to produce a <code>TokenStream</code> as output. This output is typically required to be valid Rust syntax, but like the input it's just list of tokens that we need to build somehow.</p> <p>Technically the only way to create a <code>TokenStream</code> is via its <code>FromIterator</code> implementation, which means we'd have to create each token one-by-one and collect it into a <code>TokenStream</code>. This is quite tedious, though, so let's take a look at <a href="https://crates.io/crates/syn"><code>syn</code></a>'s sibling crate: <a href="https://docs.rs/quote/0.6/quote/"><code>quote</code></a>.</p> <p>The <a href="https://docs.rs/quote/0.6/quote/"><code>quote</code></a> crate is a quasi-quoting implementation for Rust which primarily provides a convenient macro for us to use:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">use </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">quote::quote; #[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">proc_macro_attribute</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">pub fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">hello</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">attr</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: TokenStream, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">item</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: TokenStream) -&gt; TokenStream { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> input </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">syn::parse_macro_input</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">!</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(item </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">as </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">syn::ItemFn); </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> name </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= &amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">input.ident; </span><span style="color:#999999;">// Our input function is always equivalent to returning 42, right? </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> result </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">quote! { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">#</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">name</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() -&gt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u32 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">42 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} }; result.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">into</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() } </span></pre> <p>The <a href="https://docs.rs/quote/0.6/quote/macro.quote.html"><code>quote!</code> macro</a> allows you to write mostly-Rust syntax and interpolate variables quickly from the environment with <code>#foo</code>. This removes much of the tedium of creating a <code>TokenStream</code> token-by-token and allows quickly cobbling together various pieces of syntax into one return value.</p> <h3 id="tokens-and-span">Tokens and <code>Span</code></h3> <p>Perhaps the greatest feature of procedural macros in Rust 2018 is the ability to customize and use <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/proc_macro/struct.Span.html"><code>Span</code></a> information on each token, giving us the ability for amazing syntactical error messages from procedural macros:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">error: expected `fn` --&gt; src/main.rs:3:14 | 3 | my_annotate!(not_fn foo() {}); | ^^^^^^ </span></pre> <p>as well as completely custom error messages:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">error: imported methods must have at least one argument --&gt; invalid-imports.rs:12:5 | 12 | fn f1(); | ^^^^^^^^ </span></pre> <p>A <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/proc_macro/struct.Span.html"><code>Span</code></a> can be thought of as a pointer back into an original source file, typically saying something like &quot;the <code>Ident</code> token<code> foo</code> came from file <code>bar.rs</code>, line 4, column 5, and was 3 bytes long&quot;. This information is primarily used by the compiler's diagnostics with warnings and error messages.</p> <p>In Rust 2018 each <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/proc_macro/enum.TokenTree.html"><code>TokenTree</code></a> has a <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/proc_macro/struct.Span.html"><code>Span</code></a> associated with it. This means that if you preserve the <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/proc_macro/struct.Span.html"><code>Span</code></a> of all input tokens into the output then even though you're producing brand new syntax the compiler's error messages are still accurate!</p> <p>For example, a small macro like:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">#[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">proc_macro</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">pub fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">make_pub</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">item</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: TokenStream) -&gt; TokenStream { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> result </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">quote! { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">pub </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">#</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">item }; result.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">into</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() } </span></pre> <p>when invoked as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">my_macro::make_pub</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">! </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">static</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> X: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u32 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;foo&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; } </span></pre> <p>is invalid because we're returning a string from a function that should return a <code>u32</code>, and the compiler will helpfully diagnose the problem as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">error[E0308]: mismatched types --&gt; src/main.rs:1:37 | 1 | my_macro::make_pub!(static X: u32 = &quot;foo&quot;); | ^^^^^ expected u32, found reference | = note: expected type `u32` found type `&amp;&#39;static str` error: aborting due to previous error </span></pre> <p>And we can see here that although we're generating brand new syntax, the compiler can preserve span information to continue to provide targeted diagnostics about code that we've written.</p> <h3 id="procedural-macros-in-the-wild">Procedural Macros in the Wild</h3> <p>Ok up to this point we've got a pretty good idea about what procedural macros can do and the various capabilities they have in the 2018 edition. As such a long-awaited feature, the ecosystem is already making use of these new capabilities! If you're interested, some projects to keep your eyes on are:</p> <ul> <li> <p><a href="https://crates.io/crates/syn"><code>syn</code></a>, <a href="https://docs.rs/quote/0.6/quote/"><code>quote</code></a>, and <a href="https://docs.rs/proc-macro2/0.4/proc_macro2/"><code>proc-macro2</code></a> are your go-to libraries for writing procedural macros. They make it easy to define custom parsers, parse existing syntax, create new syntax, work with older versions of Rust, and much more!</p> </li> <li> <p><a href="https://serde.rs">Serde</a> and its derive macros for <code>Serialize</code> and <code>Deserialize</code> are likely the most used macros in the ecosystem. They sport an <a href="https://serde.rs/attributes.html">impressive amount of configuration</a> and are a great example of how small annotations can be so powerful.</p> </li> <li> <p>The <a href="https://github.com/rustwasm/wasm-bindgen"><code>wasm-bindgen</code> project</a> uses attribute macros to easily define interfaces in Rust and import interfaces from JS. The <code>#[wasm_bindgen]</code> lightweight annotation makes it easy to understand what's coming in and out, as well as removing lots of conversion boilerplate.</p> </li> <li> <p>The <a href="https://gitlab.gnome.org/federico/gnome-class"><code>gobject_gen!</code> macro</a> is an experimental IDL for the GNOME project to define GObject objects safely in Rust, eschewing manually writing all the glue necessary to talk to C and interface with other GObject instances in Rust.</p> </li> <li> <p>The <a href="https://rocket.rs/">Rocket framework</a> has recently switched over to procedural macros, and showcases some of nightly-only features of procedural macros like custom diagnostics, custom span creation, and more. Expect to see these features stabilize in 2019!</p> </li> </ul> <p>That's just a <em>taste</em> of the power of procedural macros and some example usage throughout the ecosystem today. We're only 6 weeks out from the original release of procedural macros on stable, so we've surely only scratched the surface as well! I'm really excited to see where we can take Rust with procedural macros by empowering all kinds of lightweight additions and extensions to the language!</p> Announcing Rust 1.31.1 Thu, 20 Dec 2018 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-31-1/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-31-1/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce a new version of Rust, 1.31.1. Rust is a systems programming language focused on safety, speed, and concurrency.</p> <p>If you have a previous version of Rust installed via rustup, getting Rust 1.31.1 is as easy as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">rustup update stable </span></pre> <p>If you don't have it already, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">get <code>rustup</code></a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1311-2018-12-20">detailed release notes for 1.31.1</a> on GitHub.</p> <h2 id="what-s-in-1-31-1-stable">What's in 1.31.1 stable</h2> <p>This patch release fixes a build failure on <code>powerpc-unknown-netbsd</code> by way of <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/56562">an update to the <code>libc</code> crate</a> used by the compiler.</p> <p>Additionally, the Rust Language Server was updated to fix two critical bugs. First, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rls/pull/1170">hovering over the type with documentation above single-line attributes led to 100% CPU usage:</a></p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#999999;">/// Some documentation </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">#[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">derive</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(Debug)] </span><span style="color:#999999;">// Multiple, single-line </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">#[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">allow</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(missing_docs)] </span><span style="color:#999999;">// attributes </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">pub struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">MyStruct { </span><span style="color:#999999;">/* ... */ </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rls/pull/1171">Go to definition was fixed for std types</a>: Before, using the RLS on <code>HashMap</code>, for example, tried to open this file</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">~/.rustup/toolchains/stable-x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/lib/rustlib/src/rust/libstd/collections/hash/map.rs </span></pre> <p>and now RLS goes to the correct location (for Rust 1.31, note the extra <code>src</code>):</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">~/.rustup/toolchains/stable-x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/lib/rustlib/src/rust/src/libstd/collections/hash/map.rs </span></pre> Tools in the 2018 edition Mon, 17 Dec 2018 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-2018-dev-tools/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-2018-dev-tools/ <p>Tooling is an important part of what makes a programming language practical and productive. Rust has always had some great tools (Cargo in particular has a well-deserved reputation as a best-in-class package manager and build tool), and the 2018 edition includes more tools which we hope further improve Rust users' experience.</p> <p>In this blog post I'll cover Clippy and Rustfmt – two tools that have been around for a few years and are now stable and ready for general use. I'll also cover IDE support – a key workflow for many users which is now much better supported. I'll start by talking about Rustfix, a new tool which was central to our edition migration plans.</p> <h2 id="rustfix">Rustfix</h2> <p>Rustfix is a tool for automatically making changes to Rust code. It is a key part of our migration story for the 2018 edition, making the transition from 2015 to 2018 editions much easier, and in many cases completely automatic. This is essential, since without such a tool we'd be much more limited in the kinds of breaking changes users would accept.</p> <p>A simple example:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">trait </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Foo { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">foo</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); } </span></pre> <p>The above is legal in Rust 2015, but not in Rust 2018 (method arguments must be made explicit). Rustfix changes the above code to:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">trait </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Foo { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">foo</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">_</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); } </span></pre> <p>For detailed information on how to use Rustfix, see <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/edition-guide/editions/transitioning-an-existing-project-to-a-new-edition.html">these instructions</a>. To transition your code from the 2015 to 2018 edition, run <code>cargo fix --edition</code>.</p> <p>Rustfix can do a lot, but it is not perfect. When it can't fix your code, it will emit a warning informing you that you need to fix it manually. We're continuing to work to improve things.</p> <p>Rustfix works by automatically applying suggestions from the compiler. When we add or improve the compiler's suggestion for fixing an error or warning, then that improves Rustfix. We use the same information in an IDE to give quick fixes (such as automatically adding imports).</p> <p>Thank you to Pascal Hertleif (killercup), Oliver Scherer (oli-obk), Alex Crichton, Zack Davis, and Eric Huss for developing Rustfix and the compiler lints which it uses.</p> <h2 id="clippy">Clippy</h2> <p>Clippy is a linter for Rust. It has numerous (currently 290!) lints to help improve the correctness, performance and style of your programs. Each lint can be turned on or off (<code>allow</code>), and configured as either an error (<code>deny</code>) or warning (<code>warn</code>).</p> <p>An example: the <a href="https://rust-lang.github.io/rust-clippy/master/index.html#iter_next_loop"><code>iter_next_loop</code></a> lint checks that you haven't made an error by iterating on the result of <code>next</code> rather than the object you're calling <code>next</code> on (this is an easy mistake to make when changing a <code>while let</code> loop to a <code>for</code> loop).</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">for</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">in</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> y.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">next</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#999999;">// ... </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p>will give the error</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">error: you are iterating over `Iterator::next()` which is an Option; this will compile but is probably not what you want --&gt; src/main.rs:4:14 | 4 | for x in y.next() { | ^^^^^^^^ | = note: #[deny(clippy::iter_next_loop)] on by default = help: for further information visit https://rust-lang.github.io/rust-clippy/master/index.html#iter_next_loop </span></pre> <p>Clippy works by extending the Rust compiler. The compiler has support for a few built-in lints, Clippy uses the same mechanisms but with lots more lints. That means Clippy's error/warning format should be familiar, you should be able to apply Clippy's suggestions in your IDE (or using Rustfix), and that the lints are reliable and accurate.</p> <p>With Rust 1.31 and the 2018 edition, Clippy is available on stable Rust and has backwards compatibility guarantees (if it had a version number, it would be 1.0). Clippy has the same stability guarantees as rustc: new lints may be added, and lints may be modified to add more functionality, however lints may never be removed (only deprecated). This means that code that compiles with Clippy will continue to compile with Clippy (provided there are no lints set to error via <code>deny</code>), but may throw new warnings.</p> <p>Clippy can be installed using <code>rustup component add clippy</code>, then use it with <code>cargo clippy</code>. For more information, including how to run it in your CI, see <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-clippy/">the repo readme</a>.</p> <p>Thank you Clippy team (Pascal Hertleif (killercup), Oliver Scherer (oli-obk), Manish Goregaokar (manishearth), and Andre Bogus (llogiq))!</p> <h2 id="rustfmt">Rustfmt</h2> <p>Rustfmt is a tool for formatting your source code. It takes arbitrary, messy code and turns it into neat, beautifully styled code.</p> <p>Automatically formatting saves you time and mental energy. You don't need to worry about style as you code. If you use Rustfmt in your CI (<code>cargo fmt --check</code>), then you don't need to worry about code style in review. By using a standard style you make your project feel more familiar for new contributors and spare yourself arguments about code style. Rust's <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/style-guide/README.md">standard code style</a> is the Rustfmt default, but if you must, then you can customize Rustfmt extensively.</p> <p>Rustfmt 1.0 is part of the 2018 edition release. It should work on all code and will be backwards compatible until the 2.0 release. By backwards compatible we mean that if your code is formatted (i.e., excluding bugs which prevent any formatting or code which does not compile), it will always be formatted in the same way. This guarantee only applies if you use the default formatting options.</p> <p>Rustfmt is not done. Formatting is not perfect, in particular we don't touch comments and string literals and we are pretty limited with macro definitions and some macro uses. We're likely to improve formatting here, but you will need to opt-in to these changes until there is a 2.0 release. We <em>are</em> planning on having a 2.0 release. Unlike Rust itself, we think its a good idea to have a breaking release of Rustfmt and expect that to happen some time in late 2019.</p> <p>To install Rustfmt, use <code>rustup component add rustfmt</code>. To format your project, use <code>cargo fmt</code>. You can also format individual files using <code>rustfmt</code> (though note that by default rustfmt will format nested modules). You can also use Rustfmt in your editor or IDE using the RLS (see below; no need to install rustfmt for this, it comes as part of the RLS). We recommend configuring your editor to run rustfmt on save. Not having to think about formatting at all as you type is a pleasant change.</p> <p>Thank you Seiichi Uchida (topecongiro), Marcus Klaas, and all the Rustfmt contributors!</p> <h2 id="ide-support">IDE support</h2> <p>For many users, their IDE is the most important tool. Rust IDE support has been in the works for a while and is a highly demanded feature. Rust is now supported in many IDEs and editors: <a href="https://plugins.jetbrains.com/plugin/8182-rust">IntelliJ</a>, <a href="https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=rust-lang.rust">Visual Studio Code</a>, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/atom-ide-rust">Atom</a>, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-enhanced">Sublime Text</a>, <a href="https://www.eclipse.org/downloads/packages/release/photon/r/eclipse-ide-rust-developers-includes-incubating-components">Eclipse</a> (and more...). Follow each link for installation instructions.</p> <p>Editor support is powered in two different ways: IntelliJ uses its own compiler, the other editors use the Rust compiler via the Rust Language Server (RLS). Both approaches give a good but imperfect IDE experience. You should probably choose based on which editor you prefer (although if your project does not use Cargo, then you won't be able to use the RLS).</p> <p>All these editors come with support for standard IDE functions including 'go to definition', 'find all references', code completion, renaming, and reformatting.</p> <p>The RLS has been developed by the Rust dev tools team, it is a bid to bring Rust support to as many IDEs and editors as possible. It directly uses Cargo and the Rust compiler to provide accurate information about a program. Due to performance constraints, code completion is not yet powered by the compiler and therefore can be a bit more hit and miss than other features.</p> <p>Thanks to the IDEs and editors team for work on the RLS and the various IDEs and extensions (alexheretic, autozimu, jasonwilliams, LucasBullen, matklad, vlad20012, Xanewok), Jonathan Turner for helping start off the RLS, and phildawes, kngwyu, jwilm, and the other Racer contributors for their work on Racer (the code completion component of the RLS)!</p> <h2 id="the-future">The future</h2> <p>We're not done yet! There's lots more we think we can do in the tools domain over the next year or so.</p> <p>We've been improving rust debugging support in LLDB and GDB and there is more in the works. We're experimenting with distributing our own versions with Rustup and making debugging from your IDE easier and more powerful.</p> <p>We hope to make the RLS faster, more stable, and more accurate; including using the compiler for code completion.</p> <p>We want to make Cargo a lot more powerful: Cargo will handle compiled binaries as well as source code, which will make building and installing crates faster. We will support better integration with other build systems (which in turn will enable using the RLS with more projects). We'll add commands for adding and upgrading dependencies, and to help with security audits.</p> <p>Rustdoc will see improvements to its source view (powered by the RLS) and links between documentation for different crates.</p> <p>There's always lots of interesting things to work on. If you'd like to help chat to us on GitHub or <a href="https://discordapp.com/invite/rust-lang">Discord</a>.</p> A call for Rust 2019 Roadmap blog posts Thu, 06 Dec 2018 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/call-for-rust-2019-roadmap-blogposts/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/call-for-rust-2019-roadmap-blogposts/ <p>It's almost 2019! As such, the Rust team needs to create a roadmap for Rust's development next year. At the highest level, Rust's development process looks like this:</p> <ol> <li>The Rust community blogs about what they'd like to see.</li> <li>The core team reads these posts, and produces a &quot;roadmap RFC,&quot; a proposal for what next year's development looks like.</li> <li>The RFC is widely discussed, and modified in response to feedback, and eventually accepted.</li> <li>This RFC becomes a guideline for accepting or postponing RFCs for the next year.</li> </ol> <p>We try to align this with the calendar year, but it doesn't 100% match up, currently. Last year, <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/01/03/new-years-rust-a-call-for-community-blogposts.html">we had a call for posts on January 3</a>, the roadmap RFC was opened <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/2314">on Jan 29th</a>, and was <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/2314#issuecomment-370576889">accepted on March 5th</a>. This year, we're starting a bit earlier, but it's still not going to be accepted before January 1.</p> <h2 id="we-need-you">We need you</h2> <p>Starting today and running until of January 15, we’d like to ask the community to write blogposts reflecting on Rust in 2018 and proposing goals and directions for Rust in 2019. Like last year, these can take many forms:</p> <ul> <li>A post on your personal or company blog</li> <li>A Medium post</li> <li>A GitHub gist</li> <li>Or any other online writing platform you prefer.</li> </ul> <p>We’re looking for posts on many topics:</p> <ul> <li>Ideas for community programs</li> <li>Language features</li> <li>Documentation improvements</li> <li>Ecosystem needs</li> <li>Tooling enhancements</li> <li>Or anything else Rust related you hope for in 2019</li> </ul> <p>There's one additional thing this year, however. With the shipping of Rust 2018 today, it's time to think about the next edition. In other words:</p> <ul> <li>Rust 2015: Stability</li> <li>Rust 2018: Productivity</li> <li>Rust 2021: ?</li> </ul> <p>We aren't yet <em>committing</em> to an edition in 2021, but that's the current estimate. Each edition has had some sort of theme associated with it. As such, we wouldn't just like to know what you're thinking for Rust in 2019, but also, what you want the theme of Rust 2021 to be. Ideally, suggestions for Rust in 2019 will fit into the overall goal of the next edition, though of course, three years is a lot of time, and so not every single thing must. As Rust matures, we need to start thinking of ever-longer horizons, and how our current plans fit into those eventual plans.</p> <p>If you're not sure what to write, check out all of the blog posts from last year <a href="https://readrust.net/rust-2018/">over at ReadRust</a>. They may give you some inspiration!</p> <h2 id="please-share-these-posts-with-us">Please share these posts with us</h2> <p>You can write up these posts and email them to <code>community@rust-lang.org</code> or tweet them with the hashtag <code>#rust2019</code>.</p> <p>The Core team will be reading all of the submitted posts and using them to inform the initial roadmap RFC for 2019. Once the RFC is submitted, we’ll open up the normal RFC process, though if you want, you are welcome to write a post and link to it on the GitHub discussion.</p> <p>We look forward to working with the entire community to make Rust even more wonderful in 2019. Thanks for an awesome 2018!</p> Announcing Rust 1.31 and Rust 2018 Thu, 06 Dec 2018 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-31-and-rust-2018/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-31-and-rust-2018/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce a new version of Rust, 1.31.0, and &quot;Rust 2018&quot; as well. Rust is a programming language that empowers everyone to build reliable and efficient software.</p> <p>If you have a previous version of Rust installed via rustup, getting Rust 1.31.0 is as easy as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">rustup</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> update stable </span></pre> <p>If you don't have it already, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/tools/install">get <code>rustup</code></a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1310-2018-12-06">detailed release notes for 1.31.0</a> on GitHub.</p> <h2 id="what-s-in-1-31-0-stable">What's in 1.31.0 stable</h2> <p>Rust 1.31 may be the most exciting release since Rust 1.0! Included in this release is the first iteration of &quot;Rust 2018,&quot; but there's more than just that! This is going to be a long post, so here's a table of contents:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-31-and-rust-2018/#rust-2018">Rust 2018</a> <ul> <li><a href="https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-31-and-rust-2018/#non-lexical-lifetimes">Non-lexical lifetimes</a></li> <li><a href="https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-31-and-rust-2018/#module-system-changes">Module system changes</a></li> </ul> </li> <li><a href="https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-31-and-rust-2018/#more-lifetime-elision-rules">More lifetime elision rules</a></li> <li><a href="https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-31-and-rust-2018/#const-fn"><code>const fn</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-31-and-rust-2018/#new-tools">New tools</a></li> <li><a href="https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-31-and-rust-2018/#tool-lints">Tool Lints</a></li> <li><a href="https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-31-and-rust-2018/#documentation">Documentation</a></li> <li><a href="https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-31-and-rust-2018/#domain-working-groups">Domain working groups</a></li> <li><a href="https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-31-and-rust-2018/#new-website">New website</a></li> <li><a href="https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-31-and-rust-2018/#library-stabilizations">Library stabilizations</a></li> <li><a href="https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-31-and-rust-2018/#cargo-features">Cargo features</a></li> <li><a href="https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-31-and-rust-2018/#contributors-to-131.0">Contributors</a></li> </ul> <h3 id="rust-2018">Rust 2018</h3> <p>We wrote about Rust 2018 <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/03/12/roadmap.html">first in March</a>, <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/07/27/what-is-rust-2018.html">and then in July</a>. For some more background about the <em>why</em> of Rust 2018, please go read those posts; there's a lot to cover in the release announcement, and so we're going to focus on the <em>what</em> here. There's also a <a href="https://hacks.mozilla.org/2018/12/rust-2018-is-here/">post on Mozilla Hacks</a> as well!</p> <p>Briefly, Rust 2018 is an opportunity to bring all of the work we've been doing over the past three years together, and create a cohesive package. This is more than just language features, it also includes</p> <ul> <li>Tooling (IDE support, <code>rustfmt</code>, Clippy)</li> <li>Documentation</li> <li>Domain working groups work</li> <li>A new web site</li> </ul> <p>We'll be covering all of this and more in this post.</p> <p>Let's create a new project with Cargo:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">cargo new foo </span></pre> <p>Here's the contents of <code>Cargo.toml</code>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">package</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#c82829;">name </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;foo&quot; </span><span style="color:#c82829;">version </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;0.1.0&quot; </span><span style="color:#c82829;">authors </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= [</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;Your Name &lt;you@example.com&gt;&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#c82829;">edition </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;2018&quot; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">dependencies</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span></pre> <p>A new key has been added under <code>[package]</code>: <code>edition</code>. Note that it has been set to <code>2018</code>. You can also set it to <code>2015</code>, which is the default if the key does not exist.</p> <p>By using Rust 2018, some new features are unlocked that are not allowed in Rust 2015.</p> <p>It is important to note that each package can be in either 2015 or 2018 mode, and they work seamlessly together. Your 2018 project can use 2015 dependencies, and a 2015 project can use 2018 dependencies. This ensures that we don't split the ecosystem, and all of these new things are opt-in, preserving compatibility for existing code. Furthermore, when you do choose to migrate Rust 2015 code to Rust 2018, the changes can be made automatically, via <code>cargo fix</code>.</p> <p>What kind of new features, you may ask? Well, first, features get added to Rust 2015 unless they require some sort of incompatibility with 2015's features. As such, most of the language is available everywhere. You can check out <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/edition-guide">the edition guide</a> to check each feature's minimum <code>rustc</code> version as well as edition requirements. However, there are a few big-ticket features we'd like to mention here: non-lexical lifetimes, and some module system improvements.</p> <h4 id="non-lexical-lifetimes">Non-lexical lifetimes</h4> <p>If you've been following Rust's development over the past few years, you may have heard the term &quot;NLL&quot; or &quot;non-lexical lifetimes&quot; thrown around. This is jargon, but it has a straightforward translation into simpler terms: the borrow checker has gotten smarter, and now accepts some valid code that it previously rejected. Consider this example:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">5</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> y </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= &amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">x; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> z </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= &amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> x; } </span></pre> <p>In older Rust, this is a compile-time error:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">error[E0502]: cannot borrow `x` as mutable because it is also borrowed as immutable --&gt; src/main.rs:5:18 | 4 | let y = &amp;x; | - immutable borrow occurs here 5 | let z = &amp;mut x; | ^ mutable borrow occurs here 6 | } | - immutable borrow ends here </span></pre> <p>This is because lifetimes follow &quot;lexical scope&quot;; that is, the borrow from <code>y</code> is considered to be held until <code>y</code> goes out of scope at the end of main, even though we never use <code>y</code> again. This code is fine, but the borrow checker could not handle it.</p> <p>Today, this code will compile just fine.</p> <p>What if we did use <code>y</code>, like this for example:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">5</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> y </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= &amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">x; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> z </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= &amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> x;
