Over time, as our suggestions improve, we'll be expanding this to automatically fix more warnings.</p> <p>if you find a compiler suggestion and want to help make it fixable, please leave a comment on <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/50723">this issue</a>.</p> <h3 id="cargo-clippy"><code>cargo clippy</code></h3> <p>Speaking of warnings, you can now check out a preview of <code>cargo clippy</code> through Rustup. Clippy is a large number of additional warnings that you can run against your Rust code.</p> <p>For example:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">let mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> lock_guard </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> mutex.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">lock</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(); std::mem::drop(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">lock_guard) </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">operation_that_requires_mutex_to_be_unlocked</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(); </span></pre> <p>This code is syntactically correct, but may have a deadlock! You see, we dropped <em>a reference to <code>lock_guard</code></em>, not the guard itself. Dropping a reference is a no-op, and so this is almost certainly a bug.</p> <p>We can get the preview of Clippy from Rustup:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">rustup component add clippy-preview </span></pre> <p>and then run it:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">cargo clippy error: calls to `std::mem::drop` with a reference instead of an owned value. Dropping a reference does nothing. --&gt; src\main.rs:5:5 | 5 | std::mem::drop(&amp;lock_guard); | ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ | = note: #[deny(drop_ref)] on by default note: argument has type &amp;std::result::Result&lt;std::sync::MutexGuard&lt;&#39;_, i32&gt;, std::sync::PoisonError&lt;std::sync::MutexGuard&lt;&#39;_, i32&gt;&gt;&gt; --&gt; src\main.rs:5:20 | 5 | std::mem::drop(&amp;lock_guard); | ^^^^^^^^^^^ = help: for further information visit https://rust-lang-nursery.github.io/rust-clippy/v0.0.212/index.html#drop_ref </span></pre> <p>As you can see from that help message, you can view all of the lints that clippy offers on the web.</p> <p>Please note that this is a preview; clippy has not yet reached 1.0. As such, its lints may change. We'll release a <code>clippy</code> component once it has stabilized; please give the preview a try and let us know how it goes.</p> <p>Oh, and one more thing: <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rustfix/issues/130">you can't use clippy with <code>cargo-fix</code> yet, really</a>. It's in the works!</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1290-2018-09-13">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h3 id="library-stabilizations">Library stabilizations</h3> <p>Three APIs were stabilized this release:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/sync/struct.Arc.html#method.downcast"><code>Arc&lt;T&gt;::downcast</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/rc/struct.Rc.html#method.downcast"><code>Rc&lt;T&gt;::downcast</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/iter/trait.Iterator.html#method.flatten"><code>Iterator::flatten</code></a></li> </ul> <p>Additionally, you can <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/51178/">now compare <code>&amp;str</code> and <code>OsString</code></a>.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1290-2018-09-13">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h3 id="cargo-features">Cargo features</h3> <p>We covered the two new subcommands to Cargo above, but additionally, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/5831/">Cargo will now try to fix up lockfiles that have been corrupted by a <code>git merge</code></a>. You can pass <code>--locked</code> to disable this behavior.</p> <p><code>cargo doc</code> has also grown a new flag: <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/5543"><code>--document-private-items</code></a>. By default, <code>cargo doc</code> only documents public things, as the docs it produces are intended for end-users. But if you're working on your own crate, and you have internal documentation for yourself to refer to, <code>--document-private-items</code> will generate docs for all items, not just public ones.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1290-2018-09-13">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h2 id="contributors-to-1-29-0">Contributors to 1.29.0</h2> <p>Many people came together to create Rust 1.29. We couldn't have done it without all of you. <a href="https://thanks.rust-lang.org/rust/1.29.0">Thanks!</a></p> Launching the 2018 State of Rust Survey Wed, 08 Aug 2018 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/2018-survey-launch/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/2018-survey-launch/ <p>It's that time again! Time for us to take a look at how the Rust project is doing, and what we should plan for the future. The Rust Community Team is pleased to announce our <a href="https://goo.gl/forms/jFydE7csObcl6vxr1">2018 State of Rust Survey</a>! Whether or not you use Rust today, we want to know your opinions. Your responses will help the project understand its strengths and weaknesses and establish development priorities for the future.</p> <p>Completing this survey should take about 10 to 15 minutes and is anonymous unless you choose to give us your contact information. We will be accepting submissions until September 8th, and we will write up our findings a month or so afterwards to <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org">blog.rust-lang.org</a>. You can see last year’s results <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/09/05/Rust-2017-Survey-Results.html">here</a>.</p> <p>This year, volunteers have also translated the survey into many languages! You can now take the survey in:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://goo.gl/forms/jFydE7csObcl6vxr1">English</a></li> <li><a href="https://wj.qq.com/s/2312110/5dff">Simplified Chinese</a></li> <li><a href="https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSc2854JNR01jBCIVKavaNrzTmMAwvjlnZzHpj7GdRXP47xyCw/viewform?hl=de">German</a></li> <li><a href="https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfMSIQ0ZrUcR_1VXXMMeb_e8U64Gv8hEJArXgpRjYdrlisjJg/viewform?hl=hi">Hindi</a></li> <li><a href="https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSckDoL8_WQ6RNlSzB1ueDaFPWbIcA5O-e-zSg1WZl-n77_TRw/viewform?hl=it">Italian</a></li> <li><a href="https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdRWKlvMzlXhM6x-4NN4jnJFvD2LjNrz3TyLivK0WpuRHW1Yg/viewform?hl=pt">Portuguese</a></li> <li><a href="https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSeYZQ27z-VDxsoYPie-uBVLEe6Hv6cIVJ1dAcx4hu1g3EVOeA/viewform?hl=ru">Russian</a></li> <li><a href="https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdq6-v8McXzfCuFqI6wNEi-kexvml_kMcqgmybfJzPa87UkiQ/viewform?hl=es">Spanish</a></li> <li><a href="https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScYMFnEzIUiomLhrRgxGsdv7pCx755h7HukqAp81e1L6B79EA/viewform?hl=sv">Swedish</a></li> <li><a href="https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfM-4aJATBiWrcV7xZLrE5DTNXwHF1QkBccQyVCB1e12qp0Qg/viewform?hl=vn">Vietnamese</a></li> </ul> <p>(If you speak multiple languages, please pick one)</p> <p>Please help us spread the word by sharing the survey link on your social network feeds, at meetups, around your office, and in other communities.</p> <p>If you have any questions, please see our <a href="https://github.com/rust-community/team/wiki/State-of-the-Rust-Language-Community-Survey-FAQ">frequently asked questions</a> or email the Rust Community team at <a href="mailto:community-team@rust-lang.org">community-team@rust-lang.org</a>.</p> <p>Finally, we wanted to thank everyone who helped develop, polish, and test the survey!</p> Announcing Rust 1.28 Thu, 02 Aug 2018 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-28/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-28/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce a new version of Rust, 1.28.0. Rust is a systems programming language focused on safety, speed, and concurrency.</p> <p>If you have a previous version of Rust installed via rustup, getting Rust 1.28.0 is as easy as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">rustup</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> update stable </span></pre> <p>If you don't have it already, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">get <code>rustup</code></a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1280-2018-08-02">detailed release notes for 1.28.0</a> on GitHub.</p> <h2 id="what-s-in-1-28-0-stable">What's in 1.28.0 stable</h2> <h3 id="global-allocators">Global Allocators</h3> <p>Allocators are the way that programs in Rust obtain memory from the system at runtime. Previously, Rust did not allow changing the way memory is obtained, which prevented some use cases. On some platforms, this meant using jemalloc, on others, the system allocator, but there was no way for users to control this key component. With 1.28.0, the <code>#[global_allocator]</code> attribute is now stable, which allows Rust programs to set their allocator to the system allocator, as well as define new allocators by implementing the <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/std/alloc/trait.GlobalAlloc.html"><code>GlobalAlloc</code></a> trait.</p> <p>The default allocator for Rust programs on some platforms is jemalloc. The standard library now provides a handle to the system allocator, which can be used to switch to the system allocator when desired, by declaring a static and marking it with the <code>#[global_allocator]</code> attribute.</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">use </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">std::alloc::System; #[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">global_allocator</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">static </span><span style="color:#666969;">GLOBAL</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: System </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> System; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> v </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Vec</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">::new(); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// This will allocate memory using the system allocator. </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> v.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">push</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); } </span></pre> <p>However, sometimes you want to define a custom allocator for a given application domain. This is also relatively easy to do by implementing the <code>GlobalAlloc</code> trait. You can read more about how to do this in the <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/std/alloc/trait.GlobalAlloc.html">documentation</a>.</p> <h3 id="improved-error-message-for-formatting">Improved error message for formatting</h3> <p>Work on diagnostics continues, this time with an emphasis on formatting:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">format!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#666969;">{_foo}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, _foo </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">6</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">usize</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); </span></pre> <p>Previously, the error message emitted here was relatively poor:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">error: invalid format string: expected `&#39;}&#39;`, found `&#39;_&#39;` | 2 | format!(&quot;{_foo}&quot;, _foo = 6usize); | ^^^^^^^^ </span></pre> <p>Now, we emit a diagnostic that tells you the specific reason the format string is invalid:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">error: invalid format string: invalid argument name `_foo` | 2 | let _ = format!(&quot;{_foo}&quot;, _foo = 6usize); | ^^^^ invalid argument name in format string | = note: argument names cannot start with an underscore </span></pre> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1280-2018-08-02">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h3 id="library-stabilizations">Library stabilizations</h3> <p>We've already mentioned the stabilization of the <code>GlobalAlloc</code> trait, but another important stabilization is the <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/std/num/index.html"><code>NonZero</code></a> number types. These are wrappers around the standard unsigned integer types: <code>NonZeroU8</code>, <code>NonZeroU16</code>, <code>NonZeroU32</code>, <code>NonZeroU64</code>, <code>NonZeroU128</code>, and <code>NonZeroUsize</code>.</p> <p>This allows for size optimization, for example, <code>Option&lt;u8&gt;</code> is two bytes large, but <code>Option&lt;NonZeroU8&gt;</code> is just one byte large. Note that this optimization remains even when <code>NonZeroU8</code> is wrapped inside another struct; the example below illustrates that <code>Door</code> is still 1 byte large despite being placed inside an <code>Option</code>. This optimization applies to user-defined enums as well: <code>Option</code> is not special.</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">use </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">std::mem; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">use </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">std::num::NonZeroU8; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Key(NonZeroU8); </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Door { </span><span style="color:#c82829;">key</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: Key, } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { assert_eq!(mem::size_of::&lt;Door&gt;(), </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); assert_eq!(mem::size_of::&lt;Option&lt;Door&gt;&gt;(), </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); } </span></pre> <p>A number of other libraries have also been stabilized: you can see the more <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1280-2018-08-02">detailed release notes</a> for full details.</p> <h3 id="cargo-features">Cargo features</h3> <p><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/5584/">Cargo will now no longer allow you to publish crates with build scripts that modify the <code>src</code> directory.</a> The <code>src</code> directory in a crate should be considered to be immutable.</p> <h2 id="contributors-to-1-28-0">Contributors to 1.28.0</h2> <p>Many people came together to create Rust 1.28. We couldn't have done it without all of you. <a href="https://thanks.rust-lang.org/rust/1.28.0">Thanks!</a></p> What is Rust 2018? Fri, 27 Jul 2018 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/what-is-rust-2018/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/what-is-rust-2018/ <p>Back in March, <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/03/12/roadmap.html">we announced</a> something new:</p> <blockquote> <p>This year, we will deliver Rust 2018, marking the first major new edition of Rust since 1.0 (aka Rust 2015).</p> <p>We will continue to publish releases every six weeks as usual. But we will designate a release in the latter third of the year (Rust 1.29 - 1.31) as Rust 2018. This new 'edition' of Rust will be the culmination of feature stabilization throughout the year, and will ship with polished documentation, tooling, and libraries that tie in to those features.</p> </blockquote> <p>Now that some time has passed, we wanted to share more about what this actually <em>means</em> for Rust and Rust developers.</p> <h2 id="language-change-over-time">Language change over time</h2> <p>One of the key questions facing language developers is &quot;how do you manage change over time&quot;? How does that work for your users? We believe quite strongly that language stability is of utmost importance. A language is the foundation that you build your application on top of, and you cannot build reliable, long-living things on a foundation of sand. The very second post on our blog, way back in October of 2014, was &quot;<a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/10/30/Stability.html">Stability as a</a> <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/10/30/Stability.html">Deliverable</a>&quot;. This laid out our plans for the six week release schedule that we still follow to this day. It also described how stability was important:</p> <blockquote> <p>It’s important to be clear about what we mean by stable. We don’t mean that Rust will stop evolving. We will release new versions of Rust on a regular, frequent basis, and we hope that people will upgrade just as regularly. But for that to happen, those upgrades need to be painless.</p> </blockquote> <p>We put in a lot of work to make upgrades painless; for example, we run a tool (called &quot;crater&quot;) before each Rust release that downloads every package on crates.io and attempts to build their code and run their tests. We have a strong culture of testing, and we use tooling to ensure that every single pull request is tested on every platform. While we still believe that the six-week process is a fantastic <em>engineering</em> strategy, it has some flaws.</p> <h3 id="losing-the-big-picture">Losing the big picture</h3> <p>Increasing the number of releases means that each release is smaller. That's the point! From an engineering perspective, this is great. But from a user-facing perspective, it's harder to keep track of what's going on in Rust unless you pay close attention every six weeks. And for those of us who do pay such attention, it's easy to lose sight of the big picture. Rust has come a long way in the last three years! Finally, for people who have tried Rust and stopped using it for whatever reason, it's hard to know if the concerns have been addressed: they'd have to pay attention every six weeks, which is not something that is likely to happen.</p> <h3 id="tiny-but-necessary-changes">Tiny but necessary changes</h3> <p>Especially in a language with static types, almost any release can contain something that breaks someone's code. Rust's <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/1105-api-evolution.md">RFC</a> <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/1105-api-evolution.md">1105</a> lays out what kinds of changes we can make when incrementing a major, minor, or patch version of the language. However, the concept of &quot;2.0&quot; is extremely overloaded in the minds of developers. 2.0 is <em>major</em> breaking change. Time to throw everything out and start again. As such, we are very wary of releasing a Rust 2.0. There are some small changes that would be nice to make without needing to bump to 2.0, however. For example, the addition of a new keyword is a breaking change. But sometimes, new features require a new keyword to work properly. In many ways, Rust is about taking tradeoffs and bending the curve. Can we have our cake and eat it too?</p> <h2 id="what-is-rust-2018">What is Rust 2018?</h2> <p>The release of Rust 1.31.0 on December 6th will be the first release of &quot;Rust 2018.&quot; This marks a culmination of the last three years of Rust's development, and brings it together in one neat package. For example, there will be a 2018 edition of the book that incorporates features stabilized since the print edition was considered finalized.</p> <p>You'll be able to put <code>edition = '2018'</code> into your <code>Cargo.toml</code>, and <code>cargo new</code> will add it by default for new projects. At first, this will unlock some new features that are not possible without it, and eventually, it will enable some new lints that nudge you towards new idioms. You can also choose <code>'2015'</code>, and if you don't have an <code>edition</code> key at all, it will default to this value. These projects will continue on as before. We'll be shipping a tool, that helps you automatically upgrade your code to use these new features and idioms. Running <code>cargo fix</code> will get your code ready in an automated fashion.</p> <p>From one perspective, editions are mostly about that cohesive package: they're about celebrating what we've accomplished, and telling the world about it. From another, editions are a way for us to make &quot;breaking&quot; changes without breaking your code. For example, <code>try</code> will become a keyword in Rust 2018. We can't make that change in Rust 2015, as it may break code that uses it as a variable name. But since you opt-in to Rust 2018, we can. We can also turn some warnings into hard errors. But these changes are extremely limited; without getting too deep into the technical details, editions can only change surface-level features; the core of Rust is still the same.</p> <h2 id="managing-compatibility">Managing compatibility</h2> <p>It goes even further than that: these two universes are compatible with one another. We are quite sensitive to the issues in other language ecosystems, where new code and old code can't interoperate. Making sure that this worked well was a key aspect of the design of editions. In some sense, editions are following in the steps of Java and C++, two languages that are known for their stability stories.</p> <p>In short, the Rust compiler will know how to compile both editions of code. This is similar to how <code>javac</code> can compile both Java 9 and Java 10, or how <code>gcc</code> and <code>clang</code> support both C++14 and C++17. Additionally, each compiler will understand how to link both kinds of code together. This means that if you're using Rust 2018, you can use dependencies that use Rust 2015 with zero problems. If you're sticking with Rust 2015, you can use libraries that use Rust 2018. It all works together. This lets people who want to use new things start immediately, while others that want to take it slower can upgrade on their own time schedule.</p> <p>Beyond that, it’s also important to mention that this release will be the <em>initial</em> release of Rust 2018; in some sense, it’s the start, not the end. We haven’t formally committed to a schedule for editions, but it’s likely that the next one will be Rust 2021. We’ll continue to add features to Rust 2018 after its release, just like we continued to add features to Rust after the Rust 1.0 release.</p> <p>It’s also important to note that Rust 2015 is not frozen. Anything that does not <em>require</em> being a part of Rust 2018 will work on Rust 2015 as well. This is due to the way editions work; given the small nature of possible changes, the compiler uses the same internal representation for all editions.</p> <h2 id="a-few-words-on-long-term-support">A few words on long-term support</h2> <p>The Rust project currently only supports the most recent version of the stable compiler. Some have wondered if the concept of editions ties into some form of longer support. It does not, however, we've been talking about introducing some sort of LTS policy, and may do so in the future.</p> <h2 id="giving-it-a-try">Giving it a try</h2> <p>We'll be doing several preview releases of Rust 2018. The most adventurous Rust users are already giving it a try on nightly; once we get feedback from them and do some polishing, we'll announce a beta that’s ready for more wide usage for you to try here on the blog.</p> Announcing Rust 1.27.2 Fri, 20 Jul 2018 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-27-2/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-27-2/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce a new version of Rust, 1.27.2. Rust is a systems programming language focused on safety, speed, and concurrency.</p> <p>If you have a previous version of Rust installed via rustup, getting Rust 1.27.2 is as easy as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">rustup</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> update stable </span></pre> <p>If you don't have it already, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">get <code>rustup</code></a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/stable/RELEASES.md#version-1272-2018-07-20">detailed release notes for 1.27.2</a> on GitHub.</p> <h2 id="what-s-in-1-27-2-stable">What's in 1.27.2 stable</h2> <p>This patch release fixes a bug in the borrow checker verification of <code>match</code> expressions. This bug was introduced in 1.27.1 with a different bugfix for <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/05/10/Rust-1.26.html#nicer-match-bindings">match ergonomics</a>.</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">transmute_lifetime</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&lt;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">&#39;a</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">&#39;b</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, T&gt;(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">t</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">&#39;a </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">T</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">,)) -&gt; </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">&#39;b</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> T { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">match </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">t, ()) { ((t,), ()) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> t, } } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> y </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Box</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">::new((</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">42</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">,)); </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">transmute_lifetime</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">y) }; println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, x); } </span></pre> <p>1.27.2 will reject the above code.</p> <h2 id="concern-over-numerous-patches-to-the-match-ergonomics-feature">Concern over numerous patches to the match ergonomics feature</h2> <p>Users have expressed concern with the frequency of patch releases to fix bugs in the match ergonomics verification by the current borrow checker on a variety of Rust's forums. There are two primary reasons for the increased rate of patch releases: significantly higher bandwidth and the age of the currently used borrow checker.</p> <p>With the formation of the Release team, Rust's ability to generate patch releases has greatly increased. This means that the investment from the compiler and core teams required to make a patch release is greatly reduced, which also makes such a patch release more likely to happen.</p> <p>The current borrow checker has been around for years now, and is beginning to show its age. The work on a better, more precise borrow checker is underway, and it has detected all of these bugs. This work is planned to be stabilized in the next few releases, so expect to hear more about it soon.</p> <p>Together, the lack of good maintenance on the current borrow checker and an increased capacity for releases make it feasible for us to ship patch releases on a more rapid and frequent basis.</p> Announcing Rust 1.27.1 Tue, 10 Jul 2018 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-27-1/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-27-1/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce a new version of Rust, 1.27.1. Rust is a systems programming language focused on safety, speed, and concurrency.</p> <p>If you have a previous version of Rust installed via rustup, getting Rust 1.27.1 is as easy as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">rustup update stable </span></pre> <p>If you don't have it already, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">get <code>rustup</code></a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/stable/RELEASES.md#version-1271-2018-07-10">detailed release notes for 1.27.1</a> on GitHub.</p> <h2 id="what-s-in-1-27-1-stable">What's in 1.27.1 stable</h2> <p>This patch release fixes a bug in the borrow checker verification of <code>match</code> expressions. This bug was introduced in 1.26.0 with the stabilization of <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/05/10/Rust-1.26.html#nicer-match-bindings">match ergonomics</a>. We are uncertain that this specific problem actually indicated unsoundness in the borrow checker, but suspected that it might be a possibility, so decided to issue a point release. The code sample below caused a panic inside the compiler prior to this patch.</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> a </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">vec![</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">to_string</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">()]; a.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">iter</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">().</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">enumerate</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() .</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">take_while</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(|(_, &amp;</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">t</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">)| </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">false</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) .collect::&lt;Vec&lt;</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">_</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&gt;&gt;(); } </span></pre> <p>1.27.1 will reject the above code with this error message:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">error[E0507]: cannot move out of borrowed content --&gt; src/main.rs:4:30 | 4 | .take_while(|(_, &amp;t)| false) | ^- | || | |hint: to prevent move, use `ref t` or `ref mut t` | cannot move out of borrowed content error: aborting due to previous error </span></pre> <p>Alongside the match ergonomics fix, a <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/07/06/security-advisory-for-rustdoc.html">security vulnerability</a> was also found in rustdoc, the standard documentation generator for Rust projects. That vulnerability is addressed by the second patch contained in this release, by removing the default search path for rustdoc plugins. This functionality will be entirely removed in Rust 1.28.0. This plugin infrastructure predates Rust 1.0 and has never been usable on stable, and has been unusable on nightly for many months. Expect to hear more about the removal in the next release: the current patch removes the default search path (instead, users must specify it explicitly), while the next release will remove the functionality entirely.</p> Security Advisory for rustdoc Fri, 06 Jul 2018 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/security-advisory-for-rustdoc/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/security-advisory-for-rustdoc/ <h2 id="quick-overview">Quick overview</h2> <p>The Rust team was recently notified of a security vulnerability affecting rustdoc plugins. If you are not using rustdoc plugins, you are not affected. We're not aware of any usage of this feature. The associated CVE is <a href="https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=%20CVE-2018-1000622">CVE-2018-1000622</a>.</p> <p>You can find the full announcement on our <code>rustlang-security-announcements</code> mailing list <a href="https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/rustlang-security-announcements/4ybxYLTtXuM">here</a>.</p> <h2 id="announcement">Announcement</h2> <p>On Tuesday July 3rd, Red Hat reported a security vulnerability in <code>rustdoc</code> to us. The problem was in rustdoc’s obscure plugin functionality, consisting of its loading plugins from a path that is globally writable on most platforms, <code>/tmp/rustdoc/plugins</code>. This feature permitted a malicious actor to write a dynamic library into this path and have another user execute that code. The security issue only happens if you're actively using the feature, and so this behavior will be removed from rustdoc in the near future, with patches landing for each channel over the next week. The plugin infrastructure predates 1.0 and is not usable on stable or nightly Rust today. Its removal should not impact any Rust users.</p> <p>As Rust’s first official CVE, this is somewhat of a milestone for us. The fix will be out in 1.27.1 on Tuesday July 10th. Because there's no embargo, we are filing for a CVE now, and will update this post with the number once we are assigned one.</p> <p>Despite the acknowledge low impact and severity of this bug, the Rust team decided to follow the full procedure we have for security bugs. We know of no one who uses this functionality, so we felt comfortable discussing it publicly ahead of the patch release. The impact is limited due to the plugin functionality being long deprecated and being unusable on all current versions of Rust, as the required library is not shipped to users. However, since the bug can potentially cause problems for users, we decided to include this in the 1.27.1 stable release.</p> <p>It’s worth noting that while Rust does prevent a lot of issues in your code at compile time, they’re issues that result from memory unsafety. This bug is a logic error. Rust code is not inherently secure, or bug-free. Sometimes, people get enthusiastic and make overly-broad claims about Rust, and this incident is a good demonstration of how Rust’s guarantees can’t prevent all bugs.</p> <p>Thank you to Red Hat for responsibly disclosing the problem and working with us to ensure that the fix we plan to ship is correct.</p> Announcing Rust 1.27 Thu, 21 Jun 2018 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-27/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-27/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce a new version of Rust, 1.27.0. Rust is a systems programming language focused on safety, speed, and concurrency.</p> <p>If you have a previous version of Rust installed via rustup, getting Rust 1.27.0 is as easy as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">rustup</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> update stable </span></pre> <p>If you don't have it already, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">get <code>rustup</code></a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1270-2018-06-21">detailed release notes for 1.27.0</a> on GitHub.</p> <p>Additionally, we would like to draw attention to something: just before the release of 1.27.0, we found <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/51686">a bug</a> in the 'default match bindings' feature introduced in 1.26.0 that can possibly introduce unsoundness. Since it was discovered very late in the release process, and has been present since 1.26.0, we decided to stick to our release train model. We expect to put out a 1.27.1 with that fix applied soon, and if there's demand, possibly a 1.26.3 as well. More information about the specifics here will come in that release announcement.</p> <h2 id="what-s-in-1-27-0-stable">What's in 1.27.0 stable</h2> <p>This release has two big language features that people have been waiting for. But first, a small comment on documentation: All books in <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/">the Rust Bookshelf</a> are <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/49623/">now searchable</a>! For example, here's <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/book/second-edition/?search=borrow">a search of &quot;The Rust Programming Language&quot; for 'borrow'</a>. This will hopefully make it much easier to find what you're looking for. Additionally, there's one new book: <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/49707/">the <code>rustc</code> Book</a>. This book explains how to use <code>rustc</code> directly, as well as some other useful information, like a list of all lints.</p> <h3 id="simd">SIMD</h3> <p>Okay, now for the big news: the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/49664/">basics of SIMD</a> are now available! SIMD stands for &quot;single instruction, multiple data.&quot; Consider a function like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">pub fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">foo</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">a</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u8</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">], </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">b</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u8</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">], </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">c</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> [</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u8</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">]) { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">for </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">((a, b), c) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">in</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> a.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">iter</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">().</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">zip</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(b).</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">zip</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(c) { </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">*</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">c </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= *</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">a </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ *</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">b; } } </span></pre> <p>Here, we're taking two slices, and adding the numbers together, placing the result in a third slice. The simplest possible way to do this would be to do exactly what the code does, and loop through each set of elements, add them together, and store it in the result. However, compilers can often do better. LLVM will often &quot;autovectorize&quot; code like this, which is a fancy term for &quot;use SIMD.&quot; Imagine that <code>a</code> and <code>b</code> were both 16 elements long. Each element is a <code>u8</code>, and so that means that each slice would be 128 bits of data. Using SIMD, we could put <em>both</em> <code>a</code> and <code>b</code> into 128 bit registers, add them together in a <code>*single*</code> instruction, and then copy the resulting 128 bits into <code>c</code>. That'd be much faster!</p> <p>While stable Rust has always been able to take advantage of autovectorization, sometimes, the compiler just isn't smart enough to realize that we can do something like this. Additionally, not every CPU has these features, and so LLVM may not use them so your program can be used on a wide variety of hardware. So, in Rust 1.27, the addition of <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/std/arch/">the <code>std::arch</code> module</a> allows us to use these kinds of instructions <em>directly</em>, which means we don't need to rely on a smart compiler. Additionally, it includes some features that allow us to choose a particular implementation based on various criteria. For example:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">#[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">cfg</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#c82829;">all</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">(</span><span style="color:#c82829;">any</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">(target_arch </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;x86&quot;</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">, target_arch </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;x86_64&quot;</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">), target_feature </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;avx2&quot;</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">)</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">)] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">foo</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { #[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">cfg</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(target_arch </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;x86&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">)] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">use </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">std::arch::x86::_mm256_add_epi64; #[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">cfg</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(target_arch </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;x86_64&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">)] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">use </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">std::arch::x86_64::_mm256_add_epi64; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">unsafe </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">_mm256_add_epi64</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">...</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); } } </span></pre> <p>Here, we use <code>cfg</code> flags to choose the correct version based on the machine we're targeting; on <code>x86</code> we use that version, and on <code>x86_64</code> we use its version. We can also choose at runtime:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">foo</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { #[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">cfg</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#c82829;">any</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">(target_arch </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;x86&quot;</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">, target_arch </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;x86_64&quot;</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">)</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">)] { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">if </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">is_x86_feature_detected!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;avx2&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">return unsafe </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">foo_avx2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() }; } } </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">foo_fallback</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(); } </span></pre> <p>Here, we have two versions of the function: one which uses <code>AVX2</code>, a specific kind of SIMD feature that lets you do 256-bit operations. The <code>is_x86_feature_detected!</code> macro will generate code that detects if your CPU supports AVX2, and if so, calls the <code>foo_avx2</code> function. If not, then we fall back to a non-AVX implementation, <code>foo_fallback</code>. This means that our code will run super fast on CPUs that support AVX2, but still work on ones that don't, albeit slower.</p> <p>If all of this seems a bit low-level and fiddly, well, it is! <code>std::arch</code> is specifically <em>primitives</em> for building these kinds of things. We hope to eventually stabilize a <code>std::simd</code> module with higher-level stuff in the future. But landing the basics now lets the ecosystem experiment with higher level libraries starting today. For example, check out the <a href="https://github.com/AdamNiederer/faster">faster</a> crate. Here's a code snippet with no SIMD:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> lots_of_3s </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">-</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">123.456</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">f32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">128</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">][</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">..</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">]).</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">iter</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() .</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">map</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(|</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">v</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">| { </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">9.0 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">*</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> v.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">abs</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">().</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">sqrt</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">().</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">sqrt</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">().</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">recip</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">().</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">ceil</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">().</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">sqrt</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">- </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">4.0 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">- </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2.0 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">}) .collect::&lt;Vec&lt;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">f32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&gt;&gt;(); </span></pre> <p>To use SIMD with this code via <code>faster</code>, you'd change it to this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> lots_of_3s </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">-</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">123.456</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">f32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">128</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">][</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">..</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">]).</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">simd_iter</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() .</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">simd_map</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">f32s</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0.0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">), |</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">v</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">| { </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">f32s</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">9.0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">*</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> v.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">abs</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">().</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">sqrt</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">().</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">rsqrt</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">().</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">ceil</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">().</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">sqrt</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">- </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">f32s</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">4.0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">- </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">f32s</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2.0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) }) .</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">scalar_collect</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(); </span></pre> <p>It looks almost the same: <code>simd_iter</code> instead of <code>iter</code>, <code>simd_map</code> instead of <code>map</code>, <code>f32s(2.0)</code> instead of <code>2.0</code>. But you get a SIMD-ified version generated for you.</p> <p>Beyond <em>that</em>, you may never write any of this yourself, but as always, the libraries you depend on may. For example, the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/regex/pull/456">regex crate has already added support</a>, and a new release will contain these SIMD speedups without you needing to do anything at all!</p> <h3 id="dyn-trait"><code>dyn Trait</code></h3> <p>Rust's trait object syntax is one that we ultimately regret. If you'll recall, given a trait <code>Foo</code>, this is a trait object:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Box&lt;Foo&gt; </span></pre> <p>However, if <code>Foo</code> were a struct, it'd just be a normal struct placed inside a <code>Box&lt;T&gt;</code>. When designing the language, we thought that the similarity here was a good thing, but experience has demonstrated that it is confusing. And it's not just for the <code>Box&lt;Trait&gt;</code> case; <code>impl SomeTrait for SomeOtherTrait</code> is also technically valid syntax, but you almost always want to write <code>impl&lt;T&gt; SomeTrait for T where T: SomeOtherTrait</code> instead. Same with <code>impl SomeTrait</code>, which looks like it would add methods or possibly default implementations but in fact adds inherent methods to a trait object. Finally, with the recent addition of <code>impl Trait</code> syntax, it's <code>impl Trait</code> vs <code>Trait</code> when explaining things, and so that feels like <code>Trait</code> is what you should use, given that it's shorter, but in reality, that's not always true.</p> <p>As such, in Rust 1.27, we have stabilized a new syntax, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/2113-dyn-trait-syntax.md"><code>dyn Trait</code></a>. A trait object now looks like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#999999;">// old =&gt; new </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Box&lt;Foo&gt; </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Box&lt;dyn Foo&gt; </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Foo </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; &amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">dyn Foo </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> Foo </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; &amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> dyn Foo </span></pre> <p>And similarly for other pointer types, <code>Arc&lt;Foo&gt;</code> is now <code>Arc&lt;dyn Foo&gt;</code>, etc. Due to backwards compatibility, we cannot remove the old syntax, but we have included a lint, which is set to allow by default, called <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/rustc/lints/listing/allowed-by-default.html#bare-trait-object"><code>bare-trait-object</code></a>. If you want to lint against the older syntax, you can turn it on. We thought that it would throw far too many warnings to turn on by default at present.</p> <blockquote> <p>Incidentally, we're working on a tool called <code>rustfix</code> that can automatically upgrade your code to newer idioms. It uses these sorts of lints to do so. Expect to hear more about <code>rustfix</code> in a future announcement.</p> </blockquote> <h3 id="must-use-on-functions"><code>#[must_use]</code> on functions</h3> <p>Finally, the <code>#[must_use]</code> attribute is getting an upgrade: <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/48925/">it can now be used on functions</a>.</p> <p>Previously, it only applied to types, like <code>Result&lt;T, E&gt;</code>. But now, you can do this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">#[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">must_use</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">double</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">x</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) -&gt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">*</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> x } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">double</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">4</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// warning: unused return value of `double` which must be used </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">_ = </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">double</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">4</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// (no warning) </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p>We've also <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/49533/">enhanced several bits of the standard library</a> to make use of this; <code>Clone::clone</code>, <code>Iterator::collect</code>, and <code>ToOwned::to_owned</code> will all start warning if you don't use their results, helping you notice expensive operations you may be throwing away by accident.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1270-2018-06-21">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h3 id="library-stabilizations">Library stabilizations</h3> <p>Several new APIs were stabilized this release:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/iter/trait.DoubleEndedIterator.html#method.rfind"><code>DoubleEndedIterator::rfind</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/iter/trait.DoubleEndedIterator.html#method.rfold"><code>DoubleEndedIterator::rfold</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/iter/trait.DoubleEndedIterator.html#method.try_rfold"><code>DoubleEndedIterator::try_rfold</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/time/struct.Duration.html#method.from_micros"><code>Duration::from_micros</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/time/struct.Duration.html#method.from_nanos"><code>Duration::from_nanos</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/time/struct.Duration.html#method.subsec_micros"><code>Duration::subsec_micros</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/time/struct.Duration.html#method.subsec_millis"><code>Duration::subsec_millis</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/collections/struct.HashMap.html#method.remove_entry"><code>HashMap::remove_entry</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/iter/trait.Iterator.html#method.try_fold"><code>Iterator::try_fold</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/iter/trait.Iterator.html#method.try_for_each"><code>Iterator::try_for_each</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/ptr/struct.NonNull.html#method.cast"><code>NonNull::cast</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/option/enum.Option.html#method.filter"><code>Option::filter</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/string/struct.String.html#method.replace_range"><code>String::replace_range</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/io/struct.Take.html#method.set_limit"><code>Take::set_limit</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/hint/fn.unreachable_unchecked.html"><code>hint::unreachable_unchecked</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/os/unix/process/fn.parent_id.html"><code>os::unix::process::parent_id</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/process/fn.id.html"><code>process::id</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/ptr/fn.swap_nonoverlapping.html"><code>ptr::swap_nonoverlapping</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.slice.html#method.rsplit_mut"><code>slice::rsplit_mut</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.slice.html#method.rsplit"><code>slice::rsplit</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.slice.html#method.swap_with_slice"><code>slice::swap_with_slice</code></a></li> </ul> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1270-2018-06-21">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h3 id="cargo-features">Cargo features</h3> <p>Cargo has two small upgrades this release. First, it now <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/5393/">takes a <code>--target-dir</code> flag</a> if you'd like to change the target directory for a given invocation.</p> <p>Additionally, a tweak to the way Cargo deals with targets has landed. Cargo will attempt to automatically discover tests, examples, and binaries within your project. However, sometimes explicit configuration is needed. But the initial implementation had a problem: let's say that you have two examples, and Cargo is discovering them both. You want to tweak one of them, and so you add a <code>[[example]]</code> to your <code>Cargo.toml</code> to configure its settings. Cargo currently sees that you've set one explicitly, and therefore, doesn't attempt to do any autodetection for the others. That's quite surprising.</p> <p>As such, we've <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/5335/">added several 'auto' keys to <code>Cargo.toml</code></a> We can't fix this behavior without possibly breaking projects that may have inadvertently been relying on it, and so, if you'd like to configure some targets, but not others, you can set the <code>autoexamples</code> key to <code>true</code> in the <code>[package]</code> section.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1270-2018-06-21">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h2 id="contributors-to-1-27-0">Contributors to 1.27.0</h2> <p>Many people came together to create Rust 1.27. We couldn't have done it without all of you. <a href="https://thanks.rust-lang.org/rust/1.27.0">Thanks!</a></p> Announcing Rust 1.26.2 Tue, 05 Jun 2018 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-26-2/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-26-2/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce a new version of Rust, 1.26.2. Rust is a systems programming language focused on safety, speed, and concurrency.</p> <p>If you have a previous version of Rust installed via rustup, getting Rust 1.26.2 is as easy as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">rustup</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> update stable </span></pre> <p>If you don't have it already, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">get <code>rustup</code></a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/stable/RELEASES.md#version-1262-2018-06-05">detailed release notes for 1.26.2</a> on GitHub.</p> <h2 id="what-s-in-1-26-2-stable">What's in 1.26.2 stable</h2> <p>This patch release fixes a bug in the borrow checker verification of <code>match</code> expressions. This bug was introduced in 1.26.0 with the stabilization of <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/05/10/Rust-1.26.html#nicer-match-bindings">match ergonomics</a>. Specifically, it permitted code which took two mutable borrows of the <code>bar</code> path at the same time.</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">let mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> foo </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Some</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;foo&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">to_string</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">()); </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> bar </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= &amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> foo; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">match</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> bar { </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Some</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(baz) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ bar.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">take</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// Should not be permitted, as baz has a unique reference to the bar pointer. </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">}, </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">None </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">unreachable!(), } </span></pre> <p>1.26.2 will reject the above code with this error message:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">error[E0499]: cannot borrow `*bar` as mutable more than once at a time --&gt; src/main.rs:6:9 | 5 | Some(baz) =&gt; { | --- first mutable borrow occurs here 6 | bar.take(); // Should not be permitted, as baz has a ... | ^^^ second mutable borrow occurs here ... 9 | } | - first borrow ends here error: aborting due to previous error </span></pre> <p>The Core team decided to issue a point release to minimize the window of time in which this bug in the Rust compiler was present in stable compilers.</p> Announcing Rust 1.26.1 Tue, 29 May 2018 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-26-1/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-26-1/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce a new version of Rust, 1.26.1. Rust is a systems programming language focused on safety, speed, and concurrency.</p> <p>If you have a previous version of Rust installed via rustup, getting Rust 1.26.1 is as easy as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">rustup</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> update stable </span></pre> <p>If you don't have it already, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">get <code>rustup</code></a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1261-2018-05-29">detailed release notes for 1.26.1</a> on GitHub.</p> <h2 id="what-s-in-1-26-1-stable">What's in 1.26.1 stable</h2> <p>A couple of issues were found in 1.26.0 which were deemed sufficient for a patch release.</p> <p>A quick summary of the changes:</p> <ul> <li>RLS no longer interferes with command line builds</li> <li>Rustfmt stopped badly formatting text in some cases</li> <li>Returning from main via <code>impl Trait</code> where the Trait is not <code>Termination</code> is no longer permitted</li> <li><code>::&lt;&gt;</code> (turbofish) no longer works for method arguments whose type is <code>impl Trait</code></li> <li><code>NaN &gt; NaN</code> no longer returns true in const contexts</li> <li>rustup should no longer fail due to missing documentation on some platforms</li> </ul> <p>If your code continues to compile, only the change to floating point comparisons may alter behavior.</p> <h3 id="rls-no-longer-interferes-with-command-line-builds">RLS no longer interferes with command line builds</h3> <p>The version of RLS shipped with 1.26.0 utilized the same target directory as Cargo from the command line, which meant that switching between the two would lead to everything being recompiled. This problem was made worse for Windows users due to a filesystem lock being left unreleased by either RLS or the compiler, leading to an increased error rate. This latter bug is not yet fixed, but it happens much less frequently with the first bug fixed.</p> <h3 id="rustfmt-bad-formatting">Rustfmt bad formatting</h3> <p>Previously, rustfmt would overindent multi-line string literals, which is now fixed.</p> <h3 id="returning-from-main-with-impl-trait-no-longer-works-when-trait-isn-t-termination">Returning from main with <code>impl Trait</code> no longer works when Trait isn't Termination</h3> <p>Previously, we only checked that the underlying type implemented the <code>Termination</code> trait. It is now only possible to return concrete types on stable, as nothing except for <code>impl Termination</code> will work, but that trait is currently unstable to import.</p> <p>For example, this will no longer work on 1.26.1:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() -&gt; impl Copy {} </span></pre> <p>But this will keep working, as it doesn't attempt to return any hidden types via <code>impl Trait</code>, but rather names types concretely.</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() -&gt; Result&lt;(), std::io::Error&gt; { </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Ok</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(()) } </span></pre><h3 id="turbofish-no-longer-works-for-method-arguments-with-impl-trait">Turbofish no longer works for method arguments with <code>impl Trait</code></h3> <p>Previously, we accidentally permitted code to specify the type of method arguments which use <code>impl Trait</code>. On 1.26.0, the code below would work, but how exactly turbofish (<code>::&lt;u32&gt;</code> below) should interact with <code>impl Trait</code> hasn't yet been decided, so we're preventing turbofish use until we can be sure the semantics are as we desire.</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Foo; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">impl </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Foo { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">bar</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">_arg</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: impl Copy) {} } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { Foo.bar::&lt;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&gt;(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); } </span></pre><h3 id="floating-point-comparisons-changed-in-constant-contexts">Floating point comparisons changed in constant contexts</h3> <p>Previously, comparing <code>NaN</code> as greater than other floating point numbers in a constant context would return true, which is a bug; now, this comparison returns false. In some cases that may mean that the behavior of code will change, but we expect this to be relatively unlikely.</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">use std::f64::NAN; const FOO: bool = ::std::f64::NAN &gt;= ::std::f64::NAN; # On 1.26.0 assert_eq!(FOO, true); # On 1.26.1 assert_eq!(FOO, false); </span></pre><h3 id="rustup-should-now-work-to-install-stable-on-platforms-with-missing-docs">rustup should now work to install stable on platforms with missing docs</h3> <p>During the development cycle for 1.26, a change was made to how we build the documentation for the standard library, which made it so that we stopped producing the documentation component for a variety of tier 2 platforms. This led to breakage when running <code>rustup update</code> on those platforms, as rustup refused to partially install Rust. Some users will need to run <code>rustup install stable</code> instead of <code>rustup update</code> to make rustup avoid the missing docs component, but this should be a one-time problem.</p> <p>This was unfortunately fixed too late to make it into 1.26 stable, so we added the patch for 1.26.1 to permit users to install Rust on these platforms.</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">rustup update info: syncing channel updates for &#39;stable-x86_64-unknown-freebsd&#39; info: latest update on 2018-05-10, rust version 1.26.0 (a77568041 2018-05-07) error: component &#39;rust-docs&#39; for &#39;x86_64-unknown-freebsd&#39; is unavailable for download </span></pre> Rust turns three Tue, 15 May 2018 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-turns-three/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-turns-three/ <p>Three years ago today, the Rust community released <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2015/05/15/Rust-1.0.html">Rust 1.0</a> to the world, with our initial vision of fearless systems programming. As per tradition, we’ll celebrate Rust’s birthday by taking stock of the people and the product, and especially of what’s happened in the last year.</p> <h1 id="the-people">The People</h1> <p>Rust is a people-centric, consensus-driven project. Some of the most exciting developments over the last year have to do with how the project itself has grown, and how its processes have scaled.</p> <p>The <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/en-US/team.html">official teams</a> that oversee the project <strong>doubled</strong> in size in the last year; there are now over a hundred individuals associated with one or more of the teams. To accommodate this scale, the team structure itself has evolved. We have top-level teams covering the language, library ecosystem, developer tooling, documentation, community, and project operations. Nested within these are dozens of subteams and working groups focused on specific topics.</p> <p>Rust is now used in a huge variety of companies, including both newcomers and big names like Google, Facebook, Twitter, Dropbox, Microsoft, Red Hat, npm and, of course, <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/11/14/Fearless-Concurrency-In-Firefox-Quantum.html">Mozilla</a>; it’s also in the top 15 languages this year on GitHub. As a byproduct, <strong>more and more developers are being paid to contribute back to Rust</strong>, many of them full time. As of today, Mozilla employees make up only 11% of the official Rust teams, and just under half of the total number of people paid to work on Rust. (You can read detailed whitepapers about putting Rust into production <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/en-US/whitepapers.html">here</a>.)</p> <p><img src="/images/2018-05-Third-Birthday/team.png" alt="Graphs of Rust team growth" /></p> <p>Finally, the Rust community continues to work on inclusivity, through outreach programs like <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/04/02/Increasing-Rusts-Reach-2018.html">Rust Reach</a> and <a href="https://rustbridge.github.io/">RustBridge</a>, as well as <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/09/18/impl-future-for-rust.html">structured mentoring</a> and investments in <a href="https://rustc-dev-guide.rust-lang.org/">documentation</a> to ease contribution. For 2018, a major goal is to <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/03/12/roadmap.html">connect and empower Rust’s <em>global</em> community</a>, which we’re doing both through conference launches in multiple new continents, as well as work toward internationalization throughout the project.</p> <h1 id="the-product">The Product</h1> <p>If you spend much time reading this blog, you’ll know that the major theme of our work over the past year has been <strong>productivity</strong>. As we said in <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/02/06/roadmap.html">last year’s roadmap</a>:</p> <blockquote> <p>From tooling to libraries to documentation to the core language, we want to make it easier to get things done with Rust.</p> </blockquote> <p>This work will culminate in a major release later this year: <strong>Rust 2018 Edition</strong>. The release will bring together improvements in every area of the project, polished into a new “edition” that bundles the changes together with updated documentation and onboarding. The <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/03/12/roadmap.html">roadmap</a> has some details about what to expect.</p> <p>The components that make up Rust 2018 will be shipped as they become ready on the stable compiler. Recent releases include:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/02/15/Rust-1.24.html">On-by-default incremental compilation</a></li> <li><a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/05/10/Rust-1.26.html">A rewritten official book</a></li> <li><a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/05/10/Rust-1.26.html">Several of the planned language improvements, including <code>impl Trait</code> and <code>match</code> improvements</a></li> </ul> <p>The next couple of releases will include <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/48556">stable SIMD</a> support, procedural macros, custom allocators, and more. The final big features — <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/2094">lifetime system improvements</a> and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/2394">async/await</a> — should both reach feature complete status on nightly within weeks. Vital tools like the RLS and <code>rustfmt</code> are also being polished for the new edition, including RFCs for finalizing the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/2436">style</a> and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/2437">stability</a> stories.</p> <p>To help tie all this work to real-world use-cases, we’ve also targeted four domains for which Rust provides a compelling end-to-end story that we want to show the world as part of Rust 2018. Each domain has a dedicated working group and is very much open for new contributors:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/announcing-the-embedded-devices-working-group/6839">Embedded devices</a></li> <li><a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/announcing-the-cli-working-group/6872">Command-line apps</a></li> <li><a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/come-join-the-rust-and-webassembly-working-group/6845/2">The browser, node.js, and portable embedding via WebAssembly</a></li> <li><a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/announcing-the-network-services-working-group-wg-net/7354">Networking services</a></li> </ul> <p>As <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/03/12/roadmap.html">Rust 2018</a> comes into focus, we plan to provide a “preview” of the new edition for cutting-edge community members to try out. Over the past couple of weeks we kicked off a sprint to get the basics nailed down, but we need more help to get it ready for testing. If you’re interested, you can dive into:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rustfix/issues/">The rustfix issue tracker</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3AA-rust-2018-preview">Bugs in the lints that drive rustfix</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/edition-guide">The new “Edition Guide”, which will need lots of eyeballs on pull requests for its content</a></li> </ul> <h1 id="the-postscript">The Postscript</h1> <p>Rust’s growth continues to accelerate at a staggering rate. It has been voted the <a href="https://insights.stackoverflow.com/survey/2018/#most-loved-dreaded-and-wanted">Most Loved Language on StackOverflow</a> for all three years since it shipped. Its community has never been healthier or more welcoming. If you’re curious about using or contributing to Rust, there’s never been a better time to get involved.</p> <p>Happy 3rd birthday, Rust.</p> Announcing Rust 1.26 Thu, 10 May 2018 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-26/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-26/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce a new version of Rust, 1.26.0. Rust is a systems programming language focused on safety, speed, and concurrency.</p> <p>If you have a previous version of Rust installed via rustup, getting Rust 1.26.0 is as easy as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">rustup</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> update stable </span></pre> <p>If you don't have it already, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">get <code>rustup</code></a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1260-2018-05-10">detailed release notes for 1.26.0</a> on GitHub.</p> <h2 id="what-s-in-1-26-0-stable">What's in 1.26.0 stable</h2> <p>The past few releases have had a steady stream of relatively minor additions. We've been working on a lot of stuff, however, and it's all starting to land in stable. 1.26 is possibly the most feature-packed release since Rust 1.0. Let's dig in!</p> <h4 id="the-rust-programming-language-second-edition">&quot;The Rust Programming Language&quot; Second Edition</h4> <p>For almost 18 months, Carol, Steve, and others have been working on a complete re-write of &quot;The Rust Programming Language.&quot; We've learned a lot about how people learn Rust since the first book was written, and this version is an improvement in every way.</p> <p>We've shipped the draft of the second edition on the website for a while now, but with a disclaimer that it was a work in progress. At this point, the book is undergoing some final, minor copy-edits, and being prepared for print. As such, with this release, we are recommending the second edition over the first. You can <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/book/second-edition/">read it on doc.rust-lang.org</a> or locally via <code>rustup doc --book</code>.</p> <p>Speaking of print, you can pre-order a dead tree version of the book <a href="https://www.nostarch.com/Rust">from NoStarch Press</a>. The contents are identical, but you get a nice physical book to put on a shelf, or a beautifully typeset PDF. Proceeds are going to charity.</p> <h4 id="impl-trait"><code>impl Trait</code></h4> <p>At long last, <code>impl Trait</code> is here! This feature has been highly desired for quite a while, and provides a feature known as &quot;existential types.&quot; It's simpler than that sounds, however. The core of it is this idea:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">foo</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() -&gt; impl Trait { </span><span style="color:#999999;">// ... </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p>This type signature says &quot;<code>foo</code> is a function that takes no arguments but returns a type that implements the <code>Trait</code> trait.&quot; That is, we're not going to tell you what the return type of <code>foo</code> actually is, only that it implements a particular trait. You may wonder how this differs from a trait object:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">foo</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() -&gt; Box&lt;Trait&gt; { </span><span style="color:#999999;">// ... </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p>While it's true that you could have written this code today, it's not ideal in all situations.
