Let's say we have a trait <code>Trait</code> that is implemented for both <code>i32</code> and <code>f32</code>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">trait </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Trait { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">method</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">impl </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Trait </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">for </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">i32 { </span><span style="color:#999999;">// implementation goes here </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">impl </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Trait </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">for </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">f32 { </span><span style="color:#999999;">// implementation goes here </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p>Consider this function:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">foo</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() -&gt; </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">? </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">5 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p>We want to fill in the return type with something. Previously, only the trait object version was possible:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">foo</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() -&gt; Box&lt;Trait&gt; { </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Box</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">::new(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">5</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">as </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Box&lt;Trait&gt; } </span></pre> <p>But this introduces a <code>Box</code>, which means allocation. We're not actually returning some kind of dynamic data here either, so the dynamic dispatch of the trait object hurts too. So instead, as of Rust 1.26, you can write this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">foo</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() -&gt; impl Trait { </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">5 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p>This doesn't create a trait object, it's like we had written <code>-&gt; i32</code>, but instead, we're only mentioning the part about <code>Trait</code>. We get static dispatch, but we can hide the real type like this.</p> <p>Why is this useful? One good use is closures. Remember that closures in Rust all have a unique, un-writable type, yet implement the <code>Fn</code> trait. This means that if your function returns a closure, you can do this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#999999;">// before </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">foo</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() -&gt; Box&lt;Fn(</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) -&gt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&gt; { </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Box</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">::new(|</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">x</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">| x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) } </span><span style="color:#999999;">// after </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">foo</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() -&gt; impl Fn(</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) -&gt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">|</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">x</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">|</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p>No boxing, no dynamic dispatch. A related scenario happens when returning iterators. Not only do iterators often include closures, but since they nest, you get quite deeply nested types. For example:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">foo</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { vec![</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">3</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] .</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">into_iter</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() .</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">map</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(|</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">x</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">| x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) .</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">filter</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(|</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">x</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">| x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">% </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">== </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) } </span></pre> <p>when compiled, gives this error:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">error[E0308]: mismatched types --&gt; src/main.rs:5:5 | 5 | / vec![1, 2, 3] 6 | | .into_iter() 7 | | .map(|x| x + 1) 8 | | .filter(|x| x % 2 == 0) | |_______________________________^ expected (), found struct `std::iter::Filter` | = note: expected type `()` found type `std::iter::Filter&lt;std::iter::Map&lt;std::vec::IntoIter&lt;{integer}&gt;, [closure@src/main.rs:7:14: 7:23]&gt;, [closure@src/main.rs:8:17: 8:31]&gt;` </span></pre> <p>That's a huge 'found type'. Each adapter in the chain adds a new type. Additionally, we have that closure in there. Previously, we'd have had to use a trait object here, but now we can simply do</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">foo</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() -&gt; impl Iterator&lt;Item = </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&gt; { vec![</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">3</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] .</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">into_iter</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() .</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">map</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(|</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">x</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">| x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) .</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">filter</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(|</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">x</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">| x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">% </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">== </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) } </span></pre> <p>and be done with it. Working with <a href="https://crates.io/crates/futures">futures</a> is very similar.</p> <p>It's important to note that sometimes trait objects are still what you need. You can only use <code>impl Trait</code> if your function returns a single type; if you want to return multiple, you need dynamic dispatch. For example:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">foo</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">x</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) -&gt; Box&lt;Iterator&lt;Item = </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&gt;&gt; { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> iter </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">vec![</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">3</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] .</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">into_iter</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() .</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">map</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(|</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">x</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">| x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">if</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">% </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">== </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Box</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">::new(iter.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">filter</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(|</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">x</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">| x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">% </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">== </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">)) } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">else </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Box</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">::new(iter) } } </span></pre> <p>Here, we may return a filtered iterator, or maybe not. There's two different types that can be returned, and so we must use a trait object.</p> <p>Oh, and one last thing: to make the syntax a bit more symmetrical, you can use <code>impl Trait</code> in argument position too. That is:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#999999;">// before </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">foo</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&lt;T: Trait&gt;(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">x</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: T) { </span><span style="color:#999999;">// after </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">foo</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">x</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: impl Trait) { </span></pre> <p>which can look a bit nicer for short signatures.</p> <blockquote> <p>Side note for you type theorists out there: this isn't an existential, still a universal. In other words, <code>impl Trait</code> is universal in an input position, but existential in an output position.</p> </blockquote> <h4 id="nicer-match-bindings">Nicer <code>match</code> bindings</h4> <p>Have you ever had a reference to an <code>Option</code>, and tried to use <code>match</code>? For example, code like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">hello</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">arg</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Option&lt;String&gt;) { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">match</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> arg { </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Some</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(name) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;Hello </span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">!&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, name), </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">None </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;I don&#39;t know who you are.&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">), } } </span></pre> <p>If you tried to compile this in Rust 1.25, you'd get this error:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">error[E0658]: non-reference pattern used to match a reference (see issue #42640) --&gt; src/main.rs:6:9 | 6 | Some(name) =&gt; println!(&quot;Hello {}!&quot;, name), | ^^^^^^^^^^ help: consider using a reference: `&amp;Some(name)` error[E0658]: non-reference pattern used to match a reference (see issue #42640) --&gt; src/main.rs:7:9 | 7 | None =&gt; println!(&quot;I don&#39;t know who you are.&quot;), | ^^^^ help: consider using a reference: `&amp;None` </span></pre> <p>Okay, sure. Let's modify the code:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">hello</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">arg</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Option&lt;String&gt;) { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">match</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> arg { </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Some</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(name) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;Hello </span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">!&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, name), </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#c99e00;">None </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;I don&#39;t know who you are.&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">), } } </span></pre> <p>We added the <code>&amp;</code>s the compiler complained about. Let's try to compile again:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">error[E0507]: cannot move out of borrowed content --&gt; src/main.rs:6:9 | 6 | &amp;Some(name) =&gt; println!(&quot;Hello {}!&quot;, name), | ^^^^^^----^ | | | | | hint: to prevent move, use `ref name` or `ref mut name` | cannot move out of borrowed content </span></pre> <p>Okay, sure. Let's make the compiler happy again by taking its advice:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">hello</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">arg</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Option&lt;String&gt;) { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">match</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> arg { </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Some</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">ref</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> name) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;Hello </span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">!&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, name), </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#c99e00;">None </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;I don&#39;t know who you are.&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">), } } </span></pre> <p>This will finally compile. We had to add two <code>&amp;</code>s, and a <code>ref</code>. But more importantly, none of this was really <em>helpful</em> to us as programmers. Sure, we forgot a <code>&amp;</code> at first, but does that matter? We had to add <code>ref</code> to get a reference to the inside of the option, but we couldn't do anything <em>but</em> get a reference, as we can't move out of a <code>&amp;T</code>.</p> <p>So, as of Rust 1.26, the initial code, without the <code>&amp;</code>s and <code>ref</code>, will just compile and do exactly what you'd expect. In short, the compiler will automatically reference or de-reference in <code>match</code> statements. So when we say</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">match</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> arg { </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Some</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(name) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;Hello </span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">!&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, name), </span></pre> <p>the compiler automatically references the <code>Some</code>, and since we're borrowing, <code>name</code> is bound as <code>ref name</code> automatically as well. If we were mutating:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">hello</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">arg</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">mut </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Option&lt;String&gt;) { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">match</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> arg { </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Some</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(name) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> name.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">push_str</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;, world&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">), </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">None </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(), } } </span></pre> <p>the compiler will automatically borrow by mutable reference, and <code>name</code> will be bound as <code>ref mut</code> too.</p> <p>We think this will remove a significant papercut for new and old Rustaceans alike. The compiler will just do the right thing more often without the need for boilerplate.</p> <h4 id="main-can-return-a-result"><code>main</code> can return a <code>Result</code></h4> <p>Speaking of papercuts, since Rust uses the <code>Result</code> type for returning errors, and <code>?</code> to make handling them easy, a common pain-point of new Rustaceans is to try and use <code>?</code> in <code>main</code>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">use </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">std::fs::File; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> f </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">File::open(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;bar.txt&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">)</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">?</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; } </span></pre> <p>This will give an error like &quot;error[E0277]: the <code>?</code> operator can only be used in a function that returns <code>Result</code>&quot;. This leads to a pattern where many people write code that <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/book/second-edition/ch12-03-improving-error-handling-and-modularity.html#extracting-logic-from-main">looks like this</a>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">run</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">config</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: Config) -&gt; Result&lt;(), Box&lt;Error&gt;&gt; { </span><span style="color:#999999;">// --snip-- </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#999999;">// --snip-- </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">if let </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Err</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(e) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">run</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(config) { println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;Application error: </span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, e); process::exit(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); } } </span></pre> <p>Our <code>run</code> function has all of the real logic, and <code>main</code> calls <code>run</code>, only checking to see if there was an error and exiting. We need to make this second function because <code>main</code> can't return a <code>Result</code>, but we'd like to use <code>?</code> in that logic.</p> <p>In Rust 1.26, you can now declare <code>main</code> that returns <code>Result</code>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">use </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">std::fs::File; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() -&gt; Result&lt;(), std::io::Error&gt; { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> f </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">File::open(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;bar.txt&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">)</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">?</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Ok</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(()) } </span></pre> <p>This now works just fine! If <code>main</code> returns an error, this will exit with an error code, and print out a debug representation of the error.</p> <h4 id="inclusive-ranges-with">Inclusive ranges with <code>..=</code></h4> <p>Since well before Rust 1.0, you've been able to create exclusive ranges with <code>..</code> like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">for</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> i </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">in </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">..</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">3 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;i: </span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, i); } </span></pre> <p>This will print <code>i: 1</code> and then <code>i: 2</code>. In Rust 1.26, you can now create an inclusive range, like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">for</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> i </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">in </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">..=</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">3 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;i: </span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, i); } </span></pre> <p>This will print <code>i: 1</code> and then <code>i: 2</code> like before, but also <code>i: 3</code>; the three is included in the range. Inclusive ranges are especially useful if you want to iterate over every possible value in a range. For example, this is a surprising Rust program:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">takes_u8</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">x</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u8</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) { </span><span style="color:#999999;">// ... </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">for</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> i </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">in </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">..</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">256 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;i: </span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, i); </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">takes_u8</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(i); } } </span></pre> <p>What does this program do? The answer: nothing. The warning we get when compiling has a hint:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">warning: literal out of range for u8 --&gt; src/main.rs:6:17 | 6 | for i in 0..256 { | ^^^ | = note: #[warn(overflowing_literals)] on by default </span></pre> <p>That's right, since <code>i</code> is a <code>u8</code>, this overflows, and is the same as writing <code>for i in 0..0</code>, so the loop executes zero times.</p> <p>We can do this with inclusive ranges, however:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">takes_u8</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">x</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u8</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) { </span><span style="color:#999999;">// ... </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">for</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> i </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">in </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">..=</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">255 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;i: </span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, i); </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">takes_u8</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(i); } } </span></pre> <p>This will produce those 256 lines of output you might have been expecting.</p> <h4 id="basic-slice-patterns">Basic slice patterns</h4> <p>Another long-awaited feature is &quot;slice patterns.&quot; These let you match on slices similar to how you match on other data types. For example:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> arr </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">3</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">]; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">match</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> arr { [</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">_</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">_</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;starts with one&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, [a, b, c] </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;starts with something else&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, } </span></pre> <p>In this case, we know <code>arr</code> has a length of three, and so we need three entries inside the <code>[]</code>s. We can also match when we don't know the length:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">foo</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">s</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u8</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">]) { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">match</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> s { [a, b] </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(), [a, b, c] </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(), </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">_ =&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(), } } </span></pre> <p>Here, we don't know how long <code>s</code> is, so we can write the first two arms, each with different lengths. This also means we need a <code>_</code> term, since we aren't covering every possible length, nor could we!</p> <h4 id="speed-improvements">Speed improvements</h4> <p>We continue to work on the speed of the compiler. We discovered that deeply nesting types was non-linear in some cases, and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/48296">a fix was implemented</a>. We're seeing up to a 12% reduction in compile times from this change, but many other smaller fixes landed as well. More to come in the future!</p> <h4 id="128-bit-integers">128 bit integers</h4> <p>Finally, a very simple feature: Rust now has 128 bit integers!</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> x: i128 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> y: u128 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span></pre> <p>These are twice the size of <code>u64</code>, and so can hold more values. More specifically,</p> <ul> <li><code>u128</code>: 0 - 340,282,366,920,938,463,463,374,607,431,768,211,455</li> <li><code>i128</code>: −170,141,183,460,469,231,731,687,303,715,884,105,728 - 170,141,183,460,469,231,731,687,303,715,884,105,727</li> </ul> <p>Whew!</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1260-2018-05-10">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h3 id="library-stabilizations">Library stabilizations</h3> <p>We stabilized <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/fs/fn.read_to_string.html"><code>fs::read_to_string</code></a>, a convenience over <code>File::open</code> and <code>io::Read::read_to_string</code> for easily reading an entire file into memory at once:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">use </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">std::fs; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">use </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">std::net::SocketAddr; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> foo: SocketAddr </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">fs::read_to_string(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;address.txt&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">)</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">?</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">parse</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">()</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">?</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span></pre> <p>You can now <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/48978">format numbers as hexadecimal with <code>Debug</code> formatting</a>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">assert!(format!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;{:02x?}&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">b</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;Foo</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">\0</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">== </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;[46, 6f, 6f, 00]&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) </span></pre> <p>Trailing commas <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/48056">are now supported by all macros in the standard library</a>.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1260-2018-05-10">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h3 id="cargo-features">Cargo features</h3> <p>Cargo didn't receive many big new features this release but rather saw a steady stream of stability and performance improvements. Cargo should now resolve lock files even faster, backtrack more intelligently, and require manual <code>cargo update</code> invocations less. Cargo's binary <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/5083">now also shares the same version as <code>rustc</code></a>.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1260-2018-05-10">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h2 id="contributors-to-1-26-0">Contributors to 1.26.0</h2> <p>Many people came together to create Rust 1.26. We couldn't have done it without all of you.</p> <p><a href="https://thanks.rust-lang.org/rust/1.26.0">Thanks!</a></p> The Rust Team All Hands in Berlin: a Recap Fri, 06 Apr 2018 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/all-hands/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/all-hands/ <p>Last week we held an &quot;All Hands&quot; event in Berlin, which drew more than 50 people involved in 15 different Rust Teams or Working Groups, with a majority being volunteer contributors. This was the first such event, and its location reflects the current concentration of team members in Europe. The week was a smashing success which we plan to repeat on at least an annual basis.</p> <p>The impetus for this get-together was, in part, our <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/03/12/roadmap.html">ambitious plans</a> to ship <em>Rust, 2018 edition</em> later this year. A week of work-focused facetime was a great way to kick off these efforts!</p> <p>We've also asked attendees to blog and tweet about their experiences at the #RustAllHands hashtag; the Content Team will be gathering up and summarizing this content as well.</p> <h2 id="highlights-by-team">Highlights by team</h2> <p>Below we'll go through the biggest items addressed last week. <strong>Note that, as always, reaching consensus in a meeting does <em>not</em> mean any final decision has been made</strong>. All major decisions will go through the usual <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs">RFC process</a>.</p> <h3 id="language-design">Language design</h3> <ul> <li><strong>Macros</strong>: put together a proposal for the 2018 edition. <ul> <li>Stabilize a forward-compatible subset of procedural macros that explicitly opts out of hygiene (by asking all names to be interpreted at the call site).</li> <li>Work out a revised API surface for procedural macros based on what we've learned so far.</li> <li>Stabilize importing macros through normal <code>use</code> statements.</li> <li><strong>Alex Crichton will drive the stabilization process</strong>.</li> </ul> </li> <li><strong>Extern types</strong>: worked through <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/43467#issuecomment-377521693">remaining issues for stabilization</a>.</li> <li><strong>Improvements to <code>derive</code></strong>: a <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/2385">proposal</a> to make <code>derive</code> more ergonomic in Rust 2018.</li> <li><strong>Best practices</strong>: set up a cross-cutting guidelines effort, encompassing the API guidelines but also including style, lints, and Lang Team recommendations.</li> </ul> <h3 id="libraries">Libraries</h3> <ul> <li><strong>SIMD</strong>: talked through final steps of stabilization; we hope to <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/48556#issuecomment-378184312">stabilize in 1.27</a>.</li> <li><strong>Allocators</strong>: developed a conservative proposal for stabilizing global allocators; <strong>Simon Sapin has set up a <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/49668">new tracking issue</a></strong>.</li> </ul> <h3 id="compiler">Compiler</h3> <ul> <li><strong>Tool integration</strong>: extensive discussion and planning about the needs of compiler clients, composable plugins, and the compiler's new query architecture.</li> <li><strong>Query compilation</strong>: a plan for end-to-end query compilation, i.e. fully-incremental compilation.</li> <li><strong>libsyntax</strong>: a long-run plan for a revamped libsyntax, shared amongst a variety of tools.</li> <li><strong>Contribution</strong>: improved contribution experience for the compiler.</li> </ul> <h3 id="community">Community</h3> <ul> <li><strong>Mozilla Activate</strong>: shipped a revamp of the page</li> <li><strong>RustBridge &quot;in a box&quot;</strong>: shipped a ton of resources.</li> <li><strong>Events</strong>: developed event standards, including: <ul> <li>Diversity Outreach</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-community/events-team/pull/18">Speaker support and quality</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-community/events-team/pull/19">Program guidelines</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-community/events-team/pull/20">Review committee guidelines</a></li> <li>Communication and transparency (e.g. <a href="https://github.com/rust-community/events-team/pull/22">timelines</a>)</li> <li>Attendee experience, accessibility and support</li> </ul> </li> </ul> <h3 id="documentation">Documentation</h3> <ul> <li><strong>Edition planning</strong>: determined resources needed for the 2018 edition, what that means for the Rust Bookshelf, and who will be responsible for each.</li> <li><strong>Team blog</strong>: “This week in Rust docs” is going to move to a new <a href="https://rust-docs.github.io/blog/">docs team blog</a>!</li> <li><strong>Doxidize</strong> (aka rustdoc2): made <a href="https://github.com/steveklabnik/doxidize">initial public release</a>; it's like https://docusaurus.io/ but for Rust.</li> <li><strong>Intermediate-level docs</strong>: contributed to <a href="https://github.com/rust-docs/team/issues/8">idea generation</a>.</li> </ul> <h3 id="tools">Tools</h3> <ul> <li><strong>Edition planning</strong>, especially for the rustfix tool.</li> <li><strong>Clippy lint audit</strong>: developed plan for reaching 1.0 on Clippy this year, based on categorizing lints into Correctness, Performance, Style, Complexity, Pedantry, and Nursery categories.</li> <li><strong>Custom test frameworks</strong>: reached consensus on most of the details for <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/2318">the RFC</a></li> <li><strong>IDEs</strong>: discussed improvements to code completion, stability improvements, and new features like refactoring and auto-import support.</li> </ul> <h3 id="cargo">Cargo</h3> <ul> <li><strong>Xargo integration</strong>: making a few more platforms tier 1 addresses the immediate need for embedded; otherwise, plan to go the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1133#issuecomment-362355002">&quot;std-aware Cargo&quot; route</a> late in 2018. Key insight: will entirely obsolete the concept of &quot;targets&quot; in rustup.</li> <li><strong>Rustup integration</strong>: with Xargo integration we can simplify rustup; plan to expose new interface via Cargo late in 2018.</li> <li><strong>Custom registries</strong>: ready to stabilize.</li> <li><strong>Profiles</strong>: the v2 design is clear, and <strong>Aleksey Kladov plans to implement</strong>.</li> <li><strong>Public dependencies</strong>: significantly revised plan to have more conservative ecosystem impact. <strong>Aaron Turon will write a blog post</strong>.</li> <li><strong>Build system integration</strong>: determined two pieces of functionality to implement to decouple the RLS from Cargo.</li> <li><strong>Project templates</strong>: developed a minimal design; <strong>withoutboats will write an RFC</strong>.</li> <li><strong>Custom workflows</strong>: designed workflow customization, which is useful for frameworks; <strong>Aaron Turon has written a <a href="http://aturon.github.io/2018/04/05/workflows/">blog post</a></strong>.</li> </ul> <h3 id="infrastructure">Infrastructure</h3> <ul> <li><strong>bors queue</strong>: hatched and resourced lots of ideas to reduce the PR queue for Rust 2018.</li> <li><strong>crater</strong>: pietroalbini is testing a bot for running crater!</li> <li><strong>Travis log bot</strong>: TimNN has <a href="https://github.com/rust-ops/rust-log-analyzer">written a bot</a> to <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/49513#issuecomment-377538323">extract errors</a> from Travis logs</li> </ul> <h3 id="wg-cli-apps">WG: CLI apps</h3> <ul> <li><a href="https://git.io/rust-all-hands-cli">WG overview slides</a>.</li> <li><strong>Survey and strategy</strong>: dove into survey data and developed strategy from it; posts forthcoming.</li> <li><strong>Distribution</strong>: &quot;distribution-friendly&quot; badge on crates.io</li> <li><strong>Extensible Cargo install</strong>: wrote <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/2376">an RFC</a> on-site!</li> </ul> <h3 id="wg-network-services">WG: network services</h3> <ul> <li><a href="https://gist.github.com/withoutboats/6d4c4639b286d3da19d89d8af82d82d7">WG overview slides</a>.</li> <li><strong>Launching the WG</strong>: determined goals for the WG, including async/await, documentaiton, mid-level HTTP libraries, and the <a href="https://github.com/tower-rs/tower">Tower</a> ecosystem. Kickoff announcement coming soon!</li> <li><strong>Async/await</strong>: finalized design and stabilization approach for RFCs (blog post and links to RFCs <a href="https://boats.gitlab.io/blog/post/2018-04-06-async-await-final/">here</a>).</li> </ul> <h3 id="wg-embedded-devices">WG: embedded devices</h3> <ul> <li><a href="https://github.com/japaric/all-hands-2018-embedded">WG overview slides</a></li> <li><strong>Embedded Rust on stable</strong>: addressed all known blockers and several mid-priority issues as well.</li> <li><strong>The Embedded Rust book</strong>: defined audience and basic outline.</li> </ul> <h3 id="wg-webassembly">WG: WebAssembly</h3> <ul> <li><a href="https://gist.github.com/fitzgen/700e134cffe9a8438524f0a39810a4d0">WG overview slides</a>.</li> <li><strong>2018 edition planning</strong>, including scoping the toolchain and book efforts for the release.</li> <li><strong>JS integration</strong>: dove into integrating JS callbacks vs Rust functions in wasm-bindgen.</li> <li><strong>Ecosystem integration</strong>: wasm-bindgen now works with CommonJS!</li> <li><strong>Code bloat</strong>, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/49488">reducing the footprint</a> of panicking from 44k to 350 bytes.</li> </ul> <h3 id="unsafe-code-guidelines">Unsafe code guidelines</h3> <ul> <li><strong>Restarted the WG</strong>: dug back into two competing approaches (&quot;validity&quot; and &quot;access&quot;-based), substantially iterated on both. <strong>Niko Matsakis and Ralf Jung will be writing blog posts about these ideas</strong>.</li> <li><strong>Pressing issues</strong>: tackled a few near-term decisions that need to be made, including <code>union</code> semantics, <code>Pin</code> semantics, <code>thread::abort</code> and more.</li> </ul> <h3 id="web-site">Web site</h3> <ul> <li><strong>Domain WG sketching</strong>: over a couple of sessions, the four domain-centered working groups (listed above) developed some initial sketches of landing pages for each domain.</li> </ul> <h3 id="rust-reach">Rust reach</h3> <ul> <li><strong>Prepared for launch</strong>, which happened <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/04/02/Increasing-Rusts-Reach-2018.html">earlier this week!</a></li> </ul> <h3 id="new-working-groups">New working groups</h3> <p>In addition to the work by existing teams, we had critical mass to form two new working groups:</p> <ul> <li><strong>Verification</strong>: bringing together folks interested in testing, static analysis, and formal verification.</li> <li><strong>Codegen</strong>: work to improve the quality of code rustc generates, both in terms of size and runtime performance.</li> </ul> <p>The Verification WG has been <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/announcing-the-formal-verification-working-group/7240/">formally announced</a>, and the Codegen WG should be announced soon!</p> <h2 id="general-reflections-and-notes-of-appreciation">General reflections and notes of appreciation</h2> <p>The combination of having a clear goal -- Rust 2018 -- and a solid majority of team member present made the All Hands extremely fun and productive. We strive to keep the Rust community open and inclusive through asynchronous online communication, but it's important to occasionally come together in person. The mix of ambition and kindness at play last week really captured the spirit of the Rust Community.</p> <p>Of course, an event like this is only possible with a lot of help, and I'd like to thank the co-organizers and Mozilla Berlin office staff:</p> <ul> <li>Johann Hofmann</li> <li>Jan-Erik Rediger</li> <li>Florian Gilcher</li> <li>Ashley Williams</li> <li>Martyna Sobczak</li> </ul> <p>as well as all the team leads who organized and led sessions!</p> Increasing Rust’s Reach 2018 Mon, 02 Apr 2018 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/increasing-rusts-reach-2018/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/increasing-rusts-reach-2018/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce that we're running our Increasing Rust's Reach program <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/06/27/Increasing-Rusts-Reach.html">again</a> this year. Increasing Rust's Reach is one of several programs run by the project to grow Rust's community of project collaborators and leaders.</p> <p>We’re looking for people inside and outside Rust’s current community from groups and backgrounds that are underrepresented in the Rust world and the technology world more generally. We want to partner with you to make Rust a more inclusive, approachable, and impactful project, while supporting your success on personal goals.</p> <p>This program matches Rust team members from all parts of the project with individuals who are underrepresented in Rust's community and the tech industry for a partnership of three (3) months, from mid-May to mid-August. Each partnership agrees to a commitment of 3-5 hours per week collaborating on a Rust project.</p> <p>By way of thanks for participating in the program, we offer a fully paid conference ticket, travel, and accomodations for every participant to a Rust Conference of their choice:</p> <ul> <li>May 26-27: <a href="https://paris.rustfest.eu/">RustFest Paris</a></li> <li>August 16-17: <a href="http://rustconf.com/">RustConf</a></li> <li>October: <a href="https://twitter.com/rustbeltrust">Rust Belt Rust</a></li> </ul> <p>Learn more about the upcoming 2018 Rust Conferences <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/01/31/The-2018-Rust-Event-Lineup.html">here</a>.</p> <p><a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/06/27/Increasing-Rusts-Reach.html">Last year</a> we had 12 participants working on several projects, from contributing to foundational ecosystem libraries like <a href="http://diesel.rs/">Diesel</a>, to discovery work on a new Rust website, to helping find developer experience and usability holes in the crates.io ecosystem. You can read more about previous participants' experiences on the brand new <a href="http://reach.rust-lang.org/">Increasing Rust's Reach website</a>!</p> <p>Many of the projects we have for this year build on the work that was accomplished last year. However, the primary focus of this year's project is the <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/03/12/roadmap.html#rust-2018-edition">2018 edition release</a>; in particular, the <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/announcing-the-2018-domain-working-groups/6737">domain working groups</a> that we kicked off with our <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/03/12/roadmap.html">2018 Roadmap</a>. </p> <p>We believe the 2018 edition is a great opportunity, not only to simply get new people involved in the Rust project, but to also demonstrate the huge impact that even newcomers to the project can make. Rust is committed to being a friendly and inclusive project that welcomes new contributors from all sorts of backgrounds—we actively want to be a project that you <em>want</em> to work on, and we're excited to learn about how we can do that better.</p> <p><a href="http://reach.rust-lang.org/#apply">Applications</a> for the program open today, and will run until April 20th. We will announce the recipients on April 30th, and the program will run from May 15th to August 17th. For more details on the timeline, check out the <a href="http://reach.rust-lang.org/#timeline">website</a>.</p> <p>We're super excited to get your applications! If you have any questions, feel free to reach out to the program committee at <a href="mail-to:reach@rust-lang.org">reach@rust-lang.org</a>.</p> Announcing Rust 1.25 Thu, 29 Mar 2018 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-25/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-25/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce a new version of Rust, 1.25.0. Rust is a systems programming language focused on safety, speed, and concurrency.</p> <p>If you have a previous version of Rust installed via rustup, getting Rust 1.25.0 is as easy as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">rustup</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> update stable </span></pre> <p>If you don't have it already, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">get <code>rustup</code></a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1250-2018-03-29">detailed release notes for 1.25.0</a> on GitHub.</p> <h2 id="what-s-in-1-25-0-stable">What's in 1.25.0 stable</h2> <p>The last few releases have been relatively minor, but Rust 1.25 contains a bunch of stuff! The first one is straightforward: we've <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/47828">upgraded to LLVM 6</a> from LLVM 4. This has a number of effects, a major one being a step closer to AVR support.</p> <p>A new way to write <code>use</code> statements has landed: <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/47948">nested import groups</a>. If you've ever written a set of imports like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">use </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">std::fs::File; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">use </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">std::io::Read; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">use </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">std::path::{Path, PathBuf}; </span></pre> <p>You can now write this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#999999;">// on one line </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">use </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">std::{fs::File, io::Read, path::{Path, PathBuf}}; </span><span style="color:#999999;">// with some more breathing room </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">use </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">std::{ fs::File, io::Read, path::{ Path, PathBuf } }; </span></pre> <p>This can reduce some repetition, and make things a bit more clear.</p> <p>There are two big documentation changes in this release: first, <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/rust-by-example/">Rust By Example is now included on doc.rust-lang.org</a>! We'll be redirecting the old domain there shortly. We hope this will bring more attention to a great resource, and you'll get a local copy with your local documentation.</p> <p>Second, back in Rust 1.23, we talked about the change from Hoedown to pulldown-cmark. In Rust 1.25, pulldown-cmark is now the default. We have finally removed the last bit of C from rustdoc, and now properly follow the CommonMark spec.</p> <p>Finally, in <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/1358-repr-align.md">RFC 1358</a>, <code>#[repr(align(x))]</code> was accepted. In Rust 1.25, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/47006">it is now stable</a>! This attribute lets you set the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_structure_alignment">alignment</a> of your <code>struct</code>s:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Number(</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); assert_eq!(std::mem::align_of::&lt;Number&gt;(), </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">4</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); assert_eq!(std::mem::size_of::&lt;Number&gt;(), </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">4</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); #[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">repr</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#c82829;">align</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">(16)</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">)] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Align16(</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); assert_eq!(std::mem::align_of::&lt;Align16&gt;(), </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">16</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); assert_eq!(std::mem::size_of::&lt;Align16&gt;(), </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">16</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); </span></pre> <p>If you're working with low-level stuff, control of these kinds of things can be very important!</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1250-2018-03-29">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h3 id="library-stabilizations">Library stabilizations</h3> <p>The biggest story in libraries this release is <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/ptr/struct.NonNull.html"><code>std::ptr::NonNull&lt;T&gt;</code></a>. This type is similar to <code>*mut T</code>, but is non-null and covariant. This blog post isn't the right place to explain variance, but in a nutshell, <code>NonNull&lt;T&gt;</code>, well, guarantees that it won't be null, which means that <code>Option&lt;NonNull&lt;T&gt;&gt;</code> has the same size as <code>*mut T</code>. If you're building a data structure with unsafe code, <code>NonNull&lt;T&gt;</code> is often the right type for you!</p> <p><code>libcore</code> has <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/core/time/">gained a <code>time</code> module</a>, containing the <code>Duration</code> type previously only available in <code>libstd</code>.</p> <p>Additionally, the <code>from_secs</code>, and <code>from_millis</code> functions associated with <code>Duration</code> were made <code>const fn</code>s, allowing them to be used to create a <code>Duration</code> as a constant expression.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1250-2018-03-29">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h3 id="cargo-features">Cargo features</h3> <p>Cargo's CLI has one really important change this release: <code>cargo new</code> will <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/5029">now default</a> to generating a binary, rather than a library. We try to keep Cargo's CLI quite stable, but this change is important, and is unlikely to cause breakage.</p> <p>For some background, <code>cargo new</code> accepts two flags: <code>--lib</code>, for creating libraries, and <code>--bin</code>, for creating binaries, or executables. If you don't pass one of these flags, in previous versions of Cargo, it would default to <code>--lib</code>. We made this decision because each binary (often) depends on many libraries, and so the library case is more common. However, this is incorrect; each library is <em>depended upon</em> by many binaries. Furthermore, when getting started, what you often want is a program you can run and play around with. It's not just new Rustaceans though; even very long-time community members have said that they find this default surprising. As such, we're changing it.</p> <p>Similarly, <code>cargo new</code> previously would be a bit opinionated around the names of packages it would create. Specifically, if your package began with <code>rust-</code> or ended with <code>-rs</code>, Cargo would rename it. The intention was that well, it's a Rust package, this information is redundant. However, people feel quite strongly about naming, and when they bump into this, they're surprised and often upset. As such, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/5013">we're not going to do that any more</a>.</p> <p>Many users love <code>cargo doc</code>, a way to generate local documentation for their Cargo projects. <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/4976">It's getting a huge speed boost</a> in this release, as now, it uses <code>cargo check</code>, rather than a full <code>cargo build</code>, so some scenarios will get faster.</p> <p>Additionally, checkouts of git dependencies <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/4919">should be a lot faster</a>, thanks to the use of hard links when possible.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1250-2018-03-29">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h2 id="contributors-to-1-25-0">Contributors to 1.25.0</h2> <p>Many people came together to create Rust 1.25. We couldn't have done it without all of you.</p> <p><a href="https://thanks.rust-lang.org/rust/1.25.0">Thanks!</a></p> Rust's 2018 roadmap Mon, 12 Mar 2018 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/2018-roadmap/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/2018-roadmap/ <p>Each year the Rust community <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1728">comes together</a> to set out a roadmap. This year, in addition to the <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/09/05/Rust-2017-Survey-Results.html">survey</a>, we put out a <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/01/03/new-years-rust-a-call-for-community-blogposts.html">call for blog posts</a> in December, which resulted in <a href="https://readrust.net/rust-2018/">100 blog posts</a> written over the span of a few weeks. The end result is the recently-merged <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/2314">2018 roadmap RFC</a>.</p> <h2 id="rust-2018-edition">Rust: 2018 edition</h2> <p><strong>This year, we will deliver <em>Rust 2018</em>, marking the first major new edition of Rust since 1.0</strong> (aka Rust 2015).</p> <p>We will continue to publish releases every six weeks as usual. But we will designate a release in the latter third of the year (Rust 1.29 - 1.31) as <em>Rust 2018</em>. This new &quot;edition&quot; of Rust will be the culmination of feature stabilization throughout the year, and will ship with polished documentation, tooling, and libraries that tie in to those features.</p> <p>The idea of editions is to signify major steps in Rust’s evolution, where a collection of new features or idioms, taken as a whole, changes the experience of using Rust. They’re a chance, every few years, to take stock of the work we’ve delivered in six-week increments. To tell a bigger story about where Rust is going. And to ship the whole stack as a polished product.</p> <p>We expect that each edition will have a core theme or focus. Thinking of 1.0 as &quot;Rust 2015&quot;, we have:</p> <ul> <li>Rust 2015: <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/09/15/Rust-1.0.html">stability</a></li> <li>Rust 2018: productivity</li> </ul> <h2 id="what-will-be-in-rust-2018">What will be in Rust 2018?</h2> <p>The roadmap doesn’t say <em>for certain</em> what will ship in Rust 2018, but we have a pretty good idea, and we’ll cover the major suspects below.</p> <h3 id="documentation-improvements">Documentation improvements</h3> <p>Part of the goal with the Rust 2018 release is to provide high quality documentation for the full set of new and improved features and the idioms they give rise to. <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/book/second-edition/">The Rust Programming Language book</a> has been completely re-written over the last 18 months, and will be updated throughout the year as features reach the stable compiler. <a href="https://rustbyexample.com/">Rust By Example</a> will likewise undergo a revamp this year. And there are numerous third party books, like <a href="http://shop.oreilly.com/product/0636920040385.do">Programming Rust</a>, reaching print as well.</p> <h3 id="language-improvements">Language improvements</h3> <p>The most prominent language work in the pipeline stems from <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/03/02/lang-ergonomics.html">2017’s ergonomics initiative</a>. Almost all of the accepted RFCs from the initiative are available on nightly today, and will be polished and stabilized over the next several months. Among these productivity improvements are a few “headliners” that will form the backbone of the release:</p> <ul> <li><strong>Ownership system improvements</strong>, including making borrowing more flexible via “non-lexical lifetimes”, improved pattern matching integration, and more.</li> <li><strong>Trait system improvements</strong>, including the long-awaited <code>impl Trait</code> syntax for dealing with types abstractly.</li> <li><strong>Module system improvements</strong>, focused on increasing clarity and reducing complexity.</li> <li><strong>Generators/async/await:</strong> work is rapidly progressing on first-class async programming support.</li> </ul> <p>In addition, we anticipate a few more major features to stabilize prior to the Rust 2018 release, including <strong>SIMD</strong>, <strong>custom allocators</strong>, and <strong>macros 2.0</strong>.</p> <h3 id="compiler-improvements">Compiler improvements</h3> <p>As of <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/02/15/Rust-1.24.html">Rust 1.24</a>, incremental recompilation is available and enabled by default on the stable compiler. This feature already makes rebuilds significantly faster than fresh builds, but over the course of the year we expect continued improvements for <em>both</em> fresh and re-builds. Compiler performance should not be an obstacle to productivity in Rust 2018.</p> <h3 id="tooling-improvements">Tooling improvements</h3> <p>Rust 2018 will see high quality 1.0 releases of the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rls">Rust Language Server</a> (&quot;RLS&quot;, which underlies much of our IDE integration story) and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rustfmt"><code>rustfmt</code></a> (a standard formatting tool for Rust code). We will continue to improve Cargo by stabilizing custom registries, public dependencies, and a revised profile system. We’re also expecting further work on <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/2136">Cargo build system integration</a>, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/issues/4959">Xargo integration</a>, and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/2318">custom test frameworks</a>, though it’s unclear as yet how many of these will be complete prior to Rust 2018.</p> <h3 id="library-improvements">Library improvements</h3> <p>Building on <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/05/05/libz-blitz.html">our work from last year</a>, we will publish a 1.0 version of the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/api-guidelines">Rust API guidelines book</a>, continue pushing important libraries to 1.0 status, improve discoverability through a revamped cookbook effort, and make heavy investments in libraries in specific domains—as we’ll see below.</p> <h3 id="web-site-improvements">Web site improvements</h3> <p>As part of Rust 2018, we will completely overhaul the Rust web site, making it useful for CTOs and engineers alike. It should be far easier to find information to help evaluate Rust for your use case, and to stay up to date with the latest tooling and ecosystem improvements.</p> <h3 id="four-target-domains">Four target domains</h3> <p>Part of our goal with Rust 2018 is to demonstrate Rust’s productivity in specific domains of use. We’ve selected four such domains to invest in and highlight this year:</p> <ul> <li><strong>Network services</strong>. Rust’s reliability and low footprint make it an excellent match for network services and infrastructure, especially at high scale.</li> <li><strong><a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/announcing-the-cli-working-group/6872">Command-line apps</a></strong> (CLI). Rust’s portability, reliability, ergonomics, and ability to produce static binaries come together to great effect for writing CLI apps.</li> <li><strong><a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/come-join-the-rust-and-webassembly-working-group/6845">WebAssembly</a></strong>. The “wasm” web standard allows shipping native-like binaries to all major browsers, but GC support is still years away. Rust is <a href="https://mgattozzi.com/rust-wasm">extremely well positioned</a> to target this domain, and provides a reasonable on-ramp for programmers coming from JS.</li> <li><strong><a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/announcing-the-embedded-devices-working-group/6839">Embedded devices</a></strong>. Rust has the potential to make programming resource-constrained devices much more productive—and fun! We want embedded programming to reach first-class status this year.</li> </ul> <p>Each of these domains has a dedicated working group for the year. These WGs will work in a cross-cutting fashion, interfacing with language, tooling, library, and documentation work.</p> <h3 id="compatibility-across-editions">Compatibility across editions</h3> <p><strong>TL;DR: Rust will continue its stability guarantee of <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/10/30/Stability.html">hassle-free updates to new versions</a></strong>.</p> <p>Editions will have a meaning for the compiler. You will be able to write:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">edition </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;2018&quot; </span></pre> <p>in your Cargo.toml to <em>opt in</em> to the new edition for your crate. Doing so may introduce new keywords or otherwise require adjustments to code. However:</p> <ul> <li>You can use <em>old</em> editions indefinitely on <em>new</em> compilers; <strong>editions are opt-in</strong>.</li> <li>Editions are set on a <em>per-crate</em> basis and can be mixed and matched; <strong>you can be on a different edition from your dependencies</strong>.</li> <li>Warning-free code in one edition must compile, and have the same behavior, on the next.</li> <li>Edition-related warnings, e.g. that an identifier will become a keyword in the next edition, must be easily fixable via an automated migration tool (rustfix). <strong>Only a small minority of crates should require <em>any</em> manual work to opt in to a new edition</strong>, and that manual work must be minimal.</li> <li>Most new features are edition-independent, and will be usable on new compilers even when an older edition is selected.</li> </ul> <p>In other words, the progression of new compiler versions is independent from editions; you can migrate at your leisure, and don’t have to worry about ecosystem compatibility; and edition migration is normally trivial.</p> <h2 id="additional-2018-goals">Additional 2018 goals</h2> <p>While the Rust 2018 release is our major focus this year, there are some additional ongoing concerns that we want to give attention to.</p> <h3 id="better-serving-intermediate-rustaceans">Better serving intermediate Rustaceans</h3> <p>One of the strongest messages we’ve heard from production users, and <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/09/05/Rust-2017-Survey-Results.html">the 2017 survey</a>, is that people need more resources to take them from understanding Rust’s concepts to knowing how to use them <em>effectively</em>. The roadmap does not stipulate exactly what these resources should look like — <a href="https://quietmisdreavus.net/code/2018/01/10/not-a-layer-cake-analogy/">probably there should be several kinds</a> — but commits us as a community to putting significant work into this space, and ending the year with some solid new material.</p> <h3 id="community">Community</h3> <p><strong>Connect and empower Rust's global community</strong>. We will pursue internationalization as a first-class concern, and proactively work to build ties between Rust subcommunities currently separated by language, geography, or culture. We will spin up and support Rust events worldwide, including further growth of the RustBridge program.</p> <p><strong>Grow Rust's teams and new leaders within them</strong>. We will refactor the Rust team structure to support more scale, agility, and leadership growth. We will systematically invest in mentoring, both by creating more on-ramp resources and through direct mentorship relationships.</p> <h2 id="a-call-to-action">A call to action</h2> <p>As always in the Rust world, the goals laid out here will ultimately be the result of a community-wide effort—maybe one including you! Here are some of the teams where we could use the most help. Note that all IRC channels refer to the irc.mozilla.org network.</p> <ul> <li><strong>WebAssembly WG</strong>. Compiling Rust to WebAssembly should be <em>the</em> best choice for fast code on the Web. Check out <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rust-wasm">rust-lang-nursery/rust-wasm</a> to learn more and get involved!</li> <li><strong>CLI WG</strong>. Writing CLI apps in Rust should be a frictionless experience--from finding the right libraries and writing concise integration tests up to cross-platform distribution. Join us at <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/cli-wg">rust-lang-nursery/cli-wg</a> and help us reach that goal!</li> <li><strong>Embedded Devices WG</strong>. Quality, productivity, accessibility: Rust can change the embedded industry for the better. Let's get this process started in 2018! Join us at <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/embedded-wg">https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/embedded-wg</a></li> <li><strong>Ecosystem WG</strong>. We'll be providing guidance and support to important crates throughout the ecosystem. Drop into the <a href="https://gitter.im/rust-lang/WG-ecosystem">WG-ecosystem room</a> and we'll guide you to places that need help!</li> <li><strong>Dev Tools Team</strong>. There are always interesting things to tackle with developer tools (IDEs, Cargo, rustdoc, Clippy, Rustfmt, custom test frameworks, and more). Drop in to #rust-dev-tools and have a chat with the team!</li> <li><strong>Rustdoc Team</strong>. With your help, we can make documentation better for everyone. Come join us in #rustdoc on IRC, and we can help you get started!</li> <li><strong>Release Team</strong>. Drop by #rust-release on IRC to get involved with regression triage and release production!</li> <li><strong>Community Team</strong>. We've kicked off several new Teams within the Community Team and are eager to add new members: Events, Content, Switchboard, RustBridge, Survey, and Localization! <a href="https://github.com/rust-community/team">Check out our team repo</a> or stop by our IRC channel, #rust-community, to learn more and get involved!</li> </ul> Announcing Rust 1.24.1 Thu, 01 Mar 2018 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-24-1/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-24-1/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce a new version of Rust, 1.24.1. Rust is a systems programming language focused on safety, speed, and concurrency.</p> <p>If you have a previous version of Rust installed via rustup, getting Rust 1.24.1 is as easy as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">rustup</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> update stable </span></pre> <p>If you don't have it already, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">get <code>rustup</code></a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/stable/RELEASES.md#version-1241-2018-03-01">detailed release notes for 1.24.1</a> on GitHub.</p> <h2 id="what-s-in-1-24-1-stable">What's in 1.24.1 stable</h2> <p>Several minor regressions were found in 1.24.0 which collectively merited a release.</p> <p>A quick summary of the changes:</p> <ul> <li>Do not abort when unwinding through FFI (this reverts behavior added in 1.24.0)</li> <li>Emit UTF-16 files for linker arguments on Windows</li> <li>Make the error index generator work again</li> <li>Cargo will warn on Windows 7 if an update is needed.</li> </ul> <p>If your code is continuing to build, then the only issue that may affect you is the unwinding issue. We plan on bringing this behavior back in 1.25 or 1.26, depending on how smoothly the new strategy goes.</p> <p>With that, let's dig into the details!</p> <h3 id="do-not-abort-when-unwinding-through-ffi">Do not abort when unwinding through FFI</h3> <p>TL;DR: the new behavior in 1.24.0 broke the <code>rlua</code> crate, and is being reverted. If you have since changed your code to take advantage of the behavior in 1.24.0, you'll need to revert it for now. While we still plan to introduce this behavior eventually, we will be rolling it out more slowly and with a new implementation strategy.</p> <p>Quoting <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2018/02/15/Rust-1.24.html">the 1.24 annoucement</a>:</p> <blockquote> <p>There’s one other change we’d like to talk about here: undefined behavior. Rust generally strives to minimize undefined behavior, having none of it in safe code, and as little as possible in unsafe code. One area where you could invoke UB is when a panic! goes across an FFI boundary. In other words, this:</p> </blockquote> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">extern </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;C&quot; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">panic_in_ffi</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { panic!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;Test&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); } </span></pre> <blockquote> <p>This cannot work, as the exact mechanism of how panics work would have to be reconciled with how the &quot;C&quot; ABI works, in this example, or any other ABI in other examples.</p> <p>In Rust 1.24, this code will now abort instead of producing undefined behavior.</p> </blockquote> <p>As mentioned above, this caused breakage. It started with <a href="https://github.com/chucklefish/rlua/issues/71">a bug filed against the <code>rlua</code> crate</a>. <code>rlua</code> is a package that provides high level bindings between Rust and the <a href="https://www.lua.org/">Lua programming language</a>.</p> <blockquote> <p>Side note: <code>rlua</code> is maintained by <a href="https://chucklefish.org/">Chucklefish</a>, a game development studio from London that's using Rust. Lua is a very popular language to use for extending and scripting games. We care deeply about production Rust users, and so handling this was a very high priority for the Rust team.</p> </blockquote> <p>On Windows, and only on Windows, any attempt to handle errors from Lua would simply abort. This makes <code>rlua</code> unusable, as any error of any kind within Lua causes your program to die.</p> <p>After digging in, the culpurit was found: <code>setjmp</code>/<code>longjmp</code>. These functions are provided by the C standard library as a means of handling errors. You first call <code>setjmp</code>, and then, at some later point in time, call <code>longjmp</code>. When you do, control flow returns to where you had previously called <code>setjmp</code>. This is often used as a way to implement exceptions, and sometimes, even coroutines. Lua's implementation uses <code>setjmp</code>/<code>longjmp</code> <a href="https://www.lua.org/pil/24.3.html">to implement exceptions</a>:</p> <blockquote> <p>Unlike C++ or Java, the C language does not offer an exception handling mechanism. To ameliorate this difficulty, Lua uses the setjmp facility from C, which results in a mechanism similar to exception handling. (If you compile Lua with C++, it is not difficult to change the code so that it uses real exceptions instead.)</p> </blockquote> <p>The issue is this: what happens when some C code <code>setjmp</code>/<code>longjmp</code>'s through Rust stack frames? Because drop checking and borrow checking know nothing about this style of control flow, if you <code>longjmp</code> across a Rust stack frame that has any type that's not <code>Copy</code> on its stack, undefined behavior will result. However, if the jump happens entirely in C, this should work just fine. This is how <code>rlua</code> was managing it: every call into Lua is <a href="https://www.lua.org/pil/24.3.2.html">wrapped with <code>lua_pcall</code></a>:</p> <blockquote> <p>When you write library functions for Lua, however, there is a standard way to handle errors. Whenever a C function detects an error, it simply calls <code>lua_error</code>, (or better yet <code>luaL_error</code>, which formats the error message and then calls <code>lua_error</code>). The <code>lua_error</code> function clears whatever needs to be cleared in Lua and jumps back to the <code>lua_pcall</code> that originated that execution, passing along the error message.</p> </blockquote> <p>So, the question becomes: Why does this break? And why does it break on Windows?</p> <p>When we talked about <code>setjmp</code>/<code>longjmp</code> inititally, a key phrase here wasn't highlighted. Here it is:</p> <blockquote> <p>After digging in, the culpurit was found: <code>setjmp</code>/<code>longjmp</code>. These functions are <em>provided by the C standard library</em> as a means of handling errors.</p> </blockquote> <p>These functions aren't part of the C language, but part of the standard library. That means that platform authors implement these functions, and their implementations may differ.</p> <p>Windows has a concept called SEH, short for <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/ms680657(v=vs.85).aspx">&quot;Structured Exception Handling&quot;</a>. Windows uses SEH to implement <code>setjmp</code>/<code>longjmp</code>, as the whole idea of SEH is to have uniform error handling. For similar reasons, C++ exceptions use SEH, as do Rust panics.</p> <p>Before we can sort the exact details of what's happening, let's look at how <code>rlua</code> works. <code>rlua</code> has an internal function, <code>protect_lua_call</code>, used to call into Lua. Using it looks like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4271ae;">protect_lua_call</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#c82829;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">.state, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, |</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">state</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">| { ffi::lua_newtable(state); })</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">?</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span></pre> <p>That is, <code>protect_lua_call</code> takes some arguments, one of which is a closure. This closure is passed to <code>lua_pcall</code>, which catches any <code>longjmp</code>s that may be thrown by the code passed to it, aka, that closure.</p> <p>Consider the code above, and imagine that <code>lua_newtable</code> here could call <code>longjmp</code>.
