Here's what should happen:</p> <ol> <li><code>protect_lua_call</code> takes our closure, and passes it to <code>lua_pcall</code>.</li> <li><code>lua_pcall</code> calls <code>setjmp</code> to handle any errors, and invokes our closure.</li> <li>Inside our closure, <code>lua_newtable</code> has an error, and calls <code>longjmp</code>.</li> <li>The initial <code>lua_pcall</code> catches the <code>longjmp</code> with the <code>setjmp</code> it called earlier.</li> <li>Everyone is happy.</li> </ol> <p>However, the implementation of <code>protect_lua_call</code> converts our closure to an <code>extern fn</code>, since that's what Lua needs. So, with the changes in 1.24.0, it sets up a panic handler that will cause an abort. In other words, the code sorta looks something like this pseudo code now:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4271ae;">protect_lua_call</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#c82829;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">.state, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, |</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">state</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">| { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> result </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">panic::catch_unwind(|| { ffi::lua_newtable(state); }); </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">if</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> result.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">is_err</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { process::abort(); } })</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">?</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span></pre> <p>Earlier, when discussing <code>setjmp</code>/<code>longjmp</code>, we said that the issue with it in Rust code is that it doesn't handle Rust destructors. So, on every platform but Windows, the above <code>catch_unwind</code> shenanigans is effectively ignored, so everything works. However, on Windows, since both <code>setjmp</code>/<code>longjmp</code> and Rust panics use SEH, the <code>longjmp</code> gets &quot;caught&quot;, and runs the new abort code!</p> <p>The <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/48572">solution here</a> is to generate the abort handler, but in a way that <code>longjmp</code> won't trigger it. It's not 100% clear if this will make it into Rust 1.25; if the landing is smooth, we may backport, otherwise, this functionality will be back in 1.26.</p> <h3 id="emit-utf-16-files-for-linker-arguments-on-windows">Emit UTF-16 files for linker arguments on Windows</h3> <p>TL;DR: <code>rustc</code> stopped working for some Windows users in edge-case situations. If it's been working for you, you were not affected by this bug.</p> <p>In constrast with the previous bug, which is very complex and tough to understand, this bug's impact is simple: if you have non-ASCII paths in the directory where you invoke <code>rustc</code>, in 1.24, it would incorrectly error with a message like</p> <blockquote> <p>fatal error LNK1181: cannot open input file</p> </blockquote> <p>The PR that caused it, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/47507">#47507</a>, has a good explanation of the behavior that ended up causing the problem:</p> <blockquote> <p>When spawning a linker rustc has historically been known to blow OS limits for the command line being too large, notably on Windows. This is especially true of incremental compilation where there can be dozens of object files per compilation. The compiler currently has logic for detecting a failure to spawn and instead passing arguments via a file instead, but this failure detection only triggers if a process actually fails to spawn.</p> </blockquote> <p>However, when generating that file, we were doing it incorrectly. As <a href="https://docs.microsoft.com/en-gb/cpp/build/reference/unicode-support-in-the-compiler-and-linker#linker-response-files-and-def-files">the docs state</a>:</p> <blockquote> <p>Response files and DEF files can be either UTF-16 with a BOM, or ANSI.</p> </blockquote> <p>We were providing a UTF-8 encoded file, with no <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Byte_order_mark">BOM</a>. The fix is therefore straightforward: produce a UTF-16 file with a BOM.</p> <h3 id="make-the-error-index-generator-work-again">Make the error index generator work again</h3> <p>TL;DR: building Rust 1.24.0 with Rust 1.24.0 broke in some circumstances. If you weren't building Rust yourself, you were not affected by this bug.</p> <p>When packaging Rust for various Linux distros, it was found that <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/48308">building 1.24 with 1.24 fails</a>. This was caused by an incorrect path, causing certain metadata to not be generated properly.</p> <p>As this issue is not particularly interesting, and only affects a small number of people, all of whom should be aware of it by now, we won't go into the details further. To learn more, please check out the issue and the resulting discussion.</p> <h3 id="cargo-will-warn-on-windows-7-if-an-update-is-needed">Cargo will warn on Windows 7 if an update is needed.</h3> <p>TL;DR: Cargo couldn't fetch the index from crates.io if you were using an older Windows without having applied security fixes. If you are using a newer Windows, or a patched Windows, you are not affected by this bug.</p> <p>In February of 2017, <a href="https://githubengineering.com/crypto-deprecation-notice/">GitHub announced that they were dropping support for weak cryptographic standards</a>. One year later, in February of 2018, <a href="https://blog.github.com/2018-02-23-weak-cryptographic-standards-removed/">the deprecation period is over, and support is removed</a>. In general, this is a great thing.</p> <p>Cargo uses GitHub to store the index of Crates.io, our package repository. It also uses <code>libgit2</code> for <code>git</code> operations. <code>libgit2</code> uses <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/aa382925(v=vs.85).aspx">WinHTTP</a> for making HTTP calls. As part of the OS, its feature set depends on the OS you're using.</p> <blockquote> <p>This section uses &quot;Windows 7&quot; to mean &quot;Windows 7, Windows Server 2018, and Windows Server 2012&quot;, because it's much shorter. The following applies to all three of these editions of Windows, however.</p> </blockquote> <p>Windows 7 <a href="https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/3140245/update-to-enable-tls-1-1-and-tls-1-2-as-a-default-secure-protocols-in">received an update</a> in June of 2016 regarding TLS. Before the patch, Windows 7 would use TLS 1.0 by default. This update allows for applications to use TLS 1.1 or 1.2 natively instead.</p> <p>If your system has not received that update, then you'd still be using TLS 1.0. This means that accessing GitHub would start to fail.</p> <p><code>libgit2</code> <a href="https://github.com/libgit2/libgit2/pull/4550">created a fix</a>, using the <code>WinHTTP</code> API to request TLS 1.2. On master, we've <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/5091">updated to fix this</a>, but for 1.24.1 stable, we're <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/5069">issuing a warning</a>, suggesting that they upgrade their Windows version. Although the <code>libgit2</code> fix could have been backported, we felt that the code change footprint was too large for the point release, especially since the issue does not affect patched systems.</p> <h2 id="contributors-to-1-24-1">Contributors to 1.24.1</h2> <p><a href="https://thanks.rust-lang.org/rust/1.24.1">Thanks!</a></p> Announcing Rust 1.24 Thu, 15 Feb 2018 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-24/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-24/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce a new version of Rust, 1.24.0. Rust is a systems programming language focused on safety, speed, and concurrency.</p> <p>If you have a previous version of Rust installed via rustup, getting Rust 1.24.0 is as easy as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">rustup</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> update stable </span></pre> <p>If you don't have it already, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">get <code>rustup</code></a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1240-2018-02-15">detailed release notes for 1.24.0</a> on GitHub.</p> <h2 id="what-s-in-1-24-0-stable">What's in 1.24.0 stable</h2> <p>This release contains two very exciting new features: <code>rustfmt</code> and incremental compilation!</p> <h4 id="rustfmt">rustfmt</h4> <p>For years now, we've wanted a tool that automatically can reformat your Rust code to some sort of &quot;standard style.&quot; With this release, we're happy to announce that a <em>preview</em> of <code>rustfmt</code> can be used with 1.24 stable. To give it a try, do this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">rustup</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> component add rustfmt-preview </span></pre> <p>There are two important aspects here: first, you're using <code>rustup component add</code> instead of <code>cargo install</code> here. If you've previously used <code>rustfmt</code> via <code>cargo install</code>, you should uninstall it first. Second, this is a preview, as it says in the name. <code>rustfmt</code> is not at 1.0 yet, and some stuff is being tweaked, and bugs are being fixed. Once <code>rustfmt</code> hits 1.0, we'll be releasing a <code>rustfmt</code> component and deprecating <code>rustfmt-preview</code>.</p> <p>In the near future, we plan on writing a post about this release strategy, as it's big enough for its own post, and is broader than just this release.</p> <p>For more, please check out <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rustfmt"><code>rustfmt</code> on GitHub</a>.</p> <h4 id="incremental-compilation">Incremental compilation</h4> <p>Back in September of 2016 (!!!), we blogged about <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2016/09/08/incremental.html">Incremental Compilation</a>. While that post goes into the details, the idea is basically this: when you're working on a project, you often compile it, then change something small, then compile again. Historically, the compiler has compiled your <em>entire</em> project, no matter how little you've changed the code. The idea with incremental compilation is that you only need to compile the code you've actually changed, which means that that second build is faster.</p> <p>As of Rust 1.24, this is now <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/4817">turned on by default</a>. This means that your builds should get faster! Don't forget about <code>cargo check</code> when trying to get the lowest possible build times.</p> <p>This is still not the end story for compiler performance generally, nor incremental compilation specifically. We have a lot more work planned in the future. For example, another change related to performance hit stable this release: <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/46910"><code>codegen-units</code> is now set to 16 by default</a>. One small note about this change: it makes builds faster, but makes the final binary a bit slower. For maximum speed, setting <code>codegen-units</code> to <code>1</code> in your <code>Cargo.toml</code> is needed to eke out every last drop of performance.</p> <p>More to come!</p> <h4 id="other-good-stuff">Other good stuff</h4> <p>There's one other change we'd like to talk about here: undefined behavior. Rust generally strives to minimize undefined behavior, having none of it in safe code, and as little as possible in unsafe code. One area where you could invoke UB is when a <code>panic!</code> goes across an FFI boundary. In other words, this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">extern </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;C&quot; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">panic_in_ffi</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { panic!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;Test&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); } </span></pre> <p>This cannot work, as the exact mechanism of how panics work would have to be reconciled with how the <code>&quot;C&quot;</code> ABI works, in this example, or any other ABI in other examples.</p> <p>In Rust 1.24, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/46833">this code will now abort</a> instead of producing undefined behavior.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1240-2018-02-15">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h3 id="library-stabilizations">Library stabilizations</h3> <p>If you're a fan of <code>str::find</code>, which is used to find a given <code>char</code> inside of a <code>&amp;str</code>, you'll be happy to see this pull request: <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/46735">it's now 10x faster</a>! This is thanks to <code>memchr</code>. <code>[u8]::contains</code> <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/46713">uses it too</a>, though it doesn't get such an extreme speedup.</p> <p>Additionally, a few new APIs were stabilized this release:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/cell/struct.RefCell.html#method.replace"><code>RefCell::replace</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/cell/struct.RefCell.html#method.swap"><code>RefCell::swap</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/sync/atomic/fn.spin_loop_hint.html"><code>std::sync::atomic::spin_loop_hint</code></a></li> </ul> <p>Finally, these functions may now be used inside a constant expression, for example, to initialize a <code>static</code>:</p> <ul> <li><code>Cell</code>, <code>RefCell</code>, and <code>UnsafeCell</code>'s <code>new</code> functions</li> <li>The <code>new</code> functions of the various <code>Atomic</code> integer types</li> <li><code>{integer}::min_value</code> and <code>max_value</code></li> <li><code>mem</code>'s <code>size_of</code> and <code>align_of</code></li> <li><code>ptr::null</code> and <code>null_mut</code></li> </ul> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1240-2018-02-15">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h3 id="cargo-features">Cargo features</h3> <p>The big feature of this release was turning on incremental compilation by default, as mentioned above.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1240-2018-02-15">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h2 id="contributors-to-1-24-0">Contributors to 1.24.0</h2> <p>Many people came together to create Rust 1.24. We couldn't have done it without all of you. <a href="https://thanks.rust-lang.org/rust/1.24.0">Thanks!</a></p> The 2018 Rust Event Lineup Wed, 31 Jan 2018 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/the-2018-rust-event-lineup/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/the-2018-rust-event-lineup/ <p>Every year there are multiple Rust events around the world, bringing together the community. Despite being early in the year, we're excited to be able to highlight several events that are already being organized!</p> <p>This year, one of the Rust Team's primary goals is to <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/2314/files#diff-1c2d6aba093cfb7e02ac5e1597207c41R13"><strong>&quot;Connect and empower Rust’s global community.&quot;</strong></a>. We'll be working throughout the year to encourage and support Rust events all over the globe.</p> <p>As always, there are nearly a hundred <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/en-US/user-groups.html">Rust User Groups</a> worldwide. If you haven't already, take a look at the <a href="https://calendar.google.com/calendar/embed?src=apd9vmbc22egenmtu5l6c5jbfc@group.calendar.google.com">Rust Community calendar</a>, to see if there's an upcoming event near you.</p> <p>If you are already running a Rust event or are interested in starting one, email the <a href="mailto:community-team@rust-lang.org">Rust Community Team</a>! We can offer you support and guidance, as well as advertise the event in blog posts like these.</p> <hr /> <h3 id="february-1-4-mozilla-rust-roadshow-brasil-2018">February 1-4: Mozilla Rust Roadshow Brasil 2018</h3> <p>The Mozilla Rust Roadshow Brasil is a series of workshops that will happen throughout the country between February 1st and 4th to broaden the adoption of Rust in Brazil. The project is organized by developers and community leaders, contributing along with Mozilla Brasil community organizers.</p> <p>Find more about who's leading and contributing to the Mozilla Rust Roadshow Brasil 2018 in <a href="https://mozillabr.org/2018/01/adding-superheroes-to-the-rust-brazilian-community/">Adding Superheroes to the Rust Brazilian Community</a>.</p> <p>Learn about the workshops and where they are happening on <a href="https://rust-br.github.io/2018-roadshow/">the Roadshow website</a>.</p> <h3 id="february-3-4-fosdem-rust-dev-room">February 3-4: FOSDEM - Rust Dev Room</h3> <p>After a very successful <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birds_of_a_feather_(computing)">Birds of a Feather</a> session for Rust last year at FOSDEM, this year will have the first edition of the <a href="https://rust-fosdem.github.io/">Rust Dev Room</a>. Co-located with <a href="https://fosdem.org/2018/">FOSDEM 2018</a>, the annual conference about free and open source software, it will bring together the Rust community in <strong>Brussels, Belgium</strong>.</p> <p>A fully packed Sunday brings you 16 talks covering topics ranging from GUI programming, robotics and multimedia to idiomatic Rust, testing and memory management. Check out <a href="https://fosdem.org/2018/schedule/track/rust/">the full devroom schedule</a>.</p> <h3 id="may-26-27-rustfest-paris">May 26-27: RustFest Paris</h3> <p>The fourth iteration of RustFest will happen on May 26th and 27th in <strong>Paris, France</strong>. Once again there will be a full day of talks and a second day with multiple workshops, allowing you to learn, connect and code together with other Rustaceans.</p> <p>The CfP and ticket sales will open soon. Keep an eye on <a href="http://rustfest.eu">rustfest.eu</a>, get all updates on the <a href="http://blog.rustfest.eu/">blog</a> and don’t forget to follow <a href="https://twitter.com/rustfest">@rustfest</a> on Twitter. Want to get a glimpse into what it's like? Check out last year's videos from <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AHprJNUCgQ0&amp;list=PL85XCvVPmGQhvs1Rnet_24B-AI3YSM2YG">Kyiv</a> or <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jywiVWKm1TI&amp;list=PL85XCvVPmGQj9mqbJizw-zi-EhcpS5jTP">Zurich</a>!</p> <h3 id="august-16-17-rustconf">August 16-17: RustConf</h3> <p><a href="http://rustconf.com/">RustConf</a> is a two-day event held in <strong>Portland, OR, USA</strong> on August 16-17.</p> <p>The first day will again offer tutorials on Rust given directly by members of the Rust core team, ranging from absolute basics to advanced ownership techniques. The second day is the main event, with talks at every level of expertise, so don't miss the CfP to submit your talk soon!</p> <p>More details will be available on <a href="http://rustconf.com/">rustconf.com</a>. You can also follow <a href="https://twitter.com/rustconf">@rustconf</a> on Twitter for all announcements.</p> <h3 id="october-rust-belt-rust">October: Rust Belt Rust</h3> <p><a href="https://www.rust-belt-rust.com/">Rust Belt Rust</a> will have its third iteration this year in October. You can once again expect two days of talks and workshops.</p> <p>More details will come soon. Follow <a href="https://twitter.com/rustbeltrust">@rustbeltrust</a> on Twitter for the latest news.</p> Announcing Rust 1.23 Thu, 04 Jan 2018 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-23/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-23/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce a new version of Rust, 1.23.0. Rust is a systems programming language focused on safety, speed, and concurrency.</p> <p>If you have a previous version of Rust installed via rustup, getting Rust 1.23.0 is as easy as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">rustup</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> update stable </span></pre> <p>If you don't have it already, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">get <code>rustup</code></a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1230-2018-01-04">detailed release notes for 1.23.0</a> on GitHub.</p> <h2 id="what-s-in-1-23-0-stable">What's in 1.23.0 stable</h2> <p>New year, new Rust! For our first improvement today, we now <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/45380">avoid some unnecessary copies</a> in certain situations. We've seen memory usage of using <code>rustc</code> to drop 5-10% with this change; it may be different with your programs.</p> <p>The documentation team has been on a long journey to move <code>rustdoc</code> to use <a href="http://commonmark.org/">CommonMark</a>. Previously, <code>rustdoc</code> never guaranteed which markdown rendering engine it used, but we're finally committing to CommonMark. As part of this release, we render the documentation with our previous renderer, <a href="https://github.com/hoedown/hoedown">Hoedown</a>, but also render it with a CommonMark compliant renderer, and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/45324">warn if there are any differences</a>. There should be a way for you to modify the syntax you use to render correctly under both; we're not aware of any situations where this is impossible. Docs team member Guillaume Gomez has <a href="https://blog.guillaume-gomez.fr/articles/2017-09-18+New+rustdoc+rendering+common+errors">written a blog post</a> showing some common differences and how to solve them. In a future release, we will switch to using the CommonMark renderer by default. This <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/41991">warning landed in nightly in May of last year</a>, and has been on by default <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/45324">since October of last year</a>, so many crates have already fixed any issues that they've found.</p> <p>In other documentation news, historically, Cargo's docs have been a bit strange. Rather than being on <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org">doc.rust-lang.org</a>, they've been at <a href="http://doc.crates.io">doc.crates.io</a>. With this release, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/45692">that's changing</a>. You can now find Cargo's docs at <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo">doc.rust-lang.org/cargo</a>. Additionally, they've been converted to the same format as our other long-form documentation. We'll be adding a redirect from <code>doc.crates.io</code> to this page, and you can expect to see more improvements and updates to Cargo's docs throughout the year.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1230-2018-01-04">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h3 id="library-stabilizations">Library stabilizations</h3> <p>As of Rust 1.0, a trait named <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/ascii/trait.AsciiExt.html"><code>AsciiExt</code></a> existed to provide ASCII related functionality on <code>u8</code>, <code>char</code>, <code>[u8]</code>, and <code>str</code>. To use it, you'd write code like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">use </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">std::ascii::AsciiExt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> ascii </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&#39;a&#39;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> non_ascii </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&#39;❤&#39;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> int_ascii </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">97</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; assert!(ascii.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">is_ascii</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">()); assert!(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">!</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">non_ascii.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">is_ascii</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">()); assert!(int_ascii.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">is_ascii</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">()); </span></pre> <p>In Rust 1.23, these methods are now defined directly on those types, and so you no longer need to import the trait. Thanks to our stability guarantees, this trait still exists, so if you'd like to still support Rust versions before Rust 1.23, you can do this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">#[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">allow</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(unused_imports)] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">use </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">std::ascii::AsciiExt; </span></pre> <p>…to suppress the related warning. Once you drop support for older Rusts, you can remove both lines, and everything will continue to work.</p> <p>Additionally, a few new APIs were stabilized this release:</p> <ul> <li>The various <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/sync/atomic/index.html#structs"><code>std::sync::atomic types</code></a> now implement <code>From</code> their non-atomic types. For example, <code>let x = AtomicBool::from(true);</code>.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/45379"><code>()</code> now implements <code>FromIterator&lt;()&gt;</code></a>; check the PR for a neat use-case.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/45682"><code>RwLock&lt;T&gt;</code> has had its <code>Send</code> restriction lifted</a></li> </ul> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1230-2018-01-04">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h3 id="cargo-features">Cargo features</h3> <p><code>cargo check</code> can now <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/4592">check your unit tests</a>.</p> <p><code>cargo uninstall</code> can now <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/4561">uninstall more than one package in one command</a>.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1230-2018-01-04">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h2 id="contributors-to-1-23-0">Contributors to 1.23.0</h2> <p>Many people came together to create Rust 1.23. We couldn't have done it without all of you. <a href="https://thanks.rust-lang.org/rust/1.23.0">Thanks!</a></p> New Year's Rust: A Call for Community Blogposts Wed, 03 Jan 2018 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/new-years-rust-a-call-for-community-blogposts/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/new-years-rust-a-call-for-community-blogposts/ <p>'Tis the season for people and communities to reflect and set goals- and the Rust team is no different. Last month, we published <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/12/21/rust-in-2017.html">a blogpost about our accomplishments in 2017</a>, and the teams have already begun brainstorming goals for next year.</p> <p>Last year, the Rust team started a new tradition: defining a roadmap of goals for the upcoming year. We leveraged our <a href="https://github.com/aturon/rfcs/blob/roadmap-2017/text/0000-roadmap-2017.md">RFC process</a> to solicit community feedback. While we got a lot of awesome feedback on that RFC, we'd like to try something new <strong>in addition to</strong> the RFC process: a call for community blog posts for ideas of what the goals should be.</p> <p>As open source software becomes more and more ubiquitous and popular, the Rust team is interested in exploring new and innovative ways to solicit community feedback and participation. We're commited to extending and improving our community organization and outreach- and this effort is just the first of what we hope to be many iterations of new kinds of community feedback mechanisms.</p> <h2 id="rust2018">#Rust2018</h2> <p>Starting today and running until the end of January we'd like to ask the community to write blogposts reflecting on Rust in 2017 and proposing goals and directions for Rust in 2018. These can take many forms:</p> <ul> <li>A post on your personal or company blog</li> <li>A Medium post</li> <li>A GitHub gist</li> <li>Or any other online writing platform you prefer.</li> </ul> <p>We're looking for posts on many topics: </p> <ul> <li>Ideas for community programs</li> <li>Language features</li> <li>Documentation improvements</li> <li>Ecosystem needs</li> <li>Tooling enhancements</li> <li>Or anything else Rust related you hope for in 2018 :D</li> </ul> <p>A great example of what we're looking for is this post, <a href="https://mgattozzi.com/rust-wasm">&quot;Rust and the case for WebAssembly in 2018&quot;</a> by <a href="https://github.com/mgattozzi">@mgattozzi</a> or this post, <a href="https://medium.com/@Hisako1337/rust-in-2017-8f2b57a67d9b">&quot;Rust in 2017&quot;</a> by <a href="https://github.com/Anonyfox">Anonyfox</a>.</p> <p>You can write up these posts and email them to <a href="mailto:community@rust-lang.org">community@rust-lang.org</a> or tweet them with the hashtag <a href="https://twitter.com/search?q=%23Rust2018"><code>#Rust2018</code></a>. We'll aggregate any blog posts sent via email or with the hashtag in one big blog post here. </p> <p>The Core team will be reading all of the submitted posts and using them to inform the initial roadmap RFC for 2018. Once the RFC is submitted, we'll open up the normal RFC process, though if you want, you are welcome to write a post and link to it on the GitHub discussion.</p> <h2 id="preliminary-timeline">Preliminary Timeline</h2> <p>We hope to get a draft roadmap RFC posted in mid January, so blog posts written before then would be the most useful. We expect discussion and final comment period of that RFC to last through at least the end of January, though, so blog posts until then will also be considered for ideas.</p> <p>Dates are likely to change, but this is a general overview of the upcoming process:</p> <ul> <li><strong>Jan 3</strong>: call for posts!</li> <li><strong>throughout Jan</strong>: read current posts, draft roadmap RFC</li> <li><strong>mid Jan</strong>: post roadmap RFC on GitHub</li> <li><strong>late Jan</strong>: evaluate roadmap based on RFC comments</li> <li><strong>late Jan - early Feb</strong>: final RFC comment period</li> <li><strong>Feb</strong>: assuming discussion has reached a steady state, and we've found consensus, accept final roadmap</li> </ul> <p>So, as we kick off 2018, if you find yourself in a reflective mood and your mind drifts to the future of Rust, please write up your thoughts and share them! We're excited to hear where <em>you</em> want Rust to go this coming year!</p> Rust in 2017: what we achieved Thu, 21 Dec 2017 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-in-2017/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-in-2017/ <p>Rust’s development in 2017 fit into a single overarching theme: <strong>increasing productivity, especially for newcomers to Rust</strong>. From tooling to libraries to documentation to the core language, we wanted to make it easier to get things done with Rust. That desire led to <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/02/06/roadmap.html">a roadmap</a> for the year, setting out 8 high-level objectives that would guide the work of the team.</p> <p>How’d we do? <em><strong>Really, really well</strong></em>.</p> <p>There’s not room in a single post to cover everything that happened, but we’ll cover some of the highlights below.</p> <h1 id="the-goals-for-2017">The goals for 2017</h1> <h2 id="rust-should-have-a-lower-learning-curve">Rust should have a lower learning curve</h2> <ul> <li><strong>Books</strong> <ul> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/second-edition/">The Rust Programming Language</a> is largely in the final stages of editing. Steve and Carol are grateful for everyone who has read the drafts and provided feedback! <a href="https://www.nostarch.com/rust">Preorder the print edition from No Starch Press</a>, scheduled for release in May 2018.</li> <li><a href="http://shop.oreilly.com/product/0636920040385.do">Programming Rust</a> by Jim Blandy and Jason Orendorff is available in print as of December 21, 2017!</li> <li><a href="https://www.manning.com/books/rust-in-action">Rust in Action</a> by Tim McNamara is in Manning’s Early Access Program, with an estimated publication date of early 2019.</li> </ul> </li> <li><strong>RustBridge curriculum</strong> <ul> <li><a href="https://rustbridge.github.io/">RustBridge workshops</a> are focused on getting underrepresented people into Rust. Ashley Williams has vastly improved <a href="https://rustbridge.github.io/a-very-brief-intro-to-rust/#1">the workshop curriculum</a> this year, and we’re planning on having a teacher training in early 2018. The curriculum is available for anyone to use, as long as events are only called RustBridge if they focus on underrepresented folks. See more about RustBridge in 2017 under the Mentorship goal!</li> </ul> </li> <li><strong>Language improvements</strong> <ul> <li>The <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/03/02/lang-ergonomics.html">Ergonomics Initiative</a> saw a large number of RFCs tackling rough edges across the language; the <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/09/18/impl-future-for-rust.html">Impl Period</a> then saw almost all of these RFCs implemented. These improvements cover ownership (<a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/2094">more flexible lifetimes</a>, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/2005">smoother pattern matching</a>, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/2115">more concise elision</a>), the module system (<a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/2126">revamping paths for greater clarity</a>, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/2128">allowing nested imports</a>), the trait system (<a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1951"><code>impl Trait</code></a>, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1733">trait aliases</a>) and more. <strong>You can get an overview of all of these changes, and their current status, on <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/46889">the tracking issue</a></strong>. Altogether, these changes should eliminate or mitigate many of the most common learnability and ergonomics hazards that have been surfaced since Rust 1.0.</li> </ul> </li> </ul> <h2 id="rust-should-have-a-pleasant-edit-compile-debug-cycle">Rust should have a pleasant edit-compile-debug cycle</h2> <ul> <li><strong>The <code>cargo check</code> workflow</strong> <ul> <li>Cargo <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/03/16/Rust-1.16.html">now offers</a> a <code>check</code> subcommand which can be used to speed up the edit-compile cycle when you’re working on getting your code to pass the compiler’s checks. This mode, in particular, skips producing executable artifacts for crates in the dependency tree, instead doing just enough work to be able to type check the current crate.</li> </ul> </li> <li><strong>Incremental recompilation</strong> <ul> <li>The cornerstone of our approach to improving compilation times is incremental recompilation, allowing rebuilds to reuse significant pieces of work from prior compilations. Over the course of the year we have put a lot of work into making this happen and now we are happy to announce that incremental compilation will <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/10/30/Stability.html">start riding the trains</a> with the next beta version of the compiler in January and become available on the stable channel with Rust 1.24 in February!</li> <li>You can see how incremental recompilation performs in practice on some of our key benchmarks below. Note that <code>-opt</code> refers to optimized builds, “best case” refers to a recompilation with no changes, and <code>println</code> refers to a recompilation with a small change, like adding a <code>println</code> call to a function body. We expect the 50+% speedups we’re seeing now to continue to grow next year as we push incremental recompilation more deeply through the compiler.</li> <li>Together with the changes in the compiler we will also update Cargo to use incremental recompilation by default for select use cases, so you can take advantage of improved compile times without the need for additional configuration. Of course you will also be able to opt into and out of the feature on a case by case basis as you see fit.</li> </ul> </li> </ul> <p><img src="/images/2017-12-Retro/incr-bench.png" alt="Incremental recompilation benchmarks" /></p> <h2 id="rust-should-provide-a-solid-but-basic-ide-experience">Rust should provide a solid, but basic IDE experience</h2> <ul> <li>Rust now has solid IDE support in IntelliJ and via the Rust Language Server (RLS). Whether you prefer a fully-featured IDE or a more lightweight editor with IDE features, you can boost your productivity by taking advantage of great Rust integration.</li> <li><strong>IntelliJ</strong>. Rust has official support in <a href="https://blog.jetbrains.com/blog/2017/08/04/official-support-for-open-source-rust-plugin-for-intellij-idea-clion-and-other-jetbrains-ides/">JetBrains' IDEs</a> (IntelliJ IDEA, CLion, WebStorm, etc.), which includes: <ul> <li>Finding types, functions and traits across the whole project, its dependencies and the standard library.</li> <li>Hierarchical overview of the symbols defined in the current file.</li> <li>Search for all implementations of a given trait.</li> <li>Go to definition of symbol at cursor.</li> <li>Navigation to the parent module.</li> <li>Refactoring and code generation</li> </ul> </li> <li><strong>RLS</strong>. The <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rls">RLS</a> is an editor-independent source of intelligence about Rust programs. It is used to power Rust support in many editors including <a href="https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=rust-lang.rust">Visual Studio Code</a>, <a href="https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=DanielGriffen.Rust">Visual Studio</a>, and <a href="https://atom.io/packages/ide-rust">Atom</a>, with more in the pipeline. It is on schedule for a 1.0 release in early 2018, but is currently <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/10/12/Rust-1.21.html">available in preview form</a> for all channels (nightly, beta, and stable). It supports: <ul> <li>Code completion (using Racer)</li> <li>Go to definition (and peek definition if the editor supports it)</li> <li>Find all references</li> <li>Find impls for a type or trait</li> <li>Symbol search (current file and project)</li> <li>Reformatting using rustfmt, renaming</li> <li>Apply error suggestions (e.g., to add missing imports)</li> <li>Docs and types on hover</li> <li>Code generation using snippets</li> <li>Cargo tasks</li> <li>Installation and update of the RLS (via rustup)</li> </ul> </li> </ul> <h2 id="rust-should-integrate-easily-into-large-build-systems">Rust should integrate easily into large build systems</h2> <ul> <li><strong>Alternative registries.</strong> Cargo now has unstable support for <a href="http://rust-lang.github.io/rfcs/2141-alternative-registries.html">installing crates from registries other than crates.io</a>. This will enable companies to manage and use internal crates as easily as open source crates. Work is underway developing crate servers that are more tailored for private use than the crates.io server is.</li> <li><strong>Cargo as a component</strong>. A lot of work this year went into gathering constraints from stakeholders who want to integrate Rust crates into a large existing build system (like <a href="https://bazel.build/">Bazel</a>). The Cargo team has <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/2136">formulated a vision</a> of Cargo as a suite of components that can be customized or swapped out, making it easy for an external build system to manage the work it is built to do, while still integrating with crates.io and with Cargo workflows. While we did not get as far as we hoped in terms of implementing this vision, there is ongoing work spiking out “build plan generation” to a sufficient degree that it can support the Firefox build system and <a href="http://gittup.org/tup/">Tup</a>. This initial spike should provide a good strawman for further iteration in early 2018.</li> </ul> <h2 id="rust-should-provide-easy-access-to-high-quality-crates">Rust should provide easy access to high quality crates</h2> <ul> <li>Crates.io added <a href="https://crates.io/categories">categories</a> this year, which aim to provide a crate organization structure targeted towards providing crates that are good for a particular purpose.</li> <li>We had a <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1824">lively RFC discussion</a> about the best way to order crates within categories and keywords, which included <a href="http://rust-lang.github.io/rfcs/1824-crates.io-default-ranking.html#appendix-user-research">a survey of how people evaluate crates</a>.</li> <li>That discussion culminated in a decision to <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io/issues/702">order crates by the number of downloads in the last 90 days</a>, and surfacing of more information for people to use when doing their evaluation.</li> <li>Some of the additional information now available for crate authors to display on crates.io includes badges for CI status, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io/issues/704">maintenance status</a>, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io/issues/706">code coverage</a>, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io/issues/705">GitHub statistics</a>.</li> <li>Most importantly, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io/issues/81">crates.io now displays a crate’s README on the crate page</a>! Crate authors are encouraged to use this capability to provide getting started documentation with a small example of what it looks like to use this crate, because good documentation and examples were among the most-mentioned positive signals that people take into account when evaluating crates.</li> </ul> <h2 id="rust-should-be-well-equipped-for-writing-robust-servers">Rust should be well-equipped for writing robust servers</h2> <ul> <li><strong>Futures and Tokio</strong> <ul> <li>Much of the story for Rust on the server has revolved around its async I/O story. The futures crate <a href="http://aturon.github.io/blog/2016/08/11/futures/">was introduced</a> in late 2016, and the Tokio project (which provides a networking-focused event loop for use with futures) <a href="https://tokio.rs/blog/tokio-0-1/">published its 0.1</a> early in 2017. Since then, there’s been significant work building out the “Tokio ecosystem”, and a lot of feedback about the core primitives. Late in the year, the Tokio team proposed a <a href="https://github.com/tokio-rs/tokio-rfcs/pull/3">significant API revamp</a> to streamline and clarify the crate’s API, and work is underway on a book dedicated to asynchronous programming in Rust. This latest round of work is expected to land very early in 2018.</li> </ul> </li> <li><strong>Async ecosystem</strong> <ul> <li>There’s been huge growth in the ecosystem around Tokio, including support for <a href="https://github.com/tokio-rs/tokio-curl">curl</a>, <a href="https://github.com/alexcrichton/tokio-openssl">openssl</a>, <a href="https://github.com/dermesser/tokio-inotify">inotify</a>, <a href="https://github.com/alexcrichton/tokio-signal">unix signals</a>, <a href="https://github.com/dwrensha/capnproto-rust">cap’n proto</a>, <a href="https://crates.io/crates/tk-sendfile">sendfile</a>, <a href="https://crates.io/crates/tokio-postgres">postgres</a>, <a href="https://crates.io/crates/couchbase">couchbase</a>, and more. In addition, Rust has async server libraries for both <a href="http://hyper.rs/">HTTP1</a> and <a href="https://github.com/carllerche/h2">HTTP2.</a></li> </ul> </li> <li><strong>Generators</strong> <ul> <li>Thanks to a heroic community effort, Rust also saw <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/2033">experimental generator support</a> land in 2017! That support provides the ingredients necessary for <code>async</code>/<code>await</code> notation, which is <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/help-test-async-await-generators-coroutines/5835">usable today</a> on nightly. Further work in this area is expected to be a high priority in early 2018.</li> </ul> </li> <li><strong>Web frameworks</strong> <ul> <li>Finally, sophisticated web frameworks like <a href="https://rocket.rs/">Rocket</a> (sync) and <a href="http://gotham.rs/">Gotham</a> (async) have continued to evolve this year, and take advantage of Rust’s expressivity to provide a robust but productive style of programming.</li> </ul> </li> </ul> <h2 id="rust-should-have-1-0-level-crates-for-essential-tasks">Rust should have 1.0-level crates for essential tasks</h2> <ul> <li><strong>Libz Blitz</strong>. The library team launched the <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/05/05/libz-blitz.html">Libz Blitz</a> this year, a major effort to vet and improve a large number of foundational crates and push them toward 1.0 releases. It was a massive community effort: we performed a crowd-sourced “crate evaluation” every two weeks, fully vetting a crate against a clear set of guidelines, assessing the issue tracker, and sussing out any remaining design questions. While not all of the assessed crates have published a 1.0 yet, they are all very close to doing so. The full list includes: <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/log/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+label%3A%22help+wanted%22">log</a>, <a href="https://github.com/sebasmagri/env_logger/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+label%3A%22help+wanted%22">env_logger</a>, <a href="https://github.com/nikomatsakis/rayon/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+label%3A%22help+wanted%22">rayon</a>, <a href="https://github.com/carllerche/mio/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&amp;q=is%3Aissue%20is%3Aopen%20label%3A%22help%20wanted%22%20">mio</a>, <a href="https://github.com/servo/rust-url/issues/319">url</a>, <a href="https://github.com/seanmonstar/num_cpus/issues/55">num_cpus</a>, <a href="https://github.com/steveklabnik/semver/issues/139">semver</a>, <a href="https://github.com/hyperium/mime/labels/help%20wanted">mime</a>, <a href="https://github.com/seanmonstar/reqwest/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+label%3Aeasy">reqwest</a>, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/tempdir/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+label%3A%22help+wanted%22">tempdir</a>, <a href="https://github.com/rust-threadpool/rust-threadpool/issues/86">threadpool</a>, <a href="https://github.com/BurntSushi/byteorder/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&amp;q=is%3Aissue%20is%3Aopen%20label%3A%22help%20wanted%22%20">byteorder</a>, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/bitflags/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&amp;q=is%3Aissue%20is%3Aopen%20label%3A%22help%20wanted%22%20">bitflags</a>, <a href="https://github.com/alexcrichton/cc-rs">cc-rs</a>, <a href="https://github.com/BurntSushi/walkdir/issues/47">walkdir</a>, <a href="https://crates.io/crates/same-file">same-file</a>, <a href="https://crates.io/crates/memmap">memmap</a>, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/lazy-static.rs/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&amp;q=is%3Aopen%20is%3Aissue%20label%3A%22help%20wanted%22%20">lazy_static</a>, <a href="https://github.com/alexcrichton/flate2-rs/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+label%3A%22help+wanted%22">flate2</a>.</li> <li><strong>API Guidelines</strong>. A great by-product of the Libz Blitz is the <a href="https://rust-lang-nursery.github.io/api-guidelines/">API Guidelines</a> book, which consolidates the official library team API guidance as informed by the standard library and the Libz Blitz process.</li> </ul> <h2 id="rust-s-community-should-provide-mentoring-at-all-levels">Rust’s community should provide mentoring at all levels</h2> <ul> <li>We ran 5 <a href="https://rustbridge.github.io/">RustBridge Workshops</a> in 2017, in Kyiv, Ukraine; Mexico City, Mexico; Portland, OR, USA; Zurich, Switzerland; and Columbus, OH, USA! RustBridge workshops aim to get underrepresented folks started in Rust. Attendees get an introduction to syntax and concepts, work on some <a href="http://exercism.io/">exercism</a> exercises, and build a web application that delivers emergency compliments and crab pictures. We hope to scale this program and help more folks run more workshops in 2018!</li> <li>The <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/06/27/Increasing-Rusts-Reach.html">Increasing Rust’s Reach program</a> brought people with skills from other areas (such as teaching) and with different experiences into Rust so that we can improve in areas where the community is missing these skills and experiences. The participants have helped immensely, and many are planning to continue helping in the Rust community going forward. We’re glad they’re here! Here are some blog posts about the experience: <ul> <li>Anna Liao: <a href="https://medium.com/@aliao22/increasing-rusts-reach-porting-a-python-application-to-rust-60eaf92d891b">Increasing Rust’s Reach: Porting a Python application to Rust</a></li> <li>Ryan Blecher: <a href="http://notryanb.github.io/increasing-rusts-reach.html">Increasing Rust's Reach: Afterthoughts</a> We learned a lot in the first incarnation of this program, and we have plans for another round in 2018!</li> </ul> </li> <li>Last but not least, we also launched the first Rust <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/09/18/impl-future-for-rust.html"><code>impl Period</code></a>. This was an ambitious effort to simultaneously help get a lot of new people contributing to the Rust ecosystem while also getting a lot of things done. To that end, we created 40+ working groups, each with their own focus area, leaders, and chat channel. These groups identified good “entry points” for people who wanted to contribute, and helped mentor them through the changes needed. This event was a wild success and resulted in changes and contributions to all areas of Rust, ranging from the compiler internals to documentation to the ecosystem at large. To those of you who participated, a great big thank you — and please keep contributing! To those of you who didn’t get a chance, don’t worry: we hope to make this a regular tradition.</li> </ul> <h1 id="2018">2018</h1> <p>We’ll be spinning up the 2018 roadmap process in the very near future; watch this space!</p> <h1 id="thank-you">Thank you!</h1> <p>We got a staggering amount of work done this year — and the “we” here includes an equally staggering number of people. Because the work has been spread out over so many facets of the project, it’s hard to provide a single list of people who contributed. For the impl period specifically, you can see detailed contribution lists in the newsletters:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/the-impl-period-newsletter-week-1/5971">Newsletter 1</a></li> <li><a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/the-impl-period-newsletter-2/6034">Newsletter 2</a></li> <li><a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/impl-period-newsletter-3/6185">Newsletter 3</a></li> <li><a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/the-impl-period-newsletter-4/6313">Newsletter 4</a></li> <li><a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/the-final-impl-period-newsletter/6408">Newsletter 5</a></li> </ul> <p>but of course, there have been contributions of all kinds during the year.</p> <p>In this post, I’d like to specifically call out the <em><strong>leaders</strong></em> and <em><strong>mentors</strong></em> who have helped orchestrate our 2017 work. Leadership of this kind — where you are working to enable others — is hard work and not recognized enough. So let’s hand it to these folks!</p> <ul> <li><strong>Cargo</strong> <ul> <li><a href="https://github.com/carols10cents">carols10cents</a>, for sustained leadership and mentoring work throughout the year on crates.io.</li> </ul> </li> <li><strong>Community</strong> <ul> <li><a href="https://github.com/carols10cents">carols10cents</a>, for running the <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/06/27/Increasing-Rusts-Reach.html">Increasing Rust’s Reach</a> program.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/ashleygwilliams">ashleygwilliams</a>, for overhauling the <a href="https://rustbridge.github.io/">RustBridge</a> curriculum and otherwise driving the program forward.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/jonathandturner/">jonathandturner</a>, for overseeing the <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/09/05/Rust-2017-Survey-Results.html">2017 Rust community survey</a>.</li> </ul> </li> <li><strong>Compiler</strong> <ul> <li><a href="https://github.com/nikomatsakis/">nikomatsakis</a>, for an incredible amount of leadership, organization, and mentoring work, <em>and</em> for a lot of high-value hacking on NLL in particular.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/arielb1/">arielb1</a>, likewise for mentoring <em>and</em> hacking work, spanning both NLL and the rest of the compiler.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/michaelwoerister/">michaelwoerister</a>, for pushing continuously on delivering incremental recompilation, and creating opportunities for others to join in throughout the year.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/eddyb">eddyb</a>, for continuing to act as a general compiler guru, and for tackling some truly heavy lifts around const generics this year.</li> </ul> </li> <li><strong>Dev tools</strong> <ul> <li><a href="https://github.com/nrc/">nrc</a>, for overseeing the dev tools group as a whole, and for steady work toward shipping the RLS and rustfmt, despite many thorny infrastructure problems to get there.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/matklad">matklad</a>, for the incredible work on <a href="https://github.com/intellij-rust/intellij-rust/blob/master/CONTRIBUTORS.txt">IntelliJ Rust</a><a href="https://github.com/intellij-rust/intellij-rust/blob/master/CONTRIBUTORS.txt">.</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/xanewok">xanewok</a>, for <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rls/graphs/contributors">enormous efforts</a> making the RLS a reality.</li> <li><a href="http://github.com/fitzgen">fitzgen</a>, for happily corralling a huge contributor base around <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rust-bindgen">bindgen</a>.</li> </ul> </li> <li><strong>Docs</strong> <ul> <li><a href="https://github.com/steveklabnik/">steveklabnik</a>, for launching and overseeing a hugely exciting revamp of rustdoc.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/QuietMisdreavus">quietmisdreavus</a>, for overseeing tons of activity in the docs world, but most especially for helping the community significantly improve rustdoc this year.</li> </ul> </li> <li><strong>Infrastructure</strong> <ul> <li><a href="https://github.com/Mark-Simulacrum">mark-simulacrum</a>, for getting the <a href="https://perf.rust-lang.org/">perf</a> website to a highly useful state, and for overhauling rustbuild to better support contribution.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/aidanhs/">aidanhs</a>, for coordinating maintenance of crater.</li> </ul> </li> <li><strong>Language</strong> <ul> <li><a href="https://github.com/withoutboats/">withoutboats</a>, for keeping us focused on the programmer experience and for helping the community navigate discussion around very thorny language design issues.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/cramertj/">cramertj</a>, for keeping us focused on <em>shipping</em>, and in particular building consensus around some of the topics where that’s been hardest to find: impl Trait, and module system changes.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/nikomatsakis/">nikomatsakis</a>, for making the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/2094">NLL RFC</a> so accessible, and pioneering the idea of using a separate repo for it to allow for greater participation.</li> </ul> </li> <li><strong>Libraries</strong> <ul> <li><a href="https://github.com/brson/">brson</a>, for envisioning and largely overseeing the Libz Blitz initiative.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/kodraus">kodraus</a>, for gracefully taking over the Libz Blitz and seeing it to a successful conclusion.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/dtolnay">dtolnay</a>, for taking on the API guidelines work and getting it to a coherent and polished state.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/budziq">budziq</a>, for a ton of work coordinating and editing contributions to the cookbook.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/dhardy">dhardy</a>, for leading a heroic effort to revamp the rand crate.</li> </ul> </li> </ul> <p>Technical leaders are an essential ingredient for our success, and I hope in 2018 we can continue to grow our leadership pool, and get even more done — together.</p> Announcing Rust 1.22 (and 1.22.1) Wed, 22 Nov 2017 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-22/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-22/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce <em>two</em> new versions of Rust, 1.22.0 and 1.22.1. Rust is a systems programming language focused on safety, speed, and concurrency.</p> <blockquote> <p>Wait, two versions? At the last moment, we <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/46183">discovered a late-breaking issue with the new macOS High Sierra</a> in 1.22.0, and for various reasons, decided to release 1.22.0 as usual, but also put out a 1.22.1 with the patch. The bug is actually in Cargo, not <code>rustc</code>, and only affects users on macOS High Sierra.</p> </blockquote> <p>If you have a previous version of Rust installed via rustup, getting Rust 1.22.1 is as easy as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">rustup</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> update stable </span></pre> <p>If you don't have it already, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">get <code>rustup</code></a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1220-2017-11-22">detailed release notes for 1.22.0</a> and 1.22.1 on GitHub.</p> <h2 id="what-s-in-1-22-0-and-1-22-1-stable">What's in 1.22.0 and 1.22.1 stable</h2> <p>The headline feature for this release is one many have been anticipating for a long time: you can now <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/42526">use <code>?</code> with <code>Option&lt;T&gt;</code></a>! About a year ago, in <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2016/11/10/Rust-1.13.html">Rust 1.13</a>, we introduced the <code>?</code> operator for working with <code>Result&lt;T, E&gt;</code>. Ever since then, there's been discussion about how far <code>?</code> should go: should it stay only for results? Should it be user-extensible? Should it be usable with <code>Option&lt;T&gt;</code>?</p> <p>In Rust 1.22, basic usage of <code>?</code> with <code>Option&lt;T&gt;</code> is now stable. This code will now compile:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">add_one_to_first</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">list</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u8</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">]) -&gt; Option&lt;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u8</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&gt; { </span><span style="color:#999999;">// get first element, if exists // return None if it doesn&#39;t </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> first </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> list.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">get</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">)</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">?</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Some</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(first </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) } assert_eq!(</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">add_one_to_first</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">10</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">20</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">30</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">]), </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Some</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">11</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">)); assert_eq!(</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">add_one_to_first</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[]), </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">None</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); </span></pre> <p>However, this functionality is still a bit limited; you cannot yet write code that mixes results and options with <code>?</code> in the same function, for example. This will be possible in the future, and already is in nightly Rust; expect to hear more about this in a future release.</p> <p>Types that implement <code>Drop</code> are <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/44456">now allowed in <code>const</code> and <code>static</code> items</a>. Like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Foo { </span><span style="color:#c82829;">a</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">impl </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Drop </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">for </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Foo { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">drop</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">mut </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) {} } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">const</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> F: Foo </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> Foo { a: </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">}; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">static</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> S: Foo </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> Foo { a: </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">}; </span></pre> <p>This change doesn't bring much on its own, but as we improve our ability to compute things at compile-time, more and more will be possible in <code>const</code> and <code>static</code>.</p> <p>Additionally, some small quality-of-life improvements:</p> <p><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/45075">Two</a> recent <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/45064">compiler changes</a> should speed up compiles in debug mode. We don't have any specific numbers to commit to with these changes, but as always, compile times are very important to us, and we're continuing to work on improving them.</p> <p><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/44287"><code>T op= &amp;T</code> now works for primitive types</a>, which is a fancy way of saying:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">let mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> y </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= &amp;</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">8</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#999999;">// this didn&#39;t work, but now does </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+=</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> y; </span></pre> <p>Previously, you'd have needed to write <code>x += *y</code> in order to de-reference, so this solves a small papercut.</p> <p><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/44251">Backtraces are improved on MacOS</a>.</p> <p>You can now <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/43949">create <code>compile-fail</code> tests in Rustdoc</a>, like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">/// ```compile_fail /// let x = 5; /// x += 2; // shouldn&#39;t compile! /// ``` </span></pre> <p>Please note that these kinds of tests can be more fragile than others, as additions to Rust may cause code to compile when it previously would not. Consider the first announcement with <code>?</code>, for example: that code would fail to compile on Rust 1.21, but compile successfully on Rust 1.22, causing your test suite to start failing.</p> <p>Finally, we <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/45041">removed support for the <code>le32-unknown-nacl</code> target</a>. Google itself <a href="https://blog.chromium.org/2017/05/goodbye-pnacl-hello-webassembly.html">has deprecated PNaCl</a>, instead throwing its support behind <a href="http://webassembly.org/">WebAssembly</a>. You can already compile Rust code to WebAssembly today, and you can expect to hear more developments regarding this in future releases.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1220-2017-11-22">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h3 id="library-stabilizations">Library stabilizations</h3> <p>A few new APIs were stabilized this release:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/44466"><code>Box&lt;Error&gt;</code> now impls <code>From&lt;Cow&lt;str&gt;&gt;</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/45095"><code>std::mem::Discriminant</code> is now guaranteed to be <code>Send + Sync</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/44895"><code>fs::copy</code> now returns the length of the main stream on NTFS.</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/44220">Properly detect overflow in <code>Instant += Duration</code>.</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/44015">impl <code>Hasher</code> for <code>{&amp;mut Hasher, Box&lt;Hasher&gt;}</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/44303">impl <code>fmt::Debug</code> for <code>SplitWhitespace</code>.</a></li> </ul> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1220-2017-11-22">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h3 id="cargo-features">Cargo features</h3> <p>If you have a big example to show your users, Cargo has grown the ability to <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/4496">build multi-file examples</a> by creating a subdirectory inside <code>examples</code> that contains a <code>main.rs</code>.</p> <p>Cargo now has the ability to <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/3992">vendor git repositories</a>.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1220-2017-11-22">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h2 id="contributors-to-1-22-0-and-1-22-1">Contributors to 1.22.0 and 1.22.1</h2> <p>Many people came together to create Rust 1.22. We couldn't have done it without all of you. <a href="https://thanks.rust-lang.org/rust/1.22.0">Thanks!</a> (and <a href="https://thanks.rust-lang.org/rust/1.22.1">Thanks again!</a>)</p> Fearless Concurrency in Firefox Quantum Tue, 14 Nov 2017 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/fearless-concurrency-in-firefox-quantum/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/fearless-concurrency-in-firefox-quantum/ <p>&quot;</p> <p>These days, Rust is used for <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/friends.html">all kinds of things</a>. But its founding application was <a href="https://servo.org/">Servo</a>, an experimental browser engine. </p> <p>Now, after years of effort, a major part of Servo is shipping in production: Mozilla is releasing <a href="https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/quantum/">Firefox Quantum</a>!</p> <p>Rust code <a href="https://hacks.mozilla.org/2016/07/shipping-rust-in-firefox/">began shipping in Firefox</a> last year, starting with relatively small pilot projects like an MP4 metadata parser to replace some uses of libstagefright. These components performed well and caused effectively no crashes, but browser development had yet to see large benefits from the full power Rust could offer. This changes today.</p> <h1 id="stylo-a-parallel-css-engine">Stylo: a parallel CSS engine</h1> <p>Firefox Quantum includes Stylo, a pure-Rust CSS engine that makes full use of Rust’s “<a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2015/04/10/Fearless-Concurrency.html">Fearless Concurrency</a>” to speed up page styling. It’s the first major component of Servo to be integrated with Firefox, and is a major milestone for Servo, Firefox, and Rust. It replaces approximately 160,000 lines of C++ with 85,000 lines of Rust.</p> <p>When a browser is loading a web page, it looks at the CSS and parses the rules. It then determines which rules apply to which elements and their precedence, and “cascades” these down the DOM tree, computing the final style for each element. Styling is a top-down process: you need to know the style of a parent to calculate the styles of its children, but the styles of its children can be calculated independently thereafter.</p> <p>This top-down structure is ripe for parallelism; however, since styling is a complex process, it’s hard to get right. Mozilla made two previous attempts to parallelize its style system in C++, and both of them failed. But Rust’s fearless concurrency has made parallelism practical! We use <a href="https://crates.io/crates/rayon">rayon</a> —one of the hundreds of <a href="http://crates.io/">crates</a> Servo uses from Rust’s ecosystem — to drive a work-stealing cascade algorithm. You can read more about that in <a href="https://hacks.mozilla.org/2017/08/inside-a-super-fast-css-engine-quantum-css-aka-stylo/">Lin Clark’s post</a>. Parallelism leads to a lot of performance improvements, including a 30% page load speedup for Amazon’s homepage.</p> <h1 id="fearless-concurrency">Fearless concurrency</h1> <p>An example of Rust preventing thread safety bugs is how style information is shared in Stylo. Computed styles are grouped into “style structs” of related properties, e.g. there’s one for all the font properties, one for all the background properties, and so on. Now, most of these are shared; for example, the font of a child element is usually the same as its parent, and often sibling elements share styles even if they don’t have the same style as the parent. Stylo uses Rust’s atomically reference counted <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/sync/struct.Arc.html"><code>Arc&lt;T&gt;</code></a> to share style structs between elements. <code>Arc&lt;T&gt;</code> makes its contents immutable, so it’s thread safe — you can’t accidentally modify a style struct when there’s a chance it is being used by other elements.</p> <p>We supplement this immutable access with <code>Arc::make_mut()</code>; for example, <a href="https://github.com/servo/servo/blob/657b2339a1e68f3a9c4525f35db023d3f149ffac/components/style/values/computed/font.rs#L182">this line</a> calls <code>.mutate_font()</code> (a thin wrapper around <code>Arc::make_mut()</code> for the font style struct) to set the font size. If the given element is the only element that has a reference to this specific font struct, it will just mutate it in place. But if it is not, <code>make_mut()</code> will copy the entire style struct into a new, unique reference, which will then be mutated in place and eventually stored on the element.</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">context.builder.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">mutate_font</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">().</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">set_font_size</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(computed); </span></pre> <p>On the other hand, Rust guarantees that it is impossible to mutate the style of the <em>parent</em> element, because it is <a href="https://github.com/servo/servo/blob/657b2339a1e68f3a9c4525f35db023d3f149ffac/components/style/properties/properties.mako.rs#L2623-L2627">kept behind an immutable reference</a>. Rayon’s scoped threading functionality makes sure that there is no way for that struct to even obtain/store a mutable reference if it wanted to. The parent style is something which one thread was allowed to write to to create (when the parent element was being processed), after which everyone is only allowed to read from it. You’ll notice that the reference is a zero-overhead “borrowed pointer”, <em>not</em> a reference counted pointer, because Rust and Rayon let you share data across threads without needing reference counting when they can guarantee that the data will be alive at least as long as the thread.</p> <p>Personally, my “aha, I now fully understand the power of Rust” moment was when thread safety issues cropped up on the C++ side. Browsers are complex beings, and despite Stylo being Rust code, it needs to call back into Firefox’s C++ code a lot. Firefox has a single “main thread” per process, and while it does use other threads they are relatively limited in what they do. Stylo, being quite parallel, occasionally calls into C++ code off the main thread. That was usually fine, but would regularly surface thread safety bugs in the C++ code when there was a cache or global mutable state involved, things which basically never were a problem on the Rust side.</p> <p>These bugs were not easy to notice, and were often very tricky to debug. And that was with only the <em>occasional</em> call into C++ code off the main thread; It feels like if we had tried this project in pure C++ we’d be dealing with this far too much to be able to get anything useful done. And indeed, bugs like these have thwarted multiple attempts to parallelize styling in the past, both in Firefox and other browsers.</p> <h1 id="rust-s-productivity">Rust’s productivity</h1> <p>Firefox developers had a great time learning and using Rust. People really enjoyed being able to aggressively write code without having to worry about safety, and many mentioned that Rust’s ownership model was close to how they implicitly reason about memory within Firefox’s large C++ codebase. It was refreshing to have fuzzers catch mostly explicit <em>panics</em> in Rust code, which are much easier to debug and fix than segfaults and other memory safety issues on the C++ side.</p> <p>A conversation amongst Firefox developers that stuck with me — one that was included in Josh Matthews’ <a href="https://www.joshmatthews.net/rbr17">talk</a> at Rust Belt Rust — was</p> <blockquote> <p>&lt;heycam&gt; one of the best parts about stylo has been how much easier it has been to implement these style system optimizations that we need, because Rust</p> <p>&lt;heycam&gt; can you imagine if we needed to implement this all in C++ in the timeframe we have</p> <p>&lt;heycam&gt; yeah srsly</p> <p>&lt;bholley&gt; heycam: it's so rare that we get fuzz bugs in rust code</p> <p>&lt;bholley&gt; heycam: considering all the complex stuff we're doing</p> <p>*heycam remembers getting a bunch of fuzzer bugs from all kinds of style system stuff in gecko</p> <p>&lt;bholley&gt; heycam: think about how much time we could save if each one of those annoying compiler errors today was swapped for a fuzz bug tomorrow :-)</p> <p>&lt;heycam&gt; heh</p> <p>&lt;njn&gt; you guys sound like an ad for Rust</p> </blockquote> <h1 id="wrapping-up">Wrapping up</h1> <p>Overall, Firefox Quantum benefits significantly from Stylo, and thus from Rust. Not only does it speed up page load, but it also speeds up interaction times since styling information can be recalculated much faster, making the entire experience smoother.</p> <p>But Stylo is only the beginning. There are two major Rust integrations getting close to the end of the pipeline. One is integrating <a href="https://github.com/servo/webrender/">Webrender</a> into Firefox; Webrender <a href="https://hacks.mozilla.org/2017/10/the-whole-web-at-maximum-fps-how-webrender-gets-rid-of-jank/">heavily uses the GPU to speed up rendering</a>. Another is <a href="https://github.com/pcwalton/pathfinder">Pathfinder</a>, a project that offloads font rendering to the GPU. And beyond those, there remains Servo’s parallel layout and DOM work, which are continuing to grow and improve. Firefox has a very bright future ahead.</p> <p>As a Rust team member, I’m really happy to see Rust being successfully used in production to such great effect! As a Servo and Stylo developer, I’m grateful to the tools Rust gave us to be able to pull this off, and I’m happy to see a large component of Servo finally make its way to users!</p> <p>Experience the benefits of Rust yourself — try out <a href="https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/quantum/">Firefox Quantum</a>!</p> Announcing Rust 1.21 Thu, 12 Oct 2017 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-21/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-21/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce the latest version of Rust, 1.21.0. Rust is a systems programming language focused on safety, speed, and concurrency.</p> <p>If you have a previous version of Rust installed, getting Rust 1.21 is as easy as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">rustup</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> update stable </span></pre> <p>If you don't have it already, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">get <code>rustup</code></a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1210-2017-10-12">detailed release notes for 1.21.0</a> on GitHub.</p> <h3 id="what-s-in-1-21-0-stable">What's in 1.21.0 stable</h3> <p>This release contains some very minor, but nice-to-have features, as well as some new documentation.</p> <p>First up, a small change to literals. Consider code like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= &amp;</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">5</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span></pre> <p>In Rust, this code is synonymous with:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> _x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">5</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= &amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">_x; </span></pre> <p>That is, the <code>5</code> here will be stored on the stack, or possibly in registers. <code>x</code> will be a reference to it.</p> <p>However, given that it's a literal integer, there's no reason that it <em>has</em> to be local like this. Imagine we had a function that took a <code>'static</code> argument, like <code>std::thread::spawn</code>.
