You might use <code>x</code> like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">use </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">std::thread; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= &amp;</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">5</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; thread::spawn(</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">move </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">|| </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, x); }); } </span></pre> <p>In previous versions of Rust, this would fail to compile:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">error[E0597]: borrowed value does not live long enough --&gt; src/main.rs:4:14 | 4 | let x = &amp;5; | ^ does not live long enough ... 10 | } | - temporary value only lives until here | = note: borrowed value must be valid for the static lifetime... </span></pre> <p>Because the <code>5</code> is local, so is its borrow, which doesn't satisfy the requirements for <code>spawn</code>.</p> <p>However, if you compile this on Rust 1.21, it will work. Why? Well, if the thing being referred to is okay to put into a <code>static</code>, we could instead de-sugar <code>let x = &amp;5;</code> like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">static </span><span style="color:#666969;">FIVE</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">5</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= &amp;</span><span style="color:#666969;">FIVE</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span></pre> <p>Here, since the <code>FIVE</code> is <code>static</code>, <code>x</code> is a <code>&amp;'static i32</code>. And so this is what Rust will now do in this kind of case. For full details, see <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/1414-rvalue_static_promotion.md">RFC 1414</a>, which was accepted in January, but started in December of 2015!</p> <p>We <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/43506">now run LLVM in parallel while generating code</a>, which should reduce peak memory usage.</p> <p>The <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rls/">RLS</a> can now be installed <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/44204">through rustup</a> by invoking <code>rustup component add rls-preview</code>. In general, many useful Rust developer tools such as the RLS, Clippy, and <code>rustfmt</code> need nightly Rust; this is the first steps toward having them work on stable Rust. Please check out the preview, and you'll hear more about these plans in the future.</p> <p>Finally, a few documentation improvements. First up, if you visit <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/std/os/">the docs for <code>std::os</code></a>, which contains operating system specific functionality, you'll now see more than just <code>linux</code>, the platform we build the documentation on. We've long regretted that the hosted version of the documentation has been Linux-specific; this is a first step towards rectifying that. This is <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/43348">specific to the standard library</a> and not for general use; we hope to improve this further in the future.</p> <p>Next, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/43916">Cargo's docs are moving!</a> Historically, Cargo's docs were hosted on doc.crates.io, which doesn't follow the release train model, even though Cargo itself does. This led to situations where a feature would land in Cargo nightly, the docs would be updated, and then for up to twelve weeks, users would <em>think</em> that it should work, but it wouldn't yet. <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo">https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo</a> will be the new home of Cargo's docs, though for now, that URL is a redirect to doc.crates.io. Future releases will move Cargo's docs over, and at that point, doc.crates.io will redirect to doc.rust-lang.org/cargo. Cargo's docs have long needed a refreshing, so expect to hear more news about Cargo's docs generally in the future!</p> <p>Finally, until now, <code>rustdoc</code> did not have any documentation. This is now <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/43863">fixed</a>, with a new &quot;<code>rustdoc</code> Book,&quot; located at <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/rustdoc">https://doc.rust-lang.org/rustdoc</a>. These docs are fairly bare-bones at the moment, but we'll be improving them over time.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1210-2017-10-12">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h4 id="library-stabilizations">Library stabilizations</h4> <p>Not too many stabilizations this release, but there's one really great quality of life change: due to the lack of type-level integers, arrays only supported various traits up to size 32. This <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/43690">has now been fixed for the <code>Clone</code> trait</a>, which also caused a lot of ICEs at times, when a type would be <code>Copy</code> but not <code>Clone</code>. For other traits, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/2000-const-generics.md">an RFC for type-level integers was accepted recently</a>, which may help with this situation. That change has yet to be implemented, however, though pre-requisite work is ongoing at the moment.</p> <p>Next, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/44567"><code>Iterator::for_each</code></a> has been stabilized, letting you consume an iterator for side effects without needing a <code>for</code> loop:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#999999;">// old </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">for</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> i </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">in </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">..</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">10 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, i); } </span><span style="color:#999999;">// new </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">..</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">10</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">).</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">for_each</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(|</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">i</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">| println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, i)); </span></pre> <p>The correct one to use depends on your situation; in the sample above, the <code>for</code> loop is pretty straightforward. But when you're chaining a number of iterators together, the <code>for_each</code> version is sometimes clearer. Consider this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#999999;">// old </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">for</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> i </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">in </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">..</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">100</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">).</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">map</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(|</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">x</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">| x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">).</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">filter</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(|</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">x</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">| x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">% </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">== </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) { println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, i); } </span><span style="color:#999999;">// new </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">..</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">100</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) .</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">map</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(|</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">x</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">| x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) .</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">filter</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(|</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">x</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">| x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">% </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">== </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) .</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">for_each</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(|</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">i</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">| println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, i)); </span></pre> <p><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/42565"><code>Rc&lt;T&gt;</code> and <code>Arc&lt;T&gt;</code> now implement <code>From&lt;&amp;[T]&gt; where T: Clone</code>, <code>From&lt;str&gt;</code>, <code>From&lt;String&gt;</code>, <code>From&lt;Box&lt;T&gt;&gt; where T: ?Sized</code>, and <code>From&lt;Vec&lt;T&gt;&gt;</code>.</a></p> <p>The <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/44593"><code>max</code> and <code>min</code> functions on the <code>Ord</code> trait</a> are now stable.</p> <p>The <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/44639"><code>needs_drop</code> intrinsic</a> is now stable.</p> <p>Finally, <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/mem/fn.discriminant.html"><code>std::mem::discriminant</code> has been stabilized</a>, allowing you to see what variant an <code>enum</code> instance is without a <code>match</code> statement.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1210-2017-10-12">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h4 id="cargo-features">Cargo features</h4> <p>Beyond the documentation features listed above, Cargo is gaining one major feature in this release: <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/4123"><code>[patch]</code></a>. Designed in <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/1969-cargo-prepublish.md">RFC 1969</a>, the <code>[patch]</code> section of your <code>Cargo.toml</code> can be used when you want to override certain parts of your dependency graph. We also have a feature, <code>[replace]</code> that has similar functionality. In many ways, <code>[patch]</code> is the new <code>[replace]</code>, and while we have no plans to deprecate or remove <code>[replace]</code>, at this point, you should use <code>[patch]</code> instead of <code>[replace]</code>.</p> <p>So what's it look like? Let's say we have a <code>Cargo.toml</code> that looks like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">dependencies</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#c82829;">foo </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;1.2.3&quot; </span></pre> <p>In addition, our <code>foo</code> crate depends on a <code>bar</code> crate, and we find a bug in <code>bar</code>. To test this out, we'd download the source code for <code>bar</code>, and then update our <code>Cargo.toml</code>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">dependencies</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#c82829;">foo </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;1.2.3&quot; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">patch.crates-io</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#c82829;">bar </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= { </span><span style="color:#c82829;">path </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&#39;/path/to/bar&#39; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p>Now, when you <code>cargo build</code>, it will use the local version of <code>bar</code>, rather than the one from <code>crates.io</code> that <code>foo</code> depends on.</p> <p>For more details, see the <a href="http://doc.crates.io/manifest.html#the-patch-section">documentation</a>.</p> <p>Additionally:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/4216">you can now <code>cargo install</code> multiple crates at once</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/4335">If you're in a virtual workspace, <code>--all</code> is now applied automatically</a>.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/4270"><code>include</code> and <code>exclude</code> fields in your <code>Cargo.toml</code> accepts patterns similar to a <code>.gitignore</code></a>.</li> </ul> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1210-2017-10-12">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h3 id="contributors-to-1-21-0">Contributors to 1.21.0</h3> <p>Many people came together to create Rust 1.21. We couldn't have done it without all of you. <a href="https://thanks.rust-lang.org/rust/1.21.0">Thanks!</a></p> impl Future for Rust Mon, 18 Sep 2017 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/impl-future-for-rust/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/impl-future-for-rust/ <p>The Rust community has been hard at work on our <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1774">2017 roadmap</a>, but as we come up on the final quarter of the year, we're going to kick it into high gear—and we want you to join us!</p> <p>Our goals for the year are ambitious:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/3">Rust should have a lower learning curve</a>.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/1">Rust should have a pleasant edit-compile-debug cycle</a>.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/2">Rust should provide a solid, but basic IDE experience</a>.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/9">Rust should provide easy access to high quality crates</a>.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/10">Rust should be well-equipped for writing robust, high-scale servers</a>.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/11">Rust should have 1.0-level crates for essential tasks</a>.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/12">Rust should integrate easily into large build systems</a>.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/13">Rust's community should provide mentoring at all levels</a></li> </ul> <p><strong>To finish off these goals, we intend to spend the rest of the year focused purely on &quot;implementation&quot; work—which doesn't just mean code!</strong> In particular, we are effectively spinning down the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs#rust-rfcs">RFC process</a> for 2017, after having merged <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pulls?utf8=%E2%9C%93&amp;q=is%3Apr%20merged%3A%3E2017-01-01">almost 90</a> RFCs this year!</p> <p>So here's the plan. Each Rust team has put together several <em>working groups</em> focused on a specific sub-area. Each WG has a leader who is responsible for carving out and coordinating work, and a dedicated chat channel for getting involved. We are working hard to divvy up work items into many shapes and sizes, and to couple them with mentoring instructions and hands-on mentors. <strong>So if you've always wanted to contribute to Rust but weren't sure how, this is the perfect opportunity for you.</strong> Don't be shy—we want and need your help, and, as per our roadmap, our aim is mentoring at <em>all</em> levels of experience. To get started, say hello in the chat rooms for any of the work groups you're interested in!</p> <h2 id="a-few-points-of-order">A few points of order</h2> <p>There are a few online venues for keeping in the loop with working group activity:</p> <ul> <li> <p>There is a <a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/">dedicated Gitter community</a> with channels for each working group, as well as a <a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/Lobby">global channel</a> for talking about the process as a whole, or getting help finding your way to a working group. <strong>For those who prefer IRC, a good <a href="https://irc.gitter.im/">bridge</a> is available</strong>!</p> </li> <li> <p>The brand-new <a href="https://www.rustaceans.org/findwork">findwork</a> site, which provides an entry point to a number of open issues across the Rust project, including those managed by working groups (see the &quot;impl period&quot; tab). Thanks, @nrc, for putting this together!</p> </li> </ul> <p>We also plan two in-person events, paired with upcoming Rust conferences. Each of them is a two-day event populated in part by Rust core developers; come hang out and work together!</p> <ul> <li><a href="http://blog.rustfest.eu/this-week-in-rustfest-9-impl-days">October 2-3 at RustFest</a>.</li> <li><a href="https://goo.gl/forms/e9hmmsFw4owhhDf62">October 24-25 at Rust Belt Rust</a>.</li> </ul> <p>As usual, all of these venues abide by the <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/conduct.html">Rust code of conduct</a>. But more than that: this &quot;impl period&quot; is a chance for us all to have fun <em>collaborating</em> and <em>helping</em> each other, and those participating in the official venues are expected to meet the highest standards of behavior.</p> <h2 id="the-working-groups">The working groups</h2> <p>Without further ado, here's the initial lineup! (A few more working groups are expected to arise over time.)</p> <p><strong>If you find a group that interests you, please say hello in the corresponding chat room!</strong></p> <h3 id="compiler-team">Compiler team</h3> <table> <tr> <td><b>WG-compiler-errors</b></td> <td>Make Rust's error messages even friendlier.</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Compiler-errors-FSZdfXAGo3uMQ1wuDcZcy">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-compiler-errors">Chat</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td><b>WG-compiler-front</b></td> <td>Dip your toes in with parsing and syntax sugar.</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Parser-and-Name-Resolution-Front-end-b0SZiNroIE1HK3lHKm8k7">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-compiler-front">Chat</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td><b>WG-compiler-middle</b></td> <td>Implement features that involve typechecking.</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Middle-Type-checker-XEPTHIWvzlvqkSC3cluTr">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-compiler-middle">Chat</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td><b>WG-compiler-traits</b></td> <td>Want generic associated types? You know what to do.</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Trait-system-LCgNlSbM5cPOyEyWdoqzW">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-compiler-traits">Chat</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td><b>WG-compiler-incr</b></td> <td>Finish incremental compilation; receive undying love.</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Incremental-Compilation-GtIsqsyiXfiyzOh99xp9R">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-compiler-incr">Chat</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td><b>WG-compiler-nll</b></td> <td>Delve into the bowels of borrowck to slay the beast: NLL!</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Non-Lexical-Lifetimes-u5uc6VxJic67K2ynmTiFV">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-compiler-nll">Chat</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td><b>WG-compiler-const</b></td> <td>Const generics. Enough said.</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Const-system-hNGg3H7sqnHb6nf39zpwl">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-compiler-const">Chat</a></td> </tr> </table> <h3 id="libs-team">Libs team</h3> <table> <tr> <td><b>WG-libs-blitz</b></td> <td>Help finish off the Blitz before all the issues are gone!</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/libz-blitz-ymXpoWVNDwVDigdrJ5o49">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-libz-blitz">Chat</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td><b>WG-libs-cookbook</b></td> <td>Work on bite-sized examples to get folks cooking with Rust.</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Rust-cookbook-DFaopl45jyZGWKI6iFDwD">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-libs-cookbook">Chat</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td><b>WG-libs-guidelines</b></td> <td>Take the wisdom from the Blitz and pass it on.</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/API-Guidelines-bDAAOER4WHdxJ1XtEAFYs">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-libs-guidelines">Chat</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td><b>WG-libs-simd</b></td> <td>Provide access to hardware parallelism in Rust! </td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/simd-9H0xb83w1TD8Tc1yEG75M">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-libs-simd">Chat</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td><b>WG-libs-openssl</b></td> <td>Want better docs for openssl? So do we.</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/OpenSSL-crate-FRMKrV0PjCVqFSBHfmNS5">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-libs-openssl">Chat</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td><b>WG-libs-rand</b></td> <td>Craft a stable, core crate for randomness.</td> <td><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/2152">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-libs-rand">Chat</a></td> </tr> </table> <h3 id="docs-team">Docs team</h3> <table> <tr> <td><b>WG-docs-rustdoc</b></td> <td>Help make docs beautiful for everyone!</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Rustdoc-issue-roundup-ZSIIXNDGEPozTM9axn0BO">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-docs-rustdoc">Chat</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td><b>WG-docs-rustdoc2</b></td> <td>Get in on a bottom-up revamp of rustdoc!</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/WG-rustdoc2-3lxugWOmvpXC2eMaAQK04">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-docs-rustdoc2">Chat</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td><b>WG-docs-rbe</b></td> <td>Teach others Rust in the browser.</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/WG-rbe-Tgd0wu70N6zSmACkNL3TI">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-docs-rbe">Chat</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td><b>WG-docs-checklist</b></td> <td>Help finish the standard library documentation!</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Finish-the-docs-checklist-WG-docs-checklist-7CiH332jWblQUTqUOVXaZ">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-docs-checklist">Chat</a></td> </tr> </table> <h3 id="dev-tools-team">Dev tools team</h3> <table> <tr> <td><b>WG-dev-tools-rls</b></td> <td>Help make Rust's IDE experience first class.</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Rust-Language-Server-RLS-XQbsngZNog9pkt0AfcMo7">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-dev-tools-rls">Chat</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td><b>WG-dev-tools-vscode</b></td> <td>Improve Rust's IDE experience for VSCode.</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Rust-support-in-Visual-Studio-Code-RZ34qWGwy04Xwc82NFi78">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-dev-tools-vscode">Chat</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td><b>WG-dev-tools-clients</b></td> <td>Implement new RLS clients: Atom, Sublime, Visual Studio...</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/New-RLS-clients-VrtQKnZR4r3uLD1VBypRI">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-dev-tools-clients">Chat</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td><b>WG-dev-tools-IntelliJ</b></td> <td>Polish up an already-rich Rust IDE experience.</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Intellij-Rust-IYJGtI7uAjdqr2igv4Y7r">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-dev-tools-IntelliJ">Chat</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td><b>WG-dev-tools-rustfmt</b></td> <td>Make Rust's code the prettiest!</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/rustfmt-7yTxFPEHtV6jktqZ2pRj1">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-dev-tools-rustfmt">Chat</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td><b>WG-dev-tools-rustup</b></td> <td>Make Rust's first impression even better!</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/rustup-mngGQUtX1UkBay3wgOGJi">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-dev-tools-rustup">Chat</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td><b>WG-dev-tools-clippy</b></td> <td>It looks like you're trying to write a linter. Want help?</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Clippy-integration-and-improvements-gebwGlwNOoy6UGLspGO4T">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-dev-tools-clippy">Chat</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td><b>WG-dev-tools-bindgen</b></td> <td>Make FFI'ing to C and C++ easy, automatic, and robust!</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/bindgen-xTXplHlfqJpnDvPhMqmfW">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-dev-tools-bindgen">Chat</a></td> </tr> </table> <h3 id="cargo-team">Cargo team</h3> <table> <tr> <td><b>WG-cargo-native</b></td> <td>Let's make native dependencies as painless as we can.</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Declarative-native-dependencies-iLRUq6Zt2tPtLWE9IyLqS">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-cargo-native">Chat</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td><b>WG-cargo-registries</b></td> <td>Going beyond crates.io to support custom registries.</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Cargo-Multiple-Registries-IrW9bRuZ1rdc4o9UPdQM9">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-cargo-registries">Chat</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td><b>WG-cargo-pub-deps</b></td> <td>Teach Cargo which of your dependencies affects your users.</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Cargo-pubpriv-dependencies-JDXpDtGRnz8CY3KYlcUBD">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-cargo-pub-deps">Chat</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td><b>WG-cargo-integration</b></td> <td>How easy can it be to use Cargo with your build system?</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Cargo-build-system-integration-1sqRG8uyCqxv9EfoS8cco">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-cargo-integration">Chat</a></td> </tr> </table> <h3 id="infrastructure-team">Infrastructure team</h3> <table> <tr> <td><b>WG-infra-crates.io</b></td> <td>Try your hand at a production Rust web app!</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Crates.io-g8NWnnNIeTq8DaqjGoZLr">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-infra-crates.io">Chat</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td><b>WG-infra-perf</b></td> <td>Let's make sure Rust gets faster.</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Perf.rlo-dp5rp6tSg7bOMmQwLygp4">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-infra-perf">Chat</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td><b>WG-infra-crater</b></td> <td>Regularly testing the compiler against the Rust ecosystem.</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Crater-D7DpG48tMhhHhrUm8kyhY">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-infra-crater">Chat</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td><b>WG-infra-secure</b></td> <td>Help us implement best practices for Rust's infrastructure!</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Securing-Infrastructure-xq5FfLQs1hkxwgxDsHi2Z">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-infra-secure">Chat</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td><b>WG-infra-host</b></td> <td>Managing the services that keep the Rust machine running.</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Host-WiqosInW7SpUblFVGKeOo">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-infra-host">Chat</a></td> </tr> <tr> <td><b>WG-infra-rustbuild</b></td> <td>Streamline the compiler build process.</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Rustbuild-Cz96pk6FBtP54JClTCDNd">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-infra-rustbuild">Chat</a></td> </tr> </table> <h3 id="core-team">Core team</h3> <table> <tr> <td><b>WG-core-site</b></td> <td>The web site is getting overhauled; help shape the new content!</td> <td><a href="https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/rust-lang.org-content-improvement-uGns2d39DFgT0X9FQg0yD">Learn more</a></td> <td><a href="https://gitter.im/rust-impl-period/WG-core-site">Chat</a></td> </tr> </table> Rust 2017 Survey Results Tue, 05 Sep 2017 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-2017-survey-results/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-2017-survey-results/ <p>It's that time of the year, where we take a good look at how things are going by asking the community at large -- both Rust users and non-users. And wow, did you respond!</p> <p>This year we had <strong>5,368 responses</strong>. <em>That's over 2,000 more responses than we had last year</em>!</p> <p>The scale of the feedback was both inspiring and humbling, and we've worked hard to read through all of your comments and suggestions. There were so many helpful ideas and experiences that people shared, and we truly do appreciate it. Without further ado, let's take a look.</p> <p><img src="/images/2017-09-05-Rust-2017-Survey-Results/do_you_use_rust.png" alt="Chart: 66.9% Rust users, 9.9% stopped using, 23.2% never used" /></p> <p>Just as we saw last year, 2/3rds of responses are from Rust users and the remainder from non-users. This year, we separated out the &quot;don't use Rust&quot; to capture those who used Rust and stopped from those who never used Rust. It's inspiring to see so many developers wanting to help us make Rust better (even if they don't use it!) so that it can reach even more people.</p> <p>We'll talk more about Rust non-users later in this report, but first let's look at the responses from Rust users.</p> <h1 id="using-rust">Using Rust</h1> <p><img src="/images/2017-09-05-Rust-2017-Survey-Results/how_long_using_rust.png" alt="Chart: 0.5% less than a day, 4.2% less than a week, 13.1% less than a month, 39.7% less than a year, 42.5% over a year" title="0.5% less than a day, 4.2% less than a week, 13.1% less than a month, 39.7% less than a year, 42.5% over a year" /> <em>(hover for more info)</em></p> <p>This year, we're seeing a growing amount of experienced users sticking with Rust, with the &quot;more than a year&quot; users growing to over 42% (up from 30% from last year). The beginners are also an impressively large set, with the &quot;less than a month&quot; crowd at just about 18%, meaning we're currently attracting nearly a 1/5th of our user base size, even as it grows larger, every month.</p> <p><img src="/images/2017-09-05-Rust-2017-Survey-Results/size_of_rust_projects.png" alt="Chart: 36.5% less 1000 lines, 46.3% 1000 to 10000 lines, 14.2% 10000 to 100000 lines, 2.1% over 100000, 0.9% don't know" title="36.5% less 1000 lines, 46.3% 1000 to 10000 lines, 14.2% 10000 to 100000 lines, 2.1% over 100000, 0.9% don't know" /> <em>(hover for more info)</em></p> <p>People are working with ever-larger amounts of Rust, with medium- and large-scale lines of code totals both nearly doubling since last year as a percentage of the whole, now making up 16% of respondents (up from last year's 8.9%). This shows a growing interest in using Rust in ever-larger projects, and a growing need for tools to support this growth.</p> <p><img src="/images/2017-09-05-Rust-2017-Survey-Results/how_often_use_rust.png" alt="Chart: 17.5% daily, 43.3% weekly, 24.4% monthly, 14.9% rarely" title="17.5% daily, 43.3% weekly, 24.4% monthly, 14.9% rarely" /></p> <p>Despite the rising amount of code developers are working with, we're seeing a small downtick in both daily and weekly users. Daily users have fallen from 19% to 17.5%, and weekly users have fallen from 48.8% to 43.3%. This could be a natural transition in this stage of our growth, as a broader range of developers begin using Rust.</p> <h1 id="path-to-stability">Path to Stability</h1> <p><img src="/images/2017-09-05-Rust-2017-Survey-Results/upgrade_stable.png" alt="Chart: 92.5% no, 7.5% yes" title="92.5% no, 7.5% yes" /></p> <p>In the last year, we made big strides in breakages caused by releases of the compiler. Last year, 16.2% of respondents said that upgrading to a new stable Rust compiler broke their code. This year, that number has <strong>fallen to 7.5% of respondents</strong>. This is a huge improvement, and one we're proud of, though we'll continue working to push this down even further.</p> <p><img src="/images/2017-09-05-Rust-2017-Survey-Results/which_version.png" alt="Chart show strong support for nightly and current stable releases" /></p> <p>Developers have largely opted to move to nightly or a recent stable (with some on beta), showing that developers are eager to upgrade and do so quickly. This simplifies the support structure a bit from last year, where developers were on a wider range of versions.</p> <p>Stable users now make up 77.9% of Rust users. Unfortunately, despite our efforts with procedural macros and helping move crates like Serde to stable, we still have work to do to promote people moving away from the nightly Rust compiler. This year shows an increase in nightly users, now at 1,852 votes it represents 51.6% of respondents using nightly, up from 48.8% of last year.</p> <h1 id="how-we-use-rust">How we use Rust</h1> <p><img src="/images/2017-09-05-Rust-2017-Survey-Results/rustup.png" alt="Chart: 90.2% rustup, 18.9% linux distros, 5% homebrew, 4.7% official .msi, 3.1% official tarball, 1.4% official mac pkg" title="90.2% rustup, 18.9% linux distros, 5% homebrew, 4.7% official .msi, 3.1% official tarball, 1.4% official mac pkg" /> <em>(hover for more info)</em></p> <p>One of the big success stories with Rust tooling was rustup, the Rust toolchain installer. Last year, we saw a wide diversity in ways people were installing Rust. This year, many of these have moved to using rustup as their main way of installing Rust, totalling now 3,205 of the responses, which moves it from last year's 52.8% to <strong>90.2%</strong>.</p> <p><img src="/images/2017-09-05-Rust-2017-Survey-Results/platforms_on.png" alt="Chart: 80.9% Linux, 35.5% macOS, 31.5% Windows, 3.2% BSD-variant" /></p> <p>Linux still features prominently as one of the main platforms Rust developers choose. Of note, we also saw a rise in the use of Windows as a developer platform at 1,130 of the 3,588 total respondents, putting it at <strong>31.5% of respondents</strong>, up from 27.6% of last year.</p> <p><img src="/images/2017-09-05-Rust-2017-Survey-Results/platforms_targetted.png" alt="Chart: 91.5% Linux, 46.7% Windows, 38.2% macOS, 16.8% embedded, 13.2% WebAssembly and asm.js, 9.9% Android, 8.9% BSD-variant, 5.3% Apple iOS" /></p> <p>Next, we asked what platforms people were targeting with their Rust projects. While we see a similar representation of desktop OSes here, we also see a growing range of other targets. Android and iOS are at healthy 9.9% and 5.3% respectively, both almost <strong>10x larger</strong> than last year's percentages. Embedded also has had substantial growth since last year's single-digit percentage. As a whole, cross-compilation has grown considerably since this time last year.</p> <p><img src="/images/2017-09-05-Rust-2017-Survey-Results/editors.png" alt="Chart: 45.8% vim, 33.8% vscode, 16.1% intellij, 15.7% atom, 15.4% emacs, 12.2% sublime, 1.5% eclipse, 1.5% visual studio" /></p> <p>Among editors, vim remains king, though we see healthy growth in VSCode adoption at 34.1% (up from last year's 3.8%). This growth no doubt has been helped by VSCode being one of the first platforms to get support for the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rls">Rust Language Server</a>.</p> <p><img src="/images/2017-09-05-Rust-2017-Survey-Results/use_rust_at_work.png" alt="Chart: 4.4% full-time, 16.6% part-time, 2.9% no but company uses Rust, 57.6% no, 2.4% not sure, 16.1% not applicable" title="4.4% full-time, 16.6% part-time, 2.9% no but company uses Rust, 57.6% no, 2.4% not sure, 16.1% not applicable" /> <em>(hover for more info)</em></p> <p>Rust in the workplace has also continued to grow. This year's <strong>4.4% full-time</strong> and <strong>16.6% part-time</strong> Rust workers show a tick up from last year's 3.7% full-time and 16.1% part-time.</p> <p><img src="/images/2017-09-05-Rust-2017-Survey-Results/part_time.png" alt="Two charts part-time: 2016: 29.6% less than 1000 lines, 55.3% 1000 to 10000 lines, 14.5% 10000 to 100000 lines, 0.6% 100000 lines. 2017: 18.9% less than 1000 lines, 56% 1000 to 10000 lines, 23.1% 10000 to 100000 lines, 2% more than 100000 lines" /></p> <p>Users who use Rust <strong>part-time</strong> in their companies showed a growth in larger projects since last year, with the medium- and large-scale projects taking up more percentage of total projects this time around.</p> <p><img src="/images/2017-09-05-Rust-2017-Survey-Results/full_time.png" alt="Two charts full-time: 2016: 4.4% less than 1000 lines, 42.6% 1000 to 10000 lines, 39.7% 10000 to 100000 lines, 13.2% more than 100000 lines. 2017: 1.9% less than 1000 lines, 27.9% 1000 to 10000 lines, 52.6% 10000 to 100000 lines, 17.5% more than 100000 lines" /></p> <p>Likewise, <strong>full-time</strong> Rust commercial users saw medium- and large-scale projects grow to taking a larger part of the pie, with projects over 100,000 lines of code making up almost 18% of the all full-time commercial respondents, and a large shift in the 10,000-100,000 lines range from 39.7% up to <strong>52.6%</strong>.</p> <h1 id="feeling-welcome">Feeling Welcome</h1> <p><img src="/images/2017-09-05-Rust-2017-Survey-Results/feel_welcome.png" alt="chart: 75.1% feel welcome, 1.3% don't feel welcome, 23.6% don't know" title="75.1% feel welcome, 1.3% don't feel welcome, 23.6% don't know" /> <em>(hover for more info)</em></p> <p>An important piece of the Rust community is to be one that is welcoming to new users, whether they are current users or potential users in the future. We're pleased to see that over 3/4th of all respondents said they feel welcome in the Rust community, with 23.6% not sure.</p> <p><img src="/images/2017-09-05-Rust-2017-Survey-Results/diversity.png" alt="chart showing 81.4% not underrepresented, and a variety of underrepresented, with no category above 5%" /></p> <p>The demographics of respondents stayed about the same year over year. Diversity and inclusiveness continue to be vital goals for the Rust project at all levels. The <a href="https://github.com/rust-community/rustbridge/">Rust Bridge</a> initiative aims for diversity at the entry level. The <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/06/27/Increasing-Rusts-Reach.html">Rust Reach</a> project, launched this year, brings in a wide range of expertise from people underrepresented in the Rust world, and pairs them with Rust team members to make Rust more accessible to a wider audience.</p> <h1 id="stopped-using-rust">Stopped using Rust</h1> <p>New this year, we separated out the people who had stopped using Rust from those who had never used Rust to better understand why they stopped. Let's take a look first at when they stopped.</p> <p><img src="/images/2017-09-05-Rust-2017-Survey-Results/stopped_using_rust.png" alt="chart: 3.2% less than a day, 18.5% less than a week, 43.1% less than a month, 30.2% less than a year, 4.9% more than a year" title="3.2% less than a day, 18.5% less than a week, 43.1% less than a month, 30.2% less than a year, 4.9% more than a year" /> <em>(hover for more info)</em></p> <p>The first surprise we had here was how long people gave Rust a try before they stopped. Our initial hunch was that people would give up using Rust in the first day, or possibly the first week, if it didn't suit them or their project. Instead, what we see is that people tried Rust for a much longer time on average than that.</p> <p>Themes from people who stopped using Rust:</p> <ul> <li>23% responded that Rust is <strong>too difficult to use</strong>.</li> <li>20% responded that they <strong>didn't have enough time</strong> to learn and use Rust effectively.</li> <li>10% responded that <strong>tools aren't use mature enough</strong>.</li> <li>5% responded they needed <strong>better IDE support</strong>.</li> <li>The rest of users mentioned the need for <strong>support for Rust in their jobs</strong>, they'd <strong>finished the project</strong> they need to use Rust in, were turned away by <strong>Rust's syntax</strong>, <strong>couldn't think of a project to build</strong>, or had a <strong>bad interaction with the Rust community</strong>.</li> </ul> <h1 id="not-using-rust">Not using Rust</h1> <p><img src="/images/2017-09-05-Rust-2017-Survey-Results/dont_use_rust.png" alt="chart: 666 company doesn't use Rust, 425 Rust is too intimidating hard to learn or too complicated, 295 Rust doesn't solve a problem for me, 255 Rust doesn't have good IDE support, 209 Rust doesn't have libraries I need, 161 Rust seems too risky for production, 89 Rust doesn't support platforms I need, 73 Rust doesn't have tools I need" /></p> <p>While the learning curve and language complexity still played a role in preventing people from picking up Rust, one aspect that resonated with many people is that there just simply aren't enough active commercial projects in Rust for people to be a part of. For some, they could surmount the learning curve if there was strong incentive to do so.</p> <h1 id="areas-for-improvement">Areas for Improvement</h1> <p>Finally, at the end of the survey we we provided a free-form area to talk about where Rust could improve. Before we get to the themes we saw, we wanted to give a big &quot;thank you!&quot; to everyone who posted thoughtful comments. There are many, many good ideas, which we will be making available to the respective sub-teams for future planning. With that, let's look at the themes that were important this year:</p> <ul> <li>17% of responses underscored the need for <strong>better ergonomics</strong> in the language. People had many suggestions about how to improve Rust for day-to-day use, to allow for easier prototyping, to work with async programming more easily, and to be more flexible with more data structure types. Just as before, the need for a much easier and smoother experience with the borrow checker and how to work with lifetimes was a popular request.</li> <li>16% of responses talk about the importance of creating <strong>better documentation</strong>. These covered a topics from helping users transition from other languages, creating more examples and sample projects, helping people get started with various tasks or crates, and creating video resources to facilitate learning.</li> <li>15% of responses point out that <strong>library support</strong> needs to improve. People mention the need for a strong support set of core libraries, of the difficulty finding high quality crates, the general maturity of the crates and the crate ecosystem, the need for libraries to cover a wide range of areas (eg web, GUIs, networking, databases, etc). Additionally, people mentioned that libraries can be hard to get started with depending on their API design and amount of documentation.</li> <li>9% of the responses encouraged us to continue to build our <strong>IDE support</strong>. Again, this year underscored that there are a sizeable section of developers that need support for Rust in their IDEs and tools. The Rust Language Server, the on-going effort to support IDEs broadly, was mentioned as one of the top items people are looking forward to this year, and comments pointed to these efforts needing to reach stable and grow support into other IDEs as well as continuing to grow the number of available features.</li> <li>8% of responses mention <strong>learning curve</strong> specifically. As more developers try to pick up Rust or teach it to coworkers and friends, they're finding that there aren't sufficient resources to do so effectively and that Rust itself resists a smooth learning experience.</li> <li>Other strong themes included the need for: <strong>faster compile times</strong>, <strong>more corporate support of Rust</strong> (including jobs), <strong>better language interop</strong>, <strong>improved tooling</strong>, <strong>better error messages</strong>, <strong><em>more</em> marketing</strong>, <strong><em>less</em> marketing</strong>, and <strong>improved support for web assembly</strong>.</li> </ul> <h1 id="conclusion">Conclusion</h1> <p>We're blown away by the response this year. Not only is this a much larger number of responses than we had last year, but we're also seeing a growing diversity in what people are using Rust for. Thank you so much for your thoughtful replies. We look forward to using your feedback, your suggestions, and your experience to help us plan for next year. </p> Announcing Rust 1.20 Thu, 31 Aug 2017 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-20/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-20/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce the latest version of Rust, 1.20.0. Rust is a systems programming language focused on safety, speed, and concurrency.</p> <p>If you have a previous version of Rust installed, getting Rust 1.20 is as easy as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">rustup</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> update stable </span></pre> <p>If you don't have it already, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">get <code>rustup</code></a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1200-2017-08-31">detailed release notes for 1.20.0</a> on GitHub.</p> <h3 id="what-s-in-1-20-0-stable">What's in 1.20.0 stable</h3> <p>In previous Rust versions, you can already define traits, structs, and enums that have &quot;associated functions&quot;:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Struct; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">impl </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Struct { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">foo</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;foo is an associated function of Struct&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); } } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { Struct::foo(); } </span></pre> <p>These are called &quot;associated functions&quot; because they are functions that are associated with the type, that is, they're attached to the type itself, and not any particular instance.</p> <p>Rust 1.20 adds the ability to define &quot;associated constants&quot; as well:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Struct; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">impl </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Struct { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">const </span><span style="color:#666969;">ID</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u32 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;the ID of Struct is: </span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, Struct::</span><span style="color:#666969;">ID</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); } </span></pre> <p>That is, the constant <code>ID</code> is associated with <code>Struct</code>. Like functions, associated constants work with traits and enums as well.</p> <p>Traits have an extra ability with associated constants that gives them some extra power. With a trait, you can use an associated constant in the same way you'd use an associated type: by declaring it, but not giving it a value. The implementor of the trait then declares its value upon implementation:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">trait </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Trait { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">const </span><span style="color:#666969;">ID</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Struct; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">impl </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Trait </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">for </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Struct { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">const </span><span style="color:#666969;">ID</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u32 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">5</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, Struct::</span><span style="color:#666969;">ID</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); } </span></pre> <p>Before this release, if you wanted to make a trait that represented floating point numbers, you'd have to write this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">trait </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Float { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">nan</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() -&gt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">Self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">infinity</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() -&gt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">Self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">... </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p>This is slightly unwieldy, but more importantly, because they're functions, they cannot be used in constant expressions, even though they only return a constant. Because of this, a design for <code>Float</code> would also have to include constants as well:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">mod </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">f32 { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">const </span><span style="color:#666969;">NAN</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">f32 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0.0</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">f32 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">/ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0.0</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">f32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">const </span><span style="color:#666969;">INFINITY</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">f32 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1.0</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">f32 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">/ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0.0</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">f32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">impl </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Float </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">for </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">f32 { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">nan</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() -&gt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">Self </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">f32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">::</span><span style="color:#666969;">NAN </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">infinity</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() -&gt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">Self </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">f32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">::</span><span style="color:#666969;">INFINITY </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} } } </span></pre> <p>Associated constants let you do this in a much cleaner way. This trait definition:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">trait </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Float { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">const </span><span style="color:#666969;">NAN</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">Self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">const </span><span style="color:#666969;">INFINITY</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">Self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">... </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p>Leads to this implementation:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">mod </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">f32 { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">impl </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Float </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">for </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">f32 { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">const </span><span style="color:#666969;">NAN</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">f32 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0.0</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">f32 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">/ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0.0</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">f32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">const </span><span style="color:#666969;">INFINITY</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">f32 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1.0</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">f32 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">/ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0.0</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">f32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; } } </span></pre> <p>much cleaner, and more versatile.</p> <p>Associated constants were proposed in <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/0195-associated-items.md">RFC 195</a>, almost exactly three years ago. It's been quite a while for this feature! That RFC contained all associated items, not just constants, and so some of them, such as associated types, were implemented faster than others. In general, we've been doing a lot of internal work for constant evaluation, to increase Rust's capabilities for compile-time metaprogramming. Expect more on this front in the future.</p> <p>We've also <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/43782">fixed a bug</a> with the <code>include!</code> macro in documentation tests: for relative paths, it erroneously was relative to the working directory, rather than to the current file.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1200-2017-08-31">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h4 id="library-stabilizations">Library stabilizations</h4> <p>There's nothing <em>super</em> exciting in libraries this release, just a number of solid improvements and continued stabilizing of APIs.</p> <p>The <code>unimplemented!</code> macro <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/42155">now accepts messages</a> that let you say why something is not yet implemented.</p> <p>We <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/42999">upgraded to Unicode 10.0.0</a>.</p> <p><code>min</code> and <code>max</code> on floating point types were <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/42430">rewritten in Rust</a>, no longer relying on <code>cmath</code>.</p> <p>We are shipping mitigations against <a href="https://access.redhat.com/security/vulnerabilities/stackguard">Stack Clash</a> in this release, notably, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/42816">stack probes</a>, and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/43072">skipping the main thread's manual stack guard on Linux</a>. You don't need to do anything to get these protections other than using Rust 1.20.</p> <p>We've added a new trio of sorting functions to the standard library: <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.slice.html#method.sort_unstable_by_key"><code>slice::sort_unstable_by_key</code></a>, <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.slice.html#method.sort_unstable_by"><code>slice::sort_unstable_by</code></a>, and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.slice.html#method.sort_unstable"><code>slice::sort_unstable</code></a>. You'll note that these all have &quot;unstable&quot; in the name. Stability is a property of sorting algorithms that may or may not matter to you, but now you have both options! Here's a brief summary: imagine we had a list of words like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">rust crate package cargo </span></pre> <p>Two of these words, <code>cargo</code> and <code>crate</code>, both start with the letter <code>c</code>. A stable sort that sorts only on the first letter must produce this result:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">crate cargo package rust </span></pre> <p>That is, because <code>crate</code> came before <code>cargo</code> in the original list, it must also be before it in the final list. An unstable sort could provide that result, but could also give this answer too:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">cargo crate package rust </span></pre> <p>That is, the results <em>may</em> not be in the same original order.</p> <p>As you might imagine, fewer constraints often means faster results. If you don't care about stability, these sorts may be faster for you than the stable variants. As always, best to check both and see! These functions were added by <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/1884-unstable-sort.md">RFC 1884</a>, if you'd like more details, including benchmarks.</p> <p>Additionally, the following APIs were also stabilized:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/ffi/struct.CStr.html#method.into_c_string"><code>CStr::into_c_string</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/ffi/struct.CString.html#method.as_c_str"><code>CString::as_c_str</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/ffi/struct.CString.html#method.into_boxed_c_str"><code>CString::into_boxed_c_str</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/io/struct.Chain.html#method.get_mut"><code>Chain::get_mut</code></a>, <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/io/struct.Chain.html#method.get_ref"><code>Chain::get_ref</code></a>, and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/io/struct.Chain.html#method.into_inner"><code>Chain::into_inner</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/option/enum.Option.html#method.get_or_insert_with"><code>Option::get_or_insert_with</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/option/enum.Option.html#method.get_or_insert"><code>Option::get_or_insert</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/ffi/struct.OsStr.html#method.into_os_string"><code>OsStr::into_os_string</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/ffi/struct.OsString.html#method.into_boxed_os_str"><code>OsString::into_boxed_os_str</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/io/struct.Take.html#method.get_mut"><code>Take::get_mut</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/io/struct.Take.html#method.get_ref"><code>Take::get_ref</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/str/struct.Utf8Error.html#method.error_len"><code>Utf8Error::error_len</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/char/struct.EscapeDebug.html"><code>char::EscapeDebug</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.char.html#method.escape_debug"><code>char::escape_debug</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/macro.compile_error.html"><code>compile_error!</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.f32.html#method.from_bits"><code>f32::from_bits</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.f32.html#method.to_bits"><code>f32::to_bits</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.f64.html#method.from_bits"><code>f64::from_bits</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.f64.html#method.to_bits"><code>f64::to_bits</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/mem/union.ManuallyDrop.html"><code>mem::ManuallyDrop</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/str/fn.from_boxed_utf8_unchecked.html"><code>str::from_boxed_utf8_unchecked</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.str.html#method.as_bytes_mut"><code>str::as_bytes_mut</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/str/fn.from_utf8_mut.html"><code>str::from_utf8_mut</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/str/fn.from_utf8_unchecked_mut.html"><code>str::from_utf8_unchecked_mut</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.str.html#method.get_unchecked"><code>str::get_unchecked</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.str.html#method.get_unchecked_mut"><code>str::get_unchecked_mut</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.str.html#method.get"><code>str::get</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.str.html#method.get_mut"><code>str::get_mut</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.str.html#method.into_boxed_bytes"><code>str::into_boxed_bytes</code></a></li> </ul> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1200-2017-08-31">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h4 id="cargo-features">Cargo features</h4> <p>Cargo has some nice upgrades this release. First of all, your crates.io authentication token used to be stored in <code>~/.cargo/config</code>. As a configuration file, this would often be stored with <code>644</code> permissions, that is, world-readable. But it has a secret token in it. We've <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/3978">moved the token</a> to <code>~/.cargo/credentials</code>, so that it can be permissioned <code>600</code>, and hidden from other users on your system.</p> <p>If you used secondary binaries in a Cargo package, you know that they're kept in <code>src/bin</code>. However, sometimes, you want multiple secondary binaries that have significant logic; in that case, you'd have <code>src/bin/client.rs</code> and <code>src/bin/server.rs</code>, and any submodules for either of them would go in the same directory. This is confusing. Instead, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/4214">we now conventionally support</a> <code>src/bin/client/main.rs</code> and <code>src/bin/server/main.rs</code>, so that you can keep larger binaries more separate from one another.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1200-2017-08-31">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h3 id="contributors-to-1-20-0">Contributors to 1.20.0</h3> <p>Many people came together to create Rust 1.20. We couldn't have done it without all of you. <a href="https://thanks.rust-lang.org/rust/1.20.0">Thanks!</a></p> Announcing Rust 1.19 Thu, 20 Jul 2017 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-19/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-19/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce the latest version of Rust, 1.19.0. Rust is a systems programming language focused on safety, speed, and concurrency.</p> <p>If you have a previous version of Rust installed, getting Rust 1.19 is as easy as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">rustup</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> update stable </span></pre> <p>If you don't have it already, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">get <code>rustup</code></a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1190-2017-07-20">detailed release notes for 1.19.0</a> on GitHub.</p> <h3 id="what-s-in-1-19-0-stable">What's in 1.19.0 stable</h3> <p>Rust 1.19.0 has some long-awaited features, but first, a note for our Windows users. On Windows, Rust relies on <code>link.exe</code> for linking, which you can get via the &quot;Microsoft Visual C++ Build Tools.&quot; With the recent release of Visual Studio 2017, the directory structure for these tools has changed. As such, to use Rust, you had to stick with the 2015 tools or use a workaround (such as running <code>vcvars.bat</code>). In 1.19.0, <code>rustc</code> now knows how to find the 2017 tools, and so they work without a workaround.</p> <p>On to new features! Rust 1.19.0 is the first release that supports <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/42068"><code>union</code>s</a>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">union MyUnion { f1: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, f2: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">f32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, } </span></pre> <p>Unions are kind of like <code>enum</code>s, but they are &quot;untagged&quot;. Enums have a &quot;tag&quot; that stores which variant is the correct one at runtime; unions elide this tag.</p> <p>Since we can interpret the data held in the union using the wrong variant and Rust can't check this for us, that means reading or writing a union's field is unsafe:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> u </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> MyUnion { f1: </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">}; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">unsafe </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ u.f1 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">5 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">}; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> value </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">unsafe </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ u.f1 }; </span></pre> <p>Pattern matching works too:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">f</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">u</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: MyUnion) { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">unsafe </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">match</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> u { MyUnion { f1: </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">10 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;ten&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); } MyUnion { f2 } </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, f2); } } } } </span></pre> <p>When are unions useful? One major use-case is interoperability with C. C APIs can (and depending on the area, often do) expose unions, and so this makes writing API wrappers for those libraries significantly easier. Additionally, from <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/1444-union.md#motivation">its RFC</a>:</p> <blockquote> <p>A native union mechanism would also simplify Rust implementations of space-efficient or cache-efficient structures relying on value representation, such as machine-word-sized unions using the least-significant bits of aligned pointers to distinguish cases.</p> </blockquote> <p>This feature has been long awaited, and there's still more improvements to come. For now, <code>union</code>s can only include <code>Copy</code> types and may not implement <code>Drop</code>. We expect to lift these restrictions in the future.</p> <blockquote> <p>As a side note, have you ever wondered how new features get added to Rust? This feature was suggested by Josh Triplett, and he <a href="https://youtu.be/U8Gl3RTXf88?list=PLE7tQUdRKcybLShxegjn0xyTTDJeYwEkI">gave a talk at RustConf 2016</a> about the process of getting <code>union</code>s into Rust. You should check it out!</p> </blockquote> <p>In other news, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/42016"><code>loop</code>s can now <code>break</code> with a value</a>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#999999;">// old code </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> x; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">loop </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">7</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">break</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; } </span><span style="color:#999999;">// new code </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">loop </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">break </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">7</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; }; </span></pre> <p>Rust has traditionally positioned itself as an &quot;expression oriented language&quot;, that is, most things are expressions that evaluate to a value, rather than statements. <code>loop</code> stuck out as strange in this way, as it was previously a statement.</p> <p>What about other forms of loops? It's not yet clear. See <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/1624-loop-break-value.md#extension-to-for-while-while-let">its RFC</a> for some discussion around the open questions here.</p> <p>A smaller feature, closures that do not capture an environment <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/42162">can now be coerced to a function pointer</a>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> f: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) -&gt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">|</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">x</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">| x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span></pre> <p>We now produce <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-installer/pull/57">xz compressed tarballs</a> and prefer them by default, making the data transfer smaller and faster. <code>gzip</code>'d tarballs are still produced in case you can't use <code>xz</code> for some reason.</p> <p>The compiler can now <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/41370">bootstrap on Android</a>. We've long supported Android in various ways, and this continues to improve our support.</p> <p>Finally, a compatibility note. Way back when we were running up to Rust 1.0, we did a huge push to verify everything that was being marked as stable and as unstable. We overlooked one thing, however: <code>-Z</code> flags. The <code>-Z</code> flag to the compiler enables unstable flags. Unlike the rest of our stability story, you could still use <code>-Z</code> on stable Rust. Back in April of 2016, in Rust 1.8, we made the use of <code>-Z</code> on stable or beta produce a warning. Over a year later, we're fixing this hole in our stability story by <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/41751">disallowing <code>-Z</code> on stable and beta</a>.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1190-2017-07-20">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h4 id="library-stabilizations">Library stabilizations</h4> <p>The largest new library feature is the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/41192"><code>eprint!</code> and <code>eprintln!</code> macros</a>. These work exactly the same as <code>print!</code> and <code>println!</code> but instead write to standard error, as opposed to standard output.</p> <p>Other new features:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/41449"><code>String</code> now implements <code>FromIterator&lt;Cow&lt;'a, str&gt;&gt;</code> and <code>Extend&lt;Cow&lt;'a, str&gt;&gt;</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/41530"><code>Vec</code> now implements <code>From&lt;&amp;mut [T]&gt;</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/41258"><code>Box&lt;[u8]&gt;</code> now implements <code>From&lt;Box&lt;str&gt;&gt;</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/41659"><code>SplitWhitespace</code> now implements <code>Clone</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/41764"> <code>[u8]::reverse</code> is now 5x faster and <code>[u16]::reverse</code> is now 1.5x faster</a></li> </ul> <p>And some freshly-stabilized APIs:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/ffi/struct.OsString.html#method.shrink_to_fit"><code>OsString::shrink_to_fit</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/cmp/struct.Reverse.html"><code>cmp::Reverse</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/process/struct.Command.html#method.envs"><code>Command::envs</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/thread/struct.ThreadId.html"><code>thread::ThreadId</code></a></li> </ul> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1190-2017-07-20">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h4 id="cargo-features">Cargo features</h4> <p>Cargo mostly received small but valuable improvements in this release. The largest is possibly that <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/4026">Cargo no longer checks out a local working directory for the crates.io index</a>. This should provide smaller file size for the registry and improve cloning times, especially on Windows machines.</p> <p>Other improvements:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/3929">Build scripts can now add environment variables to the environment the crate is being compiled in. Example: <code>println!(&quot;cargo:rustc-env=FOO=bar&quot;);</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/3979">Workspace members can now accept glob file patterns</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/3988">Added <code>--all</code> flag to the <code>cargo bench</code> subcommand to run benchmarks of all the members in a given workspace.</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/4031">Added an <code>--exclude</code> option for excluding certain packages when using the <code>--all</code> option</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/4084">The <code>--features</code> option now accepts multiple comma or space delimited values.</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/3954">Added support for custom target specific runners</a></li> </ul> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1190-2017-07-20">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h3 id="contributors-to-1-19-0">Contributors to 1.19.0</h3> <p>Many people came together to create Rust 1.19. We couldn't have done it without all of you. <a href="https://thanks.rust-lang.org/rust/1.19.0">Thanks!</a></p> The 2017 Rust Conference Lineup Tue, 18 Jul 2017 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/2017-conf-lineup/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/2017-conf-lineup/ <p>The Rust Community is holding three major conferences in the near future!</p> <h3 id="aug-18-19-rustconf">Aug 18-19: RustConf</h3> <p><a href="http://rustconf.com/">RustConf</a> is a two-day event held in <strong>Portland, OR, USA</strong> on August 18-19. The first day offers tutorials on Rust given directly by members of the Rust core team, ranging from absolute basics to advanced ownership techniques. In addition to the training sessions, on Friday there will be a RustBridge workshop session for people from underrepresented groups in tech, as well as a session on <a href="https://www.tockos.org/">Tock</a>, the secure embedded operating system.</p> <p>The second day is the main event, with <a href="http://rustconf.com/program.html">talks</a> at every level of expertise, covering basic and advanced techniques, experience reports, guidance on teaching, and interesting libraries.</p> <p><a href="http://rustconf.com/register.html">Tickets are still on sale!</a> We offer a <a href="https://tilde.wufoo.com/forms/rustconf-scholarships/">scholarship</a> for those who would otherwise find it difficult to attend. Join us in lovely Portland and hear about the latest developments in the Rust world!</p> <p>Follow us on Twitter <a href="https://twitter.com/rustconf">@rustconf</a>.</p> <h3 id="april-29-30th-sept-30-01-rust-fest">April 29-30th &amp; Sept 30-01: Rust Fest</h3> <p>Hot off another successful event in Kyiv earlier this year, we invite you to join us at <a href="http://www.rustfest.eu/">RustFest</a>, the European Rust community conference series. Over the weekend of the 30th of September we’ll gather in <strong>Zürich, Switzerland</strong> to talk Rust, its ecosystem and community. All day Saturday will have talks with topics ranging from hardware and testing over concurrency and disassemblers, and all the way to important topics like community, learning and empathy. While Sunday has a focus on learning and connecting, either at one of the many workshops we are hosting or in the central meet-n-greet-n-hack area provided.</p> <p>Thanks to the many awesome sponsors, we are able to offer affordable tickets to go on sale in couple weeks! Keep an eye on <a href="http://www.rustfest.eu/">rustfest.eu</a>, get all the updates on the <a href="http://blog.rustfest.eu/">blog</a> and don’t forget to follow us on Twitter <a href="https://twitter.com/rustfest">@rustfest</a>. Want to get a glimpse into what it's like?
