Check out the videos from <a href="https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL85XCvVPmGQhvs1Rnet_24B-AI3YSM2YG">Kyiv</a> or <a href="https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL85XCvVPmGQh8nWR_Z-fTmPGsUWuzb-dn">Berlin</a>!</p> <h3 id="oct-26-27-rust-belt-rust">Oct 26-27: Rust Belt Rust</h3> <p>For <a href="https://www.rust-belt-rust.com/">Rust Belt Rust</a>’s second year, we’ll be in <strong>Columbus, OH, USA</strong> at the Columbus Athenaeum, and <a href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/rust-belt-rust-conference-2017-registration-36237335847">tickets are on sale now</a>! We will have a day of workshops on Thursday and a day of single track talks on Friday. Speakers include Nell Shamrell, who works on Habitat at Chef, Emma Gospodinova, who is doing a GSoC project working on the Rust plugin for the KDevelop IDE, and Core Team members Aaron Turon, Niko Matsakis, and Carol Nichols. We’d love for YOU to be a speaker as well - our <a href="http://cfp.rust-belt-rust.com/">CFP</a> is open now until Aug 7. We hope to see you at the Rustiest conference in the eastern US! Follow us on Twitter <a href="https://twitter.com/rustbeltrust">@rustbeltrust</a> for the latest news.</p> Rust's 2017 roadmap, six months in Wed, 05 Jul 2017 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-roadmap-update/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-roadmap-update/ <p>In January of this year, we adopted the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/1774-roadmap-2017.md">2017 Rust Roadmap</a>, which laid out our plans for 2017. As part of the roadmap process, we plan to regularly release updates on the progress of each roadmap item. This post marks the halfway point through the year.</p> <h3 id="tracking-progress-via-roadmap-issues">Tracking progress via roadmap issues</h3> <p>First, a meta note. If you'd like to follow along with the progress on a particular roadmap initiative, or to find out more about how you can get involved, the best place to go is the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/">list of issues on the rust-roadmap repo</a>. There you will find an issue dedicated to each of the major initiatives that we are pushing on. These issues contain links to ongoing work. You'll find a number of links to issues like this in the descriptions that follow.</p> <h3 id="rust-should-have-a-lower-learning-curve">Rust should have a lower learning curve</h3> <p>The most direct way to make Rust easier to learn is to improve the way that we teach it. To that end, we've been hard at work on a brand new edition of the official &quot;Rust&quot; book (<a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/7">roadmap issue</a>), and we now have a <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/book/">complete draft available online</a>. This new edition puts ownership front and center and it also has expanded coverage of a number of other areas in Rust, such as error handling, testing, matching, modules, and more. Even better, you can <a href="https://www.nostarch.com/rust">pre-order a printed version</a> through No Starch Press. If you'd like to help out, there is still <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/book/projects/1">lots of editing work to be done!</a></p> <p>We've also been working on a number of language changes aimed at improving <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/03/02/lang-ergonomics.html">language ergonomics</a>. These range from long-standing proposals, like <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/16">non-lexical lifetimes</a> or <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1951"><code>impl Trait</code></a>, to newer ideas, like the recently approved RFCs on <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1733">trait aliases</a> and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/2005">match ergonomics</a>. On the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/17">roadmap issue</a>, you will find a large list of initiatives, organized by the part of the language that they target (e.g., ownership/borrowing, the trait system, etc). We are actively looking for people to help with writing RFCs but also implementing the accepted RFCs -- if you're interested in helping out with something, look for the &quot;mentoring&quot; contacts listed in the roadmap issue or on the tracking issue for a specific RFC. And, of course, if you think you've got a good idea that's not listed, open up a thread on internals and let's talk about it!</p> <h3 id="rust-should-have-a-pleasant-edit-compile-debug-cycle">Rust should have a pleasant edit-compile-debug cycle</h3> <p>We've been targeting the problem of improving compiler performance in a number of different ways. One of the simplest is the <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/03/16/Rust-1.16.html"><code>cargo check</code> command that we released in Rust 1.16</a> -- this command does a limited form of compilation which skips code-generation and simply looks for errors. Since code generation typically takes 50% or more of compilation time, this can be really useful in the early stages when you are writing new code and trying to get it to compile, particularly if you have a multi-crate project. This command is also used by the RLS.</p> <p>Of course, eventually you want to run your code, and for that you need a full compilation. In order to make <em>that</em> faster, we've been hard at work retooling the compiler to work in an incremental fashion. Earlier this year, we advertised <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/incremental-compilation-beta/4721">the &quot;beta&quot; release of incremental on nightly builds</a>. While the beta version sometimes achieved quite large speedups, we also found that the dependency tracking was not as robust or effective as we would like. Therefore, we are now adopting a new and improved approach to incremental compilation that we expect be ready in the next month or so. If you're interested in helping with the transition to the new system, check out <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/4">the incremental compilation roadmap issue</a> or <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/42293">the tracking issue for the new algorithm itself</a>; you can also follow <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/so-you-want-to-help-with-incremental-compilation/5313">this internals thread</a>, where we regularly post links to bugs that include mentoring instructions.</p> <p>Looking beyond incremental compilation, we've also been taking steps to optimize compilation time in other ways. Probably the most important step in that respect has been getting a new version of <a href="http://perf.rust-lang.org/">the <code>perf.rust-lang.org</code> website</a> up and running. The &quot;perf&quot; website tracks the effect of each and every PR on compilation performance, so that we can detect and correct regressions. In fact, the new website immediately led to some <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/41469">major performance improvements</a>. There is still lots of work that could be done to improve it, however, ranging from evaluating and improving our benchmark suite to improving the web interface; see the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/42611">tracking issue on this topic</a> for more.</p> <h3 id="rust-should-provide-a-solid-but-basic-ide-experience">Rust should provide a solid, but basic IDE experience</h3> <p>Since it first debuted at RustConf last year, the Rust Language Service (RLS) has been growing rapidly (<a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/6">roadmap issue</a>). It now offers support for most basic IDE operations, such as &quot;jump to definition&quot; or &quot;find all uses&quot;, as well as offering code completion (via <a href="https://github.com/racer-rust/racer">the racer project</a>). At this point, the focus is primarily on polish: making the RLS easier to install and fixing bugs. For example, we recently made it possible to <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rls#step-2-switch-to-nightly">install the RLS directly through rustup</a>.</p> <p>If you'd like to give the RLS a spin, the easiest way is to use <a href="https://github.com/jonathandturner/rls_vscode">the VSCode plugin</a>; however, the RLS is a generic server (it speaks Microsoft's <a href="https://github.com/Microsoft/language-server-protocol">Language Server Protocol</a>), and there are also clients available for a number of other editors. A word of warning: at this point, the RLS is still in an &quot;alpha&quot; period. While it is eminently usable, you may encounter bugs or other limitations.</p> <p>If you'd like to get involved with the RLS, check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/6">roadmap issue</a> or the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rls/issues">RLS issue listing</a>; in particular, those things tagged with <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rls/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3Agood-first-issue">&quot;good first issue&quot;</a>.</p> <h3 id="rust-should-provide-easy-access-to-high-quality-crates">Rust should provide easy access to high quality crates</h3> <p>As the size of the crates.io ecosystem has grown, the simple search and sorting criteria used by the crates.io website are no longer that helpful for figuring out which crates you should use. To address this, we've added <a href="https://crates.io/categories">categories</a> and <a href="http://doc.crates.io/manifest.html#package-metadata">a number of badges</a> that crate authors can add to their crates. These help people find crates for a particular purpose and judge a crate’s quality at a glance. In addition, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1824">RFC 1824</a> laid out a plan for improving the default sort in crates.io and exposing additional information to help in selecting a crate. There is <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/41616">a tracking issue</a> that lists the pieces of this RFC, and we’d love contributions towards those pieces! Once the RFC is completely implemented and people have had a chance to use the features for a while, we plan to ask the community for feedback and make adjustments.</p> <p>In addition, the effort on the <a href="https://rust-lang-nursery.github.io/rust-cookbook/">&quot;cookbook&quot;</a> described below will also be a boon for discovering crates in a task-centric way.</p> <h3 id="rust-should-be-well-equipped-for-writing-robust-servers">Rust should be well-equipped for writing robust servers</h3> <p>We've made some excellent strides the first half of this year towards making Rust well equipped for writing robust servers. The <a href="https://crates.io/crates/futures"><code>futures</code></a> crate and <a href="https://tokio.rs">Tokio</a> project continue to explore the asynchronous I/O ecosystem and have seen some heavy usage through crates like <a href="https://hyper.rs">Hyper</a> and production users like <a href="https://blog.buoyant.io/2017/03/29/introducing-linkerd-tcp/">linkerd-tcp</a>. Additionally we've seen projects like <a href="https://rocket.rs/">Rocket</a> continue to tirelessly improve the ergonomics of Rust-on-the-server. A <a href="https://users.rust-lang.org/t/what-does-rust-need-today-for-server-workloads/11114">recent discussion</a> of what the biggest blockers are today has highlighted that <a href="https://github.com/alexcrichton/futures-await">async/await</a> notation, better Tokio/futures documentation, and a solid HTTP foundation for the ecosystem are some of the next highest priorities. We plan to enable async/await notation on the nightly Rust channel by the end of the year and position it for stabilization in early 2018. This in turn should help fuel a rewrite of Tokio's/<code>future</code>'s documentation and continue to grow community support for crates such as HTTP.</p> <h3 id="rust-should-have-1-0-level-crates-for-essential-tasks">Rust should have 1.0-level crates for essential tasks</h3> <p>The <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/05/05/libz-blitz.html">Libz Blitz</a> proceeds apace! The Libz Blitz is a systematic effort to identify the most broadly used crates in the Rust ecosystem and to ensure that they all meet a consistent level of completeness and quality. This effort entails collaborating on the internals forum to review crates according to the <a href="https://github.com/brson/rust-api-guidelines">API guidelines</a>, filing and fixing the issues that arise, and writing examples for a new <a href="https://rust-lang-nursery.github.io/rust-cookbook/">&quot;cookbook&quot; of Rust examples</a>.</p> <p>The effort is structured to be highly amenable to contribution, particularly from new Rust developers, and so far has resolved 99 crate issues across 10 crates, and created more than 30 examples for the cookbook, thanks to the efforts of 53 contributors.</p> <p>If you're interested in participating, take a look at the <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/rust-libz-blitz/5184">introductory post on the internals thread</a>.</p> <!-- Thanks to Aaronepower, aergonaut, alisha17, AndyGauge, bjnyfv, brson, budziq, cetra3, cGuille, chrisvittal, cldershem, Cldfire, crazymerlyn, crypto-universe, DarkEld3r, derekdreery, dtolnay, Enet4, gsquire, imor, jaemk, jehiggs, jmcomets, kbknapp, koivunej, kper, little-dude, luisbg, MarkMcCaskey, Matt8898, Michael-F-Bryan, mikeastock, morrme, neosilky, nivkner, omh1280, opilar, pepyakin, Piripant, pwoolcoc, rap2hpoutre, robo9k, SamWhited, sb89, seanmonstar, SimonSapin, theduke, tmccombs, tomecki, tomprince, topecongiro, vedantrathore, xpayn, and everyone else who helps make Rust great. --> <h3 id="rust-should-integrate-easily-into-large-build-systems">Rust should integrate easily into large build systems</h3> <p>Most work on build system integration has focused on more clearly identifying what the challenges are and developing concrete proposals that target them. Some of the current avenues for exploration are:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/issues/3815">Support for using Cargo to create a build plan but not execute it</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/issues/3816">Support declaring external dependencies in a first-class way</a> (rather than via arbitrary build scripts as we do today)</li> </ul> <p>We are hoping to pick up the pace on this work in the second half of the year, but could use help doing so. If either of the above Cargo improvements is of interest to you, or if you have insights on build system integration in general, please reach out on the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/12">tracking issue</a>!</p> <h3 id="rust-s-community-should-provide-mentoring-at-all-levels">Rust's community should provide mentoring at all levels</h3> <p>When it comes to mentoring, we've been pursuing a few different efforts. The first, <a href="https://github.com/rust-community/rustbridge/">RustBridge</a>, is specifically aimed at bringing underrepresented folks into tech; it also serves as a great curriculum for people completely new to Rust. The materials have already been through several iterations and continue to evolve and improve, and we are going to be <a href="http://rustconf.com/training.html">running a RustBridge workshop the day before RustConf</a>. We would like to see more RustBridge events.</p> <p>We also just launched <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/06/27/Increasing-Rusts-Reach.html">Increasing Rust's Reach</a>, an initiative for hearing more from groups currently underrepresented in Rust (or technology more generally), and working together to make Rust accessible to a wider audience. While this isn't a mentorship program per se (in many cases, it's the <em>participants</em> who are doing the teaching!), it is still geared toward lowering the on-ramp to Rust's community.</p> <p>In addition, the various Rust teams have been pursuing a number of different initiatives trying to encourage people to get involved in the Rust project itself:</p> <ul> <li>We've <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/announcing-the-infrastructure-cargo-and-dev-tools-teams-disbanding-the-tools-team/5256">added three new teams</a> -- infrastructure, cargo, and dev-tools -- and hence created new areas where people can get involved.</li> <li>The lang team has adopted the new <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/language-team-shepherds/4595">shepherd role</a>. Shepherds are experienced members of the community who have demonstrated both excellent technical acumen and the ability to build consensus and understand alternative perspectives. Shepherds attend language meetings and help to steer discussion on RFCs and guide them towards a useful conclusion.</li> <li>The lang team has also been working on &quot;mentoring&quot; RFCs. The <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/17">roadmap issue for the ergonomics initiative</a>, for example, lists a number of RFCs where we are actively recruiting.</li> <li>A big part of the <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/rust-libz-blitz/5184">&quot;Libz Blitz&quot;</a> is helping to direct community effort to pushing libraries over the finish line.</li> <li>The compiler team has been actively pursuing &quot;mentoring bugs&quot; (<a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&amp;q=is%3Aopen%20is%3Aissue%20label%3AE-mentor%20label%3AT-compiler%20">bugs tagged as E-mentor</a>), which include written instructions, as well as <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/compiler-team-making-it-easer-to-contribute-to-rustc/5345">drawing up plans</a> to improve the documentation of the code and workflows.</li> </ul> <h3 id="areas-of-exploration">Areas of Exploration</h3> <p>In addition to the main roadmap items, the roadmap RFC called out two &quot;areas of exploration&quot;. These are areas with strong potential for Rust that are still in a more exploratory phase.</p> <h4 id="embedded-rust-initiative">Embedded Rust initiative</h4> <p>The embedded Rust ecosystem continues to grow. A bare metal concurrency <a href="https://docs.rs/cortex-m-rtfm/0.1.1/cortex_m_rtfm/">framework</a> for Cortex-M microcontrollers geared towards <a href="https://github.com/japaric/2wd">robotics</a> and <a href="https://mobile.twitter.com/japaricious/status/845697935572656128">control</a> systems has been recently developed. And <a href="https://www.tockos.org/">Tock</a>, an embedded OS that also targets Cortex-M microcontrollers, has been making progress towards pure <a href="https://github.com/helena-project/libtock-rs">Rust userland applications</a> and continues growing <a href="https://www.tockos.org/blog/">its driver support</a>.</p> <p>On the compiler side support for the MSP430 architecture has been improving thanks to <a href="https://github.com/rust-embedded/rfcs/issues/20">the community's effort</a>, and <a href="https://github.com/avr-rust/rust/issues">support for the AVR architecture</a> is also being worked on, out of tree, by the community.</p> <p>On the community side efforts in standardizing the development workflow are on going with the creation and development of <a href="http://blog.japaric.io/quickstart/">guides</a>, <a href="https://github.com/japaric/photon-quickstart">project templates</a>, <a href="https://github.com/japaric/cortex-m">core crates</a> and <a href="https://github.com/japaric/svd2rust">tooling</a>. Recently a <a href="https://users.rust-lang.org/t/rust-for-embedded-development-where-we-are-and-whats-missing/10861">survey</a> to identify the current needs of embedded developers was performed and the corresponding <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/15">roadmap issue</a> was updated to reflect the results. In response to the survey results a community effort to create a Hardware Abstraction Layer, that will serve as a base for building the embedded crate ecosystem, has been <a href="https://github.com/japaric/embedded-hal">started</a> and the design <a href="https://github.com/japaric/embedded-hal/issues">discussion</a> is currently on going. An &quot;Are we embedded yet?&quot; web site that will reflect the up to date state of the embedded ecosystem and track its progress is also <a href="https://github.com/rust-embedded/rfcs/issues/15">being worked on</a>.</p> <p>(Thanks to <a href="https://github.com/japaric">Jorge Aparicio</a> for this writeup.)</p> <h4 id="integrating-with-other-languages-bindgen-update">Integrating with Other Languages: <code>bindgen</code> Update</h4> <h5 id="c-and-c">C and C++</h5> <p><a href="https://github.com/servo/rust-bindgen"><code>bindgen</code></a> is the frontier for automating integration of C and C++ libraries into Rust code bases. <code>bindgen</code> takes header files as input, and outputs the appropriate foreign function and type declarations so that the C/C++ library can be used with minimal effort from Rust.</p> <p><code>bindgen</code> has become a crucial infrastructure for the <a href="https://wiki.mozilla.org/Stylo">Stylo project</a>, which brings Servo's style system to Firefox. As the Stylo project nears shipping, we've been hammering <code>bindgen</code> into shape for production. This has manifested itself as tons of reliability and correctness work. Our test suite is ever expanding, we've been focusing on correctness of struct layout, size, and alignment for ABI corner cases such as bitfields, as well as test coverage and support across different versions of libclang.</p> <p>At the same time, we've been working to improve the <a href="https://github.com/servo/rust-bindgen/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md">contribution experience</a>. We've been documenting workflows, adding <a href="https://github.com/servo/rust-bindgen/blob/master/example-graphviz-ir.png">visualizations of our internal representation</a> for debugging, and mentoring new contributors. Since the <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/announcing-the-infrastructure-cargo-and-dev-tools-teams-disbanding-the-tools-team/5256">creation of the Rust DevTools team</a>, we've also been talking with other toolsmiths about fostering contribution to common tools. Expect to hear more on this soon.</p> <p>Finally, we also introduced a <a href="https://servo.github.io/rust-bindgen/"><code>bindgen</code> Users Guide</a> to help folks get up and running with <code>bindgen</code> in their project.</p> <p>(Thanks to <a href="https://github.com/fitzgen">Nick Fitzgerald</a> for this writeup.)</p> <h5 id="other-languages-environments">Other languages/environments</h5> <p>Higher level languages come with their own integration challenges, often involving cooperation with an external runtime system (which possibly includes a garbage collector). Here's a quick rundown of some of the major projects on this front:</p> <ul> <li><strong>Ruby</strong>: the <a href="http://usehelix.com/">Helix</a> project is geared toward writing Ruby extensions in Rust, and publicly launched a couple of months ago.</li> <li><strong>Node.js</strong>: the <a href="https://github.com/dherman/neon">Neon</a> project is similarly geared toward writing Node.js modules in Rust, and continues to see active development.</li> <li>The <strong>GNOME Object system</strong>: after a sprint pairing up Rust and GNOME core developers, we have the basics of an <a href="http://smallcultfollowing.com/babysteps/blog/2017/05/02/gnome-class-integrating-rust-and-the-gnome-object-system/">integration story</a> for Rust and the GObject system.</li> <li>The <a href="http://jakegoulding.com/rust-ffi-omnibus/">Rust FFI Omnibus</a> gives guidance for the basics of calling into Rust from a variety of languages.</li> </ul> <p>There are many less high-profile projects in this space as well; if you'd like yours to be tracked as part of the roadmap, please leave a comment on the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/14">tracking issue</a>!</p> <h3 id="conclusion">Conclusion</h3> <p>In conclusion, you can see that it's been a very busy six months in Rust land. I'd like to thank all the many people who have been involved in pushing these projects over the finish line!</p> Increasing Rust’s Reach Tue, 27 Jun 2017 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/increasing-rusts-reach/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/increasing-rusts-reach/ <p><strong>EDIT: We've heard that Google Forms is not easily accessible in all countries; if that applies to you, please find the <a href="/images/2017-06-Increasing-Rusts-Reach/application.txt">application's questions in this text file</a> and send the answers via email to carol.nichols@gmail.com.</strong></p> <p>One of <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/02/06/roadmap.html">Rust's 2017 goals</a> is to make it easier to become productive in Rust by reducing its learning curve. We believe Rust has potential as an enabling technology, empowering a people who would not traditionally do system programming to take it on with confidence. But there’s a bit of a bootstrapping problem here: if we want to reach new people, we can’t do it by relying solely on the skills and perspectives of our existing community. So we’ve decided to do an experiment, and we need your help!</p> <p>We’re looking for people inside and outside Rust’s current community from groups and backgrounds that are underrepresented in the Rust world and the technology world more generally. We want to partner with you to make Rust a more inclusive, approachable and impactful project, while supporting your success on personal goals.</p> <p>We have a team of Rust community leaders to pair you with. This group isn’t particularly diverse; this is where the Rust community is right now. We acknowledge that we have lots of work to do, and this initiative is part of that work. We’re all committed to improving the diversity of the Rust community.</p> <p>The Rust team leaders have proposed projects in a variety of areas, such as improving Rust itself, working on Rust web tools, and improving usability. We’re looking for a variety of experiences and skill sets! We’re also open to project ideas of your own.</p> <p>We’re asking for a time investment of 3-5 hours per week between Aug 7 and Nov 6 (or a shorter time period within those dates). The exact scope of each of the projects is flexible, depending on your availability and goals. We expect you to check in at least weekly with a summary of your progress, and we expect you to produce a deliverable by the end of your time working on the project. The deliverable will vary based on the project; it might be pull requests, recommendations, documentation, or tutorials, for example.</p> <p>As thanks for your participation, Mozilla will cover flight, hotel, and ticket costs to the Rust conference of your choice out of:</p> <ul> <li>RustConf, Aug 18-19 in Portland, OR, USA</li> <li>RustFest, Sept 30-Oct 1 in Zurich, Switzerland</li> <li>Rust Belt Rust, Oct 26-27 in Columbus, OH, USA</li> </ul> <p>Your pair will give you the context and tools needed to help you make an impact on an important area of Rust. You’ll also have access to a private Slack to chat with the other participants and Rust team members involved in this initiative. We’re planning on highlighting the outcomes of this experiment and recognizing your contributions explicitly; we value these projects and your contributions to them highly!</p> <p>Some groups that are underrepresented in technology and in the Rust community that we would especially love insights from include women (cis &amp; trans), nonbinary folks, people of color, non-native English speakers, people who learned programming later in life (older, or only in college, or at a bootcamp as part of a midlife career change), people with disabilities, or people who have different learning styles.</p> <p><strong><a href="https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfbSGuoyZE9dctdEoC_XEZ7j2ox7jQT1zghAOF4iGds2PfBCA/viewform">Apply via this form by July 18!</a></strong> (when the day is over in all time zones). We will notify all applicants by Aug 1.</p> <p>Please contact Carol Nichols via email at carol.nichols@gmail.com or on Twitter at <a href="https://twitter.com/Carols10cents">@carols10cents</a> with any questions.</p> <hr /> <h2 id="projects">Projects</h2> <h3 id="1-user-experience-of-rust-documentation-code-browsing-tools">1. User Experience of Rust Documentation &amp; Code Browsing Tools</h3> <p>Rust partners: Nick Cameron and Steve Klabnik</p> <p>We’re looking for someone with background in graphic design, web frontend engineering, or user experience to work on the frontend/UI/UX/design for <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/std/index.html">documentation</a> and <a href="https://github.com/nrc/rustw">code browsing tools</a>. These tools have web frontends (HTML, CSS, Ember or React) and Rust backends and the tools must deeply understand Rust source code. This project will be a great way to apply experience from the design and frontend worlds, while giving you the opportunity to learn Rust in detail. We’re looking for innovative ideas to make it easier to use Rust and libraries written in Rust by improving the experience of using documentation and browsing through code.</p> <p>This project might choose multiple applicants that would work together as a team.</p> <p>Who should apply for this project:</p> <ul> <li>Background in graphic design, web design, web frontend development, or user experience</li> <li>Interest in improving usability of developer-facing documentation and tools</li> <li>Interest in learning in detail about Rust syntax and semantics</li> </ul> <img src="/images/2017-06-Increasing-Rusts-Reach/nrc.jpg" alt="Nick Cameron" class="right-thumbnail"> <p><em>About Nick Cameron: I'm a Rust core team member and lead the dev-tools team. I work on a bunch of tools including Rustdoc, Rustfmt, the Rust Language Server, and the Rust compiler. I want to make Rust developer tools awesome, and user experience is a key part of that. I want Rust to change the world (or at least the programming world), and we can't do that without making the Rust language and community more accessible to more people.</em></p> <img src="/images/2017-06-Increasing-Rusts-Reach/steveklabnik.jpeg" alt="Steve Klabnik" class="right-thumbnail"> <p><em>About Steve Klabnik: I used to work on Ruby on Rails before Rust, and one of the reasons why I love Rust is that as a project, we're committed to helping people learn Rust as their first low-level language. So in some sense, I see this as a continuation of that.</em></p> <p><em>However, by the same token, many low-level programmers are not web developers. This means that much of Rust's web stuff is... not exactly great. Since I come from the web world, I'm trying to help; but I'm only one person! And not only that, I'm more of a backend person, and so am personally lacking experience with front-end stuff.</em></p> <p><em>So, I see this project as a classic skills exchange: you bring your expertise in web technologies, we bring our expertise in Rust, everyone learns, and our code gets better!</em></p> <h3 id="2-adding-code-lints-to-the-clippy-developer-tool">2. Adding Code Lints to the Clippy Developer Tool</h3> <p>Rust partner: Manish Goregaokar</p> <p>Clippy is the linter for Rust. It’s a static analysis tool that finds issues in your code and reports them to the developer, often with suggested fixes. This project will involve adding more such lints and improving the existing ones to be more helpful and user-friendly. We would love your ideas and help in the following ways:</p> <ol> <li>Improving &amp; fixing bugs in existing Lints.</li> <li>Adding lints focused on helping people make the transition to Rust from a particular language</li> <li>Lints that serve as a tutorial that introduce ideas and teach code improvements</li> <li>Your idea!</li> </ol> <p>Who should apply for this project:</p> <ul> <li>Some experience using a linter in another language (examples: rubocop in Ruby, jslint in JavaScript, pylint in Python, Coverity, etc)</li> <li>Interest in improving the new Rust developer experience</li> <li>Interest in learning how to improve and create lints</li> </ul> <img src="/images/2017-06-Increasing-Rusts-Reach/manish.png" alt="Manish Goregaokar" class="right-thumbnail"> <p><em>About Manish Goregaokar: I'm a research engineer at Mozilla working on Servo. I care a lot about improving workflows and tooling, especially around the newcomer experience.</em></p> <p><em>I consider open source to be one of the best ways to gain proficiency in programming, and to that end I care about making it more accessible and easy to contribute to, both by systemic improvements and individual mentorship.</em></p> <h3 id="3-improve-the-approachability-of-the-design-of-rust-lang-org-and-or-crates-io">3. Improve the Approachability of the Design of rust-lang.org and/or crates.io</h3> <p>Rust Partner: Aaron Turon</p> <p>I'd love to pair up with one or more people on the design of <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/en-US/">our main website</a> and/or <a href="https://crates.io/">crates.io</a>. Both of them could <em>really</em> be improved in a way that could make a big impact on Rust's approachability, and I've got a lot of ideas (and complaints) to start with. There's also potential to bootstrap a whole new design subteam from the project, if successful.</p> <p>This project might choose multiple applicants that would work together as a team.</p> <p>Who should apply for this project:</p> <ul> <li>Background in graphic design, web design, information architecture, or user experience</li> <li>Interest in improving approachability of Rust</li> <li>Interest in investigating the motivations behind visitors to the main website and/or crates.io</li> </ul> <img src="/images/2017-06-Increasing-Rusts-Reach/aturon.jpg" alt="Aaron Turon" class="right-thumbnail"> <p><em>About Aaron Turon: I'm a Rust core team member, manage the Mozilla Rust team, and currently lead the library, infrastructure, and Cargo teams. On the technical side, I'm most driven by language design and end-to-end user experience. On the people side, I love fostering consensus, building teams, and empowering people. I live in Portland, Oregon with my partner and two daughters.</em></p> <p><em>Working in an open source community has shown me, over and over, how vital a diversity of perspectives and backgrounds can be. My hope is that, by investing in initiatives like this one, we can welcome a broader range of people and empower them within the Rust community.</em></p> <h3 id="4-improving-the-video-tutorials-at-intorust-com">4. Improving the Video Tutorials at intorust.com</h3> <p>Rust partner: Niko Matsakis</p> <p><a href="http://intorust.com/">intorust.com</a> is a website with a collection of screencasts that aim to teach key Rust concepts in an easy and accessible way. I would love to work with someone both on expanding the material to cover more parts of Rust as well as making sure that it is understandable to as broad an audience as possible. Another interesting avenue might be expanding the site to also cover background topics like the role of the stack and the heap.</p> <p>Who should apply for this project:</p> <ul> <li>Background in teaching or tutoring</li> <li>Background or interest in creating visual teaching tools like diagrams or drawings a plus</li> <li>Interest in learning Rust concepts and teaching what you learn to others</li> </ul> <img src="/images/2017-06-Increasing-Rusts-Reach/nmatsakis.jpeg" alt="Niko Matsakis" class="right-thumbnail"> <p><em>About Niko Matsakis: I'm a member of the Rust core team as well as the Rust language and compiler teams. I focus mainly on the design and implementation of the language itself. I want to do what I can to make learning Rust as smooth as possible for as many people as possible. I think that the best way to achieve this goal is to work with people with different backgrounds and experiences, since that will affect how they learn the material.</em></p> <h3 id="5-write-tutorials-for-rocket-and-diesel-parts-of-rust-s-web-framework-story">5. Write tutorials for Rocket and Diesel, Parts of Rust’s Web Framework Story</h3> <p>Rust Partner: Sean Griffin</p> <p>I’m looking for someone with experience in web development in some other web framework to help improve the documentation around Rust's frameworks in the web development space. I’d love to improve the new user experience for using <a href="https://rocket.rs/">Rocket</a> (a web framework) and <a href="http://diesel.rs/">Diesel</a> (an ORM) together. This could include writing tutorials, creating screencasts, making example applications, or improving the API documentation.</p> <p>Who should apply for this project:</p> <ul> <li>Background in teaching or tutoring</li> <li>Experience using a web framework written in some other language</li> <li>Interest in learning how to write web applications in Rust and teaching what you learn to others</li> </ul> <img src="/images/2017-06-Increasing-Rusts-Reach/sgrif.jpeg" alt="Sean Griffin" class="right-thumbnail"> <p><em>About Sean Griffin: In addition to my Rust work, I am one of the maintainers of Ruby on Rails. One of the great things about Rails (and web development) is that it has really helped to lower the barrier to entry. I think Rust can have a similar impact (both for low level programming, and competing as a high level language). However, at the moment Rust has a notoriously bad learning curve. Improving that with input from as many viewpoints as possible seems like the best way to help even the playing field once again.</em></p> <h3 id="6-extending-the-literate-programming-tool-tango">6. Extending the Literate Programming Tool Tango</h3> <p>Rust partner: Felix Klock</p> <p>I'm looking for someone interested in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Literate_programming">&quot;programs as literature&quot;</a> to help me extend <a href="https://github.com/pnkfelix/tango/"><code>tango</code></a> (a literate programming tool for Rust) so that it can be used for more than just demos and slideshows. If you have experience writing meta-commentary about your own code, documenting how it works for the purpose of teaching others about it, then you might be the person I am seeking! Check out [this markdown file](https://github.com/pnkfelix/mon-artist/blob/a3388c11e8b1910cc4eb4c31bd1540a46851618b/src/lit/s rc/format.md) that tango is able to turn into an executable Rust code file for an example of what tango can do. You can see some ideas for extensions from the <a href="https://github.com/pnkfelix/tango/issues"><code>tango</code></a> <a href="https://github.com/pnkfelix/tango/issues">issues</a> page.</p> <p>Who should apply for this project:</p> <ul> <li>Background in writing, teaching, or documentation</li> <li>Interest in, and opinions about, improving tools for creating and displaying code documentation</li> </ul> <img src="/images/2017-06-Increasing-Rusts-Reach/pnkfelix.jpeg" alt="Felix Klock" class="right-thumbnail"> <p><em>About Felix Klock: I'm the main developer of tango (as well as a member of the Rust compiler and language teams). I actively use tango for authoring my presentation slides about Rust. I hypothesize that literate Rust code can act as advertisement for Rust itself, and would like to figure out how we could make the tool more useful for real-world crates.</em></p> <p><em>More generally: I am a long adherent to the idea that computers can be a powerful <a href="http://www.ccs.neu.edu/home/matthias/HtDP2e/part_preface.html">educational tool</a>. Rust provides a unique vessel for the intrepid explorers plunging into and past the levels of abstraction that lie atop the machine. I want Rust to maximize its <a href="https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/mission/">accessibility to all</a>, so that it does not fall into an echo chamber of thought and end up as a technology only usable by elite wizards, thus missing this educational opportunity.</em></p> <h3 id="7-finding-missing-pieces-in-the-crates-ecosystem">7. Finding Missing Pieces in the Crates Ecosystem</h3> <p>Rust partner: Andrew Gallant</p> <p>I’m interested in working with someone to discover where there might be gaps in the kinds of crates that are available. This project would involve first writing a small application in the language or framework that you’re most comfortable with. Then we’d attempt to port that application to Rust and keep track of where there are libraries missing or functionality missing from the libraries that are available. The Rust community can then take your findings to fill in those gaps and make Rust usable in more scenarios.</p> <p>Who should apply for this project:</p> <ul> <li>Experience using libraries to build applications in some other programming language</li> <li>Interest in learning how to translate an application to Rust</li> <li>Interest in researching and documenting features that libraries have or don’t have</li> </ul> <img src="/images/2017-06-Increasing-Rusts-Reach/burntsushi.jpeg" alt="Andrew Gallant" class="right-thumbnail"> <p><em>About Andrew Gallant: I'm a member of the Rust library team that works with Rust in my free time. I am very interested in information retrieval, fast text search and generally improving Rust's ecosystem. I'm driven both by own personal interest in technical topics and the desire to teach. Aside from my own technical interest in languages like Rust, I really love working on the project because it provides an outlet to teach others about the things I've learned. I'm particularly interested in improving the learning outcomes for as many people as possible, and would relish the opportunity to extend that to folks that I might not have been able to reach otherwise. I live in central Massachusetts with my wife.</em></p> <h3 id="8-finding-missing-pieces-in-the-experience-of-building-a-command-line-interface-cli-program">8. Finding Missing Pieces in the Experience of building a Command Line Interface (CLI) Program</h3> <p>Rust partner: Kamal Marhubi</p> <p>I find Rust to be a great language for writing small command line tools, but I think it could be even better. I'd love to work with someone who wants to write a CLI program, or has one they want to port to Rust. There are almost certainly rough edges, and working together would be a great way to find them and improve the tooling for everyone.</p> <p>Who should apply for this project:</p> <ul> <li>Experience building and using tools with a command line interface in some other language</li> <li>Interest in learning how to write or translate a CLI program to Rust</li> <li>Interest in researching and documenting features that libraries have or don’t have</li> </ul> <img src="/images/2017-06-Increasing-Rusts-Reach/kamalmarhubi.jpeg" alt="Kamal Marhubi" class="right-thumbnail"> <p><em>About Kamal Marhubi: I've been writing Rust for about a year and a half. I help maintain nix, a library that gives a Rusty interface to unix systems APIs. I've also contributed to rustfmt, rustup, and the standard library.</em></p> <hr /> <p>We're excited to get <a href="https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfbSGuoyZE9dctdEoC_XEZ7j2ox7jQT1zghAOF4iGds2PfBCA/viewform">your application</a> before July 18! We will notify all applicants by Aug 1.</p> Announcing Rust 1.18 Thu, 08 Jun 2017 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-18/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-18/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce the latest version of Rust, 1.18.0. Rust is a systems programming language focused on safety, speed, and concurrency.</p> <p>If you have a previous version of Rust installed, getting Rust 1.18 is as easy as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">rustup</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> update stable </span></pre> <p>If you don't have it already, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">get <code>rustup</code></a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1180-2017-06-08">detailed release notes for 1.18.0</a> on GitHub.</p> <h3 id="what-s-in-1-18-0-stable">What's in 1.18.0 stable</h3> <p>As usual, Rust 1.18.0 is a collection of improvements, cleanups, and new features.</p> <p>One of the largest changes is a long time coming: core team members Carol Nichols and Steve Klabnik have been writing a new edition of &quot;The Rust Programming Language&quot;, the official book about Rust. It's being <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/book">written openly on GitHub</a>, and has over a hundred contributors in total. This release <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/">includes the first draft of the second edition in our online documentation</a>. 19 out of 20 chapters have a draft; the draft of chapter 20 will land in Rust 1.19. When the book is done, a print version will be made available through <a href="https://www.nostarch.com/Rust">No Starch Press</a>, if you'd like a paper copy. We're still working with the editors at No Starch to improve the text, but we wanted to start getting a wider audience now.</p> <p>The new edition is a complete re-write from the ground up, using the last two years of knowledge we've gained from teaching people Rust. You'll find brand-new explanations for a lot of Rust's core concepts, new projects to build, and all kinds of other good stuff. Please check it out and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/book/issues/new">let us know what you think</a>!</p> <p>As for the language itself, an old feature has learned some new tricks: the <code>pub</code> keyword has been expanded a bit. Experienced Rustaceans will know that items are private by default in Rust, and you can use the <code>pub</code> keyword to make them public. In Rust 1.18.0, <code>pub</code> has <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/40556">gained a new form</a>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">pub</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">crate</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) bar; </span></pre> <p>The bit inside of <code>()</code> is a 'restriction', which refines the notion of how this is made public. Using the <code>crate</code> keyword like the example above means that <code>bar</code> would be public to the entire crate, but not outside of it. This makes it easier to declare APIs that are &quot;public to your crate&quot;, but not exposed to your users. This was <em>possible</em> with the existing module system, but often very awkward.</p> <p>You can also specify a path, like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">pub</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">in </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">a::b::c) foo; </span></pre> <p>This means &quot;usable within the hierarchy of <code>a::b::c</code>, but not elsewhere.&quot; This feature was defined in <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/1422-pub-restricted.md">RFC 1422</a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/reference/visibility-and-privacy.html#pubin-path-pubcrate-pubsuper-and-pubself">is documented in the reference</a>.</p> <p>For our Windows users, Rust 1.18.0 has <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/40870">a new attribute, <code>#![windows_subsystem]</code></a>. It works like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">#![</span><span style="color:#c82829;">windows_subsystem </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;console&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] #![</span><span style="color:#c82829;">windows_subsystem </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;windows&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span></pre> <p>These control the <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/fcc1zstk.aspx"><code>/SUBSYSTEM</code> flag</a> in the linker. For now, only <code>&quot;console&quot;</code> and <code>&quot;windows&quot;</code> are supported.</p> <p>When is this useful? In the simplest terms, if you're developing a graphical application, and do not specify <code>&quot;windows&quot;</code>, a console window would flash up upon your application's start. With this flag, it won't.</p> <p>Finally, Rust's tuples, enum variant fields, and structs (without <code>#[repr]</code>) have always had an unspecified layout. <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/40377">We've turned on automatic re-ordering</a>, which can result in smaller sizes through reducing padding. Consider a struct like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Suboptimal(</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u8</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u16</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u8</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); </span></pre> <p>In previous versions of Rust on the x86_64 platform, this struct would have the size of six bytes. But looking at the source, you'd expect it to have four. The extra two bytes come from padding; given that we have a <code>u16</code> here, it should be aligned to two bytes. But in this case, it's at offset one. To move it to offset two, another byte of padding is placed after the first <code>u8</code>. To give the whole struct a proper alignment, another byte is added after the second <code>u8</code> as well, giving us <code>1 + 1 (padding) + 2 + 1 + 1 (padding) = 6 bytes</code>.</p> <p>But what if our struct looked like this?</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Optimal(</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u8</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u8</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u16</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); </span></pre> <p>This struct is properly aligned; the <code>u16</code> lies on a two byte boundary, and so does the entire struct. No padding is needed. This gives us <code>1 + 1 + 2 = 4 bytes</code>.</p> <p>When designing Rust, we left the details of memory layout undefined for just this reason. Because we didn't commit to a particular layout, we can make improvements to it, such as in this case where the compiler can optimize <code>Suboptimal</code> into <code>Optimal</code> automatically. And if you check the sizes of <code>Suboptimal</code> and <code>Optimal</code> on Rust 1.18.0, you'll see that they both have a size of four bytes.</p> <p>We've been planning this change for a while; previous versions of Rust included this optimization on the nightly channel, but some people wrote unsafe code that assumed the exact details of the representation. We rolled it back while we fixed all instances of this that we know about, but if you find some code breaks due to this, please let us know so we can help fix it! Structs used for FFI can be given the <code>#[repr(C)]</code> annotation to prevent reordering, in addition to C-compatible field layout.</p> <p>We've been planning on moving <code>rustdoc</code> to use a CommonMark compliant markdown parser for a long time now. However, just switching over can introduce regressions where the CommonMark spec differs from our existing parser, Hoedown. As part of the transition plan, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/40338">a new flag has been added to <code>rustdoc</code></a>, <code>--enable-commonmark</code>. This will use the new parser instead of the old one. Please give it a try! As far as we know, both parsers will produce identical results, but we'd be interested in knowing if you find a scenario where the rendered results differ!</p> <p>Finally, compiling <code>rustc</code> itself is now <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/41469">15%-20% faster</a>. Each commit message in this PR goes over the details; there were some inefficiencies, and now they've been cleaned up.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1180-2017-06-08">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h4 id="library-stabilizations">Library stabilizations</h4> <p>Seven new APIs were stabilized this release:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/process/struct.Child.html#method.try_wait"><code>Child::try_wait</code></a> is a non-blocking form of <code>Child::wait</code>.</li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/collections/struct.HashMap.html#method.retain"><code>HashMap::retain</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/collections/struct.HashSet.html#method.retain"><code>HashSet::retain</code></a> bring the <code>retain</code> API <code>Vec&lt;T&gt;</code> has to these two hash data structures.</li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/collections/binary_heap/struct.PeekMut.html#method.pop"><code>PeekMut::pop</code></a> lets you pop the top element from a <code>BinaryHeap&lt;T&gt;</code> after you've already peeked at it without needing to reorder the heap a second time.</li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/net/struct.TcpStream.html#method.peek"><code>TcpStream::peek</code></a>, <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/net/struct.UdpSocket.html#method.peek"><code>UdpSocket::peek</code></a>, <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/net/struct.UdpSocket.html#method.peek_from"><code>UdpSocket::peek_from</code></a> let you peek at a stream or socket.</li> </ul> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1180-2017-06-08">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h4 id="cargo-features">Cargo features</h4> <p>Cargo has <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/3842">added support</a> for the Pijul VCS, which is written in Rust. <code>cargo new my-awesome-project --vcs=pijul</code> will get you going!</p> <p>To supplement the <code>--all</code> flag, Cargo now has <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/3901">several new flags</a> such as <code>--bins</code>, <code>--examples</code>, <code>--tests</code>, and <code>--benches</code>, which will let you build all programs of that type.</p> <p>Finally, Cargo now supports <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/3952">Haiku</a> and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/3885">Android</a>!</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1180-2017-06-08">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h3 id="contributors-to-1-18-0">Contributors to 1.18.0</h3> <p>Many people came together to create Rust 1.18. We couldn't have done it without all of you. <a href="https://thanks.rust-lang.org/rust/1.18.0">Thanks!</a></p> Two years of Rust Mon, 15 May 2017 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-at-two-years/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-at-two-years/ <p>Rust is a language for confident, productive systems programming. It aims to make systems programming accessible to a wider audience, and to raise the ambitions of dyed-in-the-wool systems hackers.</p> <p>It's been two years since Rust 1.0 was released. Happy second birthday, Rust!</p> <p><img src="/images/2017-05-Second-Birthday/rustfest-berlin.jpeg" alt="Group picture from RustFest Berlin" /></p> <p><em>Rustaceans at RustFest Berlin, September 2016. Picture by Fiona Castiñeira</em></p> <p>Over these two years, we have demonstrated stability without stagnation, maintaining backwards compatibility with version 1.0 while also making many improvements. Conveniently, Rust's birthday is a bit under halfway through 2017, which makes this a great time to reflect not only on the progress in the last year but also on the progress of our <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/02/06/roadmap.html">2017 Roadmap</a> goals.</p> <p>After reading this post, if you'd like to give us your feedback on how we're doing and where Rust should focus next, please fill out our <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/05/03/survey.html">2017 State of Rust survey</a>.</p> <p>But first, let's do the numbers!</p> <h2 id="rust-in-numbers">Rust in numbers</h2> <p>A lot has happened since <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2016/05/16/rust-at-one-year.html">Rust's first birthday</a>:</p> <ul> <li>10,800 <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/commits/master">commits</a> by 663 contributors (438 of them new this year) added to the core repository;</li> <li>56 <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs">RFCs</a> merged;</li> <li>9 minor releases and 2 patch releases shipped;</li> <li>4,405 new <a href="https://crates.io/">crates</a> published;</li> <li>284 standard library stabilizations;</li> <li>10 languages <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/">rust-lang.org</a> has been translated into;</li> <li>48 new companies <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/en-US/friends.html">running Rust in production</a>;</li> <li>4 new teams (Docs, Style, Infrastructure, and the Unsafe Guidelines strike team);</li> <li>24 occasions of adding people to teams, 6 retirings of people from teams;</li> <li>3 babies born to people on <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/en-US/team.html">the Rust teams</a>;</li> <li>2 years of <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/10/30/Stability.html">stability delivered</a>.</li> </ul> <p>On an average week this year, the Rust community merged 1 RFC and published 83 new crates. Rust topped the &quot;<a href="https://insights.stackoverflow.com/survey/2017#technology-most-loved-dreaded-and-wanted-languages">most loved</a> language&quot; for the second year in a row in the StackOverflow survey. Also new this year is <a href="https://thanks.rust-lang.org/">thanks.rust-lang.org</a>, a site where you can browse contributors by release.</p> <h2 id="rust-in-production">Rust in production</h2> <p>In addition to the 48 new Rust friends, we now have a <a href="https://rustjobs.rs/">Rust jobs website</a>! More and more companies are choosing Rust to solve problems involving performance, scaling, and safety. Let's check in on a few of them.</p> <p><a href="https://www.dropbox.com/">Dropbox</a> is using Rust in multiple high-impact projects to manage exabytes of data on the back end, where correctness and efficiency is critical. Rust code is also currently shipping in the desktop client on Windows running on <strong>hundreds of millions</strong> of machines. Jamie Turner recently <a href="https://air.mozilla.org/rust-meetup-may-2017/">spoke at the SF Rust Meetup</a> about the details on how Rust helps Dropbox use less RAM and get more throughput with less CPU.</p> <p>Mozilla, Rust's main sponsor, has accelerated their use of Rust in production. Not only did <a href="https://blog.servo.org/2016/06/30/servo-nightlies/">Servo start shipping nightly builds</a>, <a href="https://hacks.mozilla.org/2016/07/shipping-rust-in-firefox/">Firefox 48</a> marked the first Firefox release that included Rust code as part of the <a href="https://wiki.mozilla.org/Oxidation">Oxidation</a> project. <a href="https://medium.com/mozilla-tech/a-quantum-leap-for-the-web-a3b7174b3c12">Project Quantum</a>, announced in October 2016, is an effort to incrementally adopt proven parts of Servo into Firefox's rendering engine, Gecko. <a href="https://hacks.mozilla.org/2017/05/quantum-up-close-what-is-a-browser-engine/">Check out this blog series</a> that's just getting started for a detailed look at Project Quantum.</p> <p><a href="https://www.gnome.org/">GNOME</a>, a free and open source desktop environment for Linux, went from experimenting with Rust in <a href="https://people.gnome.org/%7Efederico/news-2016-10.html#25">librsvg</a> in October 2016 to a <a href="https://wiki.gnome.org/Hackfests/Rust2017">hackfest</a> in March to work on the interoperability between GNOME and Rust to enable more GNOME components to be written in Rust. The hackfest participants made good progress, be sure to check out the reports at the bottom of the hackfest page for all the details. We're all excited about the possibilities of Rust and GNOME working together.</p> <p>This year, <a href="https://www.npmjs.com/">npm</a> started using Rust in production to serve JavaScript packages. The Rust pieces eliminate performance bottlenecks in their platform that serves around 350 million packages a day. <a href="http://2017.rustfest.eu/talks/#how-i-convinced-the-world-s-largest-package-manager-to-use-rust-and-so-can-you">Ashley Williams recently gave a talk</a> at RustFest in Ukraine about npm's experience with Rust in production; check out the <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GCsxYAxw3JQ">video</a>.</p> <p>This is just a sampling of the success stories accumulating around Rust. If you're using Rust in production, we want to <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-www/issues/new?title=New+Website+Logo%3A+%5Binsert+name%5D%0A&amp;body=To+list+your+organization%27s+logo+on+the+Rust+website%2C+fill+out+the+following+information+and+click+%22submit+new+issue%22.+Alternately%2C+you+may+edit+_data%2Fusers.yml+as+described+therein+and+submit+a+pull+request.%0D%0A%0D%0A-+Organization+name%3A+%28as+you+want+it+displayed%29%0D%0A-+Homepage+url%3A+%28homepage%2Fprimary+entry+point+for+users%29%0D%0A-+Logo+url%3A+%28svg+if+possible%2C+pngs+over+400x200px+with+transparent+backgrounds+are+also+acceptable%29%0D%0A-+How+you+are+using+Rust%3A+%28one+sentence+describing+your+use+of+Rust%29%0D%0A-+Url+describing+Rust+usage%3A+%28optional+link+to+e.g.+blog+post+explaining+how+you+use+Rust%29%0D%0A-+Organization+contact%3A+%28name+and+email.+we+may+contact+you+when+updating+this+page.+alternately+you+may+email+this+information+to+user-logos%40rust-lang.org+and+it+will+be+kept+secret%29.%0D%0A">hear yours too</a>!</p> <h2 id="rust-in-community">Rust in community</h2> <p>Speaking of conferences, We've had four Rust conferences in the last year:</p> <ul> <li>September 9-10, 2016: <a href="http://rustconf.com/2016/">RustConf 2016</a> in Portland, OR, USA;</li> <li>September 17, 2016: <a href="http://2016.rustfest.eu/">RustFest 2016</a> in Berlin, Germany;</li> <li>October 27-28, 2016: <a href="http://conf2016.rust-belt-rust.com/">Rust Belt Rust 2016</a> in Pittsburgh, PA, USA;</li> <li>April 29-30, 2017: <a href="http://2017.rustfest.eu/">RustFest 2017</a> in Kyiv, Ukraine.</li> </ul> <p>And we have at least three conferences coming up!</p> <ul> <li>August 18-19, 2017: <a href="http://rustconf.com/">RustConf 2017</a> in Portland, OR, USA;</li> <li>September, 2017: <a href="https://rustfest.ch/">Another RustFest</a> in Zurich, Switzerland;</li> <li>October 26-27, 2017: <a href="https://rust-belt-rust.com/">Rust Belt Rust 2017</a> in Columbus, OH, USA.</li> </ul> <p>That's not even including the <a href="https://rust.meetup.com/">103 meetups worldwide</a> about Rust. Will you be the one to run the fourth conference or start the 104th meetup? <a href="https://community.rs/">Contact the community team</a> for help and support!</p> <h2 id="rust-in-2017">Rust in 2017</h2> <p>The <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/02/06/roadmap.html">2017 Roadmap</a> goals have been great for focusing community efforts towards the most pressing issues facing Rust today. Of course we'd love for every aspect of Rust to improve all the time, but we don't have an infinite number of contributors with an infinite amount of time available yet!</p> <p>Let's check in on some of the initiatives in each of the goals in the roadmap. The linked tracking issues give even more detail than the summaries here.</p> <h3 id="rust-should-have-a-lower-learning-curve"><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/3">Rust should have a lower learning curve</a></h3> <p>The second edition of <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/book">The Rust Programming Language Book</a> is one chapter shy of having its initial content complete. There's lots more editing to be done to get the book ready for publication in October, though. The print version is currently available for <a href="https://www.nostarch.com/rust">preorder from No Starch</a>, and the online version of the second edition has boarded <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/beta/book/">the beta train</a> and will be an option in the documentation shipped with Rust 1.18.0. Steve and I have gotten feedback that <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/book/second-edition/ch04-00-understanding-ownership.html">the ownership chapter</a> especially is much improved and has helped people understand ownership related concepts better!</p> <p>The <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/03/02/lang-ergonomics.html">Language Ergonomics Initiative</a> is another part of the lower learning curve goal that has <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/17">a number of improvements</a> in its pipeline. The language team is eager to mentor people (another goal!) who are interested in getting involved with moving these ergonomic improvement ideas forward by writing RFCs and working with the community to flesh out the details of how these improvements would work. Comment on the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/17">tracking issue</a> if you'd like to jump in.</p> <p>Also check out:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://rust-lang-nursery.github.io/rust-cookbook/">The Rust Cookbook</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/35233">The new error format rolled out in Rust 1.12.0</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/31954">The question mark operator stabilized in Rust 1.13.0</a></li> </ul> <h3 id="rust-should-have-a-pleasant-edit-compile-debug-cycle"><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/1">Rust should have a pleasant edit-compile-debug cycle</a></h3> <p>Waiting on the compiler is the biggest roadblock preventing the Rust development workflow from being described as &quot;pleasant&quot;. So far, a lot of work has been done behind the scenes to make future improvements possible. Those improvements are starting to come to fruition, but rest assured that this initiative is far from being considered complete.</p> <p>One of the major prerequisites to improvements was adding <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2016/04/19/MIR.html">MIR</a> (Mid-level Intermediate Representation) to the compiler pipeline. This year, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/34096">MIR became a default part of the compilation process</a>.</p> <p>Because of MIR, we're now able to work on adding incremental recompilation. Nightly builds currently offer <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/incremental-compilation-beta/4721">&quot;beta&quot; support</a> for it, permitting the compiler to skip over code generation for code that hasn't changed. We are in the midst of refactoring the compiler to support finer-grained incremental computation, allowing us to skip type-checking and other parts of compilation as well. This refactoring should also offer better support for the IDE work (see next section), since it enables the compiler to do things like compile a single function in isolation. We expect to see the next stage of incremental compilation becoming available over the next few months. If you're interested in getting involved, please check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/4">roadmap issue #4</a>, which is updated periodically to reflect the current status, as well as places where help is needed.</p> <p><a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/incremental-compilation-beta/4721">The February post</a> on the &quot;beta&quot; support showed that recompiling in release mode will often be <strong>five times as fast</strong> with incremental compilation! This graph shows the improvements in compilation time when making changes to various parts of the regex crate and rebuilding in release mode:</p> <p><img src="/images/2017-05-Second-Birthday/incremental-compilation.svg" alt="Graph showing improved time with incremental compilation" /></p> <p>Try out incremental compilation on nightly Rust with <code>CARGO_INCREMENTAL=1 cargo &lt;command&gt;</code>!</p> <p><em>Thanks to Niko Matsakis for this incremental compilation summary!</em></p> <p>We've also made some progress on the time it takes to do a full compilation. On average, compile times have improved by 5-10% in the last year, but some worst-case behavior has been fixed that results in &gt;95% improvements in certain programs. Some very promising improvements are on the way for later this year; check out <a href="https://perf.rust-lang.org/">perf.rust-lang.org</a> for monitoring Rust's performance day-to-day.</p> <h3 id="rust-should-provide-a-basic-but-solid-ide-experience"><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/2">Rust should provide a basic, but solid IDE experience</a></h3> <p>As part of our IDE initiative, we created the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rls">Rust Language Server</a> project. Its goal is to create a single tool that makes it easy for any editor or IDE to have the full power of the Rust compiler for error checking, code navigation, and refactoring by using the standard <a href="http://langserver.org/">language server protocol</a> created by Microsoft and Eclipse.</p> <p>While still early in its life, today the RLS is <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rls#setup">available from rustup</a> for nightly users. It provides type information on hover, error messages as you type, and different kinds of code navigation. It even provides refactoring and formatting as unstable features! It works with projects as large as Cargo. We're excited to watch the RLS continue to grow and hope to see it make its way to stable Rust later this year.</p> <p><em>Thanks to Jonathan Turner for this RLS summary!</em></p> <h3 id="rust-should-have-1-0-level-crates-for-essential-tasks-and-rust-should-provide-easy-access-to-high-quality-crates"><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/11">Rust should have 1.0-level crates for essential tasks</a>, and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/9">Rust should provide easy access to high quality crates</a></h3> <p>The <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/05/05/libz-blitz.html">recent post on the Libz Blitz</a> details the Library Team's initiative to increase the quality of crates for common tasks; that post is excellent so I won't repeat it here. I will note that many of the issues that the Libs Team is going to create will be great starter issues. For the blitz to be the best it can be, the Libs Team is going to need help from the community-- that means YOU! :) They're willing to mentor people interested in contributing.</p> <p>In order to make awesome crates easier to find for particular purposes, crates.io now has <a href="https://crates.io/categories">categories</a> for crate authors to better indicate the use case of their crate. Crates can also now have CI badges, and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/41616">more improvements to crates.io's interface</a> are coming that will help you choose the crates that fit your needs.</p> <h3 id="rust-should-be-well-equipped-for-writing-robust-high-scale-servers"><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/10">Rust should be well-equipped for writing robust, high-scale servers</a></h3> <p>One of the major events in Rust's ecosystem in the last year was the introduction of a zero-cost <a href="https://aturon.github.io/blog/2016/08/11/futures/">futures</a> library, and a framework, <a href="https://tokio.rs/">Tokio</a>, for doing asynchronous I/O on top of it. These libraries are a boon for doing high-scale, high-reliability server programming, <em>productively</em>. Futures have been used with great success in <a href="https://github.com/facebook/wangle">C++</a>, <a href="https://finagle.github.io/">Scala</a>, and of course <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Promise">JavaScript</a> (under the guise of promises), and we're reaping similar benefits in Rust. However, the Rust library takes a new implementation approach that makes futures <em>allocation-free</em>. And Tokio builds on that to provide a futures-enabled event loop, and lots of tools for quickly implementing new protocols. A simple HTTP server using Tokio is among the fastest measured in the <a href="https://www.techempower.com/benchmarks/#section=data-r14&amp;hw=ph&amp;test=plaintext">TechEmpower</a> server benchmarks.</p> <p>Speaking of protocols, Rust's full-blown HTTP story is solidifying, with <a href="https://hyper.rs/">Hyper</a>'s master branch currently providing full Tokio support (and official release imminent). Work on HTTP/2 is well under way. And the web framework ecosystem is growing too. For example, <a href="https://rocket.rs/">Rocket</a> came out this year: it's a framework that marries the ergonomics and flexibility of a scripting framework with the performance and reliability of Rust. Together with supporting libraries like the <a href="https://diesel.rs/">Diesel</a> ORM, this ecosystem is showing how Rust can provide slick, ergonomic developer experiences without sacrificing an ounce of performance or reliability.</p> <p>Over the rest of this year, we expect all of the above libraries to significantly mature; for a middleware ecosystem to sprout up; for the selection of supported protocols and services to grow; and, quite possibly, to tie all this all together with an <code>async</code>/<code>await</code> notation that works natively with Rust's futures.</p> <p><em>Thanks to Aaron Turon for this server-side summary!</em></p> <h3 id="rust-should-integrate-easily-into-large-build-systems"><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/12">Rust should integrate easily into large build systems</a></h3> <p>Cargo, Rust's native package manager and build system, is often cited as one of people's favorite aspects of Rust. But of course, the world runs on many build systems, and when you want to bring a chunk of the Rust ecosystem into a large organization that has its own existing build system, smooth integration is paramount.</p> <p>This initiative is mostly in the ideas stage; we've done a lot of work with stakeholders to understand the challenges in build system integration today, and we think we have a good overall vision for how to solve them. There's lots of great discussion on the tracking issue that has resulted in a few Cargo issues like these:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/issues/3815">Support creating a build plan</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/issues/3816">Support declaring external dependencies</a></li> </ul> <p>There are a lot of details yet to be worked out; keep an eye out for more improvement in this area soon.</p> <h3 id="rust-s-community-should-provide-mentoring-at-all-levels"><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/13">Rust's community should provide mentoring at all levels</a></h3> <p>The &quot;all levels&quot; part of the roadmap item is important to us: it's about onboarding first-time contributors as well as adding folks all the way up at the core team level (like me, hi!)</p> <p>For people just getting started with Rust, we held <a href="https://github.com/rust-community/rustbridge">RustBridge</a> events before RustFest Berlin and Rust Belt Rust. There's another coming up, planned for the day before RustConf in Portland!</p> <p>The Mozilla Rust folks are going to have <a href="https://wiki.mozilla.org/Outreachy">Outreachy</a> and <a href="https://summerofcode.withgoogle.com/projects/#4730059156881408">GSoC</a> interns this summer working on a variety of projects.</p> <p>We've also had success involving contributors when there are low-committment, high impact tasks to be done. One of those efforts was <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2016/08/10/Shape-of-errors-to-come.html">improving the format of error messages</a>-- check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/35233">82 participants on this issue</a>! The Libz Blitz mentioned in a previous section is set up specifically to be another source of mentoring opportunities.</p> <p>In January, the Language Team introduced <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/language-team-shepherds/4595">shepherds</a>, which is partly about mentoring a set of folks around the Language Team. The shepherds have been quite helpful in keeping RFC discussions moving forward!</p> <p>We've also been working to grow both the number and size of subteams, to create more opportunities for people to step into leadership roles.</p> <p>There's also less formal ways that we've been helping people get involved with various initiatives. I've worked with many people at many places in their Rust journey: helping out with the conferences, giving their first conference talks, providing feedback on the book, working on crates, contributing to Rust itself, and joining teams! While it's hard to quantify scenarios like these, everywhere I turn, I see Rustaceans helping other Rustaceans and I'm grateful this is part of our culture.</p> <h2 id="rust-in-the-future">Rust in the future</h2> <p>At two years old, Rust is finding its way into all corners of programming, from web development, to embedded systems, and even your desktop. The libraries and the infrastructure are maturing, we're paving the on-ramp, and we're supporting each other. I'm optimistic about the direction Rust is taking!</p> <p>Happy birthday, Rust! Here's to many more! 🎉</p> The Rust Libz Blitz Fri, 05 May 2017 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/libz-blitz/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/libz-blitz/ <p>To help bring our <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/02/06/roadmap.html">2017 vision for Rust</a> to fruition, the Rust subteams are launching initiatives targeted at specific roadmap goals. <strong>This post covers the library team's major initiative: raising a solid core of the Rust crate ecosystem to a consistent level of completeness and quality.</strong> This work is guided in part by what we learned in producing the Rust standard library, and will result in a &quot;cookbook&quot; chock full of ready-made examples for common tasks, drawing from a careful selection of Rust crates.</p> <p>(Also, ICYMI: please participate in the <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/05/03/survey.html">State of Rust survey</a>; even if you don't use Rust, we'd love to hear from you!)</p> <h2 id="batteries-included">Batteries included?</h2> <p><strong>You can't be productive in a language without libraries that are easy to find and use.</strong> Of course, the easiest library to find is the standard library, and many languages have taken a &quot;batteries included&quot; approach that includes APIs for a broad set of tasks directly in the standard library. There's a lot of upside to doing so: it means there's just one place to look for common tasks, with APIs that (hopefully!) cohere across tasks, compatibility across the ecosystem, and a promise of library maintenance. What's not to like?</p> <p>There's a countervailing mindset which, in its harshest terms, says &quot;the standard library is where code goes to die&quot; (a complaint sometimes heard about batteries-included standard libraries). Because the standard library is coupled to the language itself, it is released at the same frequency as the language is, and making breaking changes means breaking the whole language.
