For these reasons and others, standard libraries tend to evolve conservatively.</p> <p>As usual in the Rust world, our goal is to have our cake and eat it too. <strong>Can we provide something like a batteries-included experience, without ossifying that code in the standard library?</strong> This is a particularly vital question for Rust because, as a community, we are still rapidly exploring and iterating on best practices for ownership-based API design.</p> <p>The key ingredient to our approach is <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2016/05/05/cargo-pillars.html">Cargo</a>, the package manager that shipped with Rust 1.0 and has been improving ever since. Cargo provides a unified dependency and workflow story across the entire Rust ecosystem, and makes adding dependencies a painless and relatively low-risk proposition. The ability to share code with ease is a powerful change to the character of, and audience for, traditional systems programming tasks.</p> <p>Because of Cargo, we can &quot;include batteries&quot; without literally putting them into the standard library; pulling in other crates is nearly as easy as using the standard library (and will likely get even easier this year). But to capitalize on this ability to the fullest, we need to have excellent libraries. <strong>Our mission for 2017 is to ensure that crates are available for a wide swath of common tasks and that they are <em>discoverable</em>, <em>cohesive</em>, <em>featureful</em>, and <em>well-documented</em>.</strong></p> <h2 id="the-rust-libz-blitz">The Rust Libz Blitz</h2> <p>Fortunately, while the standard library has stayed small and focused, the crates.io ecosystem has been growing at breakneck pace. So the challenge here isn't greenfield library work. It's more a question of: <strong>how can the Rust community work in a focused way to polish, consolidate, and surface a core set of libraries for essential tasks?</strong> Our answer is the Rust Libz Blitz.</p> <p>The basic idea is to:</p> <ul> <li>Collectively review a few crates at a time in a shared forum. The review draws in part from a set of <a href="https://github.com/brson/rust-api-guidelines">API guidelines</a>.</li> <li>Every two weeks, hold a library team meeting focused on open questions around one of these crates, with the author in attendance.</li> <li>Push this feedback onto a tracking issue for the crate, and point the Rust community there to help shoulder the burden of making improvements.</li> <li>Write up entries for each crate in a new Rust Cookbook, which will make it easy to discover the crate and jump into using it.</li> </ul> <p>The Rust library team has been quietly engaging in this process already for the past couple of months, to sort out the kinks. But now, we want to open it up to the whole Rust community. In the rest of the post, we'll dive a bit more deeply into the mechanics and goals of this process.</p> <h3 id="rust-standards-of-quality">Rust standards of quality</h3> <p>In all the work on the standard library, we have gained a sense of what makes Rust APIs great: principles like &quot;make performance characteristics clear&quot; and &quot;use ownership to encapsulate invariants&quot;; consistent naming conventions like <code>mut</code>, <code>ref</code>, <code>as</code>, <code>into</code>, that let users intuit what they don't know from what they do; small details of presentation that add up, like consistently documenting possible error cases in a dedicated &quot;Errors&quot; section; and so many more factors to consider when publishing Rust crates.</p> <p>In 2017 we plan to apply the principles behind the design of <code>std</code> to an ever-widening foundation of critical Rust libraries. Along the way we will document what we learn about Rust library design.</p> <p>The product of this process will be a mature core of libraries together with a set of <a href="https://github.com/brson/rust-api-guidelines">API guidelines</a> that Rust authors can follow to gain insight into the design of Rust and level up crates of their own interest. Today those guidelines are in a very early state, but give you a sense of where we are headed with this effort. Take a look and file issues where things are unclear or missing!</p> <h3 id="rust-standards-of-documentation">Rust standards of documentation</h3> <p>We recently ran a small survey to see what Rust programmers care most about when evaluating a crate. The <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/1824-crates.io-default-ranking.md#factors-considered-when-ranking-crates">most common criterion</a>, by far, was documentation. So a big part of the Libz Blitz process will be evaluating and improving the documentation of the targeted crates, which will supplement ongoing efforts to <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/book/">rewrite the Rust book</a> and provide comprehensive <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/29329">examples</a> for the standard library. The API guidelines contain a section dedicated to great documentation, and we aim for a consistent, easy to navigate docs experience across all of the core crates.</p> <p>Beyond documentation within the crates themselves (which tends to be more of the &quot;reference&quot; flavor), we are also starting a <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rust-cookbook">Rust Cookbook</a>, which will be organized around problems you want to solve, and provide quick, concrete example code you can drop directly into your project, drawing from a variety of crates (including the standard library). Examples like these are one of the most useful tools for quickly getting productive with a library, and collecting them all in one place, organized by problem, will help get us to a &quot;batteries included&quot; experience when working with Rust.</p> <p>Part of the work done in the Libz Blitz for each crate will be identifying the key problem statements the crate is trying to address, and adding strong examples for each to the cookbook.</p> <h3 id="rust-standards-of-discoverability">Rust standards of discoverability</h3> <p>Perhaps the biggest downside to having a small standard library is the problem of discoverability: when a Rust programmer needs to take on a task not covered by the standard library, how do they figure out where to look?</p> <p>The cookbook mentioned above will undoubtedly become a major part of our answer. But at the same time, we want to ensure that there's space for new crates to emerge, and that people can easily find crates beyond the most common problem areas. To that end, we're attacking discoverability head on, by rolling out badges for various quality indicators on crates.io, and greatly improving the default ranking of results (a design debated vigorously through <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1824">an RFC</a>). There's plenty of room for more work here, so if you have ideas about further improving discoverability on crates.io, <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/">please start a thread</a>!</p> <h3 id="rust-standards-of-community">Rust standards of community</h3> <p>We have some idea of what goes into publishing exceptional Rust crates, but the Rust library team is not the sole authority of Rust API design—the Rust crate ecosystem is created by all of us together and there are many lessons yet to learn. In recognition of that, <strong>the library team is architecting our efforts to be as welcoming and inclusive as we can</strong>.</p> <p>We will kick off forum discussions for evaluating existing crates that we believe are vital to set on a path toward stability, and which mostly need polish-level work to get there. These evaluations will be collaborative and intended for public commentary. They are designed to identify any issues separating the crate from &quot;1.0&quot; status (in terms of quality and API stability, as well as literal version number). Issues may include poor adherence to Rust API design principles, substantial missing functionality, planned API refactors, incomplete documentation, or any number of unique circumstances.</p> <p>We'll have a small handful of such evaluations going on in parallel. Every two weeks, the library team will take up one of the evaluations for discussion in our regular video conference, which will be recorded and made available on <a href="https://air.mozilla.org/">Air Mozilla</a> and the <a href="https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaYhcUwRBNscFNUKTjgPFiA">Rust YouTube channel</a>. One goal of these meetings will be to plan out a roadmap for stabilizing the crate in question. The other goal will be to identify any lessons to be learned from the crate and distill those into broadly applicable API guidelines.</p> <p>We will have a rotating band of guests (including the crate authors) at the video conferences by invitation, in order to strengthen the bonds between the Rust team and the authors of the Rust ecosystem, and to foster shared values among the same.</p> <p>Based on the evaluations and library team review, we will file issues that we believe are important to resolve before producing a stable release of the crate. <strong>We are counting on many of these issues being amenable to casual contributions</strong>.</p> <p>Here are the issues that arose from the very simple <a href="https://github.com/BurntSushi/byteorder/issues/76"><code>byteorder</code></a> crate (all resolved now):</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://github.com/BurntSushi/byteorder/issues/69">Add a supertrait to hide trait details</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/BurntSushi/byteorder/issues/68"><code>ByteOrder::default</code> should <code>panic!</code> not <code>unreachable!</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/BurntSushi/byteorder/issues/72">Put panic and error docs in &quot;Panics&quot; and &quot;Errors&quot; sections</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/BurntSushi/byteorder/issues/75">Make sure there are enough examples</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/BurntSushi/byteorder/issues/74">Add CI badges to Cargo.toml</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/BurntSushi/byteorder/issues/73">Add &quot;categories&quot; to Cargo.toml</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/BurntSushi/byteorder/issues/77">Add <code>#[doc(html_root_url)]</code></a></li> </ul> <p>Beyond <code>byteorder</code> we've already worked this process for several other simple crates to get a feel for it: <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/bitflags/issues/80"><code>bitflags</code></a>, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/tempdir/issues/28"><code>tempdir</code></a>, <a href="https://github.com/alexcrichton/flate2-rs/issues/89"><code>flate2</code></a>, and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/lazy-static.rs/issues/70"><code>lazy_static</code></a>. Even these, the most basic of crates, have some work left to do but you can expect them to have &quot;1.0&quot; releases soon. As the crates under evaluation grow in scope, presumably the tasks that arise will grow as well.</p> <h3 id="what-crates-are-we-going-to-focus-on">What crates are we going to focus on?</h3> <p>Rust has some amazing libraries in the works: things like <a href="https://tokio.rs/"><code>tokio</code></a> which is a really fast asynchronous I/O framework; like <a href="https://diesel.rs/"><code>diesel</code></a>, a really fast library for interacting with database tables; and like <a href="https://rocket.rs/"><code>rocket</code></a>, a really fast web framework.</p> <p>We are not going to be touching them.</p> <p>These high-profile libraries are built on <strong>dozens of smaller crates that perform crucial functions across the ecosystem</strong>: random number generation, memory mapping, compression, and so much more. We need to polish off the lower layers of the Rust stack so that those high-level libraries have a stable foundation to build on.</p> <p>Focusing on these lower layers is not only a practical consideration but a technical one—a crate should not be stable until its public dependencies are stable. Consider what it would mean for a hypothetical <a href="https://diesel.rs/"><code>diesel</code></a> 1.0 to export a function returning a type from a still-rapidly-developed <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/uuid/uuid/index.html"><code>uuid</code></a> 0.5. Before long it would be incompatible with other libraries using newer versions of <code>uuid</code>.</p> <p>Furthermore, many of these high-level libraries are very much undergoing their own rapid development, with their own strong leadership. We don't want to impose on those crates' authors' abilities to experiment with their designs by pressuring them to declare crates stable before they are ready. Those libraries will mature in time.</p> <p>But there are many foundational libraries that have reached relative stability, and are in some cases functionally complete and being widely used in production. Some need little work to put them across the finish line. Some, like the <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/rand/rand/index.html"><code>rand</code></a> crate, are widely used but known to have unsatisfactory designs. We want to finally put those crates to bed.</p> <p>We are currently drawing this list of foundational crates by combining crates.io dependency data, various existing curated crate listings, and good old gut feeling. The exact list is definitely up for debate, and we hope that the broader community will also apply this process completely independently to crates the libs team won't have time to discuss.</p> <h3 id="how-can-i-help">How can I help?</h3> <p>We're glad you asked! Creating a solid core of libraries for a young language is not the work of a single person or team—it is the work of the entire community. The central point of coordination is a <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/rust-libs-blitz/5184">thread on the Rust internals forum</a>. Read that thread for all the dirty details about what we're doing, and for ongoing opportunities to get involved.</p> <p>Roles that need your help:</p> <ul> <li> <p><strong>Crate lead</strong>. Each crate needs a volunteer to lead the evaluation effort. That entails starting up a thread, breaking up the evaluation work into small work items that can be taken on by others in the community, keeping the discussion moving in productive directions, making sure the evaluation is completed on time, presenting the results at the libs team meeting, and, finally, filing discrete, actionable issues on everything raised, and funneling them to TWiR.</p> <p><em>Anyone can be a crate lead, but it's a substantial commitment and is largely about organization, communication, and consensus, and requires presenting to the libs team in a video meeting.</em></p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Crate evaluator</strong>. This is the preliminary work of comparing a crate to the API guidelines, identifying deficiencies, and raising observations about API design that may impact the guidelines. It will often require working with the crate author to understand a crate's known shortcomings.</p> <p>Each evaluation will be published to the coordination thread, providing an opportunity for general feedback. Open feedback allows for a wide range of voices to be heard and is an important check against design myopia.</p> <p><em>This effort is collaborative and everyone is welcome to participate in this way at any time. The crate lead will help create opportunities to jump in.</em></p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Documentation slinger</strong>. A lot of the work involved in getting a crate up to full quality is improving documentation, including writing up cookbook entries. There will be lots of opportunities for this kind of high value work.</p> <p><em>Everyone is welcome to participate in this way at any time. The crate lead will help create opportunities to jump in.</em></p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Library hacker</strong>. Somebody must do the programming work of resolving the issues on the roadmap to stability for each crate. We expect to produce many discrete work items and that many of them will be accessible to inexperienced Rust programmers.</p> <p><em>Everyone is welcome to participate in this way at any time. The crate lead will help create opportunities to jump in.</em></p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Library designer</strong>. There remain some important libraries that are only lightly maintained but are known to require significant design work (again thinking of <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/rand/rand/index.html"><code>rand</code></a> especially). These will not improve without a dedicated and skilled author to drive them forward. We are going to be looking out for authors with the design skills necessary to fix the problems, and the social skills necessary to navigate the process.</p> <p><em>We will occasionally make pleas for help on specific design matters as they arise.</em></p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Libs team guest</strong>. The library team will spend one of their video meetings reviewing each crate evaluation. We hope that the crate authors will be interested in joining us, sharing their unique expertise, and getting to know the libs team. This kind of interaction creates strong bonds in a way that communicating through text does not. We hope this will foster shared values across the ecosystem, and pave the way for expanding the libs team more formally.</p> <p><em>This will be by invitation and focused on authors with an existing reputation for high quality work and productive collaboration.</em></p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Crate author</strong>. The libs team has some specific functionality and crates it wants to focus on this year. Outside of that, we are hopeful that the process and guidelines we develop will be widely useful and that crate authors will independently seek to evaluate and improve their own crates in similar ways.</p> </li> </ul> <h2 id="the-tl-dr">The TL;DR</h2> <p>Here's the plan:</p> <ul> <li>We will directly improve the most important crates you use every day.</li> <li>We will provide crate authors the guidance they need to do the same, in the form of <strong><a href="https://github.com/brson/rust-api-guidelines">API guidelines</a></strong>.</li> <li>We will create an endless stream of accessible contribution opportunities that directly contribute to key Rust strategic goals.</li> <li>We will produce cohesive documentation on how to use Rust's most foundational crates, in the form of a <strong><a href="https://rust-lang-nursery.github.io/rust-cookbook/">crate cookbook</a></strong>.</li> <li>We will launch a self-sustaining process of library improvement that can by applied consistently across the entire ecosystem.</li> </ul> <p>Thank you to everyone who has contributed thus far, including Alisha Aneja, Andrew Gallant, Brad Anderson, Charles Chamberlain, Dan Burkert, David Harris, Jan-Erik Rediger, Peter Atashian, Roman Frołow, Sean McArthur, Simon Sapin, Stephan Buys, Steven Fackler, Trent Spice.</p> Launching the 2017 State of Rust Survey Wed, 03 May 2017 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/2017-survey-launch/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/2017-survey-launch/ <p>Rust's second birthday is a little less than two weeks away (May 15th, 2017), so it's time for us to reflect on our progress over the past year, and how we should plan for the future. The Rust Community Team is pleased to announce our <a href="https://goo.gl/forms/pjcm3r2UjZhpAk4M2">2017 State of Rust Survey</a>! Whether or not you use Rust today, we want to know your opinions. Your responses will help the project understand its strengths and weaknesses, and to establish development priorities for the future.</p> <p>Completing this survey should take about 10 to 15 minutes, and is anonymous unless you choose to give us your contact information. We will be accepting submissions until June 12th, 2017, and we will write up our findings a month or so afterwards to <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org">blog.rust-lang.org</a>. You can see last year's results <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2016/06/30/State-of-Rust-Survey-2016.html">here</a>.</p> <p>Please help us spread the word by sharing the above link on your social network feeds, at meetups, around your office and in other communities.</p> <p>If you have any questions, please see our <a href="https://github.com/rust-community/team/wiki/State-of-the-Rust-Language-Community-Survey-FAQ">frequently asked questions</a> or email the Rust Community team at <a href="mailto:community-team@rust-lang.org">community-team@rust-lang.org</a>.</p> <p>Finally, we wanted to thank everyone who helped develop, polish, and test the survey!</p> <p>Happy birthday, Rust. Have another great year.</p> Announcing Rust 1.17 Thu, 27 Apr 2017 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-17/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-17/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce the latest version of Rust, 1.17.0. Rust is a systems programming language focused on safety, speed, and concurrency.</p> <p>If you have a previous version of Rust installed, getting Rust 1.17 is as easy as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">rustup</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> update stable </span></pre> <p>If you don't have it already, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">get <code>rustup</code></a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1170-2017-04-27">detailed release notes for 1.17.0</a> on GitHub.</p> <h3 id="what-s-in-1-17-0-stable">What's in 1.17.0 stable</h3> <p>The story of Rust 1.17.0 is mostly one of small, quality of life improvements. For example, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/39265">the <code>'static</code> lifetime is now assumed in statics and consts</a>. When writing a const or static like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">const </span><span style="color:#666969;">NAME</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">&#39;static str </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;Ferris&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">static </span><span style="color:#666969;">NAME</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">&#39;static str </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;Ferris&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span></pre> <p>Rust 1.17 will allow you to elide the <code>'static</code>, since that's the only lifetime that makes sense:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">const </span><span style="color:#666969;">NAME</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">str </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;Ferris&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">static </span><span style="color:#666969;">NAME</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">str </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;Ferris&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span></pre> <p>In some situations, this can remove lots of boilerplate:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#999999;">// old </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">const </span><span style="color:#666969;">NAMES</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">&#39;static </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">&#39;static str</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= &amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;Ferris&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;Bors&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">]; </span><span style="color:#999999;">// new </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">const </span><span style="color:#666969;">NAMES</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">str</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= &amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;Ferris&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;Bors&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">]; </span></pre> <p>Another similar improvement is &quot;field init shorthand.&quot; Similar to ECMAScript 6, which calls this &quot;Object Literal Property Value Shorthand&quot;, duplication can be removed when declaring structs, like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#999999;">// definitions </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Point { </span><span style="color:#c82829;">x</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#c82829;">y</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">5</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> y </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">6</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#999999;">// old </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> p </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> Point { x: x, y: y, }; </span><span style="color:#999999;">// new </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> p </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> Point { x, y, }; </span></pre> <p>That is, the <code>x, y</code> form will assume that its values are set to a variable with the same name in its scope.</p> <p>For another small quality of life improvement, it's common for new Rustaceans to try to use <code>+</code> to add two <code>&amp;str</code>s together. This doesn't work, you can only add <code>String + &amp;str</code>. As such, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/39116">a new error message</a> was added to help users who make this mistake:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#999999;">// code </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;foo&quot; </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;bar&quot; </span><span style="color:#999999;">// old </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">error[</span><span style="color:#666969;">E0369</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">]: binary operation `</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">` cannot be applied to </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">type</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> `</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">&#39;static str</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">` </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">-</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">-&gt; &lt;anon&gt;:</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">:</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">5 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">| </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">| </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;foo&quot; </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;bar&quot; </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">| ^^^^^ |</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> note: an implementation of `std::ops::Add` might be missing </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">for</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> `</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">&#39;static str</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">` </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">-</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">-&gt; &lt;anon&gt;:</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">:</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">5 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">| </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">| </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;foo&quot; </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;bar&quot; </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">| ^^^^^ </span><span style="color:#999999;">// new </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">error[</span><span style="color:#666969;">E0369</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">]: binary operation `</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">` cannot be applied to </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">type</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> `</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">&#39;static str</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">` </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">-</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">-&gt; &lt;anon&gt;:</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">:</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">5 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">| </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">| </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;foo&quot; </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;bar&quot; </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">| ^^^^^ | =</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> note: `</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">` can</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">&#39;t</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> be used to concatenate two `</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">str</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">` strings help: </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">to_owned</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() can be used to create an owned `</span><span style="color:#c99e00;">String</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">` from a string reference. </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">String</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> concatenation appends the string on the right to the string on the left and may require reallocation. This requires ownership of the string on the left. </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">| </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;foo&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">to_owned</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;bar&quot; </span></pre> <p>When using Cargo's build scripts, you must set the location of the script in your <code>Cargo.toml</code>. However, the vast majority of people wrote <code>build = &quot;build.rs&quot;</code>, using a <code>build.rs</code> file in the root of their project. <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/3664">This convention is now encoded into Cargo</a>, and will be assumed if <code>build.rs</code> exists. We've been warning about this change for the past few releases, and you can use <code>build = false</code> to opt out.</p> <p>This release marks <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/39431">the removal</a> of the old <code>Makefile</code> based build system. The new system, announced in Rust 1.15, is written in Rust and primarily uses Cargo to drive the build. It is now mature enough to be the only build system.</p> <p>As part of that change, packages from crates.io can now be used within Rust's build system. The first one to be added was <a href="https://crates.io/crates/mdbook">mdBook</a>, and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/39633">it's now being used</a> to render our various book-like documentation:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/">The book</a> (<a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/book">repo</a>)</li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/reference/">The reference</a> (<a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/reference">repo</a>)</li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/nomicon/">The nomicon</a> (<a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/nomicon">repo</a>)</li> </ul> <p>In addition, see those links to their respective repositories; they've been moved out of tree. Also, we've added a fourth book, still in-tree: <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/unstable-book/">The Unstable Book</a>. This provides an overview of unstable features by name, contains links to their tracking issues, and may contain initial documentation. If there's a feature you want to see stabilized, please get involved on its tracking issue!</p> <p>A few releases ago, <code>rustup</code> stopped installing documentation by default. We made this change to save some bandwidth and because not all users want a copy of the documentation locally. However, this created a pitfall: some users did not realize that this changed, and would only notice once they were no longer connected to the internet. In addition, some users <em>did</em> want to have a local copy of the docs, regardless of their connectivity. As such, we've <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/40526">reverted the change</a>, and documentation is being installed by default again.</p> <p>Finally, while this release is full of improvements, there is one small step back we want to regretfully inform you about. On Windows, Visual Studio 2017 has been released, and Microsoft has changed the structure of how the software is installed. <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/38584">Rust cannot automatically detect this location</a>, and while we were working on the neccesary changes, they did not make it in time for this release. Until then, Visual Studio 2015 still works fine, or you can run <code>vcvars.bat</code> on the command line. We hope to make this work in a seamless fashion soon.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1170-2017-04-27">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h4 id="library-stabilizations">Library stabilizations</h4> <p>19 new bits of API were stabilized this release:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/sync/struct.Arc.html#method.into_raw"><code>Arc::into_raw</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/rc/struct.Rc.html#method.into_raw"><code>Rc::into_raw</code></a> let you consume an <code>Arc</code> or <code>Rc</code> and get a raw pointer.</li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/sync/struct.Arc.html#method.from_raw"><code>Arc::from_raw</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/rc/struct.Rc.html#method.from_raw"><code>Rc::from_raw</code></a> let you take that raw pointer and get an <code>Arc</code> or <code>Rc</code>.</li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/sync/struct.Arc.html#method.ptr_eq"><code>Arc::ptr_eq</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/rc/struct.Rc.html#method.ptr_eq"><code>Rc::ptr_eq</code></a> return true if the two <code>Arc</code>s or two <code>Rc</code>s point to the same value (not just values that compare as equal).</li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/cmp/enum.Ordering.html#method.then"><code>Ordering::then</code></a> lets you chain two <code>Ordering</code>s together, and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/cmp/enum.Ordering.html#method.then_with"><code>Ordering::then_with</code></a> lets you do it with a function.</li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/collections/btree_map/struct.BTreeMap.html#method.range"><code>BTreeMap::range</code></a> allows you to iterate over a portion of a <code>BTreeMap</code>, and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/collections/btree_map/struct.BTreeMap.html#method.range_mut"><code>BTreeMap::range_mut</code></a> lets you do it mutably. <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/collections/enum.Bound.html"><code>collections::Bound</code></a> can give you even more control.</li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/process/fn.abort.html"><code>process::abort</code></a> will completely terminate a process in an abnormal fashion.</li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/ptr/fn.read_unaligned.html"><code>ptr::read_unaligned</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/ptr/fn.write_unaligned.html"><code>ptr::write_unaligned</code></a> are like <code>ptr::read</code> and <code>ptr::write</code>, but without alignment requirements.</li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/result/enum.Result.html#method.expect_err"><code>Result::expect_err</code></a> mirrors <code>Result::expect</code>, but with the <code>Err</code> case rather than the <code>Ok</code> case.</li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/cell/struct.Cell.html#method.swap"><code>Cell::swap</code></a> is similar to <code>std::mem::swap</code>, but lets you do it with <code>&amp;Cell</code> instead of <code>&amp;mut T</code>.</li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/cell/struct.Cell.html#method.replace"><code>Cell::replace</code></a> is similar to <code>std::mem::replace</code>, but lets you do it with <code>&amp;Cell</code> instead of <code>&amp;mut T</code>.</li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/cell/struct.Cell.html#method.into_inner"><code>Cell::into_inner</code></a> lets you consume the <code>Cell</code>, and extract its value.</li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/cell/struct.Cell.html#method.take"><code>Cell::take</code></a> lets you take the value out of a <code>Cell</code>, leaving its <code>Default::default</code> behind.</li> </ul> <p>In other changes, <code>Cell&lt;T&gt;</code> used to require that <code>T: Copy</code> for many of its methods, but <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/39793">this has been relaxed significantly</a>.</p> <p><code>Box&lt;T&gt;</code> <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/40009">now implements</a> over a dozen new conversions with <code>From</code>.</p> <p><code>SocketAddr</code> and <code>IpAddr</code> have <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/39372">some new conversions</a> as well. Previously, you may have written code like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;127.0.0.1:3000&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">parse</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">().</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">unwrap</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() </span></pre> <p>Now, you can write</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">SocketAddr::from(([</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">127</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">], </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">3000</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">)) </span><span style="color:#999999;">// or even </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">([</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">127</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">], </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">3000</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">).</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">into</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() </span></pre> <p>This removes some unnecessary run-time parsing, and is roughly as readable, depending on your preferences.</p> <p>Backtraces <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/38165">now have nicer formatting</a>, eliding some things by default. For example, the full backtrace:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">thread &#39;main&#39; panicked at &#39;explicit panic&#39;, foo.rs:2 stack backtrace: 1: 0x55c39a23372c - std::sys::imp::backtrace::tracing::imp::write::hf33ae72d0baa11ed at /buildslave/rust-buildbot/slave/stable-dist-rustc-linux/build/src/libstd/sys/unix/backtrace/tracing/gcc_s.rs:42 2: 0x55c39a23571e - std::panicking::default_hook::{{closure}}::h59672b733cc6a455 at /buildslave/rust-buildbot/slave/stable-dist-rustc-linux/build/src/libstd/panicking.rs:351 3: 0x55c39a235324 - std::panicking::default_hook::h1670459d2f3f8843 at /buildslave/rust-buildbot/slave/stable-dist-rustc-linux/build/src/libstd/panicking.rs:367 4: 0x55c39a235afb - std::panicking::rust_panic_with_hook::hcf0ddb069e7beee7 at /buildslave/rust-buildbot/slave/stable-dist-rustc-linux/build/src/libstd/panicking.rs:555 5: 0x55c39a22e866 - std::panicking::begin_panic::heb433e9aa28a7408 6: 0x55c39a22e9bf - foo::main::hd216d4a160fcce19 7: 0x55c39a23d44a - __rust_maybe_catch_panic at /buildslave/rust-buildbot/slave/stable-dist-rustc-linux/build/src/libpanic_unwind/lib.rs:98 8: 0x55c39a236006 - std::rt::lang_start::hd7c880a37a646e81 at /buildslave/rust-buildbot/slave/stable-dist-rustc-linux/build/src/libstd/panicking.rs:436 at /buildslave/rust-buildbot/slave/stable-dist-rustc-linux/build/src/libstd/panic.rs:361 at /buildslave/rust-buildbot/slave/stable-dist-rustc-linux/build/src/libstd/rt.rs:57 9: 0x55c39a22e9e9 - main 10: 0x7f5e5ed3382f - __libc_start_main 11: 0x55c39a22e6b8 - _start 12: 0x0 - &lt;unknown&gt; </span></pre> <p>is now instead</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">thread &#39;main&#39; panicked at &#39;explicit panic&#39;, foo.rs:2 stack backtrace: 0: std::sys::imp::backtrace::tracing::imp::unwind_backtrace at /checkout/src/libstd/sys/unix/backtrace/tracing/gcc_s.rs:49 1: std::sys_common::backtrace::_print at /checkout/src/libstd/sys_common/backtrace.rs:71 2: std::panicking::default_hook::{{closure}} at /checkout/src/libstd/sys_common/backtrace.rs:60 at /checkout/src/libstd/panicking.rs:355 3: std::panicking::default_hook at /checkout/src/libstd/panicking.rs:371 4: std::panicking::rust_panic_with_hook at /checkout/src/libstd/panicking.rs:549 5: std::panicking::begin_panic 6: foo::main 7: __rust_maybe_catch_panic at /checkout/src/libpanic_unwind/lib.rs:98 8: std::rt::lang_start at /checkout/src/libstd/panicking.rs:433 at /checkout/src/libstd/panic.rs:361 at /checkout/src/libstd/rt.rs:57 9: main 10: __libc_start_main 11: _start </span></pre> <p>By default. You can set the environment variable <code>RUST_BACKTRACE=full</code> to get the full backtrace. We may be able to do more cleanup in the future; see <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/40264">this bug</a> for more.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1170-2017-04-27">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h4 id="cargo-features">Cargo features</h4> <p>Other than the previously mentioned <code>build.rs</code> changes, Cargo has a few new improvements. <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/3731"><code>cargo check --all</code></a> and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/3691"><code>cargo run --package</code></a> are two missing flags that are now supported.</p> <p>You can now <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/3699">opt in to ignoring SSL revocation checks</a>. The default is still to check, of course.</p> <p>A new field in <code>Cargo.toml</code>, <code>required-features</code>, lets you <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/3667">specify specific features that must be set for a target to be built</a>. Here's an example: let's say that we are writing a crate that interacts with databases, and that we support multiple databases. We might have this in our <code>Cargo.toml</code>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">features</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#999999;"># ... </span><span style="color:#c82829;">postgres </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= [] </span><span style="color:#c82829;">sqlite </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= [] </span><span style="color:#c82829;">tools </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= [] </span></pre> <p>The <code>tools</code> feature allows us to include extra tooling, and the <code>postgres</code> and <code>sqlite</code> features control which databses we want to support.</p> <p>Previously, <code>cargo build</code> would attempt to build all targets, which is normally what you want. But what if we had a <code>src/bin/postgres-tool.rs</code>, that would only really be relevant if the <code>postgres</code> and <code>tools</code> features would be enabled? Previously, we would have to write something like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">#[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">cfg</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#c82829;">not</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">(</span><span style="color:#c82829;">all</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">(feature </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;postgres&quot;</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">, feature </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;tools&quot;</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">))</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">)] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;This tool requires the `postgres` and `tools` features to be enabled.&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); } #[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">cfg</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#c82829;">all</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">(feature </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;postgres&quot;</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">, feature </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;tools&quot;</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">)</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">)] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#999999;">// real code </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p>This is a lot of boilerplate to work around <code>cargo build</code>'s behavior. It's even more unfortunate with <code>examples/</code>, which are supposed to show off how to use your library, but this shenanigans is only relevant within the package, not if you were to try to use the example on your own.</p> <p>With the new <code>required-features</code> key, we can add this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">bin</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">]] </span><span style="color:#999999;"># ... </span><span style="color:#c82829;">required-features </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= [</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;postgres&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;tools&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span></pre> <p>Now, <code>cargo build</code> will only build our <code>postgres-tool</code> if we have the two features set, and so we can write a normal <code>fn main</code> without all the <code>cfg</code> nonsense getting in the way.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1170-2017-04-27">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h3 id="contributors-to-1-17-0">Contributors to 1.17.0</h3> <p>Many people came together to create Rust 1.17. We couldn't have done it without all of you. <a href="https://thanks.rust-lang.org/rust/1.17.0">Thanks!</a></p> Announcing Rust 1.16 Thu, 16 Mar 2017 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-16/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-16/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce the latest version of Rust, 1.16.0. Rust is a systems programming language focused on safety, speed, and concurrency.</p> <p>If you have a previous version of Rust installed, getting Rust 1.16 is as easy as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">rustup</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> update stable </span></pre> <p>If you don't have it already, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">get <code>rustup</code></a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1160-2017-03-16">detailed release notes for 1.16.0</a> on GitHub.</p> <h3 id="what-s-in-1-16-0-stable">What's in 1.16.0 stable</h3> <p>The largest addition to Rust 1.16 is <code>cargo check</code>. This new subcommand should speed up the development workflow in many cases.</p> <p>What does it do? Let's take a step back and talk about how <code>rustc</code> compiles your code. Compilation has many &quot;passes&quot;, that is, there are many distinct steps that the compiler takes on the road from your source code to producing the final binary. You can see each of these steps (and how much time and memory they take) by passing <code>-Z time-passes</code> to a nightly compiler:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">rustc +nightly hello.rs -Z time-passes time: 0.003; rss: 16MB parsing time: 0.000; rss: 16MB recursion limit time: 0.000; rss: 16MB crate injection time: 0.000; rss: 16MB plugin loading time: 0.000; rss: 16MB plugin registration time: 0.049; rss: 34MB expansion &lt;snip&gt; </span></pre> <p>There's a lot of them. However, you can think of this process in two big steps: first, <code>rustc</code> does all of its safety checks, makes sure your syntax is correct, all that stuff. Second, once it's satisfied that everything is in order, it produces the actual binary code that you end up executing.</p> <p>It turns out that that second step takes a lot of time. And most of the time, it's not neccesary. That is, when you're working on some Rust code, many developers will get into a workflow like this:</p> <ol> <li>Write some code.</li> <li>Run <code>cargo build</code> to make sure it compiles.</li> <li>Repeat 1-2 as needed.</li> <li>Run <code>cargo test</code> to make sure your tests pass.</li> <li>GOTO 1.</li> </ol> <p>In step two, you never actually run your code. You're looking for feedback from the compiler, not to actually run the binary. <code>cargo check</code> supports exactly this use-case: it runs all of the compiler's checks, but doesn't produce the final binary.</p> <p>So how much speedup do you actually get? Like most performance related questions, the answer is &quot;it depends.&quot; Here are some very un-scientific benchmarks:</p> <table><thead><tr><th></th><th align="right">thanks</th><th align="right">cargo</th><th align="right">diesel</th></tr></thead><tbody> <tr><td>initial build</td><td align="right">134.75s</td><td align="right">236.78s</td><td align="right">15.27s</td></tr> <tr><td>initial check</td><td align="right">50.88s</td><td align="right">148.52s</td><td align="right">12.81s</td></tr> <tr><td>speedup</td><td align="right">2.648</td><td align="right">1.594</td><td align="right">1.192</td></tr> <tr><td>secondary build</td><td align="right">15.97s</td><td align="right">64.34s</td><td align="right">13.54s</td></tr> <tr><td>secondary check</td><td align="right">2.9s</td><td align="right">9.29s</td><td align="right">12.3s</td></tr> <tr><td>speedup</td><td align="right">5.506</td><td align="right">6.925</td><td align="right">1.100</td></tr> </tbody></table> <p>The 'initial' categories are the first build after cloning down a project. The 'secondary' categories involved adding one blank line to the top of <code>src\lib.rs</code> and running the command again. That's why the initial ones are more dramatic; they involve also doing this for all dependencies, as well as the crate itself. As you can see, larger projects with many dependencies see a big improvement, but smaller ones see much more modest gains.</p> <p>We are still working on improving compile-times generally as well, though we don't have anything in particular to highlight at this time.</p> <h4 id="other-improvements">Other improvements</h4> <p>To support <code>cargo check</code>, <code>rustc</code> has <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/38571">learned to emit</a> a new kind of file: <code>.rmeta</code>. This file will contain only the metadata about a particular crate. <code>cargo check</code> needs this for your dependencies, to let the compiler check types and such from them. It's also useful for the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rls">Rust Language Server</a>, and possibly more tools in the future.</p> <p>Another large change is the removal of a long-standing diagnostic: <code>consider using an explicit lifetime parameter</code>. This diagnostic would kick in whenever you had an incorrect lifetime annotation, and the compiler thought that you might have meant something else. Consider this code:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">use </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">std::str::FromStr; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">pub struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Name&lt;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">&#39;a</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&gt; { </span><span style="color:#c82829;">name</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">&#39;a str</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">impl</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&lt;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">&#39;a</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&gt; FromStr </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">for </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Name&lt;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">&#39;a</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&gt; { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">type </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Err </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(); </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">from_str</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">s</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">str</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) -&gt; Result&lt;Name, ()&gt; { </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Ok</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(Name { name: s }) } } </span></pre> <p>Here, Rust isn't sure what to do with the lifetimes; as written, the code doesn't guarantee that <code>s</code> will live as long as <code>Name</code>, which is required for <code>Name</code> to be valid. Let's try to compile this code with Rust 1.15.1:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">rustc</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> +1.15.1 foo.rs</span><span style="color:#f5871f;"> --crate-type</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">lib </span><span style="color:#c82829;">error[E0495]:</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> cannot infer an appropriate lifetime for lifetime parameter in generic type due to conflicting requirements </span><span style="color:#c82829;">--</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&gt;</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> .</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">\f</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">oo.rs:10:5 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">| </span><span style="color:#c82829;">10 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">| </span><span style="color:#c82829;">fn</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> from_str(s: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">str</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) </span><span style="color:#c82829;">-</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&gt;</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> Result</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&lt;</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">Name, (</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">)</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ | _____^ starting here... 11 | | Ok(Name { name: s }) 12 | | } </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">| |</span><span style="color:#c82829;">_____^</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> ...ending here </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">| </span><span style="color:#c82829;">help:</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> consider using an explicit lifetime parameter as shown: fn from_str(s: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&#39;a str) -&gt; Result&lt;Name, ()&gt; --&gt; .\foo.rs:10:5 | 10 | fn from_str(s: &amp;str) -&gt; Result&lt;Name, ()&gt; { | _____^ starting here... 11 | | Ok(Name { name: s }) 12 | | } | |_____^ ...ending here </span></pre> <p>The compiler explains the issue, and gives a helpful suggestion. So let's try it: modify the code to add in the <code>'a</code>, and compile again:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">rustc</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> +1.15.1 .</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">\f</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">oo.rs</span><span style="color:#f5871f;"> --crate-type</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">lib </span><span style="color:#c82829;">error[E0308]:</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> method not compatible with trait </span><span style="color:#c82829;">--</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&gt;</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> .</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">\f</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">oo.rs:10:5 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">| </span><span style="color:#c82829;">10 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">| </span><span style="color:#c82829;">fn</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> from_str(s: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&#39;a str) -&gt; Result&lt;Name, ()&gt; { | _____^ starting here... 11 | | Ok(Name { name: s }) 12 | | } | |_____^ ...ending here: lifetime mismatch | &lt;snip&gt; help: consider using an explicit lifetime parameter as shown: fn from_str(s: &amp;&#39;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">a</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> str</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) </span><span style="color:#c82829;">-</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&gt;</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> Result</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&lt;</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">Name</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&lt;</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&#39;a&gt;, ()&gt; --&gt; .\foo.rs:10:5 | 10 | fn from_str(s: &amp;&#39;</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">a str</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) </span><span style="color:#c82829;">-</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&gt;</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> Result</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&lt;</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">Name, (</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">)</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ | _____^ starting here... 11 | | Ok(Name { name: s }) 12 | | } </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">| |</span><span style="color:#c82829;">_____^</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> ...ending here </span></pre> <p>It still doesn't work. That help message was not actually helpful. It does suggest adding another lifetime, this time on <code>Name</code>. If we do that...</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">rustc</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> +1.15.1 .</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">\f</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">oo.rs</span><span style="color:#f5871f;"> --crate-type</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">lib </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&lt;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">snip</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&gt;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> help: </span><span style="color:#c82829;">consider</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> using an explicit lifetime parameter as shown: fn from_str(s: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&#39;a str) -&gt; Result&lt;Name&lt;&#39;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">a</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&gt;</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">, (</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">)</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">-</span><span style="color:#c82829;">-</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&gt;</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> .</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">\f</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">oo.rs:10:5 </span></pre> <p>... that's what we already have, compiler!</p> <p>This diagnostic was well-intentioned, but when it's wrong, it was <em>very</em> wrong, as you can see here. Sometimes it wouldn't even suggest valid Rust syntax! Furthermore, more advanced Rust users didn't really need the suggestion, but new Rustaceans would take them to heart, and then be led down this bad path. As such, we decided that for now, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/37057">we should remove the help message entirely</a>. We may bring it back in the future, but only if we can limit false positives.</p> <blockquote> <p>An aside: the above implementation is not possible; <code>Name</code> would need to use <code>String</code>, not <code>&amp;str</code>.</p> </blockquote> <p>In other diagnostic changes, previous versions of Rust would helpfully attempt to suggest fixes for typos:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> foo </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">5</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, ffo); </span></pre> <p>Would give this error:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">error[E0425]: cannot find value `ffo` in this scope --&gt; foo.rs:4:20 | 4 | println!(&quot;{}&quot;, ffo); | ^^^ did you mean `foo`? </span></pre> <p>However, this would only happen in certain circumstances: sometimes in local variables, and for fields in structs. <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/38927">This now happens nearly everywhere</a>. When combined with <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/38154">some other related improvements</a>, this results in a significant improvement in these sorts of diagnostics.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1160-2017-03-16">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h4 id="library-stabilizations">Library stabilizations</h4> <p>21 new bits of API were stabilized this release:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/collections/vec_deque/struct.VecDeque.html#method.truncate"><code>VecDeque::truncate</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/collections/vec_deque/struct.VecDeque.html#method.resize"><code>VecDeque::resize</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/string/struct.String.html#method.insert_str"><code>String::insert_str</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/time/struct.Duration.html#method.checked_add"><code>Duration::checked_add</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/time/struct.Duration.html#method.checked_sub"><code>Duration::checked_sub</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/time/struct.Duration.html#method.checked_div"><code>Duration::checked_div</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/time/struct.Duration.html#method.checked_mul"><code>Duration::checked_mul</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.str.html#method.replacen"><code>str::replacen</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.str.html#method.repeat"><code>str::repeat</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/net/enum.SocketAddr.html#method.is_ipv4"><code>SocketAddr::is_ipv4</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/net/enum.SocketAddr.html#method.is_ipv6"><code>SocketAddr::is_ipv6</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/net/enum.IpAddr.html#method.is_ipv4"><code>IpAddr::is_ipv4</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/net/enum.IpAddr.html#method.is_ipv6"><code>IpAddr::is_ipv6</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/vec/struct.Vec.html#method.dedup_by"><code>Vec::dedup_by</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/vec/struct.Vec.html#method.dedup_by_key"><code>Vec::dedup_by_key</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/result/enum.Result.html#method.unwrap_or_default"><code>Result::unwrap_or_default</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.pointer.html#method.wrapping_offset"><code>&lt;*const T&gt;::wrapping_offset</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.pointer.html#method.wrapping_offset"><code>&lt;*mut T&gt;::wrapping_offset</code></a></li> <li><code>CommandExt::creation_flags</code></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/fs/struct.File.html#method.set_permissions"><code>File::set_permissions</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/string/struct.String.html#method.split_off"><code>String::split_off</code></a></li> </ul> <p>In addition, a number of small improvements to existing functions landed. For example <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/38469"><code>writeln!</code> now has a single-argument form</a>, just like <code>println!</code> has. This ends up writing only a newline, but is a nice bit of symmetry.</p> <p>All structs in the standard library <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/38006">now implement <code>Debug</code></a>.</p> <p>When slicing a <code>&amp;str</code>, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/38066">you'll see better errors</a>. For example, this code:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;abcαβγ&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">..</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">4</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span></pre> <p>Is incorrect. It generates this error:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">thread &#39;str::test_slice_fail_boundary_1&#39; panicked at &#39;byte index 4 is not a char boundary; it is inside &#39;α&#39; (bytes 3..5) of `abcαβγ`&#39; </span></pre> <p>The part after the <code>;</code> is new.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1160-2017-03-16">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h4 id="cargo-features">Cargo features</h4> <p>In addition to <code>cargo check</code>, Cargo and crates.io have some new polish added. For example, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/3511"><code>cargo build</code></a> and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/3515"><code>cargo doc</code></a> now take a <code>--all</code> flag for building and documenting every crate in your workspace with one command.</p> <p>Cargo now has a <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/3604"><code>--version --verbose</code> flag</a>, mirroring <code>rustc</code>.</p> <p>Crates.io now <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/3546">can show off your TravisCI or AppVeyor badges</a> on your crate's page.</p> <p>In addition, both Cargo and crates.io <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/3301">understand categories</a>. Unlike keywords, which are free-form, categories are curated. In addition, keywords are used for searching, but categories are not. In other words, categories are intended to assist browsing, and keywords are intended to assist searching.</p> <p>You can browse crates by category <a href="https://crates.io/categories">here</a>.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1160-2017-03-16">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h3 id="contributors-to-1-16-0">Contributors to 1.16.0</h3> <p>Last release, we introduced <a href="https://thanks.rust-lang.org">thanks.rust-lang.org</a>. We have been doing some behind-the-scenes refactoring work to allow for more projects than only Rust itself; we're hoping to introduce that in the next release.</p> <p>We had 135 individuals contribute to Rust 1.16. <a href="https://thanks.rust-lang.org/rust/1.16.0">Thanks!</a></p> Rust's language ergonomics initiative Thu, 02 Mar 2017 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/lang-ergonomics/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/lang-ergonomics/ <p>To help bring our <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/02/06/roadmap.html">2017 vision for Rust</a> to fruition, the Rust subteams are launching initiatives targeted at specific roadmap goals. <strong>This post covers the language team's major initiative: improving the ergonomics of the core language.</strong> The aim is to improve productivity and bring down the learning curve by streamlining features and glossing over irrelevant details.</p> <h2 id="ergonomics">Ergonomics</h2> <p><strong>Ergonomics is a measure of the friction you experience when trying to get things done with a tool</strong>. You want to achieve a state of &quot;flow&quot;, in which ideas and intuitions are steadily transformed into working code with a minimum of fuss. (And, with Rust, we want that code to be reliable and fast as well.) The great threat to this experience is <strong>interruptions</strong>, which come in many forms: looking things up, switching contexts, going through a large amount of ceremony, or dealing with reams of errors where the compiler pedantically points out tiny things you forgot. Anything that takes your attention away from the problem at hand and puts it on details that don't really matter (or don't matter <em>just yet</em>).</p> <p>A corollary is that ergonomics is rarely about raw character count. When you have good momentum, the difference between typing <code>pos</code> and <code>position</code> isn't so significant; <strong>what matters much more is how easy it is to remember the right one to type</strong>. Similarly, <em>typing</em> <code>ref</code> in a <code>match</code> pattern, or <code>*</code> to dereference an <code>&amp;i32</code>, is easy; knowing or remembering to type them, on the other hand...</p> <p>The same things you have to remember as an expert are things you have to learn as a newbie. Ergonomic improvements make life better for everyone.</p> <p>Often, the heart of the matter is the question of <strong>what to make implicit</strong>. In the rest of this post, I'll present a basic framework for thinking about this question, and then apply that framework to three areas of Rust, analyzing both the current design and some streamlining we may want to consider this year.</p> <h3 id="implicit-vs-explicit">Implicit vs explicit</h3> <p><strong>Information is implicit when it is <em>implied</em> but not <em>expressed</em>.</strong> The potential ergonomic wins are pretty easy to see: forcing you to write down information that's obvious (because it's already implied) is a pain, because it adds distracting noise and is easy to forget. Allowing you to leave it implicit reduces that friction. Yet implicitness gets a bad rap, with Python going so far as to state &quot;explicit is better than implicit&quot; as a core design rule. Why?</p> <p>Implicitness can be very powerful. After all, the compiler knows a <em>lot</em> about your code, and it's possible to leverage that to inject behavior in all kinds of subtle ways. If taken too far, these techniques can impair readability, or worse: introduce surprising behavior that can be tricky to track down, because it's the result of a subtle chain of inference. If you've had first-hand experience with these pitfalls, it's easy to come away with the sense that implicitness itself is to blame.</p> <p>But this, in my opinion, is a misdiagnosis of the problem, one that throws out the baby with the bathwater. The root issue is instead: <strong>how much information do you need to confidently understand what a particular line of code is doing, and how hard is that information to find?</strong> Let's call this the <em>reasoning footprint</em> for a piece of code. The pitfalls above come from the reasoning footprint getting out of hand, rather than implicitness per se.</p> <p>Does readability then demand that we <em>minimize</em> the reasoning footprint? I don't think so: make it too small, and code becomes hopelessly verbose, making it difficult to read by forcing too much information into view at all times. What we want is a sweet spot, where routine or easy to find details can be left out, but relevant or surprising information is kept front and center.</p> <h3 id="how-to-analyze-and-manage-the-reasoning-footprint">How to analyze and manage the reasoning footprint</h3> <p>There are three dimensions of the reasoning footprint for implicitness:</p> <ul> <li> <p><strong>Applicability</strong>. Where are you allowed to elide implied information? Is there any heads-up that this might be happening?</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Power</strong>. What influence does the elided information have? Can it radically change program behavior or its types?</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Context-dependence</strong>. How much of do you have to know about the rest of the code to know what is being implied, i.e. how elided details will be filled in? Is there always a clear place to look?</p> </li> </ul> <p><strong>The basic thesis of this post is that implicit features should balance these three dimensions</strong>. If a feature is large in one of the dimensions, it's best to strongly limit it in the other two.</p> <p>The <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2016/11/10/Rust-1.13.html"><code>?</code> operator</a> in Rust is a good example of this kind of tradeoff. It explicitly (but concisely) marks a point where you will bail out of the current context on an error, possibly doing an implicit conversion on the way. The fact that it's marked means the feature has strongly limited applicability: you'll never be surprised that it's coming into play. On the other hand, it's fairly powerful, and somewhat context-dependent, since the conversion can depend on the type where <code>?</code> is used, and the type expected in the scope it's jumping to. Altogether, this careful balance makes error handling in Rust feels as ergonomic as working with exceptions while avoiding some of their well-known downsides.</p> <p>By contrast, a feature like unrestricted implicit conversion rightfully has a bad reputation, because it's universally applicable, quite powerful, <em>and</em> context-dependent. If we were to expand implicit conversions in Rust, we would likely limit their power (by, say, restricting them to <code>AsRef</code>-style coercions, which can do very little).</p> <p>One route for strongly limiting context-dependence is employing <em>conventions</em>, in which the compiler is simply assuming a default unless told otherwise. Often such conventions are universal and well-known, meaning that you don't need to know anything about the rest of the code to know what they are. A good example of this technique in Rust is the fact that <code>mod foo;</code> looks for <code>foo.rs</code> (or <code>foo/mod.rs</code>) by default.</p> <p>One final point. &quot;Implicitness&quot; is often relative to where the language is today, something that seems radical at first—like type inference!—but then quickly disappears into the background, to the point that it no longer feels implicit at all (see <a href="https://thefeedbackloop.xyz/stroustrups-rule-and-layering-over-time/">Stroustrup's rule</a>). But sometimes a bit of implicitness really is a bad idea. The key is to carefully consider the impact on the reasoning footprint.</p> <h2 id="example-type-annotations">Example: type annotations</h2> <p>One bit of ergonomics that is increasingly taken for granted is <em>type inference</em>. In the days of yore, you'd have to annotate every local variable with its type, a practice that seems wildly verbose now—but at the time, type inference seemed wildly implicit.</p> <p>Type inference in Rust is quite powerful, but we limit the other two dimensions:</p> <ul> <li> <p>Applicability: type inference happens only for variable bindings; data types and functions must include complete, explicit signatures.</p> </li> <li> <p>Context-dependence: because data types and functions are annotated, it's easy to determine the information that's influencing the outcome of inference. You only need to look <em>shallowly</em> at code outside of the current function. Another way of saying this is that type inference is performed modularly, one function body at a time.</p> </li> </ul> <p>By and large, the amount of type inference we do in Rust seems to be a good match for what you can hold in your head.</p> <p>The type system also provides a good example of using conventions for ergonomics: <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/141">lifetime elision</a>. That feature allows you to leave off lifetimes from function signatures in the vast majority of cases (check out the RFC—we measured!). <strong>Lifetime elision greatly aids learnability, because it allows you to work at an intuitive level with borrowing before you grapple with explicit lifetimes.</strong></p> <ul> <li> <p>Applicability: lifetime elision applies to a broad class of locations—any function signature—but is limited to those cases for which the lifetimes are <em>strongly</em> implied.</p> </li> <li> <p>Power: limited; elision is just a shorthand for a use of lifetime parameters, and if you get this wrong, the compiler will complain.</p> </li> <li> <p>Context-dependence: here, we overshot. The fact that elision applies to types other than <code>&amp;</code> and <code>&amp;mut</code>, means that to even know whether reborrrowing is happening in a signature like <code>fn lookup(&amp;self) -&gt; Ref&lt;T&gt;</code>, you need to know whether <code>Ref</code> has a lifetime parameter that's being left out. For something as common as function signatures, this is too much context. We've been considering pushing in the direction of a small but explicit marker to say that a lifetime is being elided for <code>Ref</code>, a strategy similar to the one for <code>?</code> mentioned earlier.</p> </li> </ul> <p>There's also been some extensions to the original elision proposal, again carefully crafted to follow these rules, like the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1623">lifetimes in statics</a> RFC.</p> <h3 id="idea-implied-bounds">Idea: implied bounds</h3> <p>One papercut with Rust today is the fact that, for certain data structures, you end up having to repeat the same set of trait bounds over and over. <code>HashMap</code> is a good example; it takes a key type which, in practice, must satisfy the <code>Hash</code> and <code>Eq</code> traits.
