So the question is, how should we understand a signature like the following?</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">use_map</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&lt;K, V&gt;(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">map</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: HashMap&lt;K, V&gt;) { </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">... </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p>Right now, such a signature would be accepted, but if you tried to use any of <code>map</code>'s methods, you'd get an error that <code>K</code> needs to be <code>Hash</code> and <code>Eq</code>, and have to go back and add those bounds. That's an example of the compiler being pedantic in a way that can interrupt your flow, and doesn't <em>really</em> add anything; the fact that we're using <code>K</code> as a hashmap key essentially forces some additional assumptions about the type. But the compiler is making us spell out those assumptions explicitly in the signature. This situation seems ripe for an ergonomic improvement.</p> <p>It's <a href="http://smallcultfollowing.com/babysteps/blog/2014/07/06/implied-bounds/">straightforward</a> to assume bounds that are &quot;implied&quot; by the type, like assuming that <code>K</code> must be <code>Hash</code> and <code>Eq</code> above, by tying it to the type definition:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">HashMap&lt;K: Hash </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> Eq, V&gt; { ... } </span></pre> <p>What's the impact on the reasoning footprint? It means that to completely understand a signature like</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">use_map</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&lt;K, V&gt;(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">map</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: HashMap&lt;K, V&gt;) { </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">... </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p>you need to be aware of the bounds on any type constructor like <code>HashMap</code> that you're applying to a type variable like <code>K</code>. So in particular, if you're trying to invoke <code>use_map</code>, you need to know that there are some unstated constraints on <code>K</code>.</p> <ul> <li> <p>Applicability: very broad; applies to any use of generics.</p> </li> <li> <p>Power: very limited; the bounds will almost always be needed anyway, and in any case adding bounds is not very risky.</p> </li> <li> <p>Context-dependence: fairly limited; it draws from the bounds on all type constructors that are applied to type variables (like <code>HashMap&lt;K, V&gt;</code>). Usually you will be well aware of these bounds anyway, and when <em>using</em> a function like <code>use_map</code>, you're generally going to be passing in an existing <code>HashMap</code>, which by construction will ensure that the bounds already hold. The compiler can reliably also produce an error pointing directly to the type(s) imposing unfulfilled bounds.</p> </li> </ul> <h2 id="example-ownership">Example: ownership</h2> <p>A lot of work went into making Rust's ownership system ergonomic, and that work entailed judicious use of &quot;implicit&quot; features. It's particularly instructive to look at the places where borrowing is explicit, and places where it's not:</p> <ul> <li>Borrowing is implicit for the receiver when invoking a method.</li> <li>Borrowing is explicit for normal function arguments and in other expressions.</li> </ul> <p>Ownership is important in Rust, and reasoning locally about it is vital. So why did we end up with this particular mix of implicit and explicit ownership tracking?</p> <ul> <li> <p>Applicability: common, but narrowly-described: it applies only to the receiver of method calls.</p> </li> <li> <p>Power: moderately powerful, since it can determine whether the receiver can be mutated (by mutably borrowing it). That's mitigated to some degree by borrow checking, which will at least ensure that it's <em>permitted</em> to do such a borrow.</p> </li> <li> <p>Context-dependence: in principle, you need to know how the method is resolved, and then its signature. In practice, the style of <code>self</code> borrowing is almost always implied by the method name (e.g. <code>push()</code> versus <code>len()</code>). Notably, this point does <em>not</em> apply to function arguments.</p> </li> </ul> <p><strong>This design also aids learnability, by often just doing &quot;the obvious thing&quot; for borrowing, and thereby limiting the situations in which newcomers have to grapple with choices about it</strong>.</p> <h3 id="ideas-implied-borrows">Ideas: implied borrows</h3> <p>Nevertheless, there are some pain points around borrowing in Rust today. To wit:</p> <p><strong>Discarding ownership</strong>. Sometimes you have ownership of a value, like a <code>String</code>, and want to pass it to a function that only needs a borrow (say, <code>&amp;str</code>), after which you no longer need the value. Today, you <em>must</em> borrow the value in the argument:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">read_config</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">path</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Path) -&gt; Config { </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">... </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> path </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">PathBuf::new(src_dir); path.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">push</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;Config.toml&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// we have to borrow `path` with `&amp;` even though we&#39;re done with it </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> config </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">read_config</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">path); </span></pre> <p>But we could easily allow you to write <code>read_config(path)</code>, implicitly borrowing <code>path</code> for <code>read_config</code> and then <em>dropping it</em> immediately afterwards. That would retain one's ability to reason locally about ownership, since ownership of <code>path</code> is indeed fully relinquished from the caller's perspective (and the buffer is destroyed at the end of the call to <code>read_config</code>). But it allows you to gloss over the unimportant detail that the callee happened to only need a borrow. And again, if you just forgot to borrow, and try to use <code>path</code> afterward, the compiler will catch it, just as it does today. This is an example of a not terribly powerful bit of inference (it's only introducing a shared borrow for an object about to be dropped) that we'd allow to occur virtually everywhere.</p> <p><strong>Borrowing in match patterns</strong>. One stumbling block when learning Rust is the interaction between pattern matching and borrowing. In particular, when you're pattern matching against borrowed data, you often have to do a little reborrowing dance:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">match </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">*</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">foo { </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Some</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">ref</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> contents) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">... </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">None </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">... </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} } </span></pre> <p>Here we're using <code>*</code> to dereference an <code>Option</code>, and then <code>ref</code> to <em>re</em>reference its contents. Beginners and experienced Rustaceans alike tend to miss one or both of these markers, in part because it's usually <em>the only thing you could be doing</em>. Thus, we could consider inferring these markers from context:</p> <ul> <li> <p>Infer the need for dereferencing based on the type of the expression being matched and the arms of the match. That's a very limited amount of context that will already be front and center in the programmer's head.</p> </li> <li> <p>Infer the need for <code>ref</code> (or <code>ref mut</code>) based on the borrowing usage in the match arm, much like we do for closures already. That expands the reasoning footprint a bit, since you can't tell at a glance from the pattern what kind of borrow is being taken. But examining code blocks to determine the borrows <em>they</em> take is something Rust programmers do all the time, and as explained in the ownership section, the borrowing system is designed to make that easy to do. And in any case, it's still quite <em>local</em> context. As usual, if you get this wrong, the borrow checker will catch it.</p> </li> </ul> <p>In addition to that story for context-dependence, the feature would be only narrowly applicable (only to <code>match</code>) and only moderately powerful (since, again, the borrower checker will catch mistakes).</p> <p>Both of these changes would expand the reasoning footprint slightly, but in a very controlled way. They remove the need to write down annotations which are essentially already forced by nearby code. And that in turn lowers the learning curve for <code>match</code>.</p> <h2 id="example-the-module-system">Example: the module system</h2> <p>Finally, let's take the module system. In the most common usage, modules are defined like so:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">mod </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">some_module; </span></pre> <p>where <code>some_module.rs</code> is a file at an appropriate place in the source tree. You can specify an explicit path if you prefer, so this is a case of implicitness through convention. But while this bit of implicitness helps, the module system still makes a number of fine distinctions that trip up newcomers and require redundancy that even old hands can forget.</p> <h3 id="idea-eliminate-the-need-for-extern-crate-and-maybe-mod-too">Idea: eliminate the need for <code>extern crate</code>, and maybe <code>mod</code> too</h3> <p>The clearest-cut case is the <code>extern crate</code> declaration, which is used to bring an external crate into scope. The vast majority of Rust projects use Cargo for dependency management, and already specify the crates they depend on in their <code>Cargo.toml</code> file. Hence, <code>extern crate</code> is usually redundant, and it's easy to forget to add it after updating <code>Cargo.toml</code>. New users often complain about baroque distinctions between <code>mod</code>, <code>use</code>, <code>extern crate</code>, and entries in <code>Cargo.toml</code>; maybe we could improve matters by obviating the need for <code>extern crate</code>. What does that mean for the reasoning footprint?</p> <p>It means that to know what crates are in scope at the root, you need to consult the <code>Cargo.toml</code>, which becomes the sole source of truth for this concern. That's a pretty limited context: it's single place to look, and in many cases you already need some level of awareness of its contents, to know <em>which version</em> of the crate is being assumed. Inferring <code>extern crate</code> also fares well on the applicability front: only root modules are affected, so it's easy to know precisely when you need to consult <code>Cargo.toml</code>.</p> <p>Thinking along similar, but more radical lines, an argument could be made about the need for <code>mod</code> itself. After all, if we're usually just writing <code>mod some_module</code> to tell Rust to pull in a file at a canonical location with the same name, we're being forced to duplicate information that was already readily available. You could instead imagine the filesystem hierarchy directly informing the module system hierarchy. The concerns about limited context and applicability work out pretty much the same way as with <code>Cargo.toml</code>, and the learnability and ergonomic gains are significant.</p> <p>Now, both of these proposals assume your code follows the <em>typical</em> patterns, not making use of extra, non-default flexibility. There are a lot of questions about the fine details and expressiveness. But, at least from an <em>implicitness</em> perspective, neither of these changes set off any alarm bells for the reasoning footprint.</p> <h2 id="the-initiative">The initiative</h2> <p>With those aims and that design philosophy in mind, how do we plan to proceed?</p> <p>First off, we'll be using the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/17">roadmap tracker</a> to help organize ideas for ergonomic improvements. The tracker is already populated with some of the ideas the language team has been mulling over, but we'll keep it updated as proposals emerge on the <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/">the internals forum</a> and elsewhere. The language team is eager to mentor, so if one of the ideas catches your eye and you'd like guidance working toward a full-blown RFC, log your interest on the tracker! And similarly for implementation, once the RFC has merged.</p> <p>Digging deeper, there's a vital cross-cutting concern: <em>empathy</em>. The goal here is to try to imagine and evaluate ways that Rust could be different. To do this well, we need to be able to put ourselves back in the shoes of a newcomer. Of someone who prefers a different workflow. We need to be able to come to Rust fresh, shedding our current habits and mental models and trying on new ones.</p> <p>And, perhaps most importantly, we need empathy for each other. Transformative insights can be fragile; they can start out embedded in ideas that have lots of problems. If we're too quick to shut down a line of thought based on those problems, we risk foreclosing on avenues to something better. We've got to have the patience to sit with ideas that are foreign and uncomfortable, and gain some new perspective from them. We've got to trust that we all want to make Rust better, and that good faith deliberation is the way to <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2017/02/06/roadmap.html">make productivity a core value, without sacrificing the others</a>.</p> <p>Let's do this!</p> Announcing Rust 1.15.1 Thu, 09 Feb 2017 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-15-1/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-15-1/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce the latest version of Rust, 1.15.1. Rust is a systems programming language focused on safety, speed, and concurrency.</p> <p>If you have a previous version of Rust installed, getting Rust 1.15.1 is as easy as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">rustup</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> update stable </span></pre> <p>If you don't have it already, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">download Rust</a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1151-2017-02-09">detailed release notes for 1.15.1</a> on GitHub.</p> <h3 id="what-s-in-1-15-1-stable">What's in 1.15.1 stable</h3> <p>This release fixes two issues, a soundness bug in the new <code>vec::IntoIter::as_mut_slice</code> method, and a regression wherein certain C components of the Rust distribution were <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/39523">not compiled with <code>-fPIC</code></a>. The latter results in the text section of executables being writable in some configurations, including common Linux configurations, subverting an important attack mitigation, and creating longer startup times by causing the linker to do more work. For mostly-Rust codebases, the practical impact of losing read-only text sections is relatively small (since Rust's type system is its first line of defense), but for Rust linked into other codebases the impact could be unexpectedly quite significant. <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Position-independent_code">PIC</a> issues are well understood and not Rust-specific, so the rest of this post focuses on the soundness bug.</p> <p>The problem with <code>as_mut_slice</code>, a three line function, was <a href="https://www.reddit.com/r/rust/comments/5roiq7/announcing_rust_115/dd8vujs/">discovered</a> just minutes after publishing Rust 1.15.0, and is a reminder of the perils of writing unsafe code.</p> <p><code>as_mut_slice</code> is a method on the <code>IntoIter</code> iterator for the <code>Vec</code> type that offers a mutable view into the buffer being iterated over. Conceptually it is simple: just return a reference to the buffer; and indeed the implementation is simple, but it's unsafe because <code>IntoIter</code> is implemented with an unsafe pointer to the buffer:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">pub fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">as_mut_slice</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) -&gt; </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">mut </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[T] { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">unsafe </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ slice::from_raw_parts_mut(</span><span style="color:#c82829;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">.ptr </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">as </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">*mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> T, </span><span style="color:#c82829;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">len</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">()) } } </span></pre> <p>It's just about the simplest unsafe method one could ask for. Can you spot the error? Our reviewers didn't! This API slipped through the cracks because it is such a standard and small one. It's a copy-paste bug that the reviewers glossed over. This method takes a shared reference and unsafely derives from it a mutable reference. That is totally bogus because it means <code>as_mut_slice</code> can be used to produce multiple mutable references to the same buffer, which is the one single thing you must not do in Rust.</p> <p>Here's a simple example of what this bug would let you write, incorrectly:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> v </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">vec![</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">]; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> v_iter </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> v.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">into_iter</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(); </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> slice1: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">mut </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">_</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> v_iter.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">as_mut_slice</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(); </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> slice2: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">mut </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">_</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> v_iter.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">as_mut_slice</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(); slice1[</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; slice2[</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; } </span></pre> <p>Here both <code>slice1</code> and <code>slice2</code> are referencing the same mutable slice. Also notice that the iterator they are created from, <code>v_iter</code> is not declared mutable, which is a good indication something fishy is going on.</p> <p>The <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/39466">solution</a> here is trivial, just change <code>&amp;self</code> to <code>&amp;mut self</code>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">pub fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">as_mut_slice</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">mut </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) -&gt; </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">mut </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[T] { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">unsafe </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ slice::from_raw_parts_mut(</span><span style="color:#c82829;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">.ptr </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">as </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">*mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> T, </span><span style="color:#c82829;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">len</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">()) } } </span></pre> <p>With that, proper uniqueness invariants are maintained, only one mutable slice can be created at a time, and <code>v_iter</code> must be declared mutable in order to pull out a mutable slice.</p> <p>So we made that change, and we're releasing a fix. In Rust we take pride in not breaking APIs, but since this is a new, minor feature, and the present implementation is spectacularly unsound, we decided to go ahead and release the fix immediately, hopefully before too many codebases pick it up — that is, we don't consider this a breaking change that requires a careful transition, but a necessary bug fix. For more about Rust's approach to ensuring stability see the <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/10/30/Stability.html">&quot;Stability as a Deliverable&quot;</a> blog post, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/1122-language-semver.md">RFC 1122</a>, on language evolution, and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/1105-api-evolution.md">RFC 1105</a>, on library evolution.</p> <p>We're still evaluating what to learn from this, but this is a good reminder of the care that must be taken when writing unsafe code. We have some ideas for how to catch this kind of problem earlier in the development process, but haven't made any decisions yet.</p> <p>We apologize for the inconvenience. Let's go hack.</p> <h3 id="contributors-to-1-15-1">Contributors to 1.15.1</h3> <p>We had 2 individuals contribute to Rust 1.15.1. <a href="https://thanks.rust-lang.org/rust/1.15.1">Thanks!</a></p> Rust's 2017 roadmap Mon, 06 Feb 2017 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/2017-roadmap/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/2017-roadmap/ <p>Starting with 2017, Rust is following an <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1728">open roadmap process</a> for setting our aims for the year. The process is coordinated with <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2016/06/30/State-of-Rust-Survey-2016.html">the survey</a> and <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/2016-rust-commercial-user-survey-results/4317">production user outreach</a>, to make sure our goals are aligned with the needs of Rust's users. It culminates in a <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/setting-our-vision-for-the-2017-cycle/3958?u=aturon">community-wide discussion</a> and ultimately <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1774">an RFC</a> laying out a vision.</p> <p><strong>This year, the overarching theme is <em>productivity</em>, especially for early-stage Rust users</strong>. From tooling to libraries to documentation to the core language, we want to make it easier to get things done with Rust.</p> <p>A focus on productivity might seem at odds with some of Rust's other goals. After all, Rust has focused on reliability and performance, and it's easy to imagine that achieving those aims forces compromises elsewhere—like the learning curve, or developer productivity. Is &quot;fighting with the borrow checker&quot; an inherent rite of passage for budding Rustaceans? Does removing papercuts and small complexities entail glossing over safety holes or performance cliffs?</p> <p>Our approach with Rust has always been to bend the curve around tradeoffs, as embodied in the various pillars we've talked about on this blog:</p> <ul> <li><a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2015/04/10/Fearless-Concurrency.html">Memory safety without garbage collection</a></li> <li><a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2015/04/10/Fearless-Concurrency.html">Concurrency without data races</a></li> <li><a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2015/05/11/traits.html">Abstraction without overhead</a></li> <li><a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/10/30/Stability.html">Stability without stagnation</a></li> </ul> <p>In the core language we've sometimes been able to leverage things like Rust's ownership model to make features easier to use. For example, <a href="http://huonw.github.io/blog/2015/05/finding-closure-in-rust/">closures in Rust</a>, unlike those in C++, do not require explicit &quot;capture clauses&quot;; Rust's ownership tracking means that we can automatically infer whether to move or borrow data into the closure, without sacrificing reliability or performance. We've also been working to make the language easier to learn by improving the <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2016/08/10/Shape-of-errors-to-come.html">compiler's error messages</a>. And <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2016/05/05/cargo-pillars.html">Cargo</a> is an example of early focus on productivity that has only enhanced the power of systems programming with Rust, allowing for <a href="http://os.phil-opp.com/">OS</a> <a href="https://intermezzos.github.io/">projects</a> to easily build and leverage an ecosystem of shared libraries. There's so much more we can do along these lines!</p> <p>In short, <strong>productivity should be a core value of Rust</strong>, and we should work creatively to improve it while retaining Rust's other core values. By the end of 2017, we want to have earned the slogan:</p> <ul> <li>Rust: fast, reliable, productive—pick three.</li> </ul> <h2 id="the-roadmap">The roadmap</h2> <p>With that framing in mind, here's Rust's vision for 2017 in a nutshell. Each statement links to a corresponding tracker with more details:</p> <ul> <li> <p><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/3"><strong>Rust should have a lower learning curve</strong></a>. Plans include a <a href="https://github.com/aturon/rust-roadmap/issues/7">new book</a>, collecting examples and patterns, improving errors, <a href="https://github.com/aturon/rust-roadmap/issues/17">improving the core language</a>, and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/2">building IDEs</a>.</p> </li> <li> <p><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/1"><strong>Rust should have a pleasant edit-compile-debug cycle</strong></a>. Plans include <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2016/09/08/incremental.html">incremental compilation</a> and a <a href="https://github.com/aturon/rust-roadmap/issues/8">trait system overhaul</a>.</p> </li> <li> <p><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/2"><strong>Rust should provide a solid, but basic IDE experience</strong></a>. Plans are focused on the <a href="https://github.com/aturon/rust-roadmap/issues/6">Rust language service</a>.</p> </li> <li> <p><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/9"><strong>Rust should provide easy access to high quality crates</strong></a>. Plans include <a href="https://www.reddit.com/r/rust/comments/5r72aj/cratesio_has_categories/">crate categories</a>, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1824">crate ranking</a>, open-ended testing and benchmarking frameworks, new API and documentation guidelines, and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1643">guidelines for unsafe code</a>.</p> </li> <li> <p><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/10"><strong>Rust should be well-equipped for writing robust, high-scale servers</strong></a>. Plans mostly focus on the <a href="http://tokio.rs/">Tokio project</a> for asynchronous I/O and potentially <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1823">async/await notation</a>.</p> </li> <li> <p><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/11"><strong>Rust should have 1.0-level crates for essential tasks</strong></a>. Plans are under way to focus the libs team and the community on a number of important existing crates, to help polish them to 1.0 quality by the end of the year.</p> </li> <li> <p><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/12"><strong>Rust should integrate easily into large build systems</strong></a>. Plans include working with large companies incorporating Rust to understand how best to equip Cargo to smooth the process.</p> </li> <li> <p><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/13"><strong>Rust's community should provide mentoring at all levels</strong></a>. Plans include the <a href="https://github.com/rust-community/rustbridge/">RustBridge project</a> and new <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/language-team-shepherds/4595">team shepherds</a>.</p> </li> </ul> <p>In addition to these primary goals, we have highlighted two areas we'd like to explore, but where the end point is less clear:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/14">Integration with other languages, running the gamut from C to JavaScript</a>.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap/issues/15">Usage in resource-constrained environments</a>.</li> </ul> <p>The various Rust subteams are actively working on projects tied to these goals. You can track progress or jump in by watching and commenting on the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap">roadmap tracker</a>. And a fully detailed rationale for the roadmap is in <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1774">the RFC</a>.</p> <p>As the year progresses, expect to see many more blog posts announcing roadmap-related initiatives and milestones. Around the end of the year, we'll publish a <strong>retrospective</strong> aggregating the progress of the year and providing a guide to the current state of Rust.</p> <p>In the meantime—please <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-roadmap">get involved</a>! We have ambitious goals for the year, and we need all the help we can get.</p> Announcing Rust 1.15 Thu, 02 Feb 2017 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-15/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-15/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce the latest version of Rust, 1.15.0. Rust is a systems programming language focused on safety, speed, and concurrency.</p> <p>If you have a previous version of Rust installed, getting Rust 1.15 is as easy as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">rustup</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> update stable </span></pre> <p>If you don't have it already, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">get <code>rustup</code></a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1150-2017-02-02">detailed release notes for 1.15.0</a> on GitHub. 1443 patches were landed in this release.</p> <h3 id="what-s-in-1-15-0-stable">What's in 1.15.0 stable</h3> <p>Rust 1.15 sees an <em>extremely</em> eagerly-awaited feature land on stable: custom derive! To review, in Rust, you've always been able to automatically implement some traits through the <code>derive</code> attribute:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">#[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">derive</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(Debug)] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Pet { </span><span style="color:#c82829;">name</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: String, } </span></pre> <p>The <code>Debug</code> trait is then implemented for <code>Pet</code>, with vastly less boilerplate. However, this only worked for traits provided as part of the standard library; it was not customizable. With Rust 1.15, it now is. That means, if you want to turn your <code>Pet</code> into JSON, it's as easy as adding <a href="https://serde.rs">Serde</a> to your <code>Cargo.toml</code>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">dependencies</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#c82829;">serde </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;0.9&quot; </span><span style="color:#c82829;">serde_derive </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;0.9&quot; </span><span style="color:#c82829;">serde_json </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;0.9&quot; </span></pre> <p>And adding another trait to your <code>Pet</code>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">#[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">macro_use</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">extern crate</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> serde_derive; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">extern crate</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> serde_json; #[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">derive</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(Serialize, Deserialize, Debug)] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Pet { </span><span style="color:#c82829;">name</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: String, } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> pet </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> Pet { name: </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">String</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">::from(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;Ferris&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) }; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> serialized </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">serde_json::to_string(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">pet).</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">unwrap</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(); println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;serialized = </span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, serialized); </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> deserialized: Pet </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">serde_json::from_str(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">serialized).</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">unwrap</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(); println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;deserialized = </span><span style="color:#666969;">{:?}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, deserialized); } </span></pre> <p>This will output:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">serialized = {&quot;name&quot;:&quot;Ferris&quot;} deserialized = Pet { name: &quot;Ferris&quot; } </span></pre> <p>Another common use-case is <a href="http://diesel.rs">Diesel</a>. Say we had a database of <code>Pet</code>s. We could fetch them like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#999999;">// some extern crate and use lines elided here </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">#[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">derive</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(Queryable)] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Pet { </span><span style="color:#c82829;">name</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: String, } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">use </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">diesel_demo::schema::pets::dsl::</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">*</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> connection </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">establish_connection</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(); </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> results </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> pets .</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">limit</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">5</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) .load::&lt;Pet&gt;(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">connection) .</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">expect</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;Error loading pets&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;Displaying </span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;"> pets&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, results.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">len</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">()); </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">for</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> pet </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">in</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> results { println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, pet.name); } } </span></pre> <p>For full instructions, see <a href="http://diesel.rs">the website</a>.</p> <p>These kinds of libraries are extremely powerful, but rely on custom derive for ergonomics. While these libraries <em>worked</em> on Rust stable previously, they were not as nice to use, so much so that we often heard from users &quot;I only use nightly because of Serde and Diesel.&quot; The use of custom derive is one of the most widely used nightly-only features. As such, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1681">RFC 1681</a> was opened in July of last year to support this use-case. The RFC was merged in August, underwent a lot of development and testing, and now reaches stable today!</p> <p>To find out how to write your own custom derives, see <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/book/procedural-macros.html">the chapter of &quot;The Rust Programming Language&quot;</a>.</p> <p>While we've said &quot;Serde and Diesel&quot; a number of times here, there's a lot of other cool things you can do with custom derive: see <a href="https://crates.io/crates/derive-new"><code>derive-new</code></a> for another example. See <a href="https://crates.io/crates/syn/reverse_dependencies">the <code>syn</code> crate's reverse dependencies for more.</a> (<code>syn</code> is important for writing custom derives, see the book chapter, linked above, for more.) Custom derive was also known as &quot;macros 1.1&quot;, as it includes the infrastructure for supporting even more compile-time powers of Rust, nicknamed &quot;macros 2.0.&quot; Expect to hear more about this space in future releases.</p> <h4 id="other-improvements">Other improvements</h4> <p>The build system for Rust <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/37817">has been re-written in Rust, using Cargo</a>. It is now the default. This process has been long, but has finally borne fruit. Given that all Rust development happens on the master branch, we've been using it since December of last year, and it's working well. There is an open PR <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/39431">to remove the Makefiles entirely</a>, landing in Rust 1.17. This will pave the way for <code>rustc</code> to use packages from <code>crates.io</code> in the compiler like any other Rust project, and is a further demonstration of the maturity of Cargo.</p> <p>Rust has gained <a href="https://forge.rust-lang.org/platform-support.html">Tier 3 support</a> for <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/38086"><code>i686-unknown-openbsd</code></a>, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/37672"><code>MSP430</code></a>, and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/37615"><code>ARMv5TE</code></a>.</p> <p><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#compiler-performance">A number of compiler performance improvements have landed</a>. We continue to work on making the compiler faster. Expect to see more in the future!</p> <p>As a smaller improvement, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/37791"><code>?Sized</code> can now be used in <code>where</code> clauses</a>. In other words:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Foo&lt;T: </span><span style="background-color:#c82829;color:#ffffff;">?</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Sized&gt; { </span><span style="color:#c82829;">f</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: T, } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Foo&lt;T&gt; where T: ?Sized { </span><span style="color:#c82829;">f</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: T, } </span></pre> <p>This second form is now accepted, and is equivalent to the first.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1150-2017-02-02">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h4 id="library-stabilizations">Library stabilizations</h4> <p>The <code>slice::sort</code> algorithm <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/38192">has been rewritten</a>, and is much, much, much faster. It is a hybrid merge sort, drawing influences from Timsort. Previously it was a straightforward merge sort.</p> <p>If you had a <code>Vec&lt;T&gt;</code> where <code>T: Copy</code>, and you called <code>extend</code> on it, your code will <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/38182">now be a lot faster</a>.</p> <p>Speaking of things getting faster, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/37888"><code>chars().count()</code></a>, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/37882"><code>chars().last()</code>, and <code>char_indices().last()</code></a> are too!</p> <p><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/37855">Chinese characters now display correctly in <code>fmt::Debug</code></a>.</p> <p>There were a number of functions stabilized as well:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/iter/trait.Iterator.html#method.min_by"><code>std::iter::Iterator::min_by</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/iter/trait.Iterator.html#method.max_by"><code>std::iter::Iterator::max_by</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/os/unix/fs/trait.FileExt.html"><code>std::os::*::fs::FileExt</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/sync/atomic/struct.AtomicU8.html#method.get_mut"><code>std::sync::atomic::Atomic*::get_mut</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/sync/atomic/struct.AtomicU8.html#method.into_inner"><code>std::sync::atomic::Atomic*::into_inner</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/vec/struct.IntoIter.html#method.as_slice"><code>std::vec::IntoIter::as_slice</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/vec/struct.IntoIter.html#method.as_mut_slice"><code>std::vec::IntoIter::as_mut_slice</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/sync/mpsc/struct.Receiver.html#method.try_iter"><code>std::sync::mpsc::Receiver::try_iter</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/os/unix/process/trait.CommandExt.html#tymethod.before_exec"><code>std::os::unix::process::CommandExt::before_exec</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/rc/struct.Rc.html#method.strong_count"><code>std::rc::Rc::strong_count</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/rc/struct.Rc.html#method.weak_count"><code>std::rc::Rc::weak_count</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/sync/struct.Arc.html#method.strong_count"><code>std::sync::Arc::strong_count</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/sync/struct.Arc.html#method.weak_count"><code>std::sync::Arc::weak_count</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.char.html#method.encode_utf8"><code>std::char::encode_utf8</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.char.html#method.encode_utf16"><code>std::char::encode_utf16</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/cell/struct.Ref.html#method.clone"><code>std::cell::Ref::clone</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/io/struct.Take.html#method.into_inner"><code>std::io::Take::into_inner</code></a></li> </ul> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1150-2017-02-02">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h4 id="cargo-features">Cargo features</h4> <p>Cargo will now <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/3361">emit a warning</a> if you have a file named <code>build.rs</code> at the top level of a package, but don't have a <code>build = &quot;build.rs&quot;</code> annotation. This is in anticipation of inferring that <code>build.rs</code> at the top level is always a build script, but is a warning right now for compatibility reasons. Previously, all build scripts required configuration, but this convention was strong within the community, so we're going to encode it into Cargo.</p> <p>In this release, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/3368">Cargo build scripts no longer have access to the <code>OUT_DIR</code> environment variable at build time via <code>env!(&quot;OUT_DIR&quot;)</code></a>. They should instead check the variable at runtime with <code>std::env</code>. That the value was set at build time was a bug, and incorrect when cross-compiling. Please check what your packages are doing and update to use <code>std::env</code>!</p> <p>The <code>cargo test</code> command has <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/3221">gained support for a <code>--all</code> flag</a>, which is useful when you have a workspace.</p> <p>We now <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/3363">Compile statically against the MSVC CRT</a> on Windows, and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/3311">Link OpenSSL statically</a> on Mac OS X.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1150-2017-02-02">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h3 id="contributors-to-1-15-0">Contributors to 1.15.0</h3> <p>In this part of the release announcements, we usually post a list of contributors. However, we've recently started a new initiative, &quot;Thanks!&quot;, to do this in a more comprehensive way. One issue with this section is that it only counted contributions to the <code>rust-lang/rust</code> repository; those who committed to Cargo weren't thanked, for example. We also had to manually generate this list, which wasn't terrible, but running the correct git commands to determine who contributed is exactly what code is good for!</p> <p>As such, you can now visit <a href="https://thanks.rust-lang.org/">https://thanks.rust-lang.org/</a> to see more comprehensive contribution calculations. If you prefer, we also have an alias at <a href="https://%E2%9D%A4.rust-lang.org">https://❤.rust-lang.org</a> as well. For now, this will only show what we've shown in previous release posts. We do have one additional feature, which is an all-time contributions list, sorted by commit count. That's located here: <a href="https://thanks.rust-lang.org/rust/all-time">https://thanks.rust-lang.org/rust/all-time</a></p> <p>We have done some of the needed backend work to enable more repositories than only <code>rust-lang/rust</code>, but it's not quite done yet. If you'd like to get involved, please <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/thanks">check out thanks on GitHub</a>!</p> <p>We had 137 individuals contribute to Rust 1.15. <a href="https://thanks.rust-lang.org/rust/1.15.0">Thanks!</a></p> Announcing Rust 1.14 Thu, 22 Dec 2016 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-14/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-14/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce the latest version of Rust, 1.14.0. Rust is a systems programming language focused on safety, speed, and concurrency.</p> <p>As always, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">install Rust 1.14.0</a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1140-2016-12-22">detailed release notes for 1.14.0</a> on GitHub. 1230 patches were landed in this release.</p> <h3 id="what-s-in-1-14-0-stable">What's in 1.14.0 stable</h3> <p>One of the biggest features in Rust 1.14 isn't actually in the language or compiler: the <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/beta-testing-rustup-rs/3316/203">rustup tool has reached a 1.0 release</a>, and is now the recommended way to install Rust from the project directly. Rustup does a bit more than just install Rust:</p> <blockquote> <p>rustup installs The Rust Programming Language from the official release channels, enabling you to easily switch between stable, beta, and nightly compilers and keep them updated. It makes cross-compiling simpler with binary builds of the standard library for common platforms. And it runs on all platforms Rust supports, including Windows.</p> </blockquote> <p>We had <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2016/05/13/rustup.html">a previous post about Rustup</a> back in May. You can learn more about it there, or by checking it out <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rustup.rs">on GitHub</a>.</p> <p>Another exciting feature is <a href="https://users.rust-lang.org/t/compiling-to-the-web-with-rust-and-emscripten/7627">experimental support for WebAssembly</a> as a target, <code>wasm32-unknown-emscripten</code>. It is still early days, and there's a lot of bugs to shake out, so please give it a try and report them! To give you a small taste of how it works, once you have <a href="http://kripken.github.io/emscripten-site/docs/getting_started/downloads.html">emscripten</a> installed, compiling some Rust code to WebAssembly is as easy as:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">rustup</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> target add wasm32-unknown-emscripten </span><span style="color:#c82829;">$</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> echo </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&#39;fn main() { println!(&quot;Hello, Emscripten!&quot;); }&#39; </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&gt;</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> hello.rs </span><span style="color:#c82829;">$</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> rustc</span><span style="color:#f5871f;"> --target</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">wasm32-unknown-emscripten hello.rs </span><span style="color:#c82829;">$</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> node hello.js </span></pre> <p>The community has been doing interesting, experimental work in this area: see <a href="http://www.hellorust.com/emscripten/">Jan-Erik's slides</a> for the workshop he ran at <a href="http://www.rust-belt-rust.com/sessions/">Rust Belt Rust</a> for some examples, or check out <a href="http://timryan.org/rust-todomvc/">Tim's example of the classic TodoMVC project</a>. This implementation builds off of his <a href="https://crates.io/crates/webplatform">webplatform crate</a>, which exposes the DOM to Rust.</p> <p>Speaking of platforms, a large number of platforms have gained additional support:</p> <p>For <code>rustc</code>:</p> <ul> <li><code>mips-unknown-linux-gnu</code></li> <li><code>mipsel-unknown-linux-gnu</code></li> <li><code>mips64-unknown-linux-gnuabi64</code></li> <li><code>mips64el-unknown-linux-gnuabi64</code></li> <li><code>powerpc-unknown-linux-gnu</code></li> <li><code>powerpc64-unknown-linux-gnu</code></li> <li><code>powerpc64le-unknown-linux-gnu</code></li> <li><code>s390x-unknown-linux-gnu</code></li> </ul> <p>And for <code>std</code>:</p> <ul> <li><code>arm-unknown-linux-musleabi</code></li> <li><code>arm-unknown-linux-musleabihf</code></li> <li><code>armv7-unknown-linux-musleabihf</code></li> </ul> <p>If you're using one of these platforms, follow the instructions on the website to install, or add the targets to an existing installation with <code>rustup target add</code>.</p> <p>These platforms are all 'tier 2', please see our page on <a href="https://forge.rust-lang.org/platform-support.html">platform support</a> for more details.</p> <p>Just like how the community is doing interesting work on the WebAssembly target, there's also neat things going on with increasing Rust's target support beyond what's listed above. <a href="https://github.com/japaric/xargo">xargo</a> allows for easy cross-compilation of Rust to bare-metal targets. If you're writing an operating system in Rust, or doing something interesting on a microcontroller, xargo can make your life a lot simpler.</p> <p>The landing of MIR over the last few releases means that a <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#compile-time-optimizations">number of improvements to compile times</a> have landed, with more coming in the future.</p> <p>In the language, one small improvement has landed: support for <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/1492-dotdot-in-patterns.md">RFC 1492</a>. This small addition lets you use <code>..</code> in more places. Previously, say you had a struct like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Point { </span><span style="color:#c82829;">x</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#c82829;">y</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#c82829;">z</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, } </span></pre> <p>In any context where you're doing a pattern match, you could use <code>..</code> to ignore the parts you don't care about. For example:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> p </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> Point { x: </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, y: </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, z: </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">}; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">match</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> p { Point { x, </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">.. </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;x is </span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, x), } </span></pre> <p>The <code>..</code> ignores <code>y</code> and <code>z</code>.</p> <p>Consider a similar <code>Point</code>, but as a tuple struct:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Point(</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); </span></pre> <p>Previously, you could use <code>..</code> to ignore all three elements:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> p </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> Point(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">match</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> p { Point(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">..</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;found a point&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">), } </span></pre> <p>But you could not use it to only ignore parts of the tuple:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> p </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> Point(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">match</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> p { Point(x, </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">..</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;x is </span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, x), } </span></pre> <p>This was an inconsistency, and so with RFC 1492 stabilized, compiles fine as of this release. This applies to more situations than tuples; please see <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/1492-dotdot-in-patterns.md">the RFC</a> for more details.</p> <h4 id="library-stabilizations">Library stabilizations</h4> <p>There have been a number of additions to the standard library, but they don't fit into particularly nice categories for this release. Here's the highlights:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/36825"><code>println!()</code>, with no arguments, prints newline</a>. Previously, an empty string was required to achieve the same.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/37356"><code>Wrapping</code> impls standard binary and unary operators on references, as well as the <code>Sum</code> and <code>Product</code> iterators</a>, making references to these types easier to use.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/37326">Implement <code>From&lt;Cow&lt;str&gt;&gt; for String</code> and <code>From&lt;Cow&lt;[T]&gt;&gt; for Vec&lt;T&gt;</code></a>. These implementations make sense, but were not yet added.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/37230">Expand <code>.zip()</code> specialization to <code>.map()</code> and <code>.cloned()</code></a> for improved performance.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/37178">Implement <code>RefUnwindSafe</code> for atomic types</a>, as these types are &quot;unwind safe,&quot; though that wasn't obvious at first.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/37094">Specialize <code>Vec::extend</code> to <code>Vec::extend_from_slice</code></a> for performance gains.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/37470">Don't reuse <code>HashMap</code> random seeds</a>. This helps to mitigate one type of DDoS attack.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/36692">The internal memory layout of <code>HashMap</code> is more cache-friendly, for significant improvements in some operations</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/36430">Impl <code>Add&lt;{str, Cow&lt;str&gt;}&gt;</code> for <code>Cow&lt;str&gt;</code></a>. We already support <code>Add</code> for other string types, so not having it on <code>Cow</code> is inconsistent.</li> </ul> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1140-2016-12-22">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h4 id="cargo-features">Cargo features</h4> <p>As for Cargo, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/1721-crt-static.md">RFC 1721</a> has been implemented. Cargo will now pass along the values printed by <code>rustc --print cfg</code> to build scripts. The motivation for this feature is that Cargo can now compile objects for statically linking against the msvcrt on the MSVC platform.</p> <p>Cargo now works properly <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/issues/3259">with a read-only <code>CARGO_HOME</code></a>.</p> <p>Finally, Cargo will <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/issues/3175">ignore the <code>panic</code> configuration for the <code>test</code> and <code>bench</code> profiles</a>. This is important because the test runner relies on panics counting as failing tests, and so with <code>panic=abort</code>, a failing test would abort the entire test suite.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1140-2016-12-22">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h3 id="contributors-to-1-14-0">Contributors to 1.14.0</h3> <p>We had 144 individuals contribute to 1.14.0. Thank you so much!</p> <ul> <li>Abhishek Chanda</li> <li>Adam Perry</li> <li>Ahmed Charles</li> <li>Aidan Hobson Sayers</li> <li>Aleksey Kladov</li> <li>Alexander von Gluck IV</li> <li>Alex Burka</li> <li>Alex Crichton</li> <li>Alex von Gluck IV</li> <li>Amanieu d'Antras</li> <li>Andrea Corradi</li> <li>Andrea Pretto</li> <li>Andreas Sommer</li> <li>Andre Bogus</li> <li>Andrew Paseltiner</li> <li>angelsl</li> <li>Anthony Ramine</li> <li>Ariel Ben-Yehuda</li> <li>arthurprs</li> <li>Austin Hicks</li> <li>bors</li> <li>Brian Anderson</li> <li>Bunts Thy Unholy</li> <li>CensoredUsername</li> <li>Chris McDonald</li> <li>Christopher</li> <li>christopherdumas</li> <li>Christopher Serr</li> <li>Cobrand</li> <li>Corey Farwell</li> <li>Cristi Cobzarenco</li> <li>Daan Sprenkels</li> <li>Danny Hua</li> <li>David Henningsson</li> <li>Devon Hollowood</li> <li>Dmitry Gritsay</li> <li>Dominik Inführ</li> <li>Duncan</li> <li>Eduard Burtescu</li> <li>Eduard-Mihai Burtescu</li> <li>Eric Roshan-Eisner</li> <li>est31</li> <li>Fabian Frei</li> <li>Federico Mena Quintero</li> <li>Felix S. Klock II</li> <li>Florian Diebold</li> <li>Florian Hartwig</li> <li>Florian Zeitz</li> <li>Frank Rehberger</li> <li>Gavin Baker</li> <li>Geoffry Song</li> <li>Guillaume Gomez</li> <li>iirelu</li> <li>James Miller</li> <li>Jan-Erik Rediger</li> <li>Jared Roesch</li> <li>Jeffrey Seyfried</li> <li>Jesus Garlea</li> <li>Jethro Beekman</li> <li>Joe Neeman</li> <li>Johannes Muenzel</li> <li>John Firebaugh</li> <li>John Hodge</li> <li>johnthagen</li> <li>Jonas Schievink</li> <li>Jonathan Turner</li> <li>Jorge Aparicio</li> <li>Josh Stone</li> <li>Josh Triplett</li> <li>Keegan McAllister</li> <li>Keith Yeung</li> <li>KillTheMule</li> <li>Konrad Borowski</li> <li>leonardo.yvens</li> <li>Liigo Zhuang</li> <li>loggerhead</li> <li>Manish Goregaokar</li> <li>Marcin Fatyga</li> <li>Mark-Simulacrum</li> <li>Martin Glagla</li> <li>Martin Thoresen</li> <li>Mathieu Borderé</li> <li>Mathieu Poumeyrol</li> <li>Matt Brubeck</li> <li>Matthew Piziak</li> <li>Matwey V. Kornilov</li> <li>mcarton</li> <li>Michael Woerister</li> <li>Mikhail Modin</li> <li>Mikko Rantanen</li> <li>msiglreith</li> <li>Nabeel Omer</li> <li>Nathan Musoke</li> <li>Nicholas Nethercote</li> <li>Nick Cameron</li> <li>Nick Fitzgerald</li> <li>Nick Stevens</li> <li>Nikhil Shagrithaya</li> <li>Niko Matsakis</li> <li>Oliver Middleton</li> <li>p512</li> <li>ParkHanbum</li> <li>Paul Lange</li> <li>Paulo Matos</li> <li>Paul Osborne</li> <li>Peter Atashian</li> <li>Peter N</li> <li>Philip Davis</li> <li>Pieter Frenssen</li> <li>Pweaver (Paul Weaver)</li> <li>pweyck</li> <li>QuietMisdreavus</li> <li>Raph Levien</li> <li>Razican</li> <li>Robin Stocker</li> <li>Ross Schulman</li> <li>Ryan Senior</li> <li>Scott Olson</li> <li>Seo Sanghyeon</li> <li>Simonas Kazlauskas</li> <li>Simon Sapin</li> <li>Srinivas Reddy Thatiparthy</li> <li>Stefan Schindler</li> <li>Stephen M. Coakley</li> <li>Steve Klabnik</li> <li>Steven Fackler</li> <li>Tamir Duberstein</li> <li>Taylor Cramer</li> <li>Tim Neumann</li> <li>Tobias Bucher</li> <li>Tomasz Miąsko</li> <li>tormol</li> <li>Tshepang Lekhonkhobe</li> <li>Ulrik Sverdrup</li> <li>Vadim Chugunov</li> <li>Vadim Petrochenkov</li> <li>Vadzim Dambrouski</li> <li>Vangelis Katsikaros</li> <li>Wang Xuerui</li> <li>Wesley Wiser</li> <li>Zack M. Davis</li> <li>Zoffix Znet</li> <li>Артём Павлов [Artyom Pavlov]</li> <li>石博文</li> </ul> Announcing the First Underhanded Rust Contest Thu, 15 Dec 2016 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/underhanded-rust/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/underhanded-rust/ <p>The <a href="https://community.rs">Rust Community Team</a> is pleased to announce the first annual Underhanded Rust Contest, inspired by the <a href="http://www.underhanded-c.org/">Underhanded C</a> and <a href="https://underhandedcrypto.com/">Underhanded Crypto</a> contests. Our goal with <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/">Rust</a> is to make it easy to write trustworthy low-level software that is resistant to accidental security vulnerabilities. Less often challenged has been Rust's ability to protect against <em>deliberate</em> vulnerabilities in the face of scrutiny. This challenge is designed to put our language and <a href="https://crates.io/">the broader Rust ecosystem</a> to the test, to help us learn where our blind spots are and what needs to be done to address them. In short, we want you to break our stuff using reasonable, easy-to-read code. Can you write 100% safe Rust that hides a logic bug, or hide an exploit in <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/book/unsafe.html">unsafe</a> Rust that passes an audit? Now's your chance!</p> <p>For more details, see the announcement of the project at <a href="https://underhanded.rs/blog/2016/12/15/underhanded-rust.en-US.html">underhanded.rs</a>.</p> Announcing Rust 1.13 Thu, 10 Nov 2016 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-13/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-13/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce the latest version of Rust, 1.13.0. Rust is a systems programming language focused on safety, speed, and concurrency.</p> <p>As always, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/downloads.html">install Rust 1.13.0</a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/stable/RELEASES.md#version-1130-2016-11-10">detailed release notes for 1.13.0</a> on GitHub. 1448 patches were landed in this release.</p> <p>It's been a busy season in Rust. We enjoyed three Rust conferences, <a href="http://rustconf.com/">RustConf</a>, <a href="http://www.rustfest.eu/">RustFest</a>, and <a href="http://www.rust-belt-rust.com/">Rust Belt Rust</a>, in short succession. It was great to see so many Rustaceans in person, some for the first time! We've been <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/setting-our-vision-for-the-2017-cycle/3958/47">thinking a lot</a> about the future, developing a <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1774">roadmap for 2017</a>, and <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/introducing-rust-language-server-source-release/4209">building the tools</a> our users <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/2016-rust-commercial-user-survey-results/4317">tell us</a> they need.</p> <p>And even with all that going on, we put together a new release filled with fun new toys.</p> <h3 id="what-s-in-1-13-stable">What's in 1.13 stable</h3> <p>The 1.13 release includes several extensions to the language, including the long-awaited <code>?</code> operator, improvements to compile times, minor feature additions to cargo and the standard library. This release also includes many small enhancements to documentation and error reporting, by many contributors, that are not individually mentioned in the release notes.</p> <p>This release contains important security updates to Cargo, which depends on curl and OpenSSL, which both published security updates recently. For more information see the respective announcements for <a href="https://curl.haxx.se/changes.html">curl 7.51.0</a> and <a href="https://www.openssl.org/news/secadv/20160922.txt">OpenSSL 1.0.2j</a>.</p> <h4 id="the-operator">The <code>?</code> operator</h4> <p>Rust has gained a new operator, <code>?</code>, that makes error handling more pleasant by reducing the visual noise involved. It does this by solving one simple problem. To illustrate, imagine we had some code to read some data from a file:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">read_username_from_file</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() -&gt; Result&lt;String, io::Error&gt; { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> f </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">File::open(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;username.txt&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> f </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">match</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> f { </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Ok</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(file) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> file, </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Err</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(e) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">return </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Err</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(e), }; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> s </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">String</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">::new(); </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">match</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> f.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">read_to_string</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> s) { </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Ok</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">_</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Ok</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(s), </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Err</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(e) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Err</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(e), } } </span></pre> <p>This code has two paths that can fail, opening the file and reading the data from it. If either of these fail to work, we'd like to return an error from <code>read_username_from_file</code>. Doing so involves <code>match</code>ing on the result of the I/O operations. In simple cases like this though, where we are only propagating errors up the call stack, the matching is just boilerplate - seeing it written out, in the same pattern every time, doesn't provide the reader with a great deal of useful information.</p> <p>With <code>?</code>, the above code looks like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">read_username_from_file</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() -&gt; Result&lt;String, io::Error&gt; { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> f </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">File::open(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;username.txt&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">)</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">?</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> s </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">String</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">::new(); f.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">read_to_string</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> s)</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">?</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Ok</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(s) } </span></pre> <p>The <code>?</code> is shorthand for the entire match statements we wrote earlier. In other words, <code>?</code> applies to a <code>Result</code> value, and if it was an <code>Ok</code>, it unwraps it and gives the inner value. If it was an <code>Err</code>, it returns from the function you're currently in. Visually, it is much more straightforward. Instead of an entire match statement, now we are just using the single &quot;?&quot; character to indicate that here we are handling errors in the standard way, by passing them up the call stack.</p> <p>Seasoned Rustaceans may recognize that this is the same as the <code>try!</code> macro that's been available since Rust <code>1.0</code>. And indeed, they are the same. Before 1.13, <code>read_username_from_file</code> could have been implemented like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">read_username_from_file</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() -&gt; Result&lt;String, io::Error&gt; { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> f </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">try!(File::open(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;username.txt&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">)); </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> s </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">String</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">::new(); try!(f.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">read_to_string</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> s)); </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Ok</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(s) } </span></pre> <p>So why extend the language when we already have a macro? There are multiple reasons. First, <code>try!</code> has proved to be extremely useful, and is used often in idiomatic Rust. It is used so often that we think it's worth having a sweet syntax. This sort of evolution is one of the great advantages of a powerful macro system: speculative extensions to the language syntax can be prototyped and iterated on without modifying the language itself, and in return, macros that turn out to be especially useful can indicate missing language features. This evolution, from <code>try!</code> to <code>?</code> is a great example.</p> <p>One of the reasons <code>try!</code> needs a sweeter syntax is that it is quite unattractive when multiple invocations of <code>try!</code> are used in succession. Consider:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">try!(try!(try!(</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">foo</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">()).</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">bar</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">()).</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">baz</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">()) </span></pre> <p>as opposed to</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4271ae;">foo</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">()</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">?</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">bar</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">()</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">?</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">baz</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">()</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">? </span></pre> <p>The first is quite difficult to scan visually, and each layer of error handling prefixes the expression with an additional call to <code>try!</code>. This brings undue attention to the trivial error propagation, obscuring the main code path, in this example the calls to <code>foo</code>, <code>bar</code> and <code>baz</code>. This sort of method chaining with error handling occurs in situations like the builder pattern.</p> <p>Finally, the dedicated syntax will make it easier in the future to produce nicer error messages tailored specifically to <code>?</code>, whereas it is difficult to produce nice errors for macro-expanded code generally (in this release, though, the <code>?</code> error messages could use improvement).</p> <p>Though this is a small feature, in our experience so far, <code>?</code> feels like a solid ergonomic improvement to the old <code>try!</code> macro. This is a good example of the kinds of incremental, quality-of-life improvements Rust will continue to receive, polishing off the rough corners of our already-powerful base language.</p> <p>Read more about <code>?</code> in <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/0243-trait-based-exception-handling.md">RFC 243</a>.</p> <h4 id="performance-improvements">Performance improvements</h4> <p>There has been a lot of focus on compiler performance lately. There's good news in this release, and more to come.</p> <p>Mark Simulacrum and Nick Cameron have been refining <a href="http://perf.rust-lang.org">perf.rust-lang.org</a>, our tool for tracking compiler performance. It runs the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rustc-benchmarks">rustc-benchmarks</a> suite regularly, on dedicated hardware, and tracks the results over time. This tool records the results for each pass in the compiler and is used by the compiler developers to narrow commit ranges of performance regressions. It's an important part of our toolbox!</p> <p>We can use this tool to look at a <a href="https://goo.gl/6T69T2">graph</a> of performance over the 1.13 development cycle, shown below. This cycle covered the dates from August 16 through September 29 (the graph begins from Augest 25th though and is filtered in a few ways to eliminate bogus, incomplete, or confusing results).
