There appear to be some big reductions, which are quantified on the corresponding <a href="https://goo.gl/CLIAhi">statistics</a> page.</p> <br/> <p><img src="/images/2016-11-Rust-1.13/graph.png" alt="Performance graph" /></p> <br/> <p>The big improvement demonstrated in the graphs, on September 1, is from an optimization from Niko to <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/35761">cache normalized projections during translation</a>. That is to say, during generation of LLVM IR, the compiler no longer recomputes concrete instances of associated types each time they are needed, but instead reuses previously-computed values. This optimization doesn't affect all code bases, but in code bases that exhibit certain patterns, like <a href="https://github.com/alexcrichton/futures-rs">futures-rs</a>, where <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/37600#issuecomment-258696690">debug mode build-time improved by up to 40%</a>, you'll notice the difference.</p> <p>Another such optimization, that doesn't affect every crate but does affect some in a big way, came from Michael Woerister, and improves compile time for crates that export many <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/36524">inline</a> functions. When a function is marked <code>#[inline]</code>, in addition to translating that function for use by the current crate, the compiler stores its MIR representation in the crate rlib, and translates the function to LLVM IR in every crate that calls it. The optimization Michael did is obvious in retrospect: there are some cases where inline functions are only for the consumption of other crates, and never called from the crate in which they are defined; so the compiler doesn't need to translate code for inline functions in the crate they are defined <em>unless</em> they are called directly. This saves the cost of rustc converting the function to LLVM IR and LLVM optimizing and converting the function to machine code.</p> <p>In some cases this results in dramatic improvements. Build times for the ndarray crate <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/37600#issuecomment-258706020">improved by 50%</a>, and in the (unreleased) <a href="https://github.com/retep998/winapi-rs">winapi 0.3</a> crate, rustc now emits no machine code at all.</p> <p>But wait, there's more still! Nick Nethercote has <a href="https://blog.mozilla.org/nnethercote/2016/10/14/how-to-speed-up-the-rust-compiler">turned his focus to compiler performance as well</a>, focusing on profiling and micro-optimizations. This release contains <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/stable/RELEASES.md#compile-time-optimizations">several fruits of his work</a>, and there are more in the pipeline for 1.14.</p> <h3 id="other-notable-changes">Other notable changes</h3> <p>This release contains important security updates to Cargo, which depends on curl and OpenSSL, which both published security updates recently. For more information see the respective announcements for <a href="https://curl.haxx.se/changes.html">curl 7.51.0</a> and <a href="https://www.openssl.org/news/secadv/20160922.txt">OpenSSL 1.0.2j</a>.</p> <p>Macros can now be used in type position (<a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/0873-type-macros.md">RFC 873</a>), and attributes can be applied to statements (<a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/0016-more-attributes.md">RFC 16</a>):</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#999999;">// Use a macro to name a type </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">macro_rules! </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Tuple { { </span><span style="color:#c82829;">$A</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">:ty,</span><span style="color:#c82829;">$B</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">:ty } </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ (</span><span style="color:#c82829;">$A</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#c82829;">$B</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) } } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> x: Tuple</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">!</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); </span></pre><pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#999999;">// Apply a lint attribute to a single statement </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">#[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">allow</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(non_snake_case)] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let </span><span style="color:#666969;">BAD_STYLE </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">List::new(); </span></pre> <p>Inline drop flags have been removed. Previously, in case of a conditional move, the compiler would store a &quot;drop flag&quot; inline in a struct (increasing its size) to keep track of whether or not it needs to be dropped. This means that some structs take up some unexpected extra space, which interfered with things like passing types with destructors over FFI. It also was a waste of space for code that didn't have conditional moves. In 1.12, <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2016/09/29/Rust-1.12.html">MIR became the default</a>, which laid the groundwork for many improvements, including <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/35764">getting rid of these inline drop flags</a>. Now, drop flags are stored in an extra slot on the stack frames of functions that need them.</p> <p>1.13 contains a <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/37630">serious bug in code generation</a> for ARM targets using hardware floats (which is most ARM targets). ARM targets in Rust are presently in our 2nd support tier, so this bug was not determined to block the release. Because 1.13 contains a security update, users that must target ARM are encouraged to use the 1.14 betas, which will soon get a fix for ARM.</p> <h4 id="language-stabilizations">Language stabilizations</h4> <ul> <li>The <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/marker/trait.Reflect.html"><code>Reflect</code></a> trait is deprecated. See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/27749#issuecomment-244489589">explanation</a> of what this means for parametricity in Rust.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/36014">Stabilize macros in type position</a>. <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/0873-type-macros.md">RFC 873</a>.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/36995">Stabilize attributes on statements</a>. <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/0016-more-attributes.md">RFC 16</a>.</li> </ul> <h4 id="library-stabilizations">Library stabilizations</h4> <ul> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.i32.html#method.checked_abs"><code>checked_abs</code></a>, <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.i32.html#method.wrapping_abs"><code>wrapping_abs</code></a>, and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.i32.html#method.overflowing_abs"><code>overflowing_abs</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/cell/struct.RefCell.html#method.try_borrow"><code>RefCell::try_borrow</code></a>, and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/cell/struct.RefCell.html#method.try_borrow_mut"><code>RefCell::try_borrow_mut</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/35074">Add <code>assert_ne!</code> and <code>debug_assert_ne!</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/35559">Implement <code>AsRef&lt;[T]&gt;</code> for <code>std::slice::Iter</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/35627">Implement <code>CoerceUnsized</code> for <code>{Cell, RefCell, UnsafeCell}</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/36101">Implement <code>Debug</code> for <code>std::path::{Components,Iter}</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/35755">Implement conversion traits for <code>char</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/hash/struct.SipHasher.html"><code>SipHasher</code></a> is deprecated. Use <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/collections/hash_map/struct.DefaultHasher.html"><code>DefaultHasher</code></a>.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/35911">Implement more traits for <code>std::io::ErrorKind</code></a></li> </ul> <h4 id="cargo-features">Cargo features</h4> <ul> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/3038">cargo: Add --all-features flag to cargo</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/3000">cargo: Add --message-format flag</a></li> </ul> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/stable/RELEASES.md#version-1130-2016-11-10">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h3 id="contributors-to-1-13-0">Contributors to 1.13.0</h3> <p>We had 155 individuals contribute to 1.13.0. Thank you so much!</p> <ul> <li>Aaron Gallagher</li> <li>Abhishek Kumar</li> <li>aclarry</li> <li>Adam Medziński</li> <li>Ahmed Charles</li> <li>Aleksey Kladov</li> <li>Alexander von Gluck IV</li> <li>Alexandre Oliveira</li> <li>Alex Burka</li> <li>Alex Crichton</li> <li>Amanieu d'Antras</li> <li>Amit Levy</li> <li>Andrea Corradi</li> <li>Andre Bogus</li> <li>Andrew Cann</li> <li>Andrew Cantino</li> <li>Andrew Lygin</li> <li>Andrew Paseltiner</li> <li>Andy Russell</li> <li>Ariel Ben-Yehuda</li> <li>arthurprs</li> <li>Ashley Williams</li> <li>athulappadan</li> <li>Austin Hicks</li> <li>bors</li> <li>Brian Anderson</li> <li>c4rlo</li> <li>Caleb Jones</li> <li>CensoredUsername</li> <li>cgswords</li> <li>changchun.fan</li> <li>Chiu-Hsiang Hsu</li> <li>Chris Stankus</li> <li>Christopher Serr</li> <li>Chris Wong</li> <li>clementmiao</li> <li>Cobrand</li> <li>Corey Farwell</li> <li>Cristi Cobzarenco</li> <li>crypto-universe</li> <li>dangcheng</li> <li>Daniele Baracchi</li> <li>DarkEld3r</li> <li>David Tolnay</li> <li>Dustin Bensing</li> <li>Eduard Burtescu</li> <li>Eduard-Mihai Burtescu</li> <li>Eitan Adler</li> <li>Erik Uggeldahl</li> <li>Esteban Küber</li> <li>Eugene Bulkin</li> <li>Eugene R Gonzalez</li> <li>Fabian Zaiser</li> <li>Federico Ravasio</li> <li>Felix S. Klock II</li> <li>Florian Gilcher</li> <li>Gavin Baker</li> <li>Georg Brandl</li> <li>ggomez</li> <li>Gianni Ciccarelli</li> <li>Guillaume Gomez</li> <li>Jacob</li> <li>jacobpadkins</li> <li>Jake Goldsborough</li> <li>Jake Goulding</li> <li>Jakob Demler</li> <li>James Duley</li> <li>James Miller</li> <li>Jared Roesch</li> <li>Jared Wyles</li> <li>Jeffrey Seyfried</li> <li>JessRudder</li> <li>Joe Neeman</li> <li>Johannes Löthberg</li> <li>John Firebaugh</li> <li>johnthagen</li> <li>Jonas Schievink</li> <li>Jonathan Turner</li> <li>Jorge Aparicio</li> <li>Joseph Dunne</li> <li>Josh Triplett</li> <li>Justin LeFebvre</li> <li>Keegan McAllister</li> <li>Keith Yeung</li> <li>Keunhong Lee</li> <li>king6cong</li> <li>Knight</li> <li>knight42</li> <li>Kylo Ginsberg</li> <li>Liigo</li> <li>Manish Goregaokar</li> <li>Mark-Simulacrum</li> <li>Matthew Piziak</li> <li>Matt Ickstadt</li> <li>mcarton</li> <li>Michael Layne</li> <li>Michael Woerister</li> <li>Mikhail Modin</li> <li>Mohit Agarwal</li> <li>Nazım Can Altınova</li> <li>Neil Williams</li> <li>Nicholas Nethercote</li> <li>Nick Cameron</li> <li>Nick Platt</li> <li>Niels Sascha Reedijk</li> <li>Nikita Baksalyar</li> <li>Niko Matsakis</li> <li>Oliver Middleton</li> <li>Oliver Schneider</li> <li>orbea</li> <li>Panashe M. Fundira</li> <li>Patrick Walton</li> <li>Paul Fanelli</li> <li>philipp</li> <li>Phil Ruffwind</li> <li>Piotr Jawniak</li> <li>pliniker</li> <li>QuietMisdreavus</li> <li>Rahul Sharma</li> <li>Richard Janis Goldschmidt</li> <li>Scott A Carr</li> <li>Scott Olson</li> <li>Sean McArthur</li> <li>Sebastian Ullrich</li> <li>Sébastien Marie</li> <li>Seo Sanghyeon</li> <li>Sergio Benitez</li> <li>Shyam Sundar B</li> <li>silenuss</li> <li>Simonas Kazlauskas</li> <li>Simon Sapin</li> <li>Srinivas Reddy Thatiparthy</li> <li>Stefan Schindler</li> <li>Stephan Hügel</li> <li>Steve Klabnik</li> <li>Steven Allen</li> <li>Steven Fackler</li> <li>Terry Sun</li> <li>Thomas Garcia</li> <li>Tim Neumann</li> <li>Tobias Bucher</li> <li>Tomasz Miąsko</li> <li>trixnz</li> <li>Tshepang Lekhonkhobe</li> <li>Ulrich Weigand</li> <li>Ulrik Sverdrup</li> <li>Vadim Chugunov</li> <li>Vadim Petrochenkov</li> <li>Vanja Cosic</li> <li>Vincent Esche</li> <li>Wesley Wiser</li> <li>William Lee</li> <li>Ximin Luo</li> <li>Yossi Konstantinovsky</li> <li>zjhmale</li> </ul> Announcing Rust 1.12.1 Thu, 20 Oct 2016 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-12-1/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-12-1/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce the latest version of Rust, 1.12.1. Rust is a systems programming language with a focus on reliability, performance, and concurrency.</p> <p>As always, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">install Rust 1.12.1</a> from the appropriate page on our website, or install via <a href="https://www.rustup.rs/">rustup</a> with <code>rustup update stable</code>.</p> <h3 id="what-s-in-1-12-1-stable">What's in 1.12.1 stable</h3> <p>Wait... one-point-twelve-point... one?</p> <p>In <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2016/09/29/Rust-1.12.html">the release announcement for 1.12</a> a few weeks ago, we said:</p> <blockquote> <p>The release of 1.12 might be one of the most significant Rust releases since 1.0.</p> </blockquote> <p>It was true. One of the biggest changes was turning on a large compiler refactoring, <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2016/04/19/MIR.html">MIR</a>, which re-architects the internals of the compiler. The overall process went like this:</p> <ul> <li>Initial MIR support landed in nightlies back in Rust 1.6.</li> <li>While work was being done, a flag, <code>--enable-orbit</code>, was added so that people working on the compiler could try it out.</li> <li>Back <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/28748">in October</a>, we would always attempt to build MIR, even though it was not being used.</li> <li>A flag was added, <code>-Z orbit</code>, to allow users on nightly to try and use MIR rather than the traditional compilation step ('trans').</li> <li>After substantial testing over months and months, for Rust 1.12, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/34096">we enabled MIR by default</a>.</li> <li>In Rust 1.13, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/35764">MIR will be the only option</a>.</li> </ul> <p>A change of this magnitude is huge, and important. So it's also important to do it right, and do it carefully. This is why this process took so long; we regularly tested the compiler against every crate on crates.io, we asked people to try out <code>-Z orbit</code> on their private code, and after six weeks of beta, no significant problems appeared. So we made the decision to keep it on by default in 1.12.</p> <p>But large changes still have an element of risk, even though we tried to reduce that risk as much as possible. And so, after release, 1.12 saw a fair number of regressions that we hadn't detected in our testing. Not all of them are directly MIR related, but when you change the compiler internals so much, it's bound to ripple outward through everything.</p> <h3 id="why-make-a-point-release">Why make a point release?</h3> <p>Now, given that we have a six-week release cycle, and we're halfway towards Rust 1.13, you may wonder why we're choosing to cut a patch version of Rust 1.12 rather than telling users to just wait for the next release. We have previously said something like &quot;point releases should only happen in extreme situations, such as a security vulnerability in the standard library.&quot;</p> <p>The Rust team cares deeply about the stability of Rust, and about our users' experience with it. We could have told you all to wait, but we want you to know how seriously we take this stuff. We think it's worth it to demonstrate our commitment to you by putting in the work of making a point release in this situation.</p> <p>Furthermore, given that this is not security related, it's a good time to practice actually cutting a point release. We've never done it before, and the release process is <a href="https://forge.rust-lang.org/release-process.html">semi-automated</a> but still not completely so. Having a point release in the world will also <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/37173#issuecomment-253938822">shake out any bugs</a> in dealing with point releases in other tooling as well, like <a href="https://www.rustup.rs/">rustup</a>. Making sure that this all goes smoothly and getting some practice going through the motions will be useful if we ever need to cut some sort of <em>emergency</em> point release due to a security advisory or anything else.</p> <p>This is the first Rust point release since <a href="https://mail.mozilla.org/pipermail/rust-dev/2012-July/002152.html">Rust 0.3.1</a>, all the way back in 2012, and marks 72 weeks since Rust 1.0, when we established our six week release cadence along with a commitment to aggressive stability guarantees. While we're disappointed that 1.12 had these regressions, we're really proud of Rust's stability and will to continue expanding our efforts to ensure that it's a platform you can rely on. We want Rust to be the most reliable programming platform in the world.</p> <h3 id="a-note-about-testing-on-beta">A note about testing on beta</h3> <p>One thing that you, as a user of Rust, can do to help us fix these issues sooner: test your code against the beta channel! Every beta release is a release candidate for the next stable release, so for the cost of an extra build in CI, you can help us know if there's going to be some sort of problem before it hits a stable release! It's really easy. For example, on <a href="https://travis-ci.org/">Travis</a>, you can use this as your <code>.travis.yml</code>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">language</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#c82829;">rust rust</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: - </span><span style="color:#718c00;">stable </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">- </span><span style="color:#718c00;">beta </span></pre> <p>And you'll test against both. Furthermore, if you'd like to make it so that any beta failure doesn't fail your own build, do this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">matrix</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#c82829;">allow_failures</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: - </span><span style="color:#c82829;">rust</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#718c00;">beta </span></pre> <p>The beta build may go red, but your build will stay green.</p> <p>Most other CI systems, such as <a href="https://www.appveyor.com/">AppVeyor</a>, should support <a href="https://www.appveyor.com/docs/build-configuration/#allow-failing-jobs">something similar</a>. Check the documentation for your specific continuous integration product for full details.</p> <h3 id="full-details">Full details</h3> <p>There were nine issues fixed in 1.12.1, and all of those fixes have been backported to 1.13 beta as well. </p> <ul> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/36381">ICE: 'rustc' panicked at 'assertion failed: concrete_substs.is_normalized_for_trans()' #36381</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/36856">Confusion with double negation and booleans</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/36875">rustc 1.12.0 fails with SIGSEGV in release mode (syn crate 0.8.0)</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/36924">Rustc 1.12.0 Windows build of <code>ethcore</code> crate fails with LLVM error</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/36926">1.12.0: High memory usage when linking in release mode with debug info</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/36936">Corrupted memory after updated to 1.12</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/37026">&quot;Let NullaryConstructor = something;&quot; causes internal compiler error: &quot;tried to overwrite interned AdtDef&quot;</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/37112">Fix ICE: inject bitcast if types mismatch for invokes/calls/stores</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/37153">debuginfo: Handle spread_arg case in MIR-trans in a more stable way.</a></li> </ul> <p>In addition, there were four more regressions that we decided not to include in 1.12.1 for various reasons, but we'll be working on fixing those as soon as possible as well.</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/36325">ICE, possibly related to associated types of associated types?</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/36799">Compilation of a crate using a large static map fails on latest i686-pc-windows-gnu Beta</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/37154">Regression: &quot;no method found&quot; error when calling same method twice, with HRTB impl</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/37109">ICE: fictitious type sizing_type_of</a></li> </ul> <p>You can see the full diff from 1.12.0 to 1.12.1 <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/37173">here</a>.</p> Announcing Rust 1.12 Thu, 29 Sep 2016 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-12/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-12/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce the latest version of Rust, 1.12. Rust is a systems programming language with the slogan &quot;fast, reliable, productive: pick three.&quot;</p> <p>As always, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">install Rust 1.12</a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1120-2016-09-29">detailed release notes for 1.12</a> on GitHub. 1361 patches were landed in this release.</p> <h3 id="what-s-in-1-12-stable">What's in 1.12 stable</h3> <p>The release of 1.12 might be one of the most significant Rust releases since 1.0. We have a lot to cover, but if you don't have time for that, here's a summary:</p> <p>The largest user-facing change in 1.12 stable is the new error message format emitted by <code>rustc</code>. We've <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2016/08/10/Shape-of-errors-to-come.html">previously talked</a> about this format and this is the first stable release where they are broadly available. These error messages are a result of the effort of many hours of <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/35233">volunteer effort</a> to design, test, and update every one of <code>rustc</code>s errors to the new format. We're excited to see what you think of them:</p> <p><img src="/images/2016-09-Rust-1.12/borrowck-error.png" alt="A new borrow-check error" /></p> <p>The largest internal change in this release is moving to a new compiler backend based on the new Rust <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2016/04/19/MIR.html">MIR</a>. While this feature does not result in anything user-visible today, it paves the way for a number of future compiler optimizations, and for some codebases it already results in improvements to compile times and reductions in code size.</p> <h4 id="overhauled-error-messages">Overhauled error messages</h4> <p>With 1.12 we're introducing a new error format which helps to surface a lot of the internal knowledge about why an error is occurring to you, the developer. It does this by putting your code front and center, highlighting the parts relevant to the error with annotations describing what went wrong.</p> <p>For example, in 1.11 if a implementation of a trait didn't match the trait declaration, you would see an error like the one below:</p> <p><img src="/images/2016-09-Rust-1.12/old-mismatched-trait-error.png" alt="An old mismatched trait error" /></p> <p>In the new error format we represent the error by instead showing the points in the code that matter the most. Here is the relevant line in the trait declaration, and the relevant line in the implementation, using labels to describe why they don't match:</p> <p><img src="/images/2016-09-Rust-1.12/mismatched-trait-error.png" alt="A new mismatched trait error" /></p> <p>Initially, this error design was built to aid in understanding borrow-checking errors, but we found, as with the error above, the format can be broadly applied to a wide variety of errors. If you would like to learn more about the design, check out the <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2016/08/10/Shape-of-errors-to-come.html">previous blog post on the subject</a>.</p> <p>Finally, you can also get these errors as JSON with a flag. Remember that error we showed above, at the start of the post? Here's an example of attempting to compile that code while passing the <code>--error-format=json</code> flag:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">rustc</span><span style="color:#4271ae;"> borrowck-assign-comp.rs</span><span style="color:#f5871f;"> --error-format</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">json </span><span style="color:#c82829;">{</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;message&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">:</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;cannot assign to `</span><span style="color:#c82829;">p.x</span><span style="color:#718c00;">` because it is borrowed&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">,</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;level&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">:</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;error&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">,</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;spans&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">:[{</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;file_name&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">:</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;borrowck-assign-comp.rs&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">,</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;byte_start&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">:562,</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;byte_end&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">:563,</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;line_start&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">:15,</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;line_end&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">:15,</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;column_start&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">:14,</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;column_end&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">:15,</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;is_primary&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">:false,</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;text&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">:[{</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;text&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">:</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot; let q = &amp;p;&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">,</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;highlight_start&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">:14,</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;highlight_end&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">:15</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">}</span><span style="color:#c82829;">],</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;label&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">:</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;borrow of `</span><span style="color:#c82829;">p.x</span><span style="color:#718c00;">` occurs here&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">,</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;suggested_replacement&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">:null,</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;expansion&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">:null</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">}</span><span style="color:#c82829;">],</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;label&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">:</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;assignment to borrowed `</span><span style="color:#c82829;">p.x</span><span style="color:#718c00;">` occurs here&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">,</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;suggested_replacement&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">:null,</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;expansion&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">:null</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">}</span><span style="color:#c82829;">],</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;children&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">:[],</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;rendered&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">:null</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span><span style="color:#c82829;">{</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;message&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">:</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;aborting due to previous error&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">,</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;code&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">:null,</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;level&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">:</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;error&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">,</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;spans&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">:[],</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;children&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">:[],</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;rendered&quot;</span><span style="color:#c82829;">:null</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p>We've actually elided a bit of this for brevity's sake, but you get the idea. This output is primarily for tooling; we are continuing to invest in supporting IDEs and other useful development tools. This output is a small part of that effort.</p> <h4 id="mir-code-generation">MIR code generation</h4> <p>The new Rust &quot;mid-level IR&quot;, usually called &quot;MIR&quot;, gives the compiler a simpler way to think about Rust code than its previous way of operating entirely on the Rust abstract syntax tree. It makes analysis and optimizations possible that have historically been difficult to implement correctly. The first of many upcoming changes to the compiler enabled by MIR is a rewrite of the pass that generates LLVM IR, what <code>rustc</code> calls &quot;translation&quot;, and after many months of effort the MIR-based backend has proved itself ready for prime-time.</p> <p>MIR exposes perfect information about the program's control flow, so the compiler knows exactly whether types are moved or not. This means that it knows statically whether or not the value's destructor needs to be run. In cases where a value may or may not be moved at the end of a scope, the compiler now simply uses a single bitflag on the stack, which is in turn easier for optimization passes in LLVM to reason about. The end result is less work for the compiler and less bloat at runtime. In addition, because MIR is a simpler 'language' than the full AST, it's also easier to implement compiler passes on, and easier to verify that they are correct.</p> <h4 id="other-improvements">Other improvements</h4> <ul> <li>Many minor improvements to the documentation.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/35060"><code>rustc</code> supports three new MUSL targets on ARM: <code>arm-unknown-linux-musleabi</code>, <code>arm-unknown-linux-musleabihf</code>, and <code>armv7-unknown-linux-musleabihf</code></a>. These targets produce statically-linked binaries. There are no binary release builds yet though.</li> <li>In error descriptions, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/35611">references</a> and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/35080">unknown numeric types</a> have more human-friendly errors.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/35594">The compiler can now be built against LLVM 3.9</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/35414">Test binaries now support a <code>--test-threads</code> argument to specify the number of threads used to run tests, and which acts the same as the <code>RUST_TEST_THREADS</code> environment variable</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/35405">The test runner now emits a warning when tests run over 60 seconds</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/34366">Rust releases now come with source packages that can be installed by rustup via <code>rustup component add rust-src</code></a>. The resulting source code can be used by tools and IDES, located in the sysroot under <code>lib/rustlib/src</code>.</li> </ul> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1120-2016-09-29">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h4 id="library-stabilizations">Library stabilizations</h4> <p>This release sees a number of small quality of life improvements for various types in the standard library:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/cell/struct.Cell.html#method.as_ptr"><code>Cell::as_ptr</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/cell/struct.RefCell.html#method.as_ptr"><code>RefCell::as_ptr</code></a></li> <li><code>IpAddr</code>, <code>Ipv4Addr</code>, and <code>Ipv6Addr</code> have a few new methods.</li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/collections/linked_list/struct.LinkedList.html#method.contains"><code>LinkedList</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/collections/vec_deque/struct.VecDeque.html#method.contains"><code>VecDeque</code></a> have a new <code>contains</code> method.</li> <li><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/iter/trait.Product.html"><code>iter::Product</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/iter/trait.Sum.html"><code>iter::Sum</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/34828"><code>Option</code> implements <code>From</code> for its contained type</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/35392"><code>Cell</code>, <code>RefCell</code> and <code>UnsafeCell</code> implement <code>From</code> for their contained type</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/35064"><code>Cow&lt;str&gt;</code> implements <code>FromIterator</code> for <code>char</code>, <code>&amp;str</code> and <code>String</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/34946">Sockets on Linux are correctly closed in subprocesses via <code>SOCK_CLOEXEC</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/34890"><code>String</code> implements <code>AddAssign</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/34599">Unicode definitions have been updated to 9.0</a></li> </ul> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1120-2016-09-29">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h4 id="cargo-features">Cargo features</h4> <p>The biggest feature added to Cargo this cycle is &quot;<a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/2759">workspaces</a>.&quot; Defined in <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/1525-cargo-workspace.md">RFC 1525</a>, workspaces allow a group of Rust packages to share the same <code>Cargo.lock</code> file. If you have a project that's split up into multiple packages, this makes it much easier to keep shared dependencies on a single version. To enable this feature, most multi-package projects need to add a single key, <code>[workspace]</code>, to their top-level <code>Cargo.toml</code>, but more complex setups may require more configuration.</p> <p>Another significant feature is the ability to <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/2857">override the source of a crate</a>. Using this with tools like <a href="https://github.com/alexcrichton/cargo-vendor">cargo-vendor</a> and <a href="https://github.com/alexcrichton/cargo-local-registry">cargo-local-registry</a> allow vendoring dependencies locally in a robust fashion. Eventually this support will be the foundation of supporting mirrors of <a href="https://crates.io/">crates.io</a> as well.</p> <p>There are some other improvements as well:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/2974">Speed up noop registry updates</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/2921">Add a <code>--lib</code> flag to <code>cargo new</code></a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/2909">Indicate the compilation profile after compiling</a></li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/2849">Add <code>--dry-run</code> to <code>cargo publish</code></a></li> </ul> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1120-2016-09-29">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h3 id="contributors-to-1-12">Contributors to 1.12</h3> <p>We had 176 individuals contribute to 1.12. Thank you so much!</p> <ul> <li>Aaron Gallagher</li> <li>abhi</li> <li>Adam Medziński</li> <li>Ahmed Charles</li> <li>Alan Somers</li> <li>Alexander Altman</li> <li>Alexander Merritt</li> <li>Alex Burka</li> <li>Alex Crichton</li> <li>Amanieu d'Antras</li> <li>Andrea Pretto</li> <li>Andre Bogus</li> <li>Andrew</li> <li>Andrew Cann</li> <li>Andrew Paseltiner</li> <li>Andrii Dmytrenko</li> <li>Antti Keränen</li> <li>Aravind Gollakota</li> <li>Ariel Ben-Yehuda</li> <li>Bastien Dejean</li> <li>Ben Boeckel</li> <li>Ben Stern</li> <li>bors</li> <li>Brendan Cully</li> <li>Brett Cannon</li> <li>Brian Anderson</li> <li>Bruno Tavares</li> <li>Cameron Hart</li> <li>Camille Roussel</li> <li>Cengiz Can</li> <li>CensoredUsername</li> <li>cgswords</li> <li>Chiu-Hsiang Hsu</li> <li>Chris Stankus</li> <li>Christian Poveda</li> <li>Christophe Vu-Brugier</li> <li>Clement Miao</li> <li>Corey Farwell</li> <li>CrLF0710</li> <li>crypto-universe</li> <li>Daniel Campbell</li> <li>David</li> <li>decauwsemaecker.glen@gmail.com</li> <li>Diggory Blake</li> <li>Dominik Boehi</li> <li>Doug Goldstein</li> <li>Dridi Boukelmoune</li> <li>Eduard Burtescu</li> <li>Eduard-Mihai Burtescu</li> <li>Evgeny Safronov</li> <li>Federico Ravasio</li> <li>Felix Rath</li> <li>Felix S. Kollasch</li> <li>Jonathan Creekmore</li> <li>Jonathan Giddy</li> <li>Jonathan Turner</li> <li>Jorge Aparicio</li> <li>José manuel Barroso Galindo</li> <li>Josh Stone</li> <li>Jupp Müller</li> <li>Kaivo Anastetiks</li> <li>kc1212</li> <li>Keith Yeung</li> <li>Knight</li> <li>Krzysztof Garczynski</li> <li>Loïc Damien</li> <li>Luke Hinds</li> <li>Luqman Aden</li> <li>m4b</li> <li>Manish Goregaokar</li> <li>Marco A L Barbosa</li> <li>Mark Buer</li> <li>Mark-Simulacrum</li> <li>Martin Pool</li> <li>Masood Malekghassemi</li> <li>Matthew Piziak</li> <li>Matthias Rabault</li> <li>Matt Horn</li> <li>mcarton</li> <li>M Farkas-Dyck</li> <li>Michael Gattozzi</li> <li>Michael Neumann</li> <li>Michael Rosenberg</li> <li>Michael Woerister</li> <li>Mike Hommey</li> <li>Mikhail Modin</li> <li>mitchmindtree</li> <li>mLuby</li> <li>Moritz Ulrich</li> <li>Murarth</li> <li>Nick Cameron</li> <li>Nick Massey</li> <li>Nikhil Shagrithaya</li> <li>Niko Matsakis</li> <li>Novotnik, Petr</li> <li>Oliver Forral</li> <li>Oliver Middleton</li> <li>Oliver Schneider</li> <li>Omer Sheikh</li> <li>Panashe M. Fundira</li> <li>Patrick McCann</li> <li>Paul Woolcock</li> <li>Peter C. Norton</li> <li>Phlogistic Fugu</li> <li>Pietro Albini</li> <li>Rahiel Kasim</li> <li>Rahul Sharma</li> <li>Robert Williamson</li> <li>Roy Brunton</li> <li>Ryan Scheel</li> <li>Ryan Scott</li> <li>saml</li> <li>Sam Payson</li> <li>Samuel Cormier-Iijima</li> <li>Scott A Carr</li> <li>Sean McArthur</li> <li>Sebastian Thiel</li> <li>Seo Sanghyeon</li> <li>Shantanu Raj</li> <li>ShyamSundarB</li> <li>silenuss</li> <li>Simonas Kazlauskas</li> <li>srdja</li> <li>Srinivas Reddy Thatiparthy</li> <li>Stefan Schindler</li> <li>Stephen Lazaro</li> <li>Steve Klabnik</li> <li>Steven Fackler</li> <li>Steven Walter</li> <li>Sylvestre Ledru</li> <li>Tamir Duberstein</li> <li>Terry Sun</li> <li>TheZoq2</li> <li>Thomas Garcia</li> <li>Tim Neumann</li> <li>Timon Van Overveldt</li> <li>Tobias Bucher</li> <li>Tomasz Miąsko</li> <li>trixnz</li> <li>Tshepang Lekhonkhobe</li> <li>ubsan</li> <li>Ulrik Sverdrup</li> <li>Vadim Chugunov</li> <li>Vadim Petrochenkov</li> <li>Vincent Prouillet</li> <li>Vladimir Vukicevic</li> <li>Wang Xuerui</li> <li>Wesley Wiser</li> <li>William Lee</li> <li>Ximin Luo</li> <li>Yojan Shrestha</li> <li>Yossi Konstantinovsky</li> <li>Zack M. Davis</li> <li>Zhen Zhang</li> <li>吴冉波</li> </ul> Incremental Compilation Thu, 08 Sep 2016 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/incremental/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/incremental/ <p>I remember when, during the 1.0 anniversary presentation at the <a href="https://air.mozilla.org/bay-area-rust-meetup-may-2016/">Bay Area Meetup</a>, Aaron Turon talked about Dropbox so far having been pretty happy with using Rust in production there. <em>The core team has been in touch with them regularly</em>, he said, <em>asking them, you know, what do you need? And their answer is always: faster compiles ...</em> To the seasoned Rust user it is no surprise that this solicited a knowing chuckle from the audience. Improving compile times has actually been a major development focus after Rust reached 1.0 -- although, up to this point, much of the work towards this goal has gone into laying <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2016/04/19/MIR.html">architectural foundations</a> within the compiler and we are only slowly beginning to see actual results.</p> <p>One of the projects that is building on these foundations, and that should help <strong>improve compile times</strong> a lot for typical workflows, is <strong>incremental compilation</strong>. Incremental compilation avoids redoing work when you recompile a crate, which will ultimately lead to a much faster edit-compile-debug cycle.</p> <p>Today we are announcing an <strong>alpha version</strong> of incremental compilation, which marks an important milestone in the development of the feature: For the first time since implementation started towards the end of last year, all of the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/1298-incremental-compilation.md">basic components</a> are in place, the bulk of the groundwork has been done. You can give it a try in the nightly version of the compiler:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">rustc -Zincremental=&lt;path&gt; ./main.rs </span></pre> <p>This will start the compiler in <strong>incremental mode</strong>, using whatever <code>&lt;path&gt;</code> you've provided as the incremental compilation cache directory. We are also working on a <a href="https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/incremental/#tool">cargo subcommand to make this smoother</a>, letting you just write <code>cargo incremental build</code>. Once things are working reliably, of course, incremental compilation will be available through the default <code>cargo build</code> command.</p> <p>With that being said, incremental compilation is <strong>not production-ready</strong> yet: You might see crashes, you might see cases where there is no actual reduction in compile times and, most importantly, we still have to write extensive regression tests that make sure that incrementally compiled programs are always correct — so don't use it anywhere yet where it really matters. Over the next few weeks and months, however, our focus will be on making the implementation rock-solid from a correctness point of view and you will see continuous, gradual improvements in the feature's efficiency, up to a point where it will be transformative to your development experience.</p> <p>This blog post will go through why and when incremental compilation is useful to begin with, how our implementation of it works, what its current development status is, and finally what's planned for the future and how you can contribute, should you be so inclined.</p> <h1 id="why-incremental-compilation-in-the-first-place">Why Incremental Compilation in the First Place?</h1> <p>Much of a programmer's time is spent in an <strong>edit-compile-debug</strong> workflow:</p> <ul> <li>you make a <strong>small change</strong> (often in a single module or even function),</li> <li>you let the compiler <strong>translate the code into a binary</strong>, and finally</li> <li>you <strong>run the program</strong> or a bunch of unit tests in order to see results of the change.</li> </ul> <p>After that it's back to step one, making the next small change informed by the knowledge gained in the previous iteration. This essential feedback loop is at the core of our daily work. We want the time being stalled while waiting for the compiler to produce an executable program to be as short as possible — ideally short enough as not to warrant a time-consuming and stress-inducing mental context switch: You want to be able to keep working, stay in the zone. After all, there is only so much <a href="https://xkcd.com/303/">regressive fun</a> to be had while <code>rustc</code> bootstraps.</p> <p>Incremental compilation is a way of <strong>exploiting</strong> the fact that little changes between compiles during the regular programming workflow: Many, if not most, of the changes done in between two compilation sessions only have local impact on the machine code in the output binary, while the rest of the program, same as at the source level, will end up exactly the same, bit for bit. Incremental compilation aims at retaining as much of those unchanged parts as possible while redoing only that amount of work that actually <em>must</em> be redone.</p> <h1 id="how-do-you-make-something-incremental">How Do You Make Something &quot;Incremental&quot;?</h1> <p>We have already heard that computing something incrementally means updating only those parts of the computation's output that need to be adapted in response to a given change in the computation's inputs. One basic strategy we can employ to achieve this is to view one big computation (like compiling a program) as a <strong>composite</strong> of many smaller, interrelated computations that build up on each other. Each of those smaller computations will yield an <strong>intermediate result</strong> that can be <strong>cached</strong> and hopefully <strong>re-used</strong> in a later iteration, sparing us the need to re-compute that particular intermediate result again.</p> <p>Let's take a look at a simple example from algebra to make things more concrete. Let's see what it means to evaluate an expression of the form <code>a+b×c</code> incrementally. This will involve evaluating the expression once with one set of values for <code>a</code>, <code>b</code>, and <code>c</code>, and then evaluating it a second time with a different value for <code>a</code>. For the first time around, <code>a</code> will be <code>1</code>, <code>b</code> will be <code>2</code>, and <code>c</code> will be <code>3</code>:</p> <!-- a+b×c=7 / \ / b×c=6 / / \ a=1 b=2 c=3 --> <p><img src="/images/2016-08-Incremental/algebra-initial.svg" alt="Initial Computation of a+b×c" /></p> <p>Assume that we &quot;saved&quot; the intermediate results at each step, that is, we remember somewhere that <code>b×c</code> is <code>6</code> and <code>a+b×c</code> is <code>7</code>. Now, in the second round, we want to know what <code>a+b×c</code> is if we change the value of <code>a</code> to <code>4</code>. When we recompute the value of the expression, however, we see that we already know that <code>b×c = 6</code>, so we don't have to perform that computation again, and can rather skip directly to <code>(a = 4) + (b×c = 6)</code>. We thus have computed the value of our expression in just one step instead of two, sparing us an entire, tedious multiplication.</p> <!-- a+b×c=10 / \ / b×c=6 / / \ a=4 b=2 c=3 --> <p><img src="/images/2016-08-Incremental/algebra-update.svg" alt="Updating the Computation" /></p> <p>Let's see how this scheme translates to the compiler.</p> <h1 id="an-incremental-compiler">An Incremental Compiler</h1> <p>The way we chose to implement incrementality in the Rust compiler is straightforward: An incremental compilation session follows exactly the same steps in the same order as a batch compilation session. However, when control flow reaches a point where it is about to compute some non-trivial intermediate result, it will try to load that result from the incremental compilation cache on disk instead. If there is a valid entry in the cache, the compiler can just skip computing that particular piece of data. Let's take a look at a (simplified) overview of the different compilation phases and the intermediate results they produce:</p> <!-- * Diagram: compilation phases and their intermediate results AST type info object MIR code binary A A A A T T T M M M O O O O A A A A T T T M M M O O O O B A A A A T T T M M M O O O O >===========>===============>===========>===========> parse analysis codegen linking --> <p><img src="/images/2016-08-Incremental/compiler-phases.svg" alt="Compiler Phases and their By-Products" /></p> <p>First the compiler will parse the source code into an abstract syntax tree (AST). The AST then goes through the analysis phase which produces type information and the <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2016/04/19/MIR.html">MIR</a> for each function. After that, if analysis did not find any errors, the codegen phase will transform the MIR version of the program into its machine code version, producing one object file per source-level module. In the last step all the object files get linked together into the final output binary which may be a library or an executable.</p> <p>Comparing that with our algebra example from above, the pieces of AST correspond to <code>a</code>, <code>b</code>, and <code>c</code>, that is, they are the <strong>inputs</strong> to our incremental computation and they determine what needs to be updated as we make our way through the compilation process. The pieces of type information and MIR and the object files, on the other hand, are our <strong>intermediate results</strong>, that is, they correspond to the incremental computation cache entries we stored for <code>b×c</code> and <code>a+b×c</code>. Where a cache entry looks like <code>b×c = 6</code> in the algebra example, it would look something like <code>translate_to_obj_file(mir1, mir2, mir3) = &lt;bits of the obj-file&gt;</code> in the case of the compiler.</p> <p>So, this seems pretty simple so far: Instead of computing something a second time, just load the value from the cache. Things get tricky though when we need to <strong>find out if</strong> it's actually valid to <strong>use a value from the cache</strong> or if we have to <strong>re-compute</strong> it because of some changed input.</p> <h1 id="dependency-graphs">Dependency Graphs</h1> <p>There is a formal method that can be used to model a computation's intermediate results and their individual &quot;up-to-dateness&quot; in a straightforward way: <strong>dependency graphs</strong>. It looks like this: Each input and each <strong>intermediate result</strong> is represented as a <strong>node</strong> in a directed graph. The <strong>edges</strong> in the graph, on the other hand, represent which intermediate result or input can have an <strong>influence</strong> on some other intermediate result.</p> <!-- edited out More formally, let `v` be some intermediate result and `N(v)` be the dependency graph node representing `v` in the graph. Further, let `xᵢ` be the intermediate results and inputs that have to be **read** when computing `v` and let `N(xᵢ)` be their representing nodes. Then the dependency graph will contain the edges `N(v) → N(xᵢ)` for all `i`. In other words, each edge records a dependency of one intermediate result on another. --> <p>Let's go back to our algebra example to see what this looks like in practice:</p> <!-- a+b×c / \ / b×c / / \ a b c --> <p><img src="/images/2016-08-Incremental/algebra-dep-graph.svg" alt="Dependency Graph of a+b×c" /></p> <p>As you can see, we have nodes for the inputs <code>a</code>, <code>b</code>, and <code>c</code>, and nodes for the intermediate results <code>b×c</code> and <code>a+b×c</code>. The edges should come as no surprise: There is one edge from <code>b×c</code> to <code>b</code> and one to <code>c</code> because those are the values we need to read when computing <code>b×c</code>. For <code>a+b×c</code> it's exactly the same. Note, by the way, that the above graph is a tree just because the computation it models has the form of a tree. In general, dependency graphs are <strong>directed acyclic graphs</strong>, as would be the case if we would add another intermediate result <code>b×c+c</code> to our computation:</p> <!-- a+b×c b×c+c / \ / | / b×c | / / \ / a b c --> <p><img src="/images/2016-08-Incremental/algebra-dep-graph-dag.svg" alt="Example of a non-tree Dependency Graph" /></p> <p>What makes this data structure really useful is that we can ask it questions of the form &quot;if X has changed, is Y still up-to-date?&quot;. We just take the node representing <code>Y</code> and collect all the inputs <code>Y</code> depends on by transitively following all edges originating from <code>Y</code>. If any of those inputs has changed, the value we have cached for <code>Y</code> cannot be relied on anymore.</p> <h1 id="dependency-tracking-in-the-compiler">Dependency Tracking in the Compiler</h1> <p>When compiling in incremental mode, we always build the dependency graph of the produced data: every time, some piece of data is written (like an object file), we record which other pieces of data we are accessing while doing so.</p> <p>The emphasis is on <strong>recording</strong> here. At any point in time the compiler keeps track of which piece of data it is currently working on (it does so in the background in thread-local memory). This is the currently <strong>active node</strong> of the dependency graph. Conversely, the data that needs to be <strong>read</strong> to compute the value of the active node is also tracked: it usually already resides in some kind container (e.g. a hash table) that requires invoking a lookup method to access a specific entry. We make good use of this fact by making these <strong>lookup methods transparently create edges</strong> in the dependency graph: whenever an entry is accessed, we know that it is being read and we know what it is being read <em>for</em> (the currently active node). This gives us both ends of the dependency edge and we can simply add it to the graph. At the end of the compilation sessions we have all our data nicely linked up, mostly automatically:</p> <!-- AST type info object MIR code binary A A A A T T T M M M O O O O A A A A T T T M M M O O O O B A A A A T T T M M M O O O O >===========>===============>===========>===========> parse analysis codegen linking --> <p><img src="/images/2016-08-Incremental/compiler-dep-graph.svg" alt="Dependency Graph of Compilation Data" /></p> <p>This dependency graph is then stored in the incremental compilation cache directory along with the cache entries it describes.</p> <p>At the beginning of a subsequent compilation session, we detect which inputs (=AST nodes) have changed by comparing them to the previous version. Given the graph and the set of changed inputs, we can easily find all cache entries that are not up-to-date anymore and just remove them from the cache:</p> <!-- AST type info object MIR code binary A _ A _ _ _ T M _ _ O _ O _ _ A A A T _ T _ _ M O _ _ _ _ A A _ A T _ _ M _ M O O _ _ >===========>===============>===========>===========> parse analysis codegen linking --> <p><img src="/images/2016-08-Incremental/compiler-cache-purge.svg" alt="Using the Dependency Graph to Validate the Incremental Compilation Cache" /></p> <p>Anything that has survived this cache validation phase can safely be re-used during the current compilation session.</p> <p>There are a few benefits to the <strong>automated dependency tracking</strong> approach we are employing. Since it is built into the compiler's internal APIs, it will stay up-to-date with changes to the compiler, and it is hard to accidentally forget about. And if one still forgets using it correctly (e.g. by not declaring the correct <em>active node</em> in some place) then the result is an overly <strong>conservative, but still &quot;correct&quot;</strong> dependency graph: It will negatively impact the re-use ratio but it will not lead to incorrectly re-using some outdated piece of data.</p> <p>Another aspect is that the system does not try to predict or compute what the dependency graph is going to look like, it just keeps track. A large part of our (yet to be written) <strong>regression tests</strong>, on the other hand, <em>will</em> give a description of what the dependency graph for a given program ought to look like. This makes sure that the actual graph and the reference graph are arrived at via <strong>different methods</strong>, reducing the risk that both the compiler and the test case agree on the same, yet wrong, value.</p> <h1 id="faster-up-to-15-or-more">&quot;Faster! Up to 15% or More.&quot;<a href="https://xkcd.com/870/">*</a></h1> <p>Let's take a look at some of the implications of what we've learned so far:</p> <ul> <li>The dependency graph reflects the actual dependencies between parts of the source code and parts of the output binary.</li> <li>If there is some input node that is reachable from many intermediate results, e.g. a central data type that is used in almost every function, then changing the definition of that data type will mean that everything has to be compiled from scratch, there's no way around it.</li> </ul> <p>In other words, the effectiveness of incremental compilation is very sensitive to the structure of the program being compiled and the change being made. Changing a single character in the source code might very well invalidate the whole incremental compilation cache. Usually though, this kind of change is a rare case and most of the time only a small portion of the program has to be recompiled.</p> <h1 id="the-current-status-of-the-implementation">The Current Status of the Implementation</h1> <p>For the first spike implementation of incremental compilation, what we call the alpha version now, we chose to focus on caching object files. Why did we do that? Let's take a look at the compilation phases again and especially at how much time is spent in each one on average:</p> <!-- AST type info object MIR code binary A A A A T T T M M M O O O O A A A A T T T M M M O O O O B A A A A T T T M M M O O O O >===========>===============>===========>===========> parse analysis codegen linking optimize TIME: 5% 20% **65%** 10% --> <p><img src="/images/2016-08-Incremental/compiler-phases-cost.svg" alt="Relative Cost of Compilation Phases" /></p> <p>As you can see, the Rust compiler spends most of its time in the optimization and codegen passes. Consequently, if this phase can be skipped at least for part of a code base, this is where the biggest impact on compile times can be achieved.</p> <p>With that in mind, we can also give an <strong>upper bound</strong> on how much time this initial version of incremental compilation can save: If the compiler spends X seconds optimizing when compiling your crate, then incremental compilation will reduce compile times at most by those X seconds.</p> <p>Another area that has a large influence on the actual effectiveness of the alpha version is <strong>dependency tracking granularity</strong>: It's up to us how fine-grained we make our dependency graphs, and the current implementation makes it rather coarse in places. For example, the dependency graph <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/36349">only knows a single node for all methods in an <code>impl</code></a>. As a consequence, the compiler will consider <em>all</em> methods of that <code>impl</code> as changed if just one of them is changed. This of course will mean that more code will be re-compiled than is strictly necessary.</p> <h1 id="performance-numbers">Performance Numbers</h1> <p>Here are some numbers of how the current implementation fares in various situations. First let's take a look at the best case scenario where a 100% of a crate's object files can be re-used. This might occur when changing one crate in a multi-crate project and downstream crates need to be rebuilt but are not really affected.</p> <p><img src="/images/2016-08-Incremental/perf-full-re-use.svg" alt="Normalized Incremental Compilation Build Times" /></p> <p>As you can see, compiling a crate for the first time in incremental mode can be slower than compiling it in non-incremental mode. This is because the dependency tracking incurs some additional cost when activated. Note that compiling incrementally can also be faster (as in the case of the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/regex">regex</a> crate). This is because incremental compilation splits the code into smaller optimization units than a regular compilation session, resulting in less time optimizing, but also in less efficient runtime code.</p> <p>The last column shows the amount of time a rebuild of the crate takes when nothing has actually changed. For crates where the compiler spends a lot of time optimizing, like <a href="https://github.com/serde-rs/syntex/tree/master/syntex_syntax">syntex-syntax</a> or <code>regex</code>, the gain can be substantial: The incremental rebuild only takes about 22% of the time a full rebuild would need for <code>syntex-syntax</code>, only 16% for <code>regex</code>, and less than 10% for the <a href="https://github.com/alexcrichton/futures-rs/blob/master/tests/all.rs">all.rs test case</a> of the <a href="https://github.com/alexcrichton/futures-rs">futures-rs</a> crate.</p> <p>On the other hand, for a crate like the <code>futures-rs</code> library that results in little machine code when being compiled, the current version of incremental compilation makes little difference: It's only 3% faster than compiling from scratch.</p> <p>The next graph shows which impact various changes made to the <code>regex</code> crate have on incremental rebuild times:</p> <p><img src="/images/2016-08-Incremental/perf-changes.svg" alt="Build Times After Specific Changes" /></p> <p>The numbers show that the effectiveness of incremental compilation indeed depends a lot on the type of change applied to the code. For changes with very local effect we can get close to optimal re-use (as in the case of <code>Error::cause()</code>, or <code>dfa::write_vari32()</code>). If we change something that has an impact on many places, like <code>Compiler::new()</code>, we might not see a noticeable reduction in compile times. But again, be aware that these measurements are from the current state of the implementation. They do not reflect the full potential of the feature.</p> <h1 id="future-plans">Future Plans</h1> <p>The alpha version represents a minimal end-to-end implementation of incremental compilation for the Rust compiler, so there is lots of room for improvement. The section on the current status already laid out the two major axes along which we will pursue increased efficiency:</p> <ul> <li> <p><strong>Cache more</strong> intermediate results, like MIR and type information, which will allow the compiler to skip more and more steps.</p> </li> <li> <p>Make <strong>dependency tracking more precise</strong>, so that the compiler encounters fewer false positives during cache invalidation.</p> </li> </ul> <p>Improvements in both of these directions will make incremental compilation more effective as the implementation matures.</p> <p>In terms of correctness, we tried to err on the side of caution from the get-go, rather making the compiler recompute something if we were not sure if our dependency tracking did the right thing, but there is still more that can be done.</p> <ul> <li> <p>We want to have many <strong>more auto-tests</strong> that make sure that various basic components of the system <strong>don't regress</strong>. This is an area where interested people can start contributing with relative ease, since one only needs to understand the Rust language and the test framework, but not the more complicated innards of the compiler's implementation. If you are interested in jumping in, head on over to the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/36350">tracking issue</a> on GitHub and leave a comment!</p> </li> <li> <p><a name="tool"></a> We are working on the <a href="https://github.com/nikomatsakis/cargo-incremental"><em>cargo incremental</em></a> tool (implemented as a Cargo subcommand for hassle-free installation and usage) that will walk a projects git history, compiling successive versions of the source code and <strong>collecting data</strong> on the <strong>efficiency</strong> and <strong>correctness</strong> of incremental versus regular compilation. If you're interested in helping out, consider yourself invited to either hack on the tool itself or downloading and running it on a project of yours. The <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/community.html">#rustc channel on IRC</a> is currently the best place to get further information regarding this.</p> </li> </ul> <p>Thanks to everyone in the community who has contributed directly or indirectly to incremental compilation so far! If you are interested in tackling a specific implementation problem, look for <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&amp;q=is%3Aopen%20is%3Aissue%20label%3AA-incr-comp%20">issues tagged with A-incr-comp</a> or ask around in the <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/community.html">#rustc channel on IRC</a>.</p> Announcing Rust 1.11 Thu, 18 Aug 2016 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-11/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-11/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce the latest version of Rust, 1.11. Rust is a systems programming language focused on safety, speed, and concurrency.</p> <p>As always, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">install Rust 1.11</a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1110-2016-08-18">detailed release notes for 1.11</a> on GitHub. 1109 patches were landed in this release.</p> <h3 id="what-s-in-1-11-stable">What's in 1.11 stable</h3> <p>Much of the work that went into 1.11 was with regards to compiler internals that are not yet stable. We're excited about features like <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/34096">MIR becoming the default</a> and the beginnings of <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/34956">incremental compilation</a>, and the 1.11 release has laid the groundwork.</p> <p>As for user-facing changes, <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2016/07/07/Rust-1.10.html">last release</a>, we talked about the new <code>cdylib</code> crate type.</p> <blockquote> <p>The existing dylib dynamic library format will now be used solely for writing a dynamic library to be used within a Rust project, while cdylibs will be used when compiling Rust code as a dynamic library to be embedded in another language. With the 1.10 release, cdylibs are supported by the compiler, but not yet in Cargo. This format was defined in RFC 1510.</p> </blockquote> <p>Well, in Rust 1.11, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/2741">support for cdylibs has landed in Cargo</a>! By adding this to your <code>Cargo.toml</code>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#c82829;">crate-type </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= [</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;cdylib&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span></pre> <p>You'll get one built.</p> <p>In the standard library, the default hashing function <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/33940">was changed</a>, from SipHash 2-4 to SipHash 1-3. We have been thinking about this for a long time, as far back as the original decision to go with <code>2-4</code>:</p> <blockquote> <p>we proposed SipHash-2-4 as a (strong) PRF/MAC, and so far no attack whatsoever has been found, although many competent people tried to break it. However, fewer rounds may be sufficient and I would be very surprised if SipHash-1-3 introduced weaknesses for hash tables.</p> </blockquote> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1110-2016-08-18">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h4 id="library-stabilizations">Library stabilizations</h4> <ul> <li>The <code>append</code> method was added to <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/collections/binary_heap/struct.BinaryHeap.html#method.append"><code>BinaryHeap</code></a>, <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/collections/btree_map/struct.BTreeMap.html#method.append"><code>BTreeMap</code></a>, and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/collections/btree_set/struct.BTreeSet.html#method.append"><code>BTreeSet</code></a>. In addition, <code>split_off</code> was added to <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/collections/btree_map/struct.BTreeMap.html#method.split_off"><code>BTreeMap</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/collections/btree_set/struct.BTreeSet.html#method.split_off"><code>BTreeSet::split_off</code></a>.</li> <li>The <code>to_degrees</code> and <code>to_radians</code> methods were on the <code>f32</code> and <code>f64</code> types in <code>libstd</code>, but they are now in <code>libcore</code> as well.</li> <li><code>Iterator</code> has two new methods: <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/iter/trait.Iterator.html#method.sum"><code>sum</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/iter/trait.Iterator.html#method.sum"><code>product</code></a></li> <li>Both <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/cell/struct.Cell.html#method.get_mut"><code>Cell</code></a> and <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/cell/struct.RefCell.html#method.get_mut"><code>RefCell</code></a> gained <code>get_mut</code>.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/33976"><code>assert_eq!</code> accepts a custom error message, like <code>assert!</code> does</a>.</li> <li>The main thread <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/33803">is now called &quot;main&quot; instead of &quot;&lt;main&gt;&quot;</a>.</li> </ul> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1110-2016-08-18">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h4 id="cargo-features">Cargo features</h4> <ul> <li>Cargo <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/2804">added color support for Windows consoles</a>, and you can now <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/2739">configure the colors of stderr as well as stdout</a>.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/2630">Build scripts can now emit warnings</a>.</li> <li>As mentioned above, support was added <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/2741">for the cdylib crate type</a>.</li> <li>Cargo now <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/2781">prevents publishing crates when files are dirty</a>.</li> </ul> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1110-2016-08-18">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h3 id="contributors-to-1-11">Contributors to 1.11</h3> <p>We had 126 individuals contribute to 1.11. Thank you so much!</p> <ul> <li>Aaklo Xu</li> <li>Aaronepower</li> <li>Aleksey Kladov</li> <li>Alexander Polyakov</li> <li>Alexander Stocko</li> <li>Alex Burka</li> <li>Alex Crichton</li> <li>Alex Ozdemir</li> <li>Alfie John</li> <li>Amanieu d'Antras</li> <li>Andrea Canciani</li> <li>Andrew Brinker</li> <li>Andrew Paseltiner</li> <li>Andrey Tonkih</li> <li>Andy Russell</li> <li>Ariel Ben-Yehuda</li> <li>bors</li> <li>Brian Anderson</li> <li>Carlo Teubner</li> <li>Carol (Nichols || Goulding)</li> <li>CensoredUsername</li> <li>cgswords</li> <li>cheercroaker</li> <li>Chris Krycho</li> <li>Chris Tomlinson</li> <li>Corey Farwell</li> <li>Cristian Oliveira</li> <li>Daan Sprenkels</li> <li>Daniel Firth</li> <li>diwic</li> <li>Eduard Burtescu</li> <li>Eduard-Mihai Burtescu</li> <li>Emilio Cobos Álvarez</li> <li>Erick Tryzelaar</li> <li>Esteban Küber</li> <li>Fabian Vogt</li> <li>Felix S. Klock II</li> <li>flo-l</li> <li>Florian Berger</li> <li>Frank McSherry</li> <li>Georg Brandl</li> <li>ggomez</li> <li>Gleb Kozyrev</li> <li>Guillaume Gomez</li> <li>Hendrik Sollich</li> <li>Horace Abenga</li> <li>Huon Wilson</li> <li>Ivan Shapovalov</li> <li>Jack O'Connor</li> <li>Jacob Clark</li> <li>Jake Goulding</li> <li>Jakob Demler</li> <li>James Alan Preiss</li> <li>James Lucas</li> <li>James Miller</li> <li>Jamey Sharp</li> <li>Jeffrey Seyfried</li> <li>Joachim Viide</li> <li>John Ericson</li> <li>Jonas Schievink</li> <li>Jonathan L</li> <li>Jonathan Price</li> <li>Jonathan Turner</li> <li>Joseph Dunne</li> <li>Josh Stone</li> <li>Jupp Müller</li> <li>Kamal Marhubi</li> <li>kennytm</li> <li>Léo Testard</li> <li>Liigo Zhuang</li> <li>Loïc Damien</li> <li>Luqman Aden</li> <li>Manish Goregaokar</li> <li>Mark Côté</li> <li>marudor</li> <li>Masood Malekghassemi</li> <li>Mathieu De Coster</li> <li>Matt Kraai</li> <li>Mátyás Mustoha</li> <li>M Farkas-Dyck</li> <li>Michael Necio</li> <li>Michael Rosenberg</li> <li>Michael Woerister</li> <li>Mike Hommey</li> <li>Mitsunori Komatsu</li> <li>Morten H. Solvang</li> <li>Ms2ger</li> <li>Nathan Moos</li> <li>Nick Cameron</li> <li>Nick Hamann</li> <li>Nikhil Shagrithaya</li> <li>Niko Matsakis</li> <li>Oliver Middleton</li> <li>Oliver Schneider</li> <li>Paul Jarrett</li> <li>Pavel Pravosud</li> <li>Peter Atashian</li> <li>Peter Landoll</li> <li>petevine</li> <li>Reeze Xia</li> <li>Scott A Carr</li> <li>Sean McArthur</li> <li>Sebastian Thiel</li> <li>Seo Sanghyeon</li> <li>Simonas Kazlauskas</li> <li>Srinivas Reddy Thatiparthy</li> <li>Stefan Schindler</li> <li>Steve Klabnik</li> <li>Steven Allen</li> <li>Steven Burns</li> <li>Tamir Bahar</li> <li>Tatsuya Kawano</li> <li>Ted Mielczarek</li> <li>Tim Neumann</li> <li>Tobias Bucher</li> <li>Tshepang Lekhonkhobe</li> <li>Ty Coghlan</li> <li>Ulrik Sverdrup</li> <li>Vadim Petrochenkov</li> <li>Vincent Esche</li> <li>Wangshan Lu</li> <li>Will Crichton</li> <li>Without Boats</li> <li>Wojciech Nawrocki</li> <li>Zack M. Davis</li> <li>吴冉波</li> </ul> Shape of errors to come Wed, 10 Aug 2016 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/shape-of-errors-to-come/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/shape-of-errors-to-come/ <p>There are changes afoot in the Rust world. If you've tried out the latest nightly, you'll notice something is <em>a little different</em>. For the past few months we've been working on new way of reporting errors that's easier to read and understand. This is part of an on-going campaign to improve Rust's usability across the board. We mentioned ways to help us <a href="http://www.jonathanturner.org/2016/08/helping-out-with-rust-errors.html">make the transition</a> to the new errors, and already many people have jumped in (and thank you to those volunteers!)</p> <p>Let's dive in and see what's changed. We'll start with a simple example:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">borrow_same_field_twice_mut_mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> foo </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">make_foo</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(); </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> bar1 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= &amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> foo.bar1; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> _bar2 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= &amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> foo.bar1; </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">*</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">bar1; } </span></pre> <p>Here we make the error of mutably borrowing the same value twice. This is a classic error in Rust. Sure enough, the error the previous compiler gave us says pretty much that:</p> <p><img src="/images/2016-08-09-Errors/old_errors.png" alt="Picture of old error style" /></p> <p>The problem though is that it takes a few seconds to look at the message, orient yourself, and find the critical pieces. This time loss adds up. What if, instead, we cleared away everything that slows down how you read the error message?</p> <img src="/images/2016-08-09-Errors/new_errors.png" width="500" /> <p>This is the new error format. It's designed around the fundamental observation that errors should <strong>focus on the code you wrote</strong>. By doing so, you can much more easily see the context of what is going on.</p> <h1 id="design">Design</h1> <p>The key insight is putting your source code front and center - everything you see in the output builds on <em>your</em> code. By using the code you wrote as the context, we give you an easy way to know at a glance where the issue is occurring.</p> <p><img src="/images/2016-08-09-Errors/new_errors2.png" alt="Picture of new constant eval error" /></p> <p><em>Constant evaluation errors</em></p> <p>Next, once we know the location, we need to explain what is going wrong. We do this by labeling points of interest in the code that helped explain the error. The most obvious place to begin labeling is where the error has occurred. It's the &quot;what&quot; of the error.</p> <p>In this example, you can see how we use these primary labels. With them, your eyes can see both the problematic code, and a few words about the problem. Since this is the most important place to see first, we give them a bold red look with a characteristic <code>^^^</code> underline. You'll notice in the example that the combination allows you to quickly spot the error and understand what's going wrong.</p> <p><img src="/images/2016-08-09-Errors/new_errors3.png" alt="Picture of new trait mismatch" /></p> <p><em>Mismatch with trait requirement error</em></p> <p>The source of the error is not the only point of interest. There are often other points of interest that help describe &quot;why&quot; an error is occurring. By reading these secondary labels, you can understand better what is going wrong. These labels are shown in the same order they appear in your code, again, to ensure you're always able to, at a glance, understand where you are.</p> <p>In this example, secondary labels show the original requirement from the trait, so you can see it at the same time and compare the requirement and implementation for yourself.</p> <p>Primary and secondary labels work together to tell a story about what went wrong. With Rust's big focus on the borrow-checker and memory safety, users may see unfamiliar concepts when they encounter one of these errors. These labels help to walk them through how even unfamiliar errors, like borrow errors, occur.</p> <p><img src="/images/2016-08-09-Errors/new_errors4.png" alt="Picture of new type name not found" /></p> <p><em>Name not in scope, with suggestions</em></p> <p>Sometimes there's too much information to fit on a label, so the new format also supports attaching additional notes.
