Just like the previous error format, the new format supports warnings, suggestions, hints, and more.</p> <h1 id="extended-error-messages">Extended error messages</h1> <p>Once we updated the error message format, we looked for other areas we could apply the lessons we'd learned. The clear winner here were the <code>--explain</code> messages. As the name implies, the <code>--explain</code> feature allows developers to explore unfamiliar error messages with longer, more verbose, explanations.</p> <p>Today, when you can call <code>--explain</code>, you pass an error code. The compiler then prints out an extended message that goes into more detail about how errors of that form occur:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">rustc --explain E0200 Unsafe traits must have unsafe implementations. This error occurs when an implementation for an unsafe trait isn&#39;t marked as unsafe. This may be resolved by marking the unsafe implementation as unsafe. struct Foo; unsafe trait Bar { } // this won&#39;t compile because Bar is unsafe and impl isn&#39;t unsafe impl Bar for Foo { } // this will compile unsafe impl Bar for Foo { } </span></pre> <p>This has been a great way to help bridge between an error and learning an unfamiliar concept in Rust.</p> <p>While this message is helpful, it uses a general example that may not be related to your code. Taking a page from the error message work, we'll be updating the explain messages to focus on your code. For example, taking the borrow-checker error we started with, we might have an extended error message that looks like:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">error[E0499]: cannot borrow `foo.bar1` as mutable more than once at a time --&gt; src/test/compile-fail/borrowck/borrowck-borrow-from-owned-ptr.rs:29:22 The borrow checker detected that `foo.bar1` was borrowed multiple times as a mutable value. In Rust, this can not be done safely because there may be multiple owners of the value who may write to it at the same time. If this happens in parallel, the resulting value may be in an unknown state. Because this is unsafe, Rust disallows having multiple owners of the same mutable value. This is the first time `foo.bar1` is borrowed mutably. 28 | let bar1 = &amp;mut foo.bar1; | -------- And this is the second time `foo.bar1` is borrowed mutably. This is where the error occurs. 29 | let _bar2 = &amp;mut foo.bar1; | ^^^^^^^^ Note that the first borrow of `foo.bar1` continues until the borrow is released. During this time, no additional borrows can occur. This first borrow ends here: 31 | } | - After the first borrow has ended you are able to borrow it again. To fix this issue, if you need to borrow a value as mutable more than once, ensure that the span of time they are borrowed do not overlap. </span></pre> <p>In the above, you see a possible output from this new templated-style. Those of you familiar with the <a href="http://elm-lang.org/blog/compiler-errors-for-humans">Elm</a> style may recognize that the updated <code>--explain</code> messages draw heavy inspiration from the Elm approach.</p> <p>Currently, this format is still under design and development. If you'd like to help us shape what extended errors looks like, come jump into the #rust-cli channel on irc.mozilla.org.</p> <h1 id="i-want-to-help">I want to help!</h1> <p>Great! We love the enthusiasm. There's <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/35233">a lot to do</a>, and a <a href="http://www.jonathanturner.org/2016/08/helping-out-with-rust-errors.html">lot of skills</a> that could help us in different ways. Whether you're good at unit tests, writing docs, writing code, or working on designs, there are places to jump in.</p> <h1 id="conclusion">Conclusion</h1> <p>Improving Rust is an on-going activity. With the importance of addressing Rust's learning curve a <a href="https://blog.rust-lang.org/2016/06/30/State-of-Rust-Survey-2016.html">key theme in the Rust survey</a> we're as motivated as ever to find any confusing or distracting part of the Rust experience and give it a healthy amount of polish. Errors are one area where we're applying that polish helps us improve the learning curve bit by bit, and we're looking forward to seeing how far we can go.</p> Announcing Rust 1.10 Thu, 07 Jul 2016 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-10/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-10/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce the latest version of Rust, 1.10. Rust is a systems programming language focused on safety, speed, and concurrency.</p> <p>As always, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">install Rust 1.10</a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1100-2016-07-07">detailed release notes for 1.10</a> on GitHub. 1276 patches were landed in this release.</p> <h3 id="what-s-in-1-10-stable">What's in 1.10 stable</h3> <p>Rust 1.10 contains one of the most-requested features in Rust: through the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/32900"><code>-C panic=abort</code> flag</a> or a <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/2687">setting in your <code>Cargo.toml</code></a>, when a <code>panic!</code> happens, it will abort rather than unwind. Why would you want to do this? Remember that <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2016/05/26/Rust-1.9.html">panics are for unexpected problems</a>, and for many applications, aborting is a reasonable choice. With an abort, less code gets generated, meaning that binary sizes are a bit smaller, and compilation time is ever-so-slightly faster. Some very rough numbers are 10% smaller binaries, and 10% faster compilation time. This feature was defined in <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/1513-less-unwinding.md">RFC 1513</a>.</p> <p>The second big feature in 1.10 is a new crate type: <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/33553"><code>cdylib</code></a>. The existing dylib dynamic library format will now be used solely for writing a dynamic library to be used within a Rust project, while <code>cdylib</code>s will be used when compiling Rust code as a dynamic library to be embedded in another language. With the 1.10 release, <code>cdylib</code>s are supported by the compiler, but not yet in Cargo. This format was defined in <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/1510-rdylib.md">RFC 1510</a>.</p> <p>In addition, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#performance">a number of performance improvements landed in the compiler</a>, and so did <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#usability">a number of usability improvements</a> across the documentation, <code>rustdoc</code> itself, and various error messages.</p> <p>Finally, there's a large change to the way that we develop Rust that won't impact Rust users directly, but will help those distributing Rust significantly. Rust is implemented in Rust, which means that to build a copy of Rust, you need a copy of Rust. This is commonly referred to as 'bootstrapping'. Historically, we would do this by &quot;snapshotting&quot; a specific version of the compiler, and always bootstrapping from that; the snapshot would periodically be updated, as needed. Furthermore, since the Rust compiler uses unstable Rust features, in order to build a copy of the stable compiler, you would need a specific nightly version of the Rust compiler. This has served us well for years, but we've outgrown it now. The main drawback to this approach is that it requires downloading a snapshot binary, which is not ideal for an important constituency: Linux distributions. In particular, distros generally want to be able to build the latest version of Rust using only previously-packaged versions that they have produced, rather than via untrusted binaries. As such, we have modified our build system so that Rust 1.10 builds with Rust 1.9. In the future, this pattern will continue; Rust 1.11 will be built with Rust 1.10. Furthermore, you can use the stable compiler to build the compiler. This simplifies everything around bootstrapping, and helps distribution maintainers significantly, as they no longer need two packages. You can find more details about this change <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/32942">in its pull request</a>.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1100-2016-07-07">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h4 id="library-stabilizations">Library stabilizations</h4> <p>Roughly 70 APIs were made stable in this release. They break down into these rough groups:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1252"><code>std::os::windows::fs::OpenOptionsExt</code></a>, for Windows-specific file operations.</li> <li>The ability to <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1328">register and unregister panic hooks</a> with <code>std::panic::{set,take}_hook</code>.</li> <li><a href="http://doc.rust-lang.org/std/ffi/struct.CStr.html#method.from_bytes_with_nul"><code>CStr::from_bytes_with_nul</code></a>, to create a <code>CStr</code> from a byte slice (<a href="http://doc.rust-lang.org/std/ffi/struct.CStr.html#method.from_bytes_with_nul_unchecked">and an unchecked variant</a>).</li> <li>Small improvements to <a href="http://doc.rust-lang.org/std/fs/struct.Metadata.html"><code>std::fs::Metadata</code></a>.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1443"><code>compare_exchange</code> for various atomic types</a>.</li> <li>A lot of <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1479">UNIX-specific networking capabilities</a> via <code>std::os::unix::net::{UnixStream, UnixListener, UnixDatagram, SocketAddr}</code>.</li> </ul> <p>In addition, <code>Default</code> was implemented for <code>&amp;CStr</code>, <code>CString</code>, <code>UnsafeCell</code>, <code>fmt::Error</code>, <code>Condvar</code>, <code>Mutex</code>, and <code>RwLock</code>.</p> <p>Finally, on Linux, if HashMaps can't be initialized with <code>getrandom</code> they will <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/33086">fall back to <code>/dev/urandom</code> temporarily</a> to avoid blocking during early boot.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1100-2016-07-07">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h4 id="cargo-features">Cargo features</h4> <p>Cargo has received a number of small improvements in this release.</p> <ul> <li>The aforementioned <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/2687"><code>profile.*.panic</code></a> option can control how you'd like panics implemented for your project.</li> <li>Cargo now <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/2693">reports its status to stderr rather than stdout</a>.</li> <li>Rust keywords are now <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/2707">banned from crate names</a>.</li> <li>The <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/2405"><code>--force</code> flag</a> has been added to <code>cargo install</code>.</li> <li><code>cargo test</code> now takes a <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/2578"><code>--doc</code> flag</a> for running only documentation tests.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/2551"><code>cargo --explain</code> was added</a>, mirroring <code>rustc --explain</code>.</li> </ul> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-1100-2016-07-07">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h3 id="contributors-to-1-10">Contributors to 1.10</h3> <p>We had 139 individuals contribute to 1.10. Thank you so much!</p> <ul> <li>Adolfo Ochagavía</li> <li>Alan Somers</li> <li>Alec S</li> <li>Alex Burka</li> <li>Alex Crichton</li> <li>Alex Ozdemir</li> <li>Amanieu d'Antras</li> <li>Andrea Canciani</li> <li>Andrew Paseltiner</li> <li>Andrey Tonkih</li> <li>Andy Russell</li> <li>Anton Blanchard</li> <li>Ariel Ben-Yehuda</li> <li>Barosl Lee</li> <li>benaryorg</li> <li>billyevans</li> <li>Björn Steinbrink</li> <li>bnewbold</li> <li>bors</li> <li>Brandon Edens</li> <li>Brayden Winterton</li> <li>Brian Anderson</li> <li>Brian Campbell</li> <li>Brian Green</li> <li>c4rlo</li> <li>Christopher Serr</li> <li>Corey Farwell</li> <li>Cristian Oliveira</li> <li>Cyryl Płotnicki-Chudyk</li> <li>Dan Fockler</li> <li>Daniel Campoverde [alx741]</li> <li>Dave Huseby</li> <li>David Hewitt</li> <li>David Tolnay</li> <li>Deepak Kannan</li> <li>Demetri Obenour</li> <li>Doug Goldstein</li> <li>Eduard Burtescu</li> <li>Eduard-Mihai Burtescu</li> <li>Ergenekon Yigit</li> <li>Fabrice Desré</li> <li>Felix S. Klock II</li> <li>Florian Berger</li> <li>Garrett Squire</li> <li>Geordon Worley</li> <li>Georg Brandl</li> <li>ggomez</li> <li>Gigih Aji Ibrahim</li> <li>Guillaume Bonnet</li> <li>Guillaume Gomez</li> <li>Haiko Schol</li> <li>Jake Goulding</li> <li>James Miller</li> <li>jbranchaud</li> <li>Jeffrey Seyfried</li> <li>jethrogb</li> <li>jocki84</li> <li>Johannes Oertel</li> <li>Jonas Schievink</li> <li>jonathandturner</li> <li>Jonathan S</li> <li>Jonathan Turner</li> <li>JP Sugarbroad</li> <li>Kaiyin Zhong</li> <li>Kamal Marhubi</li> <li>Kevin Butler</li> <li>Léo Testard</li> <li>Luca Bruno</li> <li>Lukas Kalbertodt</li> <li>Lukas Pustina</li> <li>Luqman Aden</li> <li>Manish Goregaokar</li> <li>Marcus Klaas</li> <li>mark-summerfield</li> <li>Masood Malekghassemi</li> <li>Matt Brubeck</li> <li>Matt Kraai</li> <li>Maxim Samburskiy</li> <li>Michael Howell</li> <li>Michael Tiller</li> <li>Michael Woerister</li> <li>mitaa</li> <li>mrmiywj</li> <li>Ms2ger</li> <li>Murarth</li> <li>Nerijus Arlauskas</li> <li>Nick Cameron</li> <li>Nick Fitzgerald</li> <li>Nick Hamann</li> <li>Nick Platt</li> <li>Niko Matsakis</li> <li>Oliver 'ker' Schneider</li> <li>Oliver Middleton</li> <li>Oliver Schneider</li> <li>Patrick Walton</li> <li>Pavel Sountsov</li> <li>Philipp Matthias Schaefer</li> <li>Philipp Oppermann</li> <li>pierzchalski</li> <li>Postmodern</li> <li>pravic</li> <li>Pyry Kontio</li> <li>Raph Levien</li> <li>Rémy Rakic</li> <li>rkjnsn</li> <li>Robert Habermeier</li> <li>Robin Kruppe</li> <li>Sander Maijers</li> <li>Scott Olson</li> <li>Sean Gillespie</li> <li>Sébastien Marie</li> <li>Seo Sanghyeon</li> <li>silvo38</li> <li>Simonas Kazlauskas</li> <li>Simon Wollwage</li> <li>Stefan Schindler</li> <li>Stephen Mather</li> <li>Steve Klabnik</li> <li>Steven Burns</li> <li>Steven Fackler</li> <li>Szabolcs Berecz</li> <li>Tamir Duberstein</li> <li>Tang Chenglong</li> <li>Taylor Cramer</li> <li>Ticki</li> <li>Timon Van Overveldt</li> <li>Timothy McRoy</li> <li>Tobias Bucher</li> <li>Tobias Müller</li> <li>Tomáš Hübelbauer</li> <li>Tomoki Aonuma</li> <li>Tshepang Lekhonkhobe</li> <li>Ulrik Sverdrup</li> <li>User</li> <li>Vadim Chugunov</li> <li>Vadim Petrochenkov</li> <li>Val Vanderschaegen</li> <li>Wang Xuerui</li> <li>York Xiang</li> </ul> State of Rust Survey 2016 Thu, 30 Jun 2016 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/state-of-rust-survey-2016/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/state-of-rust-survey-2016/ <p>We recently wrapped up with a survey for the Rust community. Little did we know that it would grow to be one of the largest language community surveys. A <em>huge</em> thank you to the <strong>3,086</strong> people who responded! We're humbled by the response, and we're thankful for all the great feedback.</p> <p>The goal of the survey was simple: we wanted to know how Rust was doing in its first year. We asked a variety of questions to better understand how Rust was being used, how well the Rust tools worked, and what the challenges are for people wanting to adopt Rust.</p> <p>We plan to run a similar survey each year to track how we're progressing and spot places we can improve. With that, let's get started.</p> <h2 id="do-you-use-rust">Do You Use Rust?</h2> <p>We wanted to make sure the survey was open to both users of Rust and to people who didn't use Rust. Rust users give us a sense of how the current language and tools are working and where we need to improve. Rust non-users shed light on missing use-cases and obstacles for Rust’s adoption.</p> <p><img src="/images/2016-06-Survey/do_you_use_rust.png" alt="Do you use Rust" /></p> <p>We're happy to report that more than a third of the responses were from people not using Rust. These respondents gave a lot of great feedback on adoption roadblocks, which we'll talk about later in this blog post.</p> <h2 id="growing-numbers-trying-rust">Growing numbers trying Rust</h2> <p><img src="/images/2016-06-Survey/time_using_rust.png" alt="Time using Rust" /></p> <p>Almost 2,000 people responded saying they were Rust users. Of these, almost 24% were new users. This is encouraging to see. The community is growing, with a healthy portion of newcomers playing with Rust now that could become long-term users.</p> <p>Equally encouraging is seeing that once someone has become a Rust user, they tend to stick around and continue using it. One might expect a sharp drop-off if users became quickly disenchanted and moved onto other technologies. Instead, we see the opposite. Users that come in and stay past their initial experiences tend to stay long-term, with a fairly even spread between 3 months to 12 months (when we first went 1.0). We've seen similar patterns looking at <a href="https://crates.io/">crates.io</a> usage, as well as in the <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/research/developer-survey-2016">StackOverflow developer survey</a>.</p> <h2 id="using-rust">Using Rust</h2> <p>We asked a number of questions trying to get a clear picture of what it's like to use Rust today. The first questions focused on the Rust compiler.</p> <p><img src="/images/2016-06-Survey/versions_of_rust.png" alt="Versions of Rust you use" /></p> <p>In the above chart, you see the top five rustc version combinations for users writing Rust. At the time of the survey, version 1.8 was the latest stable release. This factors strongly in the results as the most popular version of Rust to use. Perhaps surprisingly is how much the nightly also plays a key role in for many developers, with over 400 using it as their only Rust compiler version. Stabilizing features and APIs, and thereby encouraging transition to the stable channel, continues to be a priority for the team.</p> <p><img src="/images/2016-06-Survey/after_1_0_broke_code.png" alt="Has an upgrade broken code" /></p> <p>In the pre-1.0 days, Rust releases would regularly break user's code. In reaching 1.0, we began releasing versions that maintained backwards compatibility with 1.0. For stable Rust, 83.6% of users did not experience any breakage in their project as they upgraded to the next stable version. Previous research based on automated testing against the ecosystem put this number <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/rust-regressions-2015-year-end-report/2993">closer to 96%</a>, which is more in line with expectations.</p> <p>Why the discrepancy? Looking at the data more closely, it seems people used this question as a catch-all for any kind of breakage, including packages in cargo, compiler plugins needing updates, and the changes to libc. We'll be sure to word this question more clearly in the future. But we also plan to launch a forum discussion digging further into the details, to make sure that there’s not something missing from the test automation that runs against crates.io.</p> <p><img src="/images/2016-06-Survey/easy_to_fix.png" alt="Fixing broken code" /></p> <p>Luckily, regardless of what bucket the breakage fell into, they were largely easy to solve as people upgraded.</p> <p><img src="/images/2016-06-Survey/like_cargo.png" alt="Do you like Cargo" /></p> <p>Another big piece of the Rust development experience is using the Cargo tool. Here we saw overwhelming support for Cargo, with 94.1% of people saying they would rate it a 4 or 5. This helps to emphasize that Cargo continues to be a core part of what it means to write Rust (and that people enjoy using it!)</p> <h2 id="rust-at-work">Rust at Work</h2> <p>An important part of a programming language's success is that it's used for &quot;real&quot; work. We asked a few questions to understand how Rust was doing in the workplace. Were people using it in their day jobs? How much was it being used?</p> <p><img src="/images/2016-06-Survey/rust_at_work.png" alt="Using Rust at work" /></p> <p>We were pleasantly surprised to see that already, in Rust's first year, 16.1% of Rust users are using Rust at work part-time and 3.7% are using at work full-time. Combined, <strong>nearly 1/5th of Rust users are using Rust commercially</strong>. We're seeing this reflected in the growing number of <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/friends.html">companies using Rust</a>.</p> <p>We also asked about the size of the codebases that Rust developers were building.</p> <p><img src="/images/2016-06-Survey/part_time.png" alt="Size of part-time codebases" /></p> <p><img src="/images/2016-06-Survey/full_time.png" alt="Size of full-time codebases" /></p> <p>We see strong numbers in project size as developers put more time into Rust at work. Over half of the Rust users using Rust full-time at work have codebases that are tens or hundreds of thousands of lines of code.</p> <p>Equally encouraging is the growth we expect to see in Rust in the workplace, as we see in the next chart.</p> <p><img src="/images/2016-06-Survey/rust_at_work_future.png" alt="Using Rust at work in future" /></p> <p>Of those not currently using Rust at work, more than 40% plan on being able to use Rust at work. This will help carry Rust to more places and in more areas. Speaking of carrying to more areas, we saw a wide variety of job domains represented in the survey:</p> <p><img src="/images/2016-06-Survey/demo_areas.png" alt="Demographics of work areas" /></p> <p>It's encouraging to see people from so many different backgrounds interested in Rust. It underscores Rust’s potential across a broad spectrum of programming tasks and the need for libraries to support these areas.</p> <h2 id="challenges-for-rust">Challenges for Rust</h2> <p>An important part of the survey was understanding what's getting in the way of people using Rust. This data can help guide our energies in the coming year. Over <strong>1,900</strong> people responded here, giving us a detailed picture of the challenges with using and promoting Rust. While we'll be exploring these responses in upcoming blog posts, here we'll look at three strong themes in the feedback: learning curve, immaturity of the language and libraries, and immaturity of the tools.</p> <h1 id="learning-curve">Learning Curve</h1> <p>Rust is a unique language, introducing new concepts, like ownership, that are not usually explicit in languages. While these concepts are what make Rust so powerful, they can also be an obstacle when first getting to know the language.</p> <p>In total, <strong>1 in 4</strong> people commented on the learning curve when talking about Rust's challenges. Here are some of the comments:</p> <blockquote> <p>&quot;Borrow checker is hard to grasp for a beginner.&quot;</p> </blockquote> <blockquote> <p>&quot;The borrow system, albeit powerful, can be difficult to learn.&quot;</p> </blockquote> <blockquote> <p>&quot;Steep learning curve at the beginning&quot;</p> </blockquote> <p>The proverbial gauntlet has been thrown. For Rust to do well, it will need to retain the power it has while also improving the experience of learning the language and mastering its ownership system. There are a few early initiatives here, including a <a href="http://rust-lang.github.io/book/">new Rust book</a>, an <a href="http://shop.oreilly.com/product/0636920040385.do">upcoming O'Reilly book</a>, improvements to <a href="https://github.com/jonathandturner/rfcs/blob/master/text/0000-default-and-expanded-rustc-errors.md">Rust error messages</a>, as well as improvements to the borrow checker to <a href="http://smallcultfollowing.com/babysteps/blog/2016/05/04/non-lexical-lifetimes-based-on-liveness/">give fewer false warnings</a>. We expect learning curve and developer productivity to be an area of sustained focus.</p> <h1 id="immaturity-of-the-language-and-libraries">Immaturity of the Language and Libraries</h1> <p>Of those commenting on Rust's challenges, <strong>1 in 9</strong> mentioned the relative immaturity of the Rust language was a factor. While some people pointed out their favorite missing feature, the consensus formed around the need to move the ecosystem onto the stable language and away from requiring the nightly builds of the compiler.</p> <blockquote> <p>&quot;a major blocker is how many crates still only put their best foot forward if you're using a nightly compiler&quot;</p> </blockquote> <blockquote> <p>&quot;I don't like having to use a nightly plus a build.rs for parsing json with serde. It needs to be simpler.&quot;</p> </blockquote> <blockquote> <p>&quot;I also found myself unable to use a lot of nice looking crates because many were locked on nightly because of feature usage.&quot;</p> </blockquote> <p>While there will always be a subset of users that want to live on the bleeding edge and use every new feature, it's become clear that as Rust matures it will need to build more infrastructure around the stable language and compiler.</p> <p>Closely related to the language are the libraries. People often mentioned both in the same sentence, seeing the experience of programming Rust as one built on the combination of language and library. In total, <strong>1 in 7</strong> commenters mentioned the lack of libraries. The kinds of libraries people mentioned ran the gamut in terms of topic, covering areas like GUIs, scientific/numeric computing, serialization support, web/networking, async I/O, parallel/concurrent patterns, and richer data structures (including more containers and broader coverage of general algorithms).</p> <p>Of course, immaturity is to be expected one year in, and to some degree is a problem that only time can solve. But there was also a sense that people coming to Rust wanted more of a &quot;batteries included&quot; experience, gathering together the best of the ecosystem in a simple package. There are some proposals in the works for how best to build this experience, and we’re looking forward to discussing these ideas in the coming weeks.</p> <h1 id="immaturity-of-the-tooling">Immaturity of the Tooling</h1> <p>Another strong theme for improvement was the relative immaturity of the tooling for Rust. While tools like Cargo have been invaluable to a number of Rust users, other tools need attention.</p> <p>Of non-Rust users, <strong>1 in 4</strong> responded that they aren't currently using Rust because of the lack of strong IDE support. As one user puts it <em>&quot;[f]or a complex language like Rust, good editor tooling makes the learning process interactive.&quot;</em> Modern IDEs have become a powerful way to explore unfamiliar APIs, unfamiliar language features, and unfamiliar error messages.</p> <p>Investing in IDE support not only helps new users but also helps enable teams moving to Rust and the growth of larger codebases, as we see in some of the quotes about Rust's challenges:</p> <blockquote> <p>&quot;I won't use the language until there's IDE support for it, and I know other devs that feel the same way. As productive as your language's syntax is, I'm more productive in a worse language with an editor that has code-completion.&quot;</p> </blockquote> <blockquote> <p>&quot;Users/projects considering switching languages often are not willing to sacrifice tooling quality even for a better language.&quot;</p> </blockquote> <blockquote> <p>&quot;Proper IDE support (hard to get it accepted at work for that reason)&quot;</p> </blockquote> <p>Other languages have had years to build up their tooling muscle, and for Rust to stand on even footing, we'll also have to build up our own muscle. There are some early experiments here, namely <a href="https://github.com/phildawes/racer">Racer</a> and <a href="https://github.com/nrc/rustw">rustw</a>, as well as a <a href="https://areweideyet.com/">number of IDE plugins</a>.</p> <p>We've also been investing in other tooling muscles, including a <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2016/05/13/rustup.html">new installer with cross-compilation support</a>. These are just the first steps, and we'll be exploring more ideas in further blog posts.</p> <h2 id="survey-demographics">Survey Demographics</h2> <p><img src="/images/2016-06-Survey/meetup_locations.png" alt="Popular meetup locations" /></p> <p>Today, Rust has a worldwide audience. Rather than being lumped in one place, we see Rust users in Europe, Japan, Australia, with new meetups popping up everyday. We also asked where people who responded lived, and over 1000 of the 3000 survey responses mentioned living in Europe (with USA following it up at 835).</p> <p><img src="/images/2016-06-Survey/what_language.png" alt="Demographics on programming language background" /></p> <p>The parents of most modern languages, C and C++, show strongly in terms of the programming languages that people are most comfortable with. Close by are Java and JavaScript. Perhaps one surprising point here is the large number of Python users attracted to Rust.</p> <p>For those who already have existing projects in other languages but want to use Rust, it's worth mentioning here the on-going efforts to aide in using Rust with other languages, including work to <a href="https://github.com/rustbridge/helix">integrate with Ruby</a> and <a href="https://github.com/rustbridge/neon">integrate with JavaScript/Node.js</a>.</p> <p><img src="/images/2016-06-Survey/underrepresented.png" alt="Members of underrepresented groups" /></p> <p>Rust strives to be a <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/conduct.html">warm, welcoming and inclusive community</a>. The survey shows that, despite that spirit, we have a ways to go in terms of diversity. We have nascent efforts, like <a href="https://github.com/rust-community/rustbridge">RustBridge</a>, to more proactively reach out to underrepresented groups and make Rust more accessible, but there is a lot more work to be done. We'll be watching the results of this part of the survey closely and continue to invest in outreach, mentoring, and leadership to foster inclusivity.</p> <h2 id="warm-feelings">Warm Feelings</h2> <p>At the end of the survey, we threw in a catch-all question: &quot;Anything else you'd like to tell us?&quot; Rather than being a large batch of additional things to look at, we received an outpouring of support from the community.</p> <p>I'll let some of the quotes speak for themselves:</p> <blockquote> <p>&quot;Rust has been an incredible productivity boon for me. <em>Thank you</em> so much, and keep up the good work!&quot;</p> </blockquote> <blockquote> <p>&quot;Thank you for making Rust awesome!&quot;</p> </blockquote> <blockquote> <p>&quot;Working in the Rust community has been an amazing experience.&quot;</p> </blockquote> <p>And we couldn't agree more. One of the best things about working in Rust is that you're part of a community of people working together to build something awesome. A big thank you(!!) to all of you who have contributed to Rust. Rust is what it is because of you.</p> <p>We'd love to hear your comments and invite you to jump in and participate in the upcoming discussions on ways we can tackle the challenges brought up in this survey.</p> Announcing Rust 1.9 Thu, 26 May 2016 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-9/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-9/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce the latest version of Rust, 1.9. Rust is a systems programming language focused on safety, speed, and concurrency.</p> <p>As always, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">install Rust 1.9</a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-190-2016-05-26">detailed release notes for 1.9</a> on GitHub. About 1000 patches were landed in this release.</p> <h3 id="what-s-in-1-9-stable">What's in 1.9 stable</h3> <h4 id="controlled-unwinding">Controlled unwinding</h4> <p>The biggest shift in Rust 1.9 is the stabilization of the <code>std::panic</code> module, which includes methods for halting the unwinding process started by a panic:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">use </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">std::panic; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> result </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">panic::catch_unwind(|| { println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;hello!&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); }); assert!(result.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">is_ok</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">()); </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> result </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">panic::catch_unwind(|| { panic!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;oh no!&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); }); assert!(result.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">is_err</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">()); </span></pre> <p>This new API was defined in <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1236">RFC 1236</a>.</p> <p>In general, Rust distinguishes between two ways that an operation can fail:</p> <ul> <li>Due to an <em>expected problem</em>, like a file not being found.</li> <li>Due to an <em>unexpected problem</em>, like an index being out of bounds for an array.</li> </ul> <p>Expected problems usually arise from conditions that are outside of your control; robust code should be prepared for anything its environment might throw at it. In Rust, expected problems are handled via <a href="http://static.rust-lang.org/doc/master/std/result/index.html">the <code>Result</code> type</a>, which allows a function to return information about the problem to its caller, which can then handle the error in a fine-grained way.</p> <p>Unexpected problems are <em>bugs</em>: they arise due to a contract or assertion being violated. Since they are unexpected, it doesn't make sense to handle them in a fine-grained way. Instead, Rust employs a &quot;fail fast&quot; approach by <em>panicking</em>, which by default unwinds the stack (running destructors but no other code) of the thread which discovered the error. Other threads continue running, but will discover the panic any time they try to communicate with the panicked thread (whether through channels or shared memory). Panics thus abort execution up to some &quot;isolation boundary&quot;, with code on the other side of the boundary still able to run, and perhaps to &quot;recover&quot; from the panic in some very coarse-grained way. A server, for example, does not necessarily need to go down just because of an assertion failure in one of its threads.</p> <p>The new <code>catch_unwind</code> API offers a way to introduce new isolation boundaries <em>within a thread</em>. There are a couple of key motivating examples:</p> <ul> <li>Embedding Rust in other languages</li> <li>Abstractions that manage threads</li> </ul> <p>For the first case, unwinding across a language boundary is undefined behavior, and often leads to segfaults in practice. Allowing panics to be caught means that you can safely expose Rust code via a C API, and translate unwinding into an error on the C side.</p> <p>For the second case, consider a threadpool library. If a thread in the pool panics, you generally don't want to kill the thread itself, but rather catch the panic and communicate it to the client of the pool. The <code>catch_unwind</code> API is paired with <code>resume_unwind</code>, which can then be used to restart the panicking process on the client of the pool, where it belongs.</p> <p>In both cases, you're introducing a new isolation boundary within a thread, and then translating the panic into some other form of error elsewhere.</p> <p>A final point: why <code>catch_unwind</code> rather than <code>catch_panic</code>? We are <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1513">in the process</a> of adding an additional strategy for panics: aborting the entire process (possibly after running a general <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1328">hook</a>). For some applications, this is the most reasonable way to deal with a programmer error, and avoiding unwinding can have performance and code size wins.</p> <h4 id="deprecation-warnings">Deprecation warnings</h4> <p>We introduced a new attribute for library authors: <code>#[deprecated]</code>. This attribute allows you to tag an API with a deprecation warning, which users of their crate will receive whenever they use the API, directing them to a replacement API. Deprecation warnings have long been a part of the standard library, but thanks to <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/1270-deprecation.md">RFC 1270</a> they're now usable ecosystem-wide.</p> <h4 id="new-targets">New targets</h4> <p>We now publish standard library binaries for several new targets:</p> <ul> <li><code>mips-unknown-linux-musl</code>,</li> <li><code>mipsel-unknown-linux-musl</code>, and</li> <li><code>i586-pc-windows-msvc</code>.</li> </ul> <p>The first two targets are particularly interesting from a cross-compilation perspective; see the <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2016/05/13/rustup.html">recent blog post on <code>rustup</code></a> for more details.</p> <h4 id="compile-time-improvements">Compile time improvements</h4> <p><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/32062">The time complexity of comparing variables for equivalence</a> during type unification is reduced from O(n!) to O(n). As a result, some programming patterns compile much, much more quickly.</p> <h4 id="rolling-out-use-of-specialization">Rolling out use of specialization</h4> <p>This release sees some of the first use of <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1210">specialization</a> within the standard library. Specialization, which is currently available only on <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/10/30/Stability.html">nightly</a>, allows generic code to automatically be specialized based on more specific type information.</p> <p>One example where this comes up in the standard library: conversion from a string slice (<code>&amp;str</code>) to an owned <code>String</code>. One method, <code>to_string</code>, comes from a generic API which was previously relatively slow, while the custom <code>to_owned</code> implementation provided better performance. Using specialization, these two functions are <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/32586">now equivalent</a>.</p> <p>With this simple test of specialization under our belt, we have more performance improvements on the way in upcoming releases.</p> <h4 id="library-stabilizations">Library stabilizations</h4> <p>About 80 library functions and methods are now stable in 1.9. The most major is the <code>std::panic</code> module, described earlier, but there's a lot more too:</p> <p><strong>Networking</strong></p> <ul> <li><code>TcpStream</code>, <code>TcpListener</code>, and <code>UdpSocket</code> gained a number of methods for configuring the connection.</li> <li><code>SocketAddr</code> and its variants gained <code>set_ip()</code> and <code>set_port()</code> conveniences.</li> </ul> <p><strong>Collections</strong></p> <ul> <li><code>BTreeSet</code> and <code>HashSet</code> gained the <code>take()</code>, <code>replace()</code>, and <code>get()</code> methods, which make it possible to recover ownership of the original key.</li> <li><code>OsString</code> gained a few methods, bringing it closer to parity with <code>String</code>.</li> <li>Slices gained <code>copy_from_slice()</code>, a safe form of <code>memcpy</code>.</li> </ul> <p><strong>Encoding</strong></p> <ul> <li><code>char</code> gained the ability to decode into UTF-16.</li> </ul> <p><strong>Pointers</strong></p> <ul> <li>Raw pointers gained <code>as_ref()</code> and <code>as_mut()</code>, which returns an <code>Option&lt;&amp;T&gt;</code>, translating null pointers into <code>None</code>.</li> <li><code>ptr::{read,write}_volatile()</code> allow for volatile reading and writing from a raw pointer.</li> </ul> <p>Finally, many of the types in <code>libcore</code> did not contain a <code>Debug</code> implementation. <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/32054">This was fixed</a> in the 1.9 release.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-190-2016-05-26">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h4 id="cargo-features">Cargo features</h4> <p>There were two major changes to Cargo:</p> <p>First, Cargo <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/2486">can now be run concurrently</a>.</p> <p>Second, a new flag, <code>RUSTFLAGS</code>, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/2241">was added</a>. This flag allows you to specify arbitrary flags to be passed to <code>rustc</code> through an environment variable, which is useful for packagers, for example.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-190-2016-05-26">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h3 id="contributors-to-1-9">Contributors to 1.9</h3> <p>We had 127 individuals contribute to 1.9. Thank you so much!</p> <ul> <li>Aaron Turon</li> <li>Abhishek Chanda</li> <li>Adolfo Ochagavía</li> <li>Aidan Hobson Sayers</li> <li>Alan Somers</li> <li>Alejandro Wainzinger</li> <li>Aleksey Kladov</li> <li>Alex Burka</li> <li>Alex Crichton</li> <li>Amanieu d'Antras</li> <li>Andrea Canciani</li> <li>Andreas Linz</li> <li>Andrew Cantino</li> <li>Andrew Horton</li> <li>Andrew Paseltiner</li> <li>Andrey Cherkashin</li> <li>Angus Lees</li> <li>Ariel Ben-Yehuda</li> <li>Benjamin Herr</li> <li>Björn Steinbrink</li> <li>Brian Anderson</li> <li>Brian Bowman</li> <li>Christian Wesselhoeft</li> <li>Christopher Serr</li> <li>Corey Farwell</li> <li>Craig M. Brandenburg</li> <li>Cyryl Płotnicki-Chudyk</li> <li>Daniel J Rollins</li> <li>Dave Huseby</li> <li>David AO Lozano</li> <li>David Henningsson</li> <li>Devon Hollowood</li> <li>Dirk Gadsden</li> <li>Doug Goldstein</li> <li>Eduard Burtescu</li> <li>Eduard-Mihai Burtescu</li> <li>Eli Friedman</li> <li>Emanuel Czirai</li> <li>Erick Tryzelaar</li> <li>Evan</li> <li>Felix S. Klock II</li> <li>Florian Berger</li> <li>Geoff Catlin</li> <li>Guillaume Gomez</li> <li>Gökhan Karabulut</li> <li>JP Sugarbroad</li> <li>James Miller</li> <li>Jeffrey Seyfried</li> <li>John Talling</li> <li>Jonas Schievink</li> <li>Jonathan S</li> <li>Jorge Aparicio</li> <li>Joshua Holmer</li> <li>Kai Noda</li> <li>Kamal Marhubi</li> <li>Katze</li> <li>Kevin Brothaler</li> <li>Kevin Butler</li> <li>Manish Goregaokar</li> <li>Markus Westerlind</li> <li>Marvin Löbel</li> <li>Masood Malekghassemi</li> <li>Matt Brubeck</li> <li>Michael Huynh</li> <li>Michael Neumann</li> <li>Michael Woerister</li> <li>Ms2ger</li> <li>NODA, Kai</li> <li>Nathan Kleyn</li> <li>Nick Cameron</li> <li>Niko Matsakis</li> <li>Noah</li> <li>Novotnik, Petr</li> <li>Oliver Middleton</li> <li>Oliver Schneider</li> <li>Philipp Oppermann</li> <li>Piotr Czarnecki</li> <li>Pyfisch</li> <li>Richo Healey</li> <li>Ruud van Asseldonk</li> <li>Scott Olson</li> <li>Sean McArthur</li> <li>Sebastian Wicki</li> <li>Seo Sanghyeon</li> <li>Simon Sapin</li> <li>Simonas Kazlauskas</li> <li>Steve Klabnik</li> <li>Steven Allen</li> <li>Steven Fackler</li> <li>Stu Black</li> <li>Sébastien Marie</li> <li>Tang Chenglong</li> <li>Ted Horst</li> <li>Ticki</li> <li>Tim Montague</li> <li>Tim Neumann</li> <li>Timon Van Overveldt</li> <li>Tobias Bucher</li> <li>Tobias Müller</li> <li>Todd Lucas</li> <li>Tom Tromey</li> <li>Tshepang Lekhonkhobe</li> <li>Ulrik Sverdrup</li> <li>Vadim Petrochenkov</li> <li>Valentin Lorentz</li> <li>Varun Vats</li> <li>Wang Xuerui</li> <li>Wangshan Lu</li> <li>York Xiang</li> <li>arcnmx</li> <li>ashleysommer</li> <li>bors</li> <li>ggomez</li> <li>gohyda</li> <li>ituxbag</li> <li>mitaa</li> <li>nicholasf</li> <li>petevine</li> <li>pierzchalski</li> <li>pravic</li> <li>srinivasreddy</li> <li>tiehuis</li> <li>ubsan</li> <li>vagrant</li> <li>vegai</li> <li>vlastachu</li> <li>Валерий Лашманов</li> </ul> One year of Rust Mon, 16 May 2016 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-at-one-year/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-at-one-year/ <p>Rust is a language that gives you:</p> <ul> <li>uncompromising performance and control;</li> <li>prevention of entire categories of bugs, including <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2015/04/10/Fearless-Concurrency.html">classic concurrency pitfalls</a>;</li> <li>ergonomics that often rival languages like <a href="http://lucumr.pocoo.org/2015/5/27/rust-for-pythonistas/">Python</a> and <a href="http://diesel.rs/">Ruby</a>.</li> </ul> <p>It's a language for writing highly reliable, screamingly fast software—and having fun doing it.</p> <p>And yesterday, Rust turned one year old.</p> <img src="http://rustcamp.com/images/after/cupcakes.jpg" height="300px" width="300px"> <h3 id="rust-in-numbers">Rust in numbers</h3> <p>A lot has happened in the last 365 days:</p> <ul> <li>11,894 <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/commits/master">commits</a> by 702 contributors added to the core repository;</li> <li>88 <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs">RFCs</a> merged;</li> <li>18 compiler targets introduced;</li> <li>9 releases shipped;</li> <li>1 year of <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/10/30/Stability.html">stability delivered</a>.</li> </ul> <p>On an <strong>average week</strong> this year, the Rust community merged two RFCs and published 53 brand new <a href="https://crates.io/">crates</a>. Not a single day went by without at least one new Rust library hitting the central package manager. And Rust topped the &quot;<a href="https://stackoverflow.com/research/developer-survey-2016">most loved</a> language&quot; in this year's StackOverflow survey.</p> <p>Speaking of numbers: we recently launched a <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2016/05/09/survey.html">survey</a> of our own, and want to hear from you whether you are an old hat at Rust, or have never used it.</p> <p>One place where our numbers are not where we want them to be: community diversity. We've had ongoing local outreach efforts, but the Rust community team will soon be launching a coordinated, global effort following the <a href="http://bridgefoundry.org/">Bridge</a> model (e.g. RailsBridge). If you want to get involved, or have other ideas for outreach, please let <a href="mailto:community-team@rust-lang.org">the community team</a> know.</p> <h3 id="rust-in-production">Rust in production</h3> <p>This year saw more companies <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/friends.html">betting on Rust</a>. Each one has a story, but two particularly resonated.</p> <p>First, there's Dropbox. For the last several years, the company has been secretively working on a move <a href="http://www.wired.com/2016/03/epic-story-dropboxs-exodus-amazon-cloud-empire/">away from AWS and onto its own infrastructure</a>. The move, which is now complete, included developing custom-build hardware and the software to drive it. While much of Dropbox's back-end infrastructure is historically written in Go, for some key components the memory footprint and lack of control stood in the way of achieving the server utilization they were striving for. They rewrote those components in Rust. In the <a href="https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=11283688">words of Jamie Turner</a>, a lead engineer for the project, &quot;the advantages of Rust are many: really powerful abstractions, no null, no segfaults, no leaks, yet C-like performance and control over memory.&quot;</p> <p>Second, there's Mozilla. They've long been developing <a href="https://github.com/servo/servo/">Servo</a> as a research browser engine in Rust, but their first <em>production</em> Rust code shipped through a different vehicle: <em>Firefox</em>. In Firefox 45, without any fanfare, Rust code for <a href="https://github.com/mozilla/mp4parse-rust">mp4 metadata parsing</a> went out to OSX and 64-bit Linux users; it will hit Windows in version 48. The code is currently running in test mode, with its results compared against the legacy C++ library: 100% correctness on <a href="https://telemetry.mozilla.org/new-pipeline/dist.html#!cumulative=0&amp;end_date=2016-04-07&amp;keys=__none__!__none__!__none__&amp;max_channel_version=release%252F45&amp;measure=MEDIA_RUST_MP4PARSE_SUCCESS&amp;min_channel_version=null&amp;product=Firefox&amp;sanitize=1&amp;sort_keys=submissions&amp;start_date=2016-03-03&amp;table=0&amp;trim=1&amp;use_submission_date=0">1 <em>billion</em> reported executions</a>. But this code is just the tip of the iceberg: after laying a lot of <a href="http://wiki.mozilla.org/Oxidation">groundwork for Rust integration</a>, Firefox is poised to bring in significant amounts of new Rust code, including components from Servo—and not just in test mode.</p> <p>We're hearing <a href="http://confreaks.tv/videos/rustcamp2015-using-rust-from-c-or-any-language">similar stories</a> from a range of other shops that are putting Rust into production: Rust helps a team punch above its weight. It gives many of the same benefits as traditional systems languages while being more approachable, safer and often more productive.</p> <p>These are just a few stories of Rust in production, but we'd love to <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-www/issues/new?title=New+Website+Logo%3A+%5Binsert+name%5D%0A&amp;body=To+list+your+organization%27s+logo+on+the+Rust+website%2C+fill+out+the+following+information+and+click+%22submit+new+issue%22.+Alternately%2C+you+may+edit+_data%2Fusers.yml+as+described+therein+and+submit+a+pull+request.%0D%0A%0D%0A-+Organization+name%3A+%28as+you+want+it+displayed%29%0D%0A-+Homepage+url%3A+%28homepage%2Fprimary+entry+point+for+users%29%0D%0A-+Logo+url%3A+%28svg+if+possible%2C+pngs+over+400x200px+with+transparent+backgrounds+are+also+acceptable%29%0D%0A-+How+you+are+using+Rust%3A+%28one+sentence+describing+your+use+of+Rust%29%0D%0A-+Url+describing+Rust+usage%3A+%28optional+link+to+e.g.+blog+post+explaining+how+you+use+Rust%29%0D%0A-+Organization+contact%3A+%28name+and+email.+we+may+contact+you+when+updating+this+page.+alternately+you+may+email+this+information+to+user-logos%40rust-lang.org+and+it+will+be+kept+secret%29.%0D%0A">hear yours</a>!</p> <h3 id="rust-improved">Rust, improved</h3> <p>Of course, Rust itself hasn't been standing still. The focus in its first year has been growing and polishing its ecosystem and tooling:</p> <ul> <li><strong>Ecosystem</strong>. The standard library has steadily expanded, with growth focused on <a href="http://static.rust-lang.org/doc/master/std/fs/index.html">filesystem access</a>, <a href="http://static.rust-lang.org/doc/master/std/net/index.html">networking</a>, <a href="http://static.rust-lang.org/doc/master/std/time/index.html">time</a>, and <a href="http://static.rust-lang.org/doc/master/std/collections/index.html">collections</a> APIs—and dramatically better documentation coverage. There's good support for working with C libraries via the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/libc">libc</a>, <a href="https://github.com/retep998/winapi-rs">winapi</a>, and <a href="https://github.com/alexcrichton/gcc-rs">gcc</a> crates. And new libraries for <a href="https://github.com/carllerche/mio/">low-level async io</a>, <a href="http://smallcultfollowing.com/babysteps/blog/2015/12/18/rayon-data-parallelism-in-rust/">easy parallelism</a>, <a href="http://aturon.github.io/blog/2015/08/27/epoch/">lock-free data structures</a>, <a href="http://diesel.rs/">Rails-like object-relational mapping</a>, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/regex">regular expressions</a>, and several <a href="https://github.com/Geal/nom">parsing</a> <a href="http://smallcultfollowing.com/babysteps/blog/2015/09/14/lalrpop/">libraries</a>, including <a href="https://kmcallister.github.io/talks/rust/2014-rust-macros/slides.html">html5ever</a>, a unique HTML5 parser that leverages Rust's macro system to make the code resemble the spec as closely as possible. These are just scratching the surface, of course, and ecosystem growth, curation and coherence—particularly around async IO and the web stack—will continue to be a major focus in the coming year.</li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong>Platforms and targets</strong>. Rust's memory footprint is not much bigger than C's, which makes it ideal for using in all kinds of places. Over the last year, Rust gained the ability to work directly with the native <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/25350">MSVC toolchain</a> on Windows, to target <a href="https://www.musl-libc.org/">musl</a> (thereby creating a binary that can be used with zero dependencies on <em>any</em> variety of Linux), to target Android and ARM devices, and <a href="https://forge.rust-lang.org/platform-support.html">many more platforms</a>. The new <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2016/05/13/rustup.html">rustup tool</a> makes it a breeze to manage and compile to these various targets. As of <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2016/01/21/Rust-1.6.html">Rust 1.6</a>, you can use Rust without its full standard library, limiting to a core library that does not require any OS services (and hence is suitable for <a href="http://os.phil-opp.com/">writing OSes</a> <a href="https://intermezzos.github.io/">in Rust</a>). Finally, there are an increasing number of libraries for embedding Rust code into other contexts, like <a href="http://calculist.org/blog/2015/12/23/neon-node-rust/">node.js</a>, <a href="http://blog.skylight.io/introducing-helix/">Ruby</a> and <a href="https://github.com/BurntSushi/rure-go">Go</a>.</li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong>Tools</strong>. Because Rust looks just like C on the outside, it's instantly usable with a wide range of existing tools; it works out of the box with <a href="http://lldb.llvm.org/">lldb</a>, <a href="https://www.gnu.org/software/gdb/">gdb</a>, <a href="https://perf.wiki.kernel.org/index.php/Main_Page">perf</a>, <a href="http://valgrind.org/">valgrind</a>, <a href="https://kcachegrind.github.io/html/Home.html">callgrind</a>, and many, many more. Our focus has been to <a href="https://michaelwoerister.github.io/2015/03/27/rust-xxdb.html">enrich the experience</a> for these tools by adding <a href="https://sourceware.org/ml/gdb-patches/2016-04/msg00570.html">Rust-specific hooks</a> and <a href="http://www.suchin.co/2016/05/11/Introducing-Cargo-Profiler/">workflows</a>. Another major priority is providing full IDE support, in part by providing daemonized services from the compiler; we made <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/ides.html">good progress</a> on that front this year, and thanks to the <a href="https://github.com/phildawes/racer">Racer</a> project, <a href="https://areweideyet.com/">numerous IDE plugins</a> are already providing some semantic support for Rust. At the same time, the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rustfmt">rustfmt</a> code formatting tool has matured to the point that the Rust community is ready to produce an <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1607">official style</a>. And the beating heart of Rust's workflow, <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2016/05/05/cargo-pillars.html">Cargo</a>, gained numerous abilities this year, most notably the <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2015/12/10/Rust-1.5.html">install subcommand</a>.</li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong>Compiler</strong>. We've seen some <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2015/06/25/Rust-1.1.html">across-the-board improvements</a> to compile times, and now offer <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2015/08/06/Rust-1.2.html">parallelized code generation</a> for further speedups. But the biggest wins will come from the ongoing work on <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1298">incremental compilation</a>, which will minimize the amount of work the needed when recompiling code after editing it. A vital step here was the move to a <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2016/04/19/MIR.html">custom intermediate representation</a>, which has many other benefits as well. Another focus has been errors, including <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/error-index.html">detailed explanations of most errors</a>, and ongoing work to <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/new-error-format/3438">improve the &quot;at a glance&quot; readability of errors</a>. Expect to hear more on both fronts soon.</li> </ul> <ul> <li><strong>Core language</strong>. We've kept one list purposefully short this year: growth in the core language. While we have some important features in the pipeline (like <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/243">improved error handling</a>, <a href="http://smallcultfollowing.com/babysteps/blog/2016/04/27/non-lexical-lifetimes-introduction/">more flexible borrowing rules</a> and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1210">specialization</a>), <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/production-user-research-summary/2530">Rust users</a> by and large are happy with the core language and prefer the community to focus on the ecosystem and tooling.</li> </ul> <p>There's a lot more to say about what's happened and what's coming up in the Rust world—over the coming months, we'll be using this blog to say it.</p> <h3 id="rust-in-community">Rust in community</h3> <p>It turns out that people like to get together and talk Rust. We had a sold out <a href="http://rustcamp.com/">RustCamp</a> last August, and several upcoming events in 2016:</p> <ul> <li>September 9-10, 2016: the first <a href="http://rustconf.com/">RustConf</a> in Portland, OR, USA;</li> <li>September 17, 2016: <a href="http://www.rustfest.eu/blog/happy-birthday-announcing-rustfest">RustFest</a>, the European community conference, in Berlin, Germany;</li> <li>October 27-18, 2016: <a href="http://rust-belt-rust.com/">Rust Belt Rust</a>, a Rust conference in Pittsburgh, PA, USA;</li> <li>71 Rust-related <a href="http://rust.meetup.com/">meetup</a> groups worldwide.</li> </ul> <p>And that's no surprise. From a personal perspective, the best part about working with Rust is its <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/community.html">community</a>. It's hard to explain quite what it's like to be part of this group, but two things stand out. First, its sheer <em>energy</em>: so much happens in any given week that <a href="https://this-week-in-rust.org/">This Week in Rust</a> is a vital resource for anyone hoping to keep up. Second, its <em>welcoming spirit</em>. Rust's core message is one of empowerment—you can <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2015/04/10/Fearless-Concurrency.html">fearlessly</a> write safe, low-level systems code—and that's reflected in the community. We're all here to learn how to be better programmers, and support each other in doing so.</p> <p>There's never been a better time to get started with Rust, whether through attending a local <a href="http://rust.meetup.com/">meetup</a>, saying hello in the <a href="https://users.rust-lang.org/">users forum</a>, watching <a href="http://www.infoq.com/presentations/rust-thread-safety">a talk</a>, or reading <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/book/">the book</a>. No matter how you find your way in, we'll be glad to have you.</p> <p>Happy birthday, Rust!</p> Taking Rust everywhere with rustup Fri, 13 May 2016 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rustup/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rustup/ <p><em>Cross-compilation</em> is an imposing term for a common kind of desire:</p> <ul> <li> <p>You want to build an app for Android, or iOS, or your router using your laptop.</p> </li> <li> <p>You want to write, test and build code on your Mac, but deploy it to your Linux server.</p> </li> <li> <p>You want your Linux-based build servers to produce binaries for all the platforms you ship on.</p> </li> <li> <p>You want to build an ultraportable binary you can ship to any Linux platform.</p> </li> <li> <p>You want to target the browser with <a href="http://kripken.github.io/emscripten-site/">Emscripten</a> or <a href="https://webassembly.github.io/">WebAssembly</a>.</p> </li> </ul> <p>In other words, <strong>you want to develop/build on one &quot;host&quot; platform, but get a final binary that runs on a different &quot;target&quot; platform</strong>.</p> <p>Thanks to the <a href="http://llvm.org">LLVM</a> backend, it's always been possible <em>in principle</em> to cross-compile Rust code: just tell the backend to use a different target! And indeed, intrepid hackers have put Rust on embedded systems <a href="http://mirrors.link/posts/cross-compiling-rust-on-os-x-for-raspberry-pi-3">like the Raspberry Pi 3</a>, <a href="https://blog.thiago.me/raspberry-pi-bare-metal-programming-with-rust/">bare metal ARM</a>, <a href="https://github.com/japaric/rust-on-openwrt">MIPS routers running OpenWRT</a>, and many others.</p> <p>But in practice, there are a lot of ducks you have to get in a row to make it work: the appropriate Rust standard library, a cross-compiling C toolchain including linker, headers and binaries for C libraries, and so on. This typically involves pouring over various blog posts and package installers to get everything &quot;just so&quot;. And the exact set of tools can be different for every pair of host and target platforms.</p> <p><strong>The Rust community has been hard at work toward the goal of &quot;push-button cross-compilation&quot;</strong>. We want to provide a complete setup for a given host/target pair with the run of a single command. Today we're happy to announce that a major portion of this work is reaching beta status: we're building binaries of the Rust standard library for a wide range of targets, and shipping them to you via a new tool called <strong><a href="https://www.rustup.rs">rustup</a></strong>.</p> <h2 id="introducing-rustup">Introducing rustup</h2> <p>At its heart, <strong>rustup is a <em>toolchain manager</em> for Rust</strong>. It can download and switch between copies of the Rust compiler and standard library for all supported platforms, and track Rust's nightly, beta, and release <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/10/30/Stability.html">channels</a>, as well as specific versions. In this way rustup is similar to the <a href="https://rvm.io/">rvm</a>, <a href="https://github.com/rbenv/rbenv">rbenv</a> and <a href="https://github.com/yyuu/pyenv">pyenv</a> tools for Ruby and Python. I'll walk through all of this functionality, and the situations where it's useful, in the rest of the post.</p> <p>Today rustup is a command line application, and I'm going to show you some examples of what it can do, but it's also a <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rustup.rs/">Rust library</a>, and eventually these features are expected to be presented through a graphical interface where appropriate — particularly on Windows. Getting cross-compilation set up should eventually be a matter of checking a box in the Rust installer.</p> <p>Our ambitions go beyond managing just the Rust toolchain: to have a true push-button experience for cross-compilation, it needs to set up the C toolchain as well. That functionality is not shipping today, but it's something we hope to incorporate over the next few months.</p> <h2 id="basic-toolchain-management">Basic toolchain management</h2> <p>Let's start with something simple: installing multiple Rust toolchains. In this example I create a new library, 'hello', then test it using rustc 1.8, then use rustup to install and test that same crate on the 1.9 beta.</p> <div style="height:420px;margin:20px;"> <script type="text/javascript" src="https://asciinema.org/a/37cr19qny7451wenmpb113s1r.js" id="asciicast-37cr19qny7451wenmpb113s1r" async data-speed="2" ></script> </div> <!-- ``` $ cargo new hello && cd hello $ rustc --version $ cargo test $ rustup install beta $ rustup run beta rustc --version $ rustup run beta cargo test ``` --> <p>That's an easy way to verify your code works on the next Rust release. That's good Rust citizenship!</p> <p>We can use <code>rustup show</code> to show us the installed toolchains, and <code>rustup update</code> to keep them up to date with Rust's releases.</p> <div style="height:420px;margin:20px;"> <script type="text/javascript" src="https://asciinema.org/a/ek7vdmfltncmgnip8cnuc6ua4.js" id="asciicast-ek7vdmfltncmgnip8cnuc6ua4" async data-speed="2" ></script> </div> <p>Finally, rustup can also change the default toolchain with <code>rustup default</code>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">$ rustc --version rustc 1.8.0 (db2939409 2016-04-11) $ rustup default 1.7.0 info: syncing channel updates for &#39;1.7.0-x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu&#39; info: downloading component &#39;rust&#39; info: installing component &#39;rust&#39; info: default toolchain set to &#39;1.7.0-x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu&#39; 1.7.0-x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu installed - rustc 1.7.0 (a5d1e7a59 2016-02-29) $ rustc --version rustc 1.7.0 (a5d1e7a59 2016-02-29) </span></pre> <p>On Windows, <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/downloads.html#win-foot">where Rust supports both the GNU and MSVC ABI</a>, you might want to switch from the default stable toolchain on Windows, which targets the 32-bit x86 architecture and the GNU ABI, to a stable toolchain that targets the 64-bit, MSVC ABI.</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">rustup default stable-x86_64-pc-windows-msvc info: syncing channel updates for &#39;stable-x86_64-pc-windows-msvc&#39; info: downloading component &#39;rustc&#39; info: downloading component &#39;rust-std&#39; ... stable-x86_64-pc-windows-msvc installed - rustc 1.8.0-stable (db2939409 2016-04-11) </span></pre> <p>Here the &quot;stable&quot; toolchain name is appended with an extra identifier indicating the compiler's architecture, in this case <code>x86_64-pc-windows-msvc</code>. This identifier is called a &quot;target triple&quot;: &quot;target&quot; because it specifies a platform for which the compiler generates (targets) machine code; and &quot;triple&quot; for historical reasons (in many cases &quot;triples&quot; are actually quads these days). Target triples are the basic way we refer to particular common platforms; <code>rustc</code> by default knows about 56 of them, and <code>rustup</code> today can obtain compilers for 14, and standard libraries for 30.</p> <h2 id="example-building-static-binaries-on-linux">Example: Building static binaries on Linux</h2> <p>Now that we've got the basic pieces in place, let's apply them to a simple cross-compilation task: building an ultraportable static binary for Linux.</p> <p>One of the unique features of Linux that has become increasingly appreciated is its stable syscall interface. Because the Linux kernel puts exceptional effort into maintaining a backward-compatible kernel interface, it's possible to distribute <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Executable_and_Linkable_Format">ELF</a> binaries with no dynamic library dependencies that will run on any version of Linux. Besides being one of the features that make Docker possible, it also allows developers to build self-contained applications and deploy them to any machine running Linux, regardless of whether it's Ubuntu or Fedora or any other distribution, and regardless of exact mix of software libraries they have installed.</p> <p>Today's Rust depends on libc, and on most Linuxes that means glibc. It's technically challenging to fully statically link glibc, which presents difficulties when using it to produce a truly standalone binary. Fortunately, an alternative exists: <a href="http://www.musl-libc.org/">musl</a>, a small, modern implementation of libc that can be easily statically linked. Rust has been compatible with musl since version 1.1, but until recently developers have needed to build their own compiler to benefit from it.</p> <p>With that background, let's walk through compiling a statically-linked Linux executable. For this example you'll want to be running Linux — that is, your <em>host platform</em> will be Linux, and your <em>target platform</em> will also be Linux, just a different flavor: musl. (Yes, this is technically cross-compilation even though both targets are Linux).</p> <p>I'm going to be running on Ubuntu 16.04 (using <a href="https://hub.docker.com/r/brson/rustup-demo/">this Docker image</a>). We'll be building the basic hello world:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">rust:~$ cargo new --bin hello &amp;&amp; cd hello rust:~/hello$ cargo run Compiling hello v0.1.0 (file:///home/rust/hello) Running `target/debug/hello` Hello, world! </span></pre> <p>That's with the default <code>x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu</code> target. And you can see it has many dynamic dependencies:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">rust:~/hello$ ldd target/debug/hello linux-vdso.so.1 =&gt; (0x00007ffe5e979000) libdl.so.2 =&gt; /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libdl.so.2 (0x00007fca26d03000) libpthread.so.0 =&gt; /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libpthread.so.0 (0x00007fca26ae6000) libgcc_s.so.1 =&gt; /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libgcc_s.so.1 (0x00007fca268cf000) libc.so.6 =&gt; /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6 (0x00007fca26506000) /lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2 (0x000056104c935000) libm.so.6 =&gt; /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libm.so.6 (0x00007fca261fd000) </span></pre> <p>To compile for musl instead call <code>cargo</code> with the argument <code>--target=x86_64-unknown-linux-musl</code>. If we just go ahead and try that we'll get an error:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">rust:~/hello$ cargo run --target=x86_64-unknown-linux-musl Compiling hello v0.1.0 (file:///home/rust/hello) error: can&#39;t find crate for `std` [E0463] error: aborting due to previous error Could not compile `hello`. ... </span></pre> <p>The error tells us that the compiler can't find <code>std</code>. That is of course because we haven't installed it.</p> <p>To start cross-compiling, you need to acquire a standard library for the target platform. Previously, this was an error-prone, manual process — cue those blog posts I mentioned earlier. But with rustup, it's just part of the usual workflow:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">rust:~/hello$ rustup target add x86_64-unknown-linux-musl info: downloading component &#39;rust-std&#39; for &#39;x86_64-unknown-linux-musl&#39; info: installing component &#39;rust-std&#39; for &#39;x86_64-unknown-linux-musl&#39; rust:~/hello$ rustup show installed targets for active toolchain -------------------------------------- x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu x86_64-unknown-linux-musl active toolchain ---------------- stable-x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu (default) rustc 1.8.0 (db2939409 2016-04-11) </span></pre> <p>So I'm running the 1.8 toolchain for Linux on 64-bit x86, as indicated by the <code>x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu</code> target triple, and now I can also target <code>x86_64-unknown-linux-musl</code>. Neat. Surely we are ready to build a slick statically-linked binary we can release into the cloud. Let's try:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">rust:~/hello$ cargo run --target=x86_64-unknown-linux-musl Compiling hello v0.1.0 (file:///hello) Running `target/x86_64-unknown-linux-musl/debug/hello` Hello, world! </span></pre> <p>And that... just worked! Run <code>ldd</code> on it for proof that it's the real deal:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">rust:~/hello$ ldd target/x86_64-unknown-linux-musl/debug/hello not a dynamic executable </span></pre> <p>Now take that <code>hello</code> binary and copy it to any x86_64 machine running Linux and it'll run just fine.</p> <p>For more advanced use of musl consider <a href="https://github.com/emk/rust-musl-builder">rust-musl-builder</a>, a Docker image set up for musl development, which helpfully includes common C libraries compiled for musl.</p> <h2 id="example-running-rust-on-android">Example: Running Rust on Android</h2> <p>One more example. This time building for Android, from Linux, i.e., <code>arm-linux-androideabi</code> from <code>x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu</code>. This can also be done from OS X or Windows, though on Windows the setup is slightly different.</p> <p>To build for Android we need to add the Android target, so let's set up another 'hello, world' project and install it.</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">rust:~$ cargo new --bin hello &amp;&amp; cd hello rust:~/hello$ rustup target add arm-linux-androideabi info: downloading component &#39;rust-std&#39; for &#39;arm-linux-androideabi&#39; info: installing component &#39;rust-std&#39; for &#39;arm-linux-androideabi&#39; rust:~/hello$ rustup show installed targets for active toolchain -------------------------------------- arm-linux-androideabi x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu active toolchain ---------------- stable-x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu (default) rustc 1.8.0 (db2939409 2016-04-11) </span></pre> <p>So let's see what happens if we try to just build our 'hello' project without installing anything further:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">rust:~/hello$ cargo build --target=arm-linux-androideabi Compiling hello v0.1.0 (file:///home/rust/hello) error: linking with `cc` failed: exit code: 1 ... (lots of noise elided) error: aborting due to previous error Could not compile `hello`. </span></pre> <p>The problem is that we don't have a linker that supports Android yet, so let's take a moment's digression to talk about building for Android. To develop for Android we need the <a href="https://developer.android.com/ndk/guides/setup.html#install">Android NDK</a>. It contains the linker <code>rustc</code> needs to create Android binaries. To just <em>build</em> Rust code that targets Android the only thing we need is the NDK, but for practical development we'll want the <a href="https://developer.android.com/sdk/index.html">Android SDK</a> too.</p> <p>On Linux, download and unpack them with the following commands (the output of which is not included here):</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">rust:~/home$ cd rust:~$ curl -O https://dl.google.com/android/android-sdk_r24.4.1-linux.tgz rust:~$ tar xzf android-sdk_r24.4.1-linux.tgz rust:~$ curl -O http://dl.google.com/android/repository/android-ndk-r10e-linux-x86_64.zip rust:~$ unzip android-ndk-r10e-linux-x86_64.zip </span></pre> <p>We further need to create what the NDK calls a <a href="https://developer.android.com/ndk/guides/standalone_toolchain.html">&quot;standalone toolchain&quot;</a>. We're going to put ours in a directory called <code>android-18-toolchain</code>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">rust:~$ android-ndk-r10e/build/tools/make-standalone-toolchain.sh \ --platform=android-18 --toolchain=arm-linux-androideabi-clang3.6 \ --install-dir=android-18-toolchain --ndk-dir=android-ndk-r10e/ --arch=arm Auto-config: --toolchain=arm-linux-androideabi-4.8, --llvm-version=3.6 Copying prebuilt binaries... Copying sysroot headers and libraries... Copying c++ runtime headers and libraries... Copying files to: android-18-toolchain Cleaning up... Done. </span></pre> <p>Let's notice a few things about these commands. First, the NDK we downloaded, <code>android-ndk-r10e-linux-x86_64.zip</code> is not the most recent release (which at the time of this writing is 'r11c'). Rust's <code>std</code> is built against <code>r10e</code> and links to symbols that are no longer included in the NDK. So for now we have to use the older NDK. Second, in building the standalone toolchain we passed <code>--platform=android-18</code> to <code>make-standalone-toolchain.sh</code>. The &quot;18&quot; here is the Android <a href="http://developer.android.com/guide/topics/manifest/uses-sdk-element.html#ApiLevels">API level</a>. Today, Rust's <code>arm-linux-androideabi</code> target is built against Android API level 18, and should theoretically be forwards-compatible with subsequent Android API levels. So we're picking level 18 to get the greatest Android compatibility that Rust presently allows.</p> <p>The final thing for us to do is tell Cargo where to find the android linker, which is in the standalone NDK toolchain we just created. To do that we configure the <code>arm-linux-androideabi</code> target in <a href="http://doc.crates.io/config.html"><code>.cargo/config</code></a> with the 'linker' value. And while we're doing that we'll go ahead and set the default target for this project to Android so we don't have to keep calling cargo with the <code>--target</code> option.</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">build</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#c82829;">target </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;arm-linux-androideabi&quot; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">target.arm-linux-androideabi</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#c82829;">linker </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;/home/rust/android-18-toolchain/bin/arm-linux-androideabi-clang&quot; </span></pre> <p>Now let's change back to the 'hello' project directory and try to build again:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">rust:~$ cd hello rust:~/hello$ cargo build Compiling hello v0.1.0 (file:///home/rust/hello) </span></pre> <p>Success! Of course just getting something to build is not the end of the story. You've also got to package your code up as an Android APK. For that you can use <a href="https://users.rust-lang.org/t/announcing-cargo-apk/5501">cargo-apk</a>.</p> <h2 id="rust-everywhere-else">Rust everywhere else</h2> <p>Rust is a software platform with the potential to run on anything with a CPU. In this post I showed you a little bit of what Rust can already do, with the rustup tool. Today Rust runs on most of the platforms you use daily. Tomorrow it will run everywhere.</p> <p>So what should you expect next?</p> <p>In the coming months we're going to continue removing barriers to Rust cross-compilation. Today rustup provides access to the standard library, but as we've seen in this post, there's more to cross-compilation than rustc + std. It's acquiring and configuring the linker and C toolchain that is the most vexing — each combination of host and target platform requires something slightly different. We want to make this easier, and will be adding &quot;NDK support&quot; to rustup. What this means will again depend on the exact scenario, but we're going to start working from the most demanded, like Android, and try to automate as much of the detection, installation and configuration of the non-Rust toolchain components as we can.
