On Android for instance, the hope is to automate everything for a basic initial setup except for accepting the licenses.</p> <p>In addition to that there are multiple efforts to improve Rust cross-compilation tooling, including <a href="https://github.com/japaric/xargo">xargo</a>, which can be used to build the standard library for targets unsupported by rustup, and <a href="https://users.rust-lang.org/t/announcing-cargo-apk/5501">cargo-apk</a>, which builds Android packages from Cargo packages.</p> <p>Finally, the most exciting platform on the horizon for Rust is not a traditional target for systems languages: the web. With <a href="http://kripken.github.io/emscripten-site/">Emscripten</a> today it's quite easy to run <em>C++</em> code on the web by converting LLVM IR to JavaScript (or the asm.js subset of JavaScript). And the upcoming <a href="https://webassembly.github.io/">WebAssembly</a> (wasm) standard will cement the web platform as a first-class target for programming languages.</p> <p><em>Rust is uniquely-positioned to be the most powerful and usable wasm-targetting language for the immediate future.</em> The same properties that make Rust so portable to real hardware makes it nearly trivial to port Rust to wasm. The same can't be said for languages with complex runtimes that include garbage collectors.</p> <p>Rust has <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/need-help-with-emscripten-port/3154">already been ported to Emscripten</a> (at least twice), but the code has not yet fully landed. This summer it's happening though: Rust + Emscripten. Rust on the Web. Rust everywhere.</p> <h2 id="epilogue">Epilogue</h2> <p>While many people are reporting success with rustup, it remains in beta, with some <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rustup.rs/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3A%22initial+release%22">key outstanding bugs</a>, and is not yet the officially recommended installation method for Rust (though you should try it). We're going to keep soliciting feedback, applying polish, and fixing bugs. Then we're going to improve the rustup installation experience on Windows by <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rustup.rs/issues/253">embedding it into a GUI that behaves like a proper Windows installer</a>.</p> <p>At that point we'll likely update the <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/downloads.html">download instructions on www.rust-lang.org</a> to recommend rustup. I expect all the existing installation methods to remain available, including the non-rustup Windows installers, but at that point our focus will be on improving the installation experience through rustup. It's also plausible that rustup itself will be packaged for package managers like Homebrew and apt.</p> <p>If you want to try rustup for yourself, visit <a href="https://www.rustup.rs">www.rustup.rs</a> and follow the instructions. Then leave feedback on the <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/beta-testing-rustup-rs/3316/112">dedicated forum thread</a>, or <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rustup.rs/issues">file bugs</a> on the issue tracker. More information about rustup is available in the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rustup.rs/blob/master/README.md">README</a>.</p> <h2 id="thanks">Thanks</h2> <p>Rust would not be the powerful system it is without the help of many individuals. Thanks to Diggory Blake for creating rustup, to Jorge Aparicio for fixing lots of cross-compilation bugs and documenting the process, Tomaka for pioneering Rust on Android, and Alex Crichton for creating the release infrastructure for Rust's many platforms.</p> <p>And thanks to all the rustup contributors: Alex Crichton, Brian Anderson, Corey Farwell, David Salter, Diggory Blake, Jacob Shaffer, Jeremiah Peschka, Joe Wilm, Jorge Aparicio, Kai Noda, Kamal Marhubi, Kevin K, llogiq, Mika Attila, NODA, Kai, Paul Padier, Severen Redwood, Taylor Cramer, Tim Neumann, trolleyman, Vadim Petrochenkov, V Jackson, Vladimir, Wayne Warren, Yasushi Abe, Y. T. Chung</p> Launching the 2016 State of Rust Survey Mon, 09 May 2016 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/2016-survey-launch/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/2016-survey-launch/ <p>Rust's first birthday is upon us (on May 15th, 2016), and we want to take this opportunity to reflect on where we've been, and where we're going. The Rust core team plans a post next week giving some of their perspective on the year. But we are also eager to hear from you.</p> <p>Thus, as part of the celebrations, the community team is pleased to announce the official <a href="http://goo.gl/forms/HaesyIg73g">2016 State of Rust Survey</a>! Whether or not you use Rust today, we want to know your opinions. Your responses will help the project understand its strengths and weaknesses, and to establish development priorities for the future.</p> <p>Completing this survey should take about 5 to 10 minutes, and is anonymous unless you choose to give us your contact information. We will be accepting submissions until June 8th, 2016. If you have any questions, please feel free to email the Rust Community team at <a href="mailto:community-team@rust-lang.org">community-team@rust-lang.org</a>.</p> <p>Please help us spread the word by sharing the above link on your social network feeds, at meetups, around your office and in other communities.</p> <p>Thanks, everyone who helped develop, polish, and test the survey! Once it closes, we will summarize and visualize the results here on <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org">http://blog.rust-lang.org/</a>.</p> <p>Happy birthday, Rust. Have another great year.</p> Cargo: predictable dependency management Thu, 05 May 2016 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/cargo-pillars/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/cargo-pillars/ <p>Cargo's goal is to make modern application package management a core value of the Rust programming language.</p> <p>In practice, this goal translates to being able to build a new browser engine like <a href="https://github.com/servo/servo">Servo</a> out of 247 community-driven libraries—and counting. Servo's build system is a thin wrapper around Cargo, and after a fresh checkout, you're only one command away from seeing the whole dependency graph built:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> Compiling num-complex v0.1.32 Compiling bitflags v0.6.0 Compiling angle v0.1.0 (https://github.com/emilio/angle?branch=servo#eefe3506) Compiling backtrace v0.2.1 Compiling smallvec v0.1.5 Compiling browserhtml v0.1.4 (https://github.com/browserhtml/browserhtml?branch=gh-pages#0ca50842) Compiling unicase v1.4.0 Compiling fnv v1.0.2 Compiling heapsize_plugin v0.1.4 ... </span></pre> <p>Why do these granular dependencies matter?</p> <p>Concretely, they mean that Servo's URL library (and many components like it) is not a deeply nested part of Servo's main tree, but rather an <a href="https://crates.io/crates/url">external library</a> that anyone in the ecosystem can use. This makes it possible for other Rust libraries, like web frameworks, to easily use a browser-grade URL library, sharing the costs and benefits of maintenance. And it flows both ways: recently, a new <a href="https://github.com/google/xi-editor">Rust-based text editor</a> was announced, and happened to provide a fast line-breaking library. Within days, that library <a href="https://twitter.com/mbrubeck/status/726791246014877696">replaced Servo's old custom linebreaker</a>, decreasing Servo's maintenance burden and increasing sharing in the Rust ecosystem.</p> <h2 id="the-core-concerns-of-dependency-management">The core concerns of dependency management</h2> <p>To make this all work at the scale of an app like Servo, you need a dependency management approach with good answers to a number of thorny questions:</p> <ol> <li> <p>How easy is it to add an external library, like a new linebreaker, to Servo?</p> </li> <li> <p>If I build Servo on a different machine, for a different architecture, in CI or for release, am I building from the same source code?</p> </li> <li> <p>If I build Servo for testing, will its indirect dependencies be compiled with debug symbols? If I build Servo for release, will its indirect dependencies be compiled with maximum optimizations? How can I be sure?</p> </li> <li> <p>If someone published a new version of one of Servo's dependencies after I commit to Servo, will my CI environment use the same source code as my machine? My production environment?</p> </li> <li> <p>If I add a new dependency (or upgrade one), can that break the build? Can it affect unrelated dependencies? Under what conditions?</p> </li> </ol> <p><strong>All of these questions (and many more like them) have one thing in common: predictability</strong>. One solution to this problem, common in the systems space, is vendoring dependencies—forking them directly into an application's repository—and then managing them manually. But this comes at a substantial per-project cost, since there's more to manage and configure. It also comes at an ecosystem-wide cost, since the work involved cannot easily be shared between libraries; it has to be redone instead for each application that brings a set of libraries together. And making sure you can answer all of the questions above, all of the time, is hard work indeed.</p> <p>Package managers for higher-level languages have shown that by turning dependency management over to a shared tool, you can have predictability, easy workflows that operate over the entire dependency graph, and increased sharing and robustness across the ecosystem. When we started planning Rust 1.0, we knew we wanted to bring these ideas to a systems setting, and making Cargo a central part of the way people use Rust was a big part of that.</p> <h2 id="pillars-of-cargo">Pillars of Cargo</h2> <p>Cargo is built on three major pillars:</p> <ol> <li> <p>Building, testing, and running projects should be predictable across environments and over time.</p> </li> <li> <p>To the extent possible, indirect dependencies should be invisible to application authors.</p> </li> <li> <p>Cargo should provide a shared workflow for the Rust ecosystem that aids the first two goals.</p> </li> </ol> <p>We'll look at each of these pillars in turn.</p> <h2 id="predictability">Predictability</h2> <p>Cargo's predictability goals start with a simple guarantee: <strong>once a project successfully compiles on one machine, subsequent compiles across machines and environments will use exactly the same source code</strong>.</p> <p>This guarantee is accomplished without incorporating the source code for dependencies directly into a project repository. Instead, Cargo uses several strategies:</p> <ol> <li> <p>The first time a build succeeds, Cargo emits a <code>Cargo.lock</code> file, which contains a manifest of precisely which source code was used in the build. (more on &quot;precise&quot; in a bit)</p> </li> <li> <p>Cargo manages the entire workflow, from running tests and benchmarks, to building release artifacts, to running executables for debugging. This allows Cargo to ensure that all dependencies (direct and indirect) are downloaded and properly configured for these use-cases without the user having to do anything extra.</p> </li> <li> <p>Cargo standardizes important environment configuration, like optimization level, static and dynamic linking, and architecture. Combined with the <code>Cargo.lock</code>, this makes the results of building, testing and executing Cargo projects highly predictable.</p> </li> </ol> <h3 id="predictability-by-example">Predictability By Example</h3> <p>To illustrate these strategies, let's build an example crate using Cargo. To keep things simple, we'll create a small <code>datetime</code> crate that exposes date and time functionality.</p> <p>First, we'll use <code>cargo new</code> to start us out:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">$ cargo new datetime $ cd datetime $ ls Cargo.toml src $ cat Cargo.toml [package] name = &quot;datetime&quot; version = &quot;0.1.0&quot; authors = [&quot;Yehuda Katz &lt;wycats@gmail.com&gt;&quot;] [dependencies] </span></pre> <p>We don't want to build the date or time functionality from scratch, so let's edit the <code>Cargo.toml</code> and add the <code>time</code> crate from <a href="https://crates.io/">crates.io</a>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> [package] name = &quot;datetime&quot; version = &quot;0.1.0&quot; authors = [&quot;Yehuda Katz &lt;wycats@gmail.com&gt;&quot;] [dependencies] </span><span style="background-color:#718c00;color:#ffffff;">+ time = &quot;0.1.35&quot; </span></pre> <p>Now that we've added the <code>time</code> crate, let's see what happens if we ask Cargo to build our package:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">cargo build Compiling winapi v0.2.6 Compiling libc v0.2.10 Compiling winapi-build v0.1.1 Compiling kernel32-sys v0.2.2 Compiling time v0.1.35 Compiling datetime v0.1.0 (file:///Users/ykatz/Code/datetime) </span></pre> <p>Whoa! That's a lot of crates. <strong>The biggest part of Cargo's job is to provide enough predictability to allow functionality like the <code>time</code> crate to be broken up into smaller crates that do one thing and do it well</strong>.</p> <p>Now that we successfully built our crate, what happens if we try to build it again?</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">cargo build </span></pre> <p>Nothing happened at all. Why's that? We can always ask Cargo to give us more information through the <code>--verbose</code> flag, so let's do that:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">cargo build --verbose Fresh libc v0.2.10 Fresh winapi v0.2.6 Fresh winapi-build v0.1.1 Fresh kernel32-sys v0.2.2 Fresh time v0.1.35 Fresh datetime v0.1.0 (file:///Users/ykatz/Code/datetime) </span></pre> <p>Cargo isn't bothering to recompile packages that it knows are &quot;fresh&quot;, like <code>make</code>, but without having to write the <code>Makefile</code>.</p> <p>But how does Cargo know that everything is fresh? When Cargo builds a crate, it emits a file called <code>Cargo.lock</code> that contains the precise versions of all of its resolved dependencies:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">root</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#c82829;">name </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;datetime&quot; </span><span style="color:#c82829;">version </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;0.1.0&quot; </span><span style="color:#c82829;">dependencies </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= [ </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;libc 0.2.10 (registry+https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index)&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;time 0.1.35 (registry+https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index)&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, ] [[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">package</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">]] </span><span style="color:#c82829;">name </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;kernel32-sys&quot; </span><span style="color:#c82829;">version </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;0.2.2&quot; </span><span style="color:#c82829;">source </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;registry+https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index&quot; </span><span style="color:#c82829;">dependencies </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= [ </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;winapi 0.2.6 (registry+https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index)&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;winapi-build 0.1.1 (registry+https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index)&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, ] ... </span></pre> <p>The <code>Cargo.lock</code> contains a serialized version of the entire <strong>resolved</strong> dependency graph, including precise versions of all of the source code included in the build. In the case of a package from crates.io, Cargo stores the name and version of the dependency. This is enough information to uniquely identify source code from <a href="https://crates.io/">crates.io</a>, because the registry is <em>append only</em> (no changes to already-published packages are allowed).</p> <p>In addition, the metadata for the registry is stored in a <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index/">separate git repository</a>, and includes checksum for the relevant package. Before Cargo ever unpacks a crate it downloads, it first validates the checksum.</p> <h3 id="collaborating">Collaborating</h3> <p>Now for the real test. Let's push our code up to GitHub and develop it on a different machine. Ideally, we would like to be able to pick up right where we left off, with the exact same source code for all of our dependencies.</p> <p>To do this, we check in our <code>Cargo.lock</code> and clone the repository on our new machine. Then, we run <code>cargo build</code> again.</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">cargo build Compiling libc v0.2.10 Compiling winapi v0.2.6 Compiling winapi-build v0.1.1 Compiling kernel32-sys v0.2.2 Compiling time v0.1.35 Compiling datetime v0.1.0 (file:///Users/ykatz/Code/datetime) </span></pre> <p>As expected, <strong>because we checked in our <code>Cargo.lock</code> we get exactly the same versions of all dependencies as before</strong>. And if we wanted to start collaborating with other developers on GitHub (or with other members of our team at work), we would continue to get the same level of predictability.</p> <h3 id="common-conventions-examples-tests-and-docs">Common conventions: examples, tests, and docs</h3> <p>Now that we've written our snazzy new <code>datetime</code> crate, we'd love to write an example to show other developers how it should be used. We create a new file called <code>examples/date.rs</code> that looks like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">extern crate datetime; fn main() { println!(&quot;{}&quot;, datetime::DateTime::now()); } </span></pre> <p>To run the example, we ask Cargo to build and run it:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">cargo run --example date Compiling datetime v0.1.0 (file:///Users/ykatz/Code/datetime) Running `target/debug/examples/date` 26 Apr 2016 :: 05:03:38 </span></pre> <p>Because we put our code in the conventional location for examples, Cargo knew how to do the right thing, no sweat.</p> <p>In addition, once you start writing a few tests, <code>cargo test</code> will automatically build your examples as well, which prevents them from getting out of sync with your code, and ensures they continue to compile as long as your tests are passing.</p> <p>Similarly, the <code>cargo doc</code> command will automatically compile not just your code, but that of your dependencies as well. The upshot is that the API docs it automatically produces include the crates you depend on, so if your APIs mention types from those crates, your clients can follow those links.</p> <p>These are just a few examples of a general point: <strong>Cargo defines a common set of conventions and workflows that operate precisely the same way across the entire Rust ecosystem</strong>.</p> <h3 id="updating">Updating</h3> <p>All of this means that your application won't change if you don't make any changes to your dependencies, but what happens when you need to change them?</p> <p>Cargo adds another layer of protection with <em>conservative updates</em>. This means that if you modify your <code>Cargo.toml</code>, Cargo attempts to minimize the changes made to the <code>Cargo.lock</code>. The intuition of conservative updates is: <strong>if the change you made was unrelated to another dependency, it shouldn't change</strong>.</p> <p>Let's say that after developing the library for a little while, we decide that we want to add support for time zones. First, let's add in the <code>tz</code> dependency to our package:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> [package] name = &quot;datetime&quot; version = &quot;0.1.0&quot; authors = [&quot;Yehuda Katz &lt;wycats@gmail.com&gt;&quot;] [dependencies] time = &quot;0.1.35&quot; + tz = &quot;0.2.1&quot; </span></pre> <p>After using the crate in our library, let's run <code>cargo build</code> again:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">cargo build Updating registry `https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index` Downloading tz v0.2.1 Downloading byteorder v0.5.1 Compiling byteorder v0.5.1 Compiling tz v0.2.1 Compiling datetime v0.1.0 (file:///Users/ykatz/Code/datetime) </span></pre> <p>Cargo downloaded <code>tz</code> (and its dependency <code>byteorder</code>) and compiled them, but it didn't touch the packages we were already using (<code>kernel32-sys</code>, <code>libc</code>, <code>time</code>, <code>winapi</code> and <code>winapi-build</code>). Even if one of those package authors published an update in the meantime, you can be sure that adding new crates won't mess with unrelated ones.</p> <p>Conservative updates attempt to significantly reduce unexpected changes to your source code. It stands in stark contrast to 'rebuild the world', which allows a small change to dependencies to rebuild the entire graph, wreaking havoc in its wake.</p> <p><strong>As a rule, Cargo attempts to minimize the effects of intentional changes to direct dependencies.</strong></p> <h2 id="indirect-dependencies-just-work">Indirect Dependencies &quot;Just Work&quot;</h2> <p>One of the most basic goals of an application package manager is separating direct dependencies, which are required by the application, and indirect dependencies, which those dependencies need in order to work.</p> <p>As we've seen in the <code>datetime</code> crate we built, we only needed to specify dependencies on <code>time</code> and <code>tz</code>, and Cargo automatically created the entire graph of dependencies needed to make that work. It also serialized that graph for future predictability.</p> <p>Since Cargo manages your dependencies for you, it can also make sure that it compiles all of your dependencies (whether you knew about them directly or not) appropriately for the task at hand.</p> <h3 id="testing-benchmarking-releasing-oh-my">Testing, Benchmarking, Releasing, Oh My</h3> <p>Historically, people have shied away from the kinds of granular dependencies we've seen here because of the configuration needed for each new dependency.</p> <p>For example, when running tests or type-checking your code, you would like to compile the code as fast as possible to keep the feedback loop fast. On the other hand, when benchmarking or releasing your code, you are willing to spend plenty of time waiting for the compiler to optimize your code if it produces a fast binary.</p> <p>It's important to compile not only your own code or your direct dependencies, but all indirect dependencies with the same configuration.</p> <p>Cargo manages that process for you automatically. Let's add a benchmark to our code:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">#[bench] fn bench_date(b: &amp;mut Bencher) { b.iter(|| DateTime::now()); } </span></pre> <p>If we then run <code>cargo bench</code>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">cargo bench Compiling winapi v0.2.6 Compiling libc v0.2.10 Compiling byteorder v0.5.1 Compiling winapi-build v0.1.1 Compiling kernel32-sys v0.2.2 Compiling tz v0.2.1 Compiling time v0.1.35 Compiling datetime v0.1.0 (file:///Users/ykatz/Code/datetime) Running target/release/datetime-2602656fcee02e68 running 1 test test bench_date ... bench: 486 ns/iter (+/- 56) </span></pre> <p>Notice that we're re-compiling all of our dependencies. This is because <code>cargo bench</code> defaults to release mode, which uses maximum optimizations. <code>cargo build --release</code> similarly builds in optimized mode by default.</p> <blockquote> <p>As an aside, the default behavior of each command is configurable through <a href="http://doc.crates.io/manifest.html#the-profile-sections">profiles</a> in the <code>Cargo.toml</code>. This allows you to configure things like the optimization level, whether to include debug symbols and more. Rather than forcing you to use a custom workflow if something doesn't precisely meet your needs, the profiles feature allows you to customize the existing workflows and stay within Cargo's flows.</p> </blockquote> <h3 id="platforms-and-architectures">Platforms and Architectures</h3> <p>Similarly, applications are often built for different architectures, operating systems, or even operating system version. They can be compiled for maximum portability or to make maximum use of available platform features.</p> <p>Libraries can be compiled as static libraries or dynamic libraries. And even static libraries might want to do some dynamic linking (for example, against the system version of <code>openssl</code>).</p> <p><strong>By standardizing what it means to build and configure a package, Cargo can apply all of these configuration choices to your direct dependencies <em>and</em> indirect dependencies</strong>.</p> <h3 id="shared-dependencies">Shared Dependencies</h3> <p>So far, we've looked at packages and their dependencies. But what if two packages that your application depends on share a third dependency?</p> <p>For example, let's say that I decide to add the <code>nix</code> crate to my <code>datetime</code> library for Unix-specific functionality.</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> [package] name = &quot;datetime&quot; version = &quot;0.1.0&quot; authors = [&quot;Yehuda Katz &lt;wycats@gmail.com&gt;&quot;] [dependencies] time = &quot;0.1.35&quot; tz = &quot;0.2.1&quot; + nix = &quot;0.5.0&quot; </span></pre> <p>As before, when I run <code>cargo build</code>, Cargo <em>conservatively</em> adds <code>nix</code> and its dependencies:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">cargo build Updating registry `https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index` Downloading nix v0.5.0 Downloading bitflags v0.4.0 Compiling bitflags v0.4.0 Compiling nix v0.5.0 Compiling datetime v0.1.0 (file:///Users/ykatz/Code/datetime) </span></pre> <p>But if we look a little closer, we'll notice that <code>nix</code> has a dependency on <code>bitflags</code> <em>and</em> <code>libc</code>. It now <em>shares</em> the dependency on <code>libc</code> with the <code>date</code> package.</p> <p>If my <code>datetime</code> crate gets <code>libc</code> types from <code>time</code> and hands them off to <code>nix</code>, they better be the same <code>libc</code> or my program won't compile (and we wouldn't want it to!)</p> <p>Today, Cargo will automatically share dependencies between crates if they depend on the same <em>major</em> version (or minor version before 1.0), since Rust uses <a href="http://semver.org/">semantic versioning</a>. This means that if <code>nix</code> and <code>datetime</code> both depend on some version of <code>libc 0.2.x</code>, they will get the same version. In this case, they do, and the program compiles.</p> <p>While this policy works well (and in fact is the same policy that system package managers use), it doesn't always do exactly what people expect, especially when it comes to coordinating a major version bump across the ecosystem. (In many cases, it would be preferable for Cargo to hard-error than assume that a dependency on <code>0.2.x</code> is simply unrelated to another dependency on <code>0.3.x</code>.)</p> <p>This problem is especially pernicious when multiple major versions of the same package expose global symbols (using <code>#[no_mangle]</code> for example, or by including other statically linked C libraries).</p> <p>We have some thoughts on ways to improve Cargo to handle these cases better, including the ability for a package to more explicitly express when a dependency is used purely internally and is not shared through its public interface. Those packages could be more readily duplicated if needed, while dependencies that are used in a package's public interface must not be.</p> <p>You should expect to see more on this topic in the months ahead.</p> <h2 id="workflow">Workflow</h2> <p>As we've seen, <strong>Cargo is not just a dependency manager, but Rust's primary workflow tool</strong>.</p> <p>This allows Rust to have a rich ecosystem of interconnected dependencies, eliminating the need for applications to manually manage large dependency graphs. Applications can benefit from a vibrant ecosystem of small packages that do one thing and do it well, and let Cargo handle the heavy lifting of keeping everything up to date and compiling correctly.</p> <p>Even a small crate like the <code>datetime</code> example we built has a few dependencies on small, targeted crates, and each of those crates has some dependencies of its own.</p> <p>By defining shared, well-known workflows, like &quot;build&quot;, &quot;test&quot;, &quot;bench&quot;, &quot;run&quot;, and &quot;doc&quot;, Cargo provides Rust programmers with a way to think about what they're trying to accomplish at a high level, and not have to worry about what each of those workflows mean for indirect dependencies.</p> <p>This allows us to get closer to the holy grail of making those indirect dependency graphs &quot;invisible&quot;, empowering individuals to do more on their hobby projects, small teams to do more on their products, and large teams to have a high degree of confidence in the output of their work.</p> <p>With a workflow tool that provides predictability, even in the face of many indirect dependencies, we can all build higher together.</p> Introducing MIR Tue, 19 Apr 2016 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/mir/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/mir/ <p>We are in the final stages of a grand transformation on the Rust compiler internals. Over the past year or so, we have been steadily working on a plan to change our internal compiler pipeline, as shown here:</p> <p><img src="/images/2016-04-MIR/flow.svg" alt="Compiler Flowchart" /></p> <p>That is, we are introducing a new intermediate representation (IR) of your program that we call <strong>MIR</strong>: MIR stands for <em>mid-level</em> IR, because the MIR comes between the existing HIR (&quot;high-level IR&quot;, roughly an <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abstract_syntax_tree">abstract syntax tree</a>) and <a href="http://llvm.org/">LLVM</a> (the &quot;low-level&quot; IR). Previously, the &quot;translation&quot; phase in the compiler would convert from full-blown Rust into machine-code-like LLVM in one rather large step. But now, it will do its work in two phases, with a vastly simplified version of Rust -- MIR -- standing in the middle.</p> <p>If you're not a compiler enthusiast, this all might seem arcane and unlikely to affect you directly. But in reality, <strong>MIR is the key to ticking off a number of our highest priorities</strong> for Rust:</p> <ul> <li> <p><strong>Faster compilation time</strong>. We are working to make Rust's compilation <em>incremental</em>, so that when you <em>re</em>-compile code, the compiler recomputes only what it has to. MIR has been designed from the start with this use-case in mind, so it's much easier for us to save and reload, even if other parts of the program have changed in the meantime.</p> <p>MIR also provides a foundation for more efficient data structures and removal of redundant work in the compiler, both of which should speed up compilation across the board.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Faster execution time</strong>. You may have noticed that in the new compiler pipeline, <em>optimization</em> appears twice. That's no accident: previously, the compiler relied solely on LLVM to perform optimizations, but with MIR, we can do some <em>Rust-specific</em> optimizations before ever hitting LLVM -- or, for that matter, before monomorphizing code. Rust's rich type system should provide fertile ground for going beyond LLVM's optimizations.</p> <p>In addition, MIR will uncork some longstanding performance improvements to the code Rust generates, like <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/0320-nonzeroing-dynamic-drop.md">&quot;non-zeroing&quot; drop</a>.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>More precise type checking</strong>. Today's Rust compiler imposes some artificial restrictions on <em>borrowing</em>, restrictions which largely stem from the way the compiler currently represents programs. MIR will enable <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/issues/811">much more flexible borrowing</a>, which will in turn improve Rust's ergonomics and learning curve.</p> </li> </ul> <p>Beyond these banner user-facing improvements, <strong>MIR also has substantial engineering benefits for the compiler</strong>:</p> <ul> <li> <p><strong>Eliminating redundancy.</strong> Currently, because we write all of our passes in terms of the full Rust language, there is quite a lot of duplication. For example, both the safety analyses and the backend which produces LLVM IR must agree about how to translate drops, or the precise order in which <code>match</code> expression arms will be tested and executed (which can get quite complex). With MIR, all of that logic is centralized in MIR construction, and the later passes can just rely on that.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Raising ambitions.</strong> In addition to being more <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Don%27t_repeat_yourself">DRY</a>, working with MIR is just plain <em>easier</em>, because it contains a much more primitive set of operations than ordinary Rust. This simplification enables us to do a lot of things that were forbodingly complex before. We'll look at one such case in this post -- non-zeroing drop -- but as we'll see at the end, there are already many others in the pipeline.</p> </li> </ul> <p>Needless to say, we're excited, and the Rust community has stepped up in a big way to make MIR a reality. The compiler can bootstrap and run its test suite using MIR, and these tests have to pass on every new commit. Once we're able to run <a href="https://github.com/brson/taskcluster-crater">Crater</a> with MIR enabled and see no regressions across the entire <a href="http://crates.io/">crates.io</a> ecosystem, we'll turn it on by default (or, you'll forgive a terrible (wonderful) pun, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mir">launch MIR into orbit</a>).</p> <p>This blog post begins with an overview of MIR's design, demonstrating some of the ways that MIR is able to abstract away the full details of the Rust language. Next, we look at how MIR will help with implementing <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/0320-nonzeroing-dynamic-drop.md">non-zeroing drops</a>, a long-desired optimization. If after this post you find you are hungry for more, have a look at the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/1211-mir.md">RFC that introduced MIR</a>, or jump right into <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/f7ec6873ccfbf7dcdbd1908c0857c866b3e7087a/src/librustc/mir/repr.rs">the code</a>. (Compiler buffs may be particularly interested in the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/1211-mir.md#alternatives">alternatives section</a>, which discusses certain design choices in detail, such as why MIR does not currently use SSA.)</p> Announcing Rust 1.8 Thu, 14 Apr 2016 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-8/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-8/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce the latest version of Rust, 1.8. Rust is a systems programming language focused on safety, speed, and concurrency.</p> <p>As always, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">install Rust 1.8</a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/stable/RELEASES.md#version-180-2016-04-14">detailed release notes for 1.8</a> on GitHub. About 1400 patches were landed in this release.</p> <h3 id="what-s-in-1-8-stable">What's in 1.8 stable</h3> <p>There are two new features in Rust 1.8, as well as good news for Windows users! Additionally, work is underway to replace our <code>make</code>-based build system with one based on Cargo.</p> <p>The first feature is that the various “operator equals” operators, such as <code>+=</code> and <code>-=</code>, are now overloadable via various traits. This change was accepted in <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/0953-op-assign.md">RFC 953</a>, and looks like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">use </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">std::ops::AddAssign; #[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">derive</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(Debug)] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Count { </span><span style="color:#c82829;">value</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">impl </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">AddAssign </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">for </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Count { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">add_assign</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">mut </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">other</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: Count) { </span><span style="color:#c82829;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">.value </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+=</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> other.value; } } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> c1 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> Count { value: </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">}; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> c2 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> Count { value: </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">5 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">}; c1 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+=</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> c2; println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#666969;">{:?}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, c1); } </span></pre> <p>This will print out <code>Count { value: 6 }</code>. Like the other operator traits, an associated type allows you to use different types on each side of the operator, as well. See the RFC for more details.</p> <p>The second feature is very small, and comes from <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/0218-empty-struct-with-braces.md">RFC 218</a>. Before Rust 1.8, a <code>struct</code> with no fields did not have curly braces:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Foo; </span><span style="color:#999999;">// works </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Bar { } </span><span style="color:#999999;">// error </span></pre> <p>The second form is no longer an error. This was originally disallowed for consistency with other empty declarations, as well as a parsing ambiguity. However, that ambiguity is non-existent in post-1.0 Rust. Macro authors saw additional complexity due to needing a special-case, as well. Finally, users who do active development would sometimes switch between empty and non-empty versions of a struct, and the extra work and diffs involved was less than ideal.</p> <p>On the Windows front, 32-bit MSVC builds <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/30448">now implement unwinding</a>. This moves <code>i686-pc-windows-msvc</code> to a Tier 1 platform.</p> <p>Finally, we have used <code>make</code> to build Rust for a very long time. However, we already have a wonderful tool for building Rust programs: Cargo. In Rust 1.8, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/31123">initial support landed</a> for a new build system that’s written in Rust, and based on Cargo. It is not yet the default, and there is much more work to do. We will talk about this in release notes more once it’s completely done, for now, please read the GitHub issue for more details.</p> <h4 id="library-stabilizations">Library stabilizations</h4> <p>About 20 library functions and methods are now stable in 1.8. There are three major groups of changes: UTF-16 related string methods, various APIs related to time, and the various traits needed for operator overloading mentioned in the language section.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/stable/RELEASES.md#version-180-2016-04-14">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h4 id="cargo-features">Cargo features</h4> <p>There were a few updates to Cargo:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/2081"><code>cargo init</code></a> can be used to start a Cargo project in your current working directory, rather than making a new subdirectory like <code>cargo new</code>.</li> <li><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/2196"><code>cargo metadata</code></a> is another new subcommand for fetching metadata about a project.</li> <li><code>.cargo/config</code> now has <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/2397">keys for <code>-v</code> and <code>--color</code></a></li> <li>Cargo’s ability to have target-specific dependencies <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/2328">was enhanced</a>.</li> </ul> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/stable/RELEASES.md#version-180-2016-04-14">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h3 id="contributors-to-1-8">Contributors to 1.8</h3> <p>We had 126 individuals contribute to 1.8. Thank you so much!</p> <ul> <li>Aaron Turon</li> <li>Abhishek Chanda</li> <li>Adolfo Ochagavía</li> <li>Aidan Hobson Sayers</li> <li>Alan Somers</li> <li>Alejandro Wainzinger</li> <li>Aleksey Kladov</li> <li>Alex Burka</li> <li>Alex Crichton</li> <li>Amanieu d'Antras</li> <li>Andrea Canciani</li> <li>Andreas Linz</li> <li>Andrew Cantino</li> <li>Andrew Horton</li> <li>Andrew Paseltiner</li> <li>Andrey Cherkashin</li> <li>Angus Lees</li> <li>arcnmx</li> <li>Ariel Ben-Yehuda</li> <li>ashleysommer</li> <li>Benjamin Herr</li> <li>Валерий Лашманов</li> <li>Björn Steinbrink</li> <li>bors</li> <li>Brian Anderson</li> <li>Brian Bowman</li> <li>Christian Wesselhoeft</li> <li>Christopher Serr</li> <li>Corey Farwell</li> <li>Craig M. Brandenburg</li> <li>Cyryl Płotnicki-Chudyk</li> <li>Daniel J Rollins</li> <li>Dave Huseby</li> <li>David AO Lozano</li> <li>David Henningsson</li> <li>Devon Hollowood</li> <li>Dirk Gadsden</li> <li>Doug Goldstein</li> <li>Eduard Burtescu</li> <li>Eduard-Mihai Burtescu</li> <li>Eli Friedman</li> <li>Emanuel Czirai</li> <li>Erick Tryzelaar</li> <li>Evan</li> <li>Felix S. Klock II</li> <li>Florian Berger</li> <li>Geoff Catlin</li> <li>ggomez</li> <li>gohyda</li> <li>Gökhan Karabulut</li> <li>Guillaume Gomez</li> <li>ituxbag</li> <li>James Miller</li> <li>Jeffrey Seyfried</li> <li>John Talling</li> <li>Jonas Schievink</li> <li>Jonathan S</li> <li>Jorge Aparicio</li> <li>Joshua Holmer</li> <li>JP Sugarbroad</li> <li>Kai Noda</li> <li>Kamal Marhubi</li> <li>Katze</li> <li>Kevin Brothaler</li> <li>Kevin Butler</li> <li>Manish Goregaokar</li> <li>Markus Westerlind</li> <li>Marvin Löbel</li> <li>Masood Malekghassemi</li> <li>Matt Brubeck</li> <li>Michael Huynh</li> <li>Michael Neumann</li> <li>Michael Woerister</li> <li>mitaa</li> <li>Ms2ger</li> <li>Nathan Kleyn</li> <li>nicholasf</li> <li>Nick Cameron</li> <li>Niko Matsakis</li> <li>Noah</li> <li>NODA, Kai</li> <li>Novotnik, Petr</li> <li>Oliver Middleton</li> <li>Oliver Schneider</li> <li>petevine</li> <li>Philipp Oppermann</li> <li>pierzchalski</li> <li>Piotr Czarnecki</li> <li>pravic</li> <li>Pyfisch</li> <li>Richo Healey</li> <li>Ruud van Asseldonk</li> <li>Scott Olson</li> <li>Sean McArthur</li> <li>Sebastian Wicki</li> <li>Sébastien Marie</li> <li>Seo Sanghyeon</li> <li>Simonas Kazlauskas</li> <li>Simon Sapin</li> <li>srinivasreddy</li> <li>Steve Klabnik</li> <li>Steven Allen</li> <li>Steven Fackler</li> <li>Stu Black</li> <li>Tang Chenglong</li> <li>Ted Horst</li> <li>Ticki</li> <li>tiehuis</li> <li>Tim Montague</li> <li>Tim Neumann</li> <li>Timon Van Overveldt</li> <li>Tobias Bucher</li> <li>Tobias Müller</li> <li>Todd Lucas</li> <li>Tom Tromey</li> <li>Tshepang Lekhonkhobe</li> <li>ubsan</li> <li>Ulrik Sverdrup</li> <li>Vadim Petrochenkov</li> <li>vagrant</li> <li>Valentin Lorentz</li> <li>Varun Vats</li> <li>vegai</li> <li>vlastachu</li> <li>Wangshan Lu</li> <li>York Xiang</li> </ul> Announcing Rust 1.7 Wed, 02 Mar 2016 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-7/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-7/ <p>The Rust team is happy to announce the latest version of Rust, 1.7. Rust is a systems programming language focused on safety, speed, and concurrency.</p> <p>As always, you can <a href="https://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">install Rust 1.7</a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/stable/RELEASES.md#version-170-2016-03-03">detailed release notes for 1.7</a> on GitHub. About 1300 patches were landed in this release.</p> <h3 id="what-s-in-1-7-stable">What's in 1.7 stable</h3> <p>This release is primarily about library features. While we have several language features cooking for future releases, the timeframe in which 1.7 was developed included the holidays, which means less time for commenting on GitHub and more time for spending with loved ones.</p> <h4 id="library-stabilizations">Library stabilizations</h4> <p>About 40 library functions and methods are now stable in 1.7. One of the largest APIs stabilized was support for custom hash algorithms in the standard library’s <code>HashMap&lt;K, V&gt;</code> type. Previously all hash maps would use <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SipHash">SipHash</a> as the hashing algorithm, which provides protection against DOS attacks by default. SipHash, however, is <a href="http://cglab.ca/%7Eabeinges/blah/hash-rs/">not very fast</a> at hashing small keys. As shown, however, the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fowler%E2%80%93Noll%E2%80%93Vo_hash_function">FNV hash algorithm</a> is much faster for these size of inputs. This means that by switching hash algorithms for types like <code>HashMap&lt;usize, V&gt;</code> there can be a significant speedup so long as the loss of DOS protection is acceptable.</p> <p>To see this in action, you can check out the <a href="https://crates.io/crates/fnv">fnv crate</a> on <a href="https://crates.io">crates.io</a> and create a <code>HashMap</code> via:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">extern crate</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> fnv; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">use </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">std::collections::HashMap; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">use </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">std::hash::BuildHasherDefault; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">use </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">fnv::FnvHasher; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">type </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">MyHasher </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">BuildHasherDefault&lt;FnvHasher&gt;; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> map: HashMap&lt;</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">_</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">_</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, MyHasher&gt; </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">HashMap::default(); map.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">insert</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;Hello&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); map.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">insert</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;, world!&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#666969;">{:?}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, map); } </span></pre> <p>Note that most of the time you don’t even need to specify the hasher as type inference will take care of it, so <code>HashMap::default()</code> should be all you need to get up to 2x faster hashes. It’s also worth pointing out that <a href="http://doc.rust-lang.org/std/hash/trait.Hash.html"><code>Hash</code></a> trait is agnostic to the hashing algorithm used, so no changes are needed to the types being inserted into hash maps to reap the benefits!</p> <p>Other notable improvements include:</p> <ul> <li><code>&lt;[T]&gt;::clone_from_slice()</code>, an efficient way to copy the data from one slice and put it into another slice.</li> <li>Various convenience methods on <code>Ipv4Addr</code> and <code>Ipv6Addr</code>, such as <code>is_loopback()</code>, which returns <code>true</code> or <code>false</code> if the address is a loopback address according to RFC 6890.</li> <li>Various improvements to <code>CString</code>, used for FFI.</li> <li>checked, saturated, and overflowing operations for various numeric types. These aren’t counted in that ‘40’ number above, because there are a <em>lot</em> of them, but they all do the same thing.</li> </ul> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/stable/RELEASES.md#version-170-2016-03-03">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h4 id="cargo-features">Cargo features</h4> <p>There were a few small updates to Cargo:</p> <ul> <li>An <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/2279">improvement to build scripts</a> that allows them to precisely inform Cargo about dependencies to ensure that they’re only rerun when those files change. This should help development quite a bit in repositories with build scripts.</li> <li>A <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/2224">modification to the <code>cargo rustc</code> subcommand</a>, which allows specifying profiles to pull in dev-dependencies during testing and such.</li> </ul> <h3 id="contributors-to-1-7">Contributors to 1.7</h3> <p>We had 144 individuals contribute to 1.7. Thank you so much!</p> <ul> <li>Aaron Turon</li> <li>Adam Perry</li> <li>Adrian Heine</li> <li>Aidan Hobson Sayers</li> <li>Aleksey Kladov</li> <li>Alexander Lopatin</li> <li>Alex Burka</li> <li>Alex Crichton</li> <li>Ali Clark</li> <li>Amanieu d’Antras</li> <li>Andrea Bedini</li> <li>Andrea Canciani</li> <li>Andre Bogus</li> <li>Andrew Barchuk</li> <li>Andrew Paseltiner</li> <li>angelsl</li> <li>Anton Blanchard</li> <li>arcnmx</li> <li>Ariel Ben-Yehuda</li> <li>arthurprs</li> <li>ashleysommer</li> <li>Barosl Lee</li> <li>Benjamin Herr</li> <li>Björn Steinbrink</li> <li>bors</li> <li>Brandon W Maister</li> <li>Brian Anderson</li> <li>Brian Campbell</li> <li>Carlos E. Garcia</li> <li>Chad Shaffer</li> <li>Corey Farwell</li> <li>Daan Sprenkels</li> <li>Daniel Campbell</li> <li>Daniel Robertson</li> <li>Dave Hodder</li> <li>Dave Huseby</li> <li>dileepb</li> <li>Dirk Gadsden</li> <li>Eduard Burtescu</li> <li>Erick Tryzelaar</li> <li>est31</li> <li>Evan</li> <li>Fabrice Desré</li> <li>fbergr</li> <li>Felix Gruber</li> <li>Felix S. Klock II</li> <li>Florian Hahn</li> <li>Geoff Catlin</li> <li>Geoffrey Thomas</li> <li>Georg Brandl</li> <li>ggomez</li> <li>Gleb Kozyrev</li> <li>Gökhan Karabulut</li> <li>Greg Chapple</li> <li>Guillaume Bonnet</li> <li>Guillaume Gomez</li> <li>Ivan Kozik</li> <li>Jack O’Connor</li> <li>Jeffrey Seyfried</li> <li>Johan Lorenzo</li> <li>Johannes Oertel</li> <li>John Hodge</li> <li>John Kåre Alsaker</li> <li>Jonas Schievink</li> <li>Jonathan Reem</li> <li>Jonathan S</li> <li>Jorge Aparicio</li> <li>Josh Stone</li> <li>Kamal Marhubi</li> <li>Katze</li> <li>Keith Yeung</li> <li>Kenneth Koski</li> <li>Kevin Stock</li> <li>Luke Jones</li> <li>Manish Goregaokar</li> <li>Marc Bowes</li> <li>Marvin Löbel</li> <li>Masood Malekghassemi</li> <li>Matt Brubeck</li> <li>Mátyás Mustoha</li> <li>Michael Huynh</li> <li>Michael Neumann</li> <li>Michael Woerister</li> <li>mitaa</li> <li>mopp</li> <li>Nathan Kleyn</li> <li>Nicholas Mazzuca</li> <li>Nick Cameron</li> <li>Nikita Baksalyar</li> <li>Niko Matsakis</li> <li>NODA, Kai</li> <li>nxnfufunezn</li> <li>Olaf Buddenhagen</li> <li>Oliver ‘ker’ Schneider</li> <li>Oliver Middleton</li> <li>Oliver Schneider</li> <li>Pascal Hertleif</li> <li>Paul Dicker</li> <li>Paul Smith</li> <li>Peter Atashian</li> <li>Peter Kolloch</li> <li>petevine</li> <li>Pierre Krieger</li> <li>Piotr Czarnecki</li> <li>Prayag Verma</li> <li>qpid</li> <li>Ravi Shankar</li> <li>Reeze Xia</li> <li>Richard Bradfield</li> <li>Robin Kruppe</li> <li>rphmeier</li> <li>Ruud van Asseldonk</li> <li>Ryan Thomas</li> <li>Sandeep Datta</li> <li>Scott Olson</li> <li>Scott Whittaker</li> <li>Sean Leffler</li> <li>Sean McArthur</li> <li>Sebastian Hahn</li> <li>Sebastian Wicki</li> <li>Sébastien Marie</li> <li>Seo Sanghyeon</li> <li>Sergey Duberstein</li> <li>tgor</li> <li>Thomas Wickham</li> <li>Thomas Winwood</li> <li>Tobias Bucher</li> <li>Toby Scrace</li> <li>Tomasz Miąsko</li> <li>tormol</li> <li>Tshepang Lekhonkhobe</li> <li>Ulrik Sverdrup</li> <li>Vadim Petrochenkov</li> <li>Vincent Esche</li> <li>Vlad Ureche</li> <li>Wangshan Lu</li> <li>Wesley Wiser</li> </ul> Announcing Rust 1.6 Thu, 21 Jan 2016 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-6/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-6/ <p>Hello 2016! We’re happy to announce the first Rust release of the year, 1.6. Rust is a systems programming language focused on safety, speed, and concurrency.</p> <p>As always, you can <a href="http://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">install Rust 1.6</a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/stable/RELEASES.md#version-160-2016-01-21">detailed release notes for 1.6</a> on GitHub. About 1100 patches were landed in this release.</p> <h3 id="what-s-in-1-6-stable">What's in 1.6 stable</h3> <p>This release contains a number of small refinements, one major feature, and a change to <a href="https://crates.io">Crates.io</a>.</p> <h4 id="libcore-stabilization">libcore stabilization</h4> <p>The largest new feature in 1.6 is that <a href="http://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/core/"><code>libcore</code></a> is now stable! Rust’s standard library is two-tiered: there’s a small core library, <code>libcore</code>, and the full standard library, <code>libstd</code>, that builds on top of it. <code>libcore</code> is completely platform agnostic, and requires only a handful of external symbols to be defined. Rust’s <code>libstd</code> builds on top of <code>libcore</code>, adding support for memory allocation, I/O, and concurrency. Applications using Rust in the embedded space, as well as those writing operating systems, often eschew <code>libstd</code>, using only <code>libcore</code>.</p> <p><code>libcore</code> being stabilized is a major step towards being able to write the lowest levels of software using stable Rust. There’s still future work to be done, however. This will allow for a library ecosystem to develop around <code>libcore</code>, but <em>applications</em> are not fully supported yet. Expect to hear more about this in future release notes.</p> <h4 id="library-stabilizations">Library stabilizations</h4> <p>About 30 library functions and methods are now stable in 1.6. Notable improvements include:</p> <p>The <code>drain()</code> family of functions on collections. These methods let you move elements out of a collection while allowing them to retain their backing memory, reducing allocation in certain situations.</p> <p>A number of implementations of <code>From</code> for converting between standard library types, mainly between various integral and floating-point types.</p> <p>Finally, <code>Vec::extend_from_slice()</code>, which was previously known as <code>push_all()</code>. This method has a significantly faster implementation than the more general <code>extend()</code>.</p> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/stable/RELEASES.md#version-160-2016-01-21">detailed release notes</a> for more.</p> <h4 id="crates-io-disallows-wildcards">Crates.io disallows wildcards</h4> <p>If you maintain a crate on <a href="https://crates.io">Crates.io</a>, you might have seen a warning: newly uploaded crates are no longer allowed to use a wildcard when describing their dependencies. In other words, this is not allowed:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">dependencies</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#c82829;">regex </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;*&quot; </span></pre> <p>Instead, you must actually specify <a href="http://doc.crates.io/crates-io.html#using-cratesio-based-crates">a specific version or range of versions</a>, using one of the <code>semver</code> crate’s various options: <code>^</code>, <code>~</code>, or <code>=</code>.</p> <p>A wildcard dependency means that you work with any possible version of your dependency. This is highly unlikely to be true, and causes unnecessary breakage in the ecosystem. We’ve been advertising this change as a warning for some time; now it’s time to turn it into an error.</p> <h3 id="contributors-to-1-6">Contributors to 1.6</h3> <p>We had 132 individuals contribute to 1.6. Thank you so much!</p> <ul> <li>Aaron Turon</li> <li>Adam Badawy</li> <li>Aleksey Kladov</li> <li>Alexander Bulaev</li> <li>Alex Burka</li> <li>Alex Crichton</li> <li>Alex Gaynor</li> <li>Alexis Beingessner</li> <li>Amanieu d'Antras</li> <li>Amit Saha</li> <li>Andrea Canciani</li> <li>Andrew Paseltiner</li> <li>androm3da</li> <li>angelsl</li> <li>Angus Lees</li> <li>Antti Keränen</li> <li>arcnmx</li> <li>Ariel Ben-Yehuda</li> <li>Ashkan Kiani</li> <li>Barosl Lee</li> <li>Benjamin Herr</li> <li>Ben Striegel</li> <li>Bhargav Patel</li> <li>Björn Steinbrink</li> <li>Boris Egorov</li> <li>bors</li> <li>Brian Anderson</li> <li>Bruno Tavares</li> <li>Bryce Van Dyk</li> <li>Cameron Sun</li> <li>Christopher Sumnicht</li> <li>Cole Reynolds</li> <li>corentih</li> <li>Daniel Campbell</li> <li>Daniel Keep</li> <li>Daniel Rollins</li> <li>Daniel Trebbien</li> <li>Danilo Bargen</li> <li>Devon Hollowood</li> <li>Doug Goldstein</li> <li>Dylan McKay</li> <li>ebadf</li> <li>Eli Friedman</li> <li>Eric Findlay</li> <li>Erik Davidson</li> <li>Felix S. Klock II</li> <li>Florian Hahn</li> <li>Florian Hartwig</li> <li>Gleb Kozyrev</li> <li>Guillaume Gomez</li> <li>Huon Wilson</li> <li>Igor Shuvalov</li> <li>Ivan Ivaschenko</li> <li>Ivan Kozik</li> <li>Ivan Stankovic</li> <li>Jack Fransham</li> <li>Jake Goulding</li> <li>Jake Worth</li> <li>James Miller</li> <li>Jan Likar</li> <li>Jean Maillard</li> <li>Jeffrey Seyfried</li> <li>Jethro Beekman</li> <li>John Kåre Alsaker</li> <li>John Talling</li> <li>Jonas Schievink</li> <li>Jonathan S</li> <li>Jose Narvaez</li> <li>Josh Austin</li> <li>Josh Stone</li> <li>Joshua Holmer</li> <li>JP Sugarbroad</li> <li>jrburke</li> <li>Kevin Butler</li> <li>Kevin Yeh</li> <li>Kohei Hasegawa</li> <li>Kyle Mayes</li> <li>Lee Jeffery</li> <li>Manish Goregaokar</li> <li>Marcell Pardavi</li> <li>Markus Unterwaditzer</li> <li>Martin Pool</li> <li>Marvin Löbel</li> <li>Matt Brubeck</li> <li>Matthias Bussonnier</li> <li>Matthias Kauer</li> <li>mdinger</li> <li>Michael Layzell</li> <li>Michael Neumann</li> <li>Michael Sproul</li> <li>Michael Woerister</li> <li>Mihaly Barasz</li> <li>Mika Attila</li> <li>mitaa</li> <li>Ms2ger</li> <li>Nicholas Mazzuca</li> <li>Nick Cameron</li> <li>Niko Matsakis</li> <li>Ole Krüger</li> <li>Oliver Middleton</li> <li>Oliver Schneider</li> <li>Ori Avtalion</li> <li>Paul A. Jungwirth</li> <li>Peter Atashian</li> <li>Philipp Matthias Schäfer</li> <li>pierzchalski</li> <li>Ravi Shankar</li> <li>Ricardo Martins</li> <li>Ricardo Signes</li> <li>Richard Diamond</li> <li>Rizky Luthfianto</li> <li>Ryan Scheel</li> <li>Scott Olson</li> <li>Sean Griffin</li> <li>Sebastian Hahn</li> <li>Sébastien Marie</li> <li>Seo Sanghyeon</li> <li>Simonas Kazlauskas</li> <li>Simon Sapin</li> <li>Stepan Koltsov</li> <li>Steve Klabnik</li> <li>Steven Fackler</li> <li>Tamir Duberstein</li> <li>Tobias Bucher</li> <li>Toby Scrace</li> <li>Tshepang Lekhonkhobe</li> <li>Ulrik Sverdrup</li> <li>Vadim Chugunov</li> <li>Vadim Petrochenkov</li> <li>William Throwe</li> <li>xd1le</li> <li>Xmasreturns</li> </ul> Announcing Rust 1.5 Thu, 10 Dec 2015 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-5/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-5/ <p>Today we're releasing <a href="http://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">Rust 1.5 stable</a>. This post gives the highlights, and you can find the full details in the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/stable/RELEASES.md#version-150-2015-12-10">release notes</a>.</p> <h3 id="what-s-in-1-5-stable">What's in 1.5 stable</h3> <p>The biggest news with Rust 1.5 is the introduction of <code>cargo install</code>, a new subcommand that installs Cargo application packages on the local system. This tool offers a painless way to distribute Rust applications.</p> <p>The community is already taking advantage of <code>cargo install</code> to install applications like <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rustfmt">rustfmt</a>, the work-in-progress code formatting tool for Rust. Moreover, <code>cargo install</code> can also be used to install new subcommands for Cargo itself:</p> <ul> <li><code>cargo-check</code>: statically check a project, but don't build a binary.</li> <li><code>cargo-edit</code>: add or remove dependencies for a project through the command line.</li> <li><code>cargo-graph</code>: build dependency graphs for a project using GraphViz.</li> <li><code>cargo-watch</code>: automatically re-run a Cargo command when the project changes.</li> </ul> <p>(You can find more with a <a href="https://crates.io/search?q=subcommand">crates.io search</a>.)</p> <p>In addition to these tooling changes, Rust 1.5 sees a large number of library API stabilizations, especially around the interaction of paths and the file system.</p> <p>Finally, there were a few improvements to compile times, and crate metadata shrunk <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/28521">by about 20%</a>.</p> <h3 id="contributors-to-1-5">Contributors to 1.5</h3> <p>The Rust community continues to do incredible work, and we'd like to thank the 152 contributors to this release:</p> <ul> <li>Aaron Turon</li> <li>Adolfo Ochagavía</li> <li>Ahmed Charles</li> <li>Aidan Hobson Sayers</li> <li>Aleksey Kladov</li> <li>Alex Burka</li> <li>Alex Crichton</li> <li>Alex Gaynor</li> <li>Alexis Beingessner</li> <li>Alfie John</li> <li>Amit Aryeh Levy</li> <li>Andre Bogus</li> <li>Andrea Canciani</li> <li>Andreas Sommer</li> <li>Andrew Chin</li> <li>Andrew Paseltiner</li> <li>Ariel Ben-Yehuda</li> <li>Barosl Lee</li> <li>Bastien Dejean</li> <li>Ben S</li> <li>Ben Sago</li> <li>Björn Steinbrink</li> <li>Boris Egorov</li> <li>Brian Anderson</li> <li>Bryce Van Dyk</li> <li>Carlos Liam</li> <li>Carol (Nichols || Goulding)</li> <li>Charlotte Spencer</li> <li>Chris C Cerami</li> <li>Chris Drake</li> <li>Chris Wong</li> <li>Colin Wallace</li> <li>Corentin Henry</li> <li>Corey Farwell</li> <li>Craig Hills</li> <li>Cristi Cobzarenco</li> <li>Jonas Schievink</li> <li>Jonathan Hansford</li> <li>Jorge Aparicio</li> <li>Jose Narvaez</li> <li>Joseph Caudle</li> <li>Keshav Kini</li> <li>Kevin Butler</li> <li>Kevin Yap</li> <li>Kyle Robinson Young</li> <li>Lee Jeffery</li> <li>Lee Jenkins</li> <li>Lennart Kudling</li> <li>Liigo Zhuang</li> <li>Luqman Aden</li> <li>Manish Goregaokar</li> <li>Marcello Seri</li> <li>Marcus Klaas</li> <li>Martin Pool</li> <li>Matt Brubeck</li> <li>Michael Howell</li> <li>Michael Layzell</li> <li>Michael Pankov</li> <li>Ms2ger</li> <li>Nick Cameron</li> <li>Nick Hamann</li> <li>Nick Howell</li> <li>Niko Matsakis</li> <li>Oliver Schneider</li> <li>Peter Atashian</li> <li>Peter Marheine</li> <li>Philipp Oppermann</li> <li>Remi Rampin</li> <li>Reza Akhavan</li> <li>Ricardo Signes</li> <li>Richard Diamond</li> <li>Robert Gardner</li> <li>Robin Kruppe</li> <li>Ruud van Asseldonk</li> <li>Ryan Scheel</li> <li>Scott Olson</li> <li>Sean Bowe</li> <li>Sebastian Wicki</li> <li>Seeker14491</li> <li>Seo Sanghyeon</li> <li>Simon Mazur</li> <li>Simon Sapin</li> <li>Simonas Kazlauskas</li> <li>Stefan O'Rear</li> <li>Steve Klabnik</li> <li>Steven Allen</li> <li>Steven Fackler</li> <li>Sébastien Marie</li> <li>Ted Mielczarek</li> <li>Tobias Bucher</li> <li>Tshepang Lekhonkhobe</li> <li>Ulrik Sverdrup</li> <li>Utkarsh Kukreti</li> <li>Vadim Chugunov</li> <li>Vadim Petrochenkov</li> <li>Vitali Haravy</li> <li>Vladimir Rutsky</li> <li>Wesley Wiser</li> <li>Will Speak</li> <li>William Throwe</li> <li>Willy Aguirre</li> <li>Xavier Shay</li> <li>Yoshito Komatsu</li> <li>arcnmx</li> <li>arthurprs</li> <li>billpmurphy</li> <li>bors</li> <li>christopherdumas</li> <li>critiqjo</li> <li>glendc</li> <li>kickinbahk</li> <li>llogiq</li> <li>mdinger</li> <li>nwin</li> <li>nxnfufunezn</li> <li>panicbit</li> <li>skeleten</li> <li>whitequark</li> </ul> Announcing Rust 1.4 Thu, 29 Oct 2015 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-4/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-4/ <p>Choo choo! The trains have kept rolling, and today, we’re happy to announce the release of Rust 1.4, the newest stable release. Rust is a systems programming language focused on safety, speed, and concurrency.</p> <p>As always, you can <a href="http://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">install Rust 1.4</a> from the appropriate page on our website, and check out the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/8ab8581f6921bc7a8e3fa4defffd2814372dcb15/RELEASES.md#version-140-october-2015">detailed release notes for 1.4</a> on GitHub as well. About 1200 patches were landed in this release.</p> <h3 id="what-s-in-1-4-stable">What's in 1.4 stable</h3> <p>The story of 1.4 is mostly one of improvements and stabilizations, rather than new features.</p> <p>However, there is one particular change which is a language fix that enables a new feature: <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1214">RFC 1214, “Clarify (and improve) rules for projections and well-formedness”</a>. While that’s a deeply technical title, the TL;DR is that we found some weaknesses in the definition and implementation of a few aspects of the type system. This RFC fixes these problems. Given that changes to the type system like this can cause regressions, but fixes like this are important for soundness, Rust 1.4 will warn on any code that violates the new rules, but still compile. These warnings will turn into errors in Rust 1.5. However, given the train model, the community has had time to deal with these changes while 1.4 was in beta, and the small number of crates we were aware of have already been fixed.</p> <p>These soundness fixes enable the return of the ‘scoped threads’ feature, in which you can create threads that reference data stored on the stack in a safe manner. A few crates have implemented this feature, most notably <a href="https://crates.io/crates/crossbeam">crossbeam</a> and <a href="https://crates.io/crates/scoped_threadpool">scoped_threadpool</a>. See their documentation for more information.</p> <p><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/1212-line-endings.md">RFC 1212</a> is also in this release, which changes all functions dealing with reading ‘lines’ to treat both <code>\n</code> and <code>\r\n</code> as a valid line-ending. This was determined during the RFC process to be a bugfix, but we’re mentioning it here to raise awareness. The older behavior of only dealing with <code>\n</code> made for surprising behavior, where your crate would work well on Linux and Mac OS X, but fail on Windows. This fix brings these functions more in-line (😉) with expectations.</p> <p>Rust 1.4 marks an upgrade in our Windows support: Windows builds targeting the 64-bit MSVC ABI and linker (instead of GNU) are now supported and recommended for general use, and will appear on the downloads page for the first time. Thank you to all who have helped us work out the kinks since support initially landed in Rust 1.2.</p> <p>Here’s a summary of library changes:</p> <ul> <li>48 APIs were stabilized.</li> <li>Eight APIs were deprecated.</li> <li>Two were made faster.</li> <li>Over ten various types implement new traits.</li> </ul> <p>See the <a href="https://github.com/brson/rust/blob/relnotes/RELEASES.md#libraries">release notes</a> for exact details.</p> <p>The compiler <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/27338">no longer uses <code>morestack</code></a>, which was a holdover implementation detail from long, long ago. We now use guard pages and stack probes instead, though stack probes are only implemented on Windows so far.</p> <p>Finally, one major Cargo improvement: <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/pull/1931"><code>cargo update</code> will now print extra information about what it is changing.</a> For example:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">cargo update Updating registry `https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io-index` Updating libc v0.1.8 -&gt; v0.1.10 Updating memchr v0.1.3 -&gt; v0.1.5 Updating num v0.1.26 -&gt; v0.1.27 Updating rand v0.3.9 -&gt; v0.3.10 Updating rustc-serialize v0.3.15 -&gt; v0.3.16 </span></pre> <p>Before, it would do this job silently.</p> <h3 id="contributors-to-1-4">Contributors to 1.4</h3> <p>Rust is a community-driven project, and we're very appreciative of the work of the 127 contributors who made 1.4 happen. Thank you!</p> <ul> <li>Adam Crume</li> <li>Aidan Hobson Sayers</li> <li>Aleksey Kladov</li> <li>Alex Burka</li> <li>Alex Crichton</li> <li>Alex Ozdemir</li> <li>AlexDenisov</li> <li>Alexis Beingessner</li> <li>Alisdair Owens</li> <li>Andre Bogus</li> <li>Andrea Canciani</li> <li>Andrew Paseltiner</li> <li>Ariel Ben-Yehuda</li> <li>Artem Shitov</li> <li>Barosl Lee</li> <li>benshu</li> <li>Björn Steinbrink</li> <li>bors</li> <li>Brian Anderson</li> <li>Cesar Eduardo Barros</li> <li>Chris Krycho</li> <li>Chris Morgan</li> <li>Chris Nixon</li> <li>Chris Wong</li> <li>christopherdumas</li> <li>Cody P Schafer</li> <li>Corey Farwell</li> <li>Daan Rijks</li> <li>Dave Huseby</li> <li>diaphore</li> <li>Diggory Blake</li> <li>Dong Zhou</li> <li>Dylan McKay</li> <li>Elaine &quot;See More&quot; Nemo</li> <li>Eli Friedman</li> <li>Eljay</li> <li>Erick Tryzelaar</li> <li>Felix S. Klock II</li> <li>Garming Sam</li> <li>Georg Brandl</li> <li>Gleb Kozyrev</li> <li>Guillaume Gomez</li> <li>Hunan Rostomyan</li> <li>Huon Wilson</li> <li>Ivan Jager</li> <li>Jack Wilson</li> <li>Jake Goulding</li> <li>Jake Kerr</li> <li>Jake Shadle</li> <li>James Miller</li> <li>Jan Likar</li> <li>Jared Roesch</li> <li>Jeehoon Kang</li> <li>John Thomas</li> <li>Jonas Schievink</li> <li>Jørn Lode</li> <li>Jose Narvaez</li> <li>jotomicron</li> <li>Kang Seonghoon</li> <li>Kornel Lesiński</li> <li>Lee Jeffery</li> <li>Leif Arne Storset</li> <li>Lennart Kudling</li> <li>llogiq</li> <li>Manish Goregaokar</li> <li>Marc-Antoine Perennou</li> <li>Marcus Klaas</li> <li>Marko Lalic</li> <li>Martin Wernstål</li> <li>Matěj Grabovský</li> <li>Matej Lach</li> <li>Matt Brubeck</li> <li>Matt Friedman</li> <li>Michael Choate</li> <li>Michael Layzell</li> <li>Michael Macias</li> <li>Michael McConville</li> <li>Michael Neumann</li> <li>Mickaël Salaün</li> <li>midinastasurazz</li> <li>Mike Marcacci</li> <li>mitaa</li> <li>Ms2ger</li> <li>Murarth</li> <li>Nathan Kleyn</li> <li>Nicholas Seckar</li> <li>Nick Cameron</li> <li>Nick Howell</li> <li>Niko Matsakis</li> <li>Nikolay Kondratyev</li> <li>Niranjan Padmanabhan</li> <li>Overmind JIANG</li> <li>Pascal Hertleif</li> <li>Peter Reid</li> <li>Remi Rampin</li> <li>Richard Diamond</li> <li>Robin Kruppe</li> <li>Ruby</li> <li>Ryo Munakata</li> <li>Scott Olson</li> <li>Sean Bowe</li> <li>Sean McArthur</li> <li>Sébastien Marie</li> <li>Simon Mazur</li> <li>Simon Sapin</li> <li>Simonas Kazlauskas</li> <li>Stepan Koltsov</li> <li>Steve Klabnik</li> <li>Steven Fackler</li> <li>Sylvestre Ledru</li> <li>Taliesin Beynon</li> <li>Tamir Duberstein</li> <li>Tim Cuthbertson</li> <li>Tim JIANG</li> <li>Tim Neumann</li> <li>Tobias Bucher</li> <li>Tshepang Lekhonkhobe</li> <li>Ulrik Sverdrup</li> <li>Vadim Chugunov</li> <li>Vadim Petrochenkov</li> <li>Viacheslav Chimishuk</li> <li>Victor Berger</li> <li>Vincent Bernat</li> <li>Vladimir Rutsky</li> <li>w00ns</li> <li>William Throwe</li> <li>Without Boats</li> <li>Xiao Chuan Yu</li> </ul> Announcing Rust 1.3 Thu, 17 Sep 2015 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-3/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-3/ <p>The gear keeps turning: we're releasing Rust 1.3 stable today! As always, read on for the highlights and check the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-130-september-2015">release notes</a> for more detail.</p> <h3 id="what-s-in-1-3-stable">What's in 1.3 stable</h3> <p>This is our first release shipping with the <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/nomicon/">Rustonomicon</a>, a new book covering &quot;The Dark Arts of Advanced and Unsafe Rust Programming&quot;. While it's still in draft form, this book already provides deep coverage of some of Rust's darker corners.</p> <p>On the library front, we saw a fair amount of API stabilization, including the new <code>Duration</code> API and enhancements to <code>Error</code> and <code>Hash</code>/<code>Hasher</code>. We expect to see further growth of the <code>std::time</code> module in the 1.5 timeframe.</p> <p>The 1.3 cycle also saw continuing focus on performance. Most wins here are within the standard library:</p> <ul> <li>The substring matcher now uses a <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/26327">more efficient algorithm</a>.</li> <li>There were <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/26849">improvements to zero filling</a> that speed up <code>Vec::resize</code> and <code>Read::read_to_end</code>.</li> <li>The implementation of <code>Read::read_to_end</code> has been <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/26950">specialized for <code>stdin</code> and <code>File</code></a>, resulting in additional speedups.</li> <li>The <code>PartialEq</code> implementation on slices is now <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/26884">much faster</a>.</li> </ul> <p>We're continuing to invest in Windows, with <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/26601">preliminary support for targeting Windows XP</a>. While we do not intend to treat Windows XP as a &quot;first tier&quot; platform, it is now feasible to build Rust code for XP as long as you avoid certain parts of the standard library. Work on MSVC toolchain integration is ongoing, with full support (on 64-bit) shipping in the 1.4 beta today.</p> <p>On the Cargo front, we have landed support for <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/27260">lint capping</a> as specified by an <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1193">earlier RFC</a>. The idea is that lints in your dependencies should not affect your ability to compile cleanly, which in turn makes it easier to tweak the way lints work without undue hassle in the ecosystem.</p> <h3 id="contributors-to-1-3">Contributors to 1.3</h3> <p>Rust is a community-driven language, and we're delighted to thank the 131 contributors to this release:</p> <ul> <li>Aaron Turon</li> <li>Adam Heins</li> <li>Agoston Szepessy</li> <li>Aidan Hobson Sayers</li> <li>Akos Kiss</li> <li>Alex Crichton</li> <li>Alex Newman</li> <li>Alexis Beingessner</li> <li>Alisdair Owens</li> <li>Andreas Tolfsen</li> <li>Andrew Kuchev</li> <li>Andrew Paseltiner</li> <li>Andy Caldwell</li> <li>Andy Grover</li> <li>Antti Keränen</li> <li>Ariel Ben-Yehuda</li> <li>Barosl Lee</li> <li>Benjamin Herr</li> <li>Björn Steinbrink</li> <li>Blake Loring</li> <li>Brian Anderson</li> <li>Brody Holden</li> <li>Chris Morgan</li> <li>Christian Persson</li> <li>Christian Weinz</li> <li>Cole Reynolds</li> <li>Corey Farwell</li> <li>Corey Richardson</li> <li>Cristian Kubis</li> <li>Cruz Julian Bishop</li> <li>Daniel Albert</li> <li>Dave Huseby</li> <li>Dirkjan Ochtman</li> <li>Eduard Burtescu</li> <li>Eli Friedman</li> <li>Eljay</li> <li>Esption</li> <li>Felix S. <li>Jan Likar</li> <li>Jared Roesch</li> <li>Jashank Jeremy</li> <li>Jason Schein</li> <li>Jeehoon Kang</li> <li>Jesús Espino</li> <li>Johannes Oertel</li> <li>John Hodge</li> <li>Jonathan
