<li>Kevin Butler</li> <li>Kieran Hunt</li> <li>Kornel Lesiński</li> <li>Kristof Söderström</li> <li>Lee Jeffery</li> <li>Leif Arne Storset</li> <li>Liigo Zhuang</li> <li>Makoto Kato</li> <li>Manish Goregaokar</li> <li>Marcus Klaas</li> <li>Mark Buer</li> <li>Mathieu David</li> <li>Mathijs van de Nes</li> <li>Matt Friedman</li> <li>Michael Sproul</li> <li>Michael Woerister</li> <li>Ms2ger</li> <li>Nick Cameron</li> <li>Nick Hamann</li> <li>Nick Howell</li> <li>Nicolette Verlinden</li> <li>Niko Matsakis</li> <li>OGINO Masanori</li> <li>Oliver Schneider</li> <li>P1start</li> <li>Paolo Falabella</li> <li>Pascal Hertleif</li> <li>Patrick Walton</li> <li>Pavel Pravosud</li> <li>Peter Atashian</li> <li>Peter Elmers</li> <li>Ralf Jung</li> <li>Remi Rampin</li> <li>Richo Healey</li> <li>Ryan Pendleton</li> <li>Scott Olson</li> <li>Sean Patrick Santos</li> <li>Seo Sanghyeon</li> <li>Simon Sapin</li> <li>Simonas Kazlauskas</li> <li>Steve Klabnik</li> <li>Steven Allen</li> <li>Steven Fackler</li> <li>Steven Stewart-Gallus</li> <li>Sébastien Marie</li> <li>Taliesin Beynon</li> <li>Tamir Duberstein</li> <li>Theo Belaire</li> <li>Ticki</li> <li>Tobias Bucher</li> <li>Tshepang Lekhonkhobe</li> <li>Ulrik Sverdrup</li> <li>Vadim Chugunov</li> <li>Vadim Petrochenkov</li> <li>Vincent Bernat</li> <li>Vladimir Rutsky</li> <li>Wei-Ming Yang</li> <li>Wesley Wiser</li> <li>William Throwe</li> <li>arthurprs</li> <li>bors</li> <li>diaphore</li> <li>eternaleye</li> <li>jethrogb</li> <li>krumelmonster</li> <li>mdinger</li> <li>midinastasurazz</li> <li>mitaa</li> </ul> Rust in 2016 Fri, 14 Aug 2015 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/next-year/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/next-year/ <p>This week marks three months since Rust 1.0 was released. As we're starting to hit our post-1.0 stride, we'd like to talk about <strong>what 1.0 meant in hindsight, and where we see Rust going in the next year</strong>.</p> <h3 id="what-1-0-was-about">What 1.0 was about</h3> <p>Rust 1.0 focused on stability, community, and clarity.</p> <ul> <li> <p><strong>Stability</strong>, we've discussed quite a bit in <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/10/30/Stability.html">previous posts</a> introducing our release channels and stabilization process.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Community</strong> has always been one of Rust's greatest strengths. But in the year leading up to 1.0, we introduced and refined the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs#when-you-need-to-follow-this-process">RFC process</a>, culminating with <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1068">subteams</a> to manage RFCs in each particular area. Community-wide debate on RFCs was indispensable for delivering a quality 1.0 release.</p> </li> <li> <p>All of this refinement prior to 1.0 was in service of reaching <strong>clarity</strong> on what Rust represents:</p> <ul> <li><a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2015/04/10/Fearless-Concurrency.html">Memory safety without garbage collection</a></li> <li><a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2015/04/10/Fearless-Concurrency.html">Concurrency without data races</a></li> <li><a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2015/05/11/traits.html">Abstraction without overhead</a></li> <li><a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/10/30/Stability.html">Stability without stagnation</a></li> </ul> </li> </ul> <p>Altogether, <strong>Rust is exciting because it is empowering: you can hack without fear</strong>. And you can do so in contexts you might not have before, dropping down from languages like Ruby or Python, making your first foray into systems programming.</p> <p>That's Rust 1.0; but what comes next?</p> <h3 id="where-we-go-from-here">Where we go from here</h3> <p>After much discussion within the core team, early production users, and the broader community, we've identified a number of improvements we'd like to make over the course of the next year or so, falling into three categories:</p> <ul> <li>Doubling down on infrastructure;</li> <li>Zeroing in on gaps in key features;</li> <li>Branching out into new places to use Rust.</li> </ul> <p>Let's look at some of the biggest plans in each of these categories.</p> <h3 id="doubling-down-infrastructure-investments">Doubling down: infrastructure investments</h3> <h4 id="crater">Crater</h4> <p>Our basic <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/10/30/Stability.html">stability promise</a> for Rust is that upgrades between versions are &quot;hassle-free&quot;. To deliver on this promise, we need to detect compiler bugs that cause code to stop working. Naturally, the compiler has its own large test suite, but that is only a small fraction of the code that's out there &quot;in the wild&quot;. <strong><a href="https://github.com/brson/taskcluster-crater">Crater</a> is a tool that aims to close that gap by testing the compiler against all the packages found in <a href="https://crates.io">crates.io</a>, giving us a much better idea whether any code has stopped compiling on the latest nightly.</strong></p> <p>Crater has quickly become an indispensable tool. We regularly compare the nightly release against the latest stable build, and we use crater to check in-progress branches and estimate the impact of a change.</p> <p>Interestingly, we have often found that when code stops compiling, it's not because of a bug in the compiler. Rather, it's because we <em>fixed</em> a bug, and that code happened to be relying on the older behavior. Even in those cases, using crater helps us improve the experience, by suggestion that we should phase fixes in slowly with warnings.</p> <p>Over the next year or so, we plan to improve crater in numerous ways:</p> <ul> <li>Extend the coverage to other platforms beyond Linux, and run test suites on covered libraries as well.</li> <li>Make it easier to use: leave an <code>@crater: test</code> comment to try out a PR.</li> <li>Produce a version of the tool that library authors can use to see effects of their changes on downstream code.</li> <li>Include code from other sources beyond <a href="https://crates.io">crates.io</a>.</li> </ul> <h4 id="incremental-compilation">Incremental compilation</h4> <p>Rust has always had a &quot;crate-wide&quot; compilation model. This means that the Rust compiler reads in all of the source files in your crate at once. These are type-checked and then given to LLVM for optimization. This approach is great for doing deep optimization, because it gives LLVM full access to the entire set of code, allowing for more better inlining, more precise analysis, and so forth. However, it can mean that turnaround is slow: even if you only edit one function, we will recompile everything. When projects get large, this can be a burden.</p> <p>The incremental compilation project aims to change this by having the Rust compiler save intermediate by-products and re-use them. This way, when you're debugging a problem, or tweaking a code path, <strong>you only have to recompile those things that you have changed, which should make the &quot;edit-compile-test&quot; cycle much faster</strong>.</p> <p>Part of this project is restructuring the compiler to introduce a new intermediate representation, which we call <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1211">MIR</a>. MIR is a simpler, lower-level form of Rust code that boils down the more complex features, making the rest of the compiler simpler. This is a crucial enabler for language changes like non-lexical lifetimes (discussed in the next section).</p> <h4 id="ide-integration">IDE integration</h4> <p>Top-notch IDE support can help to make Rust even more productive. Up until now, pioneering projects like <a href="https://github.com/phildawes/racer">Racer</a>, <a href="https://github.com/PistonDevelopers/VisualRust">Visual Rust</a>, and <a href="https://github.com/RustDT/RustDT">Rust DT</a> have been working largely without compiler support. <strong>We plan to extend the compiler to permit deeper integration with IDEs and other tools</strong>; the plan is to focus initially on two IDEs, and then grow from there.</p> <h3 id="zeroing-in-closing-gaps-in-our-key-features">Zeroing in: closing gaps in our key features</h3> <h4 id="specialization">Specialization</h4> <p>The idea of zero-cost abstractions breaks down into two separate goals, as identified by Stroustrup:</p> <ul> <li>What you don't use, you don't pay for.</li> <li>What you do use, you couldn't hand code any better.</li> </ul> <p>Rust 1.0 has essentially achieved the first goal, both in terms of language features and the standard library. But it doesn't quite manage to achieve the second goal. Take the following trait, for example:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">pub trait </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Extend&lt;A&gt; { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">extend</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&lt;T&gt;(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">mut </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">iterable</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: T) </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">where</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> T: IntoIterator&lt;Item=A&gt;; } </span></pre> <p>The <code>Extend</code> trait provides a nice abstraction for inserting data from any kind of iterator into a collection. But with traits today, that also means that each collection can provide only one implementation that works for <em>all</em> iterator types, which requires actually calling <code>.next()</code> repeatedly. In some cases, you could hand code it better, e.g. by just calling <code>memcpy</code>.</p> <p>To close this gap, we've proposed <strong><a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1210">specialization</a>, allowing you to provide multiple, overlapping trait implementations as long as one is clearly more specific than the other</strong>. Aside from giving Rust a more complete toolkit for zero-cost abstraction, specialization also improves its story for code reuse. See <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1210">the RFC</a> for more details.</p> <h4 id="borrow-checker-improvements">Borrow checker improvements</h4> <p>The borrow checker is, in a way, the beating heart of Rust; it's the part of the compiler that lets us achieve memory safety without garbage collection, by catching use-after-free bugs and the like. But occasionally, the borrower checker also &quot;catches&quot; non-bugs, like the following pattern:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">match</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> map.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">find</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">key) { </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Some</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">...</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">... </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">None </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ map.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">insert</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(key, new_value); } } </span></pre> <p>Code like the above snippet is perfectly fine, but the borrow checker struggles with it today because the <code>map</code> variable is borrowed for the entire body of the <code>match</code>, preventing it from being mutated by <code>insert</code>. We plan to address this shortcoming soon by refactoring the borrow checker to view code in terms of finer-grained (&quot;non-lexical&quot;) regions -- a step made possible by the move to the MIR mentioned above.</p> <h4 id="plugins">Plugins</h4> <p>There are some really neat things you can do in Rust today -- if you're willing to use the Nightly channel. For example, the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/regex">regex crate</a> comes with macros that, at compile time, turn regular expressions directly into machine code to match them. Or take the <a href="https://github.com/sfackler/rust-postgres-macros">rust-postgres-macros crate</a>, which checks strings for SQL syntax validity at compile time. Crates like these make use of a highly-unstable compiler plugin system that currently exposes far too many compiler internals. <strong>We plan to propose a new plugin design that is more robust and provides built-in support for hygienic macro expansion as well</strong>.</p> <h3 id="branching-out-taking-rust-to-new-places">Branching out: taking Rust to new places</h3> <h4 id="cross-compilation">Cross-compilation</h4> <p>While cross-compiling with Rust is possible today, it involves a lot of manual configuration. <strong>We're shooting for push-button cross-compiles</strong>. The idea is that compiling Rust code for another target should be easy:</p> <ol> <li>Download a precompiled version of <code>libstd</code> for the target in question, if you don't already have it.</li> <li>Execute <code>cargo build --target=foo</code>.</li> <li>There is no step 3.</li> </ol> <h4 id="cargo-install">Cargo install</h4> <p>Cargo and <a href="https://crates.io">crates.io</a> is a really great tool for distributing libraries, but it lacks any means to install executables. <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1200">RFC 1200</a> describes a simple addition to cargo, the <code>cargo install</code> command. Much like the conventional <code>make install</code>, <strong><code>cargo install</code> will place an executable in your path so that you can run it</strong>. This can serve as a simple distribution channel, and is particularly useful for people writing tools that target Rust developers (who are likely to be familiar with running cargo).</p> <h4 id="tracing-hooks">Tracing hooks</h4> <p>One of the most promising ways of using Rust is by &quot;embedding&quot; Rust code into systems written in higher-level languages like <a href="http://blog.skylight.io/bending-the-curve-writing-safe-fast-native-gems-with-rust/">Ruby</a> or Python. This embedding is usually done by giving the Rust code a C API, and works reasonably well when the target sports a &quot;C friendly&quot; memory management scheme like reference counting or conservative GC.</p> <p>Integrating with an environment that uses a more advanced GC can be quite challenging. Perhaps the most prominent examples are JavaScript engines like V8 (used by <a href="https://nodejs.org/">node.js</a>) and SpiderMonkey (used by <a href="http://firefox.com/">Firefox</a> and <a href="https://github.com/servo/servo">Servo</a>). Integrating with those engines requires very careful coding to ensure that all objects are properly rooted; small mistakes can easily lead to crashes. These are precisely the kind of memory management problems that Rust is intended to eliminate.</p> <p><strong>To bring Rust to environments with advanced GCs, we plan to extend the compiler with the ability to generate &quot;trace hooks&quot;</strong>. These hooks can be used by a GC to sweep the stack and identify roots, making it possible to write code that integrates with advanced VMs smoothly and easily. Naturally, the design will respect Rust's &quot;pay for what you use&quot; policy, so that code which does not integrate with a GC is unaffected.</p> <h3 id="epilogue-rustcamp-2015-and-rust-s-community-in-2016">Epilogue: RustCamp 2015, and Rust's community in 2016</h3> <p>We recently held the first-ever Rust conference, <a href="http://rustcamp.com/">RustCamp</a> 2015, which sold out with 160 attendees. It was amazing to see so much of the Rust community in person, and to see the vibe of our online spaces translate into a friendly and approachable in-person event. The day opened with a keynote from Nicholas Matsakis and Aaron Turon laying out the core team's view of where we are and where we're headed. The <a href="http://rustcamp.com/schedule.html">slides are available online</a> (along with several other talks), and the above serves as the missing soundtrack. <strong>Update</strong>: now you can see <a href="http://confreaks.tv/events/rustcamp2015">the talks</a> as well!</p> <p>There was a definite theme of the day: Rust's greatest potential is to unlock a new generation of systems programmers. And that's not just because of the language; it's just as much because of a community culture that says &quot;Don't know the difference between the stack and the heap? Don't worry, Rust is a great way to learn about it, and I'd love to show you how.&quot;</p> <p>The technical work we outlined above is important for our vision in 2016, but so is the work of those on our moderation and community teams, and all of those who tirelessly -- enthusiastically -- welcome people coming from all kinds of backgrounds into the Rust community. So our greatest wish for the next year of Rust is that, as its community grows, it continues to retain the welcoming spirit that it has today.</p> Announcing Rust 1.2 Thu, 06 Aug 2015 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-2/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-2/ <p>Today marks the <a href="http://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">completion</a> of the Rust 1.2 stable and 1.3 beta release cycles! Read on for the highlight, or check the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-120-august-2015">release notes</a> for more detail.</p> <h3 id="what-s-in-1-2-stable">What's in 1.2 stable</h3> <p>As we <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2015/06/25/Rust-1.1.html">previously announced</a>, Rust 1.2 comes with two major performance improvements for the compiler:</p> <ul> <li> <p><strong>An across-the-board improvement</strong> to real-world compiler performance. Representative crates include <a href="https://crates.io/crates/hyper">hyper</a> (compiles 1.16x faster), <a href="https://crates.io/crates/html5ever">html5ever</a> (1.62x faster), <a href="https://crates.io/crates/regex">regex</a> (1.32x faster) and <a href="https://crates.io/crates/encoding">rust-encoding</a> (1.35x faster). You can explore some of this performance data at Nick Cameron's <a href="http://www.ncameron.org/perf-rustc/">preliminary tracking site</a>, using dates 2015-05-15 to 2015-06-25.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Parallel codegen</strong> is <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/26018">now working</a>, and produces a 33% speedup when bootstrapping on a 4 core machine. Parallel codegen is particularly useful for debug builds, since it prevents some optimizations; but it can also be used with optimizations as an effective <code>-O1</code> flag. It can be activated by passing <code>-C codegen-units=N</code> to <code>rustc</code>, where <code>N</code> is the desired number of threads.</p> </li> </ul> <p>Cargo's performance has also improved dramatically:</p> <ul> <li> <p>Builds that do not require any recompilation (&quot;no-op builds&quot;) for large projects are much faster: for Servo, build time went from 5 seconds to 0.5 seconds.</p> </li> <li> <p>Cargo now supports shared target directories that cache dependencies across multiple packages, which results in significant build-time reduction for complex projects.</p> </li> </ul> <p>The 1.2 release also <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/25350">introduces support</a> for the MSVC (Microsoft Visual C) toolchain, as opposed to GNU variants. The upshot is that Rust code is now directly linkable against code built using the native Windows toolchain. The compiler bootstraps on MSVC, we have preliminary nightlies, and we are testing all rust-lang crates against MSVC. Unwinding support is not yet available (the process aborts on panic), but work is underway to land it.</p> <p>On the language side, Rust 1.2 marks the completion of the <a href="http://smallcultfollowing.com/babysteps/blog/2014/01/05/dst-take-5/">dynamically-sized type (DST)</a> work, allowing smart pointers like <code>Rc</code> to seamless apply to arrays and trait objects, so that <code>Rc&lt;[T]&gt;</code> is fully usable. This final enhancement applies to all smart pointers in the standard library. Support for external smart pointer types is available in nightlies, and will be stabilized soon.</p> <h3 id="what-s-in-1-3-beta">What's in 1.3 beta</h3> <p>One of the most exciting developments during the 1.3 cycle was the introduction of the <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/nomicon/">Rustonomicon</a>, a new book covering &quot;The Dark Arts of Advanced and Unsafe Rust Programming&quot;. While it's still in its early days, this book already provides indispensable coverage of some of Rust's more subtle aspects.</p> <p>The 1.3 cycle also saw additional focus on performance, though most wins here are within the standard library:</p> <ul> <li>The substring matcher now uses a <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/26327">more efficient algorithm</a>.</li> <li>There were <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/26849">improvements to zero filling</a> that speed up <code>Vec::resize</code> and <code>Read::read_to_end</code>.</li> <li>The implementation of <code>Read::read_to_end</code> has been <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/26950">specialized for <code>stdin</code> and <code>File</code></a>, resulting in additional speedups.</li> <li>The <code>PartialEq</code> implementation on slices is now <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/26884">much faster</a>.</li> </ul> <p>We have also made strides in our Windows support, landing <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/26601">preliminary support for targeting Windows XP</a>. While we do not intend to treat Windows XP as a &quot;first tier&quot; platform, it is now feasible to build Rust code for XP as long as you avoid certain parts of the standard library.</p> <p>On the Cargo front, we have landed support for <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/27260">lint capping</a> as specified by an <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1193">earlier RFC</a>. The idea is that lints in your dependencies should not affect your ability to compile cleanly, which in turn makes it easier to tweak the way lints work without undue hassle in the ecosystem.</p> <h3 id="contributors-to-1-2">Contributors to 1.2</h3> <p>The 1.2 stable release represents the hard work of 180 fine folks:</p> <ul> <li>Aaron Turon</li> <li>Abhishek Chanda</li> <li>Adolfo Ochagavía</li> <li>Aidan Hobson Sayers</li> <li>Akshay Chiwhane</li> <li>Alex Burka</li> <li>Alex Crichton</li> <li>Alex Stokes</li> <li>Alexander Artemenko</li> <li>Alexis Beingessner</li> <li>Andrea Canciani</li> <li>Andrew Foote</li> <li>Andrew Kensler</li> <li>Andrew Straw</li> <li>Ariel Ben-Yehuda</li> <li>Austin Hellyer</li> <li>Barosl Lee</li> <li>Ben Striegel</li> <li>Björn Steinbrink</li> <li>Brian Anderson</li> <li>Brian Campbell</li> <li>Brian Leibig</li> <li>Brian Quinlan</li> <li>Carol (Nichols || Goulding)</li> <li>Chris Hellmuth</li> <li>Christian Stadelmann</li> <li>Chuck Bassett</li> <li>Corey Farwell</li> <li>Cornel Punga</li> <li>Cruz Julian Bishop</li> <li>Dave Huseby</li> <li>David Campbell</li> <li>David Stygstra</li> <li>David Voit</li> <li>Eduard Bopp</li> <li>Eduard Burtescu</li> <li>Eli Friedman</li> <li>Emilio Cobos Álvarez</li> <li>Emily Dunham</li> <li>Eric Ye</li> <li>Erik Michaels-Ober</li> <li>Falco Hirschenberger</li> <li>Felix S. Klock II</li> <li>FuGangqiang</li> <li>Geoffrey Thomas</li> <li>Gleb Kozyrev</li> <li>Guillaume Gomez</li> <li>Gulshan Singh</li> <li>Heejong Ahn</li> <li>Huachao Huang</li> <li>Huon Wilson</li> <li>Ivan Ukhov</li> <li>Iven Hsu</li> <li>Jake Goulding</li> <li>Jake Hickey</li> <li>James Miller</li> <li>Jared Roesch</li> <li>Jeremy Schlatter</li> <li>Jexell</li> <li>Jim Blandy</li> <li>Johann Tuffe</li> <li>Johannes Hoff</li> <li>Johannes Oertel</li> <li>John Hodge</li> <li>Jonathan Reem</li> <li>Joshua Landau</li> <li>Kevin Ballard</li> <li>Kubilay Kocak</li> <li>Lee Jeffery</li> <li>Leo Correa</li> <li>Liigo Zhuang</li> <li>Lorenz</li> <li>Luca Bruno</li> <li>Luqman Aden</li> <li>Manish Goregaokar</li> <li>Marcel Müller</li> <li>Marcus Klaas</li> <li>Marin Atanasov Nikolov</li> <li>Markus Westerlind</li> <li>Martin Pool</li> <li>Marvin Löbel</li> <li>Matej Lach</li> <li>Mathieu David</li> <li>Matt Brubeck</li> <li>Matthew Astley</li> <li>Max Jacobson</li> <li>Maximilian Haack</li> <li>Michael Layzell</li> <li>Michael Macias</li> <li>Michael Rosenberg</li> <li>Michael Sproul</li> <li>Michael Woerister</li> <li>Mihnea Dobrescu-Balaur</li> <li>Mikhail Zabaluev</li> <li>Mohammed Attia</li> <li>Ms2ger</li> <li>Murarth</li> <li>Mário Feroldi</li> <li>Nathan Long</li> <li>Nathaniel Theis</li> <li>Nick Cameron</li> <li>Nick Desaulniers</li> <li>Nick Fitzgerald</li> <li>Nick Hamann</li> <li>Nick Howell</li> <li>Niko Matsakis</li> <li>Nils Liberg</li> <li>OlegTsyba</li> <li>Oliver 'ker' Schneider</li> <li>Oliver Schneider</li> <li>P1start</li> <li>Parker Moore</li> <li>Pascal Hertleif</li> <li>Paul Faria</li> <li>Paul Oliver</li> <li>Peer Aramillo Irizar</li> <li>Peter Atashian</li> <li>Peter Elmers</li> <li>Philip Munksgaard</li> <li>Ralph Giles</li> <li>Rein Henrichs</li> <li>Ricardo Martins</li> <li>Richo Healey</li> <li>Ricky Taylor</li> <li>Russell Johnston</li> <li>Russell McClellan</li> <li>Ryan Pendleton</li> <li>Ryman</li> <li>Rémi Audebert</li> <li>Sae-bom Kim</li> <li>Sean Collins</li> <li>Sean Gillespie</li> <li>Sean Patrick Santos</li> <li>Seo Sanghyeon</li> <li>Simon Sapin</li> <li>Simonas Kazlauskas</li> <li>Steve Gury</li> <li>Steve Klabnik</li> <li>Steven Allen</li> <li>Steven Fackler</li> <li>Steven Walter</li> <li>Sébastien Marie</li> <li>Tamir Duberstein</li> <li>Thomas Karpiniec</li> <li>Tim Ringenbach</li> <li>Tshepang Lekhonkhobe</li> <li>Ulrik Sverdrup</li> <li>Vadim Petrochenkov</li> <li>Wei-Ming Yang</li> <li>Wesley Wiser</li> <li>Wilfred Hughes</li> <li>Will Andrews</li> <li>Will Engler</li> <li>Xuefeng Wu</li> <li>XuefengWu</li> <li>Yongqian Li</li> <li>York Xiang</li> <li>Z1</li> <li>ben fleis</li> <li>benaryorg</li> <li>bluss</li> <li>bors</li> <li>clatour</li> <li>diwic</li> <li>dmgawel</li> <li>econoplas</li> <li>frankamp</li> <li>funkill</li> <li>inrustwetrust</li> <li>joliv</li> <li>klutzy</li> <li>marcell</li> <li>mdinger</li> <li>olombard</li> <li>peferron</li> <li>ray glover</li> <li>saml</li> <li>simplex</li> <li>sumito3478</li> <li>webmobster</li> </ul> Rust 1.1 stable, the Community Subteam, and RustCamp Thu, 25 Jun 2015 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-1/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-1/ <p>We're happy to announce the completion of the first release cycle after Rust 1.0: today we are <a href="http://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">releasing</a> Rust 1.1 stable, as well as 1.2 beta.</p> <p>Read on for details the releases, as well as some exciting new developments within the Rust community.</p> <h3 id="what-s-in-1-1-stable">What's in 1.1 Stable</h3> <p>One of the highest priorities for Rust after its 1.0 has been improving compile times. Thanks to the hard work of a number of contributors, Rust 1.1 stable provides a <strong>32% improvement</strong> in compilation time over Rust 1.0 (as measured by bootstrapping).</p> <p>Another major focus has been improving error messages throughout the compiler. Again thanks to a number of contributors, a large portion of compiler errors now include extended explanations accessible using the <code>--explain</code> flag.</p> <p>Beyond these improvements, the 1.1 release includes a number of important new features:</p> <ul> <li><em>New <code>std::fs</code> APIs</em>. This release stabilizes a <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1044">large set of extensions</a> to the filesystem APIs, making it possible, for example, to compile Cargo on stable Rust.</li> <li><em>musl support</em>. It's <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/24777">now possible</a> to target <a href="http://www.musl-libc.org/">musl</a> on Linux. Binaries built this way are statically linked and have zero dependencies. Nightlies are on the way.</li> <li><em><code>cargo rustc</code></em>. It's now possible to build a Cargo package while passing arbitrary flags to the final <code>rustc</code> invocation.</li> </ul> <p>More detail is available in the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-110-june-2015">release notes</a>.</p> <h3 id="what-s-in-1-2-beta">What's in 1.2 Beta</h3> <p>Performance improvements didn't stop with 1.1 stable. Benchmark compilations are showing an <strong>additional 30%</strong> improvement from 1.1 stable to 1.2 beta; Cargo's main crate compiles 18% faster.</p> <p>In addition, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/26018">parallel codegen</a> is working again, and can substantially speed up large builds in debug mode; it gets another 33% speedup on bootstrapping on a 4 core machine. It's not yet on by default, but will be in the near future.</p> <p>Cargo has also seen some performance improvements, including a 10x speedup on large &quot;no-op&quot; builds (from 5s to 0.5s on Servo), and shared target directories that cache dependencies across multiple packages.</p> <p>In addition to all of this, 1.2 beta includes our first support for MSVC (Microsoft Visual C): the compiler is able to bootstrap, and we have preliminary nightlies targeting the platform. This is a big step for our Windows support, making it much easier to link Rust code against code built using the native toolchain. Unwinding is not yet available -- code aborts on panic -- but the implementation is otherwise complete, and all rust-lang crates are now testing on MSVC as a first-tier platform.</p> <p>Rust 1.2 stable will be released six weeks from now, together with 1.3 beta.</p> <h3 id="community-news">Community news</h3> <p>In addition to the above technical work, there's some exciting news within the Rust community.</p> <p>In the past few weeks, we've <a href="https://internals.rust-lang.org/t/announcing-the-community-subteam/2248">formed a new subteam</a> explicitly devoted to supporting the Rust community. The team will have a number of responsibilities, including aggregating resources for meetups and other events, supporting diversity in the community through leadership in outreach, policies, and awareness-raising, and working with our early production users and the core team to help guide prioritization.</p> <p>In addition, we'll soon be holding the first official Rust conference: <a href="http://rustcamp.com/">RustCamp</a>, on August 1, 2015, in Berkeley, CA, USA. We've received a number of excellent talk submissions, and are expecting a great program.</p> <h3 id="contributors-to-1-1">Contributors to 1.1</h3> <p>As with every release, 1.1 stable is the result of work from an amazing and active community. Thanks to the 168 contributors to this release:</p> <ul> <li>Aaron Gallagher</li> <li>Aaron Turon</li> <li>Abhishek Chanda</li> <li>Adolfo Ochagavía</li> <li>Alex Burka</li> <li>Alex Crichton</li> <li>Alexander Polakov</li> <li>Alexis Beingessner</li> <li>Andreas Tolfsen</li> <li>Andrei Oprea</li> <li>Andrew Paseltiner</li> <li>Andrew Straw</li> <li>Andrzej Janik</li> <li>Aram Visser</li> <li>Ariel Ben-Yehuda</li> <li>Avdi Grimm</li> <li>Barosl Lee</li> <li>Ben Gesoff</li> <li>Björn Steinbrink</li> <li>Brad King</li> <li>Brendan Graetz</li> <li>Brian Anderson</li> <li>Brian Campbell</li> <li>Carol Nichols</li> <li>Chris Morgan</li> <li>Chris Wong</li> <li>Clark Gaebel</li> <li>Cole Reynolds</li> <li>Colin Walters</li> <li>Conrad Kleinespel</li> <li>Corey Farwell</li> <li>David Reid</li> <li>Diggory Hardy</li> <li>Dominic van Berkel</li> <li>Don Petersen</li> <li>Eduard Burtescu</li> <li>Eli Friedman</li> <li>Erick Tryzelaar</li> <li>Felix S. Klock II</li> <li>Florian Hahn</li> <li>Florian Hartwig</li> <li>Franziska Hinkelmann</li> <li>FuGangqiang</li> <li>Garming Sam</li> <li>Geoffrey Thomas</li> <li>Geoffry Song</li> <li>Graydon Hoare</li> <li>Guillaume Gomez</li> <li>Hech</li> <li>Heejong Ahn</li> <li>Hika Hibariya</li> <li>Huon Wilson</li> <li>Isaac Ge</li> <li>J Bailey</li> <li>Jake Goulding</li> <li>James Perry</li> <li>Jan Andersson</li> <li>Jan Bujak</li> <li>Jan-Erik Rediger</li> <li>Jannis Redmann</li> <li>Jason Yeo</li> <li>Johann</li> <li>Johann Hofmann</li> <li>Johannes Oertel</li> <li>John Gallagher</li> <li>John Van Enk</li> <li>Jordan Humphreys</li> <li>Joseph Crail</li> <li>Kang Seonghoon</li> <li>Kelvin Ly</li> <li>Kevin Ballard</li> <li>Kevin Mehall</li> <li>Krzysztof Drewniak</li> <li>Lee Aronson</li> <li>Lee Jeffery</li> <li>Liigo Zhuang</li> <li>Luke Gallagher</li> <li>Luqman Aden</li> <li>Manish Goregaokar</li> <li>Marin Atanasov Nikolov</li> <li>Mathieu Rochette</li> <li>Mathijs van de Nes</li> <li>Matt Brubeck</li> <li>Michael Park</li> <li>Michael Rosenberg</li> <li>Michael Sproul</li> <li>Michael Wu</li> <li>Michał Czardybon</li> <li>Mike Boutin</li> <li>Mike Sampson</li> <li>Ms2ger</li> <li>Nelo Onyiah</li> <li>Nicholas</li> <li>Nicholas Mazzuca</li> <li>Nick Cameron</li> <li>Nick Hamann</li> <li>Nick Platt</li> <li>Niko Matsakis</li> <li>Oliver Schneider</li> <li>P1start</li> <li>Pascal Hertleif</li> <li>Paul Banks</li> <li>Paul Faria</li> <li>Paul Quint</li> <li>Pete Hunt</li> <li>Peter Marheine</li> <li>Philip Munksgaard</li> <li>Piotr Czarnecki</li> <li>Poga Po</li> <li>Przemysław Wesołek</li> <li>Ralph Giles</li> <li>Raphael Speyer</li> <li>Ricardo Martins</li> <li>Richo Healey</li> <li>Rob Young</li> <li>Robin Kruppe</li> <li>Robin Stocker</li> <li>Rory O’Kane</li> <li>Ruud van Asseldonk</li> <li>Ryan Prichard</li> <li>Sean Bowe</li> <li>Sean McArthur</li> <li>Sean Patrick Santos</li> <li>Shmuale Mark</li> <li>Simon Kern</li> <li>Simon Sapin</li> <li>Simonas Kazlauskas</li> <li>Sindre Johansen</li> <li>Skyler</li> <li>Steve Klabnik</li> <li>Steven Allen</li> <li>Steven Fackler</li> <li>Swaroop C H</li> <li>Sébastien Marie</li> <li>Tamir Duberstein</li> <li>Theo Belaire</li> <li>Thomas Jespersen</li> <li>Tincan</li> <li>Ting-Yu Lin</li> <li>Tobias Bucher</li> <li>Toni Cárdenas</li> <li>Tshepang Lekhonkhobe</li> <li>Ulrik Sverdrup</li> <li>Vadim Chugunov</li> <li>Valerii Hiora</li> <li>Wangshan Lu</li> <li>Wei-Ming Yang</li> <li>Wojciech Ogrodowczyk</li> <li>Xuefeng Wu</li> <li>York Xiang</li> <li>Young Wu</li> <li>bors</li> <li>critiqjo</li> <li>diwic</li> <li>gareins</li> <li>inrustwetrust</li> <li>jooert</li> <li>klutzy</li> <li>kwantam</li> <li>leunggamciu</li> <li>mdinger</li> <li>nwin</li> <li>parir</li> <li>pez</li> <li>robertfoss</li> <li>sinkuu</li> <li>tynopex</li> <li>らいどっと</li> </ul> Announcing Rust 1.0 Fri, 15 May 2015 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-0/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-0/ <p>Today we are very proud to announce the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-100-may-2015">1.0 release of Rust</a>, a new programming language aiming to make it easier to build reliable, efficient systems. <strong>Rust combines low-level control over performance with high-level convenience and safety guarantees</strong>. Better yet, it achieves these goals without requiring a garbage collector or runtime, making it possible to <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2015/04/24/Rust-Once-Run-Everywhere.html">use Rust libraries as a &quot;drop-in replacement&quot; for C</a>. If you'd like to experiment with Rust, the <a href="http://doc.rust-lang.org/1.0.0/book/getting-started.html">&quot;Getting Started&quot; section of the Rust book</a> is your best bet (if you prefer to use an e-reader, Pascal Hertleif maintains <a href="http://killercup.github.io/trpl-ebook/">unofficial e-book versions</a> as well).</p> <p>What makes Rust different from other languages is its type system, which represents a refinement and codification of &quot;best practices&quot; that have been hammered out by generations of C and C++ programmers. As such, Rust has something to offer for both experienced systems programmers and newcomers alike: experienced programmers will find they save time they would have spent debugging, whereas newcomers can write low-level code without worrying about minor mistakes leading to mysterious crashes.</p> <h3 id="what-does-it-mean-for-rust-to-be-1-0">What does it mean for Rust to be 1.0?</h3> <p>The current Rust language is the result of a lot of iteration and experimentation. The process has worked out well for us: Rust today is both simpler and more powerful than we originally thought would be possible. But all that experimentation also made it difficult to maintain projects written in Rust, since the language and standard library were constantly changing.</p> <p><strong>The 1.0 release marks the end of that churn.</strong> This release is the official beginning of our <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/10/30/Stability.html">commitment to stability</a>, and as such it offers a firm foundation for building applications and libraries. From this point forward, breaking changes are largely out of scope (some <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1105">minor</a> <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1122">caveats</a> apply, such as compiler bugs).</p> <p>That said, releasing 1.0 doesn't mean that the Rust language is &quot;done&quot;. We have many <a href="http://internals.rust-lang.org/t/priorities-after-1-0/1901">improvements in store</a>. In fact, the Nightly builds of Rust already demonstrate <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/24965">improvements to</a> <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/24615">compile</a> <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/25323">times</a> (with more to come) and includes work on new APIs and language features, like <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1044"><code>std::fs</code></a> and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/23606/">associated constants</a>.</p> <p>To help ensure that compiler and language improvements make their way out into the ecosystem at large as quickly as possible, we've adopted a <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/12/12/1.0-Timeline.html">train-based</a> release model. This means that we'll be issuing regular releases every six weeks, just like the Firefox and Chrome web browsers. <strong>To kick off that process, we are also releasing Rust 1.1 beta today, simultaneously with Rust 1.0.</strong></p> <h3 id="cargo-and-crates-io">Cargo and crates.io</h3> <p>Building a real project is about more than just writing code -- it's also about managing dependencies. <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/11/20/Cargo.html">Cargo</a>, the Rust package manager and build system, is designed to make this easy. Using Cargo, downloading and installing new libraries is as simple as adding one line to your manifest.</p> <p>Of course, to use a dependency, you first have to find it. This is where <a href="https://crates.io/">crates.io</a> comes in -- crates.io is a central package repository for Rust code. It makes it easy to search for other people's packages or to publish your own.</p> <p>Since we <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/11/20/Cargo.html">announced cargo and crates.io</a> approximately six months ago, the number of packages has been growing steadily. Nonetheless, it's still early days, and there are still lots of great packages yet to be written. If you're interested in building a library that will take the Rust world by storm, there's no time like the present!</p> <h3 id="open-source-and-open-governance">Open Source and Open Governance</h3> <p>Rust has been an open-source project from the start. Over the last few years, we've been constantly looking for ways to make our governance more open and community driven. Since we introduced the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/README.md">RFC process</a> a little over a year ago, all major decisions about Rust are written up and discussed in the open in the form of an RFC. Recently, we adopted a <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1068">new governance model</a>, which establishes a set of subteams, each responsible for RFCs in one particular area. If you'd like help shape the future of Rust, we encourage you to get involved, either by uploading libraries to <a href="https://crates.io/">crates.io</a>, commenting on RFCs, or <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md">writing code for Rust itself</a>.</p> <p>We'd like to give a special thank you to the following people, each of whom contributed changes since our previous release (the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/AUTHORS.txt">complete list of contributors</a> is here):</p> <ul> <li><code>Aaron Gallagher</code></li> <li><code>Aaron Turon</code></li> <li><code>Abhishek Chanda</code></li> <li><code>Adolfo Ochagavía</code></li> <li><code>Alex Burka</code></li> <li><code>Alex Crichton</code></li> <li><code>Alex Quach</code></li> <li><code>Alexander Polakov</code></li> <li><code>Andrea Canciani</code></li> <li><code>Andreas Martens</code></li> <li><code>Andreas Tolfsen</code></li> <li><code>Andrei <li><code>diwic</code></li> <li><code>fenduru</code></li> <li><code>gareins</code></li> <li><code>github-monoculture</code></li> <li><code>inrustwetrust</code></li> <li><code>jooert</code></li> <li><code>kgv</code></li> <li><code>klutzy</code></li> <li><code>kwantam</code></li> <li><code>leunggamciu</code></li> <li><code>mdinger</code></li> <li><code>nwin</code></li> <li><code>pez</code></li> <li><code>robertfoss</code></li> <li><code>rundrop1</code></li> <li><code>sinkuu</code></li> <li><code>tynopex</code></li> <li><code>Łukasz Niemier</code></li> <li><code>らいどっと</code></li> </ul> Abstraction without overhead: traits in Rust Mon, 11 May 2015 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/traits/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/traits/ <p><a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2015/04/10/Fearless-Concurrency.html">Previous posts</a> have covered two pillars of Rust's design:</p> <ul> <li>Memory safety without garbage collection</li> <li>Concurrency without data races</li> </ul> <p>This post begins exploring the third pillar:</p> <ul> <li><strong>Abstraction without overhead</strong></li> </ul> <p>One of the mantras of C++, one of the qualities that make it a good fit for systems programming, is its principle of zero-cost abstraction:</p> <blockquote> <p>C++ implementations obey the zero-overhead principle: What you don't use, you don't pay for [Stroustrup, 1994]. And further: What you do use, you couldn't hand code any better.</p> <p>-- Stroustrup</p> </blockquote> <p>This mantra did not always apply to Rust, which for example used to have mandatory garbage collection. But over time Rust's ambitions have gotten ever lower-level, and zero-cost abstraction is now a core principle.</p> <p>The cornerstone of abstraction in Rust is <em>traits</em>:</p> <ul> <li> <p><strong>Traits are Rust's sole notion of interface</strong>. A trait can be implemented by multiple types, and in fact new traits can provide implementations for existing types. On the flip side, when you want to abstract over an unknown type, traits are how you specify the few concrete things you need to know about that type.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Traits can be statically dispatched</strong>. Like C++ templates, you can have the compiler generate a separate copy of an abstraction for each way it is instantiated. This comes back to the C++ mantra of &quot;What you do use, you couldn't hand code any better&quot; -- the abstraction ends up completely erased.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Traits can be dynamically dispatched</strong>. Sometimes you really do need an indirection, and so it doesn't make sense to &quot;erase&quot; an abstraction at runtime. The <em>same</em> notion of interface -- the trait -- can also be used when you want to dispatch at runtime.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Traits solve a variety of additional problems beyond simple abstraction</strong>. They are used as &quot;markers&quot; for types, like the <code>Send</code> marker described <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2015/04/10/Fearless-Concurrency.html">in a previous post</a>. They can be used to define &quot;extension methods&quot; -- that is, to add methods to an externally-defined type. They largely obviate the need for traditional method overloading. And they provide a simple scheme for operator overloading.</p> </li> </ul> <p>All told, the trait system is the secret sauce that gives Rust the ergonomic, expressive feel of high-level languages while retaining low-level control over code execution and data representation.</p> <p>This post will walk through each of the above points at a high level, to give you a sense for how the design achieves these goals, without getting too bogged down in the details.</p> <h3 id="background-methods-in-rust">Background: methods in Rust</h3> <blockquote> <p>Before delving into traits, we need to look at a small but important detail of the language: the difference between methods and functions.</p> </blockquote> <p>Rust offers both methods and free-standing functions, which are very closely related:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Point { </span><span style="color:#c82829;">x</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">f64</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#c82829;">y</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">f64</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, } </span><span style="color:#999999;">// a free-standing function that converts a (borrowed) point to a string </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">point_to_string</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">point</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Point) -&gt; String { </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">... </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span><span style="color:#999999;">// an &quot;inherent impl&quot; block defines the methods available directly on a type </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">impl </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Point { </span><span style="color:#999999;">// this method is available on any Point, and automatically borrows the // Point value </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">to_string</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) -&gt; String { </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">... </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} } </span></pre> <p>Methods like <code>to_string</code> above are called &quot;inherent&quot; methods, because they:</p> <ul> <li>Are tied to a single concrete &quot;self&quot; type (specified via the <code>impl</code> block header).</li> <li>Are <em>automatically</em> available on any value of that type -- that is, unlike functions, inherent methods are always &quot;in scope&quot;.</li> </ul> <p>The first parameter for a method is always an explicit &quot;self&quot;, which is either <code>self</code>, <code>&amp;mut self</code>, or <code>&amp;self</code> depending on the <a href="http://blog.skylight.io/rust-means-never-having-to-close-a-socket/">level of ownership required</a>. Methods are invoked using the <code>.</code> notation familiar from object-oriented programming, and the self parameter is <em>implicitly borrowed</em> as per the form of <code>self</code> used in the method:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> p </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> Point { x: </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1.2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, y: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">-</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">3.7 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">}; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> s1 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">point_to_string</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">p); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// calling a free function, explicit borrow </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> s2 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> p.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">to_string</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// calling a method, implicit borrow as &amp;p </span></pre> <p>Methods and their auto-borrowing are an important aspect of the ergonomics of Rust, supporting &quot;fluent&quot; APIs like the one for spawning processes:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> child </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Command::new(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;/bin/cat&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) .</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">arg</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;rusty-ideas.txt&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) .</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">current_dir</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;/Users/aturon&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) .</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">stdout</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(Stdio::piped()) .</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">spawn</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(); </span></pre><h3 id="traits-are-interfaces">Traits are interfaces</h3> <p>Interfaces specify the expectations that one piece of code has on another, allowing each to be switched out independently. For traits, this specification largely revolves around methods.</p> <p>Take, for example, the following simple trait for hashing:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">trait </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Hash { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">hash</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) -&gt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u64</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; } </span></pre> <p>In order to implement this trait for a given type, you must provide a <code>hash</code> method with matching signature:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">impl </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Hash </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">for </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">bool { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">hash</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) -&gt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u64 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">if </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">*</span><span style="color:#c82829;">self </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">else </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} } } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">impl </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Hash </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">for </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">i64 { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">hash</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) -&gt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u64 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">*</span><span style="color:#c82829;">self </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">as </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u64 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} } </span></pre> <p>Unlike interfaces in languages like Java, C# or Scala, <strong>new traits can be implemented for existing types</strong> (as with <code>Hash</code> above). That means abstractions can be created after-the-fact, and applied to existing libraries.</p> <p>Unlike inherent methods, trait methods are in scope only when their trait is. But assuming <code>Hash</code> is in scope, you can write <code>true.hash()</code>, so implementing a trait extends the set of methods available on a type.</p> <p>And... that's it! Defining and implementing a trait is really nothing more than abstracting out a common interface satisfied by more than one type.</p> <h3 id="static-dispatch">Static dispatch</h3> <p>Things get more interesting on the other side -- consuming a trait. The most common way of doing so is through <em>generics</em>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">print_hash</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&lt;T: Hash&gt;(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">t</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">T) { println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;The hash is </span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, t.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">hash</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">()) } </span></pre> <p>The <code>print_hash</code> function is generic over an unknown type <code>T</code>, but requires that <code>T</code> implements the <code>Hash</code> trait. That means we can use it with <code>bool</code> and <code>i64</code> values:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4271ae;">print_hash</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">true</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// instantiates T = bool </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">print_hash</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">12_</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i64</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// instantiates T = i64 </span></pre> <p><strong>Generics are compiled away, resulting in static dispatch</strong>. That is, as with C++ templates, the compiler will generate <em>two copies</em> of the <code>print_hash</code> method to handle the above code, one for each concrete argument type. That in turn means that the internal call to <code>t.hash()</code> -- the point where the abstraction is actually used -- has zero cost: it will be compiled to a direct, static call to the relevant implementation:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#999999;">// The compiled code: </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">__print_hash_bool</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">true</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// invoke specialized bool version directly </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">__print_hash_i64</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">12_</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i64</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// invoke specialized i64 version directly </span></pre> <p>This compilation model isn't so useful for a function like <code>print_hash</code>, but it's <em>very</em> useful for more realistic uses of hashing. Suppose we also introduce a trait for equality comparison:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">trait </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Eq { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">eq</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">other</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">Self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) -&gt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">bool</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; } </span></pre> <p>(The reference to <code>Self</code> here will resolve to whatever type we implement the trait for; in <code>impl Eq for bool</code> it will refer to <code>bool</code>.)</p> <p>We can then define a hash map that is generic over a type <code>T</code> implementing both <code>Hash</code> and <code>Eq</code>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">HashMap&lt;Key: Hash </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> Eq, Value&gt; { ... } </span></pre> <p>The static compilation model for generics will then yield several benefits:</p> <ul> <li> <p>Each use of <code>HashMap</code> with concrete <code>Key</code> and <code>Value</code> types will result in a different concrete <code>HashMap</code> type, which means that <code>HashMap</code> can lay out the keys and values in-line (without indirection) in its buckets. This saves on space and indirections, and improves cache locality.</p> </li> <li> <p>Each method on <code>HashMap</code> will likewise generate specialized code. That means there is no extra cost dispatching to calls to <code>hash</code> and <code>eq</code>, as above. It also means that the optimizer gets to work with the fully concrete code -- that is, from the point of view of the optimizer, <em>there is no abstraction</em>. In particular, static dispatch allows for <em>inlining</em> across uses of generics.</p> </li> </ul> <p>Altogether, just as in C++ templates, these aspects of generics mean that you can write quite high-level abstractions that are <em>guaranteed</em> to compile down to fully concrete code that &quot;you couldn't hand code any better&quot;.</p> <p><strong>But, unlike with C++ templates, clients of traits are fully type-checked in advance</strong>. That is, when you compile <code>HashMap</code> in isolation, its code is checked <em>once</em> for type correctness against the abstract <code>Hash</code> and <code>Eq</code> traits, rather than being checked repeatedly when applied to concrete types. That means earlier, clearer compilation errors for library authors, and less typechecking overhead (i.e., faster compilation) for clients.</p> <h3 id="dynamic-dispatch">Dynamic dispatch</h3> <p>We've seen one compilation model for traits, where all abstraction is compiled away statically. But sometimes abstraction isn't just about reuse or modularity -- <strong>sometimes abstraction plays an essential role at runtime that can't be compiled away</strong>.</p> <p>For example, GUI frameworks often involve callbacks for responding to events, such as mouse clicks:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">trait </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">ClickCallback { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">on_click</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">x</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i64</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">y</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i64</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); } </span></pre> <p>It's also common for GUI elements to allow multiple callbacks to be registered for a single event. With generics, you might imagine writing:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Button&lt;T: ClickCallback&gt; { </span><span style="color:#c82829;">listeners</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: Vec&lt;T&gt;, ... } </span></pre> <p>but the problem is immediately apparent: that would mean that each button is specialized to precisely one implementor of <code>ClickCallback</code>, and that the type of the button reflects that type. That's not at all what we wanted! Instead, we'd like a single <code>Button</code> type with a set of <em>heterogeneous</em> listeners, each potentially a different concrete type, but each one implementing <code>ClickCallback</code>.</p> <p>One immediate difficulty here is that, if we're talking about a heterogeneous group of types, <em>each one will have a distinct size</em> -- so how can we even lay out the internal vector? The answer is the usual one: indirection. We'll store <em>pointers</em> to callbacks in the vector:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Button { </span><span style="color:#c82829;">listeners</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: Vec&lt;Box&lt;ClickCallback&gt;&gt;, ... } </span></pre> <p>Here, we are using the <code>ClickCallback</code> trait as if it were a type. Actually, in Rust, <a href="http://smallcultfollowing.com/babysteps/blog/2014/01/05/dst-take-5/">traits <em>are</em> types, but they are &quot;unsized&quot;</a>, which roughly means that they are only allowed to show up behind a pointer like <code>Box</code> (which points onto the heap) or <code>&amp;</code> (which can point anywhere).</p> <p>In Rust, a type like <code>&amp;ClickCallback</code> or <code>Box&lt;ClickCallback&gt;</code> is called a &quot;trait object&quot;, and includes a pointer to an instance of a type <code>T</code> implementing <code>ClickCallback</code>, <em>and</em> a vtable: a pointer to <code>T</code>'s implementation of each method in the trait (here, just <code>on_click</code>). That information is enough to dispatch calls to methods correctly at runtime, and to ensure uniform representation for all <code>T</code>. So <code>Button</code> is compiled just once, and the abstraction lives on at runtime.</p> <p>Static and dynamic dispatch are complementary tools, each appropriate for different scenarios. <strong>Rust's traits provide a single, simple notion of interface that can be used in both styles, with minimal, predictable costs</strong>. Trait objects satisfy Stroustrup's &quot;pay as you go&quot; principle: you have vtables when you need them, but the same trait can be compiled away statically when you don't.</p> <h3 id="the-many-uses-of-traits">The many uses of traits</h3> <p>We've seen a lot of the mechanics and basic use of traits above, but they also wind up playing a few other important roles in Rust. Here's a taste:</p> <ul> <li> <p><strong>Closures</strong>. Somewhat like the <code>ClickCallback</code> trait, closures in Rust are simply particular traits. You can read more about how this works in Huon Wilson's <a href="http://huonw.github.io/blog/2015/05/finding-closure-in-rust/">in-depth post</a> on the topic.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Conditional APIs</strong>. Generics make it possible to implement a trait conditionally:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Pair&lt;A, B&gt; { </span><span style="color:#c82829;">first</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: A, </span><span style="color:#c82829;">second</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: B } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">impl</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&lt;A: Hash, B: Hash&gt; Hash </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">for </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Pair&lt;A, B&gt; { </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">hash</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) -&gt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u64 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> </span><span style="color:#c82829;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">.first.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">hash</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">^ </span><span style="color:#c82829;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">.second.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">hash</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> } </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p>Here, the <code>Pair</code> type implements <code>Hash</code> if, and only if, its components do -- allowing the single <code>Pair</code> type to be used in different contexts, while supporting the largest API available for each context. It's such a common pattern in Rust that there is built-in support for generating certain kinds of &quot;mechanical&quot; implementations automatically:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">#[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">derive</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(Hash)] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Pair&lt;A, B&gt; { .. } </span></pre></li> <li> <p><strong>Extension methods</strong>. Traits can be used to extend an existing type (defined elsewhere) with new methods, for convenience, similarly to C#'s extension methods. This falls directly out of the scoping rules for traits: you just define the new methods in a trait, provide an implementation for the type in question, and <em>voila</em>, the method is available.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Markers</strong>. Rust has a handful of &quot;markers&quot; that classify types: <code>Send</code>, <code>Sync</code>, <code>Copy</code>, <code>Sized</code>. These markers are just <em>traits</em> with empty bodies, which can then be used in both generics and trait objects. Markers can be defined in libraries, and they automatically provide <code>#[derive]</code>-style implementations: if all of a types components are <code>Send</code>, for example, so is the type. As we saw <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2015/04/10/Fearless-Concurrency.html">before</a>, these markers can be very powerful: the <code>Send</code> marker is how Rust guarantees thread safety.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Overloading</strong>. Rust does not support traditional overloading where the same method is defined with multiple signatures. But traits provide much of the benefit of overloading: if a method is defined generically over a trait, it can be called with any type implementing that trait. Compared to traditional overloading, this has two advantages. First, it means the overloading is less <a href="http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=75283">ad hoc</a>: once you understand a trait, you immediately understand the overloading pattern of any APIs using it. Second, it is <em>extensible</em>: you can effectively provide new overloads downstream from a method by providing new trait implementations.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Operators</strong>. Rust allows you to overload operators like <code>+</code> on your own types. Each of the operators is defined by a corresponding standard library trait, and any type implementing the trait automatically provides the operator as well.</p> </li> </ul> <p>The point: <strong>despite their seeming simplicity, traits are a unifying concept that supports a wide range of use cases and patterns, without having to pile on additional language features.</strong></p> <h3 id="the-future">The future</h3> <p>One of the primary ways that languages tend to evolve is in their abstraction facilities, and Rust is no exception: many of our <a href="http://internals.rust-lang.org/t/priorities-after-1-0/1901">post-1.0 priorities</a> are extensions of the trait system in one direction or another. Here are some highlights.</p> <ul> <li> <p><strong>Statically dispatched outputs</strong>. Right now, it's possible for functions to use generics for their parameters, but there's no equivalent for their results: you cannot say &quot;this function returns a value of some type that implements the <code>Iterator</code> trait&quot; and have that abstraction compiled away. This is particularly problematic when you want to return a closure that you'd like to be statically-dispatched -- you simply can't, in today's Rust. We want to make this possible, and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/105">have some ideas already</a>.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Specialization</strong>. Rust does not allow overlap between trait implementations, so there is never ambiguity about which code to run. On the other hand, there are some cases where you can give a &quot;blanket&quot; implementation for a wide range of types, but would then like to provide a more specialized implementation for a few cases, often for performance reasons. We hope to propose a design in the near future.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Higher-kinded types</strong> (HKT). Traits today can only be applied to <em>types</em>, not <em>type constructors</em> -- that is, to things like <code>Vec&lt;u8&gt;</code>, not to <code>Vec</code> itself. This limitation makes it difficult to provide a good set of container traits, which are therefore not included in the current standard library. HKT is a major, cross-cutting feature that will represent a big step forward in Rust's abstraction capabilities.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Efficient re-use</strong>. Finally, while traits provide some mechanisms for reusing code (which we didn't cover above), there are still some patterns of reuse that don't fit well into the language today -- notably, object-oriented hierarchies found in things like the DOM, GUI frameworks, and many games. Accommodating these use cases without adding too much overlap or complexity is a very interesting design problem, and one that Niko Matsakis has started a separate <a href="http://smallcultfollowing.com/babysteps/blog/2015/05/05/where-rusts-enum-shines/">blog series</a> about. It's not yet clear whether this can all be done with traits, or whether some other ingredients are needed.</p> </li> </ul> <p>Of course, we're at the eve of the 1.0 release, and it will take some time for the dust to settle, and for the community to have enough experience to start landing these extensions. But that makes it an exciting time to get involved: from influencing the design at this early stage, to working on implementation, to trying out different use cases in your own code -- we'd love to have your help!</p> Rust Once, Run Everywhere Fri, 24 Apr 2015 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-once-run-everywhere/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-once-run-everywhere/ <p>Rust's quest for world domination was never destined to happen overnight, so Rust needs to be able to interoperate with the existing world just as easily as it talks to itself. For this reason, <strong>Rust makes it easy to communicate with C APIs without overhead, and to leverage its ownership system to provide much stronger safety guarantees for those APIs at the same time</strong>.</p> <p>To communicate with other languages, Rust provides a <em>foreign function interface</em> (FFI). Following Rust's design principles, the FFI provides a <strong>zero-cost abstraction</strong> where function calls between Rust and C have identical performance to C function calls. FFI bindings can also leverage language features such as ownership and borrowing to provide a <strong>safe interface</strong> that enforces protocols around pointers and other resources. These protocols usually appear only in the documentation for C APIs -- at best -- but Rust makes them explicit.</p> <p>In this post we'll explore how to encapsulate unsafe FFI calls to C in safe, zero-cost abstractions. Working with C is, however, just an example; we'll also see how Rust can easily talk to languages like Python and Ruby just as seamlessly as with C.</p> <h3 id="rust-talking-to-c">Rust talking to C</h3> <p>Let's start with a simple example of calling C code from Rust and then demonstrate that Rust imposes no additional overhead. Here's a C program which will simply double all the input it's given:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">int </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">double_input</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">int </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">input</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">return</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> input </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">* </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; } </span></pre> <p>To call this from Rust, you might write a program like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">extern crate</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> libc; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">extern </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">double_input</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">input</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: libc::c_int) -&gt; libc::c_int; } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> input </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">4</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> output </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">unsafe </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">double_input</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(input) }; println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;"> * 2 = </span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, input, output); } </span></pre> <p>And that's it! You can try this out for yourself by <a href="https://github.com/alexcrichton/rust-ffi-examples/tree/master/rust-to-c">checking out the code on GitHub</a> and running <code>cargo run</code> from that directory. <strong>At the source level we can see that there's no burden in calling an external function beyond stating its signature, and we'll see soon that the generated code indeed has no overhead, either.</strong> There are, however, a few subtle aspects of this Rust program, so let's cover each piece in detail.</p> <p>First up we see <code>extern crate libc</code>. <a href="https://crates.io/crates/libc">The libc crate</a> provides many useful type definitions for FFI bindings when talking with C, and it makes it easy to ensure that both C and Rust agree on the types crossing the language boundary.</p> <p>This leads us nicely into the next part of the program:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">extern </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">double_input</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">input</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: libc::c_int) -&gt; libc::c_int; } </span></pre> <p>In Rust this is a <strong>declaration</strong> of an externally available function. You can think of this along the lines of a C header file. Here's where the compiler learns about the inputs and outputs of the function, and you can see above that this matches our definition in C. Next up we have the main body of the program:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> input </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">4</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> output </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">unsafe </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">double_input</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(input) }; println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;"> * 2 = </span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, input, output); } </span></pre> <p>We see one of the crucial aspects of FFI in Rust here, the <code>unsafe</code> block. The compiler knows nothing about the implementation of <code>double_input</code>, so it must assume that memory unsafety <em>could</em> happen whenever you call a foreign function. The <code>unsafe</code> block is how the programmer takes responsibility for ensuring safety -- you are promising that the actual call you make will not, in fact, violate memory safety, and thus that Rust's basic guarantees are upheld. This may seem limiting, but Rust has just the right set of tools to allow consumers to not worry about <code>unsafe</code> (more on this in a moment).</p> <p>Now that we've seen how to call a C function from Rust, let's see if we can verify this claim of zero overhead. Almost all programming languages can call into C one way or another, but it often comes at a cost with runtime type conversions or perhaps some language-runtime juggling. To get a handle on what Rust is doing, let's go straight to the assembly code of the above <code>main</code> function's call to <code>double_input</code>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">mov $0x4,%edi callq 3bc30 &lt;double_input&gt; </span></pre> <p>And as before, that's it! Here we can see that calling a C function from Rust involves precisely one call instruction after moving the arguments into place, exactly the same cost as it would be in C.</p> <h3 id="safe-abstractions">Safe Abstractions</h3> <p>Most features in Rust tie into its core concept of ownership, and the FFI is no exception. When binding a C library in Rust you not only have the benefit of zero overhead, but you are also able to make it <em>safer</em> than C can! <strong>Bindings can leverage the ownership and borrowing principles in Rust to codify comments typically found in a C header about how its API should be used.</strong></p> <p>For example, consider a C library for parsing a tarball. This library will expose functions to read the contents of each file in the tarball, probably something along the lines of:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#999999;">// Gets the data for a file in the tarball at the given index, returning NULL if // it does not exist.
