The `size` pointer is filled in with the size of the file // if successful. </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">const char </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">*</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">tarball_file_data</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(tarball_t </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">*</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">tarball</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">unsigned </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">index</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">size_t </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">*</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">size</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); </span></pre> <p>This function is implicitly making assumptions about how it can be used, however, by assuming that the <code>char*</code> pointer returned cannot outlive the input tarball. When bound in Rust, this API might look like this instead:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">pub struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Tarball { </span><span style="color:#c82829;">raw</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">*mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> tarball_t } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">impl </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Tarball { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">pub fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">file</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">index</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) -&gt; Option&lt;</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">[</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u8</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">]&gt; { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">unsafe </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> size </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> data </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">tarball_file_data</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#c82829;">self</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">.raw, index </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">as </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">libc::</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">c_uint</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> size); </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">if</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> data.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">is_null</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">None </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">else </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Some</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(slice::from_raw_parts(data </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">as </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">*const u8</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, size </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">as </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">usize</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">)) } } } } </span></pre> <p>Here the <code>*mut tarball_t</code> pointer is <em>owned by</em> a <code>Tarball</code>, which is responsible for any destruction and cleanup, so we already have rich knowledge about the lifetime of the tarball's memory. Additionally, the <code>file</code> method returns a <strong>borrowed slice</strong> whose lifetime is implicitly connected to the lifetime of the source tarball itself (the <code>&amp;self</code> argument). This is Rust's way of indicating that the returned slice can only be used within the lifetime of the tarball, statically preventing dangling pointer bugs that are easy to make when working directly with C. (If you're not familiar with this kind of borrowing in Rust, have a look at Yehuda Katz's <a href="http://blog.skylight.io/rust-means-never-having-to-close-a-socket/">blog post on ownership</a>.)</p> <p>A key aspect of the Rust binding here is that it is a safe function, meaning that callers do not have to use <code>unsafe</code> blocks to invoke it! Although it has an <code>unsafe</code> <em>implementation</em> (due to calling an FFI function), the <em>interface</em> uses borrowing to guarantee that no memory unsafety can occur in any Rust code that uses it. That is, due to Rust's static checking, it's simply not possible to cause a segfault using the API on the Rust side. And don't forget, all of this is coming at zero cost: the raw types in C are representable in Rust with no extra allocations or overhead.</p> <p>Rust's amazing community has already built some substantial safe bindings around existing C libraries, including <a href="https://crates.io/crates/openssl">OpenSSL</a>, <a href="https://crates.io/crates/git2">libgit2</a>, <a href="https://crates.io/crates/dispatch">libdispatch</a>, <a href="https://crates.io/crates/curl">libcurl</a>, <a href="https://crates.io/crates/sdl2">sdl2</a>, <a href="https://crates.io/crates/nix">Unix APIs</a>, and <a href="https://crates.io/crates/sodiumoxide">libsodium</a>. This list is also growing quite rapidly on <a href="https://crates.io">crates.io</a>, so your favorite C library may already be bound or will be bound soon!</p> <h3 id="c-talking-to-rust">C talking to Rust</h3> <p><strong>Despite guaranteeing memory safety, Rust does not have a garbage collector or runtime, and one of the benefits of this is that Rust code can be called from C with no setup at all.</strong> This means that the zero overhead FFI not only applies when Rust calls into C, but also when C calls into Rust!</p> <p>Let's take the example above, but reverse the roles of each language. As before, all the code below is <a href="https://github.com/alexcrichton/rust-ffi-examples/tree/master/c-to-rust">available on GitHub</a>. First we'll start off with our Rust code:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">#[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">no_mangle</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">pub extern fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">double_input</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">input</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) -&gt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ input </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">* </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p>As with the Rust code before, there's not a whole lot here but there are some subtle aspects in play. First off, we've labeled our function definition with a <code>#[no_mangle]</code> attribute. This instructs the compiler to not mangle the symbol name for the function <code>double_input</code>. Rust employs name mangling similar to C++ to ensure that libraries do not clash with one another, and this attribute means that you don't have to guess a symbol name like <code>double_input::h485dee7f568bebafeaa</code> from C.</p> <p>Next we've got our function definition, and the most interesting part about this is the keyword <code>extern</code>. This is a specialized form of specifying the <a href="http://doc.rust-lang.org/reference.html#extern-functions">ABI for a function</a> which enables the function to be compatible with a C function call.</p> <p>Finally, if you <a href="https://github.com/alexcrichton/rust-ffi-examples/blob/master/c-to-rust/Cargo.toml#L8">take a look at the <code>Cargo.toml</code></a> you'll see that this library is not compiled as a normal Rust library (rlib) but instead as a static archive which Rust calls a 'staticlib'. This enables all the relevant Rust code to be linked statically into the C program we're about to produce.</p> <p>Now that we've got our Rust library squared away, let's write our C program which will call Rust.</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">#include </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&lt;stdint.h&gt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">#include </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&lt;stdio.h&gt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">extern </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">int32_t </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">double_input</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#c99e00;">int32_t </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">input</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">int </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">main</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">int</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> input </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">4</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">int</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> output </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#c82829;">double_input</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">(input)</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">printf(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#666969;">%d</span><span style="color:#718c00;"> * 2 = </span><span style="color:#666969;">%d</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">\n</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">, input, output)</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">return </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; } </span></pre> <p>Here we can see that C, like Rust, needs to declare the <code>double_input</code> function that Rust defined. Other than that though everything is ready to go! If you run <code>make</code> from the <a href="https://github.com/alexcrichton/rust-ffi-examples/tree/master/c-to-rust">directory on GitHub</a> you'll see these examples getting compiled and linked together and the final executable should run and print <code>4 * 2 = 8</code>.</p> <p>Rust's lack of a garbage collector and runtime enables this seamless transition from C to Rust. The external C code does not need to perform any setup on Rust's behalf, making the transition that much cheaper.</p> <h3 id="beyond-c">Beyond C</h3> <p>Up to now we've seen how FFI in Rust has zero overhead and how we can use Rust's concept of ownership to write safe bindings to C libraries. If you're not using C, however, you're still in luck! These features of Rust enable it to also be called from <a href="https://github.com/alexcrichton/rust-ffi-examples/tree/master/python-to-rust">Python</a>, <a href="https://github.com/alexcrichton/rust-ffi-examples/tree/master/ruby-to-rust">Ruby</a>, <a href="https://github.com/alexcrichton/rust-ffi-examples/tree/master/node-to-rust">JavaScript</a>, and many more languages.</p> <p>When writing code in these languages, you sometimes want to speed up some component that's performance critical, but in the past this often required dropping all the way to C, and thereby giving up the memory safety, high-level abstractions, and ergonomics of these languages.</p> <p>The fact that Rust can talk to easily with C, however, means that it is also viable for this sort of usage. One of Rust's first production users, <a href="https://www.skylight.io">Skylight</a>, was able to improve the performance and memory usage of their data collection agent almost instantly by just using Rust, and the Rust code is all published as a Ruby gem.</p> <p>Moving from a language like Python and Ruby down to C to optimize performance is often quite difficult as it's tough to ensure that the program won't crash in a difficult-to-debug way. Rust, however, not only brings zero cost FFI, but <em>also</em> makes it possible to retain the same safety guarantees as the original source language. In the long run, this should make it much easier for programmers in these languages to drop down and do some systems programming to squeeze out critical performance when they need it.</p> <p>FFI is just one of many tools in the toolbox of Rust, but it's a key component to Rust's adoption as it allows Rust to seamlessly integrate with existing code bases today. I'm personally quite excited to see the benefits of Rust reach as many projects as possible!</p> Mixing matching, mutation, and moves in Rust Fri, 17 Apr 2015 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/enums-match-mutation-and-moves/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/enums-match-mutation-and-moves/ <p>One of the primary goals of the Rust project is to enable safe systems programming. Systems programming usually implies imperative programming, which in turns often implies side-effects, reasoning about shared state, et cetera.</p> <p>At the same time, to provide <em>safety</em>, Rust programs and data types must be structured in a way that allows static checking to ensure soundness. Rust has features and restrictions that operate in tandem to ease writing programs that can pass these checks and thus ensure safety. For example, Rust incorporates the notion of <em>ownership</em> deeply into the language.</p> <p>Rust's <code>match</code> expression is a construct that offers an interesting combination of such features and restrictions. A <code>match</code> expression takes an input value, classifies it, and then jumps to code written to handle the identified class of data.</p> <p>In this post we explore how Rust processes such data via <code>match</code>. The crucial elements that <code>match</code> and its counterpart <code>enum</code> tie together are:</p> <ul> <li> <p>Structural pattern matching: case analysis with ergonomics vastly improved over a C or Java style <code>switch</code> statement.</p> </li> <li> <p>Exhaustive case analysis: ensures that no case is omitted when processing an input.</p> </li> <li> <p><code>match</code> embraces both imperative and functional styles of programming: you can continue using <code>break</code> statements, assignments, et cetera, rather than being forced to adopt an expression-oriented mindset.</p> </li> <li> <p><code>match</code> &quot;borrows&quot; or &quot;moves&quot;, as needed: Rust encourages the developer to think carefully about ownership and borrowing. To ensure that one is not forced to yield ownership of a value prematurely, <code>match</code> is designed with support for merely <em>borrowing</em> substructure (as opposed to always <em>moving</em> such substructure).</p> </li> </ul> <p>We cover each of the items above in detail below, but first we establish a foundation for the discussion: What does <code>match</code> look like, and how does it work?</p> <h3 id="the-basics-of-match">The Basics of <code>match</code></h3> <p>The <code>match</code> expression in Rust has this form:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">match </span><span style="color:#666969;">INPUT_EXPRESSION </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#666969;">PATTERNS_1 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#666969;">RESULT_EXPRESSION_1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#666969;">PATTERNS_2 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#666969;">RESULT_EXPRESSION_2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">...</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> PATTERNS_n </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> RESULT_EXPRESSION_n } </span></pre> <p>where each of the <code>PATTERNS_i</code> contains at least one <em>pattern</em>. A pattern describes a subset of the possible values to which <code>INPUT_EXPRESSION</code> could evaluate. The syntax <code>PATTERNS =&gt; RESULT_EXPRESSION</code> is called a &quot;match arm&quot;, or simply &quot;arm&quot;.</p> <p>Patterns can match simple values like integers or characters; they can also match user-defined symbolic data, defined via <code>enum</code>.</p> <p>The below code demonstrates generating the next guess (poorly) in a number guessing game, given the answer from a previous guess.</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">enum </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Answer { Higher, Lower, Bingo, } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">suggest_guess</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">prior_guess</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">answer</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: Answer) { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">match</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> answer { Answer::Higher </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;maybe try </span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;"> next&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, prior_guess </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">10</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">), Answer::Lower </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;maybe try </span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;"> next&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, prior_guess </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">- </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">), Answer::Bingo </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;we won with </span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">!&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, prior_guess), } } #[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">test</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">demo_suggest_guess</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">suggest_guess</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">10</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, Answer::Higher); </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">suggest_guess</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">20</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, Answer::Lower); </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">suggest_guess</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">19</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, Answer::Bingo); } </span></pre> <p>(Incidentally, nearly all the code in this post is directly executable; you can cut-and-paste the code snippets into a file <code>demo.rs</code>, compile the file with <code>--test</code>, and run the resulting binary to see the tests run.)</p> <p>Patterns can also match <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Record_%28computer_science%29">structured data</a> (e.g. tuples, slices, user-defined data types) via corresponding patterns. In such patterns, one often binds parts of the input to local variables; those variables can then be used in the result expression.</p> <p>The special <code>_</code> pattern matches any single value, and is often used as a catch-all; the special <code>..</code> pattern generalizes this by matching any <em>series</em> of values or name/value pairs.</p> <p>Also, one can collapse multiple patterns into one arm by separating the patterns by vertical bars (<code>|</code>); thus that arm matches either this pattern, or that pattern, et cetera.</p> <p>These features are illustrated in the following revision to the guessing-game answer generation strategy:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">struct </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">GuessState { </span><span style="color:#c82829;">guess</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#c82829;">answer</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: Answer, </span><span style="color:#c82829;">low</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#c82829;">high</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">suggest_guess_smarter</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">s</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: GuessState) { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">match</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> s { </span><span style="color:#999999;">// First arm only fires on Bingo; it binds `p` to last guess. </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> GuessState { answer: Answer::Bingo, guess: p, </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">.. </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#999999;">// ~~~~~~~~~~ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ ~~~~~~~~ ~~ // | | | | // | | | Ignore remaining fields // | | | // | | Copy value of field `guess` into local variable `p` // | | // | Test that `answer field is equal to `Bingo` // | // Match against an instance of the struct `GuessState` </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;we won with </span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">!&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, p); } </span><span style="color:#999999;">// Second arm fires if answer was too low or too high. // We want to find a new guess in the range (l..h), where: // // - If it was too low, then we want something higher, so we // bind the guess to `l` and use our last high guess as `h`. // - If it was too high, then we want something lower; bind // the guess to `h` and use our last low guess as `l`. </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> GuessState { answer: Answer::Higher, low: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">_</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, guess: l, high: h } </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">|</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> GuessState { answer: Answer::Lower, low: l, guess: h, high: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">_ </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#999999;">// ~~~~~~~~~~ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ ~~~~~~ ~~~~~~~~ ~~~~~~~ // | | | | | // | | | | Copy or ignore // | | | | field `high`, // | | | | as appropriate // | | | | // | | | Copy field `guess` into // | | | local variable `l` or `h`, // | | | as appropriate // | | | // | | Copy value of field `low` into local // | | variable `l`, or ignore it, as appropriate // | | // | Test that `answer field is equal // | to `Higher` or `Lower`, as appropriate // | // Match against an instance of the struct `GuessState` </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> mid </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> l </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">((h </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">-</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> l) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">/ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;lets try </span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;"> next&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, mid); } } } #[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">test</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">demo_guess_state</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">suggest_guess_smarter</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(GuessState { guess: </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">20</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, answer: Answer::Lower, low: </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">10</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, high: </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1000 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">}); } </span></pre> <p>This ability to simultaneously perform case analysis <em>and</em> bind input substructure leads to powerful, clear, and concise code, focusing the reader's attention directly on the data relevant to the case at hand.</p> <p>That is <code>match</code> in a nutshell.</p> <p>So, what is the interplay between this construct and Rust's approach to ownership and safety in general?</p> <h3 id="exhaustive-case-analysis">Exhaustive case analysis</h3> <blockquote> <p>...when you have eliminated all which is impossible, then whatever remains, however improbable, must be the truth.</p> <p>-- Sherlock Holmes (Arthur Conan Doyle, &quot;The Blanched Soldier&quot;)</p> </blockquote> <p>One useful way to tackle a complex problem is to break it down into individual cases and analyze each case individually. For this method of problem solving to work, the breakdown must be <em>collectively exhaustive</em>; all of the cases you identified must actually cover all possible scenarios.</p> <p>Using <code>enum</code> and <code>match</code> in Rust can aid this process, because <code>match</code> enforces exhaustive case analysis: Every possible input value for a <code>match</code> must be covered by the pattern in a least one arm in the match.</p> <p>This helps catch bugs in program logic and ensures that the value of a <code>match</code> expression is well-defined.</p> <p>So, for example, the following code is rejected at compile-time.</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">suggest_guess_broken</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">prior_guess</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">answer</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: Answer) { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> next_guess </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">match</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> answer { Answer::Higher </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> prior_guess </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">10</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, Answer::Lower </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> prior_guess </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">- </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#999999;">// ERROR: non-exhaustive patterns: `Bingo` not covered </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">}; println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;maybe try </span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;"> next&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, next_guess); } </span></pre> <p>Many other languages offer a pattern matching construct (ML and various macro-based <code>match</code> implementations in Scheme both come to mind), but not all of them have this restriction.</p> <p>Rust has this restriction for these reasons:</p> <ul> <li> <p>First, as noted above, dividing a problem into cases only yields a general solution if the cases are exhaustive. Exhaustiveness-checking exposes logical errors.</p> </li> <li> <p>Second, exhaustiveness-checking can act as a refactoring aid. During the development process, I often add new variants for a particular <code>enum</code> definition. The exhaustiveness-check helps points out all of the <code>match</code> expressions where I only wrote the cases from the prior version of the <code>enum</code> type.</p> </li> <li> <p>Third, since <code>match</code> is an expression form, exhaustiveness ensures that such expressions always either evaluate to a value of the correct type, <em>or</em> jump elsewhere in the program.</p> </li> </ul> <h4 id="jumping-out-of-a-match">Jumping out of a match</h4> <p>The following code is a fixed version of the <code>suggest_guess_broken</code> function we saw above; it directly illustrates &quot;jumping elsewhere&quot;:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">suggest_guess_fixed</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">prior_guess</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">answer</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: Answer) { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> next_guess </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">match</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> answer { Answer::Higher </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> prior_guess </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">10</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, Answer::Lower </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> prior_guess </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">- </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, Answer::Bingo </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;we won with </span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">!&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, prior_guess); </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">return</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; } }; println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;maybe try </span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;"> next&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, next_guess); } #[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">test</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">demo_guess_fixed</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">suggest_guess_fixed</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">10</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, Answer::Higher); </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">suggest_guess_fixed</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">20</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, Answer::Lower); </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">suggest_guess_fixed</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">19</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, Answer::Bingo); } </span></pre> <p>The <code>suggest_guess_fixed</code> function illustrates that <code>match</code> can handle some cases early (and then immediately return from the function), while computing whatever values are needed from the remaining cases and letting them fall through to the remainder of the function body.</p> <p>We can add such special case handling via <code>match</code> without fear of overlooking a case, because <code>match</code> will force the case analysis to be exhaustive.</p> <h3 id="algebraic-data-types-and-structural-invariants">Algebraic Data Types and Structural Invariants</h3> <p><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algebraic_data_type">Algebraic data types</a> succinctly describe classes of data and allow one to encode rich structural invariants. Rust uses <code>enum</code> and <code>struct</code> definitions for this purpose.</p> <p>An <code>enum</code> type allows one to define mutually-exclusive classes of values. The examples shown above used <code>enum</code> for simple symbolic tags, but in Rust, enums can define much richer classes of data.</p> <p>For example, a binary tree is either a leaf, or an internal node with references to two child trees. Here is one way to encode a tree of integers in Rust:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">enum </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">BinaryTree { Leaf(</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">), Node(Box&lt;BinaryTree&gt;, </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, Box&lt;BinaryTree&gt;) } </span></pre> <p>(The <code>Box&lt;V&gt;</code> type describes an owning reference to a heap-allocated instance of <code>V</code>; if you own a <code>Box&lt;V&gt;</code>, then you also own the <code>V</code> it contains, and can mutate it, lend out references to it, et cetera. When you finish with the box and let it fall out of scope, it will automatically clean up the resources associated with the heap-allocated <code>V</code>.)</p> <p>The above <code>enum</code> definition ensures that if we are given a <code>BinaryTree</code>, it will always fall into one of the above two cases. One will never encounter a <code>BinaryTree::Node</code> that does not have a left-hand child. There is no need to check for null.</p> <p>One <em>does</em> need to check whether a given <code>BinaryTree</code> is a <code>Leaf</code> or is a <code>Node</code>, but the compiler statically ensures such checks are done: you cannot accidentally interpret the data of a <code>Leaf</code> as if it were a <code>Node</code>, nor vice versa.</p> <p>Here is a function that sums all of the integers in a tree using <code>match</code>.</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">tree_weight_v1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">t</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: BinaryTree) -&gt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">match</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> t { BinaryTree::Leaf(payload) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> payload, BinaryTree::Node(left, payload, right) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">tree_weight_v1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">*</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">left) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> payload </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">tree_weight_v1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">*</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">right) } } } </span><span style="color:#999999;">/// Returns tree that Looks like: /// /// +----(4)---+ /// | | /// +-(2)-+ [5] /// | | /// [1] [3] /// </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">sample_tree</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() -&gt; BinaryTree { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> l1 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Box</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">::new(BinaryTree::Leaf(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">)); </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> l3 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Box</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">::new(BinaryTree::Leaf(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">3</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">)); </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> n2 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Box</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">::new(BinaryTree::Node(l1, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, l3)); </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> l5 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Box</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">::new(BinaryTree::Leaf(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">5</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">)); BinaryTree::Node(n2, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">4</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, l5) } #[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">test</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">tree_demo_1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> tree </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">sample_tree</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(); assert_eq!(</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">tree_weight_v1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(tree), (</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">3</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">4 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">5</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); } </span></pre> <p>Algebraic data types establish structural invariants that are strictly enforced by the language. (Even richer representation invariants can be maintained via the use of modules and privacy; but let us not digress from the topic at hand.)</p> <h3 id="both-expression-and-statement-oriented">Both expression- and statement-oriented</h3> <p>Unlike many languages that offer pattern matching, Rust <em>embraces</em> both statement- and expression-oriented programming.</p> <p>Many functional languages that offer pattern matching encourage one to write in an &quot;expression-oriented style&quot;, where the focus is always on the values returned by evaluating combinations of expressions, and side-effects are discouraged. This style contrasts with imperative languages, which encourage a statement-oriented style that focuses on sequences of commands executed solely for their side-effects.</p> <p>Rust excels in supporting both styles.</p> <p>Consider writing a function which maps a non-negative integer to a string rendering it as an ordinal (&quot;1st&quot;, &quot;2nd&quot;, &quot;3rd&quot;, ...).</p> <p>The following code uses range patterns to simplify things, but also, it is written in a style similar to a <code>switch</code> in a statement-oriented language like C (or C++, Java, et cetera), where the arms of the <code>match</code> are executed for their side-effect alone:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">num_to_ordinal</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">x</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) -&gt; String { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> suffix; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">match </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">% </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">10</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">% </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">100</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) { (</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">| </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">21</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">...</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">91</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ suffix </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;st&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; } (</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">| </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">22</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">...</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">92</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ suffix </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;nd&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; } (</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">3</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">3</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">| </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">3</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">23</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">...</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">93</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ suffix </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;rd&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; } </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">_ =&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ suffix </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;th&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; } } </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">return </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">format!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#666969;">{}{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, x, suffix); } #[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">test</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">test_num_to_ordinal</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { assert_eq!(</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">num_to_ordinal</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">( </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">), </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;0th&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); assert_eq!(</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">num_to_ordinal</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">( </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">), </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;1st&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); assert_eq!(</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">num_to_ordinal</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">( </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">12</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">), </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;12th&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); assert_eq!(</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">num_to_ordinal</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">( </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">22</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">), </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;22nd&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); assert_eq!(</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">num_to_ordinal</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">( </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">43</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">), </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;43rd&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); assert_eq!(</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">num_to_ordinal</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">( </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">67</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">), </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;67th&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); assert_eq!(</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">num_to_ordinal</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1901</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">), </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;1901st&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); } </span></pre> <p>The Rust compiler accepts the above program. This is notable because its static analyses ensure both:</p> <ul> <li> <p><code>suffix</code> is always initialized before we run the <code>format!</code> at the end of the function, and</p> </li> <li> <p><code>suffix</code> is assigned <em>at most once</em> during the function's execution (because if we could assign <code>suffix</code> multiple times, the compiler would force us to mark <code>suffix</code> as mutable).</p> </li> </ul> <p>To be clear, the above program certainly <em>can</em> be written in an expression-oriented style in Rust; for example, like so:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">num_to_ordinal_expr</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">x</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">u32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) -&gt; String { format!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#666969;">{}{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, x, </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">match </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">% </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">10</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, x </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">% </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">100</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) { (</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">| </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">21</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">...</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">91</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;st&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, (</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">| </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">22</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">...</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">92</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;nd&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, (</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">3</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">3</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">| </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">3</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">23</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">...</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">93</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;rd&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">_ =&gt; </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;th&quot; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">}) } </span></pre> <p>Sometimes expression-oriented style can yield very succinct code; other times the style requires contortions that can be avoided by writing in a statement-oriented style. (The ability to return from one <code>match</code> arm in the <code>suggest_guess_fixed</code> function <a href="https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/enums-match-mutation-and-moves/#jumping-out-of-a-match">earlier</a> was an example of this.)</p> <p>Each of the styles has its use cases. Crucially, switching to a statement-oriented style in Rust does not sacrifice every other feature that Rust provides, such as the guarantee that a non-<code>mut</code> binding is assigned at most once.</p> <p>An important case where this arises is when one wants to initialize some state and then borrow from it, but only on <em>some</em> control-flow branches.</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">sometimes_initialize</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">input</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> string: </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">String</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#999999;">// a dynamically-constructed string value </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> borrowed: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">str</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#999999;">// a reference to string data </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">match</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> input { </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">...</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">100 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#999999;">// Construct a String on the fly... </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> string </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">format!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;input prints as </span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, input); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// ... and then borrow from inside it. </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> borrowed </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= &amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">string[</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">6</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">..</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">]; } </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">_ =&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#999999;">// String literals are *already* borrowed references </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> borrowed </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;expected between 0 and 100&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; } } println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;borrowed: </span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, borrowed); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// Below would cause compile-time error if uncommented... // println!(&quot;string: {}&quot;, string); // ...namely: error: use of possibly uninitialized variable: `string` </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} #[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">test</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">demo_sometimes_initialize</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">sometimes_initialize</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">23</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// this invocation will initialize `string` </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">sometimes_initialize</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">123</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// this one will not </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p>The interesting thing about the above code is that after the <code>match</code>, we are not allowed to directly access <code>string</code>, because the compiler requires that the variable be initialized on every path through the program before it can be accessed. At the same time, we <em>can</em>, via <code>borrowed</code>, access data that may held <em>within</em> <code>string</code>, because a reference to that data is held by the <code>borrowed</code> variable when we go through the first match arm, and we ensure <code>borrowed</code> itself is initialized on every execution path through the program that reaches the <code>println!</code> that uses <code>borrowed</code>.</p> <p>(The compiler ensures that no outstanding borrows of the <code>string</code> data could possibly outlive <code>string</code> itself, and the generated code ensures that at the end of the scope of <code>string</code>, its data is deallocated if it was previously initialized.)</p> <p>In short, for soundness, the Rust language ensures that data is always initialized before it is referenced, but the designers have strived to avoid requiring artificial coding patterns adopted solely to placate Rust's static analyses (such as requiring one to initialize <code>string</code> above with some dummy data, or requiring an expression-oriented style).</p> <h3 id="matching-without-moving">Matching without moving</h3> <p>Matching an input can <em>borrow</em> input substructure, without taking ownership; this is crucial for matching a reference (e.g. a value of type <code>&amp;T</code>).</p> <p>The <a href="https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/enums-match-mutation-and-moves/#algebraic-data-types-and-structural-invariants">&quot;Algebraic Data Types&quot; section</a> above described a tree datatype, and showed a program that computed the sum of the integers in a tree instance.</p> <p>That version of <code>tree_weight</code> has one big downside, however: it takes its input tree by value. Once you pass a tree to <code>tree_weight_v1</code>, that tree is <em>gone</em> (as in, deallocated).</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">#[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">test</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">tree_demo_v1_fails</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> tree </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">sample_tree</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(); assert_eq!(</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">tree_weight_v1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(tree), (</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">3</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">4 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">5</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// If you uncomment this line below ... // assert_eq!(tree_weight_v1(tree), (1 + 2 + 3) + 4 + 5); // ... you will get: error: use of moved value: `tree` </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p>This is <em>not</em> a consequence, however, of using <code>match</code>; it is rather a consequence of the function signature that was chosen:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">tree_weight_v1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">t</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: BinaryTree) -&gt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span><span style="color:#999999;">// ^~~~~~~~~~ this means this function takes ownership of `t` </span></pre> <p>In fact, in Rust, <code>match</code> is designed to work quite well <em>without</em> taking ownership. In particular, the input to <code>match</code> is an <em><a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/reference.html#lvalues,-rvalues-and-temporaries">L-value</a> expression</em>; this means that the input expression is evaluated to a <em>memory location</em> where the value lives. <code>match</code> works by doing this evaluation and then inspecting the data at that memory location.</p> <p>(If the input expression is a variable name or a field/pointer dereference, then the L-value is just the location of that variable or field/memory. If the input expression is a function call or other operation that generates an unnamed temporary value, then it will be conceptually stored in a temporary area, and that is the memory location that <code>match</code> will inspect.)</p> <p>So, if we want a version of <code>tree_weight</code> that merely borrows a tree rather than taking ownership of it, then we will need to make use of this feature of Rust's <code>match</code>.</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">tree_weight_v2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">t</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">BinaryTree) -&gt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32 </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#999999;">// ^~~~~~~~~~~ The `&amp;` means we are *borrowing* the tree </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">match </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">*</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">t { BinaryTree::Leaf(payload) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> payload, BinaryTree::Node(</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">ref</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> left, payload, </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">ref</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> right) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">tree_weight_v2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(left) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> payload </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">tree_weight_v2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(right) } } } #[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">test</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">tree_demo_2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> tree </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">sample_tree</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(); assert_eq!(</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">tree_weight_v2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">tree), (</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">3</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">4 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">5</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); } </span></pre> <p>The function <code>tree_weight_v2</code> looks very much like <code>tree_weight_v1</code>. The only differences are: we take <code>t</code> as a borrowed reference (the <code>&amp;</code> in its type), we added a dereference <code>*t</code>, and, importantly, we use <code>ref</code>-bindings for <code>left</code> and <code>right</code> in the <code>Node</code> case.</p> <p>The dereference <code>*t</code>, interpreted as an L-value expression, is just extracting the memory address where the <code>BinaryTree</code> is represented (since the <code>t: &amp;BinaryTree</code> is just a <em>reference</em> to that data in memory). The <code>*t</code> here is not making a copy of the tree, nor moving it to a new temporary location, because <code>match</code> is treating it as an L-value.</p> <p>The only piece left is the <code>ref</code>-binding, which is a crucial part of how destructuring bind of L-values works.</p> <p>First, let us carefully state the meaning of a <em>non-ref</em> binding:</p> <ul> <li> <p>When matching a value of type <code>T</code>, an identifier pattern <code>i</code> will, on a successful match, <em>move</em> the value out of the original input and into <code>i</code>. Thus we can always conclude in such a case that <code>i</code> has type <code>T</code> (or more succinctly, &quot;<code>i: T</code>&quot;).</p> <p>For some types <code>T</code>, known as <em>copyable</em> <code>T</code> (also pronounced &quot;<code>T</code> implements <code>Copy</code>&quot;), the value will in fact be copied into <code>i</code> for such identifier patterns. (Note that in general, an arbitrary type <code>T</code> is not copyable.)</p> <p>Either way, such pattern bindings do mean that the variable <code>i</code> has <em>ownership</em> of a value of type <code>T</code>.</p> </li> </ul> <p>Thus, the bindings of <code>payload</code> in <code>tree_weight_v2</code> both have type <code>i32</code>; the <code>i32</code> type implements <code>Copy</code>, so the weight is copied into <code>payload</code> in both arms.</p> <p>Now we are ready to state what a ref-binding is:</p> <ul> <li>When matching an L-value of type <code>T</code>, a <code>ref</code>-pattern <code>ref i</code> will, on a successful match, merely <em>borrow</em> a reference into the matched data. In other words, a successful <code>ref i</code> match of a value of type <code>T</code> will imply that <code>i</code> has the type of a <em>reference</em> to <code>T</code> (or more succinctly, &quot;<code>i: &amp;T</code>&quot;).</li> </ul> <p>Thus, in the <code>Node</code> arm of <code>tree_weight_v2</code>, <code>left</code> will be a reference to the left-hand box (which holds a tree), and <code>right</code> will likewise reference the right-hand tree.</p> <p>We can pass these borrowed references to trees into the recursive calls to <code>tree_weight_v2</code>, as the code demonstrates.</p> <p>Likewise, a <code>ref mut</code>-pattern (<code>ref mut i</code>) will, on a successful match, borrow a <em>mutable reference</em> into the input: <code>i: &amp;mut T</code>. This allows mutation and ensures there are no other active references to that data at the same time. A destructuring binding form like <code>match</code> allows one to take mutable references to disjoint parts of the data simultaneously.</p> <p>This code demonstrates this concept by incrementing all of the values in a given tree.</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">tree_grow</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">t</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> BinaryTree) { </span><span style="color:#999999;">// ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ `&amp;mut`: we have exclusive access to the tree </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">match </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">*</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">t { BinaryTree::Leaf(</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">ref mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> payload) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; *</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">payload </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, BinaryTree::Node(</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">ref mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> left, </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">ref mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> payload, </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">ref mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> right) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">=&gt; </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">tree_grow</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(left); </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">*</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">payload </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+= </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">; </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">tree_grow</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(right); } } } #[</span><span style="color:#c82829;">test</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">] </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">tree_demo_3</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> tree </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">sample_tree</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(); </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">tree_grow</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> tree); assert_eq!(</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">tree_weight_v2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">tree), (</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">3 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">4</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">5 </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">+ </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">6</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); } </span></pre> <p>Note that the code above now binds <code>payload</code> by a <code>ref mut</code>-pattern; if it did not use a <code>ref</code> pattern, then <code>payload</code> would be bound to a local copy of the integer, while we want to modify the actual integer <em>in the tree itself</em>. Thus we need a reference to that integer.</p> <p>Note also that the code is able to bind <code>left</code> and <code>right</code> simultaneously in the <code>Node</code> arm. The compiler knows that the two values cannot alias, and thus it allows both <code>&amp;mut</code>-references to live simultaneously.</p> <h2 id="conclusion">Conclusion</h2> <p>Rust takes the ideas of algebraic data types and pattern matching pioneered by the functional programming languages, and adapts them to imperative programming styles and Rust's own ownership and borrowing systems. The <code>enum</code> and <code>match</code> forms provide clean data definitions and expressive power, while static analysis ensures that the resulting programs are safe.</p> <p>For more information on details that were not covered here, such as:</p> <ul> <li> <p>how to say <code>Higher</code> instead of <code>Answer::Higher</code> in a pattern,</p> </li> <li> <p>defining new named constants,</p> </li> <li> <p>binding via <code>ident @ pattern</code>, or</p> </li> <li> <p>the potentially subtle difference between <code>{ let id = expr; ... }</code> versus <code>match expr { id =&gt; { ... } }</code>,</p> </li> </ul> <p>consult the Rust <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/">documentation</a>, or quiz our awesome community (in <code>#rust</code> on IRC, or in the <a href="http://users.rust-lang.org/">user group</a>).</p> <p>(Many thanks to those who helped review this post, especially Aaron Turon and Niko Matsakis, as well as <code>Mutabah</code>, <code>proc</code>, <code>libfud</code>, <code>asQuirrel</code>, and <code>annodomini</code> from <code>#rust</code>.)</p> Fearless Concurrency with Rust Fri, 10 Apr 2015 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/fearless-concurrency/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/fearless-concurrency/ <p>The Rust project was initiated to solve two thorny problems:</p> <ul> <li>How do you do safe systems programming?</li> <li>How do you make concurrency painless?</li> </ul> <p>Initially these problems seemed orthogonal, but to our amazement, the solution turned out to be identical: <strong>the same tools that make Rust safe also help you tackle concurrency head-on</strong>.</p> <p>Memory safety bugs and concurrency bugs often come down to code accessing data when it shouldn't. Rust's secret weapon is <em>ownership</em>, a discipline for access control that systems programmers try to follow, but that Rust's compiler checks statically for you.</p> <p>For memory safety, this means you can program without a garbage collector <em>and</em> without fear of segfaults, because Rust will catch your mistakes.</p> <p>For concurrency, this means you can choose from a wide variety of paradigms (message passing, shared state, lock-free, purely functional), and Rust will help you avoid common pitfalls.</p> <p>Here's a taste of concurrency in Rust:</p> <ul> <li> <p>A <a href="http://static.rust-lang.org/doc/master/std/sync/mpsc/index.html">channel</a> transfers ownership of the messages sent along it, so you can send a pointer from one thread to another without fear of the threads later racing for access through that pointer. <strong>Rust's channels enforce thread isolation.</strong></p> </li> <li> <p>A <a href="http://static.rust-lang.org/doc/master/std/sync/struct.Mutex.html">lock</a> knows what data it protects, and Rust guarantees that the data can only be accessed when the lock is held. State is never accidentally shared. <strong>&quot;Lock data, not code&quot; is enforced in Rust.</strong></p> </li> <li> <p>Every data type knows whether it can safely be <a href="http://static.rust-lang.org/doc/master/std/marker/trait.Send.html">sent</a> between or <a href="http://static.rust-lang.org/doc/master/std/marker/trait.Sync.html">accessed</a> by multiple threads, and Rust enforces this safe usage; there are no data races, even for lock-free data structures. <strong>Thread safety isn't just documentation; it's law.</strong></p> </li> <li> <p>You can even <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.0.0/std/thread/fn.scoped.html">share stack frames</a> between threads, and Rust will statically ensure that the frames remain active while other threads are using them. <strong>Even the most daring forms of sharing are guaranteed safe in Rust</strong>.</p> </li> </ul> <p>All of these benefits come out of Rust's ownership model, and in fact locks, channels, lock-free data structures and so on are defined in libraries, not the core language. That means that Rust's approach to concurrency is <em>open ended</em>: new libraries can embrace new paradigms and catch new bugs, just by adding APIs that use Rust's ownership features.</p> <p>The goal of this post is to give you some idea of how that's done.</p> <h3 id="background-ownership">Background: ownership</h3> <blockquote> <p>We'll start with an overview of Rust's ownership and borrowing systems. If you're already familiar with these, you can skip the two &quot;background&quot; sections and jump straight into concurrency. If you want a deeper introduction, I can't recommend <a href="http://blog.skylight.io/rust-means-never-having-to-close-a-socket/">Yehuda Katz's post</a> highly enough. And <a href="http://doc.rust-lang.org/book/ownership.html">the Rust book</a> has all the details.</p> </blockquote> <p>In Rust, every value has an &quot;owning scope,&quot; and passing or returning a value means transferring ownership (&quot;moving&quot; it) to a new scope. Values that are still owned when a scope ends are automatically destroyed at that point.</p> <p>Let's look at some simple examples. Suppose we create a vector and push some elements onto it:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">make_vec</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> vec </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Vec</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">::new(); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// owned by make_vec&#39;s scope </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> vec.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">push</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); vec.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">push</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// scope ends, `vec` is destroyed </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p>The scope that creates a value also initially owns it. In this case, the body of <code>make_vec</code> is the owning scope for <code>vec</code>. The owner can do anything it likes with <code>vec</code>, including mutating it by pushing. At the end of the scope, <code>vec</code> is still owned, so it is automatically deallocated.</p> <p>Things get more interesting if the vector is returned or passed around:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">make_vec</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() -&gt; Vec&lt;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&gt; { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> vec </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Vec</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">::new(); vec.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">push</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">0</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); vec.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">push</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">1</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); vec </span><span style="color:#999999;">// transfer ownership to the caller </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">print_vec</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">vec</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: Vec&lt;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&gt;) { </span><span style="color:#999999;">// the `vec` parameter is part of this scope, so it&#39;s owned by `print_vec` </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">for</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> i </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">in</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> vec.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">iter</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, i) } </span><span style="color:#999999;">// now, `vec` is deallocated </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">use_vec</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> vec </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">make_vec</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// take ownership of the vector </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">print_vec</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(vec); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// pass ownership to `print_vec` </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p>Now, just before <code>make_vec</code>'s scope ends, <code>vec</code> is moved out by returning it; it is not destroyed. A caller like <code>use_vec</code> then receives ownership of the vector.</p> <p>On the other hand, the <code>print_vec</code> function takes a <code>vec</code> parameter, and ownership of the vector is transferred <em>to</em> it by its caller. Since <code>print_vec</code> does not transfer the ownership any further, at the end of its scope the vector is destroyed.</p> <p>Once ownership has been given away, a value can no longer be used. For example, consider this variant of <code>use_vec</code>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">use_vec</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> vec </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">make_vec</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// take ownership of the vector </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">print_vec</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(vec); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// pass ownership to `print_vec` </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">for</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> i </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">in</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> vec.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">iter</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#999999;">// continue using `vec` </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, i </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">* </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) } } </span></pre> <p>If you feed this version to the compiler, you'll get an error:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">error: use of moved value: `vec` for i in vec.iter() { ^~~ </span></pre> <p>The compiler is saying <code>vec</code> is no longer available; ownership has been transferred elsewhere. And that's very good, because the vector has already been deallocated at this point!</p> <p>Disaster averted.</p> <h3 id="background-borrowing">Background: borrowing</h3> <p>The story so far isn't totally satisfying, because it's not our intent for <code>print_vec</code> to destroy the vector it was given. What we really want is to grant <code>print_vec</code> <em>temporary</em> access to the vector, and then continue using the vector afterwards.</p> <p>This is where <em>borrowing</em> comes in. If you have access to a value in Rust, you can lend out that access to the functions you call. <strong>Rust will check that these leases do not outlive the object being borrowed</strong>.</p> <p>To borrow a value, you make a <em>reference</em> to it (a kind of pointer), using the <code>&amp;</code> operator:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">print_vec</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">vec</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Vec&lt;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&gt;) { </span><span style="color:#999999;">// the `vec` parameter is borrowed for this scope </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">for</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> i </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">in</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> vec.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">iter</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, i) } </span><span style="color:#999999;">// now, the borrow ends </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">use_vec</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> vec </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">make_vec</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// take ownership of the vector </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">print_vec</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">vec);
