</span><span style="color:#999999;">// lend access to `print_vec` </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">for</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> i </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">in</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> vec.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">iter</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#999999;">// continue using `vec` </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">println!(</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#666969;">{}</span><span style="color:#718c00;">&quot;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, i </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">* </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">2</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">) } </span><span style="color:#999999;">// vec is destroyed here </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p>Now <code>print_vec</code> takes a reference to a vector, and <code>use_vec</code> lends out the vector by writing <code>&amp;vec</code>. Since borrows are temporary, <code>use_vec</code> retains ownership of the vector; it can continue using it after the call to <code>print_vec</code> returns (and its lease on <code>vec</code> has expired).</p> <p>Each reference is valid for a limited scope, which the compiler will automatically determine. References come in two flavors:</p> <ul> <li> <p>Immutable references <code>&amp;T</code>, which allow sharing but not mutation. There can be multiple <code>&amp;T</code> references to the same value simultaneously, but the value cannot be mutated while those references are active.</p> </li> <li> <p>Mutable references <code>&amp;mut T</code>, which allow mutation but not sharing. If there is an <code>&amp;mut T</code> reference to a value, there can be no other active references at that time, but the value can be mutated.</p> </li> </ul> <p>Rust checks these rules at compile time; borrowing has no runtime overhead.</p> <p>Why have two kinds of references? Consider a function like:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">push_all</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">from</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Vec&lt;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&gt;, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">to</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">mut </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Vec&lt;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&gt;) { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">for</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> i </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">in</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> from.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">iter</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { to.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">push</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">*</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">i); } } </span></pre> <p>This function iterates over each element of one vector, pushing it onto another. The iterator keeps a pointer into the vector at the current and final positions, stepping one toward the other.</p> <p>What if we called this function with the same vector for both arguments?</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4271ae;">push_all</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">vec, </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> vec) </span></pre> <p>This would spell disaster! As we're pushing elements onto the vector, it will occasionally need to resize, allocating a new hunk of memory and copying its elements over to it. The iterator would be left with a dangling pointer into the old memory, leading to memory unsafety (with attendant segfaults or worse).</p> <p>Fortunately, Rust ensures that <strong>whenever a mutable borrow is active, no other borrows of the object are active</strong>, producing the message:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">error: cannot borrow `vec` as mutable because it is also borrowed as immutable push_all(&amp;vec, &amp;mut vec); ^~~ </span></pre> <p>Disaster averted.</p> <h3 id="message-passing">Message passing</h3> <p>Now that we've covered the basic ownership story in Rust, let's see what it means for concurrency.</p> <p>Concurrent programming comes in many styles, but a particularly simple one is message passing, where threads or actors communicate by sending each other messages. Proponents of the style emphasize the way that it ties together sharing and communication:</p> <blockquote> <p>Do not communicate by sharing memory; instead, share memory by communicating.</p> <p>--<a href="http://golang.org/doc/effective_go.html">Effective Go</a></p> </blockquote> <p><strong>Rust's ownership makes it easy to turn that advice into a compiler-checked rule</strong>. Consider the following channel API (<a href="http://static.rust-lang.org/doc/master/std/sync/mpsc/index.html">channels in Rust's standard library</a> are a bit different):</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">send</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&lt;T: Send&gt;(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">chan</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Channel&lt;T&gt;, </span><span style="color:#f5871f;">t</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: T); </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">recv</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&lt;T: Send&gt;(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">chan</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Channel&lt;T&gt;) -&gt; T; </span></pre> <p>Channels are generic over the type of data they transmit (the <code>&lt;T: Send&gt;</code> part of the API). The <code>Send</code> part means that <code>T</code> must be considered safe to send between threads; we'll come back to that later in the post, but for now it's enough to know that <code>Vec&lt;i32&gt;</code> is <code>Send</code>.</p> <p>As always in Rust, passing in a <code>T</code> to the <code>send</code> function means transferring ownership of it. This fact has profound consequences: it means that code like the following will generate a compiler error.</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#999999;">// Suppose chan: Channel&lt;Vec&lt;i32&gt;&gt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> vec </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Vec</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">::new(); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// do some computation </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">send</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">chan, vec); </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">print_vec</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">vec); </span></pre> <p>Here, the thread creates a vector, sends it to another thread, and then continues using it. The thread receiving the vector could mutate it as this thread continues running, so the call to <code>print_vec</code> could lead to race condition or, for that matter, a use-after-free bug.</p> <p>Instead, the Rust compiler will produce an error message on the call to <code>print_vec</code>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Error: use of moved value `vec` </span></pre> <p>Disaster averted.</p> <h3 id="locks">Locks</h3> <p>Another way to deal with concurrency is by having threads communicate through passive, shared state.</p> <p>Shared-state concurrency has a bad rap. It's easy to forget to acquire a lock, or otherwise mutate the wrong data at the wrong time, with disastrous results -- so easy that many eschew the style altogether.</p> <p>Rust's take is that:</p> <ol> <li> <p>Shared-state concurrency is nevertheless a fundamental programming style, needed for systems code, for maximal performance, and for implementing other styles of concurrency.</p> </li> <li> <p>The problem is really about <em>accidentally</em> shared state.</p> </li> </ol> <p>Rust aims to give you the tools to conquer shared-state concurrency directly, whether you're using locking or lock-free techniques.</p> <p>In Rust, threads are &quot;isolated&quot; from each other automatically, due to ownership. Writes can only happen when the thread has mutable access, either by owning the data, or by having a mutable borrow of it. Either way, <strong>the thread is guaranteed to be the only one with access at the time</strong>. To see how this plays out, let's look at locks.</p> <p>Remember that mutable borrows cannot occur simultaneously with other borrows. Locks provide the same guarantee (&quot;mutual exclusion&quot;) through synchronization at runtime. That leads to a locking API that hooks directly into Rust's ownership system.</p> <p>Here is a simplified version (the <a href="http://static.rust-lang.org/doc/master/std/sync/struct.Mutex.html">standard library's</a> is more ergonomic):</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#999999;">// create a new mutex </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">mutex</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&lt;T: Send&gt;(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">t</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: T) -&gt; Mutex&lt;T&gt;; </span><span style="color:#999999;">// acquire the lock </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">lock</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&lt;T: Send&gt;(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">mutex</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Mutex&lt;T&gt;) -&gt; MutexGuard&lt;T&gt;; </span><span style="color:#999999;">// access the data protected by the lock </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">access</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&lt;T: Send&gt;(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">guard</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">mut </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">MutexGuard&lt;T&gt;) -&gt; </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> T; </span></pre> <p>This lock API is unusual in several respects.</p> <p>First, the <code>Mutex</code> type is generic over a type <code>T</code> of <strong>the data protected by the lock</strong>. When you create a <code>Mutex</code>, you transfer ownership of that data <em>into</em> the mutex, immediately giving up access to it. (Locks are unlocked when they are first created.)</p> <p>Later, you can <code>lock</code> to block the thread until the lock is acquired. This function, too, is unusual in providing a return value, <code>MutexGuard&lt;T&gt;</code>. The <code>MutexGuard</code> automatically releases the lock when it is destroyed; there is no separate <code>unlock</code> function.</p> <p>The only way to access the lock is through the <code>access</code> function, which turns a mutable borrow of the guard into a mutable borrow of the data (with a shorter lease):</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">use_lock</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">mutex</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Mutex&lt;Vec&lt;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&gt;&gt;) { </span><span style="color:#999999;">// acquire the lock, taking ownership of a guard; // the lock is held for the rest of the scope </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> guard </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">lock</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(mutex); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// access the data by mutably borrowing the guard </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> vec </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">access</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> guard); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// vec has type `&amp;mut Vec&lt;i32&gt;` </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> vec.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">push</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">3</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// lock automatically released here, when `guard` is destroyed </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p>There are two key ingredients here:</p> <ul> <li> <p>The mutable reference returned by <code>access</code> cannot outlive the <code>MutexGuard</code> it is borrowing from.</p> </li> <li> <p>The lock is only released when the <code>MutexGuard</code> is destroyed.</p> </li> </ul> <p>The result is that <strong>Rust enforces locking discipline: it will not let you access lock-protected data except when holding the lock</strong>. Any attempt to do otherwise will generate a compiler error. For example, consider the following buggy &quot;refactoring&quot;:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">use_lock</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">mutex</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">Mutex&lt;Vec&lt;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">i32</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&gt;&gt;) { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> vec </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">{ </span><span style="color:#999999;">// acquire the lock </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> guard </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">lock</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(mutex); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// attempt to return a borrow of the data </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">access</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> guard) </span><span style="color:#999999;">// guard is destroyed here, releasing the lock </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">}; </span><span style="color:#999999;">// attempt to access the data outside of the lock. </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> vec.</span><span style="color:#4271ae;">push</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">3</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">); } </span></pre> <p>Rust will generate an error pinpointing the problem:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">error: `guard` does not live long enough access(&amp;mut guard) ^~~~~ </span></pre> <p>Disaster averted.</p> <h3 id="thread-safety-and-send">Thread safety and &quot;Send&quot;</h3> <p>It's typical to distinguish some data types as &quot;thread safe&quot; and others not. Thread safe data structures use enough internal synchronization to be safely used by multiple threads concurrently.</p> <p>For example, Rust ships with two kinds of &quot;smart pointers&quot; for reference counting:</p> <ul> <li> <p><code>Rc&lt;T&gt;</code> provides reference counting via normal reads/writes. It is not thread safe.</p> </li> <li> <p><code>Arc&lt;T&gt;</code> provides reference counting via <em>atomic</em> operations. It is thread safe.</p> </li> </ul> <p>The hardware atomic operations used by <code>Arc</code> are more expensive than the vanilla operations used by <code>Rc</code>, so it's advantageous to use <code>Rc</code> rather than <code>Arc</code>. On the other hand, it's critical that an <code>Rc&lt;T&gt;</code> never migrate from one thread to another, because that could lead to race conditions that corrupt the count.</p> <p>Usually, the only recourse is careful documentation; most languages make no <em>semantic</em> distinction between thread-safe and thread-unsafe types.</p> <p>In Rust, the world is divided into two kinds of data types: those that are <a href="http://static.rust-lang.org/doc/master/std/marker/trait.Send.html"><code>Send</code></a>, meaning they can be safely moved from one thread to another, and those that are <code>!Send</code>, meaning that it may not be safe to do so. If all of a type's components are <code>Send</code>, so is that type -- which covers most types. Certain base types are not inherently thread-safe, though, so it's also possible to explicitly mark a type like <code>Arc</code> as <code>Send</code>, saying to the compiler: &quot;Trust me; I've verified the necessary synchronization here.&quot;</p> <p>Naturally, <code>Arc</code> is <code>Send</code>, and <code>Rc</code> is not.</p> <p>We already saw that the <code>Channel</code> and <code>Mutex</code> APIs work only with <code>Send</code> data. Since they are the point at which data crosses thread boundaries, they are also the point of enforcement for <code>Send</code>.</p> <p>Putting this all together, Rust programmers can reap the benefits of <code>Rc</code> and other thread-<em>unsafe</em> types with confidence, knowing that if they ever do accidentally try to send one to another thread, the Rust compiler will say:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">`Rc&lt;Vec&lt;i32&gt;&gt;` cannot be sent between threads safely </span></pre> <p>Disaster averted.</p> <h3 id="sharing-the-stack-scoped">Sharing the stack: &quot;scoped&quot;</h3> <p><em>Note: The API mentioned here is an old one which has been moved out of the standard library. You can find equivalent functionality in <a href="https://crates.io/crates/crossbeam"><code>crossbeam</code></a> (<a href="http://aturon.github.io/crossbeam-doc/crossbeam/fn.scope.html">documentation for <code>scope()</code></a>) and <a href="https://crates.io/crates/scoped_threadpool"><code>scoped_threadpool</code></a> (<a href="http://kimundi.github.io/scoped-threadpool-rs/scoped_threadpool/index.html#examples:">documentation for <code>scoped()</code></a>)</em></p> <p>So far, all the patterns we've seen involve creating data structures on the heap that get shared between threads. But what if we wanted to start some threads that make use of data living in our stack frame? That could be dangerous:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">parent</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> vec </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Vec</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">::new(); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// fill the vector </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">thread::spawn(|| { </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">print_vec</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">vec) }) } </span></pre> <p>The child thread takes a reference to <code>vec</code>, which in turn resides in the stack frame of <code>parent</code>. When <code>parent</code> exits, the stack frame is popped, but the child thread is none the wiser. Oops!</p> <p>To rule out such memory unsafety, Rust's basic thread spawning API looks a bit like this:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">spawn</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&lt;F&gt;(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">f</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: F) </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">where</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> F: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">&#39;static</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, ... </span></pre> <p>The <code>'static</code> constraint is a way of saying, roughly, that no borrowed data is permitted in the closure. It means that a function like <code>parent</code> above will generate an error:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#4d4d4c;">error: `vec` does not live long enough </span></pre> <p>essentially catching the possibility of <code>parent</code>'s stack frame popping. Disaster averted.</p> <p>But there is another way to guarantee safety: ensure that the parent stack frame stays put until the child thread is done. This is the pattern of <em>fork-join</em> programming, often used for divide-and-conquer parallel algorithms. Rust supports it by providing a <a href="https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.0.0/std/thread/fn.scoped.html">&quot;scoped&quot;</a> variant of thread spawning:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">scoped</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&lt;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">&#39;a</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, F&gt;(</span><span style="color:#f5871f;">f</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">: F) -&gt; JoinGuard&lt;</span><span style="color:#8959a8;">&#39;a</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">&gt; </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">where</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> F: </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">&#39;a</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">, ... </span></pre> <p>There are two key differences from the <code>spawn</code> API above:</p> <ul> <li> <p>The use a parameter <code>'a</code>, rather than <code>'static</code>. This parameter represents a scope that encompasses all the borrows within the closure, <code>f</code>.</p> </li> <li> <p>The return value, a <code>JoinGuard</code>. As its name suggests, <code>JoinGuard</code> ensures that the parent thread joins (waits on) its child, by performing an implicit join in its destructor (if one hasn't happened explicitly already).</p> </li> </ul> <p>Including <code>'a</code> in <code>JoinGuard</code> ensures that the <code>JoinGuard</code> <strong>cannot escape the scope of any data borrowed by the closure</strong>. In other words, Rust guarantees that the parent thread waits for the child to finish before popping any stack frames the child might have access to.</p> <p>Thus by adjusting our previous example, we can fix the bug and satisfy the compiler:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> <span style="color:#8959a8;">fn </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">parent</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">() { </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let mut</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> vec </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#c99e00;">Vec</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">::new(); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// fill the vector </span><span style="color:#8959a8;">let</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;"> guard </span><span style="color:#3e999f;">= </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">thread::scoped(|| { </span><span style="color:#4271ae;">print_vec</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">(</span><span style="color:#3e999f;">&amp;</span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">vec) }); </span><span style="color:#999999;">// guard destroyed here, implicitly joining </span><span style="color:#4d4d4c;">} </span></pre> <p>So in Rust, you can freely borrow stack data into child threads, confident that the compiler will check for sufficient synchronization.</p> <h3 id="data-races">Data races</h3> <p>At this point, we've seen enough to venture a strong statement about Rust's approach to concurrency: <strong>the compiler prevents all <em>data races</em>.</strong></p> <blockquote> <p>A data race is any unsynchronized, concurrent access to data involving a write.</p> </blockquote> <p>Synchronization here includes things as low-level as atomic instructions. Essentially, this is a way of saying that you cannot accidentally &quot;share state&quot; between threads; all (mutating) access to state has to be mediated by <em>some</em> form of synchronization.</p> <p>Data races are just one (very important) kind of race condition, but by preventing them, Rust often helps you prevent other, more subtle races as well. For example, it's often important that updates to different locations appear to take place <em>atomically</em>: other threads see either all of the updates, or none of them. In Rust, having <code>&amp;mut</code> access to the relevant locations at the same time <strong>guarantees atomicity of updates to them</strong>, since no other thread could possibly have concurrent read access.</p> <p>It's worth pausing for a moment to think about this guarantee in the broader landscape of languages. Many languages provide memory safety through garbage collection. But garbage collection doesn't give you any help in preventing data races.</p> <p>Rust instead uses ownership and borrowing to provide its two key value propositions:</p> <ul> <li>Memory safety without garbage collection.</li> <li>Concurrency without data races.</li> </ul> <h3 id="the-future">The future</h3> <p>When Rust first began, it baked channels directly into the language, taking a very opinionated stance on concurrency.</p> <p>In today's Rust, concurrency is <em>entirely</em> a library affair; everything described in this post, including <code>Send</code>, is defined in the standard library, and could be defined in an external library instead.</p> <p>And that's very exciting, because it means that Rust's concurrency story can endlessly evolve, growing to encompass new paradigms and catch new classes of bugs. Libraries like <a href="https://github.com/carllerche/syncbox">syncbox</a> and <a href="https://github.com/huonw/simple_parallel">simple_parallel</a> are taking some of the first steps, and we expect to invest heavily in this space in the next few months. Stay tuned!</p> Announcing Rust 1.0 Beta Fri, 03 Apr 2015 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-0-beta/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-0-beta/ <p>Today we are excited to announce the <a href="http://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">release of Rust 1.0 beta</a>! The beta release marks a very significant &quot;state transition&quot; in the move towards 1.0. In particular, with the beta release, <strong>all libraries and language features that are planned to be stable for 1.0 have been marked as stable</strong>. As such, the beta release represents an accurate preview of what Rust 1.0 will include.</p> <p>To see what has changed since 1.0-alpha2, please see the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-100-beta-april-2015">release notes</a>.</p> <p>The Beta release also marks a turning point in our <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/10/30/Stability.html">approach to stability</a>. During the alpha cycle, the use of unstable APIs and language features was permitted, but triggered a warning. As of the Beta release, the use of unstable APIs will become an error (unless you are using Nightly builds or building from source).</p> <p>The Rust ecosystem continues to grow. The <a href="https://crates.io/">crates.io</a> repository just passed 1 million downloads and has over 1,700 crates available. Many of the top crates in <a href="https://crates.io/">crates.io</a> can now be built using only stable Rust, and efforts to port the remainder are underway. Therefore, we are now recommending that new users start with the Beta release, rather than the Nightly builds, and the <a href="http://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">rustup script</a> will be modified to install Beta by default. (However, it is easy to switch to the Nightly build if some of your dependencies aren't updated yet. See the <a href="http://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">install page</a> for details.)</p> <h3 id="what-happens-during-the-beta-cycle">What happens during the beta cycle?</h3> <p><strong>The final Rust 1.0 release is scheduled for May 15th -- exactly six weeks from now.</strong> In the interim, we expect to put most of our effort into fixing bugs, improving documentation and error messages, and otherwise improving the end-user experience. We don't plan on making functional changes to stable content, though naturally we may make minor corrections or additions to the library APIs if shortcomings or problems are uncovered (but the bar for such changes is relatively high).</p> <p>While we don't expect to add any new features (or major new APIs) for the 1.0 release, that doesn't mean we're going to stop working on them altogether. In fact, quite the opposite! Per <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/12/12/1.0-Timeline.html">the train model</a>, the plan is to continue development on new features on the master branch, in parallel with the beta. And of course, we'll be issuing the beta for 1.1 release at the same time as we issue the final 1.0 release, so you shouldn't have to wait long to start putting that work to use.</p> <p>To help ensure that we don't accidentally introduce breakage as we add new features, we've also been working on an exciting new CI infrastructure to allow us to monitor which packages are building with the Nightly builds and detect regressions across the entire Rust ecosystem, not just our own test base. This infrastructure is still in the development phase, but you can see a <a href="https://gist.github.com/brson/a30a77836fbec057cbee">sample report</a> here.</p> <h3 id="a-community-achievement">A community achievement</h3> <p>As always, this Rust release is the achievement of the fantastic Rust community at large. Thanks to everyone who has participated in the RFC process, and a particular thank you to the 170 contributors for this release:</p> <ul> <li><code>Aaron Turon</code></li> <li><code>Aaron Weiss</code></li> <li><code>Adam Jacob</code></li> <li><code>Adenilson Cavalcanti</code></li> <li><code>Adolfo Ochagavía</code></li> <li><code>Ahmed Charles</code></li> <li><code>Alan Cutter</code></li> <li><code>Alex Crichton</code></li> <li><code>Alexander Bliskovsky</code></li> <li><code>Alexander Campbell</code></li> <li><code>Alexander Chernyakhovsky</code></li> <li><code>Alexis</code></li> <li><code>Alexis Beingessner</code></li> <li><code>Amol Mundayoor</code></li> <li><code>Anders Kaseorg</code></li> <li><code>Andrew Hobden</code></li> <li><code>Andrew Paseltiner</code></li> <li><code>Angus Lees</code></li> <li><code>awlnx</code></li> <li><code>Barosl Lee</code></li> <li><code>bcoopers</code></li> <li><code>Björn Steinbrink</code></li> <li><code>bombless</code></li> <li><code>Brian Anderson</code></li> <li><code>Brian Brooks</code></li> <li><code>Brian Leibig</code></li> <li><code>Camille Roussel</code></li> <li><code>Camille TJHOA</code></li> <li><code>Carol Nichols</code></li> <li><code>Caspar Krieger</code></li> <li><code>Ches Martin</code></li> <li><code>Chloe</code></li> <li><code>Chris Wong</code></li> <li><code>Cody P Schafer</code></li> <li><code>Corey Farwell</code></li> <li><code>Corey Richardson</code></li> <li><code>Dabo Ross</code></li> <li><code>Dan Burkert</code></li> <li><code>Dan Connolly</code></li> <li><code>Dan W.</code></li> <li><code>Daniel Lobato García</code></li> <li><code>Darin Morrison</code></li> <li><code>Darrell Hamilton</code></li> <li><code>Dave Huseby</code></li> <li><code>David Creswick</code></li> <li><code>David King</code></li> <li><code>David Mally</code></li> <li><code>defuz</code></li> <li><code>Denis Defreyne</code></li> <li><code>Drew Crawford</code></li> <li><code>Dzmitry Malyshau</code></li> <li><code>Eduard Bopp</code></li> <li><code>Eduard Burtescu</code></li> <li><code>Eduardo Bautista</code></li> <li><code>Edward Wang</code></li> <li><code>Emeliov Dmitrii</code></li> <li><code>Eric Platon</code></li> <li><code>Erick Tryzelaar</code></li> <li><code>Eunji Jeong</code></li> <li><code>Falco Hirschenberger</code></li> <li><code>Felix S. Klock II</code></li> <li><code>Fenhl</code></li> <li><code>Flavio Percoco</code></li> <li><code>Florian Hahn</code></li> <li><code>Florian Hartwig</code></li> <li><code>Florian Zeitz</code></li> <li><code>FuGangqiang</code></li> <li><code>Gary M. Josack</code></li> <li><code>Germano Gabbianelli</code></li> <li><code>GlacJAY</code></li> <li><code>Gleb Kozyrev</code></li> <li><code>Guillaume Gomez</code></li> <li><code>GuillaumeGomez</code></li> <li><code>Huachao Huang</code></li> <li><code>Huon Wilson</code></li> <li><code>inrustwetrust</code></li> <li><code>Ivan Petkov</code></li> <li><code>Ivan Radanov Ivanov</code></li> <li><code>Jake Goulding</code></li> <li><code>Jakub Bukaj</code></li> <li><code>James Miller</code></li> <li><code>Jessy Diamond Exum</code></li> <li><code>Jihyun Yu</code></li> <li><code>Johannes Oertel</code></li> <li><code>John Hodge</code></li> <li><code>John Zhang</code></li> <li><code>Jonathan Reem</code></li> <li><code>Jordan Woehr</code></li> <li><code>Jorge Aparicio</code></li> <li><code>Joseph Crail</code></li> <li><code>JP-Ellis</code></li> <li><code>Julian Orth</code></li> <li><code>Julian Viereck</code></li> <li><code>Junseok Lee</code></li> <li><code>Kang Seonghoon</code></li> <li><code>Keegan McAllister</code></li> <li><code>Kevin Ballard</code></li> <li><code>Kevin Butler</code></li> <li><code>Kevin Yap</code></li> <li><code>kgv</code></li> <li><code>kjpgit</code></li> <li><code>Lai Jiangshan</code></li> <li><code>Leonids Maslovs</code></li> <li><code>Liam Monahan</code></li> <li><code>Liigo Zhuang</code></li> <li><code>Łukasz Niemier</code></li> <li><code>lummax</code></li> <li><code>Manish Goregaokar</code></li> <li><code>Markus Siemens</code></li> <li><code>Markus Unterwaditzer</code></li> <li><code>Marvin Löbel</code></li> <li><code>Matt Brubeck</code></li> <li><code>Matt Cox</code></li> <li><code>mdinger</code></li> <li><code>Michael Woerister</code></li> <li><code>Michał Krasnoborski</code></li> <li><code>Mihnea Dobrescu-Balaur</code></li> <li><code>Mikhail Zabaluev</code></li> <li><code>Ms2ger</code></li> <li><code>Murarth</code></li> <li><code>Nicholas Bishop</code></li> <li><code>Nicholas Mazzuca</code></li> <li><code>Nicholas</code></li> <li><code>Nick Cameron</code></li> <li><code>Niko Matsakis</code></li> <li><code>nwin</code></li> <li><code>Oliver Schneider</code></li> <li><code>Or Neeman</code></li> <li><code>Pascal Hertleif</code></li> <li><code>Patrick Walton</code></li> <li><code>Paul ADENOT</code></li> <li><code>Paul Osborne</code></li> <li><code>Peter Elmers</code></li> <li><code>Phil Dawes</code></li> <li><code>Philip Munksgaard</code></li> <li><code>Piotr Czarnecki</code></li> <li><code>Pyry Kontio</code></li> <li><code>Raphael Nestler</code></li> <li><code>ray glover</code></li> <li><code>Ricardo Martins</code></li> <li><code>Richard Diamond</code></li> <li><code>Richo Healey</code></li> <li><code>Ruud van Asseldonk</code></li> <li><code>Ryan Prichard</code></li> <li><code>Sae-bom Kim</code></li> <li><code>Scott Olson</code></li> <li><code>Sean McArthur</code></li> <li><code>Sébastien Marie</code></li> <li><code>Seo Sanghyeon</code></li> <li><code>Simonas Kazlauskas</code></li> <li><code>Stepan Koltsov</code></li> <li><code>Steve Klabnik</code></li> <li><code>Steven Crockett</code></li> <li><code>Steven Fackler</code></li> <li><code>Tamir Duberstein</code></li> <li><code>Tero Hänninen</code></li> <li><code>Tiago Nobrega</code></li> <li><code>Tobias Bucher</code></li> <li><code>Tom Jakubowski</code></li> <li><code>Trent Nadeau</code></li> <li><code>Tshepang Lekhonkhobe</code></li> <li><code>Ulrik Sverdrup</code></li> <li><code>Vadim Chugunov</code></li> <li><code>Vadim Petrochenkov</code></li> <li><code>Valerii Hiora</code></li> <li><code>Vladimir Pouzanov</code></li> <li><code>Vojtech Kral</code></li> <li><code>Wangshan Lu</code></li> <li><code>Wesley Wiser</code></li> <li><code>York Xiang</code></li> </ul> Announcing Rust 1.0.0.alpha.2 Fri, 20 Feb 2015 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-0-alpha2/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-0-alpha2/ <p>Today, we are happy to announce the release of Rust 1.0.0.alpha.2! Rust is a systems programming language pursuing the trifecta: safe, fast, and concurrent.</p> <p>In accordance with our <a href="/2015/02/13/Final-1.0-timeline.html">status report</a> last week, this is a second alpha release, rather than a first beta release. The beta release will be six weeks from today, with the final coming six weeks after that.</p> <p>We’ve managed to land almost all of the features previously expected for this cycle. <strong>The big headline here is that all major API revisions are finished</strong>: path and IO reform have landed. At this point, all modules shipping for 1.0 are in what we expect to be their final form, modulo minor tweaks during the alpha2 cycle. See the <a href="/2015/02/13/Final-1.0-timeline.html">previous post</a> for more details.</p> <p>This coming release cycle is crucial to Rust, as this will be the last cycle that we recommend nightly builds for most users. Part of the way through the cycle, around March 9th, we expect to have all major functionality we expect in 1.0 marked as stable; we will fill in stability gaps between then and beta on March 31st. The beta release will fully introduce the &quot;stable channel&quot;, which will not allow use of unstable features but will guarantee backwards-compatibility (after 1.0). Unstable features will only be available in nightly.</p> <p>For more detail, please see the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md#version-100-alpha2-february-2015">Release notes</a>. </p> <p>Thank you to all 201 contributors for this release:</p> <ul> <li><code>Aaron Turon</code></li> <li><code>Adam Roben</code></li> <li><code>Adolfo Ochagavía</code></li> <li><code>Ahmed Charles</code></li> <li><code>Aidan Hobson Sayers</code></li> <li><code>Akos Kiss</code></li> <li><code>Alexander Bliskovsky</code></li> <li><code>Alexander Korolkov</code></li> <li><code>Alexander Light</code></li> <li><code>Alex Crichton</code></li> <li><code>Alexis</code></li> <li><code>Alfie John</code></li> <li><code>Andrea Canciani</code></li> <li><code>Andrew Barchuk</code></li> <li><code>Andrew Paseltiner</code></li> <li><code>Ariel Ben-Yehuda</code></li> <li><code>Armin Preiml</code></li> <li><code>Artem</code></li> <li><code>Barosl Lee</code></li> Schuller</code></li> <li><code>Pierre Baillet</code></li> <li><code>Piotr Czarnecki</code></li> <li><code>posixphreak</code></li> <li><code>Potpourri</code></li> <li><code>Pyfisch</code></li> Joshi</code></li> <li><code>Ryan Levick</code></li> <li><code>Sean Collins</code></li> <li><code>Sean Gillespie</code></li> <li><code>Sean Patrick Santos</code></li> <li><code>Sean T Allen</code></li> Jakubowski</code></li> <li><code>Toni Cárdenas</code></li> <li><code>Travis Watkins</code></li> <li><code>Tristan Storch</code></li> <li><code>Tshepang Lekhonkhobe</code></li> <li><code>Tyler Thrailkill</code></li> <li><code>Ulrik Sverdrup</code></li> <li><code>Vadim Chugunov</code></li> <li><code>Vadim Petrochenkov</code></li> <li><code>Valerii Hiora</code></li> <li><code>Victory</code></li> <li><code>visualfc</code></li> <li><code>Vojtech Kral</code></li> <li><code>Volker Mische</code></li> <li><code>Wangshan Lu</code></li> <li><code>we</code></li> <li><code>Willson Mock</code></li> <li><code>Will</code></li> <li><code>wonyong kim</code></li> <li><code>York Xiang</code></li> </ul> Rust 1.0: status report and final timeline Fri, 13 Feb 2015 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/final-1-0-timeline/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/final-1-0-timeline/ <p>It's been five weeks since we released Rust 1.0-alpha! Before this release cycle finishes next week, we want to give a status report and update on the road to 1.0 final.</p> <p><strong>TL;DR: Rust 1.0 final will be released by May 15, 2015</strong></p> <h2 id="what-is-the-overall-timeline">What is the overall timeline?</h2> <p>Based on the progress in this release cycle, we are now comfortable committing to a precise release schedule for 1.0:</p> <ul> <li>Rust 1.0-alpha2 -- Feb 20</li> <li>All 1.0 modules stable on nightly -- around Mar 9</li> <li>Rust 1.0-beta -- Apr 3</li> <li>Rust 1.0 -- May 15</li> </ul> <p>This schedule differs from the <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/12/12/1.0-Timeline.html">previous one</a> by nailing down an exact set of release cycles. It also opts for a second alpha release and only a single beta release.</p> <p>The main reason for calling the next release alpha2 rather than beta1 is that new path and IO APIs have only recently landed, and we would like more time to collect feedback before marking them stable. More details are below.</p> <p><strong>Update:</strong> An earlier version of this post listed Mar 31 as the 1.0-beta release date, due to a miscalculation. The correct date is Apr 3, exactly six weeks after alpha2 and six weeks before 1.0.</p> <h2 id="what-s-shipping-in-alpha2">What's shipping in alpha2?</h2> <p>We've managed to land almost all of the features <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2015/01/09/Rust-1.0-alpha.html">previously expected</a> for this cycle.</p> <p><strong>The big headline here is that all major API revisions are finished</strong>: path and IO reform have landed. At this point, all modules shipping for 1.0 are in what we expect to be their final form, modulo minor tweaks during the alpha2 cycle.</p> <p>Other highlights are as follows:</p> <ul> <li> <p><strong>Closures</strong>: Rust now supports <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/0231-upvar-capture-inference.md">full capture-clause inference</a> and has deprecated the temporary <code>|:|</code> notation, making closures much more ergonomic to use.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Destructors</strong>: New <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/769">destructor rules</a> landed, obviating the need for <code>#[unsafe destructor]</code>.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Path reform</strong>: The <code>path</code> module has been completely <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/474">redesigned</a> to resolve a number of semantic and ergonomic problems with the old module, and to take advantage of DST.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>IO reform</strong>: The <code>io</code> system has been <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/0517-io-os-reform.md">thoroughly revised</a> to improve robustness and cross-platform behavior, and to eschew ambitious high-level abstractions over the system. While almost all of the APIs are affected by this change, the changes move toward a much more conservative and consistent design.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Deref coercions</strong>: A <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/241">new coercion</a> will follow smart pointers, so that you can pass <code>&amp;Vec&lt;T&gt;</code> where <code>&amp;[T]</code> is wanted, or <code>&amp;Arc&lt;T&gt;</code> where <code>&amp;T</code> is wanted. This removes most need for explicit slicing or the dreaded &quot;cross-borrowing&quot; <code>&amp;*</code>, and means that <code>&amp;</code> can be thought of as a general &quot;borrow&quot; operator.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Feature staging</strong>: Rust now has a notion of <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/475">named API <em>features</em></a> akin to language features, which is how we will manage API stabilization going forward. These named features make it easier to manage progress in <code>std</code>, and make it plausible to detect the minimum version of Rust needed for a crate.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>For loops</strong>: The new <code>IntoIterator</code> trait is now available and used for <code>for</code> loops, making it possible to write <code>for x in &amp;vec</code> rather than <code>for x in vec.iter()</code>.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Range notation</strong>: We have <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/702">finalized range notation</a>, introducing <code>..</code> for &quot;full ranges&quot;, which will make APIs like <code>collection.remove(..)</code> possible in the future.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Trait system</strong>: New coherence rules were <a href="http://internals.rust-lang.org/t/orphan-rules/1322">finalized</a>, providing both flexibility and soundness for trait implementations.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Overflow semantics</strong>: After a long debate, the final integer overflow semantics has <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/560">been decided</a> and is expected to land for alpha2. This change is expected to make it much easier to find over/underflow bugs when used in conjunction with fuzzing, etc.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Associated types</strong>: many compiler bugs around associated types have been fixed, making them usable at large scale.</p> </li> </ul> <p>Some other changes have not landed at the time of writing but are expected for alpha2: <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/738">variance for type parameters</a>, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/458">Send changes</a>, and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/22240">the great integer audit</a>.</p> <p>Complete details will be available in the release notes next week.</p> <h2 id="why-another-alpha">Why another alpha?</h2> <p>The main reason is that we want to leave recently-landed APIs, like IO and path, unstable for a few more weeks while we collect feedback -- but the beta release is intended to disallow use of unstable features.</p> <p>In more detail, Rust is drawing a <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/12/12/1.0-Timeline.html">difference between alpha and beta</a> connected with our <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/10/30/Stability.html">stability system</a>. In alpha releases, it's possible to opt-in to unstable features, but after beta, this will be possible only when using nightly builds. The beta release will mark the point when a substantial portion of the community can move off of nightlies.</p> <p>As mentioned above, we have landed all of the major API revisions needed for the 1.0 release, including path and IO reform. However, some of these revisions landed relatively late in the cycle, and as a community we don't have enough experience with the revised APIs to declare them stable yet. Note that the API changes are, with a couple exceptions, very conservative: they generally move us in the direction of existing, successful libraries.</p> <p>By producing 1.0-alpha2, we leave open a longer window for tweaks to these APIs before declaring them stable. That window will close around March 9.</p> <h3 id="is-there-risk-of-slippage-by-not-moving-to-beta-now">Is there risk of slippage by not moving to beta now?</h3> <p>It seems unlikely. Essentially all of the language and library features needed for 1.0 have already landed, meaning that we will have <em>12 weeks</em> of time to polish between alpha2 and 1.0 final.</p> <h2 id="what-will-happen-before-1-0">What will happen before 1.0?</h2> <p>All features that are required for shipping 1.0 have now landed. What remains is polish, performance improvements, bugfixing, documentation -- and gaining enough confidence in recently revised APIs to mark them <code>#[stable]</code>.</p> <p>The alpha2 release will officially deprecate (but leave available) the old path and IO APIs. The new APIs are scheduled to be stabilized by March 9. <strong>Please try out these new APIs and help uncover problems!</strong></p> <p>After the March 9 deadline, it should be possible for substantial crates to work with &quot;stable Rust&quot;, i.e. without any use of <code>#[feature]</code>. Between then and the beta release, we hope to work directly with authors of crates.io packages to help move code to stable Rust, and to uncover any gaps in stabilization.</p> <p>By beta, we hope that a substantial part of the ecosystem will be off of nightlies and on to stable releases. Getting there will require a community-wide push toward stabilization, which we're coordinating via <a href="http://users.rust-lang.org/t/using-unstable-apis-tell-us-about-it/157/26">discuss</a> -- if you haven't, please drop by and tell us the key unstable APIs you're using.</p> Announcing Rust 1.0 Alpha Fri, 09 Jan 2015 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-0-alpha/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/rust-1-0-alpha/ <p>Today, we're excited to <a href="http://www.rust-lang.org/install.html">release</a> the alpha version of Rust 1.0, a systems programming language with a focus on safety, performance and concurrency.</p> <p>This release marks a huge milestone for Rust and its community:</p> <ul> <li> <p><strong>The language is feature-complete for 1.0</strong>. While we plan to make many usability improvements before the final release, all 1.0 language features are now in place and we do not expect major breaking changes to them.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>The core libraries are feature-complete for 1.0</strong>. API conventions have been firmly established, and core functionality -- basic types, traits, data structures and concurrency primitives -- has all been <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/10/30/Stability.html">stabilized</a>. Here again we do not expect major breaking changes before 1.0.</p> </li> </ul> <p>The Rust community really rolled up their sleeves to help push this release over the finish line; thanks to everyone who participated, and especially to the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/wiki/Doc-friends-of-the-tree">friends of the tree</a>!</p> <p>While we've come a long way in <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/09/15/Rust-1.0.html">the last four months</a>, there's a lot left to do before Rust hits 1.0 final. Read on for more.</p> <h3 id="what-happens-during-the-alpha-cycle">What happens during the alpha cycle?</h3> <p>If you're already a Rust user, the first thing you'll notice during the alpha cycle is a <em>dramatic</em> drop in the pace of breaking changes.</p> <p>Most features and modules that will ship with Rust 1.0 are in place and will change in only limited ways during this cycle, as detailed later in this post. Only a few modules -- the key ones being path manipulation and I/O -- are still stabilizing.</p> <p>We need your help to iterate on those final libraries before the beta release, and to hammer out any remaining issues on the parts of Rust we have already marked as stable. <strong>During the alpha cycle, we recommend using the nightly releases, which will continue to evolve as these APIs take their final shape.</strong></p> <p>The alpha release is part of our <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/12/12/1.0-Timeline.html">transition</a> into <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/10/30/Stability.html">stability guarantees</a>. While we're not ready to make full stability guarantees yet, this release cycle moves us much closer to that 1.0 goal. When 1.0-beta1 is released <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/12/12/1.0-Timeline.html">six weeks from now</a>, these important remaining APIs will be stable. Code that compiles on the beta release should do so with minimal changes on 1.0 final as well.</p> <h3 id="what-s-shipping-in-alpha">What's shipping in alpha?</h3> <p>Since the <a href="https://mail.mozilla.org/pipermail/rust-dev/2014-October/011267.html">previous release</a>, we've made an enormous amount of progress. We'll cover a few of the highlights here; the full details are in <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/RELEASES.md">the release notes</a>.</p> <h4 id="language-features">Language features</h4> <ul> <li> <p><strong>Dynamically-sized types (DSTs):</strong> <a href="http://smallcultfollowing.com/babysteps/blog/2014/01/05/dst-take-5/">Types whose size is only known at runtime</a> (such as array slices and trait objects) are now largely integrated into the language, including basic integration with user-defined smart pointers. <em>Implemented by Nick Cameron; rolled out by Jorge Aparicio</em>.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Multidispatch traits:</strong> Trait implementations can now be selected via <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/195">multiple types</a> (not just <code>Self</code>), which has opened the door to <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/201">many</a> <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/235">interesting</a> <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/529">APIs</a>. <em>Implemented by Niko Matsakis; rolled out by Jorge Aparicio and Aaron Turon</em>.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Associated types:</strong> Traits can now have <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/195">associated types</a>, which cuts down on verbosity with generics and aids type inference. <em>Implemented by Patrick Walton, Niko Matsakis, and Nick Cameron; rolled out by Jorge Aparicio</em>.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Where clauses:</strong> A powerful new way of specifying trait bounds, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/135">where clauses</a> have landed and enabled some <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/20398">significant</a> <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/20560">simplifications</a> in the standard library. <em>Implemented by Niko Matsakis, Patrick Walton, and Jared Roesch; rolled out by Jorge Aparicio and Aaron Turon.</em></p> </li> <li> <p><strong>&quot;Unboxed&quot; closures:</strong> Closures are now <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/114">just another way of using the trait system</a>, which required adding <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/387">higher-ranked lifetimes</a>; this allows much greater flexibility for both ownership and choosing static or dynamic dispatch. <em>Implemented by Patrick Walton, Brian Koropoff and Niko Matsakis; rolled out by Jorge Aparicio.</em></p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Macros:</strong> The <code>macro_rules</code> system has been <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/453">significantly</a> <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/550">revised</a>, cleaning up a number of rough edges and future-proofing in various ways. While macros suffer from some significant deficiencies, the macro system is a powerful and important part of Rust programming that will ship with 1.0. We plan to build a second-generation macro system after the 1.0 release. <em>Implemented by Keegan McAllister and Corey Richardson.</em></p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Integer type changes:</strong> The long-running debate about integer types was <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/544#issuecomment-68760871">recently resolved</a>: <code>int</code> and <code>uint</code> are now known as <code>isize</code> and <code>usize</code>, and no longer suggest the role of &quot;default integer&quot; in Rust. <em>Credit goes to the entire community for the vigorous debate.</em></p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Opt-in builtin traits</strong>: The marker traits that Rust uses to classify data as copyable, thread-safe, and so forth have been <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/0019-opt-in-builtin-traits.md">significantly refactored to have safer, more predicable defaults</a>. <em>Implemented by Patrick Walton and Flavio Percoco Premoli.</em></p> </li> </ul> <p>All of these language features have been rolled out throughout the standard library.</p> <h4 id="library-features">Library features</h4> <ul> <li> <p><strong>Consistent conventions:</strong> <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/199">A</a> <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/236">large</a> <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/240">number</a> <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/344">of</a> <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/430">conventions</a> <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/445">RFCs</a> have been approved, and are largely summarized <a href="http://aturon.github.io/">in the Rust Guidelines</a>; these conventions have been rolled out through all <code>#[stable]</code> parts of <code>std</code>. <em>Led by Aaron Turon</em>.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Stable core types and traits:</strong> All of the primitive types and basic building blocks (like <code>char</code>, <code>String</code>, <code>Vec</code>, <code>Box</code>, <code>Arc</code>, <code>RefCell</code> and so on) are now <code>#[stable]</code>. <em>Stabilized by Aaron Turon, Alex Crichton, Brian Anderson, Brendan Zabarauskas and Huon Wilson</em>.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Iterators and collections:</strong> A <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/216">series</a> <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/235">of</a> <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/509">RFCs</a> have been implemented to revamp and stabilize the collections APIs; iterators are also <code>#[stable]</code>. <em>RFCs by Aaron Turon and Alexis Beingessner, stabilized together with Chase Southwood, Piotr Czarnecki, Félix Raimundo, Clark Gaebel and others.</em></p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Concurrency primitives:</strong> Rust's concurrency modules have seen an overhaul, including <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/461">thread-local storage</a>, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/19274/">synchronization primitives</a>, and a new <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/20615">thread API</a> that will soon allow child threads to share data on their parent's stack. These APIs are more efficient and idiomatic than previous versions, and most are already <code>#[stable]</code>. <em>Implemented by Alex Crichton and Aaron Turon</em>.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Runtime freedom:</strong> Rust's runtime system and green-threading model has been <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/230">entirely removed</a>, which cut the static binary size of &quot;hello world&quot; in half and has <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/19169">opened the door</a> to lower-level hooks into the standard library. <em>Implemented by Aaron Turon</em>.</p> </li> </ul> <h4 id="documentation">Documentation</h4> <ul> <li> <p><strong>The Rust Programming Language:</strong> The previous split between &quot;The Guide&quot; and &quot;The guides&quot; has been rectified by combining them into <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/19897">&quot;The book&quot;</a>. <em>Led by Steve Klabnik</em>.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Rust by Example:</strong> The lovely http://rustbyexample.com/ introduction to Rust is now part of the official documentation. <em>Initiated by Jorge Aparicio</em>.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Additional API documentation:</strong> A lot of work has gone into improving API documentation, both by expanding the overview text and adding examples throughout. <em>Credit goes to the entire community, who worked tirelessly to improve these docs</em>.</p> </li> </ul> <h3 id="what-remains-to-be-done">What remains to be done?</h3> <p>A detailed list of possible breaking changes to <em>stable</em> features/APIs can be found <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/wiki/Anticipated-breaking-changes-during-1.0-alpha">here</a>. Below is a list of major areas of improvement for the alpha cycle:</p> <ul> <li> <p><strong>Improvements to <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/17307">associated types</a> and <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/18101">unboxed closures</a>:</strong> Both of these features are functional, but we plan to make significant ergonomic improvements during the beta cycle, such as <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/0231-upvar-capture-inference.md">more sophisticated capture-clause inference</a> and more <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/20300">uniform support for shorthands like <code>X::Type</code></a>.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Improvements to generics:</strong> We will explore <a href="http://smallcultfollowing.com/babysteps/blog/2014/07/06/implied-bounds/">avenues</a> to cut down on the number of redundant trait bounds that are currently required.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Path reform:</strong> The <code>path</code> module will soon be <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/474">reformed</a> to make use of DST, to give a better account of platform differences, and to more closely align with the <a href="http://article.gmane.org/gmane.comp.lib.boost.devel/256220">new C++ standard</a>. Implementation work is largely complete, and the rollout should occur soon after alpha.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>IO reform:</strong> An <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/517/">overhaul of the IO APIs</a> is being planned; please join in the conversation! These changes will be landing throughout the alpha cycle.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Sync/Send changes:</strong> We plan to tweak the definitions of the <code>Sync</code> and <code>Send</code> markers so that <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/458">threads can share stack data</a>. This may cause some minor breakage.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Integer type auditing:</strong> During the alpha cycle, we will finalize formal conventions for choosing integer types and re-audit the use of these types in <code>std</code>. This auditing may cause some breakage to <code>#[stable]</code> APIs.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Documentation for all features:</strong> Some recent feature additions, such as associated types and unboxed closures, have their RFC as the only documentation. User-facing documentation for these features will be added during the alpha cycle. The <a href="http://doc.rust-lang.org/reference.html">reference</a> will likewise be brought up to date and improved.</p> </li> <li> <p><strong>Complete API documentation:</strong> Everything marked stable will have <em>at least</em> a usage example, and hopefully complete textual explanation, before beta.</p> </li> </ul> <p>And, of course, we will continue to fix bugs and add polish throughout the alpha cycle.</p> <h3 id="contributors-to-rust-1-0-0-alpha">Contributors to Rust 1.0.0-alpha</h3> <p>This alpha release could not have happened without the help of Rust's enthusiastic community. Thanks go to:</p> <ul> <li><code>Aaron Friel</code></li> <li><code>Aaron Liblong</code></li> <li><code>Aaron Turon</code></li> <li><code>Aaron Weiss</code></li> <li><code>Adam Szkoda</code></li> <li><code>Adolfo Ochagavía</code></li> <li><code>Adrien Tétar</code></li> <li><code>Aidan Cully</code></li> <li><code>A.J.
