Kukreti</code></li> <li><code>Vadim Chugunov</code></li> <li><code>Vadim Petrochenkov</code></li> <li><code>Valerii Hiora</code></li> <li><code>Victor Berger</code></li> <li><code>Victor van den Elzen</code></li> <li><code>Viktor Dahl</code></li> <li><code>ville-h</code></li> <li><code>Vitali Haravy</code></li> <li><code>Vladimir Matveev</code></li> <li><code>Vladimir Smola</code></li> <li><code>we</code></li> <li><code>whataloadofwhat</code></li> <li><code>YawarRaza7349</code></li> <li><code>York Xiang</code></li> <li><code>Zbigniew Siciarz</code></li> <li><code>Ziad Hatahet</code></li> </ul> Rust 1.0: Scheduling the trains Fri, 12 Dec 2014 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/1-0-timeline/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/1-0-timeline/ <p>As 2014 is drawing to a close, it's time to begin the Rust 1.0 release cycle!</p> <p><strong>TL;DR: we will transition to a six week release cycle on Jan 9, 2015, and produce Rust 1.0.0 final at least two cycles afterwards</strong>:</p> <ul> <li>Rust 1.0.0-alpha -- Friday, Jan 9, 2015</li> <li>Rust 1.0.0-beta1 -- Week of Feb 16, 2015</li> <li>Rust 1.0.0 -- One or more six-week cycles later</li> </ul> <p>We talked before about <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/09/15/Rust-1.0.html">why Rust is reaching 1.0</a>, and also about the <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/10/30/Stability.html">6-week train model</a> (with Nightly, Beta, and Stable channels) that will enable us to deliver stability without stagnation. This post finishes the story by laying out the transition to this new release model and the stability guarantees it provides.</p> <h3 id="the-alpha-release">The alpha release</h3> <p>Reaching alpha means three things:</p> <ul> <li> <p>The language is feature-complete. All gates are removed from features we expect to ship with 1.0.</p> </li> <li> <p>The standard library is nearly feature-complete. The majority of APIs that will ship in 1.0 stable will already be marked as <code>#[stable]</code>.</p> </li> <li> <p><em>Warnings</em> for <code>#[unstable]</code> features are turned on by default. (Note that the <code>#[experimental]</code> stability level is <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/507">going away</a>.)</p> </li> </ul> <p>In other words, 1.0.0-alpha gives a pretty accurate picture of what 1.0 will look like, but doesn't yet institute release channels. By turning on warnings for unstable APIs but not excluding them altogether, we can get community feedback about which important APIs still need to be stabilized without those APIs simply disappearing over night.</p> <p>While we expect the pace of breakage to slow dramatically when we reach feature-complete status, <strong>1.0.0-alpha is still a <a href="http://semver.org/">pre-release</a></strong>:</p> <pre style="background-color:#ffffff;"> A pre-release version indicates that the version is unstable and might not satisfy the intended compatibility requirements as denoted by its associated normal version. </pre> <p>That is, we will reserve the right to make minor breaking changes to both the language and libraries -- including <code>#[stable]</code> APIs -- throughout the duration of the alpha cycle. But we expect any such changes to be relatively minor tweaks, and changes to <code>#[stable]</code> APIs to be very rare.</p> <h3 id="the-beta-release-s">The beta release(s)</h3> <p>Six weeks later, we will begin the beta period:</p> <ul> <li> <p>Both the language and libraries are feature-complete. All APIs shipping for Rust 1.0 are marked <code>#[stable]</code>.</p> </li> <li> <p>Release channels take effect: feature gates and <code>#[unstable]</code> APIs are available on nightly builds, but not on the beta. This change is part of <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/10/30/Stability.html">our commitment to stability</a>.</p> </li> </ul> <p>Unlike the alpha cycle, where we still expect some minor breakage, the beta cycle should <em>not</em> involve breakage unless a very significant problem is found. Ideally, <strong>the beta cycle will be focused on testing, bugfixing, and polish</strong>.</p> <p>We plan to run at least one beta cycle before the final release.</p> <h3 id="the-final-release">The final release</h3> <p>Finally, after one or more beta cycles, we will have produced a release candidate that is <strong>ready for the world</strong>:</p> <ul> <li> <p>We are ready to promise stability -- <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/10/30/Stability.html">hassle-free upgrades</a> -- for the duration of the 1.X series.</p> </li> <li> <p>The core documentation (The Guide/Guides) is fully in sync with the language and libraries.</p> </li> </ul> <p>We are incredibly excited for Rust to reach this point.</p> <h3 id="what-this-means-for-the-ecosystem">What this means for the ecosystem</h3> <p>With the <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/11/20/Cargo.html">launch</a> of Cargo and <a href="https://crates.io/">crates.io</a>, Rust's ecosystem has already seen significant expansion, but it still takes a lot of work to track Rust's nightly releases. Beginning with the alpha release, and especially approaching beta1, this will change dramatically; <strong>code that works with beta1 should work with 1.0 final without any changes whatsoever</strong>.</p> <p>This migration into stability should be a boon for library writers, and we hope that by 1.0 final there will be a massive collection of crates ready for use on the stable channel -- and ready for the droves of people trying out Rust for the first time.</p> <p>Let's do this!</p> Yehuda Katz and Steve Klabnik are joining the Rust Core Team Fri, 12 Dec 2014 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/core-team/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/core-team/ <p>I'm pleased to announce that Yehuda Katz and Steve Klabnik are joining the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/wiki/Note-core-team">Rust core team</a>. Both of them are not only active and engaged members of the Rust community, but they also bring a variety of skills and experience with them.</p> <p>Yehuda Katz will be known to many in the Rust community for his work on the initial design and implementation of the Cargo project. He is also a co-founder of <a href="http://www.tilde.io/">Tilde</a>, which has been using Rust commercially in their <a href="https://www.skylight.io/">Skylight</a> product for quite some time. Finally, he has been heavily involved with the Ruby ecosystem (through such projects as <a href="http://rubyonrails.org/">Ruby on Rails</a> and <a href="http://bundler.io/">Bundler</a>) and with JavaScript as well (through the <a href="http://emberjs.com/team/">Ember.js</a> and <a href="http://jquery.com/">jQuery</a> frameworks and the <a href="http://www.ecma-international.org/memento/TC39.htm">TC39 language committee</a>).</p> <p>Steve Klabnik is of course the primary author of the <a href="http://doc.rust-lang.org/guide.html">Rust guide</a> as well as much of Rust's documentation (not to mention independent works like <a href="http://www.rustforrubyists.com/">Rust for Rubyists</a>). He is passionate about improving the learnability of Rust and ensuring that the onboarding experience is smooth. Finally, Steve is an enthusiastic and tireless communicator. Wherever there is discussion about Rust to be found, be it IRC, the <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/">RFCs repo</a>, or <a href="http://www.reddit.com/r/rust">Reddit</a>/<a href="https://news.ycombinator.com/">HackerNews</a>, you can be sure to find a comment or two from Steve there, explaining and clarifying the situation.</p> <p>Thanks Yehuda and Steve for all your hard work, and welcome to the core team!</p> Cargo: Rust's community crate host Thu, 20 Nov 2014 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/cargo/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/cargo/ <p>Today it is my pleasure to announce that <a href="https://crates.io/">crates.io</a> is online and ready for action. The site is a central location to discover/download Rust crates, and Cargo is ready to start publishing to it today. For the next few months, we are asking that intrepid early adopters <a href="http://doc.crates.io/crates-io.html">help us</a> get the registry battle-tested.</p> <p>Until Rust itself is stable early next year, registry dependencies will need to be updated often. Production users may want to continue using git dependencies until then.</p> <h2 id="what-is-cargo">What is Cargo?</h2> <p>Cargo is a package manager <a href="http://www.rust-lang.org/">for Rust</a>, <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo">in Rust</a>. Managing dependencies is a fundamentally difficult problem, but fortunately over the last decade there's been a lot of progress in the design of package managers. Designed by Carl Lerche and Yehuda Katz, Cargo follows the tradition of successes like <a href="http://bundler.io/">Bundler</a> and <a href="https://www.npmjs.org/">NPM</a>:</p> <ol> <li> <p>Cargo leverages crates.io to foster a thriving community of crates that can easily interoperate with one another and last for years to come.</p> </li> <li> <p>Cargo releases developers from the worry of managing dependencies and ensures that all collaborators are building the same code.</p> </li> <li> <p>Cargo lets your dependencies say how they should be built, and manages the entire build process for you.</p> </li> </ol> <h2 id="a-community-on-cargo">A Community on Cargo</h2> <p>To get a feel for how Cargo achieves its goals, let's take a look at some of its core mechanics.</p> <h3 id="declaring-dependencies">Declaring Dependencies</h3> <p>Cargo makes depending on third-party code as easy as depending on the standard library. When using Cargo, each crate will have an associated <a href="http://doc.crates.io/manifest.html">manifest</a> to describe itself and its dependencies. Adding a new dependency is now as simple as adding one line to the manifest, and this ease has allowed Cargo in just a few short months to enable a large and growing network of Rust projects and libraries which were simply infeasible before.</p> <p>Cargo alone, however, is not quite the entire solution. Discovering dependencies is still difficult, and ensuring that these dependencies are available for years to come is also not guaranteed.</p> <h3 id="crates-io">crates.io</h3> <p>To pair with Cargo, the central crates.io site serves as a single location for publishing and discovering libraries. This repository serves as permanent storage for releases of crates over time to ensure that projects can always build with the exact same versions years later. Up until now, users of Cargo have largely just downloaded dependencies directly from the source GitHub repository, but the primary source will now be shifting to crates.io.</p> <p>Other programming language communities have been quite successful with this form of central repository. For example <a href="http://rubygems.org/">rubygems.org</a> is your one-stop-shop for <a href="http://bundler.io/">Bundler</a> dependencies and <a href="https://www.npmjs.org/">npmjs.org</a> has had over 600 million downloads in just this month alone! We intend for crates.io to serve a similar role for Rust as a critical piece of infrastructure for <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/10/30/Stability.html">Rust's long-term stability story at 1.0</a>.</p> <h2 id="versioning-and-reproducible-builds">Versioning and Reproducible Builds</h2> <p>Over the past few years, the concept of <a href="http://semver.org/">Semantic Versioning</a> has gained traction as a way for library developers to easily and clearly communicate with users when they make breaking changes. The core idea of semantic versioning is simple: each new release is categorized as a minor or major release, and only major releases can introduce breakage. Cargo allows you to specify version ranges for your dependencies, with the default meaning of &quot;compatible with&quot;.</p> <p>When specifying a version range, applications often end up requesting multiple versions of a single crate, and Cargo solves this by selecting the highest version of each major version (&quot;stable code&quot;) requested. This highly encourages using stable distributions while still allowing duplicates of unstable code (pre-1.0 and git for example).</p> <p>Once the set of dependencies and their versions have been calculated, Cargo generates a <a href="http://doc.crates.io/guide.html#cargo.toml-vs-cargo.lock"><code>Cargo.lock</code></a> to encode this information. This &quot;lock file&quot; is then distributed to collaborators of applications to ensure that the crates being built remain the same from one build to the next, across times, machines, and environments.</p> <h2 id="building-code">Building Code</h2> <p>Up to this point we've seen how Cargo facilitates discovery and reuse of community projects while managing what versions to use. Now Cargo just has to deal with the problem of actually compiling all this code!</p> <p>With a deep understanding of the Rust code that it is building, Cargo is able to provide some nice standard features as well as some Rust-specific features:</p> <ul> <li> <p>By default, Cargo builds as many crates in parallel as possible. This not only applies to upstream dependencies being built in parallel, but also items for the local crate such as test suites, binaries, and unit tests.</p> </li> <li> <p>Cargo supports unit testing out of the box both for crates themselves and in the form of integration tests. This even includes example programs to ensure they don't bitrot.</p> </li> <li> <p>Cargo generates documentation for all crates in a dependency graph, and it can even run <a href="http://doc.rust-lang.org/rustdoc.html#testing-the-documentation">Rust's documentation tests</a> to ensure examples in documentation stay up to date.</p> </li> <li> <p>Cargo can run a <a href="http://doc.crates.io/build-script.html">build script</a> before any crate is compiled to perform tasks such as code generation, compiling native dependencies, or detecting native dependencies on the local system.</p> </li> <li> <p>Cargo supports cross compilation out of the box. Cross compiling is done by simply specifying a <code>--target</code> options and Cargo will manage tasks such as compiling plugins and other build dependencies for the right platform.</p> </li> </ul> <h2 id="what-else-is-in-store">What else is in store?</h2> <p>The launch of crates.io is a key step in moving the Cargo ecosystem forward, but the story does not end here. Usage of crates.io is architected assuming a stable compiler, which should be <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/09/15/Rust-1.0.html">coming soon</a>! There are also a number of extensions to crates.io such as a hosted documentation service or a CI build infrastructure hook which could be built out using the crates.io APIs.</p> <p>This is just the beginning for crates.io, and I'm excited to start finding all Rust crates from one location. I can't wait to see what the registry looks like at 1.0, and I can only fathom what it will look like after 1.0!</p> Stability as a Deliverable Thu, 30 Oct 2014 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/stability/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/stability/ <p>The upcoming Rust 1.0 release means <a href="http://blog.rust-lang.org/2014/09/15/Rust-1.0.html">a lot</a>, but most fundamentally it is a commitment to stability, alongside our long-running commitment to safety.</p> <p>Starting with 1.0, we will move to a 6-week release cycle and a menu of release &quot;channels&quot;. The stable release channel will provide pain-free upgrades, and the nightly channel will give early adopters access to unfinished features as we work on them.</p> <h3 id="committing-to-stability">Committing to stability</h3> <p>Since the early days of Rust, there have only been two things you could count on: safety, and change. And sometimes not the first one. In the process of developing Rust, we've encountered a lot of dead ends, and so it's been essential to have the freedom to change the language as needed.</p> <p>But Rust has matured, and core aspects of the language have been steady for a long time. The design feels right. And there is a huge amount of pent up interest in Rust, waiting for 1.0 to ship so that there is a stable foundation to build on.</p> <p>It's important to be clear about what we mean by stable. We don't mean that Rust will stop evolving. We will release new versions of Rust on a regular, frequent basis, and we hope that people will upgrade just as regularly. But for that to happen, those upgrades need to be painless.</p> <p>To put it simply, our responsibility is to ensure that you never dread upgrading Rust. If your code compiles on Rust stable 1.0, it should compile with Rust stable 1.x with a minimum of hassle.</p> <h3 id="the-plan">The plan</h3> <p>We will use a variation of the train model, first introduced in web browsers and now widely used to provide stability without stagnation:</p> <ul> <li> <p>New work lands directly in the master branch.</p> </li> <li> <p>Each day, the last successful build from master becomes the new nightly release.</p> </li> <li> <p>Every six weeks, a beta branch is created from the current state of master, and the previous beta is promoted to be the new stable release.</p> </li> </ul> <p>In short, there are three release channels -- nightly, beta, and stable -- with regular, frequent promotions from one channel to the next.</p> <p>New features and new APIs will be flagged as unstable via feature gates and stability attributes respectively. Unstable features and standard library APIs will only be available on the nightly branch, and only if you explicitly &quot;opt in&quot; to the instability.</p> <p>The beta and stable releases, on the other hand, will only include features and APIs deemed <em>stable</em>, which represents a commitment to avoid breaking code that uses those features or APIs.</p> <h3 id="the-faq">The FAQ</h3> <p>There are a lot of details involved in the above process, and we plan to publish RFCs laying out the fine points. The rest of this post will cover some of the most important details and potential worries about this plan.</p> <h3 id="what-features-will-be-stable-for-1-0">What features will be stable for 1.0?</h3> <p>We've done an analysis of the current Rust ecosystem to determine the most used crates and the feature gates they depend on, and used this data to guide our stabilization plan. The good news is that the vast majority of what's currently being used will be stable by 1.0:</p> <ul> <li> <p>There are several features that are nearly finished already: struct variants, default type parameters, tuple indexing, and slicing syntax.</p> </li> <li> <p>There are two key features that need significant more work, but are crucial for 1.0: unboxed closures and associated types.</p> </li> <li> <p>Finally, there are some widely-used features with flaws that cannot be addressed in the 1.0 timeframe: glob imports, macros, and syntax extensions. This is where we have to make some tough decisions.</p> </li> </ul> <p>After extensive discussion, we plan to release globs and macros as stable at 1.0. For globs, we believe we can address problems in a backwards-compatible way. For macros, we will likely provide an alternative way to define macros (with better <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hygienic_macro">hygiene</a>) at some later date, and will incrementally improve the &quot;macro rules&quot; feature until then. The 1.0 release will stabilize all current macro support, including import/export.</p> <p>On the other hand, we <em>cannot</em> stabilize syntax extensions, which are plugins with complete access to compiler internals. Stabilizing it would effectively forever freeze the internals of the compiler; we need to design a more deliberate interface between extensions and the compiler. So syntax extensions will remain behind a feature gate for 1.0.</p> <p>Many major uses of syntax extensions could be replaced with traditional code generation, and the Cargo tool will soon be growing specific support for this use case. We plan to work with library authors to help them migrate away from syntax extensions prior to 1.0. Because many syntax extensions don't fit this model, we also see stabilizing syntax extensions as an immediate priority after the 1.0 release.</p> <h3 id="what-parts-of-the-standard-library-will-be-stable-for-1-0">What parts of the standard library will be stable for 1.0?</h3> <p>We have been steadily stabilizing the standard library, and have a plan for nearly <em>all</em> of the modules it provides. The expectation is that the vast majority of functionality in the standard library will be stable for 1.0. We have also been migrating more experimental APIs out of the standard library and into their own crates.</p> <h3 id="what-about-stability-attributes-outside-of-the-standard-library">What about stability attributes outside of the standard library?</h3> <p>Library authors can continue to use stability attributes as they do today to mark their own stability promises. These attributes are not tied into the Rust release channels by default. That is, when you're compiling on Rust stable, you can only use stable APIs from the standard library, but you can opt into experimental APIs from other libraries. The Rust release channels are about making upgrading <em>Rust itself</em> (the compiler and standard library) painless.</p> <p>Library authors should follow <a href="http://semver.org/">semver</a>; we will soon publish an RFC defining how library stability attributes and semver interact.</p> <h3 id="why-not-allow-opting-in-to-instability-in-the-stable-release">Why not allow opting in to instability in the stable release?</h3> <p>There are three problems with allowing unstable features on the stable release.</p> <p>First, as the web has shown numerous times, merely <em>advertising</em> instability doesn't work. Once features are in wide use it is very hard to change them -- and once features are available at all, it is very hard to prevent them from being used. Mechanisms like &quot;vendor prefixes&quot; on the web that were meant to support experimentation instead led to de facto standardization.</p> <p>Second, unstable features are by definition work in progress. But the beta/stable snapshots freeze the feature at scheduled points in time, while library authors will want to work with the latest version of the feature.</p> <p>Finally, we simply <em>cannot</em> deliver stability for Rust unless we enforce it. Our promise is that, if you are using the stable release of Rust, you will never dread upgrading to the next release. If libraries could opt in to instability, then we could only keep this promise if all library authors guaranteed the same thing by supporting all three release channels simultaneously.</p> <p>It's not realistic or necessary for the entire ecosystem to flawlessly deal with these problems. Instead, we will enforce that stable means stable: the stable channel provides only stable features.</p> <h3 id="won-t-this-split-the-ecosystem-will-everyone-use-nightly-at-1-0">Won't this split the ecosystem? Will everyone use nightly at 1.0?</h3> <p>It doesn't split the ecosystem: it creates a subset. Programmers working with the nightly release channel can freely use libraries that are designed for the stable channel. There will be pressure to stabilize important features and APIs, and so the incentives to stay in the unstable world will shrink over time.</p> <p>We have carefully planned the 1.0 release so that the bulk of the existing ecosystem will fit into the &quot;stable&quot; category, and thus newcomers to Rust will immediately be able to use most libraries on the stable 1.0 release.</p> <h3 id="what-are-the-stability-caveats">What are the stability caveats?</h3> <p>We reserve the right to fix compiler bugs, patch safety holes, and change type inference in ways that may occasionally require new type annotations. We do not expect any of these changes to cause headaches when upgrading Rust.</p> <p>The library API caveats will be laid out in a forthcoming RFC, but are similarly designed to minimize upgrade pain in practice.</p> <h3 id="will-rust-and-its-ecosystem-continue-their-rapid-development">Will Rust and its ecosystem continue their rapid development?</h3> <p>Yes! Because new work can land on master at any time, the train model doesn't slow down the pace of development or introduce artificial delays. Rust has always evolved at a rapid pace, with lots of help from amazing community members, and we expect this will only accelerate.</p> Road to Rust 1.0 Mon, 15 Sep 2014 00:00:00 +0000 https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/road-to-rust-1-0/ https://xampprocky.github.io/blog.rust-lang.org/road-to-rust-1-0/ <p>Rust 1.0 is on its way! We have nailed down a concrete list of features and are hard at work on implementing them. We plan to ship the 1.0 beta around the end of the year. If all goes well, this will go on to become the 1.0 release after the beta period. After 1.0 is released, future 1.x releases will be backwards compatible, meaning that existing code will continue to compile unmodified (modulo compiler bugs, of course).</p> <p>Of course, a Rust 1.0 release means something more than &quot;your code will continue to compile&quot;. Basically, it means that we think the design of Rust finally feels right. More specifically, it feels <em>minimal</em>. The language itself is now focused on a simple core concept, which we call ownership and borrowing (more on this later). Leveraging ownership and borrowing, we have been able to build up everything else that we have needed in libraries. This is very exciting, because any library we can write, you can write too. This really gives us confidence that Rust will not only achieve its original goals but also go beyond and be used for all kinds of things that we haven't even envisioned.</p> <h3 id="the-road-to-rust-1-0">The road to Rust 1.0</h3> <p>Rust has gone through a long evolution. If you haven't looked at Rust in a while, you may be surprised at what you see: over the last year, we've been radically simplifying the design. As a prominent example, Rust once featured several pointer types, indicated by various sigils: these are gone, and only the reference types (<code>&amp;T</code>, <code>&amp;mut T</code>) remain. We have also been able to consolidate and simplify a number of other language features, such as closures, that once sported a wide variety of options. (Some of these changes are still in progress.)</p> <p>The key to all these changes has been a focus on the core concepts of <em>ownership and borrowing</em>. Initially, we introduced ownership as a means of transferring data safely and efficiently between tasks, but over time we have realized that the same mechanism allows us to move all sorts of things out of the language and into libraries. The resulting design is not only simpler to learn, but it is also much &quot;closer to the metal&quot; than we ever thought possible before. All Rust language constructs have a very direct mapping to machine operations, and Rust has no required runtime or external dependencies. When used in its own most minimal configuration, it is even possible to write an <a href="https://github.com/charliesome/rustboot">operating</a> <a href="https://github.com/ryanra/RustOS">systems</a> <a href="https://github.com/jvns/puddle">kernel</a> in Rust.</p> <p>Throughout these changes, though, Rust has remained true to its goal of providing the <strong>safety</strong> and <strong>convenience</strong> of modern programming languages, while still offering the <strong>efficiency</strong> and <strong>low-level control</strong> that C and C++ offer. Basically, if you want to get your hands dirty with the bare metal machine, but you don't want to spend hours tracking down segfaults and data races, Rust is the language for you.</p> <p>If you're not already familiar with Rust, don't worry. Over the next few months, we plan on issuing a regular series of blog posts exploring the language. The first few will focus on different aspects of ownership and how it can be used to achieve safe manual memory management, concurrency, and more. After that, we'll turn to other aspects of the Rust language and ecosystem.</p> <h3 id="what-is-left-to-do">What is left to do</h3> <p>We've made great progress, but there is still a lot to do before the release. Here is a list of the big-ticket changes we are currently working on:</p> <ul> <li><em>Dynamically sized types:</em> This extension to the type system allows us to uniformly handle types where the size is not known at compile time, such as an array type. This enables us to support user-designed smart pointers that contain arrays or objects. Nicholas Cameron <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/commit/7932b719ec2b65acfa8c3e74aad29346d47ee992">recently landed</a> a heroic commit implementing the bulk of the work.</li> <li><em>Unboxed closures:</em> Our new <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/text/0114-closures.md">closure design</a> unifies closures and object types. Much of the spec has been implemented.</li> <li><em>Associated types:</em> We are moving our trait system to use <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/195">associated types</a>, which really help to cut down on the level of generic annotations required to write advanced generic libraries. Patrick Walton has done an initial implementation.</li> <li><em>Where clauses:</em> We are adding a flexible new form of constraints called <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/135">where clauses</a>. Patrick Walton already landed support for the basic syntax, and I have implemented the remaining functionality on a branch that should be landing soon.</li> <li><em>Multidispatch traits:</em> We are extending traits so that they can <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/195">match on more than one type at a time</a>, which opens up a lot of new opportunities for more ergonomic APIs. I have prototyped this work on a branch.</li> <li><em>Destructors:</em> We are improving our destructor semantics to not require zeroing of memory, which should improve compilation and execution times. Felix Klock has implemented the requisite analysis and is in the process of landing it.</li> <li><em>Green threading:</em> We are removing support for green threading from the standard library and moving it out into an external package. This allows for a closer match between the Rust model and the underlying operating system, which makes for more efficient programs. Aaron Turon has <a href="https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/230">written the RFC</a> and is getting started on that work now.</li> </ul> <p>At the library level, we are currently engaged in a sweep over libstd to decide what portions are stable and which are not. You can <a href="http://doc.rust-lang.org/std/stability.html">monitor the progress</a> here. (Note though that many of the 'unstable' items are simply things whose name will be changed slightly to conform to conventions or other minor tweaks.)</p> <h3 id="cargo-and-the-library-ecosystem">Cargo and the library ecosystem</h3> <p>Earlier I wrote that Rust 1.0 is not so much an endpoint as it is a starting point. This is very true. The goal for Rust 1.0 is to be an flexible substrate for building efficient libraries -- but libraries aren't any good if nobody can find them or they are difficult to install.</p> <p>Enter <a href="http://crates.io">Cargo, the Rust package manager</a>. Cargo has been undergoing rapid development lately and is already quite functional. By the time 1.0 is released, we plan to also have a central repository up and running, meaning that it will be simple to create and distribute Rust libraries (which we call &quot;crates&quot;). Oh, and of course Cargo and its associated server are both written in Rust.</p> <h3 id="release-process">Release process</h3> <p>Rust releases have been following a train schedule for a long time and we don't plan on changing that. Once we start having stable releases, however, we'll also build up a bit more infrastructure. Our plan is to adopt the &quot;channel&quot; system used by many other projects such as <a href="https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/channel/">Firefox</a>, <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved/dev-channel">Chrome</a>, and <a href="http://emberjs.com/builds/">Ember.js</a>.</p> <p>The idea is that there are three channels: Nightly, Beta, and Stable. The Nightly channel is what you use if you want the latest and greatest: it includes unstable features and libraries that may still change in backwards incompatible ways. Every six weeks, we cut a new branch and call it Beta. This branch excludes all the unstable bits, so you know that if you are using Beta or Stable, your code will continue to compile. At the same time, the existing Beta branch is promoted to the Stable release. We expect that production users will prefer to test on the Beta branch and ship with the Stable branch. Testing on Beta ensures that we get some advanced notice if we accidentally break anything you are relying on.</p> <p>With regard to the 1.0 release specifically, the plan is to release the 1.0 beta and then follow this same process to transition to the official 1.0 release. However, if we find a serious flaw in the 1.0 beta, we may defer and run an additional beta period or two. After all, it's better to wait a bit longer than wind up committed to something broken.</p> <h3 id="looking-forward">Looking forward</h3> <p>In many ways, Rust 1.0 is not so much an endpoint as it is a starting point. Naturally, we plan on continuing to develop Rust: we have a lot of features we want to add, many of which are already in the pipeline. But the work that's most exciting to me is not the work that will be done by the Rust team. Rather, I expect that having a stable base will allow the Rust community and ecosystem to grow much more rapidly than it already has. I can't wait to see what comes out of it.</p>
